text: A nice concept for the office or other area without a stove or microwave to heat up the water, the Bodum Electric Coffee and Tea maker is adequate only.The Positives.  THis is a relatively compact appliance that works without fail (but within some frustrating limits--see below), and that includes both a press for coffee and a filter for tea. In the Amazon.com picture, the tank on the right is filled with water, and one adds either coffee or tea (inside a filter) to the container on the right. When the two (washable) plastic containers are in place, the machine will turn on--heating the water which transfer over to the container with the coffee or tea.  Tea is brewed and coffee is pressed down with the familiar French press mechanism so that the water is infused with coffee and the finished product has no grounds.After brewing tea or coffee, one fits a safety lid (liquid won't pour without depressing a lever), and then pours the beverage into cup or mug. The heat turns off as soon as either container is removed.  To keep any remaining coffee/tea warm, one must remove the safety lid, put on the other (flat) lid, place it back on the Bodum, and then turn it back on.  These safety features are welcome, but also *too* cautious (as described later).  One other thoughtful feature, the tea/coffee container's hot bottom (from restng on the heating element) is somewhat protected by a lip that extends beyond it, thus minimizing contact with the surface upin which you place it.Coffee and tea taste fresh (after all, you just made it!), is hot (initially), takes a little over 7 minutes to empty a 4-5 cup (full) carafe ONCE it is heated (more on that, too) and brewing is safe. That said.....Negatives.  Yes, this will sound all "Grinchy,"  but, taken togther, I found myself disappointed, feeling it's not worth the money even at a 30% discount over list price. Many of these negatives stem from what I see (others may disagree) with a over-concern for safety.  I'd feel differently if this were a device that children will use, but I doubt they will be the primary users.Temperature.  While the initial gulps will be enjoyably hot, replacing the container on the hot plate does not keep it close to this temperature: It loses its heat in a very short period. IT's not lukewarm or tepid, but it's just not hot.Tempermental.  It appears that if the two containers are not set in the machine "just so," the Bodum will not begin heating (either that or it takes an inordinate amount of time--well over ten minutes) for a full water carafe to start transferring hot water to the other container. It appears to work best when the handle on the receiving carafe and the numbers indicating cups on the hot water carafe are facing outward--but that may just be coincidence. Basically, I have to fool around with these containers to feel confident it will begin heating.Extension Cord.  In a wonderfully paternalistic nod, Bodum informs us that--for safety reasons--they include a short ekectric cord, and that we may need to buy an extention cord (they assume that's safer, I suppose). Safety or less expense for Bodum, I wonder...Taste. Tea is not a problem, but French Press coffee should have a richer, somewhat oily (from the coffee beans) taste and texture. I think that the size of the receiving carafe mitigates against this. The carafe bottom is so wide that the coffee just settles at the bottom--there's little mixing of water and coffee as you press down (with little or no resistance) with the "plunger."  Although this may work better with smaller quantities of water, and even more coffee, the coffee is strong and fresh, but it does not taste very much like French Press coffee.Bottom line.  I can't really recommend this because of the price/value, temperature, and operating deficits noted above.  However, if you absolutely need your coffee/tea fix, have no easy access to a microwave or other heat source, and you're not too fussy about recreating conventionally made French Press coffee (and if you do use this to make tea, not just coffee), you may feel it's a worthwhile purchase.  While concern with safety is laudable, one wonders if designers could have made an equally safe product that produced a more satisfying taste at a more consistent temperature.

In the time-honored tradition of "more is more," Remington Azor 5 has five (5!)blades to hone your face to it's stubble-free, baby-bottom potential. We all know from ads that each blade not only has its own cutting action, but "lifts" your skin and whisker for an even closer cut by the next blade. The physics of this argument may be debatable, so let's stay with performance. First, though, a word about features:Appearance.  Surprisingly good. The look and almost the heft of metal in a $6-$11 product, with a grippy white inset on top (and the entire bottom) and sleek blue sides!  While no one will mistake this for real metal, it's a much more grown-up look than the supersized multi-blades and the cheapie orange plastic ones, if that matters to you.Feel in the hand. Very well-designed, with ergonomic contours for the hand-- especially the thumb--against which the razor rests. The white-colored material has a slightly sticky texture which helps hold it in your hand.Price. Good to great, depending on whether the Azor is on sale.  The blades are (really) cheaper than competitors for a similar product, and this will save you substantial money over time.General Functionality.  While there was a learning curve, you *can* attach the blade cartridge directly from its container to the razor; however, it's simpler (after some study of what fits where) to just press the blade on.  The pivoting blades move smoothly from its slight upward tilt(or--if holding the razor upside-down for a "go against the grain" upward tilt)to a 135 degree angle. In my test (see below), I had no cuts or razor burn, and the blade rinses well.Performance. The Ockham's razor of any evaluation. (Yes, I'm using that phrase incorrectly, as this has nothing to do with parsimony in one's assumptions, but somehow it just seems to fit).  Here's my experimental set-up: I used a blade on about its fifth shave (to test durability), and the skin-Azor interface was hot water with regular soap.  I used both downward and upward strokes for the closest shave obtainable.Results.  A very close, smooth shave--not perfect--but the best I've had from a razor with more than one blade. The bumper (a thin white strip that precedes the blades on an upward stroke) becomes slippery when wet and helpsthose FIVE blades glide over your face. I needed both upward and downward strokes for the closest shave, and a few horizontal strokes beneath the jaw where the contour is curviest.  Sometimes the pivot moved too much, but I discovered that I could position my thumb directly behind the blade to restrict its movement--thus almost replicating the simple but effective short power stroke of a single-bladed razor.  With just a little practice, you can master this easy technique and obtain a much closer shave.  Just as the pivot has its (resolvable) downside, so do the five blades: They quickly collect those shorn whispers, and without rinsing during your shave, you'll reduce the cutting efficacy.Bottom line. As shown in my mini-experiment, there is no single perfect razor (both electric and single-blade have their advantages), but, on balance, this is the best shave for the money out there.  With the adjustments I've suggested (or some of your own), you'll discover how to get the most out of this relatively attractive, inexpensive, and quite effective razor. Now we just wait for the launch of the 15-bladed razor.

Menthol, Menthol, Menthol.That's the first screen for anyone interested in trying this product. If you don't like the scent of menthol (with slight undertones of eucalyptus), you will like not the KING of SHAVES ALPHAGEL (what a name!) Sensitive Shave Gel, no matter how well it works for you.But let's say you can't get enough menthol!  (I'm in between--it doesn't bother me particularly, but I found the scent strong enough that, if I used Alphagel, I wouldn't want to attend a meeting without washing my face several times afterwards and letting some time go by).  The clear lotion has a nice feeling to it and applies easily to one's face. True to its description, it doesn't foam (think 1920's slapstick), nor does it even work up a lather comparable to plain soap). Bascially, you have a slightly viscous mostly-clear (some of it will turn a little white) gel on your face, like aloe vera gel only much lighter.My experience with the gel leads to this conclusion: Alphagel does much more to protect your skin than to enhance your shave.  It did not seem to appreciably soften my 2-day old stubble or give me a closer or faster shave.  In fact, the decreased friction seemed to make the razor work less well (although I used a multiple blade non-electric razor; a single blade may work better). I'd say it reduces the pain of blade on skin without lubrication, but soap and water (or water alone) would probably do as well or better.The biggest advantage is that the many natural and chemlab produced ingredients in Alphagel D) make your face feel much smoother after shaving than soap and water.  Very, very smooth, in fact.One other note--the ingredients. This may look clear and natural, but take a look at he ingredient list (from the Remington web site):Aqua (Water), Aloe Barbadensis (Aloe vera) leaf juice, Sodium laureth sulfate, Glycerin, Acrylates/C10-30 alkyl acrylate crosspolymer, Vitis Vinifera (Grape) seed oil, Melaleuca Alternifolia (Tea tree) leaf oil, Eucalyptus Globulus leaf oil, Mentha Viridis (Spearmint) leaf oil, Tocopheryl acetate, Camphor, Agar, Benzophenone-4, Mica, Cocamidopropyl betaine, Polyquaternium-11, Polyacrylamide, Limonene, Propylene glycol, Sodium chloride, Citric acid, Triethanolamine, Magnesium nitrate, Magnesium chloride, Benzyl alcohol, Potassium sorbate, Sodium benzoate, Methylchloroisothiazolinone, Methylisothiazolinone, CI 77891 (Titanium dioxide), CI 60730 (Ext Violet 2), CI 42090 (Blue 1).Bottom line: I wouldn't recommend this unless 1) you like a MENTHOL/Eucalyptus/camphor scent, and 2) you have experiece with other non-foaming gels and they woork well with your razor, and 3) you don't mind  Methylchloroisothiazolinone, Methylisothiazolinone, Polyquaternium-11, Polyacrylamide and many other substances mingling with the more familiar and natural ingredients like tea tree, spearmint, and grape seed oils, and aloe vera.Happy shaving!

Oh, the times that I or my friends have downloaded a free anti-virus program, only to have it conflict with whatever anti-virus program came with the computer. The results may be that one of the other (or both) won't work; worse, the computer may crash or work more slowly.I haven't had that problem with Trend Micro Titanium. Yes, I did remove the downloaded freeware I had been using to enhance the computer's bundled virus protection, but once I did that, there have been no problems (and I've been using this for several months now).It installs very easily, and operates smoothly and quickly. As other reviewers have noted, there's not a whole lot of user control. This is an anti-virus program that works quietly behind the scenes, occasionally popping up to ask whether you really want to go that site or add that software.  However, the unobtrusive nature of Titanium is somewhat of a drawback as well:  It's difficult to determine how well it's working, what it has removed or prevented. Go ahead, brag a little, Trend Micro!  That will give me more guidance about whether I want to purchase this again. If next year is anything like this year, the price is heavily discounted mid-year (perhaps earlier), but it's not worth it if yo uhave no other virus protection.Bottom Line: A satisfactory product that does not interfere with my computer, and that seems to work well. I can say I've had fewer problems with this software than many others. There are probably more powerful (and expensive) anti-virus tools out there, but in mnay respects this seems superior to some of the freebies available for download.

I'm going to assume that you're not pinching pennies, or that you order supplies for a company that isn't. That's because, at the current Amazon.com price (at a nice discount as of this date), you'll be paying a little over a dollar per hanging file folder; certainly, you can get a different type for cheaper.However, I'm not sure you'll find something as nice in this price range.  The first thing you may notice (other than the nicely selected pastel colors of light blue, green, and the more somber beige/brown) is the stronly reinforced tabs that cover almost all of the bar at the top of the folder. This is usually the most vulnerable point for ri[s and tears, as you remove and replace the folders from and to your desk drawer's hanging folder structure. The metal bar is very solid and won't bend unless you're doing strength contests at the office. (And, really, should you really be doing such shenanigans on company time...)  Moreover, the exposed part of the metal bar is coated; it's warm and smooth to the touch.Folder titles may be directly hand-written or typed on self-adhesive labels on the tabs extending up from the folder.  These tabs are staggered for ease of viewing while in a file drawer; tabs are located atop either the first, middle or last third of the folder.  Quarter-length tabs would have allowed for more horizontal visibility while in a drawer, but these have the advantage of a larger writing area.  The folders are made with thick 10% (minimum) "post-consumer recycled content."This is a solid buy.

...And here I thought it would transmit my brian waves to my computer, automatically correcting any misspellings or illogical ideas.This light stylus is used instead of one's (much bigger) finger tip to operate electronic keyboards, other electonic "buttons," and to scroll though (in any direction) windows on Ipods, Iphones, Ipads, and other electronic devices not made by Apple (if there are any suc devices). No more smudges, no more pressing "G" instead of "F," and no sore fingers from all thta scrolling.I really liked this product. It has great sensitivity (you don't have to press down hard to activate the screen), and it feels like it "bounces" back after you're done pressing in one spot. (It has a very interesting design, featuring a kind of sheath over the harder metal point at the end. This also, of course, protects your screen).You can buy similar products for a lot less (as low as $2.00) and a lot more; this seems to represent a good balance between functionality and economy. I have just two minor complaints; these lower my rating from a full 5 to a 4.5.  At this price, I'd expect some sort of GRIP, both to increase one's hold on the pen, and so that the pen has a warmer feeling to it. Again, a minor point.  The other quibble is that this might be very easy  to lose.  Although the pen clip works well,providing an option of colors (or, say a pen GRIP in a contrasting color) would reduce the liklihood of misplacing or losing the product.Bottom line: Works very well, greatly eases use of electonic gadgets, minor flaws, an OK price--but worrh the money. There's a one year limited warranty (not sure anyone would really use that for a $15 pen; details at [...]).

The only problem I have with this product is the Amazon.com website for it. IF you read it too hastily you may think you're purchasing one of the many  other types of Sticky Notes they sell. These include notes with adhesive at the top as well as the bottom, transparent notes, perferated sticky notes, fercryinoutloud!Nope, these are quite similar to the most commonly-used sticky note product: Post-Its, the pioneer and the predominant brand. Avery would love to change that. There's not much difference here, so price and current dicounts may be one deciding factor. As of today, with substantial discounts from Avery (50%), you'd be spending about a penny per sheet (for 200 sheets).The Post-It product most comparable to Avery's (and also sold by Amazon.com, so you can get free shipping if your total order is $25 or over is a 6-pack (two each of three pastel colors) , each with 75 sheets each (for a total of 450 Post-Its). At the current meager 5% discount, you'd be paying almost 1 and 1/2 cents per sheet.  WIth the current big discount, yer baically saving 50% per sheet with AVERY!But wait, that's only 1/2 cent more per sheet, and that's only when Avery has a 50% discount...and, and.... Post-It's are made with Recycled Paper!  *takes a melodramamine*  Avery fights back with it's own pro-social program: "All Avery Sticky Notes packaging includes Box Tops for Education coupons. This nationwide fundraising program is dedicated to helping America's schools get what they need...".So, as they say somewhere, the battle has been joined.Comparable price (well, at the usual price, watch th.t closely), quality, and social programs (recycled paper vs. some percent of money going to schools)--it comes down to values and preferences. Go with the upstart, or honor the company that invented it, ecology or education, 3 (by now, fairly boring) 3M pastel colors, or 4 (somwhat fresher) colors from Avery... Really, you can't lose, whatever your decision. In a pinch, office staff can conduct blind tests (during lunch,, naturally) to see which sticky thing they prefer.

"Bottom Line Up Top":  While individual tastes may vary, this healthy and humanely produced dog food is a real treat that bot you can your dog will feel good about; you in your head and heart, the dog in a very happy tummy.This is "one cookie" (Newman's great line in "The Young Philadelphians) that was a HUGE hit with our 14-year old Golden Retriever, "Sadie, The Wonder Dog." After some circumspect sniffing and tentative gnawing, Sadie got into these in a major way.  Yes, they're crunchy, but Sadie had no trouble chewing it up and gave us the patented "Retriever Look" signaling she wanted MORE.Ingredients:The treats are about 1" by 2" and are scored so that they can be broken in half.  THe ingredient list reads like something you'd find at a California health food retreat (well, except fo rthe meat):Organic barley, Organic lamb, Organic carrots, Organic apples, Organic palm oil, Organic molasses.In the interest of full disclosure I should tell you that Sadie is not very particular when it comes to food. Not at all. Oranges, cherry plums, lettuce, bok choy, and tofu(!) are cherished by her; she holds the bok choy with both paws as if it were a bone. She's not totally easy (she refuses to eat spinach--probably some early puppy experience), but calling her the goat of Goldens would not be a cheap shot.However, it's important that Sadie stay away from typical canine snacks, especially at her age. She has arthritis, and a poor diet has been linked to a number of disorders in older dogs. Fortunately, our vet has warned us about this, and it's become necessary to tell a certian neighbor to stop feeding her raw hamburger, baked potatoes with sour cream, bacon, etc.Now, I don't want to guilt-trip anyone over what they're feeding their pooches, but here's a (partial) list of culinary "BAD DOGS" that you won't find in Newman's pet foods. (The following--and MORE--can be found at [...]. WARNING: The following contains graphic descriptions of typical dog food ingredients.  HIDE YOUR CHILDREN.NO Poultry by-products - Ground, rendered, cleaned slaughtered poultry carcass parts such as necks, feet, lymph nodes, undeveloped eggs and intestines (and a small amount of feathers). The quality is very inconsistent between batches. Note: By product meals are often derived from 4-D meat sources - defined as food animals that have been rejected for human consumption because they were presented to the meat packing plant as "Dead, Dying, Disabled or Diseased".NO Chemical fertilizers - Chemical fertilizers have been incriminated in serious health problems in animals and are not allowed in organic-certified products.NO Antibiotics or steroids - Long-term daily administration may result in a compromised immune system, muscle wasting, and destruction of the friendly bacteria living in the intestines that aid the digestion of food and assimilation of nutrients.NO Chemical additives or artificial preservatives - Chemical antioxidants, such as ethoxyquin, BHT or BHA, that were designed to extend the shelf life and reduce fat spoilage (rancidity) of pet foods may cause allergic reactions and affect liver and kidney functions.NO Artificial Colors and Dyes - Coloring agents provide an artificial "rich and meaty" look to modify the appearance of highly processed foods and make them more appealing to pet owners.As if this weren't enough, 100's of thousand of dollars are donated by the Newman Foundation to animal advocates (lest you think this means radical animal activists, we're talking mainstream things like animal shelters, etc. Details available at the website above).Sadie says, "Give it a try!"

I'm tempted also to say I got this for a song, but enough with the puns already.  This is an easy to use, practical, and inexpensive hook onto which one attached a (supplied) two-faced adhesive strip: One side sticks to the hook, the other side attached the entire hook to the surface from which you want to hang something.Mine attached very quickly to a painted door (it took much less time than the recommended 40 seconds, and I didn't wait an hour to hang something on it.  To test its strength, I hung a framed picture weighing about tree pounds and it held one minute after I had attached the hanger to the wall. NOTE: This is NOT suitable for picture hanging, as the hook juts out about an inch from the wall. Instead, the manufacturer suggests you use their "Command Picture Hanging StripsCommand 17203 Small and Medium Picture Hanging Strips, Sawtooth Command 17042 Sawtooth Picture Hanging Hooks with Adhesives Stripsor Wire-Backed HangersCommand 17041 Wire-Backed Picture Hanger with Adhesive Strips."However, for hanging coats, totes, purses, gym bags (sans basketball), it's works very well and on almost any surface (the product labels says "Do NOT use with wallpaper. May not adhere well to vinyl surfaces."The white plastic is sort of cheap looking--but at this cheap price, I don't think anyone is REALLY expecting a "Designer" hook.  I just love advertising!  It's also interesting (and responsible) that the label suggests you do not use the product for "antiques, heirlooms, or other valuable or irreplaceable items." Oh, and "DO NOT hand items over beds."  I wouldn't trust an under $5.00 product to hang an heirloom (which couldn't be much over a few pounds anyway); I think this is a disclaimer to mitigate against expensive losses and subsequent lawsuits.What's in the box:  4 adhesive strips and 2 hooks.Bottom line here: These work for hanging bags and coats, they're fast and easy to put up AND to take down, and you can reuse the hooks with Command Medium Strips3M Command 17021P Medium Mounting Replacement Strips.Basically, I'm hooked!

The Ace pruner boasts a smooth cutting mechanism, a comfortable ergonomic grip, a simple safety lock (just hook one end over the other using the plastic hook), and strong, sharp cutting edges.  No fancy gears or springs here, but it's so comfortable, sharp, and smooth-cutting, I could easily prune fairly thick branches. It has exceeeded my expectations!If all Ace gardening products work this well, I'd be happy to purchase more instead of the more well-known (and more expensive) brands. This Christmas gift will get a lot of use this year.

I have two of these and I like them a lot.  I compared them to other tool hangers and I like this model better because it looks more sleek and less clunky.  Some of the other models on the market have levers and a lot of plastic parts that I did not find particularly appealing.I use one of these to hold my two mops, a broom, and a Swiffer floor duster.  The "inner holders" are perfect for small handle products.Installation is very easy and the screws are included.I would buy this product again and I highly recommend it.

These do the job but only if you attach the wire and keep it there long term.  If you have to disconnect the wires periodically, then these will guaranteed break as the locking mechanism will snap from the stress.I used them in my dorm to keep my laptop power cord nice and neat.  The product really cleaned up my desk and even allowed me to get the wire off of the floor.  However, I had to disconnect the laptop a few times and several of the clips broke and the whole apparatus I had set up became useless.I noticed they make a medium sized version which, from the picture, appears to look stronger.  Maybe that might be a better option in the long run.If you however plan on using the small cord clips to permanently hold onto some wires, they might work for you.For the sake of durability, I can only give it two stars.

Just buy some 22db earmuffs from Peltor.  You are paying extra for the Vic Firth logo and the assumption that these were designed for drummers.  The headphone or, to be more accurate, earmuff even says PELTOR on it.  You can just buy the equivalent 22db Peltor model and it would do the same thing for almost half the price.There are a variety of earmuffs out there with different noise reduction levels so look around before deciding on this model.

I have been detailing as a hobby for fifteen years now and during that time I have experimented with a lot of different products.  Regarding waxes, initially I used liquid waxes but I never liked the fact that you had to let some of them haze before you could begin to remove them and once you started to buff them out, they would create dust or require the application of a quick detailer spray to remove caked on residue.  For wax, I strictly use paste waxes now.I used the Mothers California Gold Pure Brazilian Carnauba about 10 years ago and the ease of use and quality really amazed me because it is very easy to apply, does not need to dry, and creates a solid barrier from the elements; it also smells great!  I've used this on black cars and white cars with excellent results.  This wax and Meguiars Gold Class were two waxes that really amazed me but I just like the Mothers better.  I haven't tried Zaino products or some of the really expensive stuff from Zymol but if you are looking at those products, You're probably not buying your car care stuff from an autoparts store.  I feel the Mothers is an exceptional wax considering it is readily available to everyone and is as good, if not better, than any high-end wax.Please read my detailing tips below and I hope they offer you some insight into how some of these products should correctly be used.Wax is not what makes your car "shine."  Wax is actually the final step that "protects" all the other steps that you have done.This is how I detail my cars...**  Work in the shade and when the paint is cool or else you will be doing more work than you need to.1.  Wash with dish soap or paint prep product like Griot's Paint Prep to remove any old wax residue and dry car2.  Clay with detailer spray (use the spray liberally...don't be afraid to make a mess with the spray and dry car when complete)3.  Machine Polish with random orbital (you can polish by hand but that takes a lot more work)4.  Hose down car...Griot's used to make an interesting orange-based "Pre-Wax Cleanser" (since discontinued) to remove any caked-on polish5.  Glaze...(Apply as many coats as you have the time for)6.  Hose down car and dry completely7.  Apply wax or paint sealant (Apply as many coats as you have the time for)**  Maintain with a "Spray-On Wax" product after each washOut of those steps, the most important is step 1 because if you're surface is not prepped correctly, the wax will not adhere correctly and can streak or look cloudy.  It's actually steps 3 and 5 that give you the "show-car" shine.  If you do those two steps right, then the wax is actually the step that protects all your hard work from the elements.  If you never had to take your car outside, you actually don't need wax as the polish and glaze gives you the "wet-look."  The concept is very similar to looking at a brand new crystal glass and one that has been run through a dishwasher for years.  Polish removes or lessens the swirl marks that refract the light and give your paint a dull look; glaze fills in whatever the polish missed and adds other filler/shine properties; wax is simply protection from the elements.Don't get me wrong, if you take any car and throw a coat of wax on, it will look better than it did without the wax because the wax does share similar properties as polish, glaze, and spray-on quick detailers but from a detailer's perspective, that's not the correct way to use wax.It sounds like a lot of work but you are only doing the seven-step process once a year or every other year.  If you're paint is properly maintained, you can just clay and wax every other month and then maintain that look with a spray-on wax every time you wash the car.Try this process out and you will see a difference.  I use Griot's polishes but I use the Mothers glaze and California Gold Pure Carnauba.  They say not to mix and match brands but I've been doing it with no problems.  Stay away from cleaner waxes as those have polishing properties and if you already polished your car, why would you introduce more polish?  Always stick to a product that says "Pure Carnauba."I want to point out that I have never seen a wax make it through an automatic car wash.  If you do all this work and run your car through one of these machines, you will lose all of your work as the detergents they use are very harsh and will strip every bit of wax off.  Only wash your car at home with a true car wash product that specifically states it won't strip wax.  Also, If you keep your car out in the baking sun, the heat will eventually melt the wax.  They say paint sealants are able to withstand this but I haven't used a paint sealant.  If your car is not garaged, you will probably have to wax your car more times than someone who maintains a garaged vehicle.For step #7 in my process, the Mothers California Gold Pure Brazilian Carnauba is my favorite wax and I highly recommend it.

When I first saw this particular model, I knew it would look great in my living room and match my TV stand. I liked the fact that this model was not boring and that it had nice moldings and pillars to enhance the look. It's usually hit or miss with this kind of furniture but it really looked good in the pictures.  When I received it, I was very satisfied with the quality and the look.  Assembly took several hours because I like to take my time.It is a very sturdy piece of furniture and it just has a quality look and feel to it.  The door hinges feel solid and I don't notice any wobble or anything.There are a few things that I was somewhat disappointed with:1.  The doors themselves could be of better quality.  When you tap on them, they have a strange hollow sound to them as if the center piece and the frame are two separate pieces that are not held tightly together.  I guess that's what you get for this price.  Aesthetically the doors look just fine.2.  The back piece that you have to nail in is not the best quality and detracts from an otherwise great piece of furniture.  The back piece has a rippled look to it and when the light hits it, it is more visible; in a dim room, you can't observe this.  Again, for under two hundred bucks, I think that's the best you will get at this price point.  I have another bookshelf that I purchased from a furniture store and the back piece is of much better quality but I also paid more for that bookshelf.Other than those two issues, I really am impressed with this library/bookshelf and I am glad I bought it.  It has a very nice look to it and I have received many compliments about it.  It certainly looks more expensive than the price would suggest.The only modification I made to the library was that I installed two rubber bumpers to the door stops so that when you close the doors, it gives it a more solid feel and is somewhat quieter.  I didn't install them on the wood, I installed them onto the black door stops that snap into the cabinet area.I want to point out that you cannot use wood glue if you wanted to because all the pieces except maybe 1 have finished edges so there would be no place for you to apply wood glue to make the item even sturdier.  The unit is very solid without any extra glue so it doesn't even matter.  Also, a few of the pieces are not labeled so make sure you place all the pieces out and take your time when picking which goes where as a few of them look alike.  The color is also darker than the picture on Amazon.  I have a TV stand that is an "espresso" color and this library is just as dark.Highly Recommended.

I own the ceramic box cutter which is an excellent product and I just purchased the retractable pocket cutter (Model 10514) which uses the same blade as the box cutter.This safety cutter is the total opposite of the box cutter in terms of functionality.  The blade is too small to do anything and the magnet is weak.  Also, I don't like the fact that the tiny blade is exposed because you can barely see it and if you are not careful, I am sure you can cut yourself or something important.  The retractable pocket cutter is what I really need for opening packages that come in the mail or opening blister packs because it has a retractable blade; a larger blade; and a rubber grip with what looks to be a larger magnet.  I don't know what I will use the safety cutter for and I might just toss it for safety reasons.

What I like about these baskets are that they are very sturdy and well-made.  You can fill them up with heavy items and when you grab them on any one side, they won't bend or flex.  I was looking for storage baskets a few years ago and I mistakenly purchased a lesser model which has less capacity and is not as well made.  I will be upgrading those baskets to these InterDesign baskets.The baskets are also stable when they are stacked as the base and top of each basket securely fit together.  Also, the design and color are very neutral and blend in very well. They are also made in the USA.At first I was hesitant to purchase them at ten bucks a piece but they are certainly a quality product and worth the extra money.Highly Recommend!

I put this in the bathroom so that I can see a little bit in total darkness before hitting the lights.  It serves its purpose and illuminates as I would like it to but the batteries will only last for four weeks.  The bathroom is a high traffic area so it is going on and off several times a day.  When you factor the cost of AAA batteries and the fact that I am only getting about four weeks of use out of them, this little light can get really expensive really fast.  Also, installing the batteries is a pain because the housing uses four plastic screws to access the three AAA batteries, I've changed the batteries out twice and my screwdriver is eating up the plastic.  I've also noticed that one screw is not as tight as it used to be.  It's all just a hassle and the plastic is pretty cheap to begin with.I have a couple of Mr. Beams battery powered lights for a closet and the den but those run on D batteries so they last much longer and are even much brighter.  Also, the plastic on the Mr. Beams product is much better quality and feels more solid.I guess it depends on how you want to use this light but I don't think using it in a bathroom when it is dark is asking too much.  Beyond that, the light is not even that bright so I don't understand where else you could put it for it to be useful.I don't recommend it.  If you want a battery powered motion light, make sure it is using higher power batteries.I will be removing this light and putting it away.

I picked up a small 4oz bottle just to see what this product could do and I am very satisfied with it.  I used it to clean up an oily and greasy granite kitchen countertop and tile backsplash and this was the only product I have ever used that cut right through it with ease.  Usually with other products, the mess would smear around and take a significant amount of elbow grease.  I noticed that I was putting in less elbow grease with this product for much better results. I want to add that I followed up the degreaser with a Vapamore MR-100 steam cleaner.  The steam cleaner alone could not do the job as the KrudKutter was needed to break up all the stains.  But the two products together have given me amazing results.The product has a very thin consistency and it is clear with  no noticeable odor.  Previously with other cleaners, the smell was so obnoxious that I could not use them unless the windows and den door were wide open.  On top of that, the other products would make the room smell terrible for hours.It says that this product is non-toxic and that is very important to me because I have some degreasers that are very irritant and not fun to use.  I like that I can use as much of this as I want without any fear that I am endangering my health.I will be switching over to KrudKutter as my go-to degreaser.  They make a "Tough Task" variant which I am going to try as well.Excellent product

I opened the package and knew right away that it was going back.  This is the second Rolodex product I have received that I have been disappointed with.  Both times, the issue was related to the quality of the mesh.The printer stand just looked sloppy to me; the mesh appeared to be dented in several places; the metal borders did not appear straight in a few locations; and the legs, when properly attached, were still wobbly.The worst part was that it was shipped with Styrofoam and I needed to use a vacuum cleaner to clean up the mess and then clean up the little pieces that got lodged in the mesh!Functionally, the printer stand just looks clumsy.  It actually looks better in the pictures and that's the reason I bought it but in real life I think it is just too big for what it is supposed to do.  Also, I don't like the fact that the shelf does not slide out because it is a deep shelf and if you were to lose something inside, it could be inconvenient to reach in and retrieve it.Lucky for me, I had another UPS shipment coming in the same day so I packaged this up quickly and sent it back on its way.

My Epson inkjet is just not economical when printing documents. It's weird, even though I print in B&W, the color cartridges seem to get used up. I bought this Brother model to print my word documents and PPT presentations for school because they are usually 20-30 pages each.Wireless setup was a breeze and I had the unit up and running in about 15 minutes. I have nothing but praise for this laser printer especially at this price point. I got it when it was 91 dollars and I think that is a steal for what you get.The printer looks great, it has a small footprint, and it does the job very well. The noise, as some reviewer's pointed out, doesn't bother me. Actually, my Epson is much much louder when printing and it has a high-pitched shrieking sound and sometimes it even sounds like it is breaking! The Brother laser printer sounds like the fan on your computer; only a little louder. The fan on the Brother does keep running for a little while after the print job is completed but it eventually shuts off. I don't mind it at all.The only weird thing is that when the printer turns on or when it is printing, the lights in my room flicker a little. Then again, I have it plugged in with a two prong adapter so I don't know if it needs to be grounded. (Problem has since been solved as I have moved the printer to a three-pronged grounded outlet.)The speed and economy of a laser printer is well worth the investment. Printing text on an inkjet is a waste of time and a waste of money. I wish I bought this laser printer years ago. At this price, you can't lose.I am very happy with this product and I highly recommend it.

I had a pair of similar adidas soccer shorts several years ago and I thought these would be of the same quality. I was wrong.I received the package today, tried the shorts on, took them off, put them back in the package, and printed a return label.The reason I am returning them is because the material is very thin and they don't look like they are of high quality. It's hard to explain, they just don't feel right. I realize they are a soccer short but I have seen better soccer shorts. I was wondering why they were only 20 bucks and now I know. Also, you need to buy these one size up. If you usually wear medium sweatpants, you should get these in a large as the medium is very tight around the waist.You don't have to take my word for it but I think you will feel the same way if you see them for yourself.Spend a few more bucks and buy better quality.You get what you pay for.

I heard the single "Catch Me I'm Falling" on a VH1 "One hit Wonders" segment and I liked it. I grew up in the 90's but I always liked 80's music so I bought this CD and I was happy to find two more songs that I thought were amazing."When I Look into Your Eyes" and "Don't Cry" are equally great songs and just make you feel good.I think the rest of the CD is pretty good too but these are the three songs that I find myself listening to the most.I think you will like the sound of Pretty Poison if you like the sound of 80's freestyle.The CD is definitely worth it.

This is a very nice table. My Sony 60" sits perfectly on it and they look good together. The finish of the wood is high quality and the construction is very good. I think it actually looks more expensive than what it costs.I ran into a few issues related to the setup that I wanted to point out so that you don't make the same mistakes I did.  Assembling this table took me about several hours longer than it should have because I installed the center panel incorrectly TWICE!  The instructions should be more accurate and tell you to install the center panel with the smooth side facing forward and the cam-lock holes facing down.  I installed the smooth side facing the rear and then when I thought I had corrected that, I actually installed the panel with the cam locks facing up.  It's easy to make this mistake because you install this section first before mounting it to the two larger bottom and top panels and it is easy to confuse the configuration.  Just take your time with this step before tightening the cam-locks because if you make the same mistake I did, you will have to disassemble a good part of the unit to make the correction.I want to point out that if you are installing AV equipment in the side shelves, you will most probably need to install them through the rear first and then screw the rear panels on.  This is because in the front, the openings are obstructed by the beveled edges of the side panels and you loose about several inches of clearance.  This can actually be a pain if you are planning on adding more equipment or adjusting the cables of the existing equipment already in the cabinet.Regarding ventilation, My AV receiver doesn't seem to get too hot to begin with and since I have the back panel off, I think it has some room to breathe.  I have my Xbox 360 in one of the cabinets and after an hour of playing, it does get really hot.  I don't think you can do anything about it though.I have my audio video receiver and a Monster Power Center installed in the center shelves and I had to remove the middle rear panel cover as it was impossible to manage all the wires from those two small holes.  If you have a very simple setup, you can keep the rear panel on but if you have a lot of wires, just leave the center panel off because it is not worth the inconvenience. Just imagine if an HDMI cable were to come loose, you would have a hard time trying to see where it plugs in if the center panel was attached.Initially I was not a fan of the silver/platinum hardware but now I actually like it and I think it looks pretty good and provides good contrast. Initially I wanted to buy hinges that matched the color of the wood but it doesn't bother me anymore.I broke a few of the plastic cam-lock covers and my screwdriver chewed up a few of the cam locks during the assembly.  I contacted Sonax and they quickly sent me these replacement parts free of charge and very quickly.  Sonax customer support is excellent and that is more of a reason to buy this product.Overall, if you need a 60" stand, I think this is a really good one for the price. I am very happy with it and I have received many compliments.

I already had a standard box cutter and I bought this just for fun to see if it could make the job any easier.I just finished cutting up a box used to ship a large TV table.  I can say that this ceramic box cutter did the job better than I could have with the metal blade.  The cutting was just more fluid and the tool feels really good in your hands.  The cardboard was a little thicker than a standard shipping box and the ceramic blade did a great job of cutting it.  I don't know how to describe it but the ceramic blade makes a very distinctive "hissing" sound when cutting through the cardboard.  I think that demonstrates that it is sharper than the metal blade because the metal blade makes a more lower pitched sound.Also, with the metal box cutters, my hand usually gets fatigued when doing a large job because the tool does not feel good in your hand.  This ceramic cutter feels good in your hand and I had little to no fatigue. I want to point out that you should take care not to drop the tool as I can see how the tool would be susceptible to breaking if it fell to the ground.Other than that, if you are cutting up a lot of boxes, I highly recommend this tool.EDIT 7/6/15:  I just wanted to update this review with a few more thoughts and suggestions.  I recently was in the basement cutting up all the Amazon boxes that I have and it just struck me that if I didn't use this tool, It would take me forever to get through that job with scissors or even a regular box cutter.  Those boxes were chopped up and tied up into medium-sized squares in no time.The ceramic blades obviously last a long time but they are also double-sided so they last even longer.  I purchased the box cutter several years ago and have been using the same side of the blade since then.  For this last job, I flipped the blade and I noticed how much sharper it was.  I guess I'm going to get another few years out of this side of the blade which is great.I noticed that there is an orange and green model of this tool and I wanted to explain the difference and my opinion on which is better.  The orange tool is a manual cutter which means that you extend the blade and it remains extended until you pull back on the lever.  The green color model is automatic which means that the blade stays extended only for as long as you have your finger or thumb on the lever.  I can understand the automatic model from a safety perspective but I think the orange manual model is the better tool.  The tool is so well-designed that for some packages, I just extend the blade and gently pull on the "U-Shaped" finger guide and it easily cuts through packaging tape.  With the green model, you would need to put more pressure for a simple task like that which I don't think is effective.  I have never cut my skin or anything by accident with the orange tool so I don't really see a need for an automatic model.  The other day I purchased the Slice Ceramic Pocket Cutter (Model # 10514) which is an automatic cutter but in this case I think the automatic mechanism is better because the tool is so small and your fingers will be on the lever at all times.  Also, since it has a magnet, you can keep it attached to a fridge or a metal object on your desk without worrying if the blade was left extended.  I think the 10400 + the 10514 are a great combination for a variety of tasks.

I bought this for my home theater so that I could hook up all the internet-enabled components. I used to think that when a product was Ethernet-enabled that meant that you had to run 100 feet of Ethernet cable from your router, through the walls, and to your components. That sounded messy to me so I always looked for WiFi-enabled products.  I initially thought about buying a bridge instead but my understanding is that the Powerline adapters were faster since they are a wired connection.  I can't verify that but that is what I was told so double check.I was also told that for the Powerline adapter kit to work, both outlets must be on the same circuit.  I don't know about you but I am not an electrician and I really do not know what this means.  So I just crossed my fingers, bought this product, and hoped for the best.The product contains two adapters; one that you plug into an outlet by your router and another that plugs into an outlet wherever your other equipment is located.  You also get two Cat5e cables which I find to be a little on the shorter side so you may want to buy a six foot or longer cable.  There is no instruction manual included just a small diagram. Honestly, you don't need an instruction manual because the four-step diagram really sums up the installation process.Here is what you do:1.  Plug the single port end into an outlet by your router2.  Connect it to a port on your router3.  Plug the other port near the other equipment4.  Connect this port to the port on the equipmentThat's it, no settings to change and you will be online (assuming both outlets are on the same circuit.)  All I had to do was go into the TV menu and perform the "connect to internet" setup and the TV recognized the signal right away.I highly recommend you spend the extra few bucks and get the four port version because you never know when you will need the extra ports.Regarding the circuit breaker issue.  My understanding is that the kitchen and the bathroom are on different circuits from the bedroom and living room.  Apparently my bedroom and the living room are on the same circuit so perhaps that might be the same for a lot of other people.I'm glad I found out about this product instead of just buying an overpriced WiFi adapter for my TV or buying a more expensive Blu-Ray player with built in WiFi. A wired connection is best so try that first before wireless.This is such a cool product and I think you will agree. I highly recommend it.EDIT: 6-month update 1/9/13:  I have never had an issue with this unit since I hooked it up. The signal and performance have remained strong!EDIT#2:  7/21/15:  Just want to point out that you should not plug these into a surge protector and perhaps even a power strip.  I recently re-did my living room and plugged this into a surge protector and I did not get signal.  Initially I thought it was something else and I kept resetting it but it turns out you have to plug these directly into an outlet.  Once I did that, problem solved.

If your speakers have five-way binding posts, I recommend you install banana connectors as opposed to just using bare wire.  The banana connectors look much nicer and offer a secure connection.  Bare speaker wire can corrode over time so why risk that when you can pop these on with minimum effort?I like the Monster product better than some other competitors because they look nice, they feel like a quality product, and I like the design of the rubber grips and knurled cap.  I have these on Monster XP cable and the install was easy and they look great on my NHT Super Zero 2.0'sJust buy them. You will be happy. Installing them is fun too!I posted two pictures for you to view.

I just bought some new speakers and I needed to put some banana plugs on my cables.  After looking at what was available on Amazon, I purchased this model based on the reviews and the fact that it looks unique. The red color also matches my FACOM tools!The last time I tried to strip some speaker cable, the ten dollar model I bought at Home Depot cut the cover as well as some of the copper wire strands. It was not a clean and uniform process.  I was not happy with that tool and I thought you had to spend a lot of money for a tool that could do the job right. That was until I used this Neiko model.This model did not come with any directions but I found a YouTube video that might help:  just go to youtubedotcom and type in qpIWgRmRIMwThis tool made quick work of some Monster Cable XP and made a clean and uniform cut.  I actually cut two wires at the same time and the process was so easy that I could not believe it.  Not even one copper wire was harmed.  What blew me away was after I made the cut, a piece of the thin shielding was left on the wire and I made another cut on that area and it took that tiny film off without cutting the copper wire!!!  All you have to do is adjust the red stopper thing if you want to create uniform cuts for many wires.  Other than that, you just put the wire in and it strips it cleanly. I also like the "ratcheting" sound that the tool makes; it just adds to the quality.The tool itself is built very well, it looks very nice and feels great in your hand, and most importantly it gets the job done and done right.  The only thing you should be careful of is getting your fingers caught in the crimping area.  The crimping area is right between the handles and it is rather sharp so don't let your fingers wander around there as you could get injured.I smiled as I was using this tool.  I just wish I had more speaker wire to cut!HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

It's not a bad printer but it is inefficient with respect to ink usage.  I use it a lot for scanning and copying and it has helped me immensely; it looks pretty good too.It gets one star because it literally gobbles up all the ink. Sometimes I even wonder if somebody is using it while I am not at home.  I thought I got this for a good deal back in 2009 until I realized that they got their money back many times over through ink sales.  I only print in text mode and it still sucks up all the ink.  I don't even print pictures or anything like that.The scanning and copying capability are actually very useful and the Wi-Fi works flawlessly.I can also verify that the machine literally shuts down if you have only one empty cartridge.  Even if your black cartridge is full, if a color cartridge is out, the printer stops functioning till you refill it. It's like Epson is holding the printer hostage till you buy their ink.The printer is also a little noisy compared to some others that I have heard even in quiet mode.  It makes a very high pitched sound when printing. My old HP from 1998 was fairly quiet.  The carbon fiber look on the top is nice and the small display looks good as well.  It has a card reader as well which is useful but redundant in this day and age.I'd like to really give it a better rating because it has some useful features but the ink issue is just unacceptable. Due to cost concerns, in the near future I will probably have to upgrade this to another model or perhaps a laser printer.EDIT November 20, 2012: I purchased a Brother laser printer and a Brother all-in-one inkjet and I packed this Epson printer up and put it in the basement.

I specifically bought this to break up cardboard boxes.  Here is an example of the last time I used this utility knife:I just purchased a 60" LED TV last week which was double boxed in one of the biggest cardboard boxes I have ever seen.  The freight company took the TV out of the box and left the box in my den.  The box is so big that it wouldn't even fit through the door and down the stairs to my basement.  I actually dragged it down to the basement and everything was going well until the box pinned me to the end of the staircase and wall. I didn't know what to do because I couldn't push it back up because it was lodged between one of the steps and the ceiling; the box couldn't go back up and it couldn't go down either because the staircase makes a sharp left turn. I didn't know what to do and I didn't have my phone and I was home alone so nobody would hear my screams for help.  I did notice that there was about four or five inches between the box and the railing so I mustered all of my strength and charged up the stairs like there was no tomorrow to my toolbox where I keep this knife. Some how I made it back up the stairs and when I came back down I used some force to squish the box a little.  If I was a large man, I would have been stuck in the basement till somebody came home to get me out.  Anyway, I knew I had to chop this box up on the staircase so I got the knife and I proceeded to dismantle it as it sat on the staircase.  Within 15 minutes, I broke it up enough to toss most of the large panels downstairs. With all the weird angles, it took a lot out of me and I had to return the next day to finish the job.  Now that I had the panels flat on the floor, this little tool went through each and every panel like a hot knife through butter.  And I want to note that this box is thicker than your regular cardboard shipping box and this knife still cut through it with ease.  Now I have the contents of the cardboard box in one trash compactor bag in small pieces.  I completed the job in 1.5 hours as it is much harder than you would think and I needed to take several breaks. Over the years, I abused this knife so much and it still does the job each and every time.I'm sure it has many other uses but for what I use it for, it is indispensable.

The first thing I noticed was that the cable itself is thick and high quality.  I was expecting some thin cheap cable of subpar quality but I was very surprised to see that this cable was built very well.  The cable is actually as thick as what you would buy from Monster. I'm glad I bought the BlueRigger and not the Amazon Basics cable which I thought looked too cheap.  The cable is imprinted with "High Speed HDMI Cable with Ethernet" on the side and it comes with some useful plastic covers for the tips so that you can protect the ends when not in use. The cable arrived spooled up in a sealed plastic bag in an Amazon box.I bought four of these cables. I am currently using two and they worked the moment I plugged them in. I watched "Planet Earth" on Blu-ray with no flickering issues and the picture was stunning.  For the price, I am very satisfied. I have nothing negative to say about this purchase.Go ahead and buy them because they are a good value and I think you will be happy with them.If I encounter any problems, I will update this review.

I only bought this because it was on sale.The biggest problem I have with this razor is that the design does not allow you to shave your upper lip area effectively.  I constantly have a small bit of stubble left in that area and if you try to use the razor to shave against the grain to shave that stubble, then you risk cutting yourself as the 5 blades make the surface area so big that you cannot maneuver in that area.I don't know why people make razor's with 4 and 5 blades when 2 is more than enough.  When you have so many blades, you cannot effectively cut around the contours of your face. This razor also cannot cut the chin area or neck area effectively.  There is always stubble left behind.  If you make 2 and 3 passes, then you again risk cutting or irritating the skin.I am just waiting for the last two cartridges to run out and then I am going back to the Mach3.Since 1999, I haven't found anything better than the Mach3.EDIT: I decided to give this unit 3 stars instead of 1 stars because I think it does give you a close shave on the flatter areas of your face and I am actually getting used to the handle of the razor.  It loses stars because you honestly need this plus a smaller razor to get to the upper lip area; using two razors is just not convenient.  The cartridge is just too big to navigate the upper lip without accidentally cutting yourself.  The ergonomics of the razor are actually pretty good but the five-blade design is just too cumbersome for intricate areas. Mach3 shaves equally as close and it gets the upper lip area so I recommend that more.EDIT #2: The more I use this, the more I am liking it.  But you still need that second safety razor to get the upper lip.  I guess my skin is just getting used to the blade and I like how it shaves the rest of my face.  My rating is more like 3.5 stars.

I used this for my undergrad medical anthro course.Like the other reviewer said, this book has absolutely no pictures or illustrations. It is just page after page of text. I mean, wouldn't it be easier to visualize a group of people or a disease if you at least had a picture to look at? For an undergrad course, I thought this book was difficult reading. There were a few selections that I read through and by the end I had no idea what I had just read about. Most of the selections are a few pages to about 10 pages but they are just so hard to read and understand. The language is definitely graduate level and some of the discussions are a bit over the top. It's actually not a traditional textbook but a selection of essays so this is probably why I did not notice any type of flow. I think this book would be a great supplement to a cultural anthropology course but I don't think using it alone to study medical anthropology is the way to go.My rating has nothing to do with the content as I am not an academic and I am not in a position to judge the selections. My review is strictly based on my opinion of this text having used it in a class as an undergrad student. If you have no problem reading dry books, then you might actually like this book. For the average person, I think this book is pretty tough and kinda boring.Buy it if you want. I give it three stars because it is so damn boring.

I actually used this book as a textbook for a bioethics course. The book seems to cover most of the relevant issues regarding medical ethics but my issue with the book is that the language is just so hard to understand. For an intro book, I think the author should have "dumbed it down" a little considering the intended audience. Instead, his writing is very wordy instead of being straight and to the point and it reads like a boring textbook. I had to read each chapter two or three times to figure out what he was trying to say. It should be noted that Tony Hope is English so he is writing from a British perspective and you will see a lot of British references like the NHS.I don't understand why some authors decide to write in a complicated fashion when they can certainly use fewer words to make the same point.I had to give the book three stars because it's a pain to read. Maybe this is how British people write but I found it to be too wordy.For the price, I don't think it's a bad deal but I'm sure you could find a better medical ethics book.Borrow it first.

This is not my first book on managing finances.  I have read Dave Ramsey's books and also several others so I am familiar with the message.  What attracted me to this book is the title which suggests that the author may introduce us to some new ideas. After reading the book, I didn't learn anything that I haven't already heard.The book itself is short with big print.  You can finish it within an hour or less.  In some ways I would say that the brevity is a good thing because it keeps your attention till the end.  With a much larger book, you might not finish it if you get bored with it or if you just don't like reading bigger books.  The author does say that he chose to keep the book short for this reason so I can't hold it against him.Basically, the message of the book is that debt is bad, possessions are bad, money is time, marketing tries to separate you from your money, how to create a basic budget, and a few other topics.  Again, nothing new here.I actually enjoyed the first eight chapters but I wasn't a big fan of the author's budget in chapter 10.  I like Dave Ramsey's plan from his book "The Total Money Makeover" better. Actually, budgeting is a very personal thing; you should create a budget that works for you not something that works for someone else.It was also nice to read a book that emphasized the idea that spending makes you a slave to your money and that possessions are a prison.  Sometimes when I see people who buy cars, fancy clothes, electronics, and other things, I automatically assume that they must have lots of money to afford those things.  This book helped emphasize the point that many of those people may be "all flash and no cash" or as the author puts it..."big hat, no cattle" (from page 48). So just because other people are buying iPads, BMW's, or other luxuries, that doesn't necessarily mean that they are doing better than you and that you should buy the same things; They might just be victims of the "GMM."One part of the book that I don't agree with is that the author suggests that you close your credit cards (after you have paid them off of course) to avoid the temptation of spending.  The idea may be the most sensible but when you factor in the damage that it will do to your credit score, I can't believe he would suggest such an idea.  You should pay off your credit cards and then just shred them or hide them.  Closing them is a very dumb move as it lowers your credit to debt ratio.Other than that, I thought it was a great introduction to the subject but nothing more than an introduction. Because books cost money and you are not supposed to waste your money, I have to give it three stars for the content.  I will give anybody who writes a book about personal finance five stars for effort because debt really is slavery and everybody needs to be educated on how to get their finances in order so that they can experience freedom.In the end, personal finance is not a science nor is it only understood by really smart people or the wealthy; it is simply common sense and discipline.  If you don't change those habits that are getting you into debt, then you will always run into debt and you will never get ahead.  If we all had the discipline to live within our means, we wouldn't even need to read books like this.

I was actually looking at the Stanley Bostitch B310HDS heavy duty stapler when I came across this Swingline model.  I actually thought the Stanley looked more appropriate for heavy duty work but I ended up choosing the Swingline model because it came with 500 staples.I am so happy that I purchased this model because it is more than enough for my needs.  I'm usually stapling stacks of PowerPoint class notes which are about 20-30 pages thick and a regular stapler can't handle that kind of load. When I first used this stapler to staple a stack of 25 pages, the staple went right through the stack like a hot knife through butter.  The stapler itself is very ergonomic and the movement is effortless and requires very little force.  I was actually surprised how fluid the motion was because the stapler doesn't really look heavy duty to me. It actually looks only slightly bigger than some other desk staplers albeit about an inch or two longer.  It also looks great on my desk.  The Stanley Bostitch and other heavy duty models are much larger and look cumbersome on your desk.You will still need a regular stapler when stapling only a few sheets together as the heavy duty staples don't staple flat when used to staple only a few sheets.Overall, this stapler is a great buy at a great price and it COMES WITH 500 STAPLES.  One thing I want to point out is that in the picture there is a "purple" colored part at the head of the stapler but in reality it really is a "bright red."  The metal construction is great, it has a non-skid base plate, and the handle really is designed to increase leverage.If you need a heavy duty stapler to staple 20-40 pages, then this is your best bet.  I think the other bigger heavy duty models are more appropriate for stapling giant stacks of paper reaching 100 pages or more.  For the average person, this should be more than enough.Highly Recommend.

It's a decent book and it's also very easy to read.  Just don't expect to find anything here that you can't find in any Intro to Management text.  All the strategies described in this book relate one way or another to some topic that you will be taught in an undergraduate introductory management course.  There is no strategy in this book that is only specific to Dell.The book is divided into two parts for a total of 15 chapters.  The first part which covers chapters 1-7 discusses the inception of Dell Computers, a few of their early struggles, and then their rise to the top and their dominance.  The second part which covers chapters 8-15 discusses all of the business strategies that Dell has employed to get to where they are today.If you do not have a management background, you will love this book because all these "strategies" will be new to you.  If you have even a basic management background, then this book is really just for entertainment purposes because you will have already been exposed to the "strategies" discussed.I decided to give the book four stars because it is easy to read and it gives you a nice overview of applied management.  If you find management textbooks boring, this book should help put them into perspective and clarify the different principles. There is a lot of positivity in this book and I was looking for greater insight into the low points or conflicts that Dell encountered over the years and how they overcame them. It does talk about one or two low points early on but nothing from the most recent years. The way the book is written, you would get the impression that Dell just rose to the top of the computer industry in a linear fashion but I'm sure there were many challenges or dips along the way and I wish Michael Dell would have talked more about them and how Dell's strategies helped them overcome those obstacles. I guess I was looking for the book to be a little more in depth than it is.I think this is still a great business book and it can only help you to be a better manager and it can only help your company. It is also a great read for business students.I recommend it.

The material of the coat feels very cheap. It does not feel soft like a good quality peacoat should. I have a Macy's Ralph Lauren peacoat that I am returning because it is too big but it is much softer and higher quality than this one and I bought it for the same price on sale. The material on this coat feels like "synthetic wool." It does not have the same feeling that a good quality wool coat should have. The material on this coat actually can get wrinkles if you fold it!The bib on the inside also looks and feels cheap and it does not feel good on your neck as it feels itchy.I literally tried this on for two minutes and then I packed it up to return it.Just trust me on this one. If you are looking for a real peacoat, this is not it. It doesn't even look like a Kenneth Cole product. It is just a cheap peacoat with a Kenneth Cole tag. Buy another peacoat or spend a little more and buy better quality. As the saying goes, you get what you pay for.EDIT: After a little bit of shopping, I ended up buying a Polo Academy peacoat from Lord & Taylor which I got for 60% off retail.  This new coat is world's different from the crappy Kenneth Cole coat.  Not only is the material and craftsmanship on another level but the coat looks like a real peacoat as far as fit and cut.  Even thought I paid double what this Kenneth Cole coat is going for, you are getting a coat that is in a different league and will never go out of style.  I suggest you continue to shop around and don't settle for the cheap stuff. If you look hard enough, there are much better peacoats out there for just a little more money.

I used this text for my class and I thought it was a great book.  The language was easy to understand, very engaging, the layout and structure are excellent and it does not read like a dry textbook.  Actually I have seen magazines that are bigger than this book. Having said that, I have no idea how they are charging almost fifty bucks for it. My last issue of the Atlantic was thicker than this text.Don't pay attention to the CourseMate stuff/fluff...it's all useless. I actually thought you would get a CD with the book but you just get an access code (how many of you use the access codes anyway?)  If you can buy the book used, just do that.We went through the whole book over the course of 15 weeks and each topic of discussion was fresh and interesting.  After taking the course and reading this book, I can honestly say that cultural anthropology has opened my mind to be sensitive to other cultures and the way they do things.  You won't forget the material like you will in some other courses.  The information you learn in this course will stay with you long after your last class.I also had an awesome professor who did a lot of group work and supplemented our lectures with relevant videos so I'm sure that played a major role in why I liked the class and this book.If you want to self-study cultural anthropology, this would also be a great book to use.  Normally I don't read textbooks through but this one was actually fun and interesting.Highly recommend.

I had the following requirements for a 2012 planner...1.  It had to be 5x8" or very close2.  It had to have ample space for weekly notes without appointment times3.  It had to have monthly calendars4.  It had to have an uncluttered layoutThis was the only product that satisfied these requirements.  All the other popular brands seemed to be lacking one or more features.Here is what I really like about the product:1.  It has tabbed months2.  A heavy duty cover3.  A good quality spiral binding4.  A laminated second page with a yearly overview of 2012 and 20135.  A Reference page with important phone numbers and contact information6.  Two address pages7.  One notes page in the back8.  A holidays page with dates for 2012-20159.  The last page has all 50 states and their capitalsIf you are looking for a weekly/monthly planner, I think this is the best one out there as far as functionality goes.  I think it is also priced fairly when compared to similar products.I give it five stars.

This is one of those products that stands alone.  I bought this item back in 2003 and I haven't come across a product that performs better.  Keep in mind that some other companies sell a similar towel and I'm sure it performs just as well.  I just stick to Griot's because they have the lifetime warranty.Before I purchased this towel, I used to use cotton towels which tend to absorb very little and instead push more water around.  They also leave behind lint no matter how many times you try to "season" the towel. Then I used a product called the "Absorber." I think it is a synthetic chamois but I just grew tired of it. This drying towel is superior to any other drying product for a few reasons.1. The waffle-weave design is perfect for absorbing water and not introducing new swirl marks.2. It has hand pockets sewn in so moving it around your paint is easy.3. It's big enough that one towel will dry a medium sized car in no time.4. It's very efficient; it cuts your drying time down considerably.My advice regarding using this towel is to make sure that you do a final rinse of your car with a flat stream of water so that most of the water sheets off.  Don't try to dry a car that has too much water already on the surface as the towel can only absorb so much.  Just remember to do that final rinse and this towel will work 10x better. Also, you might be tempted to dry off some dirty parts of your car like the windshield cowel but don't do it. Don't stain this towel.  Use this towel only on the painted surfaces and then use the Griot's door jamb towel for dirty spots.  Do your best to keep this towel clean.  I have never washed this towel since 2003 because it never got dirty and I just air dry it after every use.I liked this towel so much that I bought two.  If they ever discontinue it, I don't know what else I would use.Five stars.

I've been detailing my car since 1995.  I've used quite a few wheel cleaners during my time and this is probably my favorite.It is my favorite because it does the job well and it doesn't suffer from any of the negative aspects of some other wheel cleaners.Griot's Wheel Cleaner is not a spray-on hose-off product.  With this product, you spray it on, agitate it, and then hose it off.  Griot's includes a yellow sponge with your order which is nice.  Personally, I recommend buying their lambskin wheel mitt as it is more effective.  I actually use this product with Griot's short-handle boar's hair brush and I finish up with one of the green three-finger detail mitts.  I don't like any other detail tools for the wheels.  Griot's sells a stiff foam brush with a black handle. I've used that and it is ineffective and a waste of money.The Griot's Wheel Cleaner obviously removes the brake dust effectively.  The reason why I like it is because...1.  It doesn't have a strong chemical smell.2.  It does not irritate your skin.3.  I believe it is also environmentally friendly4.  It doesn't damage any painted surfaces both inside your wheel well and on your car.Here are some of my tips to make this product work effectively...First, always work on a cool wheel. Then, spray just enough product on the wheel so that the mist coats the whole wheel.  There is no need to waste product.  Now here is the trick, make sure when you start to agitate the wheel with either the boar's hair brush or another brush or mitt that the tool is dripping wet.  Don't use a dry tool on the wheel as it will just soak up the Wheel Cleaner and work ineffectively.  The extra water helps lather up the wheel.  Do one wheel at a time and work quickly with fast movement. Then hose the wheel down and follow up with a green detail mitt if anything is left behind.  The key to the Wheel Cleaner is to get good lather.This is one of my favorite products from Griot's Garage. I've actually never used P21S wheel cleaner because of the price and shipping charges.  I've heard some people say that the Griot's product works just as well if not better.  IMO, I don't see how a wheel cleaner could work any better than this product. The only wheel cleaner that I ever liked that was sold in an auto parts store was the Turtle Wax wheel cleaner because it was non-alkali based.  If I was desperate for a wheel cleaner, I would use that.  If I had choices, the Griot's Wheel Cleaner would be my first.Griot's now makes several other wheel cleaners for specific wheel types.  I think the Wheel Cleaner is a great general purpose wheel cleaner and you will be very happy with it. 35oz should last you a good while depending on how much you wash your car and if you use it conservatively. If you have a car that suffers from heavy brake dust and you like to keep your wheels clean, then you probably should invest in the gallon size. Griot's now makes a foaming sprayer and I just might pick that up as it seems more appropriate for this product than a misting sprayer.I highly recommend this product.

I've used this product since 2003. I actually don't use it anymore for automobiles.  I only keep an 8oz bottle so that I can clean up my drum set.  Yes, my drum set.This product has several limitations.1.  It is too "wet" and does not have enough lubricity.2.  The product goes bad pretty fast.  After sitting on your shelf, the product constantly separates and even if you shake it up, it doesn't work or look like it did when it was new.3.
