One, the reader is left with a child protagonist, the author in the 1960s, who appears to be obsessing about the familys black maid and racism, when she probably was doing no such thing.  Two, the reader is left with a child protagonist who appears to have incredible insight about what is going on in her family and the country in the 1960s, when she definitely had no such thing.  Three, it was totally inappropriate to have a deathbed scene where the maids thoughts were being described.  There is no way the author knew what this woman, who was not a fictional character, was thinking when she was dying, and it was outrageous for Ms. Barrows to create such fictional thoughts for this book.Hence, one is left feeling that this story is a bit of an odd duck.  Yet, one is also left feeling deeply moved about the life of Amelia MacIntosh, the familys maid.  Amelia MacIntosh was born in 1902 in North Carolina, the last of 13 children.  She grew up motherless, never learned to read or write, and was married off at the age of 14 by her elderly father,  to a much older man who had a drinking problem.  Her only beloved child, a son, died at the age of 12, from lack of medical care for what was possibly congenital syphilis.  She herself died in 1964 from syphilis, gotten from her husband, who may have been part of the Tuskegee syphilis experiment.  When she died at the end of the story, I could not keep from crying, no matter how hard I tried.  Thinking of Amelia MacIntoshs life and death made the tears flow.*Oh Happy Day(Note: I received a free e-copy of this book from NetGalley and the publisher in exchange for an honest review.)

This is the second kocat wood cat litter I've used.  The first one had heavier, bigger pieces and tracked badly.  This "soft step" one has a much finer texture, and doesn't track . . . or maybe it's too hard to see it in the carpet.  It's also the lightest weight cat litter I've ever used.  The cats like it fine, but they're not picky, and it clumps pretty well, so the litter boxes are easy to clean. There's been no odor, but I'm scooping every day. While the litter is light, don't expect even the small box to be that light to lug around.  It's light in the litter boxes, but a full closed box of the litter still has weight.Update 10/24: Here it is over two weeks later, and I now will have to go buy more cat litter for the two boxes. This does track a bit, I now see, but it's still an exceptional and exceptionally light litter.  Too bad it's not cheaper.

If you cook this rice on the stove top or in the microwave, it will take approximately 30 minutes from start to finish.  I cooked it instead in my Hamilton Beach Digital Simplicity Rice Cooker and Steamer, 14-Cup (Cooked) Silver (37549), where it took 60 minutes on the "whole grain" mode.  It came out perfect, too.  Well, perfect to me.  It was sticky, while this rice is not suppose to come out sticky.  But I like sticky rice and apparently so does my rice cooker--all the rice cooked in it comes out sticky.  Sticky or not, this Zatarain has a terrific white rice taste, and is suppose to be more nutritious than white rice, like  Minute Rice Long Grain White Rice - 14 oz, but it's really not. For example, Minute Rice has more protein, iron, niacin, folic acid and thiamin than the Zatarain rice.  The Zatarain rice, though, has less carbohydrates, more fiber and more calcium.  I didn't know Zatarain even made rice, and will have to check in the grocery store to see if I've simply been overlooking it.  I'll have to check and see if they have started stocking ZATARAIN'S Shrimp Creole Mix again, too.  I use to buy it all the time until no store had it any longer.  I thought they stopped making it.  Zatarain shrimp creole would go great with this Zatarain rice.

Although Killer Apes, Naked Apes, and Just Plain Nasty People: The Misuse and Abuse of Science in Political Discourse covers very serious topics, it's hard not to laugh throughout much of the book.  Author Richard J. Perry not only has written a book the general population can understand, he uses both facts and outstanding wit to go after those who are trying to pass off their personal prejudices as science.  He particularly likes to target scientists who forget to "take the 'science' ID tag off the windshield" when they drift from the field of science over to the field of social philosophy.  Give this book as a gift to anyone you know who thinks they are superior to others due to their "race" or their genes.  (I put "race" in quotation marks because, according to Dr. Perry, "race" is a "social myth disguised as a scientific category, imposed on real people who often have no more in common genetically than any two individuals selected at random from different parts of the world.")

Written with her youngest son, actress Charlotte Rae tells her life story from her Jewish childhood in Milwaukee to her current life as a 89-year-old.  There are lots of interesting stories about the plays, TV shows and movies she did, with lots of names of her fellow actors and how she felt about them.  While the cover of the book shows  The Facts Of Life: The Complete Series cast, only a small part of the book is about that show, because only a small part of her life was spent as Mrs. Garrett.  (Not that people don't still see her as Mrs. Garrett, and get all excited when they do see her! :)  Ms. Rae has been on television for over 60 years.Along with countless stories about her acting career, she also is not shy about talking about her personal life, including dealing with a drinking problem; dealing with a husband who made a startling confession one night; and dealing with her oldest son's autism, during a time period when the majority of people had never even heard the word "autistic".  The actress tells how she was so relieved and happy when a specialist finally diagnosed her son as autistic, because she thought he said her son was different because he was "artistic". The doctor had to write the word down on a piece of paper to help her understand what he was saying.  What he was saying broke her heart, too, but Ms. Rae is not one to succumb to self-pity or stupor.  Well, yes, she did drink a lot during many years of her life, but she overcame her drinking problem with the help of AA.  Charlotte Rae has always overcome adversity one way or another.  She's dedicated, she's happy, she's positive, she's thankful.(Note: I received a free e-copy of this book from NetGalley and the publisher in exchange for an honest review.)

Little Girl Blue: The Life of Karen Carpenter was a very interesting read, but not really "superior" to Ray Coleman's The Carpenters: The Untold Story : An Authorized Biography, as some reviewers have suggested. The major difference between this book and Ray Coleman's book is that Karen Carpenter is presented as a more tragic figure. Instead of being a strong-willed, opinionated woman, as she was in Mr. Coleman's book, she seems more emotionally like a confused perpetual little girl in Randy Schmidt's book. For example, the reader is told she didn't cancel her wedding to a cad, as she wanted, because her mother wouldn't let her. Mind you, she was in her thirties when she married. She then stays married to the cad, who is spending all her money, because she didn't believe in divorce, and desperately wanted children. Mind you, he had a vasectomy before they married, and told her so before they married. And what did she believe in--a marriage that was a total sham from the start?Randy Schmidt doesn't ask questions like that, or ponder any contradictions between Karen Carpenter's words and her actions. She is a victim in this book. She is the epitome of the silently suffering woman who dies from a broken heart. If that is how you see Karen Carpenter, you will love this book. If you want a book with more diverse viewpoints about her, Ray Coleman's book might be a better choice. I personally would have preferred to have read a memoir by 65-year-old Karen Carpenter, telling how she overcame her low self-esteem and her eating disorders--instead of a book entitled "Little Girl Blue".  She was a beautiful, enchanting woman, with one of the greatest pop singing voices ever . . . who simply sadly, slowly self-destructed.*Road Ode

Early on in Some Kind of Lonely Clown: The Music, Memory, and Melancholy Lives of Karen Carpenter (Hardback), author Joel Samberg describes how popular Karen Carpenter still is with fans, and how many things associated with her get sold at high prices.  One can imagine that matter was on Mr. Sambergs mind when he wrote this book, because this is strictly a fan book with nothing new in it.  While the title of the book suggests he is going to explore Karen Carpenters darker side, that really does not happen. If someone in the book was quoted as saying she seemed melancholic, others would be quickly quoted as saying she actually seemed like a happy person most of the time; although the author does strongly suggest she played a clown to cover up her unhappiness.  Hence, the title of the book.  Why  such an unflattering picture of her was chosen for the cover, however, is a mystery. Is the picture suppose to make her look lost and confused?The Carpenters fans this  biography is going to most appeal to are the ones who like to think of  Karen Carpenter as a perpetual hurt child.  For, once again, we have the theory that her mother was the main cause of her unhappiness and eating disorder.  Once again, we hear how she didnt find out her fianc had a vasectomy until right before the wedding, at which time she wanted to call it off, but her mother told her the show must go on!  Its curious that no writer has ever suggested Karen Carpenter only claimed she desperately wanted children, but in reality did not want to bear any; which could partly explain her eating disorder, which left her with the body of a boy; as well as the fact she did indeed marry a man who could not get her pregnant.  But thats the way the Karen Carpenter story tends to goeven though she was a woman in her thirties, her mean mommy was still responsible for most everything bad that happened to her.  Mr. Samberg even suggests Karen and Richard Carpenter were possibly in a constant state of anxiety due to the fact their prejudice mother might discover how many individuals they worked with were Jews!Talking about Richard Carpenter, theres no Richard bashing in this book.  Moreover, their father, like usual,  is seen like a really nice innocent bystander.  The only thing in this biography not usually found in other ones about the Carpenters is the author mentioned Karen Carpenters sexual orientation was questioned in forums about her.  Surprisingly, or not surprisingly, the author makes no similar suggestions about Richard Carpenter or the man his sister married.  This is not a book meant to create controversy.  Some Kind of Lonely Clown: The Music, Memory, and Melancholy Lives of Karen Carpenter (Hardback) is meant mostly to be a nostalgic look back at the Carpenters and the time period in which they lived.  Mr. Samberg also does a bit more speculation than others about what future projects  Karen Carpenter might have done if she had not died so young.  There is much wishful speculation.  Thats one of the things that makes this 164-page book strictly a collectors item, for those who collect anything and everything by and about the Carpenters.(Note: I received a free e-copy of this book from NetGalley and the publisher in exchange for an honest review.)

Unless you have read Jubilee, Margaret Walker may not be a name you recognize.  That's one reason Carolyn J. Brown wrote this biography--she wanted to bring attention to a black woman writer who deserves more attention and recognition.  It's basically a short biography that is written in a way the general public will appreciate, and covers Margaret Walker's life from her birth in Alabama in 1915 to her death in Chicago in 1998.  Besides being a writer, Ms. Walker was also a college professor in Jackson, Mississippi for 30 years, and started one of the first college black studies program.  She also had a happy long-term marriage, four kids and lots of grandchildren.  (There is a lovely photo in the book of her surrounded by those grandchildren.)  With all that was going on in her teaching life and her home life, it took her decades to write Jubilee.  Poetry is where she started, though, and some of her poetry is included in this biography.  Poetry would always define Margaret Walker and the South would always define her poetry."O Southland, sorrow home, melody beating in my bone andblood! How long will the Klan of hate, the hounds andthe chain gangs keep me from my own?"(Note: I received a free e-copy of this book from NetGalley and the publisher in exchange for an honest review.)

This book by singer Jewel is part memoir, part self-help.  It also has endless introspection.  Jewel is one of those souls who basically raised herself.  Her father had a drinking problem and was abusive.  Her mother, for some reason, failed to see she was responsible for raising and financially supporting her own children.  She would eventually, however, become a big part of her daughters life after her daughter acquired lots of money her mother could squander as she wished.  Jewel played in bars with her father as a very young child, and went out on her own at the age of fifteen, at times being homeless.This is a slow, sad, draining book in many ways, partly because of the circumstances of both Jewels childhood and adulthood, and partly because of all the introspection.  In other ways, however, it shows how strong a child can be, and shows how success and stardom can be made possible with hard work and perseverance.  As an adult, Jewel obviously wants to help others with her writings, others who are having or had difficult childhoods, as well as others who want to be singers and songwriters.  That is certainly commendable.  She appears to be mostly happy, too, with her current life as a mother, singer and writer. Still, by the end of the book, it was difficult not to feel sad and overwhelmed by her life story.(Note: I received a free e-copy of this book from NetGalley and the publisher in exchange for an honest review.)

Never having used a robotic vacuum, I don't know how this Bissell compares to other robotic vacuums.  I just know it's a very interesting item that works fairly well.  I say fairly, because it never picked up everything off a carpet or floor, at least not in 30 minutes.  It can run for 99 minutes, however. It also navigates very well when I have it on the "auto" mode.  Additional modes are  "spiral" "along the wall", "Z formation" and "random". There are two suction choices--normal and turbo, and the docking station that comes with it can be programmed to send the vacuum to work the floors certain days of the week.  While the vacuum can go back automatically to the docking station, I haven't tried that yet.  Mostly I've been trying it out on various floors.  It did well on green carpet, a white ceramic floor, a black ceramic floor with white grout, and a totally black thick carpet.  But it did not work at all on a black floor covering, that is sort of like a very, very thin rug.  The E5 error code comes up on dark surfaces the vacuum cannot do.The dust bin, brushroll, filter, and edge cleaning brushes are easy to clean.  Moreover, replacement filters and edge cleaning brushes will soon be available at the Bissell website for $14.  You can also buy a remote control at that web site, when it becomes available, if you did not get one with your model.  One did not come with this model.  With the remote control, you can control what direction the vacuum goes, as well as choose modes, suction powers and times. A remote would make things a bit easier, but it's not really a necessity, especially since most people will not be standing or sitting there watching the vacuum work . . . at least not after they've used it for a while. :)  This model did  include an "invisible wall" that requires four AA batteries that are not included, which will keep the vacuum from going past a certain point, such as into another room.  (Unfortunately, there currently appear to be no additional "invisible walls" that  can be purchased at the Bissell website.)  All in all, I think it's a good vacuum for those who want a vacuum running when they are not around; or for someone who wants to set it up for an elderly, ill or incapacitated person, who can't vacuum; or for someone who wants less housework to do.  Personally, I still think it's easier to just grab a vacuum and do the job yourself.  More stuff gets picked up in a shorter amount of time. Moreover, you don't have to clear the floor of stuff this vacuum might suck up, such as wires or the fringe on rugs.

This is not the first "Teach Yourself VISUALLY" book I've read, but it's the first one I've gone through from start to finish in front of the subject I'm trying to learn.  I installed Windows 10 this week on my laptop, got this book, just finished it, and now know all sorts of things about Windows 10 I did not know; things that probably would have taken some time to figure out without the book.  Some of the information in the book is very basic, so it would work for someone who had limited computer exposure.  Some of the information is more complex, but the photos and detailed directions make it all seem simple.  Windows 10 is pretty exciting, in my opinion, and Paul McFedries' manual did not dampen my excitement, but instead left me feeling more knowledgeable about Windows 10 than the average user.  That's a sign of good teaching.

I'm not sure why cups that hold only 16 ounces are considered to be 18 ounce cups, but these are nice plastic cups that can be put in the dishwasher.  Or you can recycle them if they recycle #6 plastic products in your area.  They only recycle #1 or #2 plastics where I live, so they'll either go in the dishwasher or in the trash.  Good for parties and fans of the teams.

I know I probably should wait a while before reviewing Windows 10, but I'm so happy with it that I decided I'll just update in the future if it goes bad on me.  Right now, though, it is the faster and most fabulous Windows OS I have ever used, except it doesn't have Word for free like the Vista on my Dell laptop.Okay, I'm reviewing the free download from Microsoft, which anyone can get for any device with home versions of Windows 7 or 8 on it.  Months ago, I reserved Windows 10 for my Toshiba Satellite laptop with Windows 7.  After reserving it, my Toshiba started having problems, especially on start up.  It could take me sometimes 10 minutes to get online! Firefox froze constantly, Chrome was only slightly better, and IE would hardly ever work at all.  I suspected the problems were due to Windows 10 either being downloaded or tested out on my laptop in the background. At one point, I even stopped the automatic Windows Updates so I could see what was being installed.  Unfortunately, I forgot I stopped automatically updating and when I went to Windows Updates this week, saw that I had countless critical updates.  I also had only one choice to choose--Install Windows 10.  They didn't even send me a notice it was my time to do so, after I had been waiting for the notice for months.Well, I hit the install button, left my laptop plugged in and went about my day.  When I came home and checked the download in the late afternoon, it said it had failed.  The error code suggested the laptop lost connection to the internet.  Thus, I started again and the download amount immediately went to 49% . . . but then it went down to 0%.  I then decided to try to do individual installation of all the critical updates for Windows 7, pushed cancel, and discovered I no longer could view the individual updates.  My only choice was to choose installing Windows 10 again, which I did, and my download amount immediately became 90%.  It then quickly went to 100%, the installation started and finished in no time, and I, at long last, had Windows 10.It started off with some settings questions that seemed like nothing but spying to me, so I chose "off" for all of them.  That didn't seem to slow down Windows 10 at all or mess it up or whatever.  Now, when I go online, I'm online in usually 60 seconds or so.  Firefox, Chrome and Windows Edge, which replaced IE, are all working well.  I can go from one browser to another with no problems.  Also, my Epson Expression Home XP-420 Wireless Color Photo Printer with Scanner & Copier, Adobe Digital Reader 4.5, WordPerfect Office X7 Home and Student and SecureAnywhere Internet Security Complete 2015 5 Device 1 Year PC are all working well.  Moreover, iTunes is starting up quickly, and it's going to  be interesting if I can finally get that working right, which I've never been able to do with the Toshiba.To learn everything about Windows 10, I'm using Teach Yourself VISUALLY Windows 10 (Teach Yourself VISUALLY (Tech)).  I just started the book tonight and it is terrific about explaining everything in words and pictures.  For the first time ever, I now understand what apps are and what they do.  In the past, I just ignored reading or learning about them.  The book also shows you to how to connect your Microsoft account to your Windows user account, in order to access all sorts of Windows features, some "previously inaccessible".  I still worry about spying and security with Windows 10, but right now I'm plowing ahead and hoping Windows 10 does prove itself to be the best Microsoft OS ever created. We'll see . . . .Update 10/1:  Had my first major problem--after installing Windows 10, my DVD drive was not recognized at all.  I put a disk in tonight and absolutely nothing happened. Turns out, it's an easy fix for Toshiba owners, though.  Go to your control panel . . . and you have to type that in the search box to get there . . . which is one thing I don't like about Windows 10 . . . choose programs and uninstall the following two programs: TOSHIBA Recovery Media Creator and TOSHIBA Disc Creator. Then, restart your PC and your DVD drive will be recognized.

I've used Woods surge protectors for years, and was surprised how inexpensive this one happened to be.  When I saw it, however, I realized why it was so cheap--it's a very basic, very cheap plastic surge protector for items like clock radios and such. It's an extremely tight fit putting plugs into it, too.  If you have three normal type plugs, all outlets can be used.  If you have something like a cell phone plug, though, only two outlets can be used.  (The outlets do have dust covers, so the one you can't use can be closed.)  Putting this surge protector in the top wall outlet will also allow you to use the bottom wall outlet.  It's UL listed and made in China, and I would only use it for inexpensive electronic items.

This is a story about a young woman in the 1950s with one foot in her hometown and one foot in New York City.  She immediately feels uncomfortable in more ways than one when she returns home to her small town in the South.  She doesn't fit in.  She can't be like all the other women in town.  She can't bring herself to accept a marriage proposal from a dear old friend, because she knows she can't stay, and cannot be the type of wife he wants or needs. She also has to come to grips with the fact her friend and the father she idolizes are segregationists.  Realizing her father is like that is the hardest thing she has ever had to deal with in her life.  For he's always been like a god to her.  This is a story about growing up and realizing only children should idolize others.  Maybe if some readers realized that includes idolizing authors and fictional characters, they would appreciate this novel for what it is--not only an insightful story about becoming emotionally mature, but also a detailed description of how complicated the integration issue was in the South during the 1950s.

This review will hopefully help anyone trying to decide between getting this Panasonic Plush Pro or the Panasonic MC-CL943 JETFORCE Mult-Surface Bagless Canister Vacuum Cleaner.  These two vacuums are actually exactly alike, except for their nozzles, pet/air turbine attachments and color.  Everything else is the same and you could interchange all attachments, if you had both canisters.  After using both vacuums, I think Panasonic should consider either making a model that includes both the power nozzle of this Plush Pro and the multi-surface nozzle of the other canister; or sell the nozzles as parts for anyone who wants both nozzles.The Plush Pro nozzle excels in carpet cleaning, including plusher carpet.  Its heavy and self-propelled and is as good as an upright in vacuuming.  Its also does a great job with heavy rugs and carpeted stairs.  Only, the big power nozzle makes it feel very heavy when doing stairs.  But thats where the included air turbine attachment comes in-it, too,  does stairs really, really well and can be attached directly to the handle.  Both the nozzle and the air turbine attachment easily suck up pet hair. The Multi Surface Panasonics nozzle also does a great job getting up pet hair, but I find its pet attachment useless on carpet.  Moreover, if youre vacuuming long silky type pet hair, you have to constantly pull or cut off hair from the agitator brushes and the two small wheels on the bottom of the nozzle.  This is time consuming.  The much larger, more powerful Plush Pro nozzle can handle more pet hair.  (Ill add a picture of the two nozzles side by side after the review posts.)Both models do floors well, too, but I think the Multi-Surface excels in all floors.  The Plush Pro sounds like a tank on ceramic tile floors, while the Multi-Surface glides, with its lightweight and super soft bristles.  The Pro Plush bristles are harder, typical vacuum bristles.  In addition the Multi-Surface has an innovative edge cleaning design, complete with super soft bristles in front of the nozzle that dusts the baseboards!  The Pro Plush also does baseboards well, but nothing can compete with the Multi-Surfaces edge cleaning.  As a smaller nozzle, too, it fits easier under cabinets and such, but the Pro Plush also fits under cabinets. In addition, the Pro Plush nozzle is more like the nozzles on the traditional canisters with carpet height adjustments.The canisters are heavy on these Panasonics, so they dont easily perch on stairs and cant be held while vacuuming.  Thus, even though the telescopic wand extends from two feet to three feet, a long, straight stairway could be a challenge to vacuum.  There are three filters--a cleanable pre-filter in the dust cup, a washable sponge one in the dust cup, and a HEPA exhaust one in a drawer in the canister.  To me, the HEPA one smells like an air purifier with an ionizer on.  I really like that, but some may not.  Both the HEPA and the sponge filters are replaceable.  The HEPA filter is actually suppose to be replaced when it becomes evenly dirty.  Currently, on the Panasonic website, the HEPA filter costs $8, the sponge filter costs $6 and the belt is $5.  The dust cup is easy to empty and clean, and complete directions are included in the users manual, which is a most excellent and thorough one. Safety features include a motor protector and a thermal protector.So, which model to get?  As stated earlier in the review, its too bad you cant get a model with both nozzles, or buy a nozzle by itself.  Then youd have the perfect canister vacuum. You can, however, buy an air turbine attachment for $25 at the Panasonic website, and I would recommend that for anyone getting the Multi-Surface model, who also wanted a good air powered small attachment.  If you have a lot of floors and not too thick carpet, I would indeed suggest getting the Multi-Surface model, unless you think you would be constantly cleaning the agitator brushes due to long hair or threads and such.  If you need a canister for lots of carpet, though,  including plush carpet, the Plush Pro model might be your best bet.  Both models are excellent canister vacuums, because Panasonic tends to excel in canister vacuums.

This nice looking, roomy shower caddy is replacing a much smaller one where the paint was flaking off.  Thus, it certainly is a big improvement over the old one, and stays nicely up on the shower head.  It's good it stays up, too, since the suction cups really don't work.  That's a small matter to me, though.

"Live inspired. Be wanted."They're kind of getting overly emotional about a stapler, aren't they?  No matter, this stapler is pretty, comfortable, and easily stapled papers I wanted stapled.  I used Swingline Staples, Standard, 1/4 Inch Length, 5000/Box, 5 Boxes (S7035101), because no staples were included.

When I first started reading My Southern Journey: True Stories from the Heart of the South, I had problems sticking with it.  That was due to the fact I like to read books straight through, and that's not the best way to read this book.  It's best to read all these short glimpses of the South and of a Southerner's longing for the South in short reading sessions.  Only light concentration is required, but you may be amazed how deeply you are pulled into Rick Bragg's life, both past and present. He is truly a one-of-a-kind memoirist and storyteller.  He's insightful, he's funny, he makes you almost cry when he writes about longing to feel like a child again about life and the world.

It has been a long time since I have bought a bath scale, so this one was a bit of a surprise.  It looks like a glass floor tile, and goes well with the tiles in my dressing room.  It's simple to use, too.  You just step on it and when the numbers stop flashing, there's your weight.  If you're badly nearsighted, you can even step off of the scale, pick it up and read your weight, before the numbers disappear. If you move the scale, though, when you put it back down on a floor, you need to step on it and step off of it, and then step back on it to get your correct weight.It has to be placed on a hard, flat floor, too, since it will misread on carpet.  My only disappointment in the scale is you cannot use it to weigh boxes.  They don't register at all.  Also, I was picturing cleaning it with Windex, but you can use no chemicals to clean it, only a damp cloth and a mild soap.  The scale comes with the two needed batteries--Energizer CR2032 3 Volt Lithium Coin Battery 10 Pack (2 packs of 5), has a low battery indicator, is made in China, and has a limited 5-year warranty.

This is definitely one of the oddest stories I have ever read.  On one hand, parts of it are relatively normal and interesting, such as the idea that West Virginians Homer and Elsie are taking their pet alligator Albert back to where he came from--Florida.  (Yes, that's the normal part.) On the other hand, parts are totally ridiculous and irritating beyond words, such as many of the adventures they all have on their long road trip.  The way everyone talks is often odder than odd, too.  Maybe this story is a parody or parable that I simply don't recognize or understand.  Maybe I simply don't get the humor.  The hurricane part was obviously not meant to be humorous, however, and I'm not sure what that was even doing in a book filled with silly adventures.  Finally, while Homer is a decent enough guy, Elsie is highly unlikable, and Albert . . . well, if it wasn't for Albert and his yeah-yeah-yeah happy sound, I would have quit reading the story shortly after they picked up John Steinbeck, which was way-way-way in the beginning of the book.

This cucumber seed pod was part of a set I got this summer.  Like usual, I planted late--early July--and it was mostly in the 90s all summer.  I also planted the pod in old soil in a pot.  Yet, with all those odds against it, my cucumber plant grew like crazy and I have gotten the most wonderful tasting cucumbers from it.  The best I've eaten from anywhere.  I did feed it once a week with Miracle-Gro 101411 LiquaFeed All Purpose Plant Feeding System, and I think that made a big difference, but that food is cheap and I still have lots left at the end of the season. Actually, my season is not over.  I still have cucumbers beautifully growing, and I picked four this week.  I'm starting earlier next year, though, and I'm getting more than one cucumber pod, too. It's cheap, it's easy, it's fun, it's delicious.(Note: The seed pod set, Miracle-Gro Gro-ables Veggie and Herb Kit, 8 Seed Pods,  was a free item from Amazon Vine in exchange for an honest review.)

Panasonic canister vacuums have never disappointed me.  They have always been very well made and have vacuumed very well.  This one is the first modern designed Panasonic I have ever used.  My others have been the traditional designed ones with a lid that opened and stored all the attachments.  With this one, the crevice tool and dusting brush attach to the wand with a plastic holder.  (The "pet glide" attaches nowhere.)  When I saw a picture of this vacuum, I was expecting it to be much lighter than the traditional canisters.  I was wrong.  It's just as heavy, and cannot be easily perched on a stair, just like the traditional ones cannot.Moreover, when I saw the small multi-surface nozzle, which is approximately 10 inches, I suspected the vacuum might not be as multi-surfaced as promised.  I've used vacuums with small nozzles that only did well on floors, not carpets.  But Panasonic told no lies!  I was surprised to no end how well this canister vacuumed both floors and carpets, including thicker carpet.  Even more delightfully surprising was how well it worked against baseboards and in stairway crevices.  I've never seen a vacuum work so well.  This "edge grabber" nozzle is especially designed to be special when it comes to baseboard cleaning.  There's even a super soft bristle attachment in front of the nozzle that dusts the baseboards as you vacuum.  The small-sized nozzle superbly fits under cabinets and such, too, and you can vacuum both vertically and horizontally.I've used the vacuum on thick carpet, thin carpet floor covering, ceramic tile and normal tile, and it has proved to be truly a multi-surface vacuum.  On carpeted stairs, it does a most wonderful job; but my stairs have a center platform, where I can safely place the canister to do the top part of the stairway.  Doing a long stairway that goes straight up would not be so easy, even though the wand extends from approximately two feet to approximately three feet.  As stated earlier, it's not the type of light canister that can be easily perched on stairs or held while vacuuming.  Panasonic makes sturdy vacuums.The multi-nozzle also does an excellent job of getting pet hair off carpeted stairs, while the "pet glide" attachment does not.  But the "pet glide" is suppose to be more of an upholstery attachment anyway.  It's not a powered one, however, and has just plastic rollers. Thus, if you're specifically looking for an exceptional pet hair attachment, this vacuum is definitely not for you; unless you want to get an exceptional air turbine attachment at the Panasonic website for $25.  ( Update 9/26: After writing this review, I tried this vacuum out at a home with a large,  long-haired dog with silky type hair. Not using the pet attachment, but just the multi-nozzle, all the hair was easily picked up.  Yet, you will have to constantly cut off hair and clean the agitator brush, as well as two small wheels behind it, to keep the vacuum working well. )Filter wise, there are three--a cleanable pre-filter in the dust cup, a washable sponge one in the dust cup, and a HEPA exhaust one in a drawer in the canister.  I like the smell of the HEPA one-- it smells like an air purifier with the ionizer turned on.  Both the sponge one and the HEPA one are replaceable.  In fact, the HEPA one is suppose to be replaced whenever it becomes evenly dirty.  Currently, on the Panasonic website, the sponge one costs $6 and the HEPA one costs $8.00. (There is also a belt in the nozzle, but I see no belt part number.)  The agitator in the nozzle is suppose to be cleaned once a month, and full directions are provided in the included excellent user's manual.  The dust cup cleaning/emptying directions are of course also included, and dust cup removal and care is easy.Let's see, what else . . . the cord is retractable; the control buttons are on the handle, as is an air suction control; the release buttons work pretty easily; there are directions for removing clogs in the user's manual; there is both a motor protector and a thermal protector; the canister is a pretty blue and very cool looking.  All in all, I think it is a terrific canister for anyone with multi-floor surfaces, or anyone who just wants a canister for one type of floor surface.  (It's suppose to be most gentle with wood floors.)  Once again, it's exceptional for baseboard/stair crevice cleaning.  While the canister is heavy, the handle and wand and nozzle are not particularly so, which makes it good for those who can't vacuum well with heavier handles and attachments.  This Panasonic multi-surface canister vacuum also appears to be built to last, and hopefully it will last, because the warranty (labor/parts/motor) is only one year.

Those who have read Wilkie Collins' work will probably get a lot more out of this book than those who have not.  Unfortunately, I am one of those who had never even heard of Mr. Collins before reading this biography, and ended up never feeling more than mildly interested while reading it.  Wilkie Collins was a very successful writer during Charles Dickens' time, and was a good friend of Mr. Dickens.  The women in his stories were often strong women, very different from how women were usually portrayed in fiction during that time period.  Wilkie Collins adored his mother and never married, but had two mistresses, at the same time at one point.  He was also ill with one thing or another and addicted to drugs, provided by his doctor, throughout most of his adult life. He still traveled a lot, however, and wrote a lot . . . and this is the type of brief review one not familiar with his writings will likely write, after reading Wilkie Collins: A Brief Life. :)

Since The Light Between Us: Stories from Heaven. Lessons for the Living. was being described as one for fans of Eben Alexander's Proof of Heaven: A Neurosurgeon's Journey into the Afterlife, I almost did not read it.  For I'm no fan of Dr. Alexander's book, and see it as just another New Age money-making racket book.  Since Laura Lynn Jackson is a high school teacher, though, I wanted to see how she was mixing being a teacher with being a medium, and was she going to keep her teaching job after this book was published?All in all, Ms. Jackson's book turned out to be an interesting, well-written book.  It was also hard to imagine she was making up everything in it; and if she was doing that, how she would not be quickly exposed after the book was released.  In addition, much of her work has involved doing readings for parents who have lost children, and it's really hard to imagine this woman, mother and teacher taking advantage of grieving parents!  Furthermore, she did not come across as being narcissistic and self-deluded, like Eben Alexander came across in his book.Yet, to not imagine those things means she is a genuine medium who can communicate with the dead.  Now, I've read a lot of books on mediums over the years; including The Witch of Lime Street: Sance, Seduction, and Houdini in the Spirit World, which is being published next month; and I'm not convinced there are or were any genuine mediums.  However, I'm also not convinced there are or were no genuine mediums.  While Ms. Jackson's book made me think about the matter some more, until the day I personally encounter a medium who turns me into a believer, thinking and reading about the matter is all I'll ever do.  For me, that's enough when it comes to the interesting topic of mediumship.

A Place We Knew Well: A Novel worked in some ways, but not in others.  Author Susan Carol  McCarthy did an excellent job describing in both facts and feelings what was going on in Florida during the Cuban Missile Crisis.  Her strongest character was Wes Avery, a father and husband, who dropped bombs on civilians in Japan during WWII, as well as was in a plane that flew over Hiroshima after the atomic bomb had been dropped.  It's less than 10 years later, and he knows good and well what will happen to his family, friends, neighbors and customers if they are bombed by the Russians. The crisis is also making him think more deeply about his family life, and what seems to be happening to his wife Sarah.Sarah, a most dedicated wife and mother, is becoming overwhelmed by a possible approaching hurricane and then the missile crisis.  She starts spending more and more time thinking about the past, including a singing career she could have had, and less and less time thinking about everyday reality.  At some point, she breaks, partly due to the stress and partly due to all the drugs she gets from her doctor.  This is the 1960s, when doctors handed out tranquilizers and all sorts of other pills like candy to "distressed" housewives.  Unfortunately, for both Sarah and the story, things stop working out at that point.  Sarah's story seems too incomplete and gives the book a terrible unfinished feeling.Add to that a dark family secret, as well as the arrival of a long lost relative, and the book seems like a misguided missile shooting way off in the wrong direction.  What did that family secret and lost relative contribute to the story?  In my opinion, nothing.  If they were both necessary, they should have stayed in the story's background.  But why did they exist in the first place? Was it suppose to be a comment on the stricter moral beliefs of the time? Talking about comments, what was the purpose of the nasty comment Sarah's daughter hears her mother say when she was out of her mind?  Was it suppose to make the story more dramatic or something?  Must so many contemporary fiction and nonfiction books have family secrets?  In nonfiction, so many of those secrets really aren't that interesting to those outside of the family.  In fiction, they are the same type of secrets being told over and over again.Yes, this story covered only 13 days in October of 1962.  But even with the first chapter, which takes place in 2009; as well as the unique "epilogue" at the end, which takes place in 2013; the story seemed unfinished and parts were detrimental to the novel as a whole.  Yet, I find I can't give this book any less than four stars.  One, the author did such a good job capturing the time period and the fears, as well as the weather and how it affected the feelings of those in Florida.  Two, she brought up things like Operation Pedro Pan; which most readers probably don't know about and will find interesting enough to do some further research.  Three, I love stories from the 1960s.  Moreover, although I was a few states farther north, and too young to remember the Cuban Missile Crisis at all, I still remember a military kid, four years later, bragging in class that we would be one of the first places hit, if the Russians ever bombed the United States. I believe he said that right after he played The Ballad Of The Green Berets for show-and-tell.  Ah, the 1960s . . . you had to be there . . . .

This Suave conditioner is much better than the cheaper Suave conditioners.  It doesn't cause flyaway hair.  The scent is also not too strong, but I can't place it and don't particularly care for it.  Scent wise, I'm more of a Garnier Hair Care Fructis Brazilian Smooth Conditioner, 13 Fluid Ounce and Aussie 3 Minute Miracle Moist Deep Conditioning Treatment 8 Fl Oz fan.  But I'll still use the rest of this Suave either as a hair conditioner or to shave my legs.  It's great for shaving legs!

Author Alex Sheshunoff chucks his job, New York and his Spanish girlfriend for life on an island. Any island. Well, he does have a specific group of islands in mind in the Pacific. He also is fortunately not a playboy type looking for fun in the sun. No, he had the idea of bringing 100 books with him to read. His mother, a no-nonsense Canadian who lives in Texas, gives him her honest opinion of his plan, but that does not stop our Mr. Sheshunoff! (And he still stays in contact with his mother the whole time he is gone!)Thus, off we go to Yap Island in Micronesia . . . or maybe Yap is the name of a group of islands . . .I never got that straight. I just know he ended up on one and then another . . . and another? . . . until he sort of settled down on the island of Palau. Before getting to Palau, the story was extremely funny and very educational. Probably most Americans know little about all the specifics of those little islands in the Pacific, and certainly don't know what day-to-day life is like on those islands. When it comes right down to it, not much happens on those islands, but that's one of the things that made the story so humorous at times. Other times, it was like being in an old Twilight Zone episode . . . only one that wasn't scary and had no moral . . .but was simply strange.Then, our Mr. Sheshunoff got to Palau, and unfortunately the story started dragging and was not as amusing. I don't know, I think it was because he was hanging around other Americans, such as his future wife, and Americans just weren't as funny as the natives! (Or maybe he and his editors do not know how to edit well.) Also, while he, thank God, wasn't one of those writers who thinks everyone wants to read all the intimate details of his love life, he still provided too many details of his and his wife's courtship. So, so many of those details were totally mundane, too. While I'm sure this book will provide an excellent family record for his children and grandchildren one day, the whole matter of how Alex and Sarah got together and stayed together is just not that interesting to a reader outside of the family. (Interestingly, though, she appeared to be a bit like his mother!)Finally, we get to building a house on an island in the Pacific. The story then dragged even more and became even less funny. First off, they played juvenile jokes on those who were coming to the island to help them build the house. (Really, we thought our Mr. Sheshunoff was above such adolescent pranks!) Second off, he goes into great detail about building the house. Now, if you are thinking of building a house on a Pacific island, this is the book for you! However, if you're not, and you don't like to do things like hang around Home Depot, you might skim the house building part until you get to the baby monkey part. The baby monkey is SO cute and so much more interesting than that stupid house they were building! Go to our Mr. Sheshunoff's website to see pictures of the baby monkey. (Oh, you can also see pictures of the stupid house if you want .) In addition, you will learn from the website where our Mr. Sheshunoff is today and what he's doing. I'm happy to report he is obviously still writing very funny stuff . . .and hopefully learning how to do a better job of editing his next book . . . like maybe cutting out 100 pages! :)(Note: I received a free e-copy of this book from NetGalley and the publisher in exchange for an honest review.)

Uncertainties frighten and anger Jackson.  He prides himself on his scientist-like thinking, and that's what he wants to be when he grows up--a scientist.  But, like most kids in a family with some serious problems, he has limited time to think about his future.  His dad was once a successful construction worker who was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, and could only take part-time jobs after that time.  His mother was once a middle-school music teacher, until her job was eliminated, and she then started working up to three part-time jobs at a time.  Unfortunately, all that part-time work never seemed to add up to full-time wages, and, once again, Jackson's family was looking at the possibility of having to live in their van.Living in the van didn't seem that bad to Jackson the summer before he entered second grade, but he could not fathom doing so again the summer before he was starting fifth grade.  That's when Crenshaw returned.  Crenshaw was there the first time the family became homeless, and he was back the second time it looked like homelessness was approaching.  Crenshaw was Jackson's imaginary friend, and he was one big cat.  Like Jackson, he also wasn't particularly sentimental and liked to stick to facts.  Unlike Jackson, who feared he was beginning to lose it, Crenshaw had no problem with the existence of an imaginary friend, even for a boy going into fifth grade.So this story goes . . . and it is an excellent example of a writer dealing with a major social issue without being too heavy-handed.  For some, the story will seem magical.  For others, it won't seem magical enough.  For example, at times, Crenshaw seems more like a therapist explaining why imaginary friends exist, instead of seeming like an imaginary friend created by a young boy. Yet,  maybe that's the type of imaginary friend a budding scientist would create in his mind.  Jackson also has a friend named Marisol who wants to be a scientist when she grows up.  The author is nicely demonstrating with her character the fact that having just one real friend can make all the difference in the world, to a child heading towards an uncertain time in his or her life. (Obviously,  having an unreal friend can help, too. )Uncertainty.  Legions of homeless children or those being threatened by homelessness are dealing with uncertainties every minute of their lives.  Crenshaw may be a book that helps those children.  It also may be a book that will help children who never have to face the possibility of homelessness understand better those who do.  Crenshaw is a cat.  A big cat.  There is no animal that has better survival skills or instincts.  This is not a particularly sentimental story.  It's also not a story that will scare children . . . at least not too much.  The ending is one of hope, but not hope of an unrealistic type.  Yet, the story shows magic can exist . . . even in the mind of a young scientist . . . and can help make a difficult time less difficult.  So can love.

While this Bluetooth clock radio came with a short user manual, Philips suggests going to their website to download the full user manual.  I would strongly suggest the same thing.  Your life will be easier and less confusing if you do so.  Only, finding the manual turned out to be confusing itself.  When I went to Philips support, this model was not listed.  Thus, I had to list the model in a search engine and then find it on a Philips support page that way.  (I'll list the support page in a comment after my review, so the review won't be rejected for having a web page listing.)  The full manual helps you set the clock much easier.  I used the short manual the first time I set it, and it took me a while to get it right.  It will take you a minute with the full manual instructions.  The clock can be set 12 or 24 hours, and will lose its time if there is any power outage.  Thus, you can install 2 AA batteries if you want, to keep that from happening, but you cannot use batteries to run the clock. (Note: Only the PM symbol is present on this clock.  There is no visible AM symbol.)The clock numbers have three levels of brightness that can be adjusted using the SNOOZE/BRIGHTNESS button.  I didn't find any of the levels to be too bright at night, and I am a person who likes total darkness while sleeping.  I did choose the lowest light level, however. The two alarms are also easy to set using the directions from the full manual, and you can wake up to a buzzing alarm or the radio station you last listened to.  (Remember to turn up the volume of the radio to one that will wake you, if waking up to radio.)  I only use the buzz alarm . . . which is actually more like a beep . . . and was surprised the first time I heard it, because it was so low.  I was already awake when the alarm went off, and thought there was no way that quiet buzz would wake me up.  Ah, but then the buzzing got louder and louder until I turned it off! I really like that, because that will allow you to wake up to the lowest buzzing sound that will wake you up.  (For you snoozers, it's nine minutes more sleep after hitting the snooze button.)Scanning and storing FM stations . . . and yes, it's only FM . . .is also easier if you read the full manual first.  I did not read it, simply hit the SCAN/PROG button, and it automatically scanned in 20 local stations from lowest call number to highest.  That was great, except there are more than 20 FM stations in my area, so some were left out after that scan.  But you can of course go back and manually program by storing another station in the place of a stored station.  Sound wise, I think this little 4" x 4" box has a terrific sound! I was surprised, too, how high the volume got.  This is very unlike the radio alarms of the old days, which is the last time I had a radio alarm clock.Okay, this is the Philips model that will play music from any Bluetooth device you have that is "compatible with this product".  My iPod is a classic one, so I have no Bluetooth music device.  This clock radio can memorize up to four paired devices, and the operational range will be approximately 30 feet between this clock radio and your Bluetooth device.  I do have a Bluetooth capable flip phone, and had no problem connecting my T-Mobile 768 Prepaid Phone (T-Mobile) to this Philips.  I have no desire to keep my phone connected to any Bluetooth speaker, however, so I just tested out this phone feature once.  The person who called me sounded perfectly normal while using this clock radio, but she thought there was a slight echo when I was speaking in front of the radio, but not when I was speaking towards the top of the radio. You can answer a call, end a call and reject a call with this model.  Moreover, any music playing will pause when there is an incoming call.Other things you can do . . . you can easily set a timer to turn the radio off after 15-120 minutes.  In addition, you can charge your cell phone or MP3 player or what have you with a USB cable, which is not included.  I tried charging my phone, using the cable that came with my HP Roar Mini Bluetooth Speaker, White, and it was charging fine.  (That was just to test it out, though, and I don't know how long it would take to completely charge the phone with this clock radio.)  It's certainly a nice feature to have, however, especially if you're traveling with this clock.At 4"x4" and 13.1 ounces, this clock radio can certainly easily be packed up and taken places.  Yes, you can use your cell phone as an alarm clock, and that's what I've done at home for the last few years.  Only I grew to hate using a cell phone.  Even at its loudest, sometimes it did not wake me up out of a deep sleep, and I hated the alarm sound choices. ( Music doesn't always tend to wake me up, either. I just incorporate the song playing into my dreams. :) Hence, I'm very happy to have a dedicated alarm clock once again, and this Philips is certainly a nice sounding, stylish one.

The pot I received does not look like the current item picture.  (It looks like the pot currently being advertised on this page by Lenox called the "Rick Bayless 16-qt Red Stockpot".) It does not have a glass lid, but a lid that is made of the same material as the pot.  The handle on the lid is the same as the handles on the pot, too, and all handles get very hot when cooking!  Thus, you need a pot holder to open the lid and stir your food. My pot also looks very much like a Rachael Ray 12-qt speckled red stockpot my mother bought at Walmart. Her pot was only half the price of this one, and did not come with a steamer rack, which is apparently for cooking tamales.I was hoping the included recipe booklet would encourage me to cook some new Mexican food, but I'm afraid Rick Bayless' recipes are all out of my hemisphere.  Thus, so far I've only used the pot to cook chili, and will probably use it in the future for other soups and stews, too, as well as for cooking chicken.  In addition, I was hoping it could be a large steaming pot for vegetables, since all my steaming pots are small, but a steamer rack is not a steamer basket, so that's out.  My chili did not stick to the pot, which is good since nothing abrasive can be used to clean the stockpot; and it cannot be put in the dishwasher, contrary to what the item description currently says on this Amazon page. (Bad news for me since I'm very big on putting almost everything in the dishwasher!) It's a handful to wash, too, since the pot is 9 and half inches tall.All in all, though, it is a beautiful pot with enough room to cook a whole lot of food at once.  (Thus, make sure you need a stockpot this big, instead of a 12-qt one.  The deeper the pot, the more strenuous the stirring.  And the less food you have in a tall pot, the more heat hits your arm while you are stirring.)  It also looks like it is made to last forever and ever, which is good in this day and age of cheaply made items. This Rick Bayless pot was made in Thailand for Gorham, a division of the Lenox Corporation.

I listened to music for years and years using only a $10 pair of Panasonic headphones that were discontinued a few years ago--Panasonic RP-HG10 Neck Band Headphones with XBS Extra Bass System (Discontinued by Manufacturer).  Since that time, I have searched and searched for decent sounding Panasonic small headphones.  Most newer models I tried sounded nothing like my old cheapo model.  These travel ones are better sounding than other pairs I've tried, but make sure you adjust your equalizer on your iPod or whatever to a sound that you like.  "Off" or "flat" will not work with these Panasonics. The music sounds terrible.  I strangely discovered songs sounded best on the "piano" EQ setting.  Usually, I use the "dance" or "spoken word" settings with small headphones, but neither of those sounded quite right with this pair.Listening to talking on online videos sounded like being in a tunnel to me, as did talking on the phone.  The headphones worked well with my T-Mobile 768 Prepaid Phone (T-Mobile), though, in regards to using the microphone in the cord to answer calls.  Comfort wise, I intensely dislike these Panasonics.  They are too sticky in hot weather and the band is too hard a type of plastic.  The band does have a wide size range, however.  It goes from approximately 12 to 15 inches.  But I'm just going back to my Philips SHL5100YL/28 Strada Headband Headphones, Yellow to listen to my music.  I was one of Panasonic's biggest headphone fans for years, but no more.  I think they lost their way for some reason with their smaller headphones.

When you first look at this Dell keyboard and mouse set, it appears to be nothing special, and you wonder why the combo is currently selling for $50.  Like so many other sets, both the keyboard and mouse have on/off switches, and the batteries for both are included.  (The batteries in this set, though, are suppose to last for 12 months. They are standard Duracell.)  The keyboard weighs 15.8 ounces and is 17 inches long.  The mouse weighs 3.1 ounces and is four inches long.  Both seem to be made of very thin plastic. The keyboard is comfortable enough to type on, but I don't think it's elevated enough in the back for comfortable extended use on a flat surface.  The mouse wheel is loose and smooth.  The combo uses a Logitech USB plug, and the drivers quickly installed on my laptop, after putting the plug in a USB port on my Toshiba.That USB plug can also be used in other devices, such as a TV, and that is why this keyboard and mouse set is different from many others.  As the description states, it is a multimedia set; which means it has dedicated media keys other keyboards do not; such as play, pause, fast forward and reverse, as well as three volume ones.  It's like the Logitech Wireless Touch Keyboard K400 with Built-In Multi-Touch Touchpad, Black or the Microsoft Wireless All-In-One Media Keyboard (N9Z-00001), only this Dell has a mouse and not a touchpad.  Also, the Logitech 400, which I own, does not have as many dedicated media keys as this Dell, but the Microsoft one does. (Another keyboard you may want to look at that does have all the media  keys is the Logitech Wireless Desktop MK320 Combo).I tried the Dell plug in my LG Google TV,  which turned out to be the same exact plug as my Logitech keyboard plug, and the up and down keys, volume keys, play and pause keys all worked.  But the fast forward/reverse ones did not work on a show in my Amazon library.  The media keys also worked with  my Toshiba DVD Player, although I did not try the fast forward and reverse ones. When it comes right down to it, though, I prefer not to use media keys on a keyboard, but my TV remote control, or the media controls on a laptop or screen.  Also, when using a keyboard with my Google TV, I want a touchpad, not a mouse, which is why I got the Logitech 400. Thus, I'm presently not that impressed with this Dell keyboard and mouse combo.  But, one day in the future, I may get a device that will be perfect for this set.  (And Dell desktops and laptops are still my very favorite computers!)

From start to finish, Nonsense: The Power of Not Knowing is a highly readable, engrossing book that explains how important it is to be able to deal with ambiguity, and not to be always seeking closure.  Author Jamie Holmes points out early in the book that successfully dealing with ambiguity and uncertainty does not require a high IQ, but requires that one learns to master the emotional challenge of figuring out what to do when one has no idea what to do.  He states that he hopes to convince the reader of "a simple claim":  "In an increasingly complex, unpredictable world, what matters most isn't IQ, willpower, or confidence in what we know.  It's how we deal with what we don't understand."Those who don't or won't master that ambiguity challenge are more likely to "jump to conclusions", "deny contradictions", be mentally rigid, be prejudice and "revert to stereotypes", assert control elsewhere when losing control somewhere, be less creative, be more confident about an erroneous course of action, and be trusting of those who don't deserve trust and not trusting of those who do.  There are also three things that tend to make individuals less likely to successfully deal with uncertainty and, thus, need a quick closure--fatigue, urgency and stress. States Mr. Holmes: "We have to reduce the messy world to manage it. But resolving something--fitting it into a metal box--also means that you stop scrutinizing it. Recognition means closure, and it marks the end of thinking, looking, and listening."Embracing uncertainty, on the other hand, helps creativity and invention, deepens empathy, improves your "odds of making rational decisions", makes you less likely to fixate or clutch to "one aspect of a complex and shifting reality", and opens you to outside influences and traveling . . . which in turn feeds creativity and invention. As the author quoted Jerome Bruner:  Creativity often results "when the ambiguity wins".  Even mind traveling in books can be a big help, according to Mr. Holmes.  He says:  "And it's why reading fiction--which puts us in other people's shoes--can both lower our need for closure and make us more empathetic." (Interestingly, in novels, I prefer stories with closures, but I don't feel the same way about short stories.)On page 87 of Nonsense: The Power of Not Knowing is a "closure test" that the reader can take.  But don't imagine this book is a self-help one, because it's not.  It's more a book for those who like to think.  The author provides many interesting stories, too, to help the reader visualize both successful and unsuccessful attempts to deal with ambiguity.  Those stories include ones on:  A doomsday group in the 1950s; the incredible increase in marriages after the 1906 earthquake in San Francisco; the 1992 Ruby Ridge standoff; the 1993 Waco standoff; the 1973 Yom Kippur War; and the fallacy of more and more medical testing because "the culture of medicine has little tolerance for ambiguity and uncertainty".In addition, there are stories about: The use of brain scans in criminal cases; the failure of the midi-skirt to replace the mini-skirt in the early 1970s; how ambiguity aversion leads to higher insurance premiums; Toyota; the Zara fashion store in New York;  Alexander Graham Bell; the Hand To Hand school in Jerusalem; bilinguals; Anton Chekhov; puzzles ("The act of puzzling is a protest against the mind's reduction of ambiguity."); and how in the business world "strategies with the greatest possibility of success also have the greatest possibility of failure". (While reading that part of the book, I thought it was a shame Mr. Holmes did not look at Paul Reichmann and the Canary Wharf project--The Reichmanns: Family, Faith, Fortune, and the Empire of Olympia & York. In fact, Paul Reichmann's entire career as a builder would have been most interesting to explore in this book; since it is believed that the reason he took on so many projects with so many uncertainties was because, for him, there were no uncertainties where his religious beliefs were concerned.)When I reached the epilogue of the book, I was surprised.  One, because there were so many pages left.  It turns out the book has approximately 75 pages of notes.  Two, because it didn't feel like the book was concluding.  But I guess that is appropriate for a book that is proposing it is not good to constantly seek certainties and closures. Nonsense: The Power of Not Knowing actually reminds me in some ways of Kevin Ashton's How to Fly a Horse: The Secret History of Creation, Invention, and Discovery.  Both books were about creativity, both books made me think quite a bit, and both books used up a lot of my supplies in my Post-it Study Kit with Tabs, Flags, Arrow Flags, Note Tabs, Grid Notes, Full Adhesive Notes, Label Pads, and Flag + Highlighter. ( Kevin Ashton, though, sounded more like Thomas Edison, from Mr. Holmes' description, than Alexander Graham Bell. :) I also felt the great need to quote both authors in the reviews of their books.  Hence, let me end this review with two quotes that I liked from Jamie Holmes.  One:  "The heroes of this book are all protesters, and they are protesting the premature destruction of the world's mystery."  Two: "Owning our own uncertainty makes us kinder, more creative, and more alive."

Three stars for a neutral rating.  Either this cable is defective, or the SuperSpeed port on my Seagate NAS Pro 2-Bay 2TB Network Attached Storage Drive (STDD2000100) is defective, or it's simply the wrong cable; because the cable keeps slipping out of the port.  The symbol on the cable matches the symbol on the Seagate port, however.  Thus, I have no idea what is actually wrong. Maybe I need a SuperSpeed cable that is not a "micro" one, although others are obviously using this with their Seagate storage drives.

This is a rambling, repetitious book that proposes science is God, and one cannot believe in anything unproved by science if one wants to be known as a "critical thinker".  The author also preaches humility, which was amusing; since after reading the book, the "about the author" page, and some of Mr. Harrison's website, one has the feeling he would not recognize humility if it hit him in the face. Read instead Carl Sagan's The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark.  Even though it needed better editing and had a bit of a doomsday mentality, Dr. Sagan still did a much better job of doing what Guy Harrison tried to do with this book.

This is the second Nutro dry food I've tried this month.  The first one was a turkey formula that the cats ate the first day, but didn't particularly want from then on. Thinking a chicken formula would work better with them, since their usual food is a chicken one, I got this Nutro.  (Well, I actually ordered a high protein chicken formula, and got this hairball formula by mistake.)  Unfortunately, they wouldn't eat this one at all, except to taste a few bites at first.  I'm wondering if it's not too much fiber for them.  At 11%, this food has almost five times the amount of fiber than their usual dry food.(Note: I received a free 3 pound bag of this cat food by mistake from Amazon Vine in exchange for an honest review.)

While no one will ever convince me that plastic fans are as powerful as metal ones, this large Holmes totally plastic fan does put out a lot of air.  It also can be rotated to bounce the air off the floor or off the ceiling.  It has three speeds, a two blade plug, and a 2.5 Amp/5 Amp Max, 125 Volt fuse in the plug.  By no means, can it be considered to be a quiet fan, even on the lowest setting.  Hence, it's a good fan for those who like white noise, which I do.The two support feet hold this Holmes safely on the floor or on a table or dresser, but it does not have the heavier weight of fans with metal parts.  For example, right now I'm using a mostly metal Patton fan on a dresser.  I plan on replacing it with this fan, but am having second thoughts because I'm not sure if one of my cats was chasing another, the chased cat could run in back of this fan and knock it off the dresser.  Other than that, it's a safe fan around pets and children.Being made of 100% recycled material is great, too, but the buyer is obviously paying for that price wise.  So, right now it gets four stars and will keep four stars unless it disappoints me during the rest of the summer, or amazes me in some way or another, at which time I will update this review.  Oh, and make sure you keep it dusted, because it can't be opened to clean.  If it does get dusty inside, try using a shop vac to blow out the dust.

It has been a long time since I have had a locker.  To tell you the truth, I can't remember any of them, and if I kept them neat or sloppy.  I'm using this shelf to hold an old Dell desktop computer on the floor . . . well, to keep it off the floor.  And I'm holding Five Star to their claim that the shelf can hold up to 100 pounds without collapsing.  From the product picture, I thought the drawer had a lot more top clearance, but it's actually right under the top of the shelf.  Hence, I had to give up my plan to put my external Sony DVD burner in it.  About the only things that can fit in the drawer are flash drives, CDs, DVDs, old card readers, small cords, iPods, etc.

This year for the first time I started thinking of getting a tablet, and got this book to explore Samsung's.  The Samsung Galaxy Tab S is really too expensive, though, and I can't ever seem to get into Google, even though I have an LG Google TV.  This book, however, was not hard to get into.  It's really easy to understand and would be a great quick reference book for someone with a Galaxy Tab S.  I wouldn't mind at all reading a Dummies book by Dan Gookin on the Amazon Fire HD, because that is what I've decided to get.  (Amazon is where my books are, where my music is, and where I spend most of my online time.)  Unfortunately, it appears Mr. Gookin has only written a book about the Fire phone:  Amazon Fire Phone For Dummies.

It's always easy to tell a cheap faucet from an expensive one--namely, the weight.  This is one heavy bathroom faucet that is extremely well made.  I love the sharp modern design of it.  Even though it has a 6" escutcheon for 3-hole sinks, it could not go in the dressing room I wanted it in, however; because I never really noticed how much space was between the faucet and the knobs, or that oval sinks would need a curved escutcheon.  The only sinks this faucet would fit were the downstairs powder and mud rooms.  That's okay, though, because it was perfect for the mud room, since that sink is white with a chrome frame.  Also, the fixtures in there were decades old and looked it.  It looks like this faucet was made specifically for that sink, and I expect it will last a long, long time. I'll remember the name Delta for a long time, too.

Ah, the 1920s . . . jazz . . . flappers . . .cars . . . money . . . sliced bread . . . mediums . . . seances . . . ectoplasm. Ectoplasm? If you don't know what ectoplasm is, you haven't read much about spiritualism in the 1920s. The 1920s was the golden decade for spiritualism in Europe and the United States. Due to all those who perished in World War I, as well as those who were killed by the influenza pandemic of 1918, organized religion no longer was providing enough answers and comfort to those who lost a loved one or many loved ones. People who normally would be asking God in prayers as to what was the meaning of so much death and suffering, instead began desiring to ask those who were now on the "other side". In other words, they were trying to contact the dead. And there soon was no shortage of mediums who claimed they could do exactly that, connecting anyone and everyone to the dearly departed.One of the most famous and influential persons who believed wholeheartedly in spiritualism was Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, a Scottish physician and writer, known for his Sherlock Holmes books. His oldest son survived the war, but died soon after of influenza and pneumonia. His death, along with the deaths of other family members, only strengthened Sir Arthur's desire to preach spiritualism, something he had been interested in since his twenties.  One of the most famous and influential persons who wholeheartedly denounced spiritualism was Harry Houdini, the greatest magician of his time. Houdini could not contact his father or mother after their deaths, and had seen all the tricks used by fake mediums to dupe those desperate to contact the deceased. He spent much of his lifetime exposing fake mediums, and even tried to get laws passed to lock them all up.The relationship between Sir Arthur and Houdini is one of the most interesting parts of this book. They were good friends at first. One reason being that they had certain things in common. According to author David Jaher, they both knew "the humiliation of poverty" and both wanted to "redeem their fallen families and uplift their martyred mothers". Sir Arthur also felt Harry Houdini could do supernatural things, even though Houdini repeatedly tried to show him it was all trickery. Houdini's crusade to expose mediums brought an end to their warm friendship. For Sir Arthur Conan Doyle was as much zealously dedicated to promoting spiritualism as Harry Houdini was zealously dedicated to destroying it.Then, enters Mina Crandon, the woman pictured on the book cover, who was "the witch" of Lime Street. She was no witch, however, but strictly a medium; one who was greatly impressing many of those associated with a contest by the magazine Scientific American, where a $2,500 award was being offered to anyone who could legitimately produce "physical phenomena". (Another $2,500 was offered for legitimate "spirit photography".) Supposedly. Mrs. Crandon had no interest in mediumship until she was told during a seance that she was a natural medium. Her husband, however, was highly interested in it and had even discussed it with Sir Oliver Lodge, another well-known spiritualist. Her husband was a prominent doctor, much older than his third wife, and provided young Mrs. Crandon with a much more comfortable life than she had ever known.Was Mina Crandon a real medium, truly contacting her late brother, who so often highly entertained those at her seances? Or was she a total fake, but a very talented one, as Harry Houdini claimed? That question goes on and on throughout much of the book. It's not a short read, goes into great details, and keeps the reader wondering if "the witch of Lime Street" was truly a gifted medium, not a gifted fraud. Much of the book is also about Harry Houdini's life, which should please his fans. Moreover, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle comes across very well, if not gullible at times, and doesn't end up seeming at least a little creepy like so many others in the book end up seeming, including Houdini.By the end of the book, the reader is well-versed in spiritualism, mediumship, magic, trickery, creepiness, and the undying hope held by many that those who have died are still alive elsewhere. By the end of the book, Harry Houdini is dead, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle is dead, and spiritualism is all but dead to most people. The wealth of the 1920s is gone and the Great Depression has started. One can only guess the mediums and the spirits could not provide needed physical comfort to those who were still alive on Earth, such as food, clothes, shelter and jobs.(Note: I received a free e-copy of this book from NetGalley and the publisher, as well as a hard copy from Amazon Vine, in exchange for an honest review.)

This is actually the first video game I have ever played.  I'm against them, especially for children, especially for very young children. I think they make them hyper.  Yet, after playing this one, I can see the educational benefits of it, as well as the fun a young child can have with it. With this game, using the LeapFrog LeapTV Educational Gaming System, which has a camera you place on the TV stand, the child is on the screen in the game! The characters from Frozen (2013) are all so vivid and colorful, too.  Leap TV has obviously put a lot of work and brains into their games and system.There are ads, apps and a shopping cart visible in the system, so they are trying to sell games to kids, though, or maybe that's just for the parents and grandparents of young children.  Setting up the system was a bear, too, since it made it look like you needed to connect to your Wi-Fi network, using your security password, which actually you don't need to do to play this game. (I didn't notice the skip button. But that's another review.)  I'm still not sold on video games, but as stated earlier, I do see some of the benefits, including teaching eye-hand coordination . . . which I seemed to be sorely lacking while using the transforming controller. :)P.S.  This game is for one child or two, but a second controller is needed for two children.

The Georgian Menagerie: Exotic Animals in Eighteenth-Century London is described as "entertaining and enlightening".  I think it would have been better described as "educational, and entertaining only if you find cruelty to animals entertaining".  From cages to chains; from malnutrition to starvation; from freezing to death to perishing in fires; from being tormented by owners to being tormented by spectators; from ending up in soups to ending up as wig grease; it's all there for your "entertainment".  That's what the exotic birds and animals were mostly doing in London--entertaining the masses.  Or entertaining those who could afford to own them, such as royalty.Not everyone was unkind or indifferent to animals, of course.  When animals would harm or kill humans, they usually were not ordered destroyed by the courts, but instead their owners were fined very small fines.  Loose, rampaging animals were usually the only ones destroyed.  Yes, if you prefer reading about the harm that sometimes happened to owners, trainers, keepers and sightseers of exotic animals, not to mention innocent pedestrians, go straight to Chapter 8 : "Bitten, Crushed & Maimed". Be forewarned, though, some of those attacked were children.
