My favorite tale in that chapter was the one about an elephant named Miss D'Jek who got revenge on her mean keeper one day.In all fairness, the book is not all dreary and depressing.  For example, parrot lovers may find it more "enlightening" than others.  Actually, the book did exactly what it claimed to do on page 213: "The Georgian Menagerie" has revealed the life of the city's animal merchants and bird sellers, and the significance that the birds and animals they sold held for those who owned and saw them. The diaries and letters of Londoners and visitors to the city, in addition to wills, insurance records, court records, newspapers and broadsheets reveal a city bursting with exotic birds and animals."  Now, how well the reader can stomach those revelations will greatly depend on how well the reader can stomach tales of cruelty to birds and animals.(Note: I received a free e-copy of this book from NetGalley and the publisher in exchange for an honest review.)

My cats reacted to this food as they do to all new dry food I try on them--they love it at first, but then prefer their usual dry food again.  Turkey is the first ingredient in this Nutro formula, with chicken meal being the second. From there it's two types of rice, pea protein, oatmeal, potatoes, dried beet pulp and alfalfa meal.  Alfalfa meal?  Like in rabbit food?  No corn or wheat, but are peas, potatoes, beets and alfalfa that much better for a cat?  And while it has no soybean protein, it does have soybean oil.  It also has chicken fat, though, which I always think is better than the other types of fat put in dry cat food.

This is an odd disjointed first person narrative of a junior officer serving in the last days of the US occupation of Iraq. The writing is odd, to say the least. Its full of bizarre metaphors and similes few of which convey any meaning. Instead, they seem to exist just to make the writing sound like literature. Also the book has an odd style. The author does almost no visual descriptions of people, places or layouts, but goes into, time and time again, smells. We read he goes into a place and it smell of maggots. Another place smells of balls. So we get an olfactory tour of conflict in Iraq rather than a usual visual one.The settings jump about too like an amateur horror flick (now Im doing it too). The author and his group are trailing along behind an armored vehicle and then next second hes on his face but also on the second story of a building. He enters a mosque to kill or capture a guy in a minaret. Next sentence hes waking up near the minaret or maybe not. Something happened. A rocket hit? A grenade? Were never sure.His motives arent clearly explained either. He decides he wishes to blow the whistle on someone who may have been part of an American death squad which murdered some civilians, but no reason why he got all obsessed about supposed crimes which may have occurred years ago. He then grows obsessed with an American soldier, now declared dead, who was respected by the Iraqis. Then he grows overwhelmingly obsessed with the latter soldiers now married ex-girlfriend.The one thing made clear in the book is the hopelessness of the entire war. Everything the Americans do make things worse no matter how well intended they are. If the book was a narrative on events in the war, it rates poorly. If its a narrative on hopeless pointless police action and why so many soldiers who served there today are broken men suffering from PTSD and more, it hits the target square.

I got good if limited results from this product, provided to me as a manufacturers sample, but  it will likely work better for most others. Let me explain.I have significant skin damage caused by my having lived aboard and sailed a small boat for a total of eight years. I never wore sun screen or used lotion. The combination of salt air, regular drenching of salt water and constant sun has taken its toll on my facial skin etching deep lines which likely were made worse by my constant squinting while on watch.  This etching is a good deal deeper than normal age related wrinkles.The upshot is that I got no visible change in the amount of this etching which exists around my eyes. I do think that if Id not have had the sea / sun / salt background, Id have experienced better results. I say that because the JK Vitamin C serum (odd appellation there) did significantly improve the general tone of my skin where used. My skin, while still wrinkled, appears better. I sort of glow with good health due to this products use.I think this is a five star product for most, but I can only report my experience with it and that was only partly successful. As I said at the outset, I think that those who have had a more conventional life experience will have better success with this product. They should expect the JK Vitamin C serum both improving tone and reducing wrinkles.

This is a dandy scale. The manufacturers sample sent here is well-made and good looking which does everything one would wish a kitchen scale would do. It can weigh things absolutely or TARE or the weight of an item less the weight of the container. The controls are easy to use. There is an on / off / zero switch and another switch to change units which are, grams, milliliters, pounds / ounces (dry), fluid ounces. The fluid measurements are accurate with water or liquids having the same specific density as water but less so with others.Accuracy, especially in lesser weights, is vital to the utility of a scale. When tested with known weights and against a known good scale, the Accuweight proved perfect. There was no variance between the known weights and the values shown in the easy to read LCD display.One issue may have arisen due to the smaller diameter active weighing area of the Accuweight which measures 6 inches or 15 cm. When I tried weighing a known weight pot having a one foot / 30 cm diameter, the scale proved perfectly accurate. The reason is that the active area of the scale protrudes slightly above the bezel meaning that no matter the size of the vessel being measured, the Accuweight will produce accurate results.Small, light, accurate and with all the features needed in a food / general purpose scale  who can ask for more? Highly recommended.

These pans are single use double aluminum pans with an absorbent layer between the solid bottomed and perforated upper pan.  The idea is that you bake bacon (or other foodstuff) placing it in the perforated pan and the fats or other liquid given off in the cooking process goes through the perforations and gets trapped in the absorbent layer. It works as designed.  My test trial with bacon yielded bacon that was as fat free as bacon that had been baked or fried and then drained on paper towels.There are some drawbacks - at least for me, but maybe not for you. The first and foremost for me is that these cannot be washed before use. To do so would saturate the absorbent layer making the pans just plain pans.  So you use these as the come and they dont come sealed. Here we have pans made somewhere, transported somehow, warehoused somehow and all the while being handled by people who arent anywhere near kitchen clean. This wouldnt be a big deal if they came sealed from the factory but they are open to anything. Presumably, the cooking process sterilizes them, but gee, would you feel comfortable knowing rodents may have crawled over your cookware and you used them for cooking without washing? I dont.Second is capacity. The test bacon was standard Hormel brand bacon. Each pan holds four bacon strips. Since there are 16 bacon strips in a standard 1 lb bacon package, that means that these three pans cant cook a pound of bacon. OK, theyre not expensive but neither are a few paper towels to use as drains or even a cloth towel you later wash.Lastly they are single use and are not recyclable at least in our city. The reason is the fat saturated middle layer disqualifying them from our recycle program. Again, this wont bother all and for all I know, Im the weird one feeling odd about putting aluminum in the landfill but thats my way.In the test, I cooked the Hormel bacon at 400 F for 20 minutes on the top shelf of the oven. The result was delicious  as good a bacon as Ive ever eaten. So the outcome was great but the drawbacks cause me a good deal of hesitation.

The manufacturers sample received here is a rugged and reliable performer. It consists of a solar collector, a light and a weatherproofed switch which works in series  low, high, off plus a stake for putting in the ground and some fasteners if you wish to attach this to a wall or overhang or what have you.As luck would have it, the weather during the test phase was nasty so the InaRock first got soaked with rain for a few days, then the rain froze giving it an ice jacket and finally it got a bit of snow. The function remained perfect even after this onslaught.The weather was mostly cloud covered during the test period so I left it out to charge for two days turned off. Then I turned it on low because in addition to the clouds, the light was located where it could only get light for half a day. Even so, the light managed enough of a charge to operate on low for the entire night. While the light is supposed to turn off during day time, it tended to remain on for a bit of day during morning gloom caused by some fog and dense cloud cover early on. The light faithfully turns on at night.A nice little no maintenance item good for illuminating outside areas especially walkways or steps.

This is a complex, unrealistic, muddled combination of 10% police procedural and 90% internecine squabbling.  Heres the setup. A bunch of Muslims have migrated into Canada and now plan on repaying the kind hospitality of Canadians by killing as many said Canadians as they can using some fertilizer bombs. A police informer has been killed infiltrating this plot so now we have two investigations. The first is to thwart the plot and the second to find the killer of the informer. The plot thwart element is mostly concealed from the reader.The clues tend to be the most laughably obscure oblique poetry references. For example, a bad guy says something about mud and crime. A good guy comes up, instantly, with the idea that that line is similar to a line in a poem and so he, the good guy, figures out, based on the theme of that poem, what the bad guy is about. That sort of off the wall, never-can-really-happen event pops up regularly and in fact, is a major plot point at the very end of the book.Most of the book consists of people blah blahing about their relationships. The police work against each other as do the members of the plot who have their base in a mosque. There is a brother and sister who constantly dispute. A bumbling, dimwitted inept sergeant who tries to infiltrate the mosque and who seems to be more concerned with saving some overtly guilty bomb plotters from punishment because they are young than anything else. Along the way we get a good deal of the Muslim complaint about the West invading their lands and mucking with their culture as justification for the bomb plot. Yeah. So some Saudis attack America, America in return attacks Iraq and therefore its logical and right that an Iraqi led plot exists to kill Canadians.  This is the road to peace and goodwill.By the time I was done with this book I was disgusted with every character and had no sympathy for any of them. I did have a great deal of sympathy for the innocent Canadians who were the target of the plot and wished they had a reasonably able police force to protect them from this threat. If this book is an accurate depiction of Canadian policing, Canada is in peril.

There are two features which cause these headphones, supplied to me as a manufacturers sample,  to soar above the competition. The first is the ergonomic. They have large ear cups which will accommodate all ear sizes. The mic folds neatly into an ear cup  a much better design than those which either detach or just swing out of the way. The headphones are light and so have all day comfort. I know since Ive worn these for hours straight in perfect comfort. Finally, the controls are large and easy to access including a true rheostat to control volume and an on/off switch for the mic.Tested on a Windows 7 desktop, a Windows 10 laptop and a Chromebook. There were no functional issues detected on any of these three platforms.So the design is as good as Ive ever seen in a headphone aimed at gamers, but there is a good deal more. These headphones, unlike most gaming phones, reproduce music and voice wonderfully. They could be marketed at such and be a success. I was really amazed at how good these sound.Like a few other higher end audio headphones, these have a significant bias (equalization) built in to give the phones a major bass boost and an overall very round, rich and full sound. Its not a faithful reproduction such as youd get from a reference headphone but one which the vast majority of people will prefer over the flat non-biased headphone or speaker. In addition to the fullness of the sound and bass boost, these headphones exhibit a sound clarity well beyond my expectations.This is easily a five star product and I can recommend it without reservations.

These are reasonably attractive earrings, but I think they could be better. The first minor issue I have is that the stud isnt centrally located but rather on one end of the piece. This means the earring hangs down below the earlobe rather than being centered on the lobe. I would have preferred the centered look.The sterling silver treatment is great. It is an antiqued or tarnished look giving a very attractive patina to the metal parts of the earring. The turquoise is treated with epoxy and likely colored epoxy at that. This gives the stone part a fakey-doo look because its too uniform in color and consistency to look like a stone. It is a stone, or a composite stone but it could be plastic based solely on the uniformity of color.Since the stone is the center of the earrings, I am at best lukewarm about these despite liking the silver treatment very much. I live in an area where you can find turquoise just laying around on the ground  albeit not jewel quality, but it is turquoise so Im a bit more sensitive about this material than most.One final comment: before choosing these, be sure to check the size carefully. These are relatively small as ear studs go meaning theyll work very well for some but not so well for others.One note on this review. The opinions are mine but the person wearing the earring where I formed the opinion is my wife.

To gush about a garbage can strikes me as silly even while I do it, but I will. I really am enjoying the simplehuman stainless garbage can. The reasons are two: design and execution of that design.The material is beautiful stainless steel claimed to be, and proved by me to be, fingerprint proof. The stamping and assembly are flawless. The liner top folds over the top of the can but a stainless collar fits over the fold making the can seem from the outside not to have a liner. Cant have the unsightly plastic liner ruin the otherwise clean lines of this can, now can we?The can comes with a few sample liners from simplehuman which fit the can perfectly. There is a liner storage compartment attached to the rear of the can with the liners accessible from the inside of the can making for easy deployment. While the custom liners fit perfectly and are of extremely high quality, I also tried some generic 13 gallon liners and found they did fit well and would suffice if you choose not to go with the proprietary liners.Step on the foot pedal and the lid opens. Remove your foot and the lid closes but its damped so the lid falls slowly mating with the rest of the can silently. No banging or clanging here.This is clearly a luxury good. Sure, you can find a way to hold your liners rigid for a good deal less money but you cant get the sense of everything right that way either. Were moving, one appliance at a time, to a stainless kitchen. The simplehuman rectangular step trash can has found a highly welcomed home here. It looks great, works perfectly and is a joy to use. It may sound odd to praise such a prosaic item such as a garbage can so highly, but to me, any item which has had this much care lavished on it in design, materials and assembly is brings delight every time its used.

I had no idea such a product existed so when offered a manufacturer's sample, I accepted. I drive a 16 year old truck which has no provision for playing music from a smartphone but does have a cassette slot.The system is simple. The only adjustment possible is to move the wire from exiting one side of the cassette body to the other. To do this loosen a few small screws, move the wire and tighten the screws again.The device works. The sound is a bit dull as if you listen while wearing ear muffs. Also while in use, the tape transport motor runs which I suppose is all right since the same motor would run if using a regular cassette. I tested with an iPhone 6 and a G5 iPad. I feel sure it'll work with any device that outputs signal through the standard 3.5 mm phone port.In an ideal world, I'd like a brighter sound and the transport motor not to run, but still, it does work and adds a nice entertainment dimension to older vehicles.

I've used shrink to fit plastic cable management systems in the past which worked, but which are difficult to use and awkward to remove. So when offered a sample of a reusable cable management system by the manufacturer, I eagerly accepted the offer.The system is flat piece of cloth with a zipper. Wrap a bundle of wires, fasten the zipper and the result is a neat thick black cable bundle which is a good deal neater and less visible than the individual wires.Although I have large, clumsy hands, I had no problems whatsoever bundling and then zipping close the sleeves. In fact, it was rather an enjoyable experience to get the wires behind my home entertainment system organized into barely noticeable bundles as oppose to the spaghetti monster they seemed like when loose.This system is a major improvement over the shrink to fit system and one which is a pleasure to use. The result is highly pleasing.

These are extremely warm and well-made gloves. While marketed for winter sports such as skiing or snowboarding, I planned on using them for motorcycle and bicycle riding so when the manufacturer offered me a pair as a sample, I requested them in yellow for visibility. Note: I do not recommend these to you for either riding purposes due to them not being armored. The manufacturer does not market them for these purposes either.All those disclaimers aside, the gloves did work well for both riding situations indicating that theyd do very well for winter sports. They were as warm as you want for bicycle riding - maybe too warm. They are reasonably windproof even at faster riding speeds which exceed speeds one would find on the slopes. The piping is reflective  important for road use by meaningless for general winter sports. I found these almost too warm for use while walking even in sub-freezing temperatures.Im generally an XL glove size. The L size received here were a bit tight so figure they run true to size. If youre looking for a winter sports glove or one for general use such as walking or snow shoveling in very low temperatures, these would be a good choice.

As it arrived, the headphones worked well as a standard gaming headphone tried in a variety of old and new games. The only minor drawback was that the Up and Down Volume buttons only work on Android devices which leaves at least some of us out in the cold, but no big deal.The mic plugs in to the bottom of the right ear cup using a standard 3.5 mm plug. Its already fallen out a few times when I put the headphone down on a table.  I clip on the headphone to stow the mic when not in use would be welcome but not nearly as welcome as the more common retracting mic.A really big deal is the surround sound or rather lack of it. The headphones dont magically created surround sound. Instead, this demands a driver from the Lenovo site. A visit there turned out to be a journey of frustration. The headphones arent listed as a Lenovo product and all tries at contacting the company to ask what was up hit a dead end.Finally I found a 24/7 Online Chat option.  Clicking on it said something like Sorry We Missed You and then the notice that the online chat is only operational during certain hours. So much for 24/7 online chats. Also I was online during those hours and in fact in the middle of them.I wasted a half hour on that site going in loops and finally hitting the online chat wall. As the expression goes, theres time Ill never get back.This might be an intriguing product if it worked. I have no idea because clearly Lenovo is selling a product that it doesnt even know it has cataloged.  Note the date of this review. I suggest before buying check the Lenovo site to see if the driver exists. If not, hold off until it shows up.Update: Tried online chat again. I was told an 8 minute wait. After 25 minutes where I got down to #2 and then back up to #3 maybe three times, I got a person. I was told that this was sales only and no help. I was instructed to call another 24/7 line  voice phone.  A call there proved fruitless.This may be a decent product but vended by a garbage company. Im cured of ever using Lenovo again.

The sound produced by the Crossfades is so rich that it will spoil you for other listening sources. It may also cost you money or time or both because youll wish to upgrade your digital library to rid it of lower bit rate rips. Yes, you can tell the difference.The sound is not neutral but rather is equalized to a degree that will please almost anybody except those who demand utterly flat reproduction. The best word, and forgive me for using it, is orotund to describe the sound. Its rich and full, and also exhibits extreme clarity. I heard elements in my music that Id not known were there. If you were to tell me there is a better headphone available, youd have to prove it. I think these are state of the art in any headphone and wireless as well.The bass is astounding and blends into the mid-range seamlessly. The treble is crystal clear which gives a good deal of the great clarity. This headphone will outperform, in Bluetooth, most, if not all, wired headphones. Add the supplied wire (which also has  mic) and it gets just a bit better.They move a lot of air too. I find roughly half volume as much as I can take on most devices. More and my eardrums would compress driving my eyeballs across the room. You are warned.The fit and comfort are great. Some may find the standard ear cups a bit small. If so, V-Moda offers a much more cushioned and larger ear cup which will improve comfort for anybody but to a major degree for those with large ears. There are other options available as well such as different side dcor. The standard chrome dcor is a fingerprint magnet.The Crossfade Wireless is lighter than many wired headphones despite having to accommodate the electronics for Bluetooth. The construction is rugged showing, for example, braided wiring where its exposed. Expect these to last a good long time.There are four control buttons. A multifunction to change tracks or deal with phone calls, a volume up and volume down button as well as a slider to turn the device on and set it to pair. The slider button does not protrude above the housing making it somewhat fussy to operate. The three control buttons have only slight raised markings making them difficult for me to locate and implement while the headphone is on. Its gotten better for me now after maybe 10 or 12 hours use.The box it comes in makes a grand presentation as youd expect from a headphone of this cost. If you have an audiophile giftee, these would make a great experience both for the gifter and giftee come Christmas morning.The headphones paired easily and quickly with a Windows 10 computer, a Chromebook and several iDevices from Apple. I experienced no functional issues whatsoever.I dont want to sound silly but Im telling you that these phones are a different experience in listening. I suppose you can get most of what these can do for less money because all high end items get into diminishing returns. Then again, to engineer a room and then equip it with speakers to match the sound of these Crossfade Wireless headphones could cost a brutal amount of money making the cost of these peanuts by comparison.If you want the very best in wireless headphones youve found them. Nothing in my experience comes close to matching them. Nothing.

This is a slightly padded shelf liner material which is red with dark dots on one side and white with red threads in a square pattern on the other side. The material is thick enough to give a bit of a cushion to the liners you cut from the bulk rolls.Measuring and cutting are made much easier by the dots. Measure to a dot, then cut along the dotted line. This caused me, an indifferent seamstress type, to be able to cut dead straight pieces in both directions.If you choose to go with this product, be sure to measure your needs before ordering. Without measuring but just seat of pants, I figured two rolls would do much of not all of my small 1953 era kitchen, but it only did about 35%.The product straight from the roll doesnt lay down flat. This doesnt affect function but it does appearance. See the photo which shows my after cabinet. I ran a full size piece through a normal washing machine cycle and it came out fine. The colors didnt run or stain the whites also in the wash. After, the piece did lay down a bit flatter. If the buckling bothers you, I suggest you run your pieces through the wash and weight down after to press flat.Nothing remarkable to say here in form or function. I think the red liner makes my white inside painted cabinets look better and I also like the quiet of when you put dishes down on the stuff. A nice product.

This is another in the Amazon Basics line. Ive bought many Basics products and found them all to be a good deal better than what Id expect from a generic item although, I suppose, Amazon itself is now a brand. Still, I think if this as a generic because the brand is the same as the vendor.The set is three pots and two frying sort of pans. The pots all have lids and the lids each have a vent. The largest lid also fits the smaller fry pan. The large fry pan is the only item lacking a lid.Construction is fairly heavy aluminum with a truly superb non-stick coating for the cooking surface. The handles are soft touch which stay cool even after an hour on the burner. The handles are extraordinarily comfortable and non-slip as well.The surface which touches the burners has dots (see photograph) which may be functional or decorative. Im not clear on it. Anyway, the units all heat quickly as youd expect from aluminum and also distribute the heat perfectly. I browned some meatballs in the larger fry pan and noted no difference in browning if the meatball was in the center or edges of the pan.The fry pans are shallow having walls of only about 1.75 or 4.5 cm height. The walls are curved so you can do the one handed flip if you are good in the kitchen. None of the pots or pans has a spout for easy pouring.Ive never used a non-stick fry pan before. I expected some instructions on conditioning the set but none were included so I just washed them and then put them into service. Note: I cook with cast iron and have been carrying two such pans around with me for years now. I used to consider them non-stick until I tried the Amazon Basic fry pan. I just threw a few meatballs made with beef and egg into the pan on high. I figured Id get some sticking, but there was none. The few bits of food which seemed to cling to the pan washed off with nothing but the water stream from my standard kitchen faucet.I cant fault these performance-wise. I would have liked to have pour spouts on at least the sauce pots and fry pans as well as a lid for the larger fry pan. The bottom line is how they perform and thats where these win and win big. Im sold on non-stick pans.

This stuff is terrific and the value here is tremendous too. We use this not only as a skin lotion, but as a cooking oil. In fact, it's become our go to cooking oil. It's not as high temperature as either refined coconut oil or that old standby peanut oil but it works well enough to get the job done frying or stir frying. It also smells nice and we're convinced it's a healthier oil than most alternatives. I suggest you do your own research and decide for yourself if the claims and findings about coconut oil are convincing.Contrary to what you may think, this will not suffuse your food with a coconut taste. We use it on every sort of food including those with a delicate taste and find this oil imparts no unwanted flavors or odors to the food.The manufacturer's sample received here is simply great stuff. Not much more to say.

The device isn't fully functional. When the Mediasonic was equipped with a 1 TB WD drive, the PC (Windows 7U 64) recognized the addition of a USB device but couldn't not 'see' or work with the disc.I'm presuming that this is a defective or partly defective unit and that yours will function well, but I can only review what I receive.

Coconut this or that seems to be the Thing of the Day - at least for now. This set of shampoo and conditioner has coconut in it which doesn't seem to add or subtract anything I can see. I tried both and found results as I'd expect from good quality products.A better test was use by my wife who reported, like me, good results. I thought her long fine hair was a bit softer and silkier than usual after using this product set. So for sure, score at least one point for this.The only issue I had was that the conditioner pump arrived in a non-functional state. It wouldn't pop up to be in pumping position. A quick trip out to the garage shop addressed this. It was just stuck badly, but there wasn't any non-tool way to free it.A good solid product which, if you want or don't care about a coconut add in will serve well. Note: this product has a neutral post use smell. It will not leave you smelling like coconuts.

For a mystery / thriller book to succeed it needs at least two elements missing here in Run. It needs to be plausible within the context the author sets and the protagonist must be one we wish to do well.The protagonist has no likable characteristics. He's an utterly self-centered snob who worries constantly about stuff such as furniture or art. For example, in the middle of a chase (the book is mostly made up of chases) he'll observe with disdain how a house is furnished with IKEA - which I suppose is a bad thing. He obsesses over the laughable fake art of Roy Lichtenstein which is more an illustration of our times' degeneration than anything else.The plausibility isn't. This guy, some sort of database designer who has no training and isn't in good physical shape, constantly outdoes dozens of police as well as trained agents from Homeland Security. At one point, he's trapped in a room inside a grocery store where both the room and store are surrounded by police and Homeland Security agents out to capture him. He escapes using a trick loosely stolen from a Steven Seagal movie, Under Siege and just happens to find a truck he casually drives away in. He wrecks others' property casually leaving a misery in his wake.More: he manages to overcome, at close quarters, two highly trained professional killers / agents. He always seems to know in advance what sort of equipment he'll need so he just happens to grab something that later in the chase is necessary for him to survive or pull some other stunt.Worse, he's a fool. The entire book's chain of events is set in motion at the very start by him being a complete bozo only matched in bozo-ness by his annoying wife. They get into a fight which, by content, infers they have IQ's less than their shoe sizes.In sum, a fast paced breathless series of chases interspersed with exposition where all players try to figure out why they're chasing around. It's both exciting and annoying.

This is everything I'd hoped for in a second flush Darjeeling tea. The aroma is delightfully floral as hoped for and the taste just a bit more robust grape like flavor than first flush which is both lighter and more astringent.On that topic, I want to post a caution about this tea. If you brew it too long, it will grow, in my opinion, unpleasantly astringent. Here, I've noted that the 3 minute mark is the outer limit for brew times or that overlay comes to bear. Of course, if you like that in a tea, then brew it for a full four minutes but I prefer leaving the delicate aroma and taste along and not bring that to bear.In sum, this is really good stuff and also bears the seal saying it's genuine Darjeeling. That's important because approximately 75% of what's sold as Darjeeling isn't the real thing.

Supersymmetry is an absurd sort of scifi thriller book which, in some ways, is like the old scifi from the golden age.  People back then would retire to a lab and within a few days make a space ship which would take off and function perfectly. Here we have people doing things like writing complex computer programs while chatting up a storm and finding the programs work first time without a trial / debugging cycle. Not even one. Nice work if you can get it. Other laughable events occur every few pages. For example, in one minor incident, simple machines learn how to manipulate and understand quantum mechanics by reading RFID cards.Back in the golden age, atomic power was going to solve everything. Today it's quantum this and quantum that. So here we have nonsensical explanations all supposedly due to the quanta allow people to behave like some out of control swords and sorcery bunch. They think up a new power and then slam bang they can do it from splitting themselves into as many as 40 individuals to teleporting to time travel. Well, why not - it's after all a probable multiverse.As a hard science book, this one lost me at the very start when the top scientist explained he's holding a universe captive by projecting an energy field. Well, there is no such thing and there can't be because energy is a measurement of work capacity similar to a kilometer being a measure of distance. One would `t say with a straight face "I'm projecting a kilometer field" and one can't say that about an energy field. It's absurd.From time to time in the book, the players, when the action gets frantic (which is about every 10 pages) stop and start wasting time with sophomoric philosophizing. I think the author has been too much influenced by Star Trek which does the same silly thing time and time again.I'll grant it's an exciting ride but so are some swords and sorcery books where, to save everything, the good guy at the last minute remembers the Lost Spell. Here, we get the same thing but wrapping itself up in a pretend hard science disguise. An interesting fusion of magicks mixed with a lot of physics jargon which tends to run completely off the rails at the end. It's a fast trip to a merry improbable conclusion.

This meter works perfectly as a TDS monitor. While to be truly accurate, you'd have to calibrate it using a few known (high and low TDS) solutions as it comes in the box, it works well to give a comparative reading.I tested the manufacturer supplied sample against tap water finding a TDS reading of 152 ppm. Run the water through a filter and the meter, after being rinsed with distilled water, read 5 ppm. Shows how effective a filter can be for your drinking water.The device is supposed to be a temperature monitor also but I couldn't see how this worked. Still, for the money, the TDS meter is, if there is no thermometer, a good deal.In sum, a TDS monitor at a price anybody can live with.

I'm awarding this manufacturer's supplied sample of the ThermoPro TP-11 four stars because while it it works well, the calibration is off enough to result in an overcooked (in the case of the sample received here) meal. The reason I feel so good about this product is that it does perform as advertised which, sadly to say, isn't always the case with these remote cooking thermometers meant for grill cooking.Cut to the chase: the transmission of data from the sender to the receiver unit worked at a distance of 50 feet (15 m) through structural brick outside walls and plaster on lath inside walls. Other units tried failed this test.The issue is one of accuracy. You need to calibrate this unit before testing. I checked the temperature readout against a calibrated Thermoworks Thermopen finding that within the cooking range (120F - 185F) the ThermoPro TP-11 read from 4 to 6 degrees F low. So, if yours is like the sample sent me by the manufacturer, you'll end up overcooking your food if you believe the readings on the TP-11.Note: No probe can tolerate having its cable crushed by a grill lid. To assure a long life, lead the probe wire out a hole in your cover or if there is no hole, then prop the grill cover up with a small rock. One slam of a grill lid on a probe cable will ruin the cable.From a performance view, this is an easy five star unit. However, the calibration issue will be an issue for those who havent access to a known good thermometer which works within the food range and will result in meals which are over or undercooked.
This is just a fairy tale unrelated to the Noah story as I understand it. I spent the time watching either confused or annoyed.

This is a review in two parts. The first is about the edition CEB Deep Blue Kids' Bible and the second about this translation.Part 1The CEB Deep Blue Kid's Bible is a superb effort at making scripture easily accessible. I've rarely seen the like of it. There are summaries of all the books and the actual textual matter is laced with various callouts expanding one's knowledge of text. I found many of these callouts to be quite thought provoking. In addition, there are many notes and reference materials to clarify the text. I particularly enjoyed learning from the glossary and the section dealing with biblical weights, measurements and money.For example, one callout dealt with the two stories of creation which mystifies many. The callout suggests that these two exist because two different authors also existed and each had a different take on what happened so now you have two ways to look at the biblical account of creation. Neat.My only gripe about this production relates to the goofy cartoon children which frolic through the pages. These look like Pixar kids and add nothing to the book's value. Worse, they subtract from it.This bible is suitable for all ages but is labeled as being for ages 8 - 12. Drop the silly cartoons which would embarrass an adult and you have a book which will bring scripture to all.Part 2The CEB (Common English Bible) put my teeth on edge at least once per page.  I have no quibble with the accuracy of the translation but the grammar and word usage chosen are terrible to my way of thinking. This translation takes the bible by the neck and wrings all the nobility and majesty from it. Let me give you a few examples:Genesis:KJV: Now the serpent was more subtil than any beast of the field which the Lord God had made.CEB: The snake was the most intelligent of all the wild animals that the Lord God had made.Esther:KJV:  Likewise shall the ladies of Persia and Media say this day unto all the king's princes, which have heard of the deed of the queen. Thus shall there arise too much contempt and wrath.CEB: This very day, the important women of Persia and Media who hear about the queen will tell the royal officials the same thing. There will be no end of put-downs and arguments. (put-downs?)PsalmsKJV: The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want.CEB: The Lord is my shepherd. I lack nothing.Sure, the Elizabethan usage in  KJV is difficult for us today but it's not Chaucer either.  It takes some effort but it pays off in reading soaring, majestic wonderful English rather than flat declarative boring phrases.In sum, the work and added material in this bible are superb making it suitable and highly desirable for not only 8 to 12, but 8 to any age. However, I am a bit of a traditionalist and cannot abide the butchering (as I see it) of the bible by sinking to the lowest level vulgate in this translation.I enjoyed my time so far with the added material here and learned a good deal too. I plan on spending a good deal more time with the book too. There is a good deal of superb material. Five stars plus for the added material and production values. For me, though, I can't award the entire work five stars because of the flat, boring almost nasty (to my narrow way of thinking) translation. Your milage may vary.

Dennis Lims book on David Lynch has an achievement of sorts: by the time I was done reading it, Id had all I wanted to be fed about Lynch, his life and is work. Some may call Lynch an opportunistic artiste while others the product of a degenerate society who himself is a vanguard of that degeneracy. Either or neither may be correct in whole but both are surely correct in parts.To be fair to Lynch, he was born into a society and exists in same that would reject a painting called Thanksgiving Dinner at the Jones but celebrate a painting called Tommy Jones Stabbed in the Eye by His Mom at Thanksgiving Dinner.  So his disgusting images, as described all too well by Lim, in his initial film Eraserhead and elsewhere, are easy to explain existing. After all, his first artistic recognition was a multimedia presentation called Six Men Getting Sick and that seems to have set the tone of Lynchs future media work. Six Men is available for viewing on YouTube.I am not familiar with Lynchs work and got this book to learn about Lynch as someone Id heard of but didnt know.  I also viewed a few episodes of Twin Peaks which may be Lynchs most well-known work and one now back in production for showing about a year from this writing.  Based on this limited exposure, Id say that Lim has chosen to emphasize the repulsive aspects of Lynchs work and gloss over other aspects.For example, Twin Peaks is soaked in teen angst as well as high school politics. These are common tropes which arent covered or even mentioned in the book. In addition, there is a good deal of plain old scenic videography like a travelogue. So I make a bit of a leap here and wonder if non-revolting aspects of other Lynch works are likewise left out.Still, the final test of a critical analysis / biography such as Lims book is if, at the end, you are left wanting more. I wasnt and thats good.

This is an ideal six outlet charger for most USB devices. The manufacturer's sample received here is exceptionally well made. It has a remarkably solid and heavy feel to it. While such a feel doesn't necessarily mean superior function, I prefer using devices that give the sense they were carved from a billet - even if that's not the case. Aesthetics count at least some, but function is foremost.Function with the Foxnovo is near ideal. Each port is capable of 2.4 A or the full 12 watts but being 'smart' these ports throttle down in the case of devices which can't tolerate such amperage. We decided to test the charger by loading it up completely with six devices which were a mix of iPhone, iPad, Kindle, Samsung G5 and two Bluetooth headsets. All were charged well and with no sign of any overcharging.A few people who have Samsung devices, such as the G6, which can be fast charged using a special Samsung protocol may find a a lack in this charger because it lacks such a port. For those folks, the Foxnovo will work well but not as fast as one having this service. For the vast majority of people who have common USB charged devices, the Foxnovo is perfect, well made and should give years of service.

The Bestten 3-outlet Power Strip with three USB outlets received here as a manufacturer's sample functioned in all ways exactly as expected. The three 120 V outlets are, as the USB ports, switched. There are two 5 watt USB ports and one 2.4 12 watt port. The unit appears well made in all respects.No claims are made for suitability with Apple products so as a test we tried them here using an iPad G3 and iPad G5, an iPhone 6 and an iPhone 6+ all of which were charged without incident. In addition, we charged up a Samsung G5 phone and several Bluetooth headsets. Through all these tests, the Bestten functioned perfectly.Things would be perfect if all ports were 12 watt capable since the charger is 'smart' meaning it senses the attached device's ability to accept a charge. As things stand, the Bestten can only rapidly charge a single device, such as an iPad or a Galaxy, which can accept the full 2.5 A or 12 watts. A tablet takes a good long while to charge at 1 A or 5 watts.Still, it's quite convenient to have USB charging in the same device as one which turns one outlet into three. Overall, a nice device.

Others likely will find this book more interesting or exciting or both. I didn't particularly enjoy it despite the fast pace due to several things. To start, it reads not as a standalone novel but a continuing chapter in a series. The author takes some trouble to explain that this or that person has had this or that conflict with another so they are still angry but that's no substitute for having read the previous (???) volumes.There is a great deal of danger but no tension at all. There is no doubt the stars will survive because they are part of a continuing story. So it was just "let's get on with it watching you croak all the bad guys and be the heroes once more" rather than wonder how it'll come out.There are some continuity issues. For example, at one point a character is hoping to be rescued by a spaceship she's current flying around on. Our adventurers take hours to reach a particular place but return in minutes. Two characters are caught in an almost fatal avalanche but then get up, dust  themselves off and without food or sleep, go into a few battles prevailing all the way.The tedious tropes are abounding. We have the captain who is, of course, a rogue. We have a crew who are all misfits but with amazing talents. They have a ship which is faster, more armored and more armed than anything anybody else has. We of course, have the pretty female who is so strong and great fighter than no man can stand up to her.Well paced simplistic shoot 'em up with little thinking demanded. If that's what you're seeking, you've found it.

To say that the Panasonic ER-GB60-K is a good trimmer is to put it mildly. It's terrifically adaptable for use on body, beard and head - at least male heads for the most part. The unique, to my knowing, aspect of this shaver is that it uses only two combs with a height adjuster from 1 to 20 to adjust the amount of hair left from .5 mm or 1/64" to 20 mm or just short of an inch. This means, if you wish to have a beard in the latest fashion of looking like slight fuzz, the Panasonic will so that easily. The adjustability is in .5 mm or 1/64" increments meaning this is the most precise trimmer / shaver I've ever encountered.  By far.Similarly, if you want to leave longer hair, almost up to an inch, this will accommodate you. Interestingly, in this age of specialization, the trimmer isn't contraindicated for anywhere on the body from bikini to face. So this will work well as a whole body trimmer but keep in mind that this isn't a shaver. The minimum hair left is .5 mm or 1/16th of an inch which may, to some, seem the same as a close shave but it's not. That much hair left on the face will be noticeable.The dry only handle is lightweight and remarkably comfortable due to its tapered in the middle shape. As an additional benefit, the manual has a little tutorial on barbering so the do it yourself audience which is the target market is better assured of getting a good result. The tutorial is long on facial hair but also includes how to give you a uniform head hair buzz cut or trim for a conventional haircut. My wife has been trimming the back of my neck for years now. We learned, to our surprise, she was doing it wrong. Trying the way in the Panasonic manual resulted in much better results in shorter time as well.I can't find a thing wrong or lacking in this trimmer and also can't think of anyway it can be improved. It's a really nice unit.

The list of warnings about the use of the device and the contraindications of application are truly daunting. I wont attempt a comprehensive listing of all the warnings but besides not using if you have a suntan, the instructions warn against using if you menstruating, have any moles, warts, bruises or other injuries to the target areas, are diabetic or have a rash. Theres a good deal more too.In addition, the device as an epilator is contraindicated for use where many would like to use it such as the underarms, thighs, torso or face. The only areas suggested for use of the epilator head are the legs from the knees to the ankles and the arms from the elbows to the wrists except the softer posterior areas of the lower arm. Specific areas of forbidden use are the backs of knees, crooks of the arms, underarm and any area where your skin is less than perfectly tight which would eliminate older folks entirely as well as anybody whos recently lost weight.Areas such as the back or abdomen where men may wish to remove hair arent part of the suggested use areas. Same goes for the face where some women may wish to epilate. This leaves the epilating head as quite limited in utility. Many women wish to epilate their legs but is it common to do the same to your forearms? Id think it one of those rather rarely desired cosmetics, but maybe Im wrong.Taking my life in my own hands, I used the epilator head on tanned skin. The device did work well leaving itself covered in full length hair it had removed from the tried areas. It wasnt painful to use but not pleasant either. Afterwards I felt as if I had moderate sunburn for maybe 15 minutes and then it subsided. So the discomfort from use of this device in epilator mode was quite small. Overall the impression is closer to a bad razor burn which quickly goes away than anything else.The shaver head is useful in a variety of places the epilator isnt. It works as expected in all regards. This is the head you need to use in your bikini areas because the epilator is specifically forbidden to be used here. I would not try it either.In sum, this does work but the limited scope of recommended places the epilator can be used makes almost pointless. For most women, the only use will be the lower legs  assuming it can be used at all. Given this limited scope of application, my guess would be most would be better off with a conventional personal groomer many of which are made by Panasonic.

Productivity Software is an amalgam of crowd sourced recommendations taken from his Web site, Zen Market, of what the crowd thinks is the best app or Web site or other resource for a huge variety of needs. The idea that there are bests in all categories for everybody is ludicrous but the recommendations are still highly useful. In fact, the book is useful in a reverse manner from what its intended to do.The intention is, say, you want to find the best travel aggregators so you look up and find the two recommended (Kayak and Google Fights). However, if you dont know that aggregators exist, stumbling across this entry in the book may end up saving you major money on your next trip or finding a better flight or many other good things.I can quibble over some of the recommendations. One of my real gripes is the popularity of reddit and Yelp. Both are recommended, but at least the reddit misery is balanced by a Quora entry which is where you can really get your question answered civilly and intelligently. Yelp has been so corrupted by fake reviews that in many cases, its useless but that entry isnt balanced by the tightly moderated Tripadvisor where the ability to fake reviews is much reduced compared to Yelp.The lesson is that the books entries may have themselves been skewed by the same forces which have ruined some of the value of Yelp or reddit. Still, the book must have value for everybody or almost everybody. For example, did you know there is a home delivery service for dope? No, I didnt either and while Im not interested in the product, I was quite interested that its available for home delivery.Besides the recommendations, you get quotes from Jeff Bezos as well as a bit of a narrative at each section by the author.  Like the recommendations themselves, the book is a good resource and a thought provoker.

The Searcher is a ghost story, wrapped around a thriller and all encased in a fantasy. It involves, chiefly, a mysterious stranger who shows up apparently on a mission which cant be accomplished due to the apparent beneficiary being dead. The stranger is odd in appearance and has incredible powers and information he pulls out when needed but not hinted at before.The action involves a town with a foggy past, its founder, current town fathers and a whole raft of remarkably nasty drug lords who have amazing powers as well. In the case of the drug lords, the powers arent celestial but are at least as incredible as the mysterious strangers other earthly powers.The whole ride is enjoyable if more than a bit cruel. There is no questioning the writing skill of the author  its a pleasure to read. He, however, doesnt play fair in some ways. Any time we have a fantasy sort of book, or a sci fi or other books where current rules are suspended, we the readers are due knowing what the limits and bounds or the new rules are. If not, we get unsatisfactory scenes such as a central character who, when in peril, flies away like Superman. Fair only if we know he can fly before the peril descends.The narrative is exquisitely detailed. The action takes place within a day and fills the 500 pages easily. Again, here, the author doesnt play fair. We get pages of detail about how this or that character spends his or her time only for us to learn, when things get tight, that the one major detail which is critical about this time has been left out and that the detail offered is all meaningless static.Still, despite these issues, there is no denying that the major elements of a good novel exist here. The characters are well drawn, even if we dont get a good idea what the mysterious stranger is although there is some clarification in an epilogue.  Anybody who isnt a psychopath will hate the bad guys, although one is mysteriously given a pass at the end, and also wish the good guys well. Again, who is good and bad tend to shift around a bit and when all the chips fall, many are, at best, ambiguous.The Searcher is clearly a well done genre busting novel. I only wish itd have played a bit fairer with the reader.

This is, with one limitation, a perfect solution to the need to create a Y for garden sorts of hoses. The manufacturer's sample received here is well made. The valves needed to be 'unstuck' with  a bit of effort initially but after the first move, work smoothly and easily. They seal completely. The fit and finish is ideal throughout.The only issue which may not be for many, is that the outlet side has only a 1 cm diameter (approximately) or .4" The inlet side is a full 2 cm (approximately) meaning it'll flow without restriction the common 5/8" or 3/4" garden hose. However, if you close one side of the Y you cut down the effective size of the fluid path to half of the diameter of the hose.So if you have both sides of the Y flowing, there is no or negligible loss of total flow but if you were to close one side, the resulting flow would be less than if there were no Y fitting in the fluid path. The upshot is that this design is perfect if both sides of the Y are open but not ideal if only one side were open.If you need a Y and the single sided bore constriction isn't a major factor for you, then this is an ideal solution to that need.

The manufacturer's sample received here is beautifully made. The stock is very heavy and the finish polished to a thick lustrous shine. The handles are cover with a thick silicone making them comfortable and easy to grip.However, the silicone coating is also an issue. The two concave sections of the juicer don't come completely together but are held apart by this coating when you have the juicer fully closed. This means there is juice left in the fruit after the juicer is as compressed at it can be made to close.Both my wife and I had no problems taking a fully mashed lemon from the juicer and, using our fingers, get a good deal more juice from the fruit. This issue could have been easily resolved by making the top concave section just a few mm deeper.Still, even with this issue, this juicer would be of great utility to older people or those with arthritis or other issues causing a grip limitations. For those with a normal grip, a finger squeeze may not be as neat, but it will mean more juice.

The manufacture's sample received here was a bit of a surprise. Unlike most bud type ear phones, these feel like they're carved from billet steel giving them a high quality sense when held or used. The bass is significantly superior to competing products I've used. My wife, a musician, agrees. The noise cancellation is reasonably effective but clearly cannot match a quality over the ear headphone. Still, some is better than none.They come in a nice case. The cord is very flexible making them both comfortable in use and also this means the cord puts less stress on the buds which lessens the tendency of them to pull out of the ear.So far all's to the good but there are some aspects which are, if not bad, at least areas of possible improvement.The buds are marked 'Right' and 'Left' in a small non-contrasting italic font which is difficult to see in lower light or by those who have less then prefect close vision. This could be reduced by using a large 'R' and 'L' instead of the whole word. The issue could be eliminated by color coding the buds or using a one/two bump to identify right and left by feel.Also these lack the over the ear hooks of buds marketed for athletic pursuits. While these do retain well for normal buds they would be retained that much better and in more situations by the addition of these inexpensive over the ear hooks. I remain utterly baffled by ear buds lacking those retaining hooks. Seems like a no brainer to have them in all such products.Still for what they are, they are great. After all, sound and convenience is what ear buds are all about here and the Audiosharp AS1217's are superior in both areas.

The SanDisk Extreme SDXC seems to be no more or less than advertised. When placed in a camera, nothing I could do would overload it taking either stills or video.  I didnt have any 4k equipment to test. Video was HD or 1080.There was only one maybe glitch. Im not counting it against the card because I cant tell where the fault lay. The card read and wrote fine in two card readers. One was a Mac and one a PC on a USB 3 port. However, one card reader which attaches directly to the mainboard in the PC, couldnt write to the card. It claimed the card was write protected no matter which way I moved the switch. This reader did read form the card all right.I include that incident for what its worth if anything to you.Keep in mind that this is a full size SD card and not a micro in a carrier. As such, it wont work in some devices.  Overall, its a very fast card no more and no less.

These are ties with an option Ive never seen before. The manufacturers samples received here have releases which make them reusable. The reuse trigger is a swiveling pawl which engages ratcheting teeth. Other than the swivel, this mechanism is identical to other ties.However, unique in my experience to these ties, an easy flick of the pawl swivels it out of engagement releasing the tie for reuse. Being nylon, these ties would work for dozens of reuses too. Now most folks, after using a tie, snip it to remove the long tail left after snugging. Needless to say, if you snip, you also make the tie a good deal less suited for reuse. Then again, the release can still be useful because it means you can remove the tie instantly without tools  a major advantage over ties demanding a tool for removal.I cant see how this release would undo the tie by accident either. Still, Id not use them in critical environments such as aircraft or marine where a released tie may cause mayhem. I saw no way to safe the release.These ties are definitely an improvement over common ties for most applications and a major improvement if you want to use these for a temporary hold.

These washcloths are exactly as advertised in all respects. They are astonishingly soft but also just as absorbent as any other terry sort of cloth.At first blush, it seems almost magic that a woody grass can be made into something this soft. The secret is modern chemistry where the fibers of the bamboo are made to yield rayon which is then woven into this cloth. Yes, rayon, which sounds as if itd be made from oil is really a plant product and has always been just that.For those concerned with green issues, of course bamboo is less an environmental load than growing, say, cotton. However, there are downstream issues of processing. Bamboo can be processed into rayon using either open or closed systems which have differing impacts. The manufacturers sample received here didnt discuss which of these broad category processes these washcloths use.These would be by far the best washcloths to use for babies due to them being so soft. If you prefer a rougher cloth for washing, then these work less well. Two adults slightly disagreed on these. One prefers the softness and one would prefer a bit of a loofa feel to washcloths.If you have a baby or care for one, run; dont walk, to get a set of these. If you are an adult, its your call if you want a silky smooth soft feel to you bathing or if you prefer the rough stuff.

This was, for me, a remarkably enjoyable book. Here are my reasons:-The good guys are immediately and consistently likable. There is no hesitation in wishing them well.-The bad guys or who may be the bad guys are more that one faction and we're not sure even up to the end of the book if they are bad guys, good guys or neutral. In the end, the bad guy is revealed but my guess is that some readers will feel the so called bad guy had a few good points and maybe wasn't so bad after all.-The pacing is consistent neither going into frantic chase mode or long sags of explanation.-The science is great. The author, in a long end note, explains what elements of the science are real, what aren't and what may be.-And best of all, all people behave intelligently throughout. There are no stupid moves which are inserted to get the author out of a tight spot. Both the good and bad / maybe bad guys act thoughtfully throughout. Sometimes the bad guys win but sometimes the good guys win too. The book is fantastic but felt like real life-The book's thoughtfulness on time travel blows every other time travel book out of the water. The author has thought of issues I've never seen before and I have to conclude he's got the right of it. What good would being able to travel a tiny split second back into the past do you? Well, it'd have more impact than the invention of fire to us. No, I won't do a spoiler.-The ex Ranger hero isn't a superman who can enter a room full of angry tigers, wrestle then and prevail even after 72 hours of no sleep or food. Instead he's a human.Terrifically plotted, well paced and thoughtful. Not much to ask for more.

Im going to admit to a great reviewer sin: I didnt finish this book. Let me explain why and why I have two starred it as well. I stuck it out for well over 100 pages, but lifes too short.The apparent protagonist (one isnt sure) has a major unexplained history with many other characters and at least one shadowy institution. However, none is explained which lead me to enormous frustration wondering what hes doing / thinking and why because going by the information given, hes acting insanely. Its as if this isnt a novel but instead part two or for all I know, part fifty two of a story where I came in toward the middle or maybe the end but surely not the beginning.Other people too behave in unrealistic manners. The opening scene is not only bizarre, but utterly incomprehensible and makes no sense internally even accepting the little information were given within that scene. Later in the book, the probable protagonist, a policeman I think, is given tens of thousands of files to digitize via a scanner.  For no given reason, he opens one file, gets obsessed with it and abandons his work as a digitizer and instead starts chasing his tail all over the LA basin trying to solve this cold case.What may be an interesting area of the book is fatally damaged by again making no sense. It concerns a family of Jewish Czechs who have immigrated into the US. No time frame is given other than it must be post WWII because there is talk of the camps. So this family, lost in the temporal drift of a poorly constructed novel, bicker over nothing comprehensible. The chief dispute is over the 17 year old daughter (17 years 11 months, were told) wishing to take a pottery class but wants to keep it a secret not only from her parents, but from her friend who covers for her.I heard of secrecy but being secretive even from your own best friend about a silly pottery class? Yes, she then meets up with some traditional Jews who teach her some ceremonies her parents either never did or abandoned but the secrecy was due to clay initially. If she wont discuss a pottery class, what will she discuss?The writing style is inconsistent. One voice uses the enormously annoying present tense for past actions  a recent unfortunate trend. So we get sentences like (not in the book but made up by me to give you an idea): Long ago, Bobby walks into the room. He sees Ethel. He knows immediately that Ethel is. The other voice uses the predicate for past actions and its like a breath of fresh air, really. Then we get back to the muddled tense voice.OK, I repeat here: nothing makes any sense likely because the roots of events are in the previous volumes or something. So we seem to have what may be a major player who is a ghost or a something able to fly around, observe events, have an effect on events and even materialize into a human form to seduce males. Is this the golem? Is this a succubus? A ghost? An imaginary being? I have no idea nor do I have any idea if this being has any limits or if its omniscient and omnipotent. There are hints that this whatever and what I take to be the digitizing policeman have had a major relationship in the past but gee, who can be sure what happened in volume 34 of this set?I confess to being a simple minded reader. I dont wish to go hundreds of pages holding unrelated players and events in my head hoping that by page 450 the authors will pull it all together for me. Even at 17 I knew my life was too short to waste it reading the assigned Ulysses so I requested an alternate. When asked by my teacher why I didnt want to read it, I said I had no patience for pretentious garbage masquerading as literature. He laughed and assigned me an alternative.Ill grant this isnt pretentious, but its not for me. My life was too short to waste wading through nonsense at 17 and my life left to live is even less today. So for these reasons, and many others I wont go into because by now I've either made my point with you or I can't, I am out.Paul looks around his office and decides hell put a 30 at the end of the review hes writing.30.

The Ammex nitrile glove reviewed here fits a bit small. I usually take an X-L or an XX-L and while these did fit, they didnt slide on but were quite tight but not uncomfortable. I use gloves for doing work on the cars and bikes where the task, such as removing and replacing a drive chain on a bike (motorcycle) can leave very difficult to remove oily dirt on ones hands.Previously I used latex gloves I got from a medical supply source. Those latex ones are not surgery gloves by any means but more for examining or doing lite biohazard work such as bedpan duty. The problem I had with these are that they tended to rip very easily putting me in the awkward situation of having to either stop work and re-glove or live with the knowing that I was getting greasy hands.I hoped the nitrile gloves would be more robust or in other words, less prone to ripping while still being easy on and off. I wasnt disappointed. I did a major cleaning and lubrication of two motorcycle drive chains while wearing a set of the Ammex gloves.  Neither glove ripped. The gloves are thin enough that they dont hinder fine motor skills as well.To my surprise, they came off easily too without me needing to turn them inside out as I always have to with the latex gloves. This gave me an idea. I put them back on and used a heavy duty mechanics hand cleaner to wash the gloves just as if I was washing my hands. They came clean easier than real hands would due to their smooth surface. I took them off, dried them and now theyre ready for re-use. Beats me how many uses theyll take but so far so good.Clearly a step up from the conventional latex gloves. Im sold. They work just as advertised with no surprises good or bad.

By far the most useful part of the Etekcity Square One is the tape but the other parts are useful too. This puts this device solidly in the why not category.  By that I mean if youre going to get a measuring tape, why spend money on just a tape when you can get a multitool for about the same cost. To top it off, the tape part is superior to most tapes.By superior, the tape is in inches and centimeters. The manufacturers sample provided me has a feature Ive never seen before in any tape although others must have it. The inch side of the tape has more than hash marks between the marked inches. It also has fractions in eighths marked at the appropriate hash mark. This means when youre looking at measurement between the whole inches, you can see in a flash the eighths rather than count up or down from the half or whole measures to see if the exact measure easily.OK, I never had any significant issues seeing the exact measurement but this does make that task just that much easier and less prone to error. Now that I see Etekcity has it, I have to wonder why the other half dozen tapes we have accumulated around here dont.The other tools will have varying utility. For us, the straight edge and pencil holder and  sharpener have good utility while the protractor is something we cant figure how wed use. Still, no harm having it along for the ride. The belt clip holds the device well. In use, its no more obtrusive when clipped to the belt than a standard measuring tape.To me, this is clearly the way to go if you are in the market for a tape or wish to give one for a gift. Its a better than usual tape included in a multitool and all for the price of a typical tape alone.

That there is demand for a product such as the Mobiilink Quick Charger six port charger says a good deal about our society. That the two of us can almost fill two of these Mobiilink Chargers with devices says quite a bit about us.However, that's a different discussion. As it turns out, we do have more devices than outlets or at least outlets in convenient places to act as charging stations. The Mobiilink charger is a compact 60 watt device meaning it can devote a full 10 watts per USB port which is whats needed to charge up the larger devices such as tablets. It also means it can charge small devices such as phones that much quicker.We loaded up the sample supplied by the manufacturer with a variety of mostly discharged devices including two iPads (G3 and G5) an iPhone 6, an iPhone 6+, a Bluetooth headset and a Samsung Galaxy 5 as a stress test. We do not have a device meeting the Qualcomm fast charge standard to test. The Mobiilink had no issues charging all the devices up and we felt the charge time was the same as if we had we each device on its own dedicated 10 watt solo charger.The plug which goes into the 120 v outlet is a standard plug rather than having a lump at its outlet end so it take up a minimum real estate at that end.Overall, I can report the operation perfect and the design thoughtful and well-functioning. Its decreased the amount of clutter we had around the outlets formerly dedicated to an ad hoc charging station. All the combinations of devices and charge / data cables worked perfectly. We could not induce any errors or issues of any sort and we tried.Little devices such as this are hardly mandatory for life, but they also decrease the little annoyances we each face every day and as such, the Mobiilink has earned a valued  place in our household.

There aren't many advantages to glass cooking or storage over other materials, but those few advantages may be so important to some that the disadvantages aren't important.The main advantage is that glass is utterly non-reactive. It seems that daily we're bombarded with statements a typical citizen can't evaluate about the dangers of this or that metal or this or that plastic. This plastic causes cancer. That metal makes you senile. It goes on and on. Few materials, if more than one, are never accused of these sorts of issues that one always good material is glass.Also to some, glass looks good. It does too until you let it get a bit grungy and then it looks, well, less than good.The downsides of glass exist too. It's heavy. It can break although the Pyrex brand tempered glass is surprisingly strong, it isn't nearly as strong as, say, steel. It doesn't conduct heat well. It can't be used on the stove top either. So you need to decide for yourself if the advantages outweigh the obvious disadvantages.This set is well made with covers that fit securely. The glass is dishwasher safe while the covers are top shelf dishwasher only. The set is advertised for cooking, microwaving and storage but the blub does say the glass is preheated oven save rather than the glass with a cover. The covers are microwave ok (tried extensively here) but do not have valves to release expanding gasses as the nuke process marches on. This is an issue for `waving, in my view. If you plan on regularly using these to microwave food, I suggest you choose the set with the valves in the cover.  We leave a bit of the cover cracked which so far has worked ok.If you're looking for a glass set of cooking and or storage containers, this is definitely one to consider. We've cooked, `waved and stored many things using this set and found no issues other than the lack of a release valve in the covers for microwaving. Works as expected with nothing surprising either good or bad.

`Saving Sophie' is an instantly engrossing novel involving many factions. Some are the unambiguous good guys, some the clearly bad guys but many who are either in between or who will change your mind as the story unfolds and we get to see that what appears like one thing at first blush really isn't that but something else.The pacing is, for the most part, brisk. There is a good deal going on which means a fairly long novel, but there's no filler. All the events either move the plot forward, get us to know the players a bit more or, to an unusual extent, give up background history on about the Israel / Palestine area and dispute. Those who are in the camp that all Muslims are evil and should be exterminated will be annoyed to find many who are just trying to live their lives in peace and prosperity.  Not to despair  - there's some major Arab baddies in there too.A good deal of the plot is clever. I especially enjoyed how one set of criminals use the police to accomplish the criminal's ends. The other side is that much of what must occur stretched my credulity to the breaking point. There are several sets of bad guys and one of the questions is if they are linked and if so how and why. One set seems to behave like the Three Stooges one time and beyond Godfather clever the next. This inconsistency bothered me a bit.Also at one point, two people just sort of run into each other in a major eye roller of coincidence and then there are the international three letter agencies relying on a bunch of civilians to pull off a major operation in an area the civilians have no familiarity with. Finally, a man is gravely injured so much that the docs want to keep him sedated for another week, but he's awakened, takes a bruising long trip and then, when needed, he sprints into physical action. It's just silly, really.Still, an exciting well-paced story where you'll want the good guys to win (well, unless you are a sociopath), the bad guys to lose and the loose ends all tied up. You won't be disappointed.

We'd never tried an LED bulb before for household use so when offered a manufacturer's sample, I eagerly accepted.The Madking A19 has a conventional base and doesn't seem to demand any special handling or treatment in any way. Screw it in and turn it on just like any old Edison. In use, the light is quite warm. I estimate it as being 3,200k which puts it toward the romantic side of the spectrum. People look great in this temperature lighting. It's not ideal for reading but not bad either.Put in the old watt output standard, I'd guess the output is just a bit less than what you'd expect from a 60 watt bulb. In other words, it's ideal for most household and business uses. Of course, the huge advantage of this is you get almost 60 watts of light for 1/10 the cost in electricity. Also the LED nature of this bulb promises long life.In the recent past, these LED bulbs were so expensive that even long life and less electricity usage couldn't justify their cost but that's not the case with the newer generation LED's such as the Madking A19. Also unlike the other economical bulb, the florescent, there is no issue of hazardous gas inside.We're sold on these and will be replacing our conventional filament and florescent bulbs with Madkings as those burn out.

This product went from high expectations while in the box to a  bit of disappointment in use.The good parts:1. The HA100 looks good. It's quite small - roughly 2 1/2" x 2 1/4" across and only maybe 3/4" thick. The fit and finish are excellent showing a combination of the shiny high tech black common and a nice brushed finish for the top.2. Operation is flawless. It showed up on several tested iPhones and iPads and paired quickly and easily. There was no issue getting a good signal to several output devices using both the 3.5 mm and RCA plugs (both supplied).The not so good parts:1. It has no internal battery. The factory supplied way to power it is to use the supplied 120 v power cord so you're tied to needing a outlet to use the HA100.2. The power cord has, at its plug end, one of those incredibly annoying huge transformers which hog up a great deal of space at the outlet or power strip. This hog of a transformer is oriented ideally for a power strip and is thinner than others. Still, I'm sick and tired of this trend of having a huge block at the plug end of a power cord. I have some power strips where I lose half the outlets due to these transformers blocking more than their share of real estate. In this case, the HA100's transformer isn't a worse case than others but it's still something I want to never have to contend with again.
