Having IMDB on my Fire providing scene trivia as I watch on the TV is so cool.This is the complaints section. My major complaint is how Amazon continues to ignore Google's existence. I want the real You Tube, not a third-party workaround. I also have Chromecast. It would be nice if Fire offered similar projection functionality. I really wish either device, preferably Chromecast, would allow me to listen to Audible via my TV.

This is my first Breville appliance and I am in love. Rarely do I write reviews so quickly after purchase, but this product inspires evangelism. I drink a lot of tea every day; it has replaced coffee. My microwave is broken and my stovetop tea kettle started dribbling. It was time for a change.This appliance is everything Breville promises and positive reviews have confirmed. It is truly amazing. If you are into tea, you'll be into this. I drink flavored tea -- white, green, oolong, black, rooibos and herbal. I'm thankful for the simplification this tea maker provides. I'll be perfectly honest and admit that I frequently used the microwave for single cups of tea. I'd memorized how long to heat the water for each type of tea. The stovetop tea kettle had me cutting back on my tea consumption! It took too long to boil the water and the trial and error on the temperature got real tiring real fast.I'm so loving this appliance! So far, I'm all about the custom setting. Teavana's Earl Grey Black and Adagio's Earl Grey Bravo require either a different temp or steeping time than the pre-setting for black tea. It's easy as pie to adjust the settings and steeping time.  These two teas have come out perfectly. I expect the rest of my collection will fare the same.2/16/15 update -- made a perfect cup of oolong. if I leave the basket in place, it also helps me to remember that I can steep my oolong more than once.Here are my gripes, major and minor.  I am a 'dishwasher-safe' kinda girl and it pains me the carafe is not dishwasher safe. You can't even clean it under running water. How inconvenient is that? My minor gripe is the water markings. Would it have killed them to use ounces too? Breville knew this product would be sold in the U.S. All metric markings is just inconsiderate.2/21/15 UpdateI know it was probably done for safety reasons, but having to remember to hit the keep warm button every time I replaced the carafe wasn't easy for me. However, after a week of use. I've decided that I don't like the keep warm function at all. I don't know if it's the heat or oxidation, but subsequent cups don't taste the same as the first. This is obviously more pronounced further from the brewing cycle. Now when I brew a pot, I pour my first cup and put the rest into a thermos (if it's going to be a long time between cups.)You will need the Revive cleaner Breville makes. I used it after a week and it really worked well. I couldn't take the staining any longer. I think I read that the staining makes the tea taste better. I guess I'll miss out on that benefit because I prefer the new and shiny look.Would I recommend this? Absolutely, but only for a real tea enthusiast or aficionado (I claim enthusiast.) It's too pricey for the casual drinker.

I received this product free for review. It replaced my Simple Human Sensor Pump. I love that this touchless dispenser has feet that keep the base from resting directly on the countertop. In comparison to the Simple Human model, the controls here are less intuitive. Adjusting the amount of soap it dispenses requires a little more effort than I'd like. Also, I feel like this unit has to be primed a bit more to get a smooth flow. However, with all of that said, this is a great value at $20 (if it holds up over time).

I'll admit I use this for more than nonstick cookware. It works fine for nonstick, but I like that it gives me a head start on my stainless steel pots and pans too. Works best when you have larger surfaces to clean. I had to get some stuff out of a cupcake pan; Using this scrubber was more difficult that expected.The handle feels appropriate.  I like that the head is replaceable. What would make this five stars is if the handle was stainless. A stainless tray would be nice too.

I am a Tea Beyond Tea Ambassador, so I got this teapot for free. I had been eyeing the Juliet model for a while, but now that I have this one, I think it's more elegant. I love pink and butterflies, so this works for me in such a beautiful way.It is simply beautiful. The whimsical pink butterfly reminds me of childhood make-believe tea parties and playing dress-up -- all happy memories. It looks so delicate and pretty that I feel like I could be English royalty or at least part of the nobility.  It's my happy escape.I love that it is dishwasher safe. The strainer has slits in it which allow more for more sediment and even smaller leaves to get through. I typically use perforated or mesh retainers, so that's a new experience for me.  It's certainly not a deal-breaker.I understand why it's a smaller size for the blooming teas. I wish there was a larger version, so I could do tea for four using loose-leaf tea.

I recieved this set for free to review. The timing couldn't have been better. My increasing aches and pains were telling me I needed to restart my yoga practice. One of the things that bothered me when I was a yoga regular was slipping on the mat. I have a couple of pairs of yoga socks (the kind without space for individual toes) and they helped, but weren't a perfect solve. These socks are! Getting them on takes a little more time, but that's a small price to pay for a better yoga experience.  My only complaint is that the pinky toe seemed really long.I'd never tried yoga gloves before. These are a nice idea, but the fit wasn't snug enough for me, so they didn't work as well as the socks. They may be perfect for you.

I love this book so much, I stopped reading the hard copy and bought the Kindle version, so I could have it with me at all times. I love the refreshing approach the author takes with beauty. Basing it in a modern Christian perspective is very meaningful. The Scriptures used to set the foundation of the book were inspirational.I found the advice very helpful. The only thing that was a bit unclear was how to determine your coloring. The author included a link to her website for more information.  Perhaps one of the best things about the book is that she provides solutions that can work with any budget. This is really evident in the jeans chapter. I recommend this for women who are unsure of their personal style and beauty and those who are in transition -- like from college to the workforce.

UPDATED 8/27/14:Thank you so much to LegoGirl who pointed out there may be an issue with epilation and using the Lumea. I spoke with a really wonderful customer service rep and she said that you can epilate, but you need to wait until you see some hair growth before using the Lumea. I will edit my review accodingly and update as the weeks go by.I may change my rating and review as time goes on. Time will tell if this ultimately significantly slows my unwanted hair growth. I found the color chart for skin and hair confusing. My skin color doesn't fall into the last two categories and my hair color is black, which means I should be able to use this device. However, I am an African-American with coarse hair. I've been unable to use products like this in the past. So we'll see.For the most part, the product is easy to use. I sometimes have problems using it under my arms because of the sensor. (If your skin/hair combo is inappropriate for the device, it won't allow you to use it.) It will be working fine and then stop. I then switch to my leg, fire off one pulse and then go back to my underarm. It works fine after that.The sensation isn't the world's most pleasant. I can deal with my epilator, but level 5 on this is no joke. The most I can stand is level 4.

I am supposed to wear compression socks every day. It is not something I enjoy because compression socks, in the past, were like torture. They would roll down (and stay down) or develop a wrinkle at the ankle, which was pretty painful. These socks are an improvement. While they did not completely eliminate the swelling, they felt better on my legs than other compression socks as the day wore on. They did develop a crease at the ankle, but I was able to pull them up a bit. The top didn't immediately roll back down. I just had to pull them up a few times. With other socks, I'd have to take them off once they rolled down the first time.

I've had the cord about six months. I purchased it to go with the high-speed adapter. Cord worked great, no issue with charging. My issue is that the cord has started to fray at the usb end. Some of the apps I use don't work with Kindle's auto rotate feature. The screen has to be oriented so that the power jack is at the bottom.  If you charge frequently with the Kindle standing in this position, the cable will start to separate where it connects to the usb plug. Amazon is sending a free replacement.

This is a nice "bathroom counter lotion"  I like to apply it any time I've washed my hands. Instant softness and the effect lasts until the next hand washing.I hate the smell. You could not tell this has shea butter in it by the smell; it's perfume-y and unpleasant. As a body lotion, this doesn't cut it for me because it doesn't last all day. I've moved on to thicker creams and butters.I won't replace this bottle once it's gone.

My Type 4 hair is very dry. This is an awesome daily moisturizer. Absorbs super fast and the smell is to die for. On days when I' don't refresh my curls with water, I use it morning and night. I just pat a little in onto my hair very gently. I have to admit that because I love the way it smells so much, I add it to the mix on wet hair days too.

For those who need a hair butter, your search ends here! This works wonderfully as part of the LOC (liquid, oil, cream) method. Ultra moisturizing. My hair usually takes longer to absorb butters, but I think the whipped texture of this product gives it an edge. It is a permanent part of my arsenal for softer natural curls.

Love, love, LOVE it on my Type 4 hair. Absorbs easily. Great smell. Makes my thirsty curls softer. As part of the LOC (liquid, oil, cream) method, this is a winner.  I live in Chicago, so this is my three-season skin moisturizer. I'll use Oyin Handmade Whipped Shea Butter, Rich Almond, 8oz in the winter. Smells like chocolate. I wish there were other options.
My new "every day" styler for my wash and go. The curl definition is somewhere between Kinky-Curly Curling Custard and Design Essentials Curl Forming Custard.

I use a body oil every day. My absolute favorites are Baby Products Jonnson & johnson Baby Oil with Shea and Cocoa Butter 14 oz. Kids, Infant, Child and Neutrogena Body Oil, Light Sesame Formula, Fragrance Free, 8.5 Ounce. This product is about the same in providing moisture. It's obviously an attempt to catch onto the Moroccan Oil craze. Other than the exotic fragrance, I don't think the product is in the same league. When I looked at the back of the bottle, I didn't see much that made me believe I was getting a worthy Moroccan Oil substitute.

I wish I could really tell you if it opened bottles well or not. I can't get it to hold a charge! I charged it Monday. The indicator said I had 30 uses left. Picked it up Wednesday and it needed charging again. But, as soon as you plug it in, it says you have 30 uses remaining. If you wait a minute and use it while charging, it's does ok. Too late for you to be impressed because you're so angry because you had to wait for it to charge.  This is a piece of crap. I would give it zero stars if I could. I can't believe a good brand would make such a poor product.

I used this for the first time to make chili and I am impressed! After a stainless Crock-Pot that boiled my food and a Hamilton Beach 33967A Set 'n Forget Programmable Slow Cooker, 6-Quart that died, I was starting to wonder if  I would have to upgrade to All-Clad to get the features I wanted and a good quality slow cooker. It was love at first brown with this baby.Being able to brown in the unit was unbelievable! What a convenience. I didn't have to kill myself trying to get all of the fond off the bottom of the dish because there was no need to transfer the food for slow cooking. I have to admit that I doubted whether or not it would brown properly, so I cranked up the temperature. Wrong move! The suggested 350 degrees was absolutely perfect. Once my chili was assembled, changing the cooking function was a breeze. There were no surprises during the slow cooking.So, I can vouch wholeheartedly for the awesomeness of the browning and slow-cooking functions. Can't wait to steam something!

I've decided to do this review over time because this product makes some seven-day claims, so I think the best way for me to keep track is to log daily progress.Let me say I am a big fan of Jergens Glow Daily Moisturizer Med to Tan, 7.5 Ounce, Packaging May Vary and Nivea Sun-Kissed Beautiful Legs, for Medium to Dark Skin, 6.7 oz. I think Nivea gives you more shimmer, but I could be wrong. I'm excited to see what this product can do.I am African-American with light skin that tans easily. My skin has a yellow undertone and it is extremely dry in the winter. I feel like the testing is a bit unfair since it's freezing cold in Chicago now. Any lotion would be challenged. This brings me to my first point.Day 1This is not a deep-moisturizing lotion. You'll need backup if this is what you're trying to use it for. I could see this as a spring/summer option. I also would like to see just a hint of shimmer. I didn't see any, so I'm wondering about the "illuminating" claim.Day 2This product provides the slightest shimmer, almost imperceptible. Definitely not a winter lotion. My skin is dry hours later.Day 3I tried something new. Usually, I apply lotion after showering. Today, I applied this later in the day. It feels like any regular lotion on my skin.Day 4Meh. I'm ready to move on.Day 5When is day 7??! This stuff is okay for my arms which are less dry than my legs. I still can't see proof of the other benefits.Day 6This stuff moisturizes the best when I don't have to leave the house and face the cold, but it's still not worth me trading of my regular stuff.Day 7Thank goodness it's over! I would not buy this. I just didnt see any real benefits. Even for spring and summer, I'd rather use Glow Daily or the Nivea product.

I received this scale free for review. I also have the OXO Food Scale, so this is more of a comparative review. I am an avid baker, so my scale gets a a lot of use. I'll start with the positives. This scale is gorgeous. It looks so clean and elegant on my counter. The display lights up with each use, so everything is sharp and easy to read. This is different from the OXO scale; on it, you have to press a button for the backlit display.This scale is very sleek and compact. Here is where things go from great to okay. If you use a really large bowl, it obscures the display. (The OXO display unit pulls out for this purpose.) This doesn't work for the heavy baking I do. For imperial measurements, the display uses decimals; I'm used to fractions. My last gripe is the special batteries it takes (minor in the overall scheme of things but important to me). What happened to good old AAA?With that said, I don't think this is a bad product; it just doesn't work for all of my needs.  This would be an awesome scale for portion control.

I'll start with the positives first. I love the style of this book. In a post YouTube, Craftsy world, I believe things have shifted in terms of how people like information presented to them. This book does a wonderful job of explaining the techniques in an easily-digestible fashion. The photography is excellent. You need to know how to make a bound buttonhole? This is the book for you.Here's why I give it only three stars: if I counted correctly, there are only eight techniques covered in the main section of the book (the part with the good photos). There are more in the appendix, but you get illustrations instead of photos. If I were making my first tailored jacket or pants, I'm not sure there's enough in this book to get me through it. For instance, there's nothing about linings.What I would love is a hybrid of this book and Couture Sewing Techniques, Revised and Updated. This book has depth, but lacks breadth. Couture Sewing Techniques has breadth, but I think it needs more depth via step-by-step pictures. Conversely, Couture Sewing: The Couture Cardigan Jacket, Sewing secrets from a Chanel Collector is perfect, because it has the right amount of depth for a single project. Maybe this book would have been better if it were two books -- one dedicated to jackets and one to pants.

I've had this book for three years. Now, I think I can write an informed review. As the title may imply, this is not a book for the novice, which is why I struggled with reviewing earlier -- I just couldn't understand it. While my skills may not have improved much in three years, my sewing knowledge has and that's what this book requires.Others have spoken to this edition versus the previous ones. I can speak to, as someone relatively new to sewing, how this book compares to other couture sewing books. This book is a must-have reference. It covers a lot within its 12 chapters. I do take issue with how things are covered. The book gives very clear step by step instructions, but the illustrations are a bit lacking. I like the updated approach taken in Shaeffer's newer books, Couture Sewing: Tailoring Techniques and Couture Sewing: The Couture Cardigan Jacket, Sewing secrets from a Chanel Collector. These text are easier to grasp because of the step-by-step photography. They layouts are cleaner and overall feel more modern. The DVDs are wonderful aides.To be fair to the publisher, I'm sure photography and DVDs would have added exponentially to the cost; I'm inclined to think it's worth it. Now, what's missing from the newer books is the history and background in Couture Sewing Techniques. It's that information that makes for good reading. It tells you why a particular technique is important. I like having that info.I guess if you are an experienced home sewer or professional, this book is a five-star deal. As someone who is self-teaching, this book is unnecessarily advanced in terms of presentation, not content. I'm hoping the next revision is more along the lines of her newer books.
Works great! Didn't realize it was so big, but that's a minor complaint!  The size helps you get in there and get a good pinch. The flip-top lid is wonderful. I highly recommend!

The pieces in my unit don't fit together properly. One of the "branches" won't fit tightly onto the post because there's extra metal sticking up around the hole where the screw goes. This lip prevents the screw from sitting flush in the hole. The branch ends up swinging from side to side. Last night, I noticed another branch was loose.When I took the tree out of the box for assembly, one of plastic casters was broken and had fallen off the base of the unit. I had to use Super Glue to attach it.I missed the deadline to return it due to holiday travel and sickness. Besides, it's to heavy for me to lug somewhere for shipping. I really justt want someone to send me replacement branches and screws, but I haven't figured out how to reach manufacturer yet.
The only metal appears to be the decorative brushed pink surface. The rest is hard plastic. Case arrived cracked. Stickers on screen protector couldn't be peeled off cleanly.

This is one of the best sewing books! I'm fascinated by the classic Chanel jacket because of it's iconic status and exquisite craftsmanship. I'm not one for designer labels, but I want a similar jacket for the quality. As a home sewer, it's one of those garments that done well, will be a source of pride for years to come. This book will help you get there.Three cheers for a book dedicated to the subject. I was wondering why this hadn't happened before. However, it is worth the wait! I love getting a sneak peak into Shaeffer's personal collection. The garment index makes interesting reading.On to the making of the jacket. Shaeffer starts at the beginning -- with suggested fabrics and a good pattern. Of course there is a section on the famous trims. There's a detailed resources section in the back of the book; you'll know where to go for what.The book assumes you can manage diagnosing and correcting any fit issues on your own. You'll do this with a toile. In terms of construction, this book breaks down a very daunting process into digestible chunks starting with the quilting. This is still advanced stuff and obviously includes tailoring. Please bone up on your hand stitches.  There are chapters on buttonholes, the three-piece sleeve, edge finishing, hand-set sleeves, patch pockets and finishing.Perhaps my favorite chapter is "What Makes Chanel's Cardigan Jacket Different." I love it for the historical perspective. It helps ground you as you think about what you want your finished jacket to look like.In the DVD, you're walked through each step of the construction process. The DVD and the book can stand alone as complete instructional tools. Together, they are awesome. I will say that based on the reviews, I'd decided not to purchase Couture Sewing: Tailoring Techniques. After watching the DVD that accompanies this book, I will purchase Couture Sewing:  Tailoring Techniques for the DVD. If the DVD instruction is as good as it is on this DVD, it's worth the purchase.If you want to make your own Chanel-style cardigan jacket, this book is a must. As other reviewers have mentioned, the techniques here are specific to construction a Chanel-style jacket, but they will help make you a better sewer as you apply them to other projects. This is a great addition to any sewing library.

I purchased this case because I thought it was the best of the limited options I had for the Fire HDX 8.9" around Christmas. The case is good quality. It took me a day or so to get used to it. I love to hold my Kindle portrait style and read it like a book. Unfortunately, this is easier to do without the case because the Kindle is so light and the case adds more weight than expected.The design is really cool. It's the best feature. You need to place the Kindle on a harder surface to take full advantage of it.In terms of protection, if the cover is pulled back, the Kindle is very vulnerable to damage. When trying to use the Fire in bed, I have had it come out of the case a couple of times. I dropped it yesterday and the Kindle bounced out of the case. I don't like having to slide the device out of the case in order to take photos; I wish slots for the camera had been cut in the the case. I also wish that the device sat deeper in the case so that the edges of device were flush with the case. My cell phones feel better protected in their cases, but I don't expect this device to take as much wear and tear as those do. However, dropping the Fire is a much more costly prospect.Lastly, why isn't pink a color option?As more manufacturers start making cases, I will check to see if something better comes along. This case will do for now, but It's not ideal. The leather case looks great, but it's not worth the money because your device isn't protected very well. I'm really disappointed in Amazon.

I like my new Kindle Fire HDX 8.9, but I'm not not in love with it. I've used the iPad, iPad mini and Blackberry Playbook, so I had a pretty good idea of what I wanted in a tablet. In the end, I narrowed it down to the Kindle Fire and iPad because I'm a member of Prime and I wanted to view Amazon streaming video on on a mobile device. Also, my favorite apps are not available for Android devices. I chose the Kindle Fire because of price and I know I will still one day get an iPad. So, the Fire is my iPad Mini. In terms of functionality, and I'll discuss this more below, the Fire is more reader and less tablet.With all that said, here's what I do love about the device -- it's a great value. The size is perfect for reading and I do love to hold it portrait style and read it like a book. If I feel really daring, I do so without the origami case so that I can appreciate how lightweight it is. The Amazon leather origami case is a really cool idea, but not great protection. Took me a day or so to get used to it. I do wish is was lighter and I wish I could get it in pink.I like the organization of my stuff -- carousel, home page/favorites and collections. I do have suggestions for improvements:1. I wish you could add web pages to the carousel2.  I wish the tablet would learn that just because I used something recently, I don't want it in the carousel.3.  I wish the collections could be for more than apps. For example, for my morning devotion time, I would love a collection that contained my gospel playlist, Bible reading apps and certain Kindle books.4.  There's no way to organize picturesMayday is so sweet. Although, I've realized that the help is really about technical issues, not bigger questions like why can't the device run Google apps. Still, this is an awesome feature if you a gifting the Fire to someone who is not tech savvy.As expected, the Amazon apps work great. I would like more visual notification to indicate which movies and TV shows that can be downloaded to the device. It should be just as easy to spot as the Prime indicator.The biggest disappointment with the Fire is no Google apps (as of January 1, 2014). This is why I consider the Fire more of a reader and less of a tablet. Without Google apps like Drive, Google Maps; YouTube and the full cadre of Android apps (like Instagram), this device fails to be a really serious workhorse. For those who use Chrome, you never realize how much you depend on it until it's gone. Don't be confused by the Google apps you see in the Amazon Appstore. These are workarounds developed by others; there are no Google apps, developed by Google, in the Appstore. You can sideload some Anddroid apps onto the Kindle (and I have done so for Instagram and PocketBible), but my point is that I shouldn't have to.If Google and Apple can find common ground, I simply don't understand why Amazon has to be so territorial with the Kindle. I'm wondering if this is the same marketing mistake Blackberry made with the Playbook; the marketplace has pretty much decided that we need two mobile operating systems, iOS and Android. I'm sure Amazon will say that developers have the option of putting versions of their apps in the Amazon App Store, but the fact that many haven't says something.Being forced to live without Google apps has forced me to discover a new favorite app -- Feedly, for blog reading. I've downloaded it to my Android and Apple devices.My next biggest issue with the Fire is the Special Offers. (I know I have the option of removing them for $15.) I'm complaining not because they are there, but because they are so 'untargeted' to me. Amazon has more than a decade of my purchasing history, wish lists, web data and tons of my reviews. Serve me ads for stuff you'd think I'd buy. I was expecting Special Offers to be so much better -- as good as recommendations on my Amazon.com homepage. The Special Offers are generally crappy because I have no interest in the products.Update 2/17/14: I have found a bug in the music playlists. I create my playlists on the cloud using my Kindle. I then dowload them to the device. All of the songs are already saved to the device before I download the playlist. However, songs will be missing from the downloaded playlist. The cloud version has 117 songs, the on-device version has three. Mayday and customer support gave me a solution. So, I uninstalled all music from the device and downloaded it all again from the cloud. I then downloaded the cloud playlists and the problem was solved -- for a few hours. Later, when I updated and created new cloud playlists; uninstalled the device playlists; and downloaded the cloud playlists again, songs were missing.Update 3/15,14: After weeks of back and forth, the issue above was resolved with a replacement Kindle. My cloud playlists loaded onto the device without a hitch. I haven't revised the cloud versions and tried to reload onto the device yet; no new songs have caught my ear. I have to say the getting the issue resolved left me very frustrated. Amazon's usually stellar customer service just didn't bring its A-game. I was so relieved when the rep I spoke with a week ago agreed to ship me another device. It took way too long to get to that solution.I find the speed to be slower than my iPhone and Galaxy phone.  I used all three while playing my favorite mobile game via Wi-Fi. When response time matters, I go for the iPhone instead of the Fire.My Fire has a problem connecting to free Wi-Fi. I haven't hit the Mayday button yet to figure out if it's something I'm doing wrong. The device will connect, but it takes a long while for it to tell you that you need to go to the provider's web page to agree to the terms and conditions. Opening the Silk browser yourself to get to the permissions page doesn't always work.I ordered the 16GB version based on other reviewers' comments regarding Prime movie and TV downloads. If I had it to do over again, I would have given more thought to the 32 GB because I have the Wi-Fi version. If I had gotten Wi-Fi+4G, 16 GB would have been just fine because I would have always had the connectivity to stream what I wanted to watch.All in all, the Fire isn't a bad purchase. I think how much you like it depends on what you're used to from other tablets and even your smartphone. It's a good value, but Amazon needs to rethink the relationship with Google. My user experience isn't as rich as it could be without more Android apps.

I love, love, love this teapot. First, I love its understated design; it feels modern and classic. Also, it just looks good in a stainless steel/black kitchen. It holds about 50 oz of water, which brings me to my second love -- it's huge! The capacity is great for entertaining. Or, if you are like me and drink multiple cups a day, brew a pot of tea in the morning and transfer it to a carafe. Last and best, the large spout means it doesn't get clogged with tea leaves. It pours beautifully! Now you don't have restrict the movement of your tea during brewing by using an infuser. Your cup of tea will be better for it. This pot is a must buy for anyone who brews loose leaf tea!

I love the Fabulous Fit fitting system. I have have a Dritz My Double Deluxe Dress Form, Medium. These pads made padding out the form much easier. The contoured pads come in multiple shapes and the instructions are VERY clear. I just picked my fitting issue and then used the pads to represent the issue correctly on my form. This is the second dress form I've padded it out and let me tell you, it takes FOREVER to do this with batting. The pads are a wonderful assist. You should still grab a bag of batting to help fill out the form.As amazing as the pads are, I wouldn't suggest this product for everyone. If you can sew a pattern pretty much straight from the envelope with minor alterations, you really don't need these pads. However, if you have multiple fitting issues that require substantial pattern adjustments, you need these pads. They really save you some headaches if you fit your garment on your form as you sew.My form is a 3/4 form, so they were kind enough to send me one of the knit covers for the 3/4 form. I think you get would normally get two of the other covers.My only criticism is the actual foam. I don't like how it changes color over time. Granted, you can only tell if you're staring at the form. I wish the pads were rubber instead.

I know absolutely nothing about hand stitching. I avoid it like the plague. I purchased this book to overcome my ignorance and fear. After falling in love with the Great British Sewing Bee, I realized I needed to know how to sew by hand and I was so inspired by what the finalists were able to do without a sewing machine.So here's what I needed the book to do: cover the basic hand stitches used in garment construction: basting, slip stitch, running stitch, overcasting, tailor's tacks and hemming stitches, etc. The book does all that plus covers more. There are more than 35 "Functional Stitches" in the book. I love the large step-by-step pictures. This book has more breadth, but not necessarily depth than The Complete Book of Sewing New Edition.Since I'm even more clueless about embellishment, the book seems awesome in this regard. Again, the large pictures are wonderful. I had no idea there were so many different types of decorative stitches and techniques. This is Chapter 3 and consists of about 40 different stitches/techniques. There's even a directory of motifs!The information on thread, needles and pins is thoughtful. Of course there is info about hoops and frames. There are a few topics in the book that are a nice surprise, but seem odd for a book on hand sewing:  measuring for drapes and dressmaking, reading sewing patterns, estimating fabric requirements for dressmaking, types of zippers and info on pressing. Maybe it's just me.It's a good, solid book. It is extremely well organized. (Within each chapter and subsection, stitch are presented in order of skill level.) Buy it more for the information on decorative hand sewing.

I am a sewing nerd. I have to be because sewing is something I don't seem to have a natural talent for. I have to work at it. Although my mother, stepmom and aunts used to sew and sew well, the gift seems to have almost skipped a generation. My saving grace consists of books and online classes. So glad I can count this book among that number.I will be perfectly honest in that I didn't buy this book for the pattern. I bought it for the techniques and that is what I'm reviewing. Because this book contains a pattern, I'll use The Colette Sewing Handbook: Inspired Styles and Classic Techniques for the New Seamstress and Sew Serendipity: Fresh and Pretty Designs to Make and Wear for comparison. Both are wonderful books that not just help you construct the included patterns, they teach you how to sew. The same is true for this book. The Colette Sewing Handbook is the best of the three because of breadth and depth. Sew Serendipity and this book are more similar because both really whet your creative appetite with embellishment and customization.Here are my specific love notes about this book:1. The reason I bought the book was because it teaches you how to line the skirt. I am so frustrated about the lack of linings in ready-to-wear fashion and the how-to in most skirt patterns.2.  The information is presented clearly. The photos are great!3.  The skirt variations are cuteI do think the book lacks in some areas. The first is fit. Although the pattern is sized to 20, there are no instructions for how to alter the pattern if you need a bigger size. What if you find that either the front or back hem is longer than the other? There's no info on how to resolve the issue. I know that's a problem I will have, but I know how to fix it.The book doesn't have any information about fabric choices or preparation. The technique I wish the book included is how to use hem lace. The book has four options for hems: turned and stitched, rolled, bias and ruffled. I realize I'm being extremely picky.This book is for the beginner stitcher. She or he will be able to get a quick win with this book.

This is my new favorite book on fit. I have a gazillion books on fit, so that's high praise. Here's why -- clarity. You will learn how to read wrinkles and drag lines and correct them. For me, this was an eye-opening approach to fitting -- it's all about the muslin.Let me get back to the clarity. The title gives you a clue -- the photography is some of the best I've seen in a sewing book. I sincerely hope it becomes the new standard. The book is also well-written.  The author covers a number of fitting concerns and explains each very clearly. I hadn't seen the concept of the horizontal balance line before and I love it! It is very helpful.The beauty of this book is the muslin photography. It really helped me understand exactly what I was seeing as I evaluated my own garments. Most of my other books use drawings and it's just not the same.Once you have identified your issues via the photography, the book does teach you how to alter your patterns. When it comes to the pattern work, I switch to more in-depth alterations books like Fit for Real People: Sew Great Clothes Using ANY Pattern (Sewing for Real People series) or Pattern Fitting With Confidence, depending on which alterations method I want to use (slash and spread, pivot and slide or the seam method. If you have a good grasp of pattern alterations, you may not need the supplemental books.I do have to give the author credit for the "Fundamentals of Altering Patterns Chapter. Many seasoned stitchers may already know this info, but for newbies it provides a one-stop shop for the process of altering patterns. They way it's written underscores that when doing alterations, you've kind of become a pattern drafter. Here's some of what the chapter contains:-Blending Seams, Using the Rulers and Adding Seam Allowances-Lengthening and Shortening Patterns and Grainline Arrows-Walking and Truing a Pattern-Placing and Creating Notches-Controlling Patterns with Built-in Ease-Truing Difficult Seams-Moving the Placement of a Seam-Moving a Dart to a New Location-Truing Dart Legs-Scaling Patterns Up and Down-Working in an Efficient OrderI think this book is a must-have! You will not regret the purchase.

This ebook is choc full of excellent info! It is written EXTREMELY well! It is the best resource I've seen on darts. What I thought was priceless was "Fit and Fashion."  It contained an illustration of a t-shirt pattern over the original bodice pattern. Now I get why a dartless fitted knit shirt for me is a pipe dream!My only gripe is the "Join the Discussion" prompts at the end of each section. I registered at the website, received a confirmation, but I never got the second email that would allow me access to the site. I would love to see the additional information posted there. Can't wait to see the rest of the books in this series!

Let me start by saying I don't think this book lives up to it's title. It's a strong promise and I'm not sure what I'd need to see in a book to live up to "Flatter the Curves You Want To Keep and Drape the Ones You Don't."  Perhaps I'd like more suggestions and how-to for design elements that would help achieve the promise.This book starts at the beginning - seriously with Essential Sewing Equipment and a Fabric Glossary.  Because of the title, I was expecting more intermediate info.Next is a very nice section on the body shapes:  hourglass, triangle, inverted triangle, round and oval.  For each figure type, you get an illustration, description of the body type, flattering styles, looks to avoid and appropriate fabrics.  The styles and fabrics are summarized in a check list.  There's nothing new here, but it's nice to see it included in a sewing book. It has examples of sewing patterns that work for each shape. To live up to the "flatter and drape" part of the title, more examples here would have been helpful.Next up is choosing and reading patterns, transferring markings, measurements and layouts.  There are a couple of pages on seam allowance and ease. Meh.The Adapting Patterns section is pretty good.  I really like how this part of the book has a mini table of contents. For each subchapter listed (Shoulder, Neckline, Bust, Hollow Back, Sleeve Length, Armhole, Waist, Hip, Stomach, Bottom, Crotch Depth and Height), there is a brief summary of potential fit issues.  A very brief Dos and Don'ts for jacket sleeves, pants length and skirts follows; it's mostly about proportion.  The alterations are photographed clearly (think The Complete Photo Guide to Perfect Fitting.)  A few garment construction tips are also included.The book includes a chapter on Making a Toile.  It's pretty detailed regarding how to correct its fit.  The book ends with Core Techniques, which covers basic sewing skills.I got the impression that this was a book for sewing for plus sizes. It may have been my mistake. Sewing for Plus Sizes: Creating Clothes that Fit and Flatter is a wonderful book on sewing for plus sizes.I guess the beauty of the book is that you get some fashion info with your pattern fitting and alterations info. Great information and it is a clear, concise read. Unfortunately, the book does not bridge the gap well enough between here's what you should wear and how to make it happen. Instead of just showing me how to adjust a standard pattern for wide hips, show me ways to change the neckline of a top to draw attention away from my hips. If part of the answer includes embellishment, show me how to apply trim or add studs.I do like seeing photographs and illustrations of "real women." You can get a more in-depth fashion info about fitting your shape from Curves Rule and Flat Is Fabulous: Sexy, Stylish Looks for Every Figure and/or The Science of Sexy: Dress to Fit Your Unique Figure with the Style System That Works for Every Shapeand Size.  There are certainly more in-depth alterations books out there.If you are new to sewing, this may be a good starter book. It's not overwhelming and it covers basic skills while providing sound fashion advice. As your skills progress, you'll need to expand your library. If you're also clueless about what looks good on you, this book is a lucky strike extra.

The best caramels are homemade, full of butter and cream. But who has time? Not to mention the mess it makes. These soft cremes are a convenient and very tasty replacement. This tin is huge, 2.25 pounds, and thats a lot of cremes, and a lot of goodness. Sure, they dont have all the butter and cream, but those ingredients dont travel all that well.  The texture is very soft and creamy. There are three flavors in the tin, caramel, vanilla and caramel, and butterscotch and caramel. The first two are very good, and the butterscotch and caramel is good, but I wish it had more of a butterscotch flavor. It has only a hint of butterscotch. If you promise me butterscotch, I want to taste butterscotch.I have this tin on my desk at work, and I have had a steady stream of visitors very much enjoying the cremes.

I am now the proud owner of three of these panini/grill/griddle appliances, one by Cuisinart, one by George Foreman (the Evolve system, which more or less doesnt have a griddle plate), and this DeLonghi. Each has its good points and bad points; however, right now I prefer the DeLonghi.It works very well, and I really like the ceramic-coated grill and griddle. The controls are among its best features. I like that they are flat at the front of the device as it makes them extremely easy to read and to manipulate. Using this device is a no-brainer. By contrast, the George Foreman has electronic pushbuttons that are confusing and make you press them again and again. The Cuisinart has the controls vertically on the front, so I have to bend down to read them or to change a setting.I like that this device can be used as a panini press, with the top down, with heating elements on top and bottom, or open up flat where you can cook on each of the two surfaces. You cannot do that with the George Foreman.Of my three devices, it is easiest to remove and replace the plates on the DeLonghi. There is only one button to push to disengage the plates, and on replacing them there are two slots they slip into and then click. The plates are also clearly labeled as to which is the upper and which is the lower. That seems trivial, but I found it annoying on the other two competing devices.The appliance heats up in a reasonable time, and there is a green light to let you know when it has reached the desired temperature. It seems to hold the correct temperature very well, much better than the Cuisinart.It has a searing temperature, the maximum temperature, of 450. Thats not quite as high as the George Foreman which reaches 500 but it is sufficient for most uses.There are still a few improvements that could be made. The grease drip cups are quite awkward. There is no slot in which they can be engaged. You simply place them below the drainhole. They can easily be bumped with an elbow and then you have grease dripping. They also have to be stored separately.The griddle plates and the grill plates are also separate which means only one can be stored in the machine, and you have to store the other separately. The Cuisinart has reversible plates, so there is no storage issue, and the grease catcher also stores within the Cuisinart itself.The Panini press feature also seems just a bit heavy. The manual suggests a sturdy bread such as ciabatta. I definitely would not use a soft bread in this machine with the top down.So, all in all, of my three choices of this type of appliance, the DeLonghi is my current favorite. It is not perfect, but it has more options that the George Foreman, and it maintains temperature better than the Cuisinart.  It is also the easiest to use.Update:I have now had this for a while, and I have to report one very annoying problem that is causing me to knock several stars off.  I don't cook very often, and I'm sure I've used this appliance less than a dozen times.  Today I used it for the first time in several weeks.  I cooked some chops from frozen, and even with the lid closed, there was some grease splatter on the control panel.  I took a damp paper towel with a little Dawn detergent on it and wiped the panel.  No abrasives, no scrubbing.  So it is shocking to report that all -- all -- of the markings on the control panel wiped off.  Seriously, there is nothing left.  No temperature markings, no indicators of any kind.  This is absurd.

Wow, the first bite of this was so salty, it was startling.  After a few bites, I got used to it and didn't mind it so much.  But that's not my goal when eating good dark chocolate.I also would prefer larger (or even whole) pieces of pistachios.  That probably would have helped balance the salt better as well.I have to say this is the first Scharffen Berger variety that I have not been thrilled with.

These arrived with the medium-size rubber tips on the earbuds.  I could barely get them even part way in place in my ears.  I switched the tips out to the smaller size (included) and still could not get them to fit in my ears  They kind of flop out at an angle.  Its a shame because if I hold them up more-or-less in place for a few seconds, it seems they may have a nice sound.

A few months ago, I purchased a slow cooker.  It sat in the box while I tried to figure out something to make in it that wasnt more trouble than it was worth.  The stupid things dont brown or saut.  Hmmm, sure wished I had one of the new multi-cookers.And now I do, and all I can say is the slow cooker, still in the box but not worth returning (I got it on a lightning deal and it would cost as much to send it back), so its going to the Salvation Army or Goodwill.This Philips Multi-Cooker browns and slow cooks.  It also steams (a steamer basket is included), bakes, reheats, slow cooks, browns, and just about anything else you can think of.  So far, I have used it to steam various vegetables, reheat frozen pot roast, and making a big pot of slow-cooked chicken paprikash (after sauting the onions and chicken in the same pot).  I really want to bake the chocolate walnut cake in the recipe book.  Yes, you can bake in it.  It also makes rice and risotto, but I have not tried that feature as I spent a ton of money on a Zojirushi rice cooker at the same time I bought the slow cooker/doorstop.It worked like a charm in each instance.  The frozen pot roast, I usually defrost a day in the refrigerator.  Only I forgot.  So it went in the Multi-Cooker, a huge hunk of frozen meat, potatoes and gravy.  It came out perfect.  The paprikash can be made on a stove, but its a mess as it simmers and splatters.  I sauted the onions, good Hungarian paprika and chicken in the Multi-Cooker, than added the other ingredients, closed the lid, and let it slow cook for five hours, until the chicken was falling off the bones. It was perfect, with no splatters, no stirring, no fuss.  It was more flavorful than making it in a pressure cooker, as well.So it has done everything I wanted with perfection.  It is meant to cook most items with the lid down, and no stirring is required.  Set it, walk away, and forget it.  Only when you brown or saut do you usually keep the lid up.  So anything that you want to slow cook or simmer, especially, is a dream in this appliance.There are numerous presets, but you can easily adjust any cooking time or temperature.A nice feature is that the outside gets warm but not burning hot.  There is a small steam vent, and when I used the boil/steam feature, steam comes out of that, so that is the one area you need to be cautious around.Still, there are things to consider.  This is a large appliance.  I havent measured it, but Amazon says it is 17 inches long.  Its big.  It does have a nice, big handle so you can easily pick it up and move it off the counter.Despite the large size, the cooking pot only holds a bit over four quarts.  That was plenty big for four huge chicken breasts with bones and four cups of liquid.  If I had needed to cook five chicken breasts, they would not have fit.The instruction page (its one giant sheet that needs to be folded like a road map) is not overly convenient.  It also is a bit confusing.  In more than one place, it says to refer to Steps 6 and 7 in the Preparing section (not quite the exact wording, but I dont have it in front of me).  I found a preparing section under the Rice instructions, but it only has six steps.  I guess number 7 refers to the bullet points under number 6.  Still, it is essentially a non-brainer to get this thing working.There is a recipe book with 16 recipes.

This is a very nice speaker for the size and for the price.  Dont expect the same quality and volume as from a nice, expensive big pair of speakers.  Its one 8-inch long speaker.  But you can take it anywhere (its rechargeable) and it has good sound.It can be set horizontal or vertical, and I have noticed a slight difference in sound, probably because of the small size.  Also, the surface it is set on can affect the sound more than a larger speaker.  So if you are not happy with the sound, try moving it a bit and see the difference.It is quite sturdy, not flimsy or lightweight.  Very solid.  Its a very good choice for its price range.

I really had never given any thought to parboiled rice before.  I didnt even know what it was.  I had to do a little research.  It turns out it is much more nutritious than regular white rice, almost as good as brown rice.  So if you like white rice, this is a much better choice.  It essentially is white rice that was processed in a way that retains nutrients that are lost with regular white rice.In addition, the grains stay separate, never sticky.  So it looks nice on the plate.As far as the taste, it tastes like white rice, so you can use it any recipe that calls for white rice, as long as you dont need sticky rice, and you will have the benefits of more nutrients.Good stuff.

I have not yet read the earlier books by this writing team, but after reading Death of a Nightingale, I definitely intend to purchase them.Death of a Nightingale is a wonderfully constructed, smart suspense tale.  I read it in two evenings.  I had a hard time putting it down the first evening.  I was totally swept up in the story and the characters.  It totally kept me off guard, with surprise after surprise.  After about three-quarters of the book, I began to have suspicions about what was going on, but I could never have guessed at all the twists and turns.  It all comes together, and it all makes sense, unlike so many suspense books.The first fifty-or-so pages can seem a bit overwhelming, as there are a lot of characters, any of which have Danish or Russian or Ukrainian names.  It all quickly gets sorted out and the characters are very easy to keep straight, especially as the action, suspense and excitement build and build and never let up.In addition, we have real characters, not just names.The actions all make sense and follow smoothly.  There was never a time when I wanted to roll my eyes at coincidence, as I do in oh-so-many novels.  This one is clever and complex, and highly entertaining.I strongly recommend this book.

I am writing this review based on what this book is, not on what it is not.It is not a long, detailed biography of Richard II, his reign or his time.  For that matter, its not even a short biography of Richard II, his reign or his time.It does rather elegantly and robustly cover the main events in the dispute between Richard and the nobles, leading to the formation of the Lords Appellant and their downfall.  Earlier major events, such as the Peasants Revolt, are only briefly covered.  The book ends with the exile of Bolingbroke and Mowbray.The print length is described by Amazon as 78 pages, reflecting the narrow range of material covered.  What is covered, though, is told in a very entertaining and lively manner.  It was an enjoyable read, and I recommend it for anyone who has some knowledge of Richard II and wants to learn a bit more, or, someone like myself, who just wanted a quick refresher.  I especially enjoyed the authors (sometimes fanciful) discussion of the personalities involved.  His spotlight on Thomas of Woodstock was particularly interesting.It does not debate conflicting chronicles or theories.  The author does, in the afterword at the end, discuss some of the more controversial theories he advances and his sources and reasons for making them.  Otherwise, there are no footnotes or other direct sources cited.  So, again, if you are looking for a scholarly, microscopic investigation of the life and reign of Richard II, this isnt it.  If you do want to know why Richard II is considered by some historians to be one of the worst, if not the worst, ruler in English history, this small book will explain it to you in exciting prose.  I highly recommend it on that level.The title, many of you will know, is a paraphrase of the line from Shakespeare, "Keeps Death his court."

A beautifully crafted novel, full of marvelous, complex characters.  The author portrays a long-term political hostage situation in -- incredibly -- a lovely, warm and intimate tale of desperation and hope.  Everything about it is a surprise.  It is a joy to read.If you are not an opera fan (I am), don't be turned off by the connection.  An opera singer is central to the plot, as is the effect of her singing and her persona on the terrorists and captives, but you don't need to know anything more than she has a beautiful voice and sings beautiful songs.By the way, if anyone doubts the effect she can have just by walking into a room, I had an interesting experience. I was attending a special concert held in a cathedral.  At the last moment, with the entire audience seated but before the lights went down, a woman came walking down the entire length of the aisle to a seat held for her in the front row.  The whole audience gasped, oohed and awed.  There was something about her that just lit up the room.  People around me were asking, in breathless tones, who she was.  I recognized her immediately as a well-known opera singer.  As I read this book, I relived that moment over and over again, as the singer in this book has the same effect on people.

Good quality, and arrived very quickly.  I'm new to using these as I usually do silk thread beading with bullion (French wire) at the ends.  I'm doing several necklaces now with wire instead of silk, and these guards work beautifully.  They are definitely easier than the bullion and more suitable for wire.  I've ordered more in additional sizes.  I just wish they came in larger packs.  I needed 12 for a six-strand necklace, and had to buy two packs.

I am on my second package of these, and, so far, not one broken.  No problems doing the crimp.  I was a bit nervous doing the first one as I had not done any crimping in many years -- I usually do knotted silk thread for my beads -- but the first one worked perfectly, as did the second, third . . .  etc.

These work perfectly.  Very easy to use.  They are virtually identical to other crimpers that cost several dollars more, which came in handy for me as I thought I had lost my old crimpers and so bought these.  Of course, I found the lost ones a few days after these arrived.  Oh, well.

This hat is way too flimsy for many purposes.  If you want it just to wear sitting on a patio or beach, it probably is wonderful.  If you want to actually wear it and move around, it is not so wonderful.I walk over three miles a day, to and from work, and I always want to have a wide-brim hat to limit my use of sunscreen.  I cannot tolerate any extended amount of sun exposure as my skin burns and Im left with dark splotches that take months to go away (with the help of a prescription cream).  This hat seemed perfect, especially since it has a chin strap to hold it in place.The chin strap does keep the hat on my head.  However, the slightest hint of a breeze causes the brim to flip and flop up and down, left and right, back and forth.  Without the chin strap, Im sure the hat would fly off with the softest breeze.Since the brim is directly on eye-level, it is constantly in my line of sight, and the never-ending jerking movement only inches from my eyes is very distracting.  I tend to constantly pay attention to the direction my hat brim is currently moving when I should be watching where I am walking.  Often, too, the movement of the brim leaves my face partially or completely exposed to the sun.I have never actually worn this hat when there is anything resembling a wind.  In fact, I check the weather first to make sure there is never any more than a breeze.  I assume with the constant movement I get from a breeze, a wind would make it useless.As far as being packable, what they mean is you can press it down flat.  You cannot roll it up.  There is a thin wire that goes around the brim and it is easily damaged and bent.  So to put it in a suitcase, its probably best to put it in first, so it is up against the flat side of the suitcase.In addition to this hat, I have several roll-up and packable wide-brim visors that I use.  They do not flap in the breeze, and they always protect my face, but they do not protect the top of my head or the back of my neck.  For that reason, I wanted this hat.  Unfortunately, I cannot deal with the dancing brim.I bought two of these hats on a lightning deal and had them delivered to my work address.  I immediately tossed the box in the trash.  Otherwise, I would have returned them once I saw how the brim moves.So, they may or may not work for you, depending on how you want to use them.

Ive had a few of these through the years  this is my third.  Each one lasted several years.  I found that I really cant do without.I use this for summer clothes  gauzy dresses or silk items that I dont want to put in the washing machine, as well as quick wash-ups where I dont want to go put coins in the laundry machines (I live in a condo with a laundry room).  One of its best uses is for cashmere sweaters and scarves.  I wash them in the sink or tub and a few minutes in this spinner and they are almost dry.Note that it does not produce heat.  It simply spins clothes very, very fast and pulls all the water out.  You cant squeeze another drop out, no matter how hard you try.  So you can hang clothes up and never have anything dripping.  They will dry super fast on the hanger.The machine has a dial to set the time to spin.  Most items only need two minutes, but it goes up to four.  That is the only setting.Be careful to not overfill the tub.  If you do, a piece can spin up and down the insides.  Not good.  I let that happen once, but Ill never do it again.Be sure to remove the bottom screws before you use the machine.  Its got warnings all over it to do that, but I have a relative who ignored the warnings.  The screws are designed to hold moveable parts during shipping and then are to be discarded.  They, of course, prevent moveable parts from moving  not good to leave in place!My only complaint is the very short cord.  You need to have an electrical outlet near a sink or tub where the spinner can be set so it is flat and where the water can drain out.  I live in a very old condo with one electrical outlet in my bathroom.  The cord cannot reach the sink and just barely reaches the tub without an inch to spare.

Sometimes I buy a book and put it aside, wondering why I bought it.  Every now and then, when I finally getting around to reading that book, Im doubly surprised and delighted to find its excellent.And what a surprise this was.  I really dont remember what prompted me to buy it.  But Im glad I did.  It is a wonderful look at Edward, the Black Prince, son of Edward III, his life and his times.  It is a fictional account, and Im sure it makes Edward out to be a better person than he was in real life.  Here he is charming, humble, thoughtful and well-meaning.  He is very likeable.  Even his father comes across as likeable, and thats not easy.  Not that they arent portrayed as warriors.  They are.  But they are not unreasonable.  The author does a terrific job.The book covers his youth and his training as a knight, as well as a few of his most famous battles.  We see both the lofty goals and the hypocrisy of knighthood.  The Earl responsible for his training emphasizes honesty and duty to the king and other knights, but he has no qualms about cheating townspeople and robbing a young runaway couple of everything they own.  Later, we see those lessons in war as they pillage and burn crops and entire villages in France to draw out and deprive the French king and lords, with no regard for the innocent victims.Edwards ferocious temper (from which he most likely got his nickname) is only shown in battle.  Oddly, I understand that some modern historians are now claiming Edward wasnt quite the bloodthirsty, ferocious warrior depicted earlier, and that he only slaughtered hundreds instead of thousands of innocent victims.This is not a romance novel, but we do have the recurring appearance of Joan of Kent, Edwards eventual bride.  She herself is a fascinating character.  I wish English contemporary historians had paid a little more attention to women, and we knew more about her intriguing life story.  She had to be very remarkable.All in all, this book is very interesting, very well written, and kept my attention throughout.  I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys exciting historical fiction and the glamor and drama of the Plantagenets.

I was fascinated by the idea of someone writing a fictional tale of Cleopatra VII from the viewpoint of her relationship with her sisters, Berenice and Arsinoe, especially as these sisters have been ill-used by history.  The concept sounded very interesting.  Well, parts of it were interesting, parts of it werent interesting, and parts of it were . . . really weird.First of all, Cleopatra herself does not appear in this book.  It appears that the author intends this to be the first volume in the currently trendy trilogy (or maybe worse) scheme.  The problem with trilogies, especially in dealing with the unknown, is that the author is forced to fill up page after page with fluff -- things that would never make it into a single-volume effort.  In this book, to say some of the fiction reaches past fluff directly into the absurd would be an understatement.  Its essentially a soap opera.The book begins with the king, Ptolemy XII, and his daughter Cleopatra having fled the country.  There is little historical context given as to how or why this happened (and we really dont know if Cleopatra accompanied him or not).  The book has Berenice IV somehow becoming queen, and the implication is either that she overthrew the king (her father) or he simply ran off and she filled the vacuum he left.  Neither, of course, is quite true, but the historical records are very confusing as to exactly what happened and who took over (one of the various women named Cleopatra Tryphaena is most likely, followed by Berenice, or maybe the two together), so I can live with the simplification presented.I did not like, however, how Cleopatra Tryphaena (here presented as Berenices mother) was turned into a two-dimensional monster.  It smacked of hack female writing (I dont know why so many bad women writers have to turn so many of their female characters into two-dimensional, evil shrews with no redeeming qualities  her C.T. is positively mentally unbalanced).  And again and again the author has various characters making comments about useless females.  It was very irritating and repetitious.  Why do female authors do that?  Keep in mind that there were some very important queens shortly before the time period discussed.Im also not sure why she felt the need to turn Cleopatras mother into a concubine, who is also vilified.  The historical record, or what little remains of it, did not preserve the name of Cleopatra VIIs mother (relatively few female names do come down through the millennia), but the one thing we can state is that there is nothing out of the ordinary about Cleopatras lineage.  The contemporary Romans sought to discredit and disparage Cleopatra in every way imaginable, but they never, ever implied that she was not of royal birth.  Trust me, if there had been the slightest rumor about her mother not being a queen, the Romans would have played it up without mercy.  Look at how they attacked Ptolemy XII (her father) for playing the flute!Unfortunately, once Berenice becomes ruler, the author has no idea what to do with her.  Theres a lot of muttering about Cyprus (again with no historical reference), but other than that, the author cant think of anything better for Berenice to do than go husband hunting.  Once again, I had to think of an old-fashioned soap opera.Still, I liked Berenice very much and thought her chapters were interesting, although too limited.  However, her chapters alternate with those of her younger sister, Arsinoe.  I would rather the author had concentrated on Berenice and forgotten Arsinoe.We know nothing about the real Arsinoes childhood.  We dont even know how old she was in relation to Berenice and Cleopatra.  The author has made her a child, about to turn nine years old at the beginning of the story.  Its as good a theory as any of the others.  The rest of Arsinoes story, as covered in this book, is completely fictionalized and shockingly bad.  I dont want to give away any spoilers, but, oh, my gosh, why?  Apparently, the author felt a need to invent some rather unique and bizarre experiences to set up Arsinoes later actions (not covered in this book).I was also very annoyed by the writing.  The author wants you to remember that the ultimate goal will be to cover Cleopatras life.  So she has Arsinoe, on page after page, thinking of Cleopatra, wishing Cleopatra were there, remembering something Cleopatra said, wondering what Cleopatra would do.  Over and over and over again.  The repetition just about drove me mad.  Too, I would hate to count the number of (way too many) times that Ganymedes calls Arsinoe, my dear, but I started to cringe each and every time.  At least it made me remember which secondary character he was.  I couldnt keep the others straight, as they were so interchangeable.  I hated Ganymedes; unfortunately, he will be an important person in later events, so hes bound to return in future volumes.Other than that, the writing tends to the florid and melodramatic.  There are so many over-the-top phrases and expressions in this book that made me either gag, groan or laugh out loud.  I almost stopped reading the book after about thirty pages as I didnt think I could get past the description of Arsinoe eating a grape.  Its that bad.  After a while, I got used to it, though, and seldom gasped out loud at the bad writing.  I say seldom, not never.If I, for any reason, had to read this book over again (that reason involving nothing less than a loaded pistol held to my temple), I would entirely skip the Arsinoe chapters and only read the Berenice chapters.For those interested in an excellent fictional life of Cleopatra, try Margaret Georges, The Memoirs of Cleopatra.  It is well written and follows the historical record.  Its a beautiful book.  For some factual information on interesting earlier Ptolemaic queens, try Arsinoe of Egypt and Macedon (about Arsinoe II) by Elizabeth Donnelly Carney and Berenice II and the Golden Age of Ptolemaic Egypt by Dee L. Clayman.  I also found The Crown of Arsinoe II: The Creation of an Image of Authority by Maria Nilsson, interesting.  Dont, however, confuse the earlier Arsinoe II or Berenice II with the Arsinoe and Berenice in this book.So how to rate this book?  The writing is two-star.  Its drifts way too often into really, really over-the-top ostentatious and pretentious melodrama.  (I have an advanced reader copy and am not allowed to quote, but I sure wish I could  there are some howlers in this book.  By the way, its also possible that some of it may change for the better before the books publication.  We can only hope.)  The Arsinoe chapters, especially the later ones, are preposterous, also earning a two-star rating.  But I really, really liked Berenice, even though her character and sphere of influence were so limited by the authors imagination.  I would give the Berenice chapters four stars.  So about two-and-a-half stars overall.  I tend to be generous, and I do appreciate the authors efforts on behalf of Berenice, so maybe I will give this three stars, but I could just as easily go with two.  Needless to say, I have no desire to read the forthcoming volumes.

I really couldnt tell these were partly recycled cotton.  Its a great idea.  All those old t-shirts and things have to go somewhere, why not make them useful.The towels are quite soft and absorbent, although I was not crazy about the tight area near the edge  Im sure there is a name for that section, sort of like a waffle weave.  (I wish I could point.)  Its a bit rough.I got the white towel set and washed them, as usual, before using.  I live in a condo and use a laundry room, so I cannot speak to the amount of lint left behind in the lint filter.  However, I did notice white lint in my bathroom when using the towels.  In fact, I have a mesh strainer in the drain and it clogged up with a fine layer of lint.  Maybe the towels need to be washed twice to remove lint before using.I do not use any sort of fabric softener or any dryer sheets as I do not like the smells and also dryer sheets cut down on absorbency for towels as they leave a coating.  That kind of defeats the purpose.The bath towel is huge; in fact, Im short and it and it trails on the ground if I dont pay attention.  I dont generally use wash cloths, so I cant speak to that.  I do like the mat.  It is the sort of mat you put down on the floor for stepping onto after bathing, and then it is lightweight enough to throw into the washing machine with the towels.  Its not the sort of mat you would leave on the floor all the time as it will move around.All in all, a pretty good set.

Okay, I am a cynic.  I never believed this stuff would work.  I honestly and truly saw a difference in two days.  There are no miracles here so far  I drink tea and cola all day long, both of which stain teeth yellow, but it definitely and noticeably began removing yellow in the first few uses.  I was astonished.  My teeth arent sparkling white, but I havent finished the total program yet, still have more than half a tube left, so I will update this later when I see the final results, but I just wanted to say it absolutely and quickly makes an obvious difference.  Can it totally remove many, many years of tea and cola stain?  Probably not, but I never expected it to.  I just wanted not to be so sunshine yellow, and it definitely has had an impact.I have very sensitive teeth, and it has not been painful.  Oddly, it hardly bothers my gums at all.  After a few uses, it did start to make my tongue and lips just a bit numb and tingly, but the sensation does not last long.  All I do then is skip a session or even a day, so it does not become an issue.The taste is not bad.  If you have ever had a sore in your mouth where you had to rinse your mouth with a hydrogen peroxide solution, it is a similar taste.  Not yummy, but easily tolerable.Also, my teeth feel very clean and smooth, almost like I just had a professional cleaning.  Nice.My teeth were very dark and very yellow because of all the cola and tea I drink all day long.  I had not used any whitening products in many years.  I had my teeth professionally whitened years ago, and it was a waste of money as it simply didnt work.  It also caused extreme sensitivity and outright pain.  It totally turned me off the idea of trying whitening again, but, I started thinking there must have been some advancements in whitening since then, but I didnt want to pay a lot to try one.  Using this Crest gel system was completely different and so much easier and less painful.  And it cost hundreds of dollars less than for the professional treatment.The Crest system was not only relatively cheap, but I could do it at home.  It was easy, virtually painless, and I got almost immediate results.  Very pleased.  Why waste hundreds of dollars at the dentist?

As a general rule, I dont like to use any styling products or anything else that stays on my hair.  I have had long hair most of my life and still do; they eventually will bury me with long hair.  However, as the years have passed by, my hair now can get a bit frizzy at the ends; also when I tie it back, I wind up with little fluffy flying frizzies sticking out on the sides around my face.  Not an attractive look.  Those are all new things Ive had to deal with.This product has come in handy.  I only use it on dry hair on days when I need it.  Its a little hard to use on dry hair as it dries very quickly, so I have to move fast.  I put a bit on my hands and run it through the ends as quickly as possible, then brush.It really does help the appearance of my hair.  Those frizzies behave themselves and smooth out.  Shine?  I dont know.  My hair is ash blonde infused with gray, so a dull color made duller by gray.  It never was shiny, so I dont expect a product to make it so.All in all, I am happy with this product.

Love this mouse.  It's very comfortable to use.  It works on most surfaces -- just for the heck of it, I tried using it on carpet! -- yes, it worked exactly as if I were using a mouse pad.  I truly love the scroll wheel -- if you want to scroll a long way down a Web page, just give that wheel a good spin and it flies.  Of course, you can also move the wheel a small amount to scroll down a bit, but I've never seen scrolling fly like this does when you give it a good spin.I ordered the Brilliant Rose color, and it's really nice.  It is a deep, metallic rose color, very nice and not like anything I've ever seen before.High recommended.

What a beautiful movie.  To give away any of the plot would be a crime, so I'll just say it seemed like the most incredible portrayal of true love that I have ever seen in a movie.  A bit of a spoiler alert:  it's not a silly romcom.  Far, far from it.The cast is perfect.  Ellen Burstyn shines.  Martin Landau, Elizabeth Banks and Adam Scott are terrific.If you are looking for one of the vulgar and stupid "comedies" that have taken over the entertainment industry, this is not for you.  If you enjoy good acting and a good story, and don't mind shedding a tear or twenty, this is for you.  I loved it.

Sandra Bullock is terrific in this film.  I have to say the plot is better than I expected and took some very interesting turns.  Many of the reviews I read when the movie was in theaters made it seem too depressing.  It's not, really.  Sandra just keeps plugging away, no matter how dire the situation.Not a great movie by any means, but I'm glad I finally got a chance to see it.

This is a very enjoyable version of Mark Twain's book.  As of this writing, the only version available is the 94-minute version, which was cut from the original broadcast length.  This is bad news for us Guy Williams fans, as I believe a subplot about his character's background has been removed.  His role is fairly minimal in what remains of the film.  I hope one day we can again see the entire film.Still, the title refers to the "prince and the pauper," and those characters are great fun.  The young actor does quite well, and the deception of one boy playing two parts is handled gracefully.This is a good film for the entire family to enoy.

Not quite as good as the very best Hungarian kolbasz, but still very enjoyable.  Nice flavor and texture.  It may have a bit too much salt for some people, but I liked it.My favorite thing, from childhood, is to cut it in relatively small pieces and fry them until they start to brown a bit on the cut sides.  Then take them out of the pan and throw in some scrambled eggs.  The eggs pick up the flavor and make a wonderful meal with the sausage.I should add that there was very little grease in the pan after I fried the pieces.I would buy this again.  As I said, I have had better, but I no longer have a convenient source for great kolbasz.  This is very good kolbasz, and I can appreciate it.

Very good salami.  I liked the texture and the good flavors.  Not bland at all.  When sliced, it does not have that greasy, slick and slimy feel of packaged grocery-store salami.  I can't compare it to the authentic made-in-Hungary salami as I have not had that in years.  I would definitely buy this again.

Just about anything you want in a vacuum is right there in the box.  What cant you do with it?  Its an upright, a canister, and a lift away all in one, and its quite easy to switch between modes as needed.  Its even pretty -- shiny, colorful and really snazzy looking -- and I never thought I would say that about a vacuum cleaner.  The particular configuration I received contained about every attachment I could ever want, from cleaning hard wood floors to deep pile carpets, dusting, etc.  Everything works as I hoped.  I especially like the dusting attachment.  I could not really test the pet hair tool as I am currently in a sorrowful petless state, so I can only say I hope it works when I do move in another year or two and officially become Crazy Cat Lady Supreme.So whats not to love?  Well, storage.  Good golly, Miss Molly, this thing is huge.  It is a very tall vacuum cleaner in its upright position, a whopping 46 inches.  The top of the handle stands six inches above my old vacuum, which looks like a weakling midget compared to the Shark.  Two problems there  one, I am very short (52) and the handle comes up to my armpit (although, of course,  I don't vacuum with it fully upright), and, two, I stored my old vacuum in a small cupboard (I live in a big-city apartment where space is at a serious premium) and this one will not fit in the cupboard because of the height.
