The Zubulake standards are now widely used across the nation.That describes the most important holding from the Zubulake opinions (to be closely followed by the standards for spoliation and adverse inference), but why read this book instead of the opinions?  Zubulakes e-discovery suffers in comparison.  The collected opinions are shorter.  Zubulake gives the important points from each opinion; but those arent exactly hidden in the opinions themselves.  In fact, the Zubulake opinions are very well written as judicial opinions go.  Zubulakes writing isnt bad, but, promises to tell her personal story aside, she makes the fatal error of stripping every possible personal detail from it.  The prose left is dull and lifeless.Zubulakes e-discovery is probably most valuable as a window inside a clients mind.  A brilliant, stubborn mind.  She makes the mistake of thinking that because employment discrimination isnt novelit forms a decent chunk of any federal judges docketthat it must be routine.  She mocks the proposed mock trial on the basis that there was nothing to test, apparently forgetting that fallible humans who could use the practice would be arguing her case.

The best thing that can be said about Browns new biography of Tolkien is also the worst: it is very short.  192 pages (in paperback) isnt much room to tell the story of anyones life, let alone Tolkiens.  I havent read a book on Tolkienother than Tom Shippeys masterful Author of the Centurysince I was in school, but Brown doesnt seem to cover any new ground.  As is to be expected of a book from a Christian publisher, Brown gives ample attention to Tolkiens faith, but Tolkiens faith is hardly novel.  I did find the discussion of the trouble his mothers conversion (and his along with her) to Catholicism interesting; its the sort of thing its easy for a modern American to discount.  His friendship with C.S. Lewis is another expected focus, but despite the relative attention it gets the length of the book demands that it come off as cursory nonetheless.  Tolkiens crooked road to academiahe was initially a poor student because he spent all his time on Germanic languages rather than the Classics he majored inis another highlight; his actual career in academia is barely mentioned.  All in all, I enjoyed it and Im glad I read it, but if youre a hardcore Tolkien fan dont expect much, if anything, new.Disclosure: I received a complimentary e-copy of Tolkien via NetGalley.

The Color of Justice starts off in a familiar fashion, with an idealistic white attorney in small town Mississippi facing the choice whether to defend a black man accused of murdering a white woman.  (Ill skip over descriptions of athletic attorney, the supportive wife, the nurturing black mother figure, the wealthiest man in town, and the venal prosecutor because youve seen them before.)  Collins attempts to put a twist on things by continuing the story from 1964 in 2014.  The book jacket and this review must remain necessarily vague about the role that the 2014 story plays, but just be forewarned that it only shows up well, well into the book.  Its also very jarring and abrupt when it does, but I think that is by design and effective.The Color of Justice is anchored by awful, awful dialogue.  Which is a shame, because outside of the dialogue Collins does a great job dealing with issues that can easily come off as trite.  The legal drama is strong, and the aforementioned familiar character types surprise us frequently enough.  Collins is perhaps at his best in avoiding an overly simple narrative.  Our young, idealistic attorney is very close to just letting the whole thing pass.  The young black man accused of murder is angry.  The sheriff doesnt really think he did it, but like a lot of residents of the small town he just doesnt want to rock the boat.  The twist at the end, unfortunately, isnt much of a revelation and overall the book comes out as just average.Disclosure: I received a complimentary e-copy of The Color of Justice via NetGalley.

A Plunder of Souls is D.B. Jacksons third book in the Thieftaker Chronicles (three and counting and no sign of slowing).  The Thieftaker Chronicles chronicle the adventures of Ethan Kaille, a thieftaker in 1760s Boston and a conjurer.  D.B. Jackson has a PhD in American History and is an accomplished fantasy author (as David B. Coe): both show.  In A Plunder of Souls, Kaille has been hired as by a local church to investigate a series of grave desecrations.  Its soon clear that something more sinister than mere grave robbing is afoot and that Kaille is in over his head.A Plunder of Souls gets off to an unfortunate start.  By book three, my default is the less Sephira Pryce, the better.  Ethan and Sephiras relationship begins to change during the book, though, and she winds up playing a different, more interesting, role here than in the first two books.  We also continue to see a more assertive Kaille, a welcome bit of character progression in the second book.Unfortunately, American history takes a back seat in book three.  The main historical event of note is a minor influenza epidemic.  Samuel Adams makes a cameo, but otherwise the Sons of Liberty are silent.  This is particularly disappointing after the second book.I do have one particular complaint about the ending.  Jackson makes a decision that I think is about future books, not this one and this one suffers for it.  It isnt going to stop me from waiting with anticipation for the next book, though.

Saving Your Marriage Before It Starts has everything you can ask for from a marriage counseling book.  Its faith-based, cites to scripture and contemporary empirical work, recognizes both the natural male and female perspectives, tells story about real life, and is grounded in reality.  There is also homework and accompanying workbooks.  The book is aimed for premarital counseling (how we used it), but I think it would benefit couples at any stage.

I looked forward to reading Of Sorrow and Such because I really enjoyed Sourdough and Other Stories and The Bitterwood Bible, all of which take place in the same world.  Unfortunately, although Of Sorrow and Such is readable, it's overly derivative and logically weak.The main character, the witch Mistress Gideon (formerly Sykes), is always in some degree of peril. Witches are hunted by the church and then burned at the stake in the same villages where they have healed many neighbors with herbs and spells.  Once witch hunters arrive at the village of Edda's Meadow in search of Selke, another witch Mistress Gideon has secretly sheltered, not only they but several of the town's other women are in peril.  Because, although Mistress Gideon claims to be able to perceive whether anyone has magical ability, she's as surprised as everyone else to discover that some of her neighbors are shapeshifters. They even have a club with monthly meetings. Mistress Gideon has been routinely restoring a woman whose husband is trying to slowly poison her, believing no one else can help.  At a crucial moment near the end of the book, the woman's mother-in-law turns out to be a powerful witch eager to protect her daughter-in-law. And there are more deux ex machinas, plus an overly heavy-handed message that Men are Bad and Women Are Good and Support Their Sisters.If you're a Sourdough/Bitterwood fan, as I am, Of Sorrow and Such is worth reading.  But I hope any future works set in this world will be better.
Light, refreshing, slightly tart.  I think of it as a spring and summer scent.

Protagonist Maia is the fourth and (and youngest) son of an emperor by his cast-off fourth (and last) wife.  When the book opens, Maias beloved mother has been dead for some years.  Maia was brought up in the back end of nowhere by his abusive distant cousin Setheris, who was exiled from court for some unproven treason. Maia has lived the life of an impoverished rural noble for all of his 18 years. He has received the minimum of education even for such a noble.All this changes at the very beginning of the book, when the courier Csevet brings the news that Maias father and three older brothers were killed in an airship accident. (Even though the novel takes place in some vague equivalent of the Middle Ages.) Maia is now the emperor. That is, if he can fight off several less legitimate, but much more aggressive and knowledgeable claimants who already live at court.  On Setheriss advice (he wants to use Maia to gain some important position) Maia immediately travels to court to claim his throne.Although part of The Goblin Emperor is about how Maia foils treacherous plots and investigates the deaths of his relatives (hint: not accidental), the main theme is how Maia gains what hes always lacked. Luxurious rooms, clothes, jewels, and meals are part of it, but Maias emotional needs are stronger. He wants relatives, and although most are dead he befriends most of the ones that are left, even his fathers cast-off first wife. He wants friends, and although he comes to realize that his position makes disinterested friendship impossible, he does gain the strong loyalty of a number of people, especially (most of) his bodyguards. Maia is childishly delighted to receive loads of fancy gifts for his 19th birthday, even though he realizes they are all from nobles who want something from him. He also adores being taken care of by his personal dressers/wardrobe people. More maturely, Maia does want to do good and make a difference, often an our-world politically correct difference regarding race, gender, or social class.I enjoyed this book, but I had some problems with it. First, Maia is several years younger emotionally than chronologically. Hes very passive, and constantly feels sorry for himself over events that happened years earlier. Im not sure if the age dissonance is intentional on the authors part, but the self-pity gets tiresome. One of Maias emotional needs is to cast off his practical dependence on Setheris, but he merely switches his dependence to other people as they volunteer to help.And there are aspects of world building where I just could not suspend my disbelief. In particular, the four imperial bodyguards, pairs of whom stay on duty 12 hours a day until the emperors death, when they all are sworn to commit ritual suicide so they can be buried with him. (Sarah Monettes work sometimes contains S & M aspects. Maia even voluntarily watches a treacherous bodyguard commit mandatory suicide, described in gory detail.) First, four bodyguards is not enough, if the real purpose is to have the emperor well guarded and not for the author to describe a kind of master-slave relationship. The several rival claimants to the throne and their numerous allies really want to kill Maia. Its hard to see how only two bodyguards (at any given time) could realistically defend him against a band of attackers. (Maia himself has no self-defense training.) Then, bodyguards who always work 12-hour days cant possibly be effective. (At the beginning, when only one pair has been hired, they stay on duty with no sleep for several days in a row; this while traitors lurk everywhere.) To be alert, bodyguards need to eat well and sleep well. They also need to regularly practice their skills for defending the emperor.  Its not clear whether these are swordplay, knife work, martial arts, or what (though half the bodyguards have some kind of magical skill), but Id assume theyd need to stay expert in several forms of defense. And last, if they are hired young and keep their jobs till the emperor dies of old age, they will be four old guys (well, since Maia is so PC, one bodyguard is female) defending another old guy.  Hardly effective, as in this society Id expect people to pass their physical peak by 40.The Goblin Emperor has its charms, and its certainly lighter than Sarah Monettes Doctrine of Labyrinths series. I just wish the author had thought it out more thoroughly.
I got these for my husband to use in polishing a houseful of antique brass light fixtures. He's gone through a ton of cloth rags already and we were running out. These cloths are a great substitute.

A History of Architecture in 100 Buildings has the limitations youd expect of a book that covers the entire world (though some parts more than others) and a vast historical range. Many famous structures (the author rather unfortunately did not limit himself to buildings) are omitted. (The author says one selection criteria is that he had to have seen the structure himself.) Although the descriptions are reasonably informative, they are all short (about 2  pages including photos).  The photos are rather small and scanty (few interiors, for one thing).  Although this book is no less flawed than a college class such as Introduction to the Worldwide History of Art, where the instructor displays so many famous paintings so fast the students can hardly keep track, its no better.  The scope of this book forces it to be superficial.Although Im not an architectural expert, I grew up near and have visited one of the famous buildings described in this book:  Frank Lloyd Wrights Fallingwater.  Author Dan Cruickshank says that one of the criteria for a great building is functionality. I agree. He admits that Fallingwater is flawed, in the sense that it was built with insufficient structural support (it had to be extensively retrofitted in a period from the mid 1990s into the early 2000s.) Thats a major problem right there. But other functional problems appeared much earlier. Local rumor had it that the family of department store magnates who commissioned Fallingwater donated it to the state of Pennsylvania because they found it impossible to use. Wright was a prima donna.  He could have placed the house near the falls, but chose to place it directly over them because, I was told, he felt the inhabitants would appreciate the view more if they had to intentionally go outside to look at it.  The downside was that the house was plagued with mold and leaks, as any sensible person might have anticipated. I was also told that Wright could have pigmented the huge concrete balconies so that they would never need repainting, but chose to require paint because he felt the inhabitants would appreciate the house more if they had to keep it up regularly.  As anyone who ever purchased a money pit can tell you, thats not true. Finally, Wright designed all the beds for short people because he himself was short and felt no one should be taller.  His clients were tall, so sleeping in the beds turned out to be difficult. The author doesnt mention any of these problems.This book should have been published as a large-format coffee-table book with big photos, that people could leaf through occasionally without expecting a thorough education in either world architecture or any specific structure.

Home by Nightfall covers two cases tackled by 1870s gentleman detective Charles Lenox. A former MP, Lenox is now a partner in a London detective agency and determined to make it a success. A new case presents an excellent opportunity. A famous concert pianist has mysteriously disappeared, the newspapers are abuzz, and Scotland Yard is baffled. Unfortunately, family duty impels Lenox to leave the case to his partners and travel to his home town, Marketplace, to support his grieving, newly widowed brother Edmund. Lenox is like other fictional detectives in that wherever he goes, crime promptly occurs. A series of strange petty thefts is capped by the murder of Marketplaces mayor.  Of course Lenox is hired to investigate, aided by his brother. And of course both mysteries are solved.The marketing copy for this book enthusiastically declares it to be the equal of Charles Dickens and Jane Austen. Very different writers, but Ill let that pass.  The important point is that this is a pleasant cozy mystery with a mildly Victorian atmosphere and workmanlike prose. A fun enough read for fans of such mysteries, but hardly great literature.

I use turmeric to reduce tendon inflammation. It helps somewhat, if taken regularly over time. These capsules are certainly more convenient than my former method of making bulk turmeric (bought as a spice in an Indian grocery) into a paste and eating it!

This historical novel takes place in 1788, primarily in Florida. There are four main characters, each of whom narrates different chapters (which are clearly labeled to avoid confusion). Three of them (Bob, a black slave; Istillicha, a Creek Indian; and Cat, a poor and somewhat delusional white man) are runaways hoping to better their lives. Their mutual need for funds impels them to commit a road robbery. The fourth man, LeClerc, is an agent sent to bring them to justice. He is keenly interested in what brought men from such different cultures together and in why they committed the crime. Author Katy Simpson Smith also addresses universal issues of race, freedom, and relationships. Free Men is sensitive and beautifully written. Five stars.

I have found biotin to be very helpful in making my post-menopausal hair and nails somewhat less brittle. Because I only need to take one capsule a day, the 120 capsules in this bottle will last me awhile.

At a dinner party, at which Alexander Hamilton was present and Aaron Burr was not, Hamilton expressed the opinion that Burr was politically dangerous. Mild as this insult was for a politician, another guest reported the comment to the newspapers. Burr demanded a retraction; Hamilton refused. In the ensuing duel, the United States lost the man who had set up much of the financial institutional structure of the young United States. After briefly fleeing charges of murder, Burr managed to finish his term as Vice President.Such a duel could only be a result of long-standing rivalry and personality conflict. In War of Two, author John Sedgwick explores how both mens careers and interactions led up to the duel, then continues the biography of Burr till his death years later. Other famous characters include George Washington and Thomas Jefferson. This fascinating book is thoroughly researched from original sources, and many period letters are reproduced in it. Five stars.

This 2015 anthology contains 20 stories, reprinted from the periodicals and anthologies in which they originally appeared. I was intrigued that only one apiece were originally published in Asimovs and The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction. Most are from the semi-pro-zines, especially Lightspeed. (I suppose Tor.com is considered pro.) I keep up with what I think are the best online SF publications (as well as the two above-mentioned print magazines), so most of these stories are not new to me. But its a nice selection, including stories by Theodora Goss, Neil Gaiman, Jo Walton, and Kelly Link. I merely wish it were much larger, and included more stories from mainstream publications I dont read (there are three from The New Yorker). No anthology, Im afraid, is going to replace Terri Windlings and Ellen Datlows defunct annual, The Years Best Fantasy and Horror.

The United States Constitution stated that no ban could be placed on the importation of slaves till 1808.  Such a ban did go into effect in 1808, but the illegal slave trade continued for decades. No God But Gain is a study of the economic consequences of the illegal slave trade in the early 19th century, the period being seen as itself and not merely as a lead-up to the Civil War. This book shows how heavily the nation depended on the slave trade and how our Founding Fathers protected it and participated in it. The Monroe Doctrine, hubristic in its mention of both North and South America (the US had only 16 warships at the time) was created to protect the illegal slave trade. This is a well-researched, readable study of an important and somewhat neglected topic.

This book is best for spiralizer enthusiasts, and people who somehow acquired a spiralizer and now want to know what to do with it. People who are committed to using or at least trying out a spiralizer. Im not one of them. Id heard that spiralizers are the hot new kitchen gadget (and inexpensive, I checked!) and admired the lovely curls of vegetables on a few blogs. Authors Marilyn Haugen and Jennifer Williams gave me the information I needed, in a cogent up-front description of different kinds of spiralizers and a list of what vegetables and fruits can be spiralized. What they didnt do is explain *why* Id want a spiralizer, how it would improve my cooking. My sense is that spiralizers are great if you follow one of a variety of special diets: low-carb, gluten free, paleo, and others. But I dont follow any special diet. I was hoping the 150 recipes would convince me, but they didnt. I see that I can use zucchini instead of pasta noodles and spiralize vegetables Id normally chop, but big deal. And the recipes are not to my personal taste; theres nothing here that thrills me. That said, this is a clearly written cookbook with a scattering of attractive photos, and I am sure many people will love the recipes.

Made to Kill is a stylish noir detective novel, written in the style of Raymond Chandler and taking place in an alternate 1960s. Private detective Raymond Electromatic is the worlds last remaining robot. The brains of the operation is Rays office manager, the supercomputer Ada. Amoral Ada is increasing the firms revenues by having Ray moonlight as an assassin. Because he needs to have his data tapes transferred every night, when he reboots the next morning he has no memory of previous events. This complicates his investigations, but theres more:  Gold bars, beautiful women, famous actors, Cold War Russian spies, and Satanic rituals. Theres plenty of action, but this is not a thriller. Author Adam Christopher keeps the tone light, without the book ever becoming a spoof. Although the plot does have a definite end, this is the first book in a trilogy. Im looking forward to the next two.

This product is a skin cleanser and mild exfoliator that you don't have to rinse off your skin with water.  You just saturate one of the 90 little (about 2 inches wide) circular pads provided and wipe it across your face. It works, but it's much too expensive for me to consider actually buying it.

This product is a combined shaving cream, acne cream, and moisturizer.  Note that I said cream--this is a light, airy product, not what I'd call a gel. It does the job, but many less expensive products are on the market.

Waltons previous book in this series, Superposition, resolves without any hint of a sequel, so I was rather surprised to see this one published. Like Superposition, Supersymmetry is a fast-paced, high-tech, near-future, hard science fiction thriller that aims to keep you on the edge of your seat for all 302 pages.  It largely succeeds, though readers not interested in physics may be slightly intimidated.  Its got a supervillain (the varcolac) same as in Superposition, which wants to destroy the world while the characters try to defeat it. This book begins about 15 years after the first book, with some of the same characters plus new ones added. The characters are pretty shallow, but we can all get behind the idea of saving the world. Techies will love all the gadgets, thriller fans will love the destruction the varcolac wreaks. Supersymmetry is not great literature, but competently and smoothly written. Although it resolves, I imagine that author David Walton could always manage to revive the varcolac at need.

These sponges have a scrub side and a mop-up side. The scrub side is *slightly* more abrasive than other scrubbers Ive used.  It works fine for getting off food stuck to cooking pots, but its not miraculous. You still have to use elbow grease. The sponge side is of average thickness, and treated with an antimicrobial coating so it wont smell funky. The shape of the combo is a kind of shortened hourglass, where you always have to grasp the combo on the same side, so its hard to get a new scrubbing area when an old one wears out. Overall, this is a useful basic kitchen scrubber. Its purple, if you care.

The Beautiful Bureaucrat is short, really a novelette. Thats the right length, because it might be hard to stick with its moody, surreal, bleak (but occasionally humorous) atmosphere for a longer stretch. A loving young couple, Josephine and Joseph, move from the hinterland to an unnamed city. Because theyre financially marginal (and want to have a child as well), Josephine accepts the worst data-entry job you can imagine. Not only does her boss have foul breath and tell her not to think, shes physically damaged and emotionally exhausted. Only one coworker, the oddly named Trishifanny, is willing to talk to her. Joseph also accepts a job, and Josephine has no idea what it is except that sometimes he doesnt come home and his cell phone messages are incomprehensible. But then events at work slowly begin to reveal whats really happening--which is impossible to explain without spoilers. Just dont expect this book to always make logical sense. Its all about ideas. And language; its beautifully written.

I am really enjoying these truffles.  They are not excessively sweet; they have that dark chocolate flavor. The liqueurs give them just a little bite and well, they seem more sophisticated.  OK, I wish they were huger!  I wish there were some nut flavors in addition to the liqueurs!  Then again, I haven't looked at the rest of the Moonstruck Chocolate collection and should really go do that.

This is a high-end pot, fancier than I'd ever buy for myself. It would make a great wedding or holiday gift. The color is a trendy, vibrant red. The pot's size enables you to cook anything large, either on a burner or in the oven. Roasts, casseroles, soups . . . The pot heats very evenly and the lid seals well.  The lid doubles as a burger grill but I have no need for that feature.  Cleaning is easy.  The only drawback I can see, for some people, is the weight.  You don't want to give an elderly relative with arthritis a cast-iron pot of this size.

Commissaire Georges Dupin has some familiar characteristics in a detective. Hes intelligent, analytical, independent to the point of insubordination, and addicted to a beverage, in this case coffee. Hes endured the horrible fate of being exiled from Paris, but the good luck of having settled in the ideal vacation destination of Brittany. The books setting is not only beautiful, but historicGauguin and other artists congregated there, in Pont-Avon. An aged hotelier named Monsieur Penec dies, it looks like murder, and an extremely valuable painting by Gauguin disappears. Dupin investigates. Theres the usual set of unpleasant characters who lie, etc. The pace moves along nicely without being frenetic, and theres a satisfactory conclusion.Id call this a cozy mystery in the sense that its not gruesome and the setting of Pont-Avon is, um, to die for. The local chamber of commerce should be distributing this book. Its clear that this is the first book in a series. I look forward to reading more of them.

This is one of a very few graphic novels Ive read that was not speculative fiction. Its a series of touching vignettes in the life of a small-town GP in Wales. Apparently, unlike in the US, doctors there actually care about their patients. This  often becomes emotionally difficult for the narrator. His personal life has its downs as well, including (despite his being married), unrequited feelings for one of his medical partners. His struggles to be a good doctor and a good human being are admirable. The black-and-white art is . . . OK.  Its not unprofessional, but its not the best either. It does work with the narrative, though. Four stars.

This is a good basic set of wrenches. The seven different sizes, plus the two ends on each (ratcheting open and box closed), enable you to do pretty much anything you'll ordinarily want to do with a metric wrench. Five stars.

Uprooted is a comfortable, homey YA fantasy, reminiscent of Patricia McKillips work. Its predictable, but pleasantly so. The narrator/heroine Agnieszka lives in a vaguely Russian village at the edge of a sinister wood. Every ten years, the local sorcerer/lord known as the Dragon chooses a village girl to live in his tower. When their term is up, the girls come home educated and refined, with purses full of silver for their dowries.  They briefly visit their parents, then move to larger cities that have better opportunities. The chosen girl is always a local belle. While Agnieszka was growing up, everyone expected her best friend Kasia to be the Dragons next choice. Kasia is the most beautiful girl, and the most skilled in all the domestic arts (her parents made sure she was trained to serve a nobleman). No one expects the Dragon to choose Agnieszka, who is perpetually muddy and untidy, and whose only skill seems to be finding the unexpected, whether fruit out of season or more often, trouble.Of course, the Dragons choosing spell lands on Agnieszka. Once in the tower, Agnieszka discovers that the returning servants told the truth when they claimed the Dragon didnt molest them. However, Agnieszkas inability to cook, clean, or even dress neatly, coupled with her plain face and low social status, leads the fastidious Dragon to utter an endless stream of sarcastic comments typical of a certain kind of romance hero. Agnieszka also finds it very hard to learn even the simplest spells. (Interestingly, shes already literate.) But Agnieszka does have magical ability. Lots of it. Its just a *feminine* magical ability:  Organic, intuitive, inconsistent, largely nonverbal, nurturing, and cooperative. The only manual shes in tune with is a neglected handwritten journal by the long-dead witch Baba Yaga. Whereas the Dragons magic is masculine:  Logical, scientific, explicable, and tidy. It takes the Dragon awhile to understand and work with Agnieszkas ability, but he does.Agnieszkas talent for getting into trouble is also in full force.  By trouble, I mean politics, treachery, assassination, and war, which quickly lead Agnieszka back into the wider world, including the court, its royalty, and its experienced wizards. Here the 17-year-old Agnieszka is fully the awkward adolescentinsecure, socially inept, emotionally driven, and constantly bumbling around major political issues. However, her intense loyalty to her home village and to her friend Kasia, and her instinct for somehow figuring out the right thing to do, remain in force.Through all the books action. And there is lots of action. Uprooted is one of those books where the characters seldom eat or sleep but somehow, remain strong enough not to only keep their wits about them but to constantly work strong magic. Or for the lesser characters, just to kill people with swords and arrows. This book keeps you reading fast enough to ignore not only a certain amount of predictability in the plot, but a certain amount of shallowness in the characters. The author throws in a couple of female warriors but other than them (maybe even including them), weve met most of the characters before in other books by other authors.If youre looking for a fun, fast, light, fantasy read, check out Uprooted.

I've read a number of Ms. Koval's Drylands stories in SF magazines and found them plodding and overly long for their plots.  So why did I buy *all* the volumes in the Glamour series to date and read them without any break except for short stories in SF magazines and nonfiction that I needed to read?  Probably because I'm always hoping for a genuinely good Austen follow-on and this wasn't the Drylands series.  And Im sure my dislike of Glamour in Glass is due to the cumulative effect of all the books.  But it took me many weeks to read this latest, a chapter at a time, looking for any excuse to do anything else by the end of the chapter.It's not just that the author tells but doesn't show.  She very carefully *explains* and *repeats* just in case the reader didn't get her points the first few dozen times.  The book opens with the author making sure the reader knows that in the previous volume, protagonist Jane, Lady Vincent had a miscarriage and now isnt sure if she can have children or even wants them, because if she had them she might not be able to continue her work.  I appreciate the effort to recap so the reader doesnt have to buy all the books.  But then, the author conscientiously works in these points every single chance she gets, throughout the book. Then, from previous books we know that Janes husband tends to overdo it when working glamour/magic, to the point of fainting and even on occasion to the brink of death.  His frailties, and Janes wifely admonishments not to overdo it, are constantly present. When Vincent collapses from exertion in yet *another* scene and Jane flutters round him *again*, and they have that wise little talk about marital control/cooperation yet *again*, I was going, no, please no, no, no, and put the book down yet again.  Then the glamour is a kind of ethereal weaving technique with the author constantly giving the names of the various knots, which are in a glossary, but who cares? Theres an awful lot of narrative consisting of Jane ties this knot, and then she ties another knot, and then her husband ties a knot, and on occasion other people tie knots, and then they tie them off. And on, and on, and on, and on, and on, and on, and on.  Its exactly like reading a technical manual, except theres no chance of learning anything useful.Meanwhile, aside from all the potentially thrilling action being rendered insufferably tedious in this manner, the characters are cardboard.  Readers will probably know the two protagonists' handful of characteristics from previous novels, and these people dont develop any further.  Theres a stock villain with a stock financial motivation. The henchpeople barely register as people. Theres Lord Byron, and the author assumes everyone knows what hes like already. There are a number of characters who extensively aid the protagonists, but their motives are unclear and their personalities nonexistent.  It's impossible to emotionally engage with these books.Avoid this book. Avoid this series.  If youve been hoping it will improve, it doesnt.  Oh, and Jane's fertility issues look like they're intentionally being left open for resolution in yet another book. My speculation is that because the Vincents constantly discover ground-breaking techniques, they will discover how a female glamourist can be a wife and mother. Giving the author the opportunity to beat the reader around the head with yet more social education about how this is a good thing. Because that's another problem--the author seems to think marital happiness, women working, and social diversity are things no one else has ever heard of before, so readers all need to be carefully educated, and educated, and educated . . .

My husband and I finally buckled down to cleaning our filthy concrete patio and driveway. This product works very well but you have to also apply abrasion, in our case a scrub brush.  This cleaner had no negative effect on the lawn.

I haven't eaten a Reese's peanut butter cup in years.  These are just like I remember, peanut butter, chocolate, salt, and sugar.  Their sole claim to wholesomeness appears to be that they are gluten free . . . This is a LOT of candy.  Buy this size for Halloween or Christmas or Easter, not for ordinary household use. Unless you have a really large family.

I'm middle-aged and I still get pimples and whiteheads. This scrub does a good job of cleaning my skin without being oily (oddly, there are some oily facial scrubs out there), which helps a lot in preventing pimples. I also adore the scent. Five stars.

Librarian Simon Watson doesnt have his life together. Nor his family home, a fixer-upper on a crumbling cliff above Long Island Sound. Hes unemployed, broke, and bad at relationships. A book dealer he doesnt know sends him a book that has his grandmothers name in it. Its a log book for Peabodys traveling circus, which dates back to the 18th century. Simon discovers the worrying information that women in his family line drown on July 24. His mother drowned on July 24, and considering that her act as a circus mermaid required her to hold her breath for about 10 minutes, hes always wondered how. His sister Enola works for a traveling circus reading tarot cardsno mermaid act, but their mother taught Enola and Simon breathing techniques. When July 24 approaches and Enola suddenly visits, acting troubled, Simon works to research his familys secrets and save her from what hes come to believe is a curse.Simons point of view alternates with those of Peabody performers Amos The Wild Boy and his lover mermaid Evangeline. The different narrative strains are handled skillfully, maintaining the readers interest without confusion.Its tempting to compare The Book of Speculation to The Night Circus, but the fact is, circuses and carnivals are just currently fashionable in fantasy (even when its marketed as mainstream fiction).

Thirteen-year-old Oliver Dalrymple (Boo), is a kid from a normal middle-class, Midwestern family. However, Olivers classmates dont consider him normal at all; they constantly torment him. Hes apparently leucistic (on the albino spectrum), and has Aspergers (on the autism spectrum). Hes also highly intelligent and deeply interested in science, which doesnt even endear him to his teachers. And he has a heart defect.Boo collapses in front of his school locker after, for the first time, faultlessly reciting the periodic table of elements hes striven to memorize. He wakes up in Town, which iswhat? a benign purgatory? A deitys science experiment? Its populated exclusively by American kids who died at the age of 13. (They wonder, are there other Towns for other demographics?) The kids live there for 50 years, without aging physically (though at least some age emotionally). Then they disappear towhere? Town mysteriously receives periodic deliveries of necessities, such as clothing and furniture, some of which look used/donated. And with strictly vegan food. But not with televisions, radios, and most other technology; nor does the library (to Boos sorrow) contain any science books. Some kids believe there are portals to the world of the living that they can use to visit their loved ones.Budding scientist Boo is eager to research all these questions. However, with encouragement from his counselor, long-time resident Mama Thelma Rudd, for the first time in his life he also makes friends. These include Johnny Henzel, a classmate who informs Boo that they both were shot by the same crazed murderer. Boo, Johnny, Thelma, and their friend Esther Haglund travel around Town to resolve the killers identity and at the same time, Towns other mysteries. And Boo records it all in a journal (this book) addressed to his beloved parents, hoping he can get it to them someday. The chapter titles are from the periodic table.This YA novel is very readable for adults. Its sophisticated, wryly humorous, suspenseful, and moving.

The "mildly scented" version of this wash does indeed have a pleasant, rather astringent scent.  I got it to use for myself because I am often irritated by soaps and shampoos. This works very well as a body wash for adults. It doesn't work well for me as a shampoo. Unlike babies, I put conditioner and gel on my hair and this doesn't get it off. But I recommend it as a body wash for adults with sensitive skin.

The Vorrh has been praised as an astonishing book by no less than Alan Moore. Partly because it's not a Tolkien knockoff--but many excellent contemporary works of fantasy aren't, including Mythago Wood, which this book reminded me of. However, it is staggeringly inventive. The Vorrh is an imaginary forest first envisioned by early surrealist poet and playwright Raymond Roussel, whose poems include "Impressions of Africa" (and who is also a character in this novel). It's ancient, trackless, dangerous, and reputed to contain not only cannibals but the Garden of Eden. Victorian/Edwardian style colonists live at its edge.In addition to Roussel, fictionalized real-life characters include photographer Eadweard Muybridge (whose photos definitively viewed the motions of animals, but who suffered from double vision after an accident) and Sir William Gull, Queen Victoria's personal physician. Fully fictional ones include the cyclops Ishmael, who was raised by robots; Cyrena Lohr, a blind woman who regains her sight after a fling with Ishmael; and the Bowman, who has forgotten his own name.The plot of The Vorrh does not have a simple linear or chronological path. It's the first book in a trilogy, so the next two volumes may clarify matters. Author B. (Brian) Catling says he has completed them but I could find no publication dates. He's also written a quartet (I'm not clear if it's related to the trilogy), and several other unpublished novels. All this in addition to being a professor of fine art, a sculptor, and several other artistic careers. Yes. Astonishing. But getting back to The Vorrh, I wouldn't blame you if you held off till the other volumes are published and read them all at once.  It's very immersive.

The Moon explodes suddenly, for no apparent reason, and deadly meteorite storms begin to pummel the Earth. Its inhabitants are faced with the prospect of their planet becoming uninhabitable in a couple of years. Pop scientist Dubois Jerome Xavier Harris is tasked with finding a solution. Space colonies?  Underground refuges? The world's nations set up a genetic ark in the International Space Station, but the station itself is struck by meteors, which annihilate much equipment, frozen embryos, and personnel.  The eventual survivors are the Seven Eves of the title, the mothers of future humankind.Thirty thousand years later, humankind is prospering in a ring of space habitats that orbit the Earth. The transformed Earth looks like a good place to establish a colony for some of the billions of people living in the habitats. What they don't know is that other humans survived in underground and undersea refuges. Their civilization is much less sophisticated than that of the space habitats, but they are already repopulating the Earth's surface.What with the time frame of 30,000 years and the length of 869 pages, SevenEves can only be called epic.  However, the abundance of action, intrigue, and science-fictional speculation kept me involved to the end of the book.

This was a perfectly decent region-free DVD player. Except:  Although I only watched a DVD only every two or three evenings, the player died after 7 1/2 months. It suddenly started emitting horrible grinding noises while freezing DVDs that had no problems in themselves.  My husband thinks it's the bearings. So I just had to order a new player.

Superposition is told in two strictly alternating viewpoints, in chapters clearly labeled Up-Spin and Down-Spin (until the last chapter when all is neatly wrapped up). In the Up-Spin chapters, protagonist Jacob Kelley narrates his arrest and trial for the murder of Brian Vanderhall. Vanderhall was a brilliant but obnoxious physicist who continued to work at the (fictional) New Jersey Super-Collider after Kelley left to pursue an academic career. In the Down-Spin chapters, the Jacob Kelley of an alternate universe/timeline narrates his version of events. He frantically searches for the real killer and for his wife and children, who have disappeared and who may be dead.Alternate universes/timelines, complete with people meeting themselves, are so very popular in contemporary science fiction that little effort is usually made to explain the science. However, author David Walton (an engineer at Lockheed Martin) explains the science in great detail. The explanations are simple, but frequent and at times lengthy. They are carefully worked in. Vanderhall has developed applications/software for quantum physics that enable the characters to do pretty much anything (deflect bullets, teleport, you name it) whenever the plot requires it. Vanderhall was aided by quantum intelligences whose motives are mysterious but whose actions are sinister. Kelley's Romanian brother-in-law/sidekick Marek calls them varcolacs, folkloric demons that, according to Wikipedia, can be either vampires, werewolves, ghosts, or goblins. That seems accurate enough; strip away the quantum explanations and you have flexibly useful alien monsters. Even more improbably, Kelley's defense attorney presents the quantum explanations to a jury; for example, the point where Vanderhall was both dead and alive.The book is so action packed that you don't really notice all the plot's improbabilities till afterward, when you take a breath and think about them. It is, however, noticeable that the characters are very flat. Both Jacob Kelleys go through many horrendous experiences. They frequently claim they are emotionally devastated, but that's mostly the author telling rather than showing. The geeky joys of physics and the less geeky joys of thrilling action come off as much more important.Despite my weak physics background, I enjoyed Superposition more than most very hard science fiction. However, I don't recommend it to readers who insist on a character-driven novel.

Reimagined fairy tales  are by no means new, so the issue is whether A Wicked Thing reimagines Sleeping Beauty well.  You wont quite find out by reading this book, because it turns out to be only the first in a two-book series.In this half, Princess Aurora of Alyssinia has slept for a hundred years, to be awakened by a kiss from Prince Rodric of the current ruling family and the news that her swift marriage to him is being arranged by his parents, King John the Third and Queen Iris of Falreach. Aurora is in a very difficult situation. Her family and everyone else she knew are dead. (And hundreds of strangers have kissed her while she was asleep.) She doesnt know her fianc. He seems nice, but weak. He knows that they are being manipulated by his parents, who have strong political agendas. The kingdom of Alyssinia has been suffering under their reign and Auroras awakening is legendarily supposed to cure all its troubles. Other people with political agendas in which they want to involve Aurora include Tristan, a member of a revolutionary group whom Aurora meets in a tavern. (Aurora is virtually imprisoned in the castle, but manages to sneak out at night.) Then theres foreign Prince Finnegan, who urges Aurora to flee with him. (Somehow, the royal family lets him speak with her unsupervised.) Since Wicked Things is something of a romance, naturally Prince Rodric, Prince Finnegan, and Tristan all have their charms and are potential love interests.Not an easy situation for anyone to cope with.  But Aurora is unbelievably spineless, even by historical standards. Surely she noticed some palace and national politics going on in her precursed life?  Surely, as a princess, she was taught how to cope with them, how to be firm when necessary? Surely, as a princess, she would have been told she would probably have to marry a stranger for political reasons?The language of A Wicked Thing is lovely. However, the plot gives the effect of a work that started out as one book, then was padded and left without a strong ending to conform to a two-book contract. Many of the characters are fairly flat except for Aurora, who is annoying. I really wanted to love this book because I love fairy tale retellings.  Maybe the problem is that I'm too old for a YA book. But Ive seen Sleeping Beauty retold much better.

I found Women of Will to be a very annoying book. It's not a scholarly analysis of Shakespeare's plays. It's not a concerted look at Shakespeare's theatrical company, his life, his times, or really anything. It's an undisciplined ramble where if the author feels like throwing in any observation she just does it. So we have paragraphs like, "The ways in which Shakespeare wrote about women fall roughly into five cycles. I call them five Acts because, odd as it may seem, the five cycles resemble the five-act structure in Shakespeare's plays. This leads me to ask, do our psyches develop over our lifetimes in five different movements (our minds, not our bodies; our bodies travel through the seven ages of man)--and is that why stories often have five phases?" And assertions like, "Many people think [Shakespeare's] sonnets are all conceit--all made up--there is no lover or beloved in life, only in imagination. But I don't buy it. If Shakespeare were not writing about life, he wouldn't be connecting so passionately to what he's saying." It's fully credible that Shakespeare--a married man who had extramarital affairs with people of both genders--loved one or a number of them. This is just a thoughtless riff instead of any serious examination of Shakespeare's relationships or any attempt to find out who any of the sonnets are about.I don't recommend Women of Will unless you are such a major Shakespeare fan that you will read absolutely anything written about his work.

I have no children, but I like good moisturizing body washes so I decided to try this one. It washes my sensitive skin well without irritation. However, it is not suitable as a face wash because it should not get into the eyes. The container is rather small, but you don't need to use much at once. As usual, the scent seems to be controversial. I like scented products unless the scent absolutely knocks me over the head. I found this product to have a pleasant, light floral scent.

Grace Keepers is "soft" science fiction, intent on examining a society and its characters. It reminds me of Ursula LeGuin's work. The setting is some world, whether Earth or other, where most of the land mass has been covered by rising sea levels.  Although the characters sense the gradual dwindling of the land and their already scarce resources, this is not a dystopia or a post-apocalyptic novel. People simply accept this as the way things are. There are two parts to society: the damplings, who live on ships and seafood, and the landlockers, who live on tiny plots of land, some of it "reclaimed," where the houses are on stilts.The book brings the two worlds together by means of the Circus Excalibur, which travels around the islands and gives shows in return for food and money. North, one of the two main characters, is the circus's bear trainer and performer, where part of the wonder is the viewing of a bear (the inference is that most species, especially large ones, are endangered). The other main character, Callanish, is the "grace keeper," or funeral director/priestess, for one of the islands. Other characters include Red Gold/Jarrow, the charismatic ringmaster/circus owner (and at around 40, old for this society); Avalon, his young, beautiful, self-centered, greedy, bitchy wife; Ainsel, his grown son from his first marriage; the acrobats/lovers Melia and Whitby; Flitch, a messenger who travels from island to island; and Odell, Callanish's alcoholic grace-keeper neighbor.One theme of the book is self-delusion. Red Gold is obsessed with the idea of his descendents returning to the land (which he left to marry his first wife). He believes this will give them not only higher social status, but wealth and happiness (even though the landlockers' lives are as hardscrabble as the damplings'). To this end, he wants to marry the bear girl North to Ainsel, a marriage neither desires, even though they've known each other since childhood. Much of the plot revolves around Red Gold's saving money for the very expensive land (while portions constantly disappear to police fines and bribes), and trying to pretend that North and Ainsel love each other and that North's pregnancy was caused by Ainsel. Red Gold firmly believes in the glamour of his circus, no matter how tattered it is. He also believes his wife is loving and kind.North believes in the love of her bear, even though it's a restive and dangerous animal. Callanish believes in the love of her mother and wants to return to her, even though her mother physically attacked her and made her a grace keeper (which is an exile and punishment). Fitch and Odell each believe that they can form a workable relationship with Callanish. As you'll guess, another theme of this book is loneliness.Aside from a number of circus members who are mostly background (because their functions are necessary to the circus), the characters are well-rounded and complex. Fitch, for example, could be seen simplistically as a condescending, exploitative, domineering male, but he does have some real feeling for Callanish and can behave well, as well as badly. Avalon is a type we all love to hate, but that's necessary to the plot. In part of the book, you can't tell whether Melia is sincere or whether she is acting, as she does so well.The marketing copy says that Grace Keepers is "inspired in part by Scottish myths and fairy tales." Actually, that is a very minor theme and you don't have to know any Scottish tales to understand the book. It does help to keep mermaids in mind:  Is humanity slowly adapting so that people can live both on land and in the sea?Five stars for this gentle, melancholy, yet ultimately hopeful book.

These are so bad for your teeth. There is so much sugar. I can feel the coating on my teeth after I eat these. But at the same time, they do taste nice. They are chewy and a bit citrusy. If you like lemon flavored candies, you will probably like these. They are pretty addictive though and you may find yourself scarfing down a whole bag quickly. Even at 14 ounces, these last a pretty long time. They took me about a week to go through and I was popping them like they were pills. I think that the price is reasonable if you have Prime Pantry.

I'm addicted to this foaming cleanser. It's got a nice neutral scent. It has a beautiful clean looking ocean blue color. I only use Method soaps in my home now. They are gentle and attractive. This bottle is also aesthetically pleasing. My house looks awesome despite having very little furniture inside because all of my items inside are accents. My water bottle are pretty. My soap dishes are fancy. My soap is Method. Would definitely recommend to those who like to have their house have Feng Shui

These are pretty healthy. I mean they are fig. I saw them first at Wegman's. A coworker actually gave me some to try. They taste more flavorful than you would expect from a healthy snack. I find them dense and chewy. The compact nature makes it hard to swallow without a drink. But the flavors are pleasant enough. I would give this 4 stars and I am a very picky eater. I will buy these again as a healthy alternative to junk food (such as potato chips or breakfast bars).

Used this once so far. It looks really professional and is a good value. You can use it to take notes and hold your resume. You will look more polished with this than with regular folders. I am impressed by the quality for the price. It's affordable for students that have just graduated and those who are trying to save money but still make a good first impression. I may get more of these for my relatives.

Inexpensive and works as expected. I bought this because I thought the price was reasonable for a rechargeable battery 4 pack. There were some that were much more expensive than this, which I did not like. I just needed some batteries that could be reused and not empty my wallet. I am using them in my xbox controllers. I think they charge pretty quickly. The indicator light lets you know when they are charging and also when they are done. This product is very straight forward to use and Energizer is a good brand. I haven't had issues yet.

I heard a lot of buzz around this, but wasn't sure what to expect. I mean it is about Nazi's and Japanese winning WWII. A pretty controversial alternate reality. The production value of the story is interesting. The main actors are pretty good. The storyline looks intriguing. Found this to be a great Prime find.

I like to look at food pics. I think I have some kind of disorder where I just enjoy staring at beautiful meals and documenting them. I take pictures of the food I eat. I have done it so much and talked about meals so much that I have ended up influencing my friends to do the same. Food & Wine has great photos of unusual meals. I am not sure if I will make all of these or any of these. Usually, the meals are very fancy. I would think this magazine is geared more towards really experienced chefs and not novices, in terms of recipes and advice, but it's still pretty for those who are food voyeurs. I think it would be cool if they expanded this magazine's scope and reach to include articles on food related tangents like their upcoming festival schedules, restaurants, cook shows, features on specific chefs, cooking show reviews, etc.  But maybe that's not their intent. Anyways, I am still giving this 5 stars because of the mouthwatering photos. I probably won't renew my order for it though because it is not my cup of tea.  It was very interesting and well put together though.

This is wonderful. I think Straczynski is a genius and he should write more screenplays, specifically for Superman. He manages to take a mythos that has been done a thousand times and change minor but important details to give the story a completely fresh take. His stories and characters manage to have more dimension than the original. I would argue that he really enhances the appeal of the whole Clark Kent/ Superman essence. Growing up, I watched everything Superman related: all the cartoons, all the movies (Christopher Reeves), Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman, Smallville, etc. I found this product to be superior to many of those listed and stronger in many ways.  I really enjoyed this addition to the superman legacy. I really hope that Straczynski  continues to write them and the artists continue to draw this.  It's a really engaging storyline. This comic is great for those who liked vol. 1 and vol. 2.  It picks right off from where it left off.  Let's petition for a vol. 4+++!

I really enjoy fortune magazine. I wasn't sure if I would... I read Forbes a lot. I also read some online magazines. Financial magazines can be hit or miss. Sometimes they are too technical or other times they are too fluffy. This magazine is a bit of a mixture of both. It does have some advertisement in it, which is clearly geared to hype up a company or sell you a product but they also feature interesting opinion articles. I like to read about the perspectives of different people who have made it and what their stories are. It's just nice to read in a layman fashion. I do not work in the financial sector and I am female. So, for my demographic, this was engaging.

I eat these like they are candy. They have vitamin C which is water soluble, so that's ok. I love the taste of these candies, I mean health drops. They really do help you during sore throat days or when your throat feels dry. They also make you feel less hungry sometimes when you are up late at night and want a munchie. It's good to just suck on a flavored lozenge and then you don't end up digesting too many carbs past midnight.  The halls defense pack is a solid oval shaped vitamin supplement. This version tastes like fruit juice with perhaps some added sugar. All of the citrus taste like the respective fruits they come from. (Ex. the orange tastes like orange, the grapefruit like a sweeter version of grapefruit, etc.)  This large pack will last you a good while, even if you are like me, popping them like crazy.

I don't sweep. I don't mop. I swifer. This product is really great. It makes it very convenient to wipe the floor. I prefer disposable wipes because it is really gross using the same mop head over and over to clean the floor. I don't want to reuse something that will just pick up dirt and grime and then become less effective over time. These Swiffer wipes are perfect for hardwood floors and laminate. I have used them on my kitchen, living room, dining room, and bathroom. They have picked up all kinds of dust, juices, hair, food particles, etc. It's really great. I would definitely buy more of this product again. I also like how they come in different scents now. Way to go P&G.

It's even better looking in person. I am weird. I took a really long time to shop for a blanket. Like abnormally long time.. I was shivering for several weeks because I couldn't decide. I didn't want to waste money and buy a bunch or return a bunch that I didn't need. I just wanted to get a warm enough blanket that I could throw around when I was feeling cold but didn't feel like turning up the heat in the house. The velvet plush is perfect for my purposes. It is soft and velvety. It is aesthetically pleasing, a bit of lighter shade of grey than what is pictured. It comes out of the wash perfectly fine (as long as you put it on gentle cycle and low heat).  It is a really good throw. I am happy too about the price point. It was less than $20 when I got it. I would definitely recommend it at lower then $20 price.

These tissues actually are a bit softer than regular Kleenex and also other no name brands. I didn't really notice the difference that much until I switched away from this to regular ones. I was trying to save money but as anyone who has ever had a cold knows, it SUCKS to have to use rough tissues. I rubbed my nose to the point my skin was peeling. It was all red and sore. That's just because the Kleenex I used before were really rough and not smooth. I much prefer now these ultra soft tissues. There is also I think an even more expensive version that is silken. That is really nice. Usually when you blow your nose, you need several sheets. So, any little irritation can be really annoying over a long time.  I would buy this ultra soft product again.

I like this icing because it is not too sweet. It does taste mildly like cream cheese, so there is a savory and sweet rich character to it. I find it to be the perfect topping for boxed cakes. The can is enough to top 24 cupcakes generously or 2 giant sheet cakes. The icing last a long time before you open the lid and peel back the metal tab. It lasts a few weeks once you've opened it for the first time. That's not bad for icing; considering the fact that icing is mostly sugar (food for microbes).  I would buy this again for sure.  Amazon's price with Prime Pantry is reasonable.

This toilet paper is appropriately priced for a large pack that is shipped to your house. Sure, you can get cheaper toilet rolls but then you would have to remember to go outside in the bitter cold of winter and pick up a huge box.  It can take up a lot of grocery bag space. I like to have my rolls delivered to my house for convenience purposes. I find this brand to be soft on tushies. The rolls last a decent amount of time. They don't have a bad scent. They look attractive. Would probably buy this brand again.

These are individually wrapped and super thin. They work well as liners. They make sure your underwear stays clean.  I know that sounds gross but you never know when you might leak!  If you laugh too hard, it could spill. These liners are super thin. They feel as light weight as a small piece of paper. That's great because you can carry a lot with you in your pocket or purse. They don't take up much space. They do their job. There are a lot that come in a pack.  I bought this from Amazon not knowing that it was a 2 pack. So, you actually get 240 of these. I think they will last a long time, assuming you go through a sheet a day.

These are really unhealthy probably. But they taste so darn good. I have gone through the box so quickly. I may end up ordering more. The strawberry and frosting are a bit sweet. But it is still awesome to have as a early morning breakfast or mid evening snack. Sometimes you just like to have something soft and warm and gooey to munch on. I find warming these in the toaster oven to much improve the flavor. I never eat these cold.  The smell of them cooking is also amazing. I will possibly get more of these by the time I am done typing this review.

Well, the good news is I am now eating breakfast. The bad news is it is because I am trying to get rid of these as fast as I can. The bars are ok. They are probably really healthy for me, even. I can taste the fruit and fiber. The issue I have with these are there is a LOT of fiber. I mean, I can literally chew the oats. It's really really really fibrous. I find the texture to be a bit unappetizing due to the fact that I have to chew flavorless oats before I can get to the fruity center. I wouldn't mind if the oats tasted a bit more like something, but they don't. They taste like oats. Maybe health nuts will love this bar.  But I am a firm believer that food needs to taste good. Even if it is healthy, it is possible to make it taste good. There are ways to add flavor without dumping in high fructose corn syrup. I think the food industry needs to just get more creative about it.

This watch is really expensive. I can't really afford it. But I got it anyways. Yay for my new years resolution to save more.  Anyways, I tried this out in the mall. It is really comfortable compared to ordinary leather straps. It is very light weight and perfect for extra small wrists and hands. I have very tiny wrists. Most watch cannot fit my hand because of it. If I ever got arrested by police, I am sure I could escape - that's how small my wrists are. Anyways, this watch is perfect for really tiny arms.It is made of really soft leather. It is not made of the fake/ cheap grade leather that rubs the skin the wrong way. It feels like it is made from the actual hide (1 piece) not a bunch of strips that have been plasticized together. The watch is also true to color. The black shown in the picture matches the black color in person. This is important to note because a lot of things don't look the same online through a computer screen verses in real life. I like that they didn't hire professional photographers to distort the image of the watch to make it look more marketable.The face of the screen has panels on it, which I presume are used to store the solar powered light. The watch was set once by me when it first arrived and has been fine ever since. It's accuracy rivals other watches. For those who are visually impaired, it may be difficult to see the demarcation on the watch face. They are thin silver strips that note the hours.  Fortunately, I am near sighted and not far sighted so it is not hard for me to read the watch. If you are far sighted, you probably will hate this watch.  But if you are near sighted and don't mind tilting the screen to reflect light, you can easily see the position of the watch hands.This watch matches all clothing. It is such a simple elegant watch. You can wear it to interviews or to the beach. It blends in with everything. That's what I like the most about it. It looks like it could either be really inexpensive or really expensive. That's how perfect the design is. It is the ultimate incognito watch.

I like these because they are inexpensive compared to the other sandals online. But I do think that for the material, it should not be $8.99. It could be cheaper. These are not super high quality. They are pretty standard bath slippers. The material reminds me of disposable plastic. I think they look as pictured, but the picture kind of makes it looks like it would be made out of softer material maybe.  The shoe will serve my purposes though as a travel shower shoe. I am paranoid of getting HPV or foot fungus. Hence, the purchase of these.  If you need a shoe to travel with that is useable for protection against germs, this may be it.

It looks like it is pictured and it comes on time.  I am giving it a 3.5 stars.It is just bigger than I thought, a lot bigger. I have small hands and it almost is the size of 1/2 of my hand.The rabbit is very flat and broad.  It is squishy like a soft flat pancake.

This tastes good. It is also soft and fluffy, as long as you don't over cook it. Be cautious of different cooking times based on altitude and ovens. I find this product easy to use and easy to reproduce. The only thing that I don't like is the yellow color. That's just a peeve of mine. It looks artificial to me. I wish they would pick another color that looks more natural. For some reason, I just can't get over how artificially yellow this cake mix is. Even bananas are not this yellow. I found this to be very artificial looking, even though it tastes fine. Can't they make this lighter colored, more like flour or something?

I'm loving this test prep book so far. I found this to be extremely useful. I haven't taken the new GRE yet. I plan to in a bit. The prep is good because there are a large variety of questions from the actual makers of the exam. I found that the format has changed a lot from the old exam. I took the old exam over 9 years ago. Now, I am trying to 'refresh' my memory on how math standardized exams work. This book is very helpful because it gives me actual questions that were used. It has the right 'difficulty' level for me to train on. The answers come in the back and have some explanation. You can use this as a study aid. I would definitely recommend this book if its the only test prep you plan on getting. I also bought the GRE full prep book from ETS so I can try that after I finish this. I have been slowly working on this for a couple of weeks. It's helping me jog my memory for sure.

I don't know if I will permanently switch over to the Always liners, since the Carefree liners are individually packed.  I only got this because it was on sale. I kind of regret getting this because I actually find it inconvenient to have them all unwrapped. I am afraid of dirt or germs getting on these. The wrapping on the carefree makes me feel better. Aside from that, this product works as described. It is the standard liner. The material is flexible and holds some liquid. It is soft.  The sticky side is not too sticky that it is hard to remove. The cushion is not irritating to the skin. You can even sleep with these on.  It is designed to fit briefs.

This blanket is really soft. I like the fact that it was inexpensive but also warm. You do get what you pay for but I think it is a good value because the product retains heat well and looks nice. It does not look luxurious by any means but it is attractive and comfortable. The insulation works as well as my Amazon down alternative blanket. I have put this in the washing machine a total of 1 time so far. It has withstood the wash. I put it on gentle cycle since other reviewers mentioned the threading can become undone if you wash it too much or too hard. I find the item to be exactly as pictured and reasonably priced. Therefore, I am giving this 5 stars.  The other similarly priced blankets currently available on amazon have lower aggregate and / or were described as not soft.

This variety pack is good for those who like Pop chips and want to try out all the flavors. I found some flavors to be superior to others, but this may be due to my personal preference. The BBQ flavor is their strongest in my opinion. I do like the fact that all their flavors taste different from one another. The popped chip is less oily and has a nice crunch. The chips themselves remind me of a cross between a cheese puff (minus the cheese) and a normal potato chip. I find them light and airy with an interesting texture. I would buy these again if they went on sale and/or had other flavors offered in a variety pack. This box may be too big for one person to eat alone. It may be more appropriate for large families. The expiry of the chips that I received were a few months out.

These scissors are sturdy and cut well. I use them to open packaging. I like the fact that they are sharp but with somewhat rounded edges and also plastic handles. The design is attractive. I find these to be light weight and easy to use. I have smaller hands and these are not a problem for me. They are made by a good brand, also.

This is small but it tastes good. Haribo bears are a bit firm relative to other gummies but they have a good taste to it. It is a little bit acidic and a little bit sweet. There is a variety of flavors. I like the 5 oz bag because they are not too large. It's hard to stop eating gummies once you have sampled some. I would buy this brand again when I am in a gummy eating mood.

I don't usually like chocolate flavor, nor chocolate flavored cakes but this was pretty good. I made mini cupcakes out of it. The cupcakes were all very moist and not too dry. They had even aeration in it, even though I used a fork to whisk it. I didn't use a blender. I basically beat this by hand and just followed the instructions. The cake is very easy to make and affordable. I would buy this product again. It is exactly as described. 4.5 stars (rounding up)

This is enough icing for 2 whole cakes. I bought this because I wanted to decorate some cupcakes but didn't think I had the time to make icing from scratch. The flavor of this icing is nice. It is not too sweet. It paints on easily. I found the flavor to taste like milk chocolate. There was plenty of icing. I would recommend this to others and would buy this again as a time saver.

I ran out of shows to watch during the Summer. I had seen a lot of commercials for Rizzoli and Isles in the movie theatres, but never actually saw any of it before until recently. I saw that it was in its 6th season and kept hearing about it.  One day I went on YouTube and saw the first episode. Angie Harmon is a really great actress! I started watching the show because of her and then started to like it. It is not really that great, like Elementary is, but it is decent enough. I think the show started to improve from season 1 to season 2, so I have hopes that it will be stronger.  I like the cast being females that get along as opposed to the traditional male dominated ones. When shows always make the male the hero, it can be trite. I like that there is some uniqueness to the storyline. The acting is good, in all the characters are pretty likeable.

This product just tastes okay. I have had other strawberry fruit strips that tasted sweeter. Maybe its because this is all natural that it just tastes ok. The coloring is greyish, which is more indicative of actual natural strawberries. Nonetheless, I do think taste is important too.  Good product if you like healthy snacks that are not too sweet.

Always is a really good brand, but they have been stepping it up with their engineering. Instead of settling for a middling product, it looks like they are improving theirs. This is a great sign!  I might buy some of their stock. The pads are soft and flexible. They absorb well. They are shorter than the overnight version. They feel like memory foam. They do not irritate your skin as much as some of the previous versions can with prolonged use. These are great pads. I highly recommend them. Also, really good are the Infinity Radiant Pearl version. Those are a bit more expensive but so worth it, too.

Although this is more expensive than 'normal pads', this is well worth the price. It is way more comfortable and soft on your tushy. It doesn't rub you the wrong way. You can easily wear this and feel like you are not wearing a pad. It absorbs a lot of liquid and provides huge coverage. I always buy these when I can. In fact, I stock up on these because I heard rumors that they might discontinue it. Always Infinity is so great. They really need to advertise it better because most people don't know about them. I only found out about them by chance because I think I had a coupon. The one up from this is Always Infinity Radiant. Those are amazing, too!  Super thin and flexible. Very comfortable. Incredibly absorbant. Who knew pads could be so wonderful?

This movie can be described as "Campy Fun."  It was pretty good for a free movie!  I would recommend this to those who are looking for something light hearted and Disney-esque.  The only thing that goes against it is the fact that there is somewhat adult humor scattered throughout. It may not be whole-ly appropriate for really young kids. Otherwise, this movie has decent acting. It also has superstars like Samuel L Jackson and big names like Jessica Alba in it.  The storyline is pretty basic. A new girl tries to fit in at a school, where she doesn't quite belong. She learns what is important and deals with relationships. The 'twist' is that she is a trained assassin. The movie is more like a comedy than is dark like Nikita. If you don't mind cheesiness than this one is good for a rainy day or late night.

The turkey pepperoni and cheese on crackers is one of their stronger variety packs. I like the taste much better than some of the others, which can be hit or miss. The cheese is of a cheese consistency. The flavor is not bad. The caramel lollipop tastes nice. The turkey slices add some protein and make this more filling. The nuts and fruit pack go well with the rest of this meal. Solid choice.

I believe Elon Musk will save mankind from extinction.  Mark my words.  This guy is a genius!!! But more importantly, he is using his huge brain to try and help solve world problems.  Not get rich quick problems, but WORLD SALVATION PROBLEMS.  Seriously, the sun is a dying star. Look it up.  We have maybe a few more thousand years on this planet. Our resources are dwindling.  Our food supply now depends on genetic modification. Traditional farming methods are not able to feed the masses. We polluting the oceans, killing the fish, toxifying the air, fumigating the sky and destroying our ozone. I can totally see how ONE extinction level event would be enough to wipe us off the face of the universe, if we don't do it ourselves with all the wars and socioeconomic battles we have going on right now.... Alas,  most people are concerned only about their daily problems (how to make money, live a comfortable life) and not their children's or children's children's (how to protect the planet, plan for the future).  We consume so much and not all of these are renewable resources.  Fossil fuels are depleting! WE are FRACKING.  Time to do something about it... Someone anyone.  Come up with a solution!!!!  "Colonize mars" says Mr. Musk.  Prior to reading this book, I would have thought this was lunatic talk. After reading this book, I totally believe Elon believes what he believes and it all makes sense.Just an amazing story.  I love the way this is written. I am only part way through it. I will update this review if anything changes, but so far this is really well written. I have had a hard time putting it down. It's just incredible what Elon Musk has gone through and how well Ashlee Vance tells his story. It reads like a movie. It is so easy to visualize. You can totally see, feel inspired, and want to do great things from learning about Elon's terrible childhood and obstacles he faced to what he has become today. It's awesome! I love tales like this because it is so incredibly motivational.You feel a lot from a biography. That's how you know the writer is talented.Today, I want to meet Elon! But since I am not rich nor famous (yet), I will have to suffice with this book.  To give some tidbits for people who are considering buying this, this book is for you if you like reading biographies and are curious about how great ideas are executed upon.  I love the fact that Mr. Musk was willing to share his story with the world. In my opinion, Ashlee Vance did a good job of describing a balanced point of view.
