So after a barbaric act committed by him and a few friends as young men, Ballin finds himself with a choice between a guaranteed short life on a distant mining facility or the possibility of an even shorter life aboard a starship in the Imperial Navy. In the end the choice is made for him, and he finds himself a lifer in the navy.Now a grown man and a lieutenant on the front lines, Ballin is unceremoniously appointed leader of a group of marine grunts setting out to rescue Princess Aeya from a local uprising on some distant rock of a planet. Not too happy being appointed the leader of the marines, and the marines not too happy with his appointment, Ballin finds a way to prove himself in the eyes of the grunts with his acts of loyalty to the troops. As a lifer, Ballin has little way of climbing the ranks in the Imperial Navy, yet his actions in the Princess's rescue sees him appointed the leader of all marines in the fleet.Now appointed to a new ship, the Cinesstar, Ballin finds himself the protector of not only the Princess but the Empress as well. After struggling to keep his crew alive under the horrible leadership of the ship's not so noble CO, Ballin finds a way to fight against enemy forces both within and beyond Imperial borders. As time goes on, it seems just about everyone is out to see the destruction of the Cinesstar. Forces meet in secret to hatch plans to see that death is brought to the ship, yet as time goes on it becomes more and more clear that the target of these assassin plans is not the royalty aboard, but Ballin himself. In the end we watch as one man, ripped apart and put back together again, finds a way to not only bring peace to his one ship, but to his people as well.Characters:Although there are plenty of great characters within the pages of Treasons, it is Ballin that is by far the most outstanding. Painted as a loyal soldier for the fleet, Ballin also proves himself an honor-bound man willing to sacrifice all for his crew and his ship. Ripped apart by war over and over again, Ballin reads more as a sacrificial combatant than a martyr for the cause, but as the page numbers go on, the reader will see that his character is not without flaw. In the end, our hero is just a broken man wiling to make the ultimate sacrifice for loyalty and peace.Writing:As a reader, we all want every book we read to be a real page turner, to be forced to stay awake long after our bedtimes. Here, in Choice of Treasons, we actually get a book difficult to put down; a rarity with books with such high page numbers. The characters in this book are very well refined and are written with incredible depth and meaning. Thankfully there is little in the way of filler, surprising given the 600+ page count, and every page is integral to the events on the next. And even though this is a space opera slash scifi book, the science fiction is left light so that the story can make for a more impactful presentation without being dragged down by irrelevant techno-babble.Conclusion:Although I initially delayed downloading this book because it is outside my usual Star Wars  Star Trek addiction, I enjoyed this book very much and look forward to the second installment out early 2016. The characters were brilliantly portrayed and the story was well crafted and presented. In the end the book achieved everything I look for in a great SciFi book and had all the elements that make me okay with the cover price. As someone who calls himself a huge fan of space operas, I recommend this to anyone looking for a good cat and mouse space drama.5 out of 5 stars from me.* I received this in exchange for an honest review.

Volume 12 is an extravaganza of G.I. JOE goodness. Plumb full of everything that makes ARAH so good, lines the pages of this volume from start to finish. Want all your favorite characters, and a few new ones too, to push the story forward? Get this volume. Want all your favorite vehicles that you pushed around your living room carpet as a child in one 100 page offering? Get this volume. Want to have a bit of a G.I. JOE - Transformer crossover? Get this volume. You want to see Larry Hama lay rest to one of the JOE's best characters in the absolute best way possible. Get this volume!This volume is an incredible read. From start to finish, Larry Hama's creativity had me glued to each page as I watched the JOEs overcome a terrible threat from mechanical monsters, one of them controlled by one of the JOE's greatest enemies. But the true heart of this particular volume lies within the send off for one of the greatest characters ever created, the JOE universe aside. Sacrificing himself for the greater good and his closest friends, he is given page after page after page of tribute, fitting for someone of his grandness.This is without a doubt a brilliant collection of individual issues. My only wish had been that the story had slowed down just a tad in the beginning as some of the combat against the mech units was a little too fast. But wow the tribute at the end will go down in JOE history.Get this volume today!*Product received in exchange for an honest review.

A little less than a year ago, I first heard that Karen Traviss was going to be writing for the JOE franchise. Having read her work in the Star Wars franchise and knowing that she is a more than capable writer, I was very excited to see what she could create in the JOE universe. This is mostly because she has an amazing ability to make her characters real. She does this by creating meaningful back stories, realistic personalities and abilities, and by giving them compelling and meaningful story arcs. Having this ability is something that she shares with the ARAH JOE creator, Larry Hama.However, the GI JOE created by Larry Hama is virtually nowhere to be found in the new IDW storyline. Yes, the JOE characters are present, and, yes, we also know that after years of IDW comics that these JOEs are not the ones we fell in love with in the eighties, but let there be no doubt that these JOEs in no way shape or form resemble the old JOEs.But pushing that aside, there are some great characters and great storylines within this issue. The characters are very mature, and the story is modern and unforgivingly real. This issue and the last read like a graphic novel based on a full fledged novel (something I wish Traviss would have been offered over a comic book storyline). The story is very fresh and original and pushed forward by great dialogue and intelligent world building. My only wish that this new JOE was actually that, new.With this new arch and this new feel, my opinion is that the tie to the Real American Hero world should have been severed and this production be called by a new name with new characters as this story really has nothing to do with the ARAH JOEs previously established. The other option is to have created a new JOE all together as done from the 60's JOEs and the 80's JOEs.So, in conclusion. This JOE is a great reimagining of the old JOE. With deep characters and realistic story arcs, Karen Traviss has brought a more adult feel to the Franchise. However, this isn't really a "A Real American Hero GI JOE" story and the only ties that bind it to the ARAH JOE are the character's names. Time for an actual reboot, or a renaming.Good book...not JOE.*Offered in exchange for an honest review.

At the end of Star Trek The Returned Part II, Peter David set the stage for the final battle between the forces he so carefully placed upon the chess board. Now, in Part III, we watch as those opponents square off in a nail-biting fight to the death.Meckenzie Calhoun, now free from his manic quest for genocide against those whom destroyed his race, is now face-to-face with his new enemy in an even more dangerous quest to prevent them from getting to the Milky Way Galaxy and to end their evil attempt to rid the Universe of all sentient life. Meanwhile, Robin Lefler and Mark Henry have now paired up in both their ongoing struggle against those who would see the death of young Prince Swan and against the all powerful Q. And last but not least, a once trusted crew member whom lost her trust and respect, works hard to regain it when life and death dangles by a thread.So the three main story arcs from the first two installments carry on into the third, but you may be asking why I would give this one only three stars when I gave the first to installments such high praise. Well, to be perfectly honest, Peter David crossed a line in this third one that I still have yet to forgive him for - and I read this over a month ago.In Part three, Peter David attempts to flip the script in many ways, both in story and in character plots. We watch as Mackenzie turned from being hellbent on destroying the race that destroyed his, only to be cut off at the knees by this new but extremely deadly force with incredibly well mannered speech. This introduction eventually showed Mackenzie the error in his genocidal rage, but it also took away his end purpose and taking away much of his purpose in the book. But that arch is the least of my complaints.Second is the interaction between Mackenzie and Soleta. It appears that Peter David didn't want to pull any punches in this trilogy and decided to push the envelope with his characters interactions. This event, which I won't describe in detail, was shocking to say the least. A violation so intense will leave some readers surprised at just how out of left field it is. But even though Soleta crosses a very wide line with Mackenzie, Peter David does find a way to sort things out in the end, and most is forgiven between the characters. But last is the offense I have yet to forgive.About half way through the book, Peter decides to push the envelope as far as it will go. Q and Mark Henry finally have their dual, a dual that Peter cleverly lays out in a way that harkens back to the old TNG TV days. But the interaction between Q and Henry is not where my issue lies, rather in an act that Q perpetrates on young Prince Swan in a scene that I will describe below. If you wish not to read the spoiler jump one paragraph down.In this scene, Q, as described by Peter, assaults young Swan in a very aggressive manner that is completely out of norm for Q. In a battle with Robin and Henry, Peter describes not only the dropping of the child but also the removal of the babies lungs, a scene that leaves the young child gasping for air with nonexistent organs. In all my years of following Trek and being a fan of Q, I have never known him to be cruel for cruel sake. This scene is way outside his established personality and has no place in his character. I'm not sure why Peter found it necessary to have this scene included, even though the ending of Part III tries to iron it out, but to me it is so over the top and not at all what Q is that it has left me offended to this very day.So, even though Part III has many issues that take some of the shine off of what Part II and Part I set up, it is still one of Peter David's better works. There are things I would have not done, and many things I would not have thought of, but in the end this series is true to what the New Frontier has always been...fun.A decent ending to the series. Give it a read.*Offered in exchange for an honest review.

When shopping for protein powders there are a few things that are always questioned. First, does this actually absorb into whatever we are mixing it into? And, yes, it does mix well with liquid. Second, does it taste okay? I used this with milk and was quite surprised on just how much it tasted like chocolate milk even though it isn't labeled as such. It has a rich, natural taste that doesn't taste like chalk or chemicals. Third, does it have an aftertaste? No, not really. It does leave traces if you heavily mix it into whatever liquid you choose, but washing it down isn't an issue. Forth, does it actually work? This is where I cannot give you an answer. I take protein powders to help with my extreme metabolism and add weight I wouldn't otherwise maintain, but because I also have Pyroluria, I am also very sensitive to copper, so much so that I cannot often drink well-water because of its copper levels. I think that is why I react badly to this product because it is farmed with copper levels that exceed my personal limits. But even though this doesn't work well with my health condition, I know that if it did it would be my protein powder of choice. With its rich taste and its ability to easily mix well with milk, I would choose this over all other brands.*I received this item in exchange for an honest opinion.

]Minor Plot Spoilers Ahead[At the end of The Returned Part I, we left off with Mackenzie Calhoun and the crew of the Excalibur successfully navigating their way through a wormhole and into a previously unexplored pocket universe. Once through, the crew find Mackenzie's arch enemies, the D'myurj, ruthlessly slain by a yet unknown enemy force. Now, surrounded by the broken corpses of those he, himself, came to slay, he is now faced with an even greater threat to himself, his crew, and potentially the universe from which he came. Who are these savage beings able to reap such destruction upon the race that slaughtered his own kind? Will he and his crew face the same fate as the Excalibur sensors pick up an incoming ship on long range sensors? And will this new threat end his quest for vengeance?But the questions that surround Mackenzie Calhoun are just one of three major storylines that The Returned Part II offers. Back home in the Milky Way galaxy, Robin Lefler and Mark Henry also have their fair share of going-ons, as Robin and Mark continue to repel the enemies of the young prince Swan. New found attractions and the acts of kindness open new doors for the duo along the way, too. And power struggles and fate twist the futures of many once and future kings, as The Awesome hand picks the head unto which the crown sits.But danger on the horizon is far from the only thing that The Returned Part II has to offer, as Peter David intertwines his usual sense of humor, suspense, and out-of-nowhere plot twists along the way. You think you were surprised at the cliffhanger in Part I, well just wait til you see the cliffhanger ending in Part II!The Returned Part II is a great second entry in to the three part series and builds a lot of suspense and anticipation for Part III, but I would be failing as a reviewer if I did not point out some of the shortcomings of the second installment. For me the Calhoun story, and the Lefler story are great story arcs, my issue is with the enemies that Mr. David has created in this offering. The savage and barbaric enemy force that Calhoun is now faced with reads very unevilish (and, yes, I know that isn't a word). In fact every enemy in this pocket universe(and sometimes out of it) is the nicest group of mass-murders one can think of. They read the polar opposite of what every evil villain that has come before should read as. And, yes, Peter David does create his characters to be vastly different than most found in other books, and that is why we love him, but here they read off. Now this makes for a more threatening force when the enemies contradict their established ways, but to me anyways, I would have preferred a slightly less non-threatening cast of villainy.Overall, I love this second installment and look forward to the third with great anticipation. Read it.Four stars.*Offered in exchange for an honest opinion.

Star Trek The More Things Change is at its core, a one act play set on a single stage. When a Trill commissioner takes ill it is the responsibility of both Spock and Doctor Christine Chapel to race her to medical help aboard a Trill star ship. But nothing can ever be so easy in the Star Trek franchise, as a mysterious foe attempts to halt their shuttle and board them. It is Spock that must keep the small shuttle space-worthy and on course to their Trill rescuers, and Doctor Chapel whom must keep her patient alive long enough to reach them.Written in novella form (short story), Star Trek The More Things Change focuses heavily on three main story arcs. The first is that the small three person group must get to their destination. This simple act makes for compelling storytelling as it focuses the reader on a simple aspect of the story and resists overextending the book into filler. It also connects the reader more strongly to the characters and their personalities, trials, and tribulations. In a more focused story, the reader gets to delve deeper into the characters inner thoughts, feelings, and connections to their world.The second story arc is the setting. With ninety-five percent of the book set within the confines of the shuttle, the story leaves behind complex story arcs and focuses the reader on a single environment. This single stage also allows for the environment itself to become a character. In this book the shuttle's constant need for mechanical repair, and the constant barrage of fire it is under, make it a source for sympathy for the reader. Will it hold out long enough to reach its destination? Will Spock be able to keep it alive long enough to carry it precious cargo to safety?And of course the third major story arc is the predator constantly stocking them for no apparent reason. This story arc will be the cliff hanger, the climatic mountain that sets up the finale. In the end we see just who this faceless, nameless enemy is, and the revelation is in tone with the Trek universe.So even though this book is short in nature, it is big in story. Secrets are revealed, love is found and lost, life is protected, and the evil foe meets their destiny. Some may find the one stage environment a little claustrophobic, but I found it refreshing as a reader and appreciated the focus it gave the story. My only issue with the book is that the ending surrounding the enemy battle seemed to be clipped a little too fast and neat. Perhaps an extended battle scene that drew out the finale just a tad bit more would have been fitting.All-in-all a good read. Four stars.* I received this book in exchange for an honest opinion.

The Clone Wars era has never been a huge draw for me, but that time frame does has a few big characters that can get even the most casual Star Wars fan excited; one being Darth Maul, the other being Asajj Ventress.Asajj, the once Sith apprentice of Count Dooku and member of the Nightsisters, saw her storyline vanish into thin air as The Clone Wars cartoon left the airwaves. But despite the cartoon's cancellation, Asajj fans demanded a continuation to her story. With that, author Christie Golden was tasked to bring Asajj's cartoon tale to print form.Long time readers of the Star Wars franchise know that Christie Golden is no stranger to the SW universe given her prior introduction near the end of the old EU and scheduled, but canceled, release of the Jiana Solo stories that were to take place after the events of the Fate of the Jedi series. Readers of her prior work, both in the Star Wars franchise and outside of it, know that her talents are best used when focusing on more heartfelt tales. So, with that in mind, we should find, and in my opinion do find, that the combination of a previously written tale for Asajj by the cartoon crew and Christie Golden's writing skills make for a deep and meaningful tale.]General plot points ahead with very minor spoilers[The tale itself is a simple premise. The Jedi council, faced with the prospects of losing the Clone War to Count Dooku and his yet unknown Master, are forced to consider a more confrontational plan of action. A Jedi, a master Jedi, must be chosen to hunt down Dooku and end his reign of terror. It is this plan that is the root of the book: and it is a story that will test not only the resolve of the Jedi Council, but of the reader themselves. But hunting down the elusive and powerful fallen Jedi will be no easy task. But there is one whom can make the nearly impossible possible, and that one is Asajj Ventress.]More aggressive plot points ahead with some spoilers along the way[I will not be giving away the whole plot of the book in this review, but there are plot points and story arcs that must be addressed. First is the root story of the book, the plot to hunt down Dooku. This plot idea, in my opinion, is a strong one. It is a plot idea that we haven't quite seen in a Jedi driven tale before. Now, to refrain from giving the whole plot away, I will just say that the premise of the Jedi "hunting" down Count Dooku is one that must be handled with great care and sensitivity. The Jedi we know and love have centuries of tradition and moral restraint that must be adhered to. For me, I can sense that both the cartoon writers and Christie Golden had trouble maintaining tradition but also executing the plan. The book struggles to find the balance between the Jedi code and the action needed to be taken to save millions, if not billions, of lives. It is this struggle that will surprise some readers with just how far some Masters will fall to achieve the goal, and it will surprise even more with just how far the Council will join in that descent.But this struggle to maintain a moral balance in the Council's plan radiates outward to every main character in the book as well. I sense that some readers will be tasked with the roller coaster feel as the main characters seem to switch their loyalties like the sides of a coin flipping through the air. But where some of this unbalance harms the book, it also helps it in a way. At the core of the book is a love story, a love story that reflects what most love stories do...tragedy.But one can not have a one sided relationship. In comes Master Vos.Vos is a little known Jedi both to fans and to other characters in the book. He is a man that lives in the shadows, an infiltrator, a spy. It is these talents that make him the perfect candidate to connect with the once apprentice of his main target, and connect they do. It is this interaction that will have many readers guessing until the end. Is Vos's unique talent to infiltrate just a tactic to win his way to Dooku through Ventress? Is his willingness to follow her into darkness a ploy to attain his goal? Will his brush with the darkside end his connection to the Jedi way or is it just another avenue to ending the savage reign of the Count.It is this imbalance, this willingness to swap loyalties that will both infuriate and intrigue readers. Just how far will the main characters and the Council fall down the rabbit hole before they lose the war and themselves? Will you side with the tactics needed to achieve peace or will you reject the premise that the ends justify the means? But whatever choice you make as a reader, the story has some surprises along the way. Some will make you mad, some will make you happy. Some will pull at your heart strings and others will leave you an emotional mess. But at the end of the day that is what books are for and some measure that emotional tug of war as a measure of just how good a book can be.A good book with meaningful story arcs, but a book that , at times, struggles to properly set up those arcs and stay connected to events that happen later in the franchise.A good book. Read it.*I received this book in exchange for an honest review

It's the return of Mackenzie Calhoun, the fearless Captain of the USS Excalibur and husband to Starfleet Admiral, Elizabeth Shelby. But what Captain Calhoun returns to is emptiness. The kind of emptiness that can torture an ordinary man's soul. The kind of emptiness that can crush an ordinary man's spirit. But Mackenzie Calhoun is no ordinary man, he is the man thrust into the folds of rebellion after witnessing his father's execution. He is the man that liberates his home world from evil oppressors at the mere age of 20. And he is the man who will reap his revenge upon the ones that slaughtered his people.But the road to vengeance must start somewhere, sometime. And what better place than here on the barren surface of Xenex? What better time than now? Surrounded by the memories of a planet once full of life, Mackenzie Calhoun can only now look over the desolate land in search for any indication that one, if he could be only so lucky to find one, a single survivor beyond himself. But the extinction of his people is undeniable, he is the last, the only, a fact that is only accepted after it is carried to his ears by the voice of his wife. But with acceptance comes action, and with Mackenzie Calhoun action is only a matter of time.Time. It is the force that controls the past, the present, the future. It's linear heritage spans countless generations before and will span countless generations after the flash in the pan that is Mackenzie Calhoun. However, time's iron like grip on the events of the universe is not without weakness, without manipulation. And it is with that knowledge that Mackenzie Calhoun finds himself staring at the Guardian.It is the mechanical construct left behind by some long forgotten alien race. It is the mechanical construct that is the key to unlocking the future return of his people. Oh how easy it would be to simply walk back in time and warn his people of the coming doom. To prepare them for the war that is about to be upon them. But why stop there when the options are limitless? But time is a beast not easily tamed. One right move could save his people, while one wrong move could cost them much more than just their lives. It is a tough choice to make. Will he risk the timeline to save his people, or will time retain the memories of the past?But Mackenzie Calhoun will not be the only one faced with hard choices. Will the proud Starfleet Admiral put her career on the line for marriage and love? Will a once Romulan spy recover from her permanent slumber and awaken only to violate her loyalties to her new crew? Will the son of a mother be turned over to murders to be raised as their leader? And will the son of a father succeed in his quest to murder the one that created him?These are just a few of the many questions that Peter David lays out in the first installment of The Returned. You will read as leaders return to the positions they rightfully hold. The return of crewmen once feared gone to illness, injury, or ascension. The return of unimaginable threats only to find there are bigger and badder predators beyond the shadows. But most of all, you will watch as one of the most prolific authors returns to what he does best, create.A stellar story that reads true to past works.*Product offered in exchange for an honest review.

In years gone by, we as Star Wars fans have been tempted by fancy covers and advertisements for books featuring the dark Lords of the Sith taking leading roles in 300 plus page books. And, of course, once we crack the covers of those books, we find stories heavily geared towards other characters and superficial, stereotypical tales of our favorite villains only getting a few chapters along the way. Here, in Lords of the Sith, written by Paul S. Kemp, we actually get what the cover and the ads have promised.Lords of the Sith is one of few books that actually provides a story for the dark Lords and gives progress to their characters. With a compelling storyline and in depth character interaction, Lords breaks the mold of stories past and leaves behind the stereotypical dark cloud riding in to correct the failings of pathetic imperial  officers and incompetent stormtroopers.Warning  Minor Plot detail ahead.The story: Lords main focus takes place soon after the budding rebellion takes root. The tide is beginning to turn for the Imperial power share, and the Emperor has taken note. Always a seer of coming events, the Emperor leaves the safety of deep Imperial space and joins Lord Vader on a trip to the new front lines  an unusual occurrence to say the least.Meanwhile, a group of Twi'lek rebels, lead by the father of the new rebellion  and the father of someone else we know well  has been given intelligence of the coming visit. This is the opportunity he has been waiting years for, the opportunity to strike a heavy blow to the Empire. But destroying an Imperial Star Destroyer carrying a diplomatic contingent would be a great blow, destroying an Imperial Star Destroyer carrying the Emperor and Lord Vader themselves would be a death blow, and this is that opportunity delivered hot and fresh.The goods: Lords, with Paul S. Kemp at the helm, delivers meaningful characters that leap from the page, but, where most Star Wars books fail, Kemp is able to deliver compelling character descriptions and tales to the darker side of the Force as well. The Emperor is no longer the evil old man relegated to the confines of his chair on the death star bellowing dark orders and mystery with an evil laugh. Here in Lords, we watch as the Emperor himself takes an active role in the story and channels a sort of Yoda-esk quality along the way through action packed fighting scenes and Force frenzies. But beyond a more physical story for the Emperor, we also see a more personal side as well with his old friend Vader. As the story progresses, we watch as Kemp explores both the rule of two and long history between the two characters.The bads: I think most readers will be absorbed by the first half of the book. The Twi'lek storyline is fast paced, action packed, meaningful, and has a bunch of hidden Easter eggs for the devote fans amongst us. But I also believe most fans will be somewhat disappointed as the book crosses the fifty percent mark as the action and depth start to fade away as compelling story arcs give way to more lackluster bug chases and cave dwelling fight scenes. Although the book is still good with the lesser climatic storylines in the later half, this bridge from the first half of the book may be a little hard for some readers to cross. This transition from first half to second half also sets up for a less compelling finale, as the characters that were the main feature of the first half have been somewhat absent in the arc of the second, an absence that hurts what should have been a more meaningful ending.Overall, Lords, is one of the better books that has been released recently. In my opinion this one is the best since Kenobi, and is very deserving of a read by both fanatic fans and the occasional visitor. Perhaps it could have used a little more editing and a little more focus near the end, but don't let that dissuade you from giving it a read.Five stars and a standing ovation for Paul S. Kemp.

I think the most asked question about this book will be, "Is this book anything like I, Jedi?" and that is a fair question to ask. Given that I, Jedi set the standard for first-person perspective writing in the old EU, it is the foundation for first-person books written after, and I guess the short answer to that question would have to be no, but that doesn't make it bad.Heir to the Jedi is set in the era between Ep IV and V, and continues to tell the tale of young Luke Skywalker. In this time period, Luke is still that young farm boy from Tatooine, full of gung-ho spirit but also naivete. This is where Heir to the Jedi's story comes into play. Most, I feel, will not really take to this book because it reads thin, almost sophomoric, especially for an accomplished writer. But once you have finished the book, I think you will come to the same conclusion that I have and see that this lack of deep plotting better serves the time frame, and immaturity of Luke, that the story takes place around.The story itself revolves around Luke teaming up with a young woman to track down and rescue a brilliant mathematician before the evil Empire can get their hands on her. Overall this story is somewhat lackluster on itself, but if you walk into it with somewhat low expectations, the book will read like a rainy day book instead of a must read. Now some may find that unexceptable and be critical of it, but in the end the book is really neither really good nor really bad...it's okay good.The strong points offered can be found in Luke's inner thoughts. Again, given the time frame don't expect anything too deep, but do expect to see Luke from a different perspective than most books can give. Another strong point is seeing things from Luke's point of view.Some of the book's low points would be around a somewhat forced love interest that seems rushed and very thinly setup. The book feels very one sided given it's first person perspective, but I'm sure more points of view could have been provided through better dialogue. The author had a firm grasp on the characters written, but the story itself neither provided them avenues for greatness nor deep enough plots to make the reader connect to them when they were lost.For me this book fits in okay with the other Empire and Rebellion books. Given that this series of books is neither blockbuster nor gangbuster, it fits in just fine.Read it. Expect little going in. Soft four stars.*I received this in exchange for an honest review.

Upon receiving this item, there were three main questions I had for this item. The first is, will this item maintain an already chilled liquid and for how long? The second was, will this chill a liquid that is at room temperature and by how much? The third was, will this item leave an aftertaste if left in the liquid? So lets break down each question in a more in depth way.Question 1: Will this help maintain a liquids already chilled temp and for how long.I took two bottles of tap water and placed them in the refer over night. I also did the same with the Vinomio Chiller in the freezer. I then placed both bottles on the table at room temperature and measured one with the Chiller and one with out over a span of four hours...and here are the results.Room Temp was 62.5 degrees.Hour 0: Water temp was 36 degrees.Hour 1: Without the Chiller was 47 degrees. With the Chiller was 44 degrees.Hour 2: Without the Chiller was 53 degrees. With the Chiller was 52 degrees.Hour 3: Without the Chiller was 59 degrees. With the Chiller was 59 degrees.As you can see by the results, the Chiller has little effect maintaining temperature over a span of three hours, but that is not unreasonable, here is why. Room temperature is constant and will continue to transfer that constant temp to a chilled item. Without a constant reintroduction of a lower temp item, the water will continue to rise. Given this Chiller rod is very small and is covered in Stainless Steel, the temperature of the room will overpower the ability of the rod in short order. I think a better test is how much heat transfer will occur when warm water is "chilled" by a cooler rod, so let's test it.I allowed a bottle of water to reach room temperature over night and also placed the Chiller back in the freezer over night, too. Then the next day, I placed the rod in the room temperature water to see how much the water will cool and how long it will take it to chill to its max limit. Here are the results.Hour 0: Water temp 62 degrees. Then placed the frozen rod in the water.5 Min later: 57 degrees10 Min later: 57 degrees15 Min Later: 58 degrees20 Min Later: 59 degrees30 Min later: 61 Degrees40 Min later: 62 DegreesSo the Chiller can reduce the water by 5 degrees and hold it at a lower temp for 40 minutes.And finally, will this leave an aftertaste? No, it does not.As you can see by the test results above, the Chiller has some effect, but little at best. So where does that leave us? Well, for the most part, the Chiller does not meet its advertised promise of "Keeps your wine chilled to perfection" and is better than a dripping pan that bottles are usually kept in. Perhaps in regards to being a cleaner, no-drip, item, the Chiller is better, but given its small size one should not expect either a large chilling effect or a chilling effect that lasts over a long period of time.And I think that is where the problem lies, the Chiller is just too small to handle any amount of fluid much larger than itself. There are items that are similar to this that may work better, such as stainless steel ice cubes that can better chill fluid because of their size in comparison to the amount of fluid placed around them...but I'll leave those tests and comparisons to you.In short, the Chiller works, but not to the limits on would expect.A solid three stars from me.*I received this item in exchange for an honest review.

From the back of the card.Series 1 #6Armaments: Medium-Range Sludge-Firing 105mm Mortar CannonSpecial Equipment: Doplar Radar Scanners and Lock-Target Range Finders with Integrated Thermal Tracking MetersCurrent Deployment: Eco-WarriorsThe Septic Tank smells like a cross between burning oil and a backed-up sewer pipe. The scent of it it alone is enough to send most men in retreat. Arm it with an unlimited supply of the most vile and lethal toxic sludge ever devised, and G.I. JOE is in trouble. This Cobra ordnance unit should not be engaged without a heavy supply of G.I. JOE Anti-Tox. Get even a teaspoon of the sludge on you and it's like swan diving into a pool of battery acid.Impel does a great job bringing these vehicle cards to market with original artwork and a great presentation on quality materials. I'm glad I purchased these, and I think you would be too.

From the back of the card.Series 1 #103The Lower Depths-The JOEs were in the sewers of New York City investigating Cobra activity. They discovered the Dreadnoks, along with a troop of Vipers, planting canisters of nerve toxins. The Freadnoks fled, but the JOEs followed the canisters' detonator wires. They stumbled upon a group of homeless people living in an old, abandoned subway station. They convinced one of them, an old army sergeant, to help them find Cobra. The Sarge led them to a hub of Cobra activity below a telephone company building. Discovered by Cobra, the JOEs retreated. Cobra began detonating the canisters, which only turned out to be stink bombs. But the JOEs didn't catch on that the canisters were just a decoy so Cobra could tap into the phone company's lines.Impel's decision to include Special Mission covers and breakdowns shows just how much Impel really focused on the whole of the franchise. Perhaps not the focal point of the G.I. JOE franchise given the actual characters and vehicles take center stage, but these Special Mission cards are much needed to complete a fans collection.

From the back of the card.Series 1 #85Burn-OutStalker, Leatherneck, Slip-Stream and Crank-Case were sent to the war-torn Middle East to rendezvous with the mercenary pilot Deke. Deke provided them with the locations of Colonel Sharif's surface to air missile sites (SAMS), but was later captured by Sharif. He found out that there was one site he hadn't known of, and escaped. At a nearby airbase, the JOEs were accomplishing the real mission objective - to steal the latest Russian aircraft, a YAK-36. However, the YAK was not prepared for flight, so the JOEs commandeered a Russian condor plane - and hid the YAK inside! Meanwhile, Ace and several other jets were taking out the SAMS nearby, but the one Deke hadn't known about was hidden at the end of the airfield the JOEs were trying to take off from. Deke stole a jet and flew it into the SAM, losing his own life, but allowing the JOEs to escape.Impel's decision to include Special Mission covers and breakdowns shows just how much Impel really focused on the whole of the franchise. Perhaps not the focal point of the G.I. JOE franchise given the actual characters and vehicles take center stage, but these Special Mission cards are much needed to complete a fans collection.

They posed as fisherman aboard the Swedish Trawler Christina to recover a disabled U.S. submarine. But the October Guard, the Soviet equivalent if G.I. JOE, and Cobra had both learned of the disabled sub and sent aerial support to the scene. The October Guard helicopter, Diana in charge, engaged in combat with Cobra FANGS, led by the Baroness. Once again, the two teams clashed. Meanwhile, Torpedo and Wet-Suit slipped aboard the Russian vessel and got its captain, Capt. Bulgakov, safely off board. It was revealed that the JOEs had intentionally leaked false information about a sub to the two other teams to create a diversion while they picked up Bulgakov - who was defecting.Impel's decision to include Special Mission covers and breakdowns shows just how much Impel really focused on the whole of the franchise. From the back of the card.Series 1 #93Sheep's Clothing-The JOEs were sent to Frankfurt, Germany, when four terrorist thieves took hostages at the U.S. Post Exchange. The thieves planned to drive the armored car to the airport, where they would rendezvous with a plane hijacked by associated terrorists. The JOEs caught their guards unawares and quickly overcame the unsuspecting thieves. The JOEs then disguised themselves as the thieves and continued on to the airport. As the JOEs did drive-by survey of the house, they saw a couple sitting at a table and a couple standing. Assuming the two standing were the terrorists, the JOEs prepared a plan. Lady Jaye approached the front door, posing as a saleslady. The woman who was seated answered the door, and Lady Jaye tipped her off that the JOEs were here to rescue her. But it turned out that the JOEs had it all backwards, and the woman shot Lady Jaye. Meanwhile, Shockwave had entered through an upstairs window, taking out a terrorist who was holding a boy. In his camouflage fatigues and face paint, he's invisible to their eyes.These 1991 Impel cards are really well made and are printed on high quality stiff cardboard. The artwork is all original and well done. I'm glad I picked these up and think you will be too.

From the back of the card.Series 1 #129File Name: Krimov, Anatoly FyodorovichGrade: CaptainBirthplace: Odessa, Ukrainian Soviet Socialist RepublicPrimary MOS: Commando Operations (Naval Infantry)Special Training: Black Sea Regiment Soviet Naval InfantryCurrent Assignment: October Guard CommanderHeading up the Soviet equivalent of the G.I. JOE team could be a pretty cushy job. But Red Star doesn't want parades, medals and a statue of himself on Red Square. He wants results. Which is probably why he's the best soldier the Russians have ever seen.These 1991 Impel cards are really well made and are printed on high quality stiff cardboard. The artwork is all original and well done. I'm glad I picked these up and think you will be too.

From the back of the card.Series 1 #30File Name: Hinton, Marvin F.Birthplace: Biloxi, MSBranch: U.S. ARMYGrade: E-5Primary MOS: Heavy Machine GunnerSecondary MOS: CookRoadblock prefers cooking to brawling, but is excellent at either. He was working as a bouncer in hopes of making enough money to go to school in France and became a gourmet chef, but was talked into enlisting. Although appalled by military menus and preparation techniques, he still became a great cook. Not only can he pack the biggest, meanest machine gun, but he can create exquisite meals out of simple K-rations.These 1991 Impel cards are really well made and are printed on high quality stiff cardboard. The artwork is all original and well done. I'm glad I picked these up and think you will be too.

From the back of the card.Series 1 #136File Name: Groen, Christopher R.Grade: E-6Birthplace: Helena, ARPrimary MOS: NAVY S.E.A.L.Secondary MOS: Underwater Arms DeveloperSpecial Training: Advanced InfantryCurrent Assignment: ClassifiedTracker can pick up trails that a bloodhound would have trouble spotting. He's fast, methodical, and can track Cobra on water as well as on land. That's pretty good for someone who grew up in a Midwestern town where the biggest body of water was a small creek nearly five miles away. Add to that the fact he can hide as well as he can track, and you've got a soldier who can give Snake-Eyes and Storm Shadow a run for their money.These 1991 Impel cards are really well made and are printed on high quality stiff cardboard. The artwork is all original and well done. I'm glad I picked these up and think you will be too.

From the back of the card.Series 1 #65File Name: Owens, Cory R.Grade: E-4Birthplace: Wichita, KSPrimary MOS: DemolitionsSecondary MOS: Artillery CoordinatorCurrent Assignment: DemolitionsLight Foot has made being careful an art form. Sure he's got an airfoil-powered robotic mine detector with a digitized oscillating frequency module and a built-in geiger counter/spectrometer and scintillometer to help him look for land mines in the field. But then, finding an antipersonnel mine is the easy part. Getting it out of the ground and disarming it is where Light Foot really earns his keep.These 1991 Impel cards are really well made and are printed on high quality stiff cardboard. The artwork is all original and well done. I'm glad I picked these up and think you will be too.

From the back of the card.Series 1 #23File Name: Skoog, Tormod S.Birthplace: Hibbing, MNBranch: U.S. ARMYGrade: E-4Primary MOS: Explosive Ordinance DisposalSecondary MOS: DemolitionsA high school dropout, Tripwire is a very clumsy person for the most part. He spent two years in a Zen monastery but was expelled for breaking and spilling too many things. He joined the army, and there he discovered explosives. It seems that the only time he's not dropping, tripping, or breaking is when he's around high explosives.These 1991 Impel cards are really well made and are printed on high quality stiff cardboard. The artwork is all original and well done. I'm glad I picked these up and think you will be too.

It is hard to review a Volume presentation of completely different works, but I will try. The story begins when the Turtles are thrown back in time. It is difficult to explain why as there is little story explaining what has happened to cause this. As the story continues one would think that this is fleshed out, however, the writers really abandon this plot point. In fact, the writers seem to abandon just about everything they set up.Not only are plot points abandoned but any sense of common thread is thrown out the window as well. The artwork moves from a focus on a very young audience to a much older one and everyone in between. With scenes that look like they are better suited for coloring books, to scenes that look they should be in a graphic novel, there is no sense of continuity between the presentations. The story follows close suit, as the plots are muddled and disjointed between issues and usually end without concluding the actual story.It appears to me that there was no actual game plan for this series. Almost as if the people creating it split up into different teams and didn't communicate what the plan was with each other, all coming up with a different end product.Skip this one.

From the back of the card.Series 1 #43File Name: Graves, Robert W.Grade: SP-4Birthplace: Columbus, OHPrimary MOS: InfantrySecondary MOS: Small Arms Armorer, Artillery CoordinatorCurrent Assignment: ClassifiedSpecial Training: Advanced Infantry TrainingGrunt knows soldiering better than anything. From maneuvering to manpower, he knows the enemy's maximum firing range, how many rounds their guns can hold, and the quickest way to put them on the fritz. He's mean, stubborn, and refuses to quit even when he's outnumbered and outgunned. Put him on the line, and he'll outfight any man.These 1991 Impel cards are really well made and are printed on high quality stiff cardboard. The artwork is all original and well done. I'm glad I picked these up and think you will be too.

OK, take this from a lover of all things Apple... This is really a great TV box. The software is admittedly new, but is already pretty darn good, especially for a first-generation device. I have two non-smart TVs. For one, I have an Apple TV, which is untouchable due to the Airplay and iCloud features... if you are invested in the Apple ecosystem at all, you need at least one Apple TV in your house for this reason. For the other TV, I used to have the latest and greatest Roku (Roku 3, I think it was... I can't tell now because I hit it with a hammer too many times). That was my second Roku, bought to replace my first one which had a terrible problem where it was somehow injecting a constant hum into my sound system. The new Roku had no hum, and performed quite well, except IT WOULDN'T STAY CONNECTED TO MY WIFI NETWORK. It was the most frustrating thing ever, and I tried every single solution I could think of, even changing encryption and channels on my wireless router about 10 times. I was resetting everything on a nightly basis to get it to work, and even that only worked half the time. I finally got just too frustrated, and demolished the Roku 3, and now I will never purchase a Roku device again.Anyways, on to the device that I'm supposed to be reviewing. The Amazon Fire TV went on a cyber monday sale for half price, and I must say it was a steal at that price. It came setup with my Amazon account already, which was nice and convenient. The WiFi performs as good or better than the Apple TV, and lightyears better than either Roku before it. I have not had any connectivity issues with it, except in WatchESPN, but I'm pretty sure that's an ESPN problem. It is the fastest by far at loading videos. Amazon videos somehow start playing instantly (it's like magic, I swear), while videos from other sources take a few seconds at most to begin playing. The remote is good, but not great. The voice search is also very good, but I wish it could reach into more apps. Gaming is nothing special, but this would be an easy and cheap way to trick young kids into thinking you bought them a real gaming console. I like how slim the box is... for a wall-mounted TV it would be preferable to mount to the back of the TV itself, since the remote does not require line of sight to function. The packaging was very nice, even better than typical Amazon stuff in my opinion. I have not had a single hiccup with the software... no bugs, no freezes, no crashes. Honestly, if it weren't for the Airplay and iCloud integration I mentioned above, I would probably replace my Apple TV with another one of these. Sure, it prioritizes Amazon content over other content, but I don't hold that against them. It is still just as easy to access Netflix on this device as on anything else.

Installed on a 2005 Honda Accord. Very good value. Make sure to snap them all the way in when installing. It takes a firm press, I almost thought I was about to break something, but you will definitely hear and feel when it snaps in. Works as well as any other, at least out of the box. I will update this review when they start to show signs of aging.

Wow. I got these phones bundled with a Tascam DR-05 recorder for the price of the headphones alone. I ordered the bundle more for the recorder, but the headphones are certainly the more impressive of the two items. These will bring out things you've never heard before in music that you've heard a hundred times over. When I made uncompressed recordings with the DR-05, I had a hard time telling the difference between live sound and recorded sound when I closed my eyes. These headphones seem to be very unbiased and flat in response. They have no distortion at any volume. The passive noise cancellation is even surprisingly good. Low sound bleed as long as they are sealed up nice around your ears (still some bleed at extreme volumes though). The sound quality is almost too good sometimes -- you will start to notice imperfections in professionally-produced music with these. I really can't think of a better pair of headphones for anywhere close to this price. I love the cable selection (which adds a lot of value... they are usually the first thing to go bad in my experience) and the carry pouch. The white color is a very pure white -- I am afraid to get them dirty. It looks nice, but I would go with black if ordering again. They are more comfortable, durable, and flexible than any other over-ear headphones I've owned, and I've owned quite a few. Every time I let a friend try these out, they have one of two initial reactions, depending on the type of music being demoed... 1) a slight backwards tilt of the head, with eyes slowly closing and a smug grin that slowly widens [most common with classical music], or 2) an apparent paralysis of everything but the face, which develops sharply raised eyebrows and a slight jaw-drop [usually rap or electronic/dance].Yeah, get these headphones.

The quality is fairly basic and cheap, but for officially licensed apparel, the price is not bad (especially if you can get it under $20, which I did). The sizing was dead on for me, although I would prefer slightly longer sleeves. I am 5'11 180 and got a large and it is very comfortable. I love the design and graphics. Almost retro, but modern at the same time. Great gift for a Bears fan, will help offset the disappointment that is the 2014 Bears.

I got this device bundled with the Audio-Technica ATH-M50x headphones for the selling price of the headphones alone, so I was happy with the deal even before trying the products out. Now that I have put them through their paces, I can't believe I basically got this device for free. It has met or exceeded all of my expectations. Specifically, the built-in stereo condenser mics are way better than I expected. I have used many condenser mics before, and background noise is almost always an issue (unless you're in a professional studio or something). If you're more than a few inches from a condenser, you have to crank up the trim such that you can hear people on the other side of the room breathing through the mix. If you place them too close, they seem to become exponentially more sensitive and peak out too easily. That's where I was surprised with this device... The response curve seems much more gradual, and a nice range of input level is provided, such that placing the mic just a few inches from the source (in my case, an acoustic guitar, cajon, and several other instruments) becomes very easy to mix while reducing background noise almost entirely. I even recorded some electric guitar from my fender tube amp, and placed right next to the speaker, this thing performed like a champ.The mics are very natural and neutral -- flat, in a good way. Combined with the excellent M50x studio reference headphones, when I recorded anything from voices to instruments to random ambient noise, upon playback I could close my eyes and honestly would have a hard time telling the difference between live sound and recorded sound. Of course, this is only when recording uncompressed... Switch to mp3 format and even a little compression sounds terrible on those headphones. The interface is not that bad compared to other recording devices. It only took me a few minutes to get a hang of all the controls. People expecting this to be like an iPhone in ease of use will be disappointed, though. The batteries last forever, the microSD card slot is easy to access, and everything is quick and simple with this thing. Seems durable enough as long as you're not dropping it on concrete. I also received a 4GB card instead of the 2GB that was advertised. No complaints here :DAs another reviewer or two have explained, there is a software upgrade from the manufacturer's website which adds some nice features to this already-excellent device. The most notable feature is the overdubbing. After updating, while the monitor mix is turned on, you can press record and select whether or not to overdub the current track. If you opt to overdub, the current track will play through the headphone jack, while you record over it. The original track is kept, along with the overdubbed version. As far as I can tell, once overdubbed, there is no way to isolate the new track from the one you dubbed over (in order to mix as separate tracks). So, while this isn't really a multi-track recorder, it is actually quite simple to perform basic multi-track recordings, as long as you don't need to do much post-production. You can even add in reverb (either at the input or the output), so I was able to record full song samples with a blending reverb effect all on this device, onto one track. The only mixing I did was live, and if I didn't like my last track, I would just redo it.So, yeah, this thing is worth the money, especially in the bundle that I got. This isn't exactly professional-level equipment, but it's close enough for those who just want a decent quality recording without breaking the bank, even for someone who is very picky like me.

Excellent watch. Was delivered in a very nice box, and was already set to the proper time, accurate to the minute. My wife absolutely loved getting it for her birthday and thought it was the perfect gift. The colors are nice and it goes with a lot of different styles of clothing and accessories. While it looks dainty, both the band and the watch itself feel fairly solid and durable. The leather band of course is quite stiff, causing it to tend to fall to the sides of the wrist, but it will get softer and more broken in over time. I can't speak to the solar charging since we've only had it for a month, but all is well so far. The price is great online. Definitely recommended!

From a functional standpoint, I am happy with the case as it does what it claims, and is a good value compared to more expensive brands. However, the color in the pictures is very misleading... at least for the blue one, anyways. The pictures clearly show a darker, true blue, but what I received is most definitely teal or blue-green. My wife told me it looks girly. I don't agree with her, but I would certainly rather have the pictured deep blue (to match my school colors). I have sent an email to Maxboost about this and will update my review if and when I receive a response.

This thing is really nothing special, but it has a nice, sharp dot with plenty of brightness levels. It mounts nice and solid, and I didn't have any problems getting it sighted in either. I used it with the excellent Lucid M7 riser on a custom built super-lightweight AR-15, and the whole thing fully loaded weighs less than 5lb, which is amazing. Obviously, with no magnification, you're very limited on range (even when shooting from a rest because the dot starts to cover your target completely at long distance). However, this is a great multi-purpose red dot. I will probably end up putting it on my Vepr-12 shotgun and get something magnifying for my AR. For both-eyes-open defensive shooting, this thing will do just fine!

While I don't have a Lucid M7, I bought this because it looks sleek, won't break the bank, and appears to be one of the lighter full-height riser options on the market. I recently built an AR-15 that weighs less than 4 pounds, so I didn't want to defeat the purpose by putting a heavy optics rig on it. As a test run, I paired this with the Bushnell Trophy red dot and it is a very decent rig for the money. I plan upgrading the optic at some point (aimpoint micro H-1), but this riser is probably here to stay. It is a solid product from a solid company.

I've only had this for a few days, but considering the price, this has already far surpassed my expectations. I cannot speak much yet to the longevity or durability, but this thing absolutely sucks balls... balls of lint, dust, hair, etc. I vacuum quite frequently, and up until now I have been using a Roomba with the aerovac bin for regular scheduled sweeps, and a nicer hoover upright model for deep cleans about once per week. When I got this, I made the initial pass through a few rooms in the house... The dust bin was PACKED after running through just three bedrooms and a small hallway. This vacuum seems to be picking up so much more dust that has been left behind by years for other more expensive vacuums. Sure, this one lacks some of the nicer features, but even if it only lasts me a year or two, the cleaning ability is impressive. It gets edges quite well, and the turbo brush is nice for stairs. It's also super easy to empty the dust bin. I really don't think any fancy features are worth paying at least twice as much for a vacuum, when you can get a good basic clean for this price.

These are basically the same price as buying just the refill cartridges for the Mach3 (still the greatest razor ever made). Difference is, with these, if you lose your razor, no big deal. There's five more where that came from, and you don't need to fuss with carrying cases and swapping out cartridges. These each come with a replaceable plastic cover over the blades so they're perfectly fine to just toss in a bag when you travel. However, these are still more expensive than they need to be, and for that reason, I am considering joining dollarshaveclub... very tempting. But these are still solid.

I was lucky to pick up a museum collection Sting for a heck of a price, and I had to get the official scabbard to go with it of course. I don't think it's worth more than a hundred bucks by any means, but if you can find a good deal on it, let me reassure you that the quality is great and it's worth getting for your Sting replica. The leather is soft and the fittings are nice and tight. This looks so amazing that I geek every time I see it.

I was lucky to pick up a museum collection Glamdring for a steal of a price, and of course I had to get the officially licensed scabbard to go with it. This is probably not worth more than a hundred bucks, but if you can find a good deal on it, let me reassure you that the quality is great and it is worth picking up for your Glamdring replica. The leather is soft, the trim is tightly fastened, and the sword looks straight up kingly in this scabbard. I am such a nerd.

OK, this is not something I would take to battle. However, the reticle on mine shows up bright and clear. It doesn't look too cheap, which is good. I encountered very slight variation in zero when switching reticles, but it was so small that it really doesn't matter unless you're benchrest shooting with this. There is definite parallax error when viewed from different angles so if you're going for the bullseye, keep that reticle in the same place in the window every time. Construction is solid enough, it seems to hold zero quite well when tightened down, but I certainly wouldn't trust this in rain or extreme conditions. For plinking and range work, this is a fun sight and an excellent value, but I wouldn't bet my life on it by any means.

Solid, secure, comfortable... This is the best single-point sling I have used. Not a perfect match for Magpul FDE but it's close enough for me. I'm 6'0, 175, average to athletic build, and this has perfect adjustment limits for my taste.

Nothing not to like here... and yes, they work with magnets because they're steel. In fact, I like to hang my magnetic leather money clip with a bunch of Benjamins in it straight from my collar... That way, everyone knows I'm legit from the get-go. Also, when people see you undress and pull stainless collar stays that say "SHARK" from your shirt, their only logical conclusion is that you are the most interesting man in the world. Say good bye to curly, shriveled-up collars forever, and get ready for guys and gals alike to gawk at your stiff, straight, smooth, and perfectly-ballasted neck frames.

This tool is the bees knees. It does everything you need for AR work, and it is so solid and strong that it can withstand any and all abuse you can put it through. BUT THAT STUPID OD GREEN POWDER COATING IS TERRIBLE! It wears off on your barrel nuts, your flash hiders, and your castle nuts too easily. Sure, it won't permanently ruin anything, but Tapco totally missed it on the decision to powder coat this thing green. They should have gone with black, or a different type of finish altogether. Everything else about it is awesome, including the price. It is probably the best tool I own, but I just can't give it five stars with that dumb coating. Still, you should buy one. I wouldn't work on an AR with any other multi-tool unless I had to.

Wow. The standard Mossberg pistol grip is so bad, and I never realized just how bad it is until I bought this. This grip improves the feel, control, felt impulse, comfort, etc... it is better in every regard, and a necessary upgrade for anyone serious about shooting their cruiser. Hogue rocks!

This works alright, about what you'd expect from a cheap trimmer. Sometimes I use it without the adjustable portion for precision lines and areas, and that is fairly effective as well. I usually keep it on the lowest setting because it is really easy to accidentally bump it down. Works great when you're traveling since the battery lasts forever! I've done about 5 full beard trims and still going strong on one charge now.

The metal is a little thin but it is good quality printing. I have this in my workshop and it is a great addition. Honestly I could do without the fake bullet holes, but whatever. Everyone loves it when they see it! BTW, does anyone have .22LR in stock yet? :D

This thing is great, although when I was putting it on it felt like I was going to break it. The plastic feels a little cheap but I haven't had any issues with the function. Nice, huge, bright fiber dot is really easy to pick up during the day and even helps at night a little. With heavy recoil, this makes it so much easier to get off consecutive accurate shots quickly.

This works very well for its intended purpose, but a caution about using it on a nice black finish that you want to keep black: when this stuff smears, it takes a while to clean it all off because it just keeps smearing. Other than that it is a great product.

The first time I ordered this, I got some stupid floor mat with a message from my dog. Silly Amazon... I don't even own a dog. So I contacted customer service and they got me the right one. No worries there. Anyway, this is nothing special but works fine, especially if you have a non-slip mat underneath. Otherwise it will slide around. Print and build quality seem nice. Makes people laugh. Glad I got it!

I bought two of these for mounting a scope to a basic flat top AR. They worked great, were solid, and easy to remove using only my fingers which is nice, but the scope was just a little higher than I'd like. I had to give more of a chin weld than a cheek weld. The scope I was using was the BSA tactical 4x30mm with the included rings.

These work very well provided you follow the instructions about initially flushing them to get any flakes out. Use cold water only through them and don't let them completely dry out. Good price here... I usually use them for three to four months since I don't use my Brita for anything but drinking, and they are as good on day one as they are on day 90. Great alternative to bottled water. You don't need spring water from Fiji to have great-tasting hydration.

OK, these are just a little rough. But when the name brand option is literally ten times more expensive, there's no reason not to buy these if you need offset BUIS. The way I see it, I just need backup sights for SHTF, optic failure, or preliminary optic setup, in which case I don't need to be shooting 1/2 MOA at 500 yards. Either way, these things are holding zero on my AR-15 just fine after I got them adjusted. Some people say buy once, cry once, but when you can buy once and not cry at all, that's the way to go.

I have a couple non-vital sensors out on my Accord, so the check engine light is always on. I periodically check with this thing just to make sure I'm not getting any more error messages that could be more serious. It always works, but I'm not sure the message-clearing ability does anything with my car because I can't get the check engine light to go off even for a moment. Either way, at this price, every automobile owner should have one of these. I can't believe I ever paid mechanics for simple diagnostics that I could do this easily myself!

I leave this in my car and it works quite well. After pairing, it automatically connects to my phone when I turn the car on, and as far as I can tell is just as good as having integrated bluetooth in the car. My only issue (and I think I must have bought a lemon) is that it will not work in cold weather. It turns on but the display flickers and it does not transmit an FM signal. The bluetooth usually connects right away, but it the transmitter won't work until my car warms up. This is slightly annoying but I probably got a bad unit, I was just too lazy to return it or anything. When it works, it sounds great through my radio. It even automatically starts playing music when I get in the car, which is cool in conjunction with iTunes radio (plays where you left off, or just shuffles your library if nothing was playing before). Bluetooth controls are very responsive. 5 stars for the product features, 3 stars for quality control, 4 stars total.

I needed a sling for my PAP AK pistol and this fit the bill and the budget easily. Sure, it's not the nicest sling out there, but it doesn't seem like a piece of junk at all. With an AK pistol hanging on your torso, nobody is going to mess with you except perhaps the government. Those guns have some heft to them but this felt comfortable and secure.

I have a couch with dark upholstery, and I CANNOT STAND all the lint and hair that shows up so easily on it. Giving it a pass with a fresh sheet or two from these picks up almost everything and makes it look great again. It sure beats getting out the vacuum. I wish they were a little more sticky, but just change to a fresh layer often and you should be good to go. 5 rolls will last me forever. I also like how the handle is offset from the center, so there's always room to keep your grip around it so you can apply proper pressure.

This TV certainly has rough edges and will not live up to the Samsungs, LGs, and Sharps of the world, especially from a user-interface standpoint. However, considering the relatively dirt-cheap price, it is more than worth it for those who want to get a headstart into the 4K world. I got pretty decent picture quality out of the box with OTA broadcast signals, and excellent picture quality from my 1080p Apple TV. I am actually rather impressed with the quality of the 4K upscaling, especially with the Apple TV signal. It really does look better than native 1080p, though it doesn't look nearly as good as native 4K. I have tinkered with the settings a little bit but I didn't have to do a firmware upgrade. Maybe mine was already upgraded?Anyways, to get on to the big issue here... No support for HDMI 2.0 yet, so with native 4K you're limited to 30Hz over HDMI. This is fine for movies because they are typically 24fps, but games and other video content will look inferior at 30Hz. Now, I have contacted Seiki customer service on two occasions, once by phone and once by email (via their weird online support system). Both times took longer than I would have liked, but at least I got responses. The guy on the phone told me confidently that the current models of their 4K TVs will support HDMI 2.0 by means of a future firmware upgrade. The email support response said that they are merely working to see if that is a possibility. So, there seems to be some ambiguity about whether this TV is actually as "future-proof" as it seems. I don't know enough about the technology to know whether it is possible to increase data throughput with a mere firmware upgrade, but since HDMI 2.0 will use the same cables as previous versions, I'd say this is quite possible and is likely a matter of the encoding/decoding scheme at both ends of the cable, rather than the hardware itself. The TV is obviously capable of 120Hz, so I tend to believe what the guy said on the phone. How long it will take to get this firmware upgrade, I have no idea. Even if HDMI 2.0 never pans out for this model, I'm still glad I bought it.

I never realized how dirty my cabin filter was and how much it affected the smell of the cabin air. Swapped out for this one, and it's almost like a new car again, minus the new leather smell. My Accord has over 180k miles on it and I don't think that filter has ever been changed. Just don't pay someone for this filter and service! So easy, a caveman could do it. Buy here and change yourself. There are good instructions on Youtube. Cheers!

I agree with other reviews that say this model of the case suffered a dip in quality. However I still believe it is the best credit card iPhone case out there. My 5S has taken many tumbles and falls without suffering a single scratch (and no, I don't use a screen protector). I carry 4 cards in it without a problem (two licenses and two bank cards). They don't seem to move at all while in the case, unlike some wallet cases that are a bit more loose and can allow the cards to rub around and get messed up. It obviously adds some thickness, but those with bigger hands will appreciate getting more to hold on to (these phones are dumbtastically thin these days). Definitely not the cheapest good case out there, but it may be the most practical one of all since it can save you from carrying a wallet around altogether while not hindering the ease of using the phone at all.

This ain't your momma's breakfast blend coffee. This is productivity-boosting, baby-making, mind-accelerating stuff. It's fairly bold, but at the same time it has a strange lightness about it. There's no weird aftertaste, very low acidity... You just get great, strong coffee with a clean finish, whether you go black or you load it up with fru-fru. This now shares the top spot for my favorite coffee along with Starbucks' Casi Cielo (I'm not a huge fan of most other roasts from Starbucks, but they nailed that one).

I got a 50" Seiki 4K TV for a heck of a deal, so I had to try plugging in a laptop to get some decent native 4K content. With the program Switchresx, I was able to make a setting that output 4K at 12Hz (using OS 10.9 Mavericks). I had no issues with the adapter whatsoever. Video at that speed looks pretty bad, but images and websites and text were all incredibly clear and expansive. Large PDFs and AutoCAD files look awesome this big! Until HDMI 2.0 comes out (and I get a faster computer... ha), this will do just fine.

I got sick of the people at Valvoline telling me my filter was dirty every single oil change (I only go if I have the $15 oil change coupon, by the way, so don't judge.) I picked up this filter, dropped it in pretty easily (I am not a big car guru but I am usually pretty handy at following instructions), and it seems great. I don't think I've gotten more power or gas mileage as some claim, but shifting gears does seem the tiniest bit smoother. I'd say it's worth the price but by no means a necessary upgrade. Still, a well-made product at a competitive price from a respected brand is hard to pass up.

I reviewed the PD32 UE before, so this review will be similar in format. These two lights are very similar, and they are both near-perfect EDC/self-defense flashlights. The major difference here is the included batteries and charger with this light. I will say that they work just fine, and it's still a heck of a lot better than having to use the CR123A cells. Longer runtime and rechargeable with the 18650s, there's no reason to use CR123A batteries with this light unless you have to for some reason. However, there are better 18650 cells and chargers out there, but for the value these are fine because they work. On the PD35:Pros:-Awesome light output for size-Good battery life (considering output)-Tough but lightweight construction-Strobe accessible from any brightness setting-Strobes at the full 850 lumens (PD32 UE only strobes at 400)-Can be mounted on weapons with an attachment-Looks like a miniature lightsaber-Momentary or locking switch-Sturdy pocket/belt clipCons:-Doesn't remember strobe setting (i.e. can't activate immediately)-Does not come with the diffuser tip like the PD32 UE did-No S.O.S. mode like the PD32 UE-Wide beam angle doesn't throw too far-Can't tailstand-Gets hot quick on the highest setting-Lowest setting sometimes isn't low enoughComparing the beam to the PD32 UE, I noticed this one is slightly narrower and slightly cooler in color. I prefer the slightly narrower beam, because it throws a little farther, but I actually liked the warmer color of the PD32 UE a little better. This is mostly preference as the PD35 still has very good CRI (more like one of those 'daylight' CFL bulbs that just look a little too blue at night, but still renders colors very well).The brightness increase is barely noticeable except on the strobe setting. This light hurts to look at even on the lowest setting, so be careful when shining it at people. The strobe is especially disorienting, so please be sensitive to those around you. Overall a killer flashlight, and you won't find a better deal for the price!

Got this for my nephew for Christmas. It might have been the least expensive toy that he got, but he plays with it more than any of the others. He knows the names of all the trains, and has rescued each one at some point using Harold.

This should work fine if you don't require a lot of torque. I was getting a little too forceful into a tightening job (yes I was using it properly) and the rubber strap just snapped. Seems like a good product for less extreme jobs though.
Excellent part. These can certainly be found for cheaper, but this is true mil-spec and consistent quality. Perfect torquing and great fit. I used it on a Palmetto State upper.

These are ok... some look a little bent out of shape, but they still fly just fine. There's probably better pellets out there for the money, but I haven't had major concerns. Seems as accurate as I need them to be. Used in a Gamo Hornet they're nice and fast but not supersonic.

Generally, these have good QC and consistent accuracy. Unless you need special purpose pellets, just get a bunch of these and be done with it. Very good no-frills pellets, with an easy-open tin to boot. Recommended!

Step 1: buy a Gamo hornet (or equivalent)Step 2: throw away the scopeStep 3: buy this scope insteadStep 4: mount and zeroStep 5: hit the bullseye repeatedlyStep 6: never zero againStep 7: click yes to let me know that my review was helpful :D--UPDATE--Took this thing (still mounted on my Gamo Hornet and only zeroed once, ever) out to the lake. I was accurately lobbing pellets out to the opposite bank of the lake, roughly 200yds away, all WITHIN the field of view of the scope. I was using the very bottom tick on the reticle, but able to get about 6-foot groupings straight away when I did my part (very little wind, chilly day). Still amazed with both scope and gun.

It's cheap, has nice attachment methods (clip, audio jack insert), and feels much better on the screen than the rubber-only-tipped styli. I'm using it with a new iPad Air. Really smooth and accurate to write/draw with. It is very light so it feels kinda cheap, but that doesn't affect it's usability. Get one just in case you get those artistic urges... drawing with your finger is so lame and difficult.

Put this on a mosin nagant with an archangel stock. Went on easy, seems pretty solid, I wouldn't bring it to battle but for a range gun it performs quite well. Doesn't feel like it could take too much beating, but then again it's not the most crucial part of your gun so I don't really care if it's not built like a tank. I've used a Harris before and they're definitely better, but if you're looking to save some dimes on a nonessential tactical accessory, this will do just fine.

I got this with my new iPad Air and am very glad I did. I had no problems setting it up or typing with it.
