Only when the charge was more complete was I able to get it to work.Of course, you don't have to use the battery pack- you can just open the panels, aim at the sun, plug your phone or other electronic device directly into the panels, and charge on the spot. Because the panels are foldable, they are very compact and easy to take with you. I find that this direct charge method works best for me. Since I cannot always count on the battery pack working the way it should, I prefer to just use the panels directly. Of course, this is only possible when the sun is shining so one cannot ignore the battery pack completely. And you have to be very careful if you leave the panels outside to charge because they cannot be allowed to get wet. If you suspect any chance of rain, then you cannot leave them outside. If the panels get wet, the device is ruined.A backup power source is essential when you use electronics on a regular basis. There are many such devices available, but this is one of the few that is powered by the sun, making it ideal when outdoors and in need of an electrical source. It does have a few issues as I described above, but I still find it useful and will be sure to take it with me whenever a festival or other event beckons and I cannot afford to run out of power.

Every kitchen needs a colander and the Oxo Good Grips Stainless Steel Colander is a very good one for general use. It can hold up to four quarts and drains away the water and other liquids for reasonably quick straining and food preparation.We have a couple of different colanders in our kitchen and I tend to reach for whichever one is available. With this Oxo colander added to the ranks, it has become, in most instances, our go- to colander for draining pasta and other foods. The stainless steel finish is much more attractive than that of other colanders and I like the legs because they grip well and prevent sliding. The colander can be cleaned in the dishwasher, too, but I prefer hand washing because, among other reasons, it helps maintain the shiny finish.If there are any issues with this colander, the only one that comes to mind is the small openings at the bottom. The holes on the sides of Oxo Good Grips Stainless Steel Colander are large enough to drain water quickly, but the holes on the bottom are not and you need to wait a little longer to make sure the water has drained completely. I discovered this when dumping pasta that I thought was drained back into the original pot. A small amount of water poured back with the pasta and quick examination shows the reason is due to the smaller holes in the bottom. They will work- you just have to give them a little more time than you may be accustomed.Colanders are a necessity for even the least talented cooks among us and the Oxo Good Grips Stainless Steel Colander is a very good device for the task at hand. It looks nice, stays in place, and gets the liquids away from foods in reasonable time for efficient food preparation.

Steering wheels are usually rather plain in appearance and they can lose their luster and grip over time. This is where a steering wheel cover can help and the Bell Automotives Foose Wheelin Steering Wheel Cover is a good option for this purpose.My steering wheel is a few years old and is losing its grip so I figured a cover like this would be helpful. It takes time and effort to install the cover because it has to be stretched to reach around the edge of your steering wheel. There is just enough give and stretchiness to make it work, but it does take effort.This cover has a distinct chemical/petroleum scent that will bother some people. It gradually fades over time but it is very noticeable at first. In those early days, the strong scent will wear off on your hands and you will be able to smell it when you exit the vehicle. Again, it does wear off so you only need to exercise a small amount of patience.As for its usefulness, I find this steering wheel cover a good one. It has a stylish look and it adds a nice degree of gripping power when you drive. I live in a hot climate but I noticed right away that the surface of this cover doesnt get hot- even when my car is left sitting in direct sunlight. The gripping is what I like best, though. My original steering wheel was a little too narrow and was worn so it would sometimes slip when I grabbed it. That problem is gone with this steering wheel cover. I have much more confidence now as I drive.Steering wheel covers are not something most of us give much thought to, but a good steering wheel with sufficient gripping traction does make driving easier and safer. The Bell Automotives Foose Wheelin Steering Wheel Cover is a good cover for any steering wheel. Try to ignore the chemical- like scent when you first install it because it will fade away, leaving you with a stylish steering wheel cover that improves driving and performance.

Certain office supplies/tools are essential in every household and one of them is scissors. A good pair of scissors is useful for so many things and Mead Academie Stainless Steel Scissors are sufficient for most household uses.What makes a good pair of scissors? Most will agree that cutting ability and comfort are both key and with these Mead scissors, the cutting and comfort are both sufficient. The blades are sharp enough to easily cut paper and cloth and my girls like using this pair of scissors for their crafts. Comfort is good, too, and they are designed so that both left and rand- handed individuals can use them. The space for the thumb could use a little larger opening, but otherwise the comfort is sufficient.These scissors are lighter in weight than others in our household and that makes them just right for the kiddos. We have other scissors than contain a lot more metal and weigh much more. Mead Academie Stainless Steel Scissors are lighter than that, but not so light to make them seem weak. I tested them on cutting a few different things and they worked fine. They are not heavy duty enough for the really difficult cutting jobs, but Im pretty sure Mead didnt intend them to be.With Mead Academis Stainless Steel Scissors, we have yet another pair of scissors to satisfy household needs. Scissors tend to get misplaced in our household, but these will likely remain in place at my kids craft table. They seem ideally suited for this purpose and they suit the kids needs well.

My dog loves dog treats as much as any other and he especially loves softer treats with just the right doggie- inducing scent. Natural Balance Hip and Joint Salmon Jerky Treats offer both qualities, with special ingredients to help dogs with joint issues.Starting with the basics, these dog treats are flattened, rectangular squares, brown in color, with a stench all their own. Its not a terrible scent, but it does get your attention and the attention of your dog. The treats are packaged in a re-sealable bag to keep them fresh and each treat contains glucosamine and chondroitin for joint health.Moving on to the treats themselves, I had no problem getting my dog to devour these treats. They met his criteria- soft and with an attractive scent- so he took to them immediately. He only weighs about 20 pounds so he was able to make this last for a small amount of time, but I think its safe to say that a larger breed will inhale these in seconds.These dog treats list salmon as the top ingredient, and thats good. But they also list sucrose as the third ingredient, which is a bit of a disappointment as I do not see why sugar is needed. There is a preservative or two as well, but the ingredients are better overall than what you get with other dog treats.Every dog deserves the occasional treat and Natural Balance Hip and Joint Salmon Jerky Treat seem like a very good treat to me. The price is rather high, but they do have good qualities and could be useful for larger dogs and others with hip and joint problems.

Young artists will like the Mead Academie Watercolor Paint Set. A better than basic set with 12 assorted colors and a small brush, this paint set is ready to go out of the box. Just grab a cup of water and some paper, and youre ready to go.This paint set looks pretty simple and in many ways, it is simple. But I find it better than others of its type for a couple of key reasons. The most important is the brush. Paint sets like this often come with a brush so this is nothing unusual but with other, similar paint sets the brush is often very cheap in quality and doesnt paint well or last long. The brush here is much better. I also like the assortment of colors because they include shades you dont see in other sets.The tray, with its assortment of colors, hinged lid, and included brush, reminds me of the paint sets we used as kids. The three sections on the lid can be used to mix colors and the paint is non- toxic and safe. Its small size makes it easily portable and there is enough paint to last many months with normal use. Sure, there are fancier, more deluxe paint sets out there but for the money, this set is going to be difficult to match. It has everything for the young artist in your home with few if any flaws.

Rachel Ray Nutrish Soup Bone Dog Treats are a good treat for dogs with enough staying power and good taste to keep dogs occupied. The chicken scent and flavor is a hit with my dog and he likes chewing and enjoying these treats, making them a good distraction to keep him happy and quiet.Nutrish products are better than the average dog food with better ingredients and less of the artificial stuff that you dont want your dog to have. These treats are not perfect in this regard, as there are some less desirable ingredients on the label, but they are better than average and limited feeding should make them fine for most dogs.Moving to the flavor and other factors, my dog seems to like these very much and they do last a fair amount of time. Im not sure why, but my dog likes to gnaw on these treats a little at a time and that helps them last. I have noticed, from reading other reviews, that other dogs eat these treats much more quickly. I guess my dog is just different, or it could be the fact that he is smaller- only about 22 pounds- and older, 12 years old, and perhaps cant chomp away like he once could.Each package of Rachel Ray Nutrish Soup Bone Dog Treats contain only 3 bones and that means the price per bone is a little steep. If my dog gobbled these up in a couple of minutes, then Im not sure I would recommend them considering the price. But my dog makes them last and combined with his love of the treats and generally good ingredients, Im giving this product a recommendation.

Dandruff and dry scalp are sometimes an issue for me. I usually keep a separate bottle of anti- dandruff shampoo on hand for occasional use and Im always up for trying a new brand. This is what led me to consider CLEAR Men Scalp and Hair Anti- Dandruff Shampoo.I have never used anything from CLEAR before so I went into this experience with no previous brand- name bias. And I am happy to report that the results are positive. My hair feels soft and my scalp feels less dry than before. There is less itching and my hair looks good.This shampoo is thick and it has a scent that is menthol- like. When applied to the hair and scalp, it produces a cooling, tingling effect that is not unlike other shampoos with tea tree mint. Yes, its only a feeling, but it does make you feel like something special is happening to your hair and scalp. I like that the scent isnt overbearing and the same could be said of the cooling effect. Some of these tea tree mint/medicated shampoos are too intense. CLEAR seems to have everything in check.With its ability to control dandruff and make my hair look and feel great, CLEAR Men Scalp and Hair Anti- Dandruff Shampoo earns a high recommendation from me. I dont know how readily available this product is at my local stores, but its definitely a product I will look for and purchase again.

A good toy for toddlers, the Fisher Price 3 in 1 Bounce, Ride and Stride Elephant helps youngsters develop while having fun. The toy lets then bounce, ride, and walk along as they listen to the sounds and enjoy the light up buttons and songs.This toy is intended for toddlers under the age of 3 and most will take to it right away. Those on the younger side will like bouncing more than anything while those toward the upper end of the recommended age range will like riding and pushing. My youngest child is outside of the recommended age range, but she is lightweight for her age and liked riding the most. It takes a little bit of effort, but with just a small amount of leg power, young children can push themselves along without any assistance.Kids will love the sounds and lights that are part of this toy. The good news for parents is that you can shut off the sounds- a feature you dont always get with similar toys. This is nice for adults who get impatient with the constant sounds coming from kids toys. In truth, the sound isnt that loud or that bad with this toy, but its nice to know that it can be shut off, if desired.A toy that encourages activity, keeps kids interested, and helps them develop has all the makings of a keeper and this toy is just that. The price could turn some people away, but its not too bad and the fun and other advantages make this toy worth the money.

This is the continuation of the history of Caesar by Napoleon III.  Volume 2 is truly focused on Caesar.It's certainly interesting reading a sitting monarch's view of one of the most favorite people in history. I very much enjoyed Napoleon's writing style.  Shame he was a monarch and not a full time writer.Picked up while free, but worth paying for.  11,346 locations, Appendix starts at 5,803.  Appendix D is on the lieutenants of Caesar.

This is a very enjoyable history of Rome (Caesar starts about 2/3 of the way in).  But keep in mind, this is really a defense of Napoleon I.  Unsurprisingly, we get lots of thoughts on the author's Uncle.  However, it's a pretty good read all and all.  I enjoyed it a great deal, and definitely recommend.Picked this up while free, but certainly worth paying for.  6,772 locations, footnotes start at 4,560.
A quick read, Wodehouse wrote some great humor and provided a peak into the world of the Upper class in England.Well worth your time, and free to boot!

Thanks to the FFG Holiday Sales (check out in November) I got this on the cheap.This is a collection of 3 short adventures set in the Jericho Reach for Deathwatch Marines.As you would expect, this is a very dangerous set of adventures set on a Feral World, a heretical Tech World and in search of a missing inquisitor.Should be fun to run, but with additions as needed by your GM.

A pretty good movie, it's an interesting take on the Great Detective and his attempts to remember his last case.  McKellen is quite good as Holmes, and the time lapse is an interesting idea.The Special Features are two items that are really just alternative trailers

If you've read my FFG Star Wars reviews, you are probably as surprised as I am writing this.  I don't think I've ever done a 3 star review for the SW FFG books, much less a 2 star.So what is the issues(s)?Adventure #2 for FaD - Holocron #2.  When even the author notes this is an issue, perhaps you should write an adventure that doesn't require a holocron.  For a rare item, 2 for 2 is way too much.  Correction - the short adventure in the FaD screen does not involve a holocron, so call it 2 out of 2 and 1/2.The location of the 3rd part.  I'm not happy that we immediately go to a location that is iconic for the Old Republic players, especially as the Empire is going their best to make everyone forget it exists.I'm not a fan of a new Force power in an adventure.  Fortunately, I don't like it.I think some of the Morality costs are way off.  So turning in a non-criminal for torture and execution is the same Morality cost as killing a murderer who is fleeing?  Nope, nope, no chance.I don't recall this from other books, but the little type in italics on a dark red background are really hard to read.  My wife thought so as well, so not just me.The Clone trooper doesn't know why or remember why he fought Jedi?  Because he was bred to follow orders, that's why.  He would remember it quite well.  If you want to argue he questions it now, fine, but he sure as heck remembers it and why he did it.  It just seems like a fundamental misunderstanding of the Clone troopers to me.I do like the new race.  The Sathari are basically Kenku, and I like Kenku.Overall, easily the most disappointed I've been in a FFG SW product.

Yes, this is the abridged version, but it still is over 15k locations in the study of ancient ritual and magical practices.  Different cultures and different locations perhaps, but so often humanity came to the same conclusions.  It's really quite amazing.  Having now read this, it's a reminder of how much great literature is out there that I had never read.  The King of the Wood will definitely stay with me forever.Seriously, if you don't have this get it now.

A rather depressing story of a miserable woman, this is the life history of one of the Austrian empresses.  I had heard of her and her ultimate fate, but this is a nice summary of her life.1,088 locations long.  Picked it up while free, but worth paying for.

This is a collection of some odd and interesting facts about Cthulhoid New England.  It's an interesting read, but hardly a necessary pick up.If you have the spare cash, it's worth considering as you should be able to pull some ideas from it.

This is a really nice supplement.  Some nice information on New Orleans (not a full sourcebook, but good info), a short article on the King in Yellow and 7 adventures.  I didn't see a clunker among them, so this is an easy recommendation for a Cthulhu GM.

I would have liked to give this more of a chance but the scan is not good.  There are far too many letters replaced with ? to make trying to read this much fun.If a better version is put up, give it a try.

This is a nice start into the history of the Great War.  I'm not sure I agree as much with the author with Germany being the prime culprit, I think Austria gets off the hook a bit, but I do agree that Russia just could not back down ago.Worthwhile pick up for any history buff.2,230 locations long.  Picked up while free

I appreciate that Philip gets a decent chunk of this book.  Often from when I read about Alexander, there is a few pages on Philip, and that's that.  It's nice to get a full look at Philip.  Frankly, he's quite the interesting sort himself.  You have to wonder how he would have done when he attacked the Persians.Working table of contents.2,661 locations long.  Picked it up while free
This really gets you a a nice look at Seward.  Often forgotten as one of the victims of the assassination plot, this is a nice history of a key politician during the 19th century.

So when I get a book on Cleopatra, I actually want to be reading about her. 10% of the way in, and I get a lecture on incest. Still no Cleopatra. I really didn't need the author's religious views and boring writing, I wanted to learn about Cleopatra.,Pity.2,432 locations.  Got it while free, but not worth that even.

The author covers the history of Europe (France, Spain, Germany, Eastern Roman Empire) in this nice work.  The author does a good job of bringing the personal conflicts together, as well as the lack of history at times.The author was not a fan of the Papacy or Islam, so be warned of that if it will offend.7,085 locations.  Picked it up while free.

This is the story of the death of the USS Maine, and the war that came from it.  It's really amazing that after all of this time, we still don't know what happened to it.I am unclear from this whether it was a clear night or overcast.  This says both in the same paragraph....732 locations long.  Picked it up while free.

Finally watched this, and I was very pleasantly surprised.  There is a lot of feel of the original for me.  Sure, it's more for children, but I was 6 when Star Wars first came out and I think a lot of people don't remember that it was a kids movie (as they've grown up with it).I like the art style much better than the Clone Wars.Hera is my favorite character of the crew.  Chopper...odd little droid.  Not a huge fan of the force sensitives, but that's OK.Strangely, not a big fan of the cameos.  Threepio was way over the top.  And someone get Lando a sandwich.

A very enjoyable show.  It's nice to see Peggy Carter take center stage and carry the show so well.  Hint, hint Marvel - we will watch a Black Widow movie.As wife noted, this is the first show in quite a while that the lead actually is the most likable character.  Hayley Atwell does a stupendous job as Peggy and Jarvis is really good as well.We get a Howlin Commandoes appearance, and even Arnim Zola shows up.Well worth watching.  The special is a gag reel.

This was written around 1900.  It gives a very interested and detailed view of the development of Russia and the nature of the varied people.  There are some really interesting insights into the religions and political views of Russia and how it developed.I really would be interested to know what the author would think of events in Russia now.Picked it up while free.  1,686 locations long.
Arguably the best thing I've seen on a television.  It makes you laugh, and cry and remember why you love Big Bird.Just magnificent.Free on Amazon Prime.

UHF is firmly in my age range, so watching it through for the first time was a revelation.  UHF had a plot!So much of this would be lost to the current generation, but for an X like me is't just wonderful.  Weird Al is very watchable and the Seinfeld guy hits his role well.It also has Victoria Jackson before she went crazy

The promised Strange recursion book is out.There is a bit more on Ardeyn and Ruk - The Resoultion is a ship being built to travel to other recursions.  You can decide what you think of Scotty being on it.Atlantis - pretty much a necessary recursion.Camlot le Morte - there has to be a Arthurian recursion.  But Camelot meets the Borg? Is this really a thing?  And of course Gwen is the villain.  Because....reasons...Seriously, the Borg?Nazi worldHalloween - an interesting ideaMesozoica - typical lost world ideaMicrocosmica - one of my favorites - a neat idea to have the recursion set in a living creature (or the recursion is alive, I suppose)/New Centropolis - generic superheroNew York Grey - man the greys are real jerksOceanmist - not a lot here, but I like what isR639 - everyone is dead recursionRebel Galaxy - 90% Star wars and 10% WH40KSamurai Sky - EdoSeishin Shore - an odd magic recursionStarship Heinlein - life on a generation shipSword Realms - It's D&D.  The Forgotten Realms.  The Sword Coast.  Seriously.Wuxia City - Chinese martial arts recursionZed America - the required zombie recursionThere are also a number of short (seeds) ideas.  I like Castle One as an idea, but another Zombie recursion?Also included are some new character options.Too many of the detailed recursions are things that are just silly (Borg Camelot?) or so generic that I'm not sure what the point is.  If I want to play in Forgotten Realms, that is the background I'll use.

Shadows over Filmland is a nice combination of Trail of Cthulhu and the old RKO/Universal Horror stories.  I think it would take people who are a bit more willing to put their tongue firmly in their cheek, but nicely done regardless.Death Across the Nile - a neat idea thisWhite Bokor - a follow up to a Bela Lugosi movieDr. Grave Dust - a colleague of the ReanimatorDreams of Dracula - not quite the Dracula story you are thinking ofThe Green Ape - sad, sad storyThe Lord of the Jungle - more forgettable to meThe Night I DiedThe Non-Euclidean ManThe Black Chateau - I really enjoyed this oneUnder A Werewolf MoonThe Preserve - a rather interesting idea for a monster team up.  Nicely done.The Final Reel - what could go wrong with a movie about Cthulhu?Any Trail GM should be able to find enough here to be worth their while

The Imperial Handbook is a good read.  It's Legends, so don't cry "Canon" with it, but I find this to be a neat read about the Imperial Navy, Army, Doctrine and the Stormtrooper Corps.  I really like having details on the military structure in terms of organization and ranks.One neat bit is that famous Rebels give their opinions on what is in the handbook.Tarkin really was one messed up mamajama.

Some nice Trail investigations.A baby is kidnapped.  But is everything right at home?  Heck, is the baby normal?The Red Hook Cult revisited.  Creepity.The Wreck - a really nice idea to the start of this one.A run in with the Witch Cult.Definitely worth considering for a Trail GM.

This book is a ton of detail (often in table form) about 1907 Germany.  I don't believe I can properly express the amount of detail that is here.  If you want to know about crops, and the economic impact of colonies and shipbuilding, and industrialization, and the sixty hour work week, this will be Heaven for you.Closes with the Polish problem.  Very interesting how the Poles were out-competing the Germans in what is now Polish territory.8,970 locations long.  Picked it up while free

Dreamhounds of Paris is an amazing idea for a campaign.  A Dreamlands game set in Paris using the Surrealist movement.  This is why I don't write role playing games - I never would have thought of this as an idea.The idea is that surrealists are changing the Dreamlands with their ideas, and your players go along for the ride.  In fact that's not fully correct, as the idea is that your players ARE the surrealists of the time.  It's another astounding idea, and I do like that Mr. Laws even says that he's "bribing" your players to play them by making them better then normal starting characters.This is the sort of book that screams out for full color throughout it, but we do get some color pictures in the middle, which are wonderful.I'm honestly not sure if I have the GM'ing chops to do this sort of game properly.  However, one heck of a read regardless.

The screen is what you would esxpect, but would have been nice if FFG had updated it for the armored robes.  Oh well.The main reason I get the screens are for the adventure.  This one takes you to Phemis for lightsaber crystals.  A rather important place, with Ilum being hidden.  It's a short servicable adventure, with an interesting villain.  I do appreciate FFG providing ideas on how he could show up further, or go rogue.Also included are suggestions for Knight level play - i.e., more powerful starting characters with better gear.A good pick up for a GM.

This is the story of the religious battles in France between the Protestants and Catholics during an 18 year period.  It's truly remarkable how willing people were, and are, to kill each other in the name of their God.  I do think that Catherine gets a bit of a raw deal in this version.12,592 locations long.  However, the appendix is half of this and is in French.  Bit of an issue, as I don't read French.  Picked up while free.

Written around 100 years ago, this is a nice summary of the formation of the British Empire.  It starts in the Middle Ages and continues on to just after the World War (WWI to us).  I found quite a lot I did not know in this, and if you have any interest in how the world developed, knowing about the British Empire is a good idea.Some of the language won't go over as well in the 21st Century, but remember when it was written.Picked it up while free.  6,803 locations long.

If you already play EotE or AoR, you'll probably get this, so really not aimed at you.  Why wouldn't you want Consulars, Guardians, Sentinels, Warriors, Seekers and Mystics?So, new people.  Let's talk.Yes, there are 3 core rule books.  Star Wars Edge of The Empire RPG Core Rulebook, Star Wars Age of Rebellion Rpg: Core Rulebook and now Force and Destiny.  The starship left a long time ago on 3 core rulebooks.  Personally, I wanted all 3.  I even have 2 of the Beta books, but got one really cheap.  Edge of the Empire is more of scoundrel/bounty hunter type of game.  Edge of the Empire doesn't have to be where the game is, it's more the type of game.  Age of Rebellion - go fight the Empire.  Force and Destiny is much more of a Force game, as all of the characters are Force users.  EotE and AoR do have a Force user universal specialization, so they don't close out the Force as an option.  If you only want one core rule book, you need to think about the type of game you want to do very heavily.Next thing.  The funny looking dice.  The narrative dice system looks odd, but it really does work well.  Why should dice rolling be just failure or success?  What if you succeed at your locking picking of that office door, but the janitor notices on a Despair and decides to make a few credits with a blackmail attempt?  Or if you miss the stormtrooper, but distract him so well that your friendly Wookie gets an advantage on their try?  The more you play with the dice, the easier it gets.  One warning though.  Some very smart people have pointed out that with D20 and other game systems, it's easy for a player to "hide".  I agree that you can't do this with the narrative dice system.  It's much more of a cooperative system in which the players and GM interpret the dice.  This will take you in unexpected directions, but that is the fun!  You succeed with two Triumphs!  The Prince really likes you!  But you had a Despair.  The Princess doesn't!  Run with it!Beginner sets are great places to get dice, by the way.I do think that if you really want to use the Force in a heavy way, you need to get Force and Destiny.  The characters are not Jedi or Sith, but are generic enough (for the most part) that you can create them or a Force Witch, or whatever you want.I also appreciate the Force die.  There are more dark force sides, than light, but the light sides have more pips.  You also have the option to give in to the dark side for extra power.  But there can be a cost....There are quite a bit of races available in in the various books, as well as fan made supplements.  Also try the Order 66 podcast for really great information on the system - but I never listen, so what do I know.

This is the print book I've been waiting for, a guide to Firewall. Well, it's really more of the basics, than a guide. As decentralized as Firewall is, you really can have a cell doing whatever you want it to do. Heck, your players could be working for a rogue group doing it's own thing.The book does a great job of showing just how decentralized Firewall is, as different servers could easily be working against each other. Firewall also has plenty of different roles and factions, so it's possible that you could be deliberately working to stop another Firewall faction.It's also clear that some of the Firewall servers are most definitely not the good guys. Read Leaving Firewall on page 73. Yeesh.200 pages long. As always, I really love the build in bookmark. A great idea. Note - the tops of the character samples in the back were cut off in the print version. Looks bad, but these things happen.I really see this as a must get book for an EP game.

At over 25k locations, this is a massive history of the Crusades from the West to the Holy Land and North Africa.  Spain and the Baltic are touched upon, but they are not the main subject of this.This was started over 200 years ago, so some of this might offend, but if you can ignore that it's a great read showing the turmoil in the Holy Land, as well as some of the changes back home.  I never realized that the Teutonic Knights were active in Palestine - always figured they were on the Baltic, so learned something new.I picked up while free, but a great buy regardless.

This is definitely a worthwhile pick up for a SR fan, as you get a look at Australia.  It's nice to get some information other than "Here there be Manastorms."  Urban life, the Outback a history lesson is all here.  In addition, there is a more general discussion of awakened spots in the world.

Unnatural Murder is a fascinating read about a murder, but really more about just what it was like at the court of James I.  The Countess of Somerset is an engaging personality, but it's a great read as a murder mystery as well.Highly recommend.

Warwick the Kingmaker is a rather favorable account of this War of the Roses figure.  Warwick fought for the man he trained and helped make King of England, and then changed sides when he felt he had no choice.  Further proof that even being a noble was hard in the Middle Ages.2,696 locations long.  Picked up while free.

Nelson is clearly up there on the list of interesting historical figures.  Arguably the greatest Admiral ever, Nelson was also a very flawed person.  Which makes for one heck of a read.  Nelson took chances in battle, which normally paid off.  He also, arguable, died at the right time in his life.7.805 locations.  Picked up while free.

The story of Charles XII is the kind of story that no one in Hollywood would believe, if you brought them the script.  Invading the Ukraine?  Attacking against 5-1 odds when the enemy is fortified?  Whatever It was, Charles XII had It, but he definitely and some to learn about how to rule though.  Brilliant and lucky he was in battle, but he was just as bad at diplomacy.A great read for anyone interested in history.3,370 locations.  Picked it up while free.

The Night of the Long Knives is an interesting post-apocolyptic story that really grew on me as I got further in.The three main characters are rather interesting as they reveal more about themselves, and with the way that the Deadlanders have formed their own twisted form of society with its own set of rules.  Now, I think it would have worked better with more time between when the missiles started flying and when the story picks up, but to each their own.Picked up while free.  No art in the free version, as noted

Many of us thrilled at the accomplishments of the Space Shuttle program and mourned its tragedies and would appreciate a look back at its history.  If you are one of those, find a comfortable chair, maybe on your porch or by your fire, pour your favorite drink and open The Space Shuttle: Celebrating Thirty Years of Nasas First Space Plane.Its seven stages each begin with a narrative explaining that particular phase of the program, its inception, development, and closure, its crossroads,  its highs and lows, its accomplishments and its lost heroes.  After the introduction each stage contains a summary of every shuttle mission with dates, orbiter, crew and significant missions.The most enticing feature of this book is its pictures.  The cover shows the orbiter with its open cargo bay and Canada Arm silhouetted against earth and space.  On page after page we see equipment and crew, rockets and orbiter, launches and landings, life aboard and space walks, space stations and satellites and incredible blues and whites and stark black.Author Piers Bizony has created a work that will rekindle memories and introduce us to details that had slid by as we lived our lives and while the shuttle explored overhead.  It took me back to the day when a friend suggested that we have lunch at Charlies with its big screen television to watch the first landing, and an awesome sight it was.  Pick up The Space Shuttle, savor your own memories and enjoy.I did receive a free copy of this book to read and review.

Many of us thrilled at the accomplishments of the Space Shuttle program and mourned its tragedies and would appreciate a look back at its history.  If you are one of those, find a comfortable chair, maybe on your porch or by your fire, pour your favorite drink and open The Space Shuttle: Celebrating Thirty Years of Nasas First Space Plane.Its seven stages each begin with a narrative explaining that particular phase of the program, its inception, development, and closure, its crossroads,  its highs and lows, its accomplishments and its lost heroes.  After the introduction each stage contains a summary of every shuttle mission with dates, orbiter, crew and significant missions.The most enticing feature of this book is its pictures.  The cover shows the orbiter with its open cargo bay and Canada Arm silhouetted against earth and space.  On page after page we see equipment and crew, rockets and orbiter, launches and landings, life aboard and space walks, space stations and satellites and incredible blues and whites and stark black.Author Piers Bizony has created a work that will rekindle memories and introduce us to details that had slid by as we lived our lives and while the shuttle explored overhead.  It took me back to the day when a friend suggested that we have lunch at Charlies with its big screen television to watch the first landing, and an awesome sight it was.  Pick up The Space Shuttle, savor your own memories and enjoy.I did receive a free copy of this book to read and review.

I read the Instaread Summary and analysis of The Quartet as I was listening to the audio book of Joseph Ellis book.  The two work well together.The Instaread version summarizes the background and facts of this outstanding book (see my review in this website) and introduces the reader to the important characters and their relationships.  Perhaps its most useful segment is the Themes section that outlines the issues which impelled and retarded the transition from the Articles of Confederation to the Constitution.I found this Instaread work to be very helpful in that it highlights the important aspects of The Quartet.  If you read it in advance it helps you know what to look for.  If you read the two simultaneously it reinforces themes.  As a post-read it helps remind you of what you read and may entice you to go back over pages that you may not have appreciated the first time around.  This Instaread is a valuable assist to the casual or serious reader of The Quartet.I did receive a free copy of this book to read and review.

The Quartet is part biography, part history but mostly the tale of the Second American Revolution that replaced the loose confederation under the Articles of Confederation with the stronger government under the Constitution.The Constitutional convention did spring out of American earth as do trees and wild flowers.  Interstate squabbling readied the soil.  Shays Rebellion was the catalyst but cultivation required the work of far sighted statesmen who stroe to bring it to full fruit.  The Quartet are George Washington, the indispensable man who was coaxed out of retirement to again save the floundering country, James Madison who overcame his provincial constraints to promote a strong national government and forge the compromises that made it possible, Alexander Hamilton, the youthful native of the West Indies who could see the virtues of unity and John Jay whose international experience showed the place a united America could take in the world.Author Joseph Ellis draws the reader out of the present and into a nation in which loyalty was to a state and the foreign included the other 12.  This facet of the book brought to mind another book I have read and reviewed in this site, Moses Robinson and the Founding of Vermont by Robert A. Mello.  The Vermont story differed from that of the 13 states only in degree in that, not being admitted into the Union, it had more reason than others to toy with a British alliance as an alternative to the American one.  Comparing what Ellis says about the weak associations among the states with the Vermont situation as portrayed by Mr. Mello helps the reader understand the nature of political organization under the Articles.The articles themselves were designed to enable 13 colonies, while in the process of becoming states, to unite against a common British enemy.  They were much less suited for a growing, peaceful nation. The issues to be overcome in the transition to the Constitution were many.  The fear that a remote, national government would repeat the tyranny of the ministry in London, that a standing army could trample rights not enumerated until the adoption of the Bill of Rights, the tyranny of the large states over the small or the small over the large just to name a few.  What were the things that would unify these disparate states?  Ellis posits the public debt, western lands that could be the heritage of all states and people and a new external enemy, the Indians.I give high rankings to works that change my viewpoint on a part of history.  The Quartet meets that test.  At its end I had a much deeper understanding of the political milieu of the Articles and the process necessary to develop the Constitution under which we live.  The Constitutional Convention and the ratification process was a Second American Revolution because it transformed 13 loosely confederated sovereignties into a strong federal system. The process was not complete but continues to our day.  Ellis makes it clear that the founders did not envision that they were designing a governmental authority for the ages but one for their time that would give way as spring gives way to summer.  This book is a valuable addition to the early history of our land.I did receive a free copy of this book with the request, but not the obligation, to post a review.

War Of Two is a dual biography of Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr.  It follows their lives as they intertwine through New York and national politics.  Their backgrounds were different.  Hamilton, born in the Caribbean of questionable lineage, came to America with nothing but his own talents to propel him on his way.  Burr, the son of the President of the College of New Jersey (now Princeton University) and grandson of Rev. Jonathon Edwards, was as close to American aristocracy as one could be without money.  Each found a place in the Continental Army, Hamilton on Washingtons staff and Burr in the conquest of Fort Ticonderoga and the attack on Quebec.In the law they both became prominent members of the New York Bar.  In politics Hamilton was the driving force behind that Federalist Party while Burr played both sides until declaring for Jeffersons Democratic Republicans.  When Hamilton guided the Constitutional Convention Burr managed to remain non-committal on the issue.  While serving as the first Secretary of the Treasury Hamilton adopted the British precedent of nationalizing the debt to create a bond to hold the country together.  As Hamilton manipulated President Adams cabinet from behind the curtains Burr was elected to the U. S. Senate and made a reputation as a politician on the rise.  Whereas Hamiltons one case of adultery became a scandal in which adultery was the most appealing explanation, Burrs habitual philandering had little or no impact on his career.The undoing of both men began with the1800 election.  The defeat of the Federalists deprived Hamilton of his access to power.  Scheming by Burr, the acknowledged vice-presidential candidate, to win the presidency, with Federalist support, in the House of Representatives after he and Jefferson tied in the Electoral College, made an enemy out of Jefferson and put the new vice-president on the road out of politics.  Dumped from Jeffersons ticket in 1804 Burrs attempt to revive his career by winning election as Governor of New York was foiled by Hamiltons efforts.  Perceived insults during the campaign drove Burr to request an interview at Weehawken, New Jersey.  Shockingly enough, this was the eleventh duel in which Hamilton participated, but only the second in which potentially fatal shots were fired.Their duel was fought between two men whose political influence was spent.  Hamiltons personality and Federalist decline and Burrs 1800 scheme eliminated them from the governmental stage.  From Hamilton it would take his life within hours. Burr it would condemn to decades of shame, reproach, and flight from the law and his own reputation.  Conspiracy with Gen. Wilkinson to detach the Western territories from the United States to create an empire for Burr to rule led only to failure and an unsuccessful prosecution for treason.  Debt, exile and ignominy were all that was left for Burr.Author John Sedgwick has masterfully woven two extraordinary lives into a spellbinding literary work.  I have read much about this era but learned new things from these pages.  It gave me a better understanding of two crucial figures in the early days of the Republic with glimpses of their interaction with other players, such as George Washington,  John Adams, George Clinton and Thomas Jefferson.  I emerged with a much greater understanding of their era.  That has made War Of Two a most worthwhile read.

The Way Forward is part autobiography, part political manifesto and part vision of the future.  Now Speaker Paul Ryan begins with the story of his selection for the 2012 ticket, the campaign and the goals he and Mitt Romney hoped to achieve.  He then tells of his youth, his jobs, finding his father dead of a heart attack, getting into politics and his early career in the House of Representatives.  He then shifts into the problems he sees in terms of unsuccessful policies, failed leadership, and liberal courses that are doomed to failure from the beginning.  He contrasts his home town of Janesvilles response to adversity with that of Detroit.  Whereas Janesville lost its GM Plant without losing its soul, Detroit spiraled into disaster.  Ryan tells of his efforts to reach out to his constituents, Republicans and Democrats alike, as he seeks to represent them all.Ryan speaks of the challenge to Republicans to articulate how conservative policies can improve peoples lives and the gives some prescriptions as to what the GOP needs to do to become the governing party of the United States.  In the end his finds signs of hope throughout America, even in Detroit, the most tragic victim of liberal misdirection and mismanagement.From this book I got a sense of what drives Paul Ryan: his Catholic faith, the life he and his family have shared in Janesville and his core beliefs.  I understand why he was so reluctant to accept the speakership.  Besides the difficulties of leading a divided caucus the position runs counter to the path he has followed during his congressional career.  Early on Rep. Barney Frank told him that too many come to Congress as generalists and accomplish little.  He advised Ryan to concentrate on two or three things and get to know them.  Ryan specialized on the budget and feels that he can really make a difference in that area while the Speaker is, by definition, a generalist who may not be able to take advantage of the expertise he has developed.  Ryan is committed to making government work, not to create disruption.  I recommend The Way Forward to anyone looking for what motivates Paul Ryan and a path for our nations future.

I had read and reviewed the first volume of This Book Needs A Title so, when I was offered a free copy to review this one I took author Ted Ficklestein up on it.The poems in this book are short and witty.  Some are inspiring, like A Climb To A Mountain, others are funny, like Reading Up (it is best read from the bottom) and others are profound, like Changing The World.  Pick it up, page through it and pick the ones that appeal to you.

This book is the second in the volume of the Nixon Tapes as edited by Douglas Brinkley and Luke A. Nichter.  Covering the period January to July 1973 it focuses heavily on Watergate, although with a few other topics, including a visit by Leonid Brezhnev.  At one point Nixon suggested sending an armored division to reduce the Indian protests at Wounded Knee.  How about that for the last battle of the Indian Wars?What I like about these books is that they take you right into the Oval Office.  This is not someones interpretation of what went on.  This is history in the makers' own words.  I was impressed with the amount of time the President and his advisors spent trying to figure out who knew what and who would say what.  Nixon kept comparing the situation to the Hiss case and tried to gauge what a U. S. Attorney could prove against members of his administration.  I am always surprised at how the conversation seems so matter of fact.  I am sure that some of the same attitudes are displayed, but not recorded, in many other offices and homes.  I started out thinking that I would just read a sampling to get a taste of the tapes but kept finding more and more that interested me.  I will return to it again and again.

World War II At Sea is an oversize book combining narrative, pictures and maps.  After beginning with a timeline and an assessment of the naval strengths of the World Powers in 1939 it goes through sections, usually 4-6 pages in length, dealing with notable naval events of the War.Author Jeremy Harwood has compiled a selection of World War II incidents from a variety of phases, theatres and belligerents.  Some are famous, like Dunkirk, Bismarck, Mers-el-Kabir and Pearl Harbor.  Others are things that, with all my reading, I had never heard of such as the mistaken sinking of Athenia, a British passenger vessel, by a German U-Boat two days into the war or Slapton Sands where German S-boats, similar to U. S. PT boats, attacked Allied vessels training for D-Day.  Some sections consider naval battles, like Midway and Coral Sea, while others explain sea-land operations, such as Torch, Husky and D-Day, with emphasis on the maritime segments of those battles.  American had submarines too and readers are introduced into their part in the strangling of Japan.This coffee table book has the perfect combination of pictures and narrative.  Your guests can lightly peruse it and be awed by the might, combat and wreckage.  The serious reader will find facts enough to hold interest and maps to illustrate details that are hard to grasp in other works.  Each section has fact sheets of the significant vessels involved.  I am glad that I read this book.  I will put it out at time throughout the year and will consult it when I am studying a particular action.  A book that serves all of these purposes merits a place in any World War II library.I did receive a free copy of this book to read and review.

Letters from the Front is a collection of letters home from the Spanish American War to World War II.  They were written to Wisconsin but they could have been sent to anywhere USA.  They bring us the observations, worries, hopes and dreams of those who kept America free.  Some you may have heard of, like Billy Mitchell and Richard Bong, but most are men who, if they were lucky, went back to Wisconsin to live ordinary American lives. In their words we are introduced to the sights they saw, the hardships they endured, the battles they fought, their politics and their hopes for the future.Tourism existed in 1899 for Martin Stuhr who reached the Hawaiian Island and a Paradise it seemedwe made a tour of the Island and Visited an extinct Volcano known as Diamond Head.Amidst the carnage of 1918 Lee F. Pickett could appreciate nature My dear mother:Many song birds, chiefly sky larks, make the mornings beautiful with their songs.  Even on the front line while the whistling shells and bursting high explosives make everything hideous, these little birds keep on with their cheerful little songs.  Sometimes I wonder why it is that animals calling themselves civilized human beings dare to call themselves such and carry on such a war, while the little birds whom we class among the lower type of animals can spread so much cheer and gladness about on this earth.In 1944 J wrote of practicing darts in an English pub.  Surprising numbers of letters were addressed to teachers, such as Miss Trowbridge who heard from Stewart C. Yeo from New Guinea: wet clothes; no shelter; excessive rain and mud; dirty clothes; cold rations.  Several nights my jungle hammock only served to collect rain so by morning Id be sleeping in a couple inches of water.  When morning came I merely took my clothes off; squeezed the excess water pit and put them on for another day.  If I had been able to remove my shoes there was usually a quart of water in each of my small boots to be poured outwe had a picnic as compared to the infantry-they really got the dirty work.The letter writers preserved their views of their views of public figures and events of the day.  In a 1918 letter Lyle Phillips wrote: Here no one care much about politics though.  Roosevelt and Tafts answer to President Wilson caused a unanimous laugh at our mess the other night, but that was all.  Wilson surely is popular here with everybody.  According to Bene Smith a 1944 visit by Eleanor Roosevelt to a hospital in San Diego fell flat: they havent forgotten her crack she made about Marines after she toured the South Pacific last year she said that Marines whove seen S.P. duty and fighting shouldnt be allowed to come back her as they werent socially or morally fit to associate with American Citizens & should be left on island.  The death of President Roosevelt left Thurm  only able to say its better to have Truman enstead (sic) of Wallace while Miss Trowbridge heard that President Truman failed to impress me as being the eloquent statesman and leader.I was surprised to learn that POWs were able to send letters and request items.  Writing from Stalag Luft I in 1945, Paul asked My dearest if you send a food parcel to include plenty of chocolate and all things as condensed as possible-such as-Bisquick-Buckwheat-Pancake flour-jams-nut-fruit cake e.t.c. perhaps some dried fruits.All wars end and the warriors ponder their future.  In 1945 Don Gocker worried employers will holler no education and when he gets out of college ask How much experience have you had?  Apparently things worked out better for Don than he feared.These letters are gems, snippets of the threads that linked troops and home.  We are fortunate that Michael E. Stevens so skillfully selected and arranged these treasures and supplemented them with photos.  The Wisconsin Historical Society Press has made a great contribution to preserving our heritage in this book and This Wicked Rebellion by John Zimm and Michael Edmonds, which I also read and reviewed.  Pick up Letters from the Front.  Read it, savor it and tuck it away where, like the letters of which it is composed, you can enjoy it again and again.I did receive a free copy of this book to read and review.

I was looking for a fairly modern, comprehensive study of the battle for Germany so I picked up Armageddon.  Good choice!  Unlike many volumes it includes both the Eastern and Western fronts.  Beginning in September 1944 it covers Market Garden before shifting to the Vistula then taking the reader step by step to victory and the return home.  Author Max Hastings has provided us with an excellent overview of the closing events of the War in Europe.The great contribution of this book to World War II literature is its depth of analysis.  Hastings assesses battles, performance of armies and their leaders as well as the relative efforts on the Eastern vs. Western Fronts.  He tends to be critical of American, British and Canadian forces, both brass and GIs as compared to their German and Red Army counterparts.  Western caution after The Bulge is contrasted with Soviet aggression and ruthlessness.  Comparisons are often made to the conclusions of other historians who have evaluated the same topics.  Drawing heavily of quotations from many participants he pictures of the war as seen by those who fought it.  I took particular interest in quotes from later public figures such as Helmut Schmidt and Henry Kissinger.  While Armageddon does cover both fronts, I found it to be more heavily weighted toward the West, even while repeatedly reminding readers that most of the fighting was done in the East.This is an excellent book for the mature student of World War II in Europe.  It challenges the myths in which American, British and Canadian readers have been immersed while putting the contributions of the contending armies into perspective.  I recommend that we read other historians to get the fasts then turn to Armageddon for the reality check.

Abandon Ship is the tragic story of the sinking of the Cruiser U.S.S. Indianapolis on July 29, 1945.  Tragic for its loss of life when peace was so near, for the precautions untaken, for the ordeal of sailors awaiting rescue and for the court martial that followed in its wake.The book begins with the background of Capt. Hashimoto and his I-24 Capt. McVay and his Indianapolis and some of their key crewmen.  It follows with a narrative of the sinking from both the American and Japanese perspectives.  The Indianapolis having slipped beneath the waves, attention turns to the hundreds of survivors adrift with their life preservers and bits of wood, vegetables and cans, their skin and eyes smarting from oil irritation, their hopes of rescue rising and falling with each wave.  Through four days of searing sun, fish and shark attacks, death and sinking hopes they floated before rescue arrived.Once the survivors were being given treatment the investigations began.  McVay was charged with two counts of negligence, for contributing to the sinking by failing to zig-zag, and for impeding the rescue by not causing a radio message to be sent.  Much of the book consists of summaries of testimony from many witnesses, including Hashimoto.  This section of the book makes for fascinating reading.  The author delves into the unique nature of the only World War II court martial of a captain for losing his ship and the possibility that others, or Navy procedures, may have been at fault for not initiating the search when Indianapolis did not appear as scheduled.  I will not spoil the mystery by mentioning the outcome of the court.Author Richard F. Newcomb has done an excellent job of assembling available information and weaving it into a narrative that is easy to follow and interesting to read.  Abandon Ship is a classic part of any study of the closing days of World War II.

Lost In Shangri-La is the entrancing story of a joy ride gone bad and the seven week jungle ordeal of the three survivors and their rescuers.  On May 13, 1945 24 American servicemen and WACs set out on a sightseeing flight over Shangri-La, a beautiful and mysterious valley in the mountains of New Guinea.  Envelopment by swirling clouds with a rock in it led to a wreck that left only two men and a WAC as badly injured survivors.  Treating each others wounds and befriending natives enabled them to survive until a unit of Filipino medics and troops parachuted in to provide more advanced care while the survivors built up their strength for travel.  Then the question was how to get out of this inaccessible valley surrounded by Japanese to the south and natives to the north?  I do not want to spoil it for you so lets just say that it was an ingenious plan fraught with peril.While not an event that impacted the course of the war, Author Mitchell Zuckoff has crafted a tale of tragedy, adventure, heroism and relationships built across cultural boundaries thousands of years old.  There is even humor, particularly over misunderstandings between native and intruder. Lost In Shangri-La  is a good book to lose yourself in.

Time Capsule Books present what is now history as news.  The 1945 Time reported the news of a monumental year, beginning with the whipping up of the Battle of the Bulge,  the death of FDR, Hitler, Mussolini and Glenn Miller, the Atomic Bomb, the End of World War II and the founding of the United Nations.  Amidst all this was the launching of the Kaiser-Frazer Automobile Company the return of baseball stars to the diamond and a general return to normalcy across the United States.  We read history for more thought out analysis of events but books like this help us see history as it was lived.  Over the last 6 years I have re-read the Time Capsules for 1939-1945.  I am glad that began and am glad that it persevered to the end.

The Envoy is the story of Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenbergs struggle to save the Jews of Hungary in the closing days of World War II.  In 1944 and 1945 Hungary had the last sizeable population of Jews in occupied Europe.  Urgency to complete the final solution to the Jewish problem rose as the Allies closed in.  SS Col. Adolf Eichmann was determined to fulfill his duty to exterminate the hundreds of thousands of Hungarys Jews.  Working with the cooperation of Hungarian Fascists the S.S. engaged in a daily struggle with Wallenberg over how many Jews would be sent to the death camps and how many would be saved.Wallenberg was the most open and energetic of the Swedish and Swiss diplomats who intervened on the Hungarian Jews behalf.  His methods were to issue Swedish citizenship passes to Jews and then protect them in safe houses that were legal extensions of the Swedish and Swiss embassies.  As the Red Army approached, both the potential for liberation and the threat of accelerated persecution increased.  By the Soviet arrival an estimated 20,000-100,000 Jews had been saved by initiatives with which Wallenberg was involved.Salvation for his Jewish clients brought peril for Wallenberg.  Arrested by Soviet troops as a German spy, he disappeared into the Gulag from which he would never return.  His fate is shrouded in mystery with official records of his death in 1947 being disputed by later claims of sightings.  Author Alex Kershaw suggests that Russia must hold information that could shed light on Wallenbergs time in their custody.  Wallenberg became an international cause celebre in the 1980s when a Jew whom he had saved was elected to the House of Representatives from California.  Wallenberg was declared an honorary U. S. Citizen, a title he shares only with Winston S. Churchill.  With the surge of Reagan era attacks on Soviet human rights policies Wallenberg became a cause whose time had come.Alex Kershaw has written a series of World War histories that focus on the experiences of a few individuals (see my reviews of Avenue of Spies and The Liberator).  The ones I have read are excellent and this is no exception.  The contrasting personifications of the self-sacrificing Wallenberg and the all-consuming hatred of Eichmann carve the evil of the Holocaust into unmistakable relief.  Stalin is quoted as saying "One death is a tragedy, a million deaths is a statistic.  Kershaw has succeeded in transforming millions of deaths into tragedies.  He has done it with a wordsmiths craft that draws the reader into the action and never lets him out until the end.

This Teiklis Measuring Set includes 5 measuring cups and 5 measuring spoons, both made of metal.  They are sturdy and well-marked.  The heavy glass 2 cup measuring cup is solid and less likely to knock over than lighter weight plastic ones.  The one drawback to this set is that the glass cup measures in milliliters and ounces, but not in cups.  This would be a nice feature.  Overall this is a good set for cooking.I did receive a free set for testing and review.

I have long been a fan of the Old West and my interest in Legends And Lies was piqued by Instareads Summary and Analysis (see my review at: http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00XTIJYC0/ref=pdp_new_dp_review).As suggested by the Instaread Summary, this book is an entertaining introduction to the lives of fourteen personalities who added spice to the west from colonial times to the 20th Century.  Some were early pioneers, such as Daniel Boone who opened Kentucky before moving west to Missouri and Davy Crockett who fought Indians, served in Congress and died at the Alamo.  Kit Carson was an explorer who negotiated treaties with Indians.  Others were lawmen, at least part of the time, like Wild Bill Hickok and Bass Reeves, the dedicated Deputy U. S. Marshall who may have been the model for The Lone Ranger of radio and television.  The most colorful characters are usually the villains and this book is no exception.  The chapters on Black Bart, the Gentleman Bandit who lived a settled life between heists from Wells Fargo and left poems with each job, Jesse James, the Missouri bandit who robbed trains and banks throughout the central part of the country, Billy the Kid who killed and rustled through New Mexico and Butch Cassidy and Sundance who took their trade to Bolivia, fill in the facts behind the legends.  The West could never have won without the Cavalry and George Custer was not just the man who found disaster at the Little Big Horn but was a professional soldier whose story is as fascinating as any. Then there was Doc Holliday, the tubercular dentist who made gambled and drank his way into friendship with the Earps and immortality in the Gunfight at the OK Corral.  Eventually, of course, the Old West passed into history and it fell to the showmen, prominently Buffalo Bill Cody and Little Sure Shot, Annie Oakley, to bring its Indian battles and shooting exhibitions to fans everywhere.This book brings names and legends to life.  It presents them as real people who lived their lives in their places and times.  I was unfamiliar with Bass Reeves and was reassured to learn that Doc Holliday was, for his day, a competent dentist.  While the facts are interesting its greatest attraction is that Legends and Lies is just a good read.  Pick it up, enjoy and you just might find yourself returning to those thrilling days of yesteryear when

No Simple Victory is a critical examination of World War II in Europe by Norman Davies, an export on Polish and Eastern European involvement in that war.  It presents a much different perspective than that usually encountered by American, Canadian or British readers.  The points of the book are two-fold: first, that the bulk of the fighting occurred on the Eastern Front and secondly that the goodness of the Good War was soiled by reliance on the forces of a tyrannical Soviet Union to achieve victory.Davies challenges things we thought we knew, such as that D-Day was not among the largest battles of the War, American, British and Canadian efforts were helpful, but not essential to defeat Germany and that Nazis did not have a monopoly on atrocities.This book focuses heavily on the sordid record of the Soviet Union in its treatment of its own and conquered peoples, the depravity of Stalin and the naivet and whitewashing propaganda with which Western leaders treated Soviet behavior.  The hardship imposed by mass movements of people to conform to revised borders is given the attention that would be expected from a scholar of Polish history.I have read extensively on World War II but No Simple Victory forced me to view it from a different perspective.  I was aware that the bulk of the fighting was done on the Eastern Front but this made the proportionality more apparent.  It also brings the nature of Stalin and Soviet policy to the fore and aids in its understanding.  This is not a good starting point for World War II students but is an essential step toward an appreciation of the true nature of World War II in Europe.

When I was offered a free sample of these washcloths to test and review I quickly accepted the offer.  They are marketed as baby washcloths because of their small size and extremely soft material.  We do not have a baby to test them on but I wish I had these washcloths when we did.  I took them to test for adult use.  They are smaller than most adult washcloths but not as small as the name would lead you to believe.  I would not want to use them in a bath or shower but they are perfect for washing your face.  Whether you have a baby or not these washcloths deserve a place in your bathroom.

This Twinox manicure set is well made of sturdy stainless steel.  The scissors is sharp enough to trim nails or cut hairs.  The file smooths the sharp edges and the point is good for cleaning under the nails. The tweezers converge at a point to easily pluck out that nagging splinter.  It all tucks into a leather case that fits into a cloth case for easy storage or transport.  This manicure set has earned its place in my nightstand.
The Purcell Hand Sanitizing wipes are gentle on the skin but hard on the dirt.  Available in a variety of fresh scents they are both pleasant and cleansing.  These are the wipes for me.

This Remington PF7400 F4 Battery Operated Electric Razor is light weight, easy to grip and takes a charge quickly.  It gives a good, close shave, has a pop-up trimmer and cleans easily.  The cap has extensions that make it easy to balance when at rest.  It has everything I would ask for in a razor.

14-18: Understanding The Great War helps the reader understand the War through the understandings of those who fought it, lived through it and commemorated it.  Chapter by chapter the authors examine how civilized societies turned into brutal warriors, collectively and individually, and how they dealt with this transformation.The magnitude of the struggle was unprecedented.  The neat wars of the past between professional armies were replaced by total war as masses were inducted into the military and entire nations were channeled into support of the war effort.  Civilians who had never fought before found themselves hating enemies they did not know, picking off perfect strangers and cleaning trenches of the frightened and wounded.  What would they report about their service?  Although uniformed personnel suffered most of the casualties, civilians found themselves bombarded, expelled from their homes and forced to work for their countrys invaders.  How do they reconcile their loyalty to homeland with their acts of self-preservation?  How did the war affect the peoples faith and how did men of the cloth and their flocks pray to the same God for help in killing their fellow men?  How did individuals and nations assuage their grief and with what rituals did they conduct their mourning?Authors Stephane Audoin-Rouzeau and Annette Becker raise and try to answer these questions and more.  Originally written in French by French scholars it focuses on the French experience, but not the exclusion of other belligerents.  The writing flows so well that I would not have known that it was a translation had I not been told.  I did pick up a few facts of interest.  Australia was the only significant belligerent not to adopt conscription, most armies were dominated by peasants and War Memorials listing the dead and tombs of the unknown arose in the wake of the Great War.  At times I concluded that the American Civil War anticipated the course of the World War I and its aftermath.  A fairly balanced study of the Armenian Massacre is presented as the Turks sought to remove civilians potentially sympathetic to the Ottoman Empires Russian enemies.  At the end of this work I felt that I was aware of some currents flowing below the surface of battle and politics that so often dominate other tomes.  Understanding will take more reflection and more reading.  It is a good read early in the Centennial as it will help readers appreciate some of the thoughts they will encounter in future histories. For that it is worth picking up.I did receive a free copy of this book with the hope, but not the requirement, of a review.

I always like to share Robyn Carrs novels with the women in my life to get the feminine take on them.A New Hope is Carrs newest Thunder Point novel.  The series is set in the small, picturesque Oregon town of Thunder Point.  The main characters are Ginger Dysart and Matt Lacoumette.  Ginger and Matt meet at Matts sisters wedding.  Both characters are getting over failed first marriages.  They help each other discover what went wrong in their previous relationships.  These discoveries help them heal so they can go on with their lives.  Robyn Carr does an excellent job of telling the story and holding the readers interest.  A New Hope is captivating novel whether this is your first Thunder Point book or if you have had the pleasure to read the whole series.  Carr explains all the characters to the reader and their connections to each other.  This is an enjoyable read.

The DB Power Fashion Wind Clip Lamp is a very handy device for reading or when you need a light up close.  Its battery powered off of a recharger so no cord is necessary.  At the touch it cycles through three levels of brightness.  It has a clip for attachment to a table and, what I really like, is two strips across the base to hold it in place if you just want to sit it on a flat surface.  The neck bends to get into the just right position.  I am looking forward to many hours of enjoyment from this lamp.I did get a free lamp for testing and review.

I have long heard of St. Theresa, The Little Flower, and finally decided to read her life in her own words.  Her autobiography consists of three writings she produced under the direction of her superiors in the Carmel.  It tells the story of her faith driven life and the family that nurtured it.  We read of her mothers death, her adoption of her older sister as a replacement mother, her fathers joy as one after another of her daughters entered the convent and her familial and religious relationship with her sisters in home and the Carmel.  It provides a perspective on life.  I found my lessons on its pages.  Find yours.

World War II was not fought only on battlefields and the seas by soldiers and sailors, but also in factories by workers and managers. A City at War is the story of this home front told from the perspective of organized labor. Author Richard L. Pifer lays the background of Milwaukees historic industrialization and the state of its economy and workforce as well as the economic and political milieu in which it grew. Readers learn of Milwaukees transformation from a processor of food to a producer of steel and machinery. Pifer also explains the ongoing rivalry between the craft unions, concentrated in the A F of L and the industrial unions of the CIO. Resulting jurisdictional disputes would continue to contribute to labor unrest during the war. With its German and industrial heritage Milwaukee was unique among American cities in repeatedly election Socialist mayors.A City At War chronicles the role of organized labor in negotiating the agreements for overtime and work rules and organizing patriotic initiatives, such as war Bond Drives that enabled industry and labor to contribute to the war effort. I have read histories of industrys role in providing tools need by the military, but this is the first book I have seen viewing the history from labors perspective. One topic the labor historian must address is labors record of striking while Americas sons were fighting and dying, a practice some regard as disloyal. Pifer confronts the issue head on. He demonstrates that both management and labor maintained a perspective extending into an era of peace when struggles over profits, wages and work rules would determine the success of companies and the security of workers. Pifer makes the case that strikes were fewer and of shorter duration during the war than they were before and would be after. World War II is shown as a time during which inflation was rampant, even though partially suppressed by wage and price controls. Workers endured economic hardships while struggling to make ends meet and preserve their post-war prosperity. Although focusing on Milwaukee, its experience overlapped that of many other communities. I finished this tome with a deeper understanding of the role domestic labor relations played in contributing to victory. It is essential to an understanding of the home front in World War II.I did receive a free copy of this work for reading and review.

Avenue of Spies is the tale of the Jackson family, American Dr. Sumner, his Swiss born wife Toquette, and their son Phillip as they live through the German occupation of Paris during World War II.  It involves the Resistance, deprivation, internment and, well I do not want to give the story away.Author Alex Kershaw has woven a true story into novel-quality reading.  I do not just mean that it is written well, but it is the story of a family caught up in war.  Neither big battles nor generals play much role in this book.  The people themselves are not important to the history of the war, but their story is. It does give the reader an appreciation for what people like the Jacksons endured. As I read it I kept wanting to know what would happen next.  Read it and find out for yourself.I did receive a free copy of this book for reading and review.

Collections of a Civil War Trivia Junkie is a cornucopia of facts about any aspect of the Civil War: the people (yes, women included), the battles, the armaments, you name it, this has it.Some reference businesses we know (Goodyear and American Express for two) others individuals (which Confederate agent in England was the uncle of a U. S. President?) some battles, such as those that occurred under winter conditions and terms like Pyrrhic victory are defined.  Some turn on mental lightbulbs.  I had long heard of Hanger Orthopedics, but never realized that Hanger was a Confederate private who designed his own prosthesis.The book is organized into 14 chapters, each of which contains over 50 questions and answers, interspersed with related photos.  Following that are Lists of Alternate Battle Names, Observation Balloon Corps, Defiles, Vessels, Civil War Firsts, Stamps, Horses, Houses, International Aspects, Nicknames, Statistics, Campaigns, definitions of Principles of War, Prisons, Raids and Campaigns, Women and more.Author John Nischwitz entertains the St. Louis Civil War Roundtable with his Trivia Quizzes and now has made them available to the reading public.  This is a book you may not read straight through but one you will pick up now and then, maybe while watching the game, and go through a few pages.  Some entries will pass almost unnoticed, many will be interesting and others will be true gems, an I didnt know that moment.  Collections of a Civil War Trivia Junkie is a rewarding read for anyone with an interest in our great national conflict.

The triumph of the American Revolution almost ended in a disaster of financial insolvency, military revolt and the death of a new nation just aborning.  Sword in Their Hands chronicles the roads to that lead to that crisis, the characters who spawned the Newburgh Conspiracy and the Father who saved his country once again.Author Dave Richards has done an excellent job of explaining the background to the events and the people involved.  The main problem stemmed from the weakness of a Continental Congress that assumed the obligation to prosecute a war without the ability to impose taxes and states unwilling to pay their assessment to the national government.  Army officers fought for years without pay or supplies while Congress and the states looked to each other to provide the means to continue.  With victory won they faced abonnement: uncompensated, impoverished, victims of the country whose independence they had just won.  With the Army headquartered at Newburgh, New York leaders called a meeting to prepare an ultimatum to Congress calling for payment of a pension or a lump sum to save its officer corps from poverty and disgrace.  Just in its moment of victory the Army threatened to march on Congress, stage a military coup and scuttle the American experiment with democracy.  As he had in the past and would in the future, George Washington rose to the occasion.  A surprising and unwelcome visitor, he implored his men to do nothing that would tarnish their place in the hearts of their countrymen.  Seeing they remained unconvinced, he produced a letter.
