It's interesting to see a Roundworld librarian encounter the UU's librarian, and we can root for the wizards to win.

Deb Wise has a lot of experience creating light-ish desserts.  It's her day job, after all.  In this book she offers a good selection of meal-ending sweets, from pies and cookies and cakes and fruit-based-but-not-pie things to muffins and puddings.  Plenty of variety.Each recipe comes with a photo.  Each comes with clear directions - not to be taken lightly.  Each category comes with a few tips and techniques, some of which were new to me.But what of the recipes themselves?  Of course I've tried only a few, and can't speak for all.  The sweet-savory muffins were good, and the chocolate cookies ditto.  The biscotti recipe worked. I'm not a pie or cooked-fruit person so can't judge there.  But she doesn't just reduce the serving sizes.  These are genuinely lightened desserts that get the most taste for the reduction in calories.One large caveat:  she uses Cool-Whip in a lot of the mousse-type and pie-type recipes.  If you can't countenance that, the number of recipes you can use here is reduced by quite a bit.  If you're on the fence, check out her defense of the stuff.

Here is a huge and elaborate cat condo, with plenty of levels and hiding places and even ladders for the elderly cat who might stoop to use one rather than leaping up.  There are three top perches, so your cats can work out their dominance issues by competing for the highest one.  Lots of rope-covered surfaces to sharpen claws on.It is HEAVY, and assembly is not simple.  The diagrams are clear enough and they label the pieces (except the screws).  BUT assembly starts with the middle rather than going top down or bottom up, which was confusing.  But, as long as you have two people available you can get it done.  Just keep referring to the picture of the finished item and you will probably not go wrong.  Note that the ladders are anchored only at the top.Quality is not great.  One of the steps for the ladders came off in the shipping box, and they're just stapled on.  We were able to whop that step back on, but I don't know if it will stay long.Our cats have not yet taken to it, but they're cats.  If we ignore the thing for a while, or if we seed it with catnip, we expect they'll eventually give it a whirl.

It's useful to  have soft butter always available on the table.  You could leave your butter out like the Danes (for example) do, but that only works if you use a lot of butter or don't mind slightly rancid butter much of the time.The French trick of keeping butter at the right temperature with cold water has been around a while, but the containers are the wrong shape for the butter available in America.  This butter keeper solves that problem.  But be careful.  If your butter comes in the long sticks you want the company's other model.  If you use the shorter thicker sticks this is the one for you.It's possible to jam the longer stick into this model, but you have to cut and shape it which defeats the purpose and the convenience.Based on first impression, this is an excellent method of keeping butter soft without spoiling it.  I really like having room temperature butter available all the time.

This is an excellent and thoroughly protective case for my iPhone 6.  It has a soft outer bumper, shock protection, and a screen protector.  The whole thing is enclosed, so no dust.  It comes with a belt clip if you use such things.  I don't, so I'm glad the clip can be removed easily.  Charging cables work fine for me, and straight-line connector headphones work fine too.  Not sure if an angled-connector headphone would work, so that's something to consider.Of course the case makes the phone package bulkier and heavier, but it's a good tradeoff if you're the type who drops things.  This is not a sleek fashion case.The only drawback is that the pictorial instructions for opening the case to get your phone into it are ludicrous.  The second picture, in particular, looks like you're supposed to wave a tuning fork at the thing.  The trick is to use a credit card to pry the soft shell away from the rest of the case.  Now you don't have to go to the Interwebs for help.

This is the good stuff - Swiss chocolate.  The current fad is all for dark chocolate with higher and higher percentages of cocoa.  Which is all very nice, but leads to ignoring the considerable pleasures to be had from milk chocolate, especially the high end Swiss versions.  The bar includes almonds, hazelnuts, and raisins - but not enough to overwhelm the chocolate flavor.  The texture is excellent, and the block divisions in the bar make it possible (though not easy!) to partake in limited portions.Not cheap, but the quality is commensurate with the price.  Enjoy!

Resumes for Dummies is an excellent up to date book about resume writing and other aspects of the 21st century job search.  Your public library is full of books on resumes that are out of date.  Things have changed, between the advent of social media and the shift away from the one-size-fits-all chronological tombstone resume.  This book is fully up to date, and written by a true resume expert.Areas covered include how to handle social media and job boards, keeping yourself from being passed up because too many sources forward your info to a job opening,  best formats for different situations, setting up your plain text resume, choosing the best words to represent your experience, targeting your resume for different jobs, and so on.  There are sample layouts and, most welcome, sample resumes for different situations from job changing through being fired, through a series of progressive jobs with a single employer, and of course, the new worker with essentially no experience. An area where the book really shines is in finding ways to present summary information to make you stand out.Little or no wasting time on the obvious, lots of fresh valuable information and advice, and SAMPLES.  An excellent resource.

We don't grill a whole lot, partly because of the painfully long time it can take to start the coals, and the residual taste of lighter fluid that comes along.  This thing solves the problem, as long as you grill within a short distance of an electrical outlet.  Which we do.Set up the coals, turn the thing on to the first setting, and they light.  Switch to the second setting which blows air around, and they get going pretty quickly.  Yes, you have to stand there and hold it, but that's no burden.  Someone should be around to chat with.Once you're finished using it you have to find a safe place for it to cool down.  As long as you plan for it, not a burden.  So:  lighter-fluid-free start for your coals, usable within a few feet of an electrical outlet.  A good solution for a nagging problem.

Most of us probably think that atheism and skepticism about supernatural powers are relatively recent phenomena, and that before the Enlightenment and certainly in the ancient world everybody believed whatever the dominant society presented as its official religious belief.  Tim Whitmarsh's study of atheism (mainly in the classical world) affirms otherwise.  He starts the book with a chapter that presents the argument that skeptics toward the supernatural and miracles or supernatural beings have been present throughout history, and that there was always variety of unbelief, belief, and undecidedness (which we now call agnosticism).He goes on to present various authors and episodes of out and out atheism (mainly from plays or other art plus a few court records and philosophical treatises), belief in a different type of god than the society offered (Socrates and his personal daimon versus the ritualized sacrifices that the Greek polis performed publicly for one example), and other recorded evidence of skeptical or atheistic belief.  His learning is evident, and the scope of the inquiry is broad.  The book will be a valuable reference and roundup and guide for people interested in classical beliefs and in whatever skeptical or atheistic or unusual attitudes were reflected in literature, philosophy, and whatever court records and histories we have - ranging from pre-Homeric Greece through the classical period and on through Constantine.  Whitmarsh carefully distinguishes between the various types of unbelief and skepticism, and reminds us that the term and position of "atheism" means something different in the age and culture where monotheism is the religious norm than it did in ancient polytheistic times.As usual with such topics, you may find that the author is more interested in it than you are.  Nevertheless, this is a popular work, not intended simply for scholars.  It comes with full notes, which is welcome for those cases where you might be skeptical of a bit of information yourself.

Assuming that you use a paper appointment calendar, this one is excellent.  Middle-sized with one week to the page plus a series of really lovely and intriguing photographs of items from the Smithsonian's vast holdings.  They take care to balance among historical artifacts and art, and everything they choose is worth looking at; nothing too challenging but not just masterpiece pictures of flowers.The blocks are smallish at 7 to a page, so this isn't for you if you have a complex schedule.  The paper is heavy enough to survive being written on, unlike some fancy engagement calendars.So:  the weekly featured photos live up to the title, the quality is high enough for its likely users.  What's not to like?

This latest entry in the series is one of the best, featuring superb suspense, splendid characters, just enough of the grotesque and macabre to keep a reader fascinated.  The image of the burning man is threaded so neatly into the plot that somehow reflects modern the problems of domestic terrorism and the anarchy of the mob while still evoking the spirit of wartime (WW II) London and Sherlock Holmes in The sign of the Four! The ending was not unexpected yet followed the classic arc of tragedy in a way that paid homage to it and elevated the story to an epic.  Christopher Fowler succeeds in having us care about the relationship between all the characters, not just Bryant and May, Janice Longbright or the various victims.I already know how it comes out but I've re-read the last few chapters over again twice.  So that's a good sign.If you like this kind of suspenseful pastiche and enjoy crime stories set in London, and you somehow have missed this series up to now, you have a treat coming.

This is one heck of a jacket. Intended for extreme weather conditions, so it is may be a bit much for your ordinary windy day.  But it is great.  Lots of pockets intelligently placed, really excellent cuffs that keep wind out, and it looks nice.  The hood and standup collar together do a great job with wind and rain.  Lots of ways to adjust it to your preferences.For very cold temperatures you would probably want the liner (sold separately), but on its own this jacket does very well with wind and temperatures above freezing.Recommended for those who don't need or are aware of the need for a liner.

This is handy add-on for those stylish thin laptops that dispense with Ethernet ports.  Everybody uses WiFi, right?  Wrong.  Sometimes there is no WiFi, and virtually always Ethernet is faster.  And safe from possible WiFi eavesdropping.For many Macs and (I'm told, no personal experience here) some Windows machines you'll need a driver.  These can be downloaded from TP-Link's site.  On Mac the installation is simple.If you have a USB port that follows the older slower standards, your Ethernet will be slower too.  Still beats nothing, by a lot.

Ryan Berkley is well-known on the Internet (primarily via Etsy) for his oddly compelling head-and-shoulders portraits of animals in human costume.  This small book includes 26 of the portraits, along with breathlessly whimsical descriptions of each animal's life that satirize...something.  They mostly sound modern and slightly repellent, like those descriptions of people in ads for Scotch.  Many satirize some form of modern-life obsession, and all focus on some aspect of social life.  Whimsy has to be taken in small doses to work best.It's a small book, and the art is fascinating.  Probably best as a gift book or a bedside book in a guest room.  Which is no knock on it at all.

Most of the time I wear funky watches.  Old Swatches, brightly colored designer-ish watches, nonstandard time indications, etc.  That's my style.  But sometimes I need something less jazzy and more traditional.  This fills the bill nicely.  It's a high-quality quartz watch with a certain flair.  Two-tone band (silver and a nice rose gold) with a rose gold dial and small jewels marking the hours.  There's a second hand, which is a good thing.  The date indicator is discreet rather than huge.It's not really an evening watch (too big), but it bridges the gap between funky and evening well.  I could wear it to a job interview, for example.It's about as unobtrusive and traditional as I can stand to wear, and feels solid on the wrist.  Appears durable;  I'll report back if there are any problems.

If you are a fan of Joann Weir you will love this book.  Her voice and personality and approach are evident throughout, and there is plenty of personal history with photos.  Her grandparents, her parents, her various cooking teachers (Madeleine Kammen most prominently), her colleagues at Chez Panisse and afterwards are all represented here, with frankness and humor. Overall, a delight.Recipes abound, many of which are tempting and nearly all of which fall into Weir's remit of California-Mediterranean cooking.  Unsurprisingly, a large proportion are high-effort/high-reward.  But you can start with a simple tomato and mayo sandwich from her childhood, presented as lovingly and photographed as attractively as the more modern recipes.  Everything is here because Joanne Weir loves it and because it has a place in her life and history.  The recipes are clear.  I don't yet know how many work well, as I have not tried a lot, but there are no signs of problems in the recipes as written.Is this a must-have cookbook?  Not at all.  Is it full of good stuff and gorgeous pictures?  Yes.  If you are a cookbook collector (meaning that cookbooks don't have to be essential to find a place in your home) you'll be happy with it.  And, again, if you're a Joanne Weir fan you really really want this.

Chaya Deitsch lucked out in life.  She was raised in a close Hasidic (Lubavitcher) family with a warm and loving-but-not-smothering mother.  The family lived far enough away from Crown Heights so they were not under the direct and intense scrutiny of the community as they might have been.  The community rules were somewhat less rigid when she was growing up than they are now.  When she removed herself from the community, she was able to keep her connections to her family.  She's not angry, she's not out to show how bad she had it and how awful the community is. Thus her story is an important counterpoint to the recent burst of revenge memoirs by people who grew up Orthodox and by people who joined the Hasidic world and then left.The book traces her childhood, her transition to adulthood through a faraway yeshiva and then to a secular college.  At which point we leave her until the epilogue in which she tells her parents that she is no longer frum.  Of course they already know - they're no dummies - and her mother especially shows great character and parental skill in her reactions.My problem with the book is that Chaya Deitsch's childhood just isn't that interesting and her adolescence is nothing unusual - she's not all that externally rebellious and she narrates pretty much from her childhood and adolescent point of view, without much analysis or insight.  Her love for her extended family is clear throughout, however.  The few moments when insights break through the narrative are among the best in the book.  Her realization that non-Orthodox Jews don't think they're sad sinful failures at Judaism, but rather form their own communities with their own norms and customs that are satisfying to them is one example.It's only fair to judge the book as the author wrote it, without whining that I would prefer some different book.  But in this case I wanted to hear much more about the author's post-college life and current relationship with her sisters.  That's the real differentiator in this story over the many I-fled-Orthodox-oppression memoirs.  Perhaps she wanted to spare her sisters' privacy, a decision I respect.  Still, the best parts of the book are the beginning and ending sections.So, should you read this book?  Yes, if you want to know how someone can rebel without breaking ties to family.  Be warned, however:  you need a certain level of Jewish knowledge (or a certain facility with Google searches).  There are uncommon Yiddish terms (ainek'l for one) without a glossary, and language from prayers is quoted with no explanation.  This is a good thing, because it marks the book as not intended for those who simply want to gawk at the strange Hasidic world.

My cats are not particularly picky eaters, but they both have dental issues.  This means they need to have soft food, not shreds or fillets or serious chunks.  Despite the name, and as promised in the description, this stuff is more like pate than chunks, and my cats have no trouble lapping it up.They're happy, the food doesn't sit around in the bowls and smell up the place, and there are no evident digestive issues.  Happy cats, happy owners.  Cost doesn't seem out of line, but each of us has to judge that based on family budget.

National Geographic knows how to do a coffee table book, and is expert in combining text and graphics in a compelling narrative.  Here is the story of the Old West, our national westward movement and the frontier that shaped our culture for two centuries, conveyed in a series of short essays about events, people, and places.  Each comes with at least one truly stunning original picture, map, or photo.  The sequence of history is here, from  the Louisiana purchase and the Lewis and Clark expedition all the way through Teddy Roosevelt, statehood for the various territories, and the closing of the West.  Also, and more interestingly, we see how transportation, the Civil War and related tensions, settlement, Chinese railroad workers, mining, cowboys and sheepmen were all part of the economic and cultural story of the West.  And Indians, both as warriors and as mistreated residents of reservations and the schools that tried to stamp out their culture.The whole thing is splendid.  The graphics are superb, and used well.  The sidebars and illustrative stories are well-selected and well-written.  I can't imagine anyone not enjoying this beautiful presentation of the sweep and pettiness and glory and shameful episodes of the American West.  The less attractive parts of the story are not hidden, but not dwelt on disproportionately either.  There's a lot to romanticize in our national story of westward movement, and this book leaves that possibility open.  In the back of the book you'll find suggestions for further reading, and complete photo/graphics credits.  These last two components are important, as they increase the credibility of the book.

This is an excellent dog food.  Made in the USA, no strange chemical ingredients, and based on fish.  My dog LOVES it.  We started by mixing it with her previous weight control food to ensure that it didn't upset her stomach.  Success there, so we gradually increased the proportions.  She seems reasonably satisfied and full, though like all dogs she still scavenges from the floor.  Just less so.The drawback here is cost, at least for a large dog.  The four-pound bag would feed her for less than a week.  If you have a small dog who needs weight control food, the cost/benefit balance looks pretty good.  For a larger dog not so much.  We will probably use this stuff in rotation with other foods, as a reward.

The Agile methodology (or approach) to software development is still relatively new.  The promise of Agile, when it is not used as an elaborate cover for the old no-process no-planning no-accountability way software was developed in the Very Bad Old Days, is that customers can be made happy with continuous delivery of software that gets ever closer to what they want - usable software that works without bugs and without security risks.So how do you find out whether your Agile team is producing as well as it can?  What do you measure?  How do you measure it?  In the new world of development and build and tracking tools, almost everything can be instrumented to provide data.  So how do you fulfill the Agile goal of measuring only what matters?  How do you figure out what matters?  Davis has provided lots of measurement tools with examples of the metrics produced AND several case studies that show how to implement his ideas AND guidance on how to discover what matters in your situation by measuring various things.  Finally, there is guidance on how to match metrics to the Agile principles and how to use the metrics to improve your team and processes - and products, which is what your customers care about.  And then there is an appendix with full and explicit info on constructing a metrics system using commonly available tools.This is a highly technical book; you have to understand the jargon and know modern software engineering and build processes to understand it and benefit from it  There is no list of acronyms and no glossary of concepts, so you really have to know the field.  The index is spotty and inconsistent, a minor irritant.  None of this ultimately matters if you're part of the intended audience of this book - Agile teams and their first-level supervisors and leads.

Mixed review here.  The shape of the pitcher is great, as is the size.  The filtered water tastes much better than what comes directly out of the tap.  But I can't get the thing to pour without major dripping and dribbling, unless I remove the cover first.  Something about the design of the automatically lifting spout cover makes for drips.Others have mentioned a learning curve in this regard.  Maybe I'm just clumsy, but I've tried every trick I know and the thing still dribbles unless I remove the cover.

This year's entry in the Best American Essays anthology is filled with personal autobiographical essays, reflecting the interests of the editor, with few of the magazine-article type of essay that can be equally marvelous and personal and illuminating.  Which means that the bar is very high; the world is chockablock with memoirs and autobiographies, and there are a whole heck of a lot of writers who have already written about, say, aging.There are a few standouts here:  Isaiah Berlin's message to the 21st century, Margo Jefferson on her upbringing in a fiercely upper class Black family in the 50s, David Sedaris on whatever, Justin Cronin on his very young daughter's relationship with God and religion, Zadie Smith on New York life, and more.  The authors I find irritating are still irritating (though they may be favorites of yours): Sven Birkerts and Phillip Kennicott are represented by typical work.  For my money, neither of them succeeds in taking a common topic (growing up gay, being sick while also being an extremely sensitive guy) and making it interesting.  On the other hand, Tim Kreider makes owning and mourning a cat touching and interesting.Still, you'll probably find at least a few works here that get to you.  Recommended to fans of the series, who already know that quality varies within each volume.

Middle Eastern flavors are irresistible, and the Israeli version that falls at the crossroads of many other cuisines in the region is no exception.  The success of Yotam Ottolenghi's series of cookbooks is proof of that.  Here we have another gorgeous cookbook that incorporates the personal story of a charismatic chef and also delivers reliable recipes for terrific food.There are lots of photos, the recipes are written clearly, and the book lies blessedly flat when you open it.  Why don't more publishers do that?  So far I've tried his version of tehina (garlic/tahini sauce) and dishes made with it; the amazing watermelon-feta-olive salad; Simple Sumac Onions; and his version of pita.  I prefer other pita recipes to his, but the other things I tried were beyond excellent.Some of the recipes require lots of ingredients, but few are exotic and many recur.  Few seem fussy for the sake of fussiness or presume that you have an army of prep cooks, though most require real effort at a level commensurate with the reward.  Plenty of them wring glorious flavor from everyday ingredients like lentils and rice and onions and ginger with herbs, while others depend on expensive fish or meat.So do you need this if you already have Ottolenghi's books?  Absolutely.  Solomonov's take on Israeli cooking is different enough that you'll want to get into it, and he knows how to tell a good story.  The book hits all the requirements for a cookbook in these days of recipes on the Internet: interesting recipes that work, an author with personality and a good story, and beautiful photos.

Works for me to prevent muscle cramps.  Magnesium is a trace element that should come through diet, and I eat a varied diet with lots of fruit and vegetables.  Nevertheless, when I take magnesium I don't get foot cramps and finger cramps.  When I skip the magnesium I get the muscle cramps.These pills are on the large side so if you have trouble swallowing pills you might look elsewhere.  Otherwise, they seem fine.  They deliver the benefit my doctor promised and they have no side effects that I can determine.

I've had this product for an hour, and love it.  It solves the problems I had with my previous surge protector/USB charger thing, and has some extra virtues of its own.First, it has enough power to charge my iPad mini 3, which the previous item didn't.  When I connected the mini, it announced that it wasn't charging, though it actually did charge at a slow trickle rate.  This one just starts charging.Second, it accomodates more plugs - a total of six some of which are at an angle so you can acually plug in six items.Third, it has charging and grounding lights.Fourth, it comes with actually useful documentation, written with a little bit of humor.  The doc covers how to attach the plug to your outlet, because you have to remove the outlet plate mounting screw if there is one, or remove the surge protector's screw if you have a decorative plate with no mounting screw.  Sure, YOU can figure this out for yourself but there are other people on the planet who can't.  Plus a little humor in documentation, especially if it doesn't interfere with clear communication, is a good thing.  As a technical writer I'm envious of whoever got to write this booklet.It comes in the usual we-think-you're-a-thief-so-you-must-wrestle-to-liberate-your-purchase packaging.  Luckily you only have to liberate it once.  So if you need a not-ugly surge protector that also multiplies outlets and handles charging of two hungry devices, this one is great.I'm planning to buy another one for my home office with my own money.

So what is your goal in visiting San Francisco, the Bay Area and the wine country?  Presumably to find vineyards and drive around to things inaccessible without a car, given that you're looking at a book of road trips, which does a decent job of laying out road trips.However, the definition of Bay Area is pretty limited, though probably apt for people heading to the wine country.  San Francisco itself is very lightly covered, and I'm not really sure why they put it in the book given that there are other more complete sources of SF information and that driving around the city is more pain than pleasure.  If I were queen of the universe or at least in charge of Lonely Planet I would have left out the brief coverage of the city itself and put in more thorough coverage of everything else.On the good side, they do cover Muir Woods which is glorious and (essentially) accessible only by car.  The map is usable, and there is not an overwhelming amount of choice for any one area.  This last may be a fault too; more varied choices would be welcome.  But this is a brief packable guide, not a comprehensive one.So if this book fits your need for a compact but reasonably authoritative guide to a few good road trips in Northern California, you'll do okay with this.  If you really want something more comprehensive, stay away.

Feet of Clay is perhaps not the very best Pratchett, but marvelous nontheless.  Written years before his Alzheimer's began to affect the depth and breadth of his writing.Here he takes on his version of the Jewish legend of the Golem, a huge and tireless worker created from clay.  As usual with Pratchett there are political undertones - a Golem's rights movement, essentially, springs up in Ankh-Morpork.  The Golems start to act a bit strange, holding meetings at which the human world thinks they must be up to no good.  So the Golems' activities are controlled by "the words in their heads"?  Even though theirs are on a strip of paper and ours are more abstract, aren't we controlled by the same thing?This is the only Pratchett to have anything close to specific Jewish content, so if your synagogue book club is looking for an interesting novel of ideas that will definitely support a lively discussion, consider Feet of Clay.

Jeffrey Buller has been an executive and a change leader in higher education, before he became a consultant in educational leadership.  In this useful, practical, and inspiring book he presents the case for productive change processes in education, with examples as well as methods for transformative change.  "Change" can mean anything, from lengthy and pointless strategic planning exercises to practical and effective reconsiderations of organizational structure and processes and policies.  Long ago when I worked at a university (staff, not faculty) I was press-ganged into participating in one of those strategic planning things, and I agree entirely with Buller's takedown of the whole thing.  Months of effort resulting in a lot of turf defense and meaningless reports.He both describes usable processes for leading real change, and talks about the ways in which leadership itself must change.  Unlike many consultants, whose books are vague and full of promises, this one gives you enough real and actionable material that you may not need an outside change leader like Buller.Other reviewers have explained more of the specific content; I'm content to recommend the book highly - for anyone on higher education staff or faculty or anyone involved in attempts to create transformative change there.

My new MacBook is great, but it doesn't have an Ethernet adapter.  Rather than buying a pricey Thunderbolt-to-Ethernet cable, I requested this adapter.  It's small and light, and it works for Ethernet.  I had to track down the Mac driver on the Displaylink site, but that's no big deal.Because this machine has an HDMI port already I haven't tested the video features for Mac.  I did test on a Dell Alienware laptop, and it does automatically install the driver and support dual display use there.  The body of the adapter got very warm very fast, so keep an eye on that.So:  compact multifunctional adapter that works well - other users report video problems but in my simple use case I didn't see them.  Displaylink support seems good, or at least they interact promptly and thoroughly with their users.

Never mind whether the cloud is a fad or a fantasy or the actual next savior of IT for businesses and organizations.  Enterprise IT (the data center in the basement with offsite storage and maybe a hosted web presence and a few outsourced apps or services) is so 2010.If you are a business or IT executive tasked with figuring out how to move your organization to cloud computing, or if you are an analyst or consultant preparing strategies for others, this is the book you need to figure out your cloud computing strategy and go a long way toward implementing that strategy.  It's just technical enough for that purpose, and will certainly equip you to understand and evaluate what vendors are trying to sell you.  He even acknowledges that the old data center and dumb terminal model is not that different from cloud computing in concept.Bond defines the basics, then works through the process from planning through operational and application transformation (separate processes!), deployment, billing, security, management, etc.  In each area there are use cases, scenarios, tools, checklists, lessons learned, and concrete, actionable advice.  If you take away nothing else from this book, the advice not to write your own cloud management tool is golden.You can read a zillion biased white papers, you can hire a cloud consultant, or you can read this book and get the advice and understanding you need.  I'd pick this book.

These Scotch brand Kids Scissors are lightweight. They have comfortable grips and the lefthanded students are happy they can use them too.The blunt tips are safe as promised.  A good feature is the short blades, which are easier for kids to control.  The blades are sharp enough, too, to cut paper cleanly.  And the handles are all the same color, so no fuss over who gets which color.I'm going to buy another set so there are no arguments over who gets the nifty new scissors and who gets stuck with the old ones.

This is Elizabeth Gilbert's first self-help book (or her second, if you count Eat, Pray, Love as some of its readers seem to do), and it is excellent.  Gilbert sets out to debunk some of the big misconceptions about the creative life, such as the tormented artist and the drama that supposedly goes with and supports creativity, and that it's better to be a noble failure than to produce actual creative work.  She doesn't want to take away a bit of the magic.  In fact, as her title says, she presents creativity as a kind of big magic.  Your creative idea or project is inside you, and wants to be expressed by you.  If you don't take heed, the idea will eventually move on to someone else.  Creativity isn't limited to what we usually call art; Gilbert considers any activity involving skill and giving joy as creative work, including the pursuit of figure skating in middle age.Gilbert sensibly identifies perfectionism as a kind of fear - why does it matter if your work is not perfect?  Better that it be complete than that it await perfection. Your creativity need not support you in the world.  That's not its responsibility.  You might think that's easy for Gilbert to say, and she does acknowledge the great good luck she's had with her big bestseller.  But that was preceded by years of day jobs and squeezing her writing in the time left from other things.The book is genuinely inspiring, contains both good advice and good stories, and avoids the usual cliches around creativity. Recommended.

Linda Gregerson is one of those poets who is deeply respected by a lot of other poets and less well known to the public, even to the public of poetry readers.  This is her first volume of selected poems, and it is intelligently structured with 10 new poems and about 10 poems each from her previous collections.  This lets readers compare the poems from before she found her preferred stanza to the many that came afterward.Gregerson writes for people who can catch allusions to The Great Books and who can pick up other hints as well.  Her last few books are set in an open stanza with the lines indented and broken in a manner that is her own - the long lines are a bit like CK Williams.  Unlike so many recent poets, she has and uses an ear and she has and uses a facility for language - lots of the lines are just plain lovely.  Many poems include little puzzles of the "do you know what I am referring to" variety, but none seem to be there just for fun or to trick the reader.  Instead, I found my mind and memory stretched.Most of the work has an emotional core, and she follows the injunction one of my poet friends once passed to me:  if you write about common experiences or emotions, couch them in unusual terms.  There is illness and loss here, along with love and other emotions, and lots of consideration of visual arts.The only way to tell if you'll enjoy Gregerson and meet her challenges to the reader is to look at a few of the poem - the ones Amazon includes on this page are representative of her best.  She's no Billy Collins or Mary Oliver, whose meaning is easy to grasp and whose pleasures are immediate.  But the rewards are high if you are equipped to stay the course.  Just don't ask me whether these are lyrical, descriptive, or meditative poems - none of those categories quite fits.

Agatha Christie wrote a lot of mysteries where the method was poison.  Poison wasn't all that easy to get, and the effects of poison aren't usually the instant death we see on TV.  Kathryn Harkup has put together a compendium of poisons known to Christie, with a description of the use, effects, place in the pharmacopia, ease of obtaining, and so on.  With notes relating each poison to the Christie book(s) where it was used.Some interesting points:  there are more chemists and scientists and druggists than you might expect in Christie's books, reflecting the ways poison could be obtained then and throwing more people under suspicion.  Christie made some large and small mistakes about poisons, some of which seem deliberate.You won't learn how to poison people from this book (whew) - the Internet is your best source there.  Just don't search from your home computer, or hide your IP address when you do and clear your search history.  There isn't as much Christie as one might hope.  The writing is serviceable.  The alphabetic organization prevents more general discussion, I think.This seemed like a golden idea to me - Christie is popular and important, and people love the idea of poison.  If you're a Christie buff you'll want to read this.  If you are interested in forensics generally or even in poisons specifically, there are better sources.  But the book just didn't sparkle or surprise as much as I hoped.

Zipper is already touchy after a week, and it's awkward to talk on the phone.  But if you want something that makes it easy to get to the phone and also carries your cards, cash, and a few keys this works well.  Lots of card slots, and the pouch is deep enough for  another small item or two.

This is the third book in the Science of Discworld series, which might more properly be called something else since the science relates to Roundworld, not Discworld.  The conceit is that Roundworld is a wizardly science experiment gone wrong, and that it exists inside the Unseen University.  The wizards feel responsible enough to keep intervening in Roundworld's history.  Each book in the series is set in alternating chapters, one carrying a vintage Pratchett story of how the wizards fix something with the aid of Hex, and the other set carrying pretty good popular science.It's clear to me that Pratchett himself wrote the story chapters - the voice is right and there are some true Pratchett touches (see page 207 for one example).  His concern with story and with what runs the world shows up here.  Rincewind, Stibbons, and the Chancellor all behave consistently with their portrayals elsewhere, and the wizards are still concerned mainly with food and with exerting as little effort as possible.  The portrayal of Darwin, especially Darwin attempting to figure out what he is doing on a chair talking to people who aren't quite people, is vintage Pratchett.The popular science ranges further than you might suspect, covering not just the origins of evolution as a theory but also how discoveries and inventions get made.  Cohen and Stewart are both good writers, but they do go on a bit too long.Obviously this is not the best introduction to Pratchett, but if you are interested in science and you enjoy Pratchett, you'll like this.  Just be sure what you're getting.  At this late date, when there wil be no more fresh Discworld material, it's a pleasure to read a full-bore Pratchett story.  Much more actual Pratchett here than in the miserable Long Earth series.

Campbell's regular canned version of chicken noodle soup is a mainstay of the emergency pantry.  We keep a can around just in case we don't have any other options for a quick lunch.  It is what it is - lots of sodium, plus broth that is a bit on the sweet side but does taste sort of like chicken.  And there's always a few chicken-ish morsels in there.This version is modernized in two ways.  It comes in one of those newfangled cardboard packages, and it is made with organic ingredients.  There are lots of definitions of organic, but I assume that the vegetables were grown "organically" and the chicken fed "organically" and the wheat grown "organically" and so on.  Not sure what the mysterious "organic flavoring" might be.But none of this matters, because the soup just doesn't taste good.  Bland despite the huge sodium load.  Didn't taste much like chicken at all.  Not horrible, really, but disappointing.  Definitely not worth the extra cost or fuss.

This is a standard good hairdryer that gets hot enough to dry my short hair quickly and to dry the other user's medium length hair reasonably fast.  What I like is a blast of hot air to shape and dry really fast, as my hair falls naturally into its best shape that way.  What the other user wants is to get her straightish hair dry without frizzing out.This thing does both.  It's on the light side for a full strengh dryer, and has a middle heat setting.  Small enough for my small hands to hold and manipulate easily.  It has the standard concentrator and diverter accessories, which I don't use but you might.  Not meant as a travel dryer, but smaller than many.So:  does the job just fine, nothing special but decently balanced and not too heavy.  Good value for the Amazon price, and attractive.

This book is a gem.  Michelson specializes in helping people get good medical care in serious or challenging illness, but his advice and strategies make sense for routine medical care as well.  Many patients are so used to doing what the doctor says that they don't take charge of their own care -and thus get overtreated, ignored, or otherwise get less than the best outcome and care.Michelson blends persoanal and individual stories with an excellent set of steps and strategies for getting the best care.  Speaking up for yourself, selecting a good doctor, coordinating your care, doing research that your doctor might not have time to do, being a collaborator with the doctor and an advocate for yourself, and so on.  And having someone else as your quarterback, the person who coordinates things and advocates for you.  And, perhaps most important, ways to make yourself seem like a person rather than a case when you're in the hospital.Much of what Michelson recommends is essentially assertiveness, and he includes what amount to scripts for handling potentially awkward conversations with medical people.  So - practical information, inspiration, and personal stories that illustrate and inspire.If you are facing a health crisis or serious chronic condition in yourself or in someone close to you, read this book and put the steps and actions into practice.  It really could save your life.

This is a compact manual burr grinder that has some good features - a detachable handle so it can be stored compactly, and an infinitely adjustable grind setting and a brush that helps clean it well.  Like all manual grinders it is quiet.  Takes maybe two minutes to grind enough for a single large mug of drip coffee.Which is exactly what I need so I can have freshly ground coffee at the office.  For me the grind has been reasonably consistent, with not too much dust.  I'm not sure how durable the grinding surface will turn out to be, but for my purposes this little grinder is close to perfect.One caution:  be careful when you take it apart or put it back together; the metal edge of the top compartment is sharp and you can cut yourself on it if you're clumsy enough.

Tip top Pratchett - wherein everyone in Ankh-Morpork gets a guitar and plays it badly.  Lots of troll jokes related to what he calls Music with Rocks In.  The usual mix of insights - you'd swear he played in a band at some point but that's the magic of the imagination at work - and humor.

Lots of interesting offbeat recipes, which mainly work.  Best for experienced bakers.  You'll need a scale that measures in grams and a converter to go from Celsius/gas mark temperatures to Farenheit.  If you've got those you're ready for some great baking.

This is a book full of delicious illustrations, with a fine surrealistic twist in the story.  But you have to check your feminist whatevers at the door, and put up with a princess in a warrior culture who doesn't get a real warrior horse but a cute little round pony in a sweaterinstead.  She makes the best of it, and gets to participate in the big battle, just not in way you might expect.If you're a Kate Beaton fan you'll love this.  If you don't get her humor you'll be indifferent at best.  If you expect a princess-gets-to-be-a-straightforward-conquering-heroine story you'll be disappointed.

I learned to like power toothbrushes relatively late in light, and these are the hard-to-find replacement heads for my favorite brush.  Fits fine, works fine, and doesn't have those stupid slits in the back of the head and stem that always dribble.New models aren't always better.  If you like this one, grab the replacement heads while you can.

China Mieville writes in lots of genres and mixes of genres, all of which have weirdness in common.  Not pointless wierdness, rather delicious weirdness in service of an actual story.  This is a book of short stories, highly various, ranging from 2-3 pagers to much longer works.  All exhibit his characteristic skill, many are less complex in structure and language than some of his novel-length work.If you've like any of Mieville's previous work you'll find something to like here, and you will probably find your horizons widened.  He comes up with a great variety of interesting premises, and spins each one out to the right length for it...or at least ONE of the right lengths for it.  Recommended, as long as you remember that even genius can occasionally misfire.

I have coarse dry short hair, with some grey ones mixed in that are even coarser.  I wash and blow dry daily.This shampoo works well for me in our rather hard water.  My hair feels good to the touch (neither stripped to the point where it is squeaky nor too thickly coated) and falls properly into style.Yes, I've had even better results with high end shampoos at four times the price, but this stuff is great for the price.

The amount of criticism that surrounded this series when it was first announced/published was really nothing short of shocking and a lot of it continues to this day. Between the people that hated the idea of a female Thor and the people that said it had poor writing....well, lets just say that positive statements were few and far between. What made this even more shocking is that I read the series from the start and thoroughly enjoyed it. I thought Jason Aaros writing was great and I personally loved the idea of a female Thor. Its nice to switch things up from time to time and take LONG running series in complete new and bold directions. In my opinion, comic sales in general would be doing much better if companies were far more open to taking these kinds of bold risks as they can really introduce new life into a lot of the long running series out there.I am a big fan of Thor and own a large amount of his comics and this was honestly like a breath of fresh air. I liked it so much I purchased the hard cover versions even tho I already own all of the comics. I normally do that sort of thing with series I really like. The bottom line - if your a fan of Thor and you haven't read this series yet, do yourself a favor and give it a shot and judge the title for yourself. Don't listen to all the negativity surrounding this title. Just go in with a clear open mind, without any preconceived notions, and I have no doubt that a lot of people out there will really love this series.One of the best aspects of the series is the mystery surrounding who this Thor really is and the series cleverly puts clues here and there along the way. One of the reviews I read a awhile back (can't remember who it or where I read it) really summed it up best, it said something along the lines of this arc being half-mystery and half-rookie-adventure. It really is a great description. If your planning on reading this and don't already know Thor's identity, don't go and look it up, regardless of how tempted you may be. You will ultimately wind up taking away the one of the single best aspects to this series, the mystery regarding who she really is.So to sum this up, I for one really enjoyed this series and I sincerely hope that this isn't the last we have seen of this character. I really hope that this series will inspire other companies and even Marvel to take more bold risks like this. If your a fan of Thor, you at least owe it to yourself to give this series a shot and to do so with an open mind.4 Stars!

In my opinion, Mark Texiera is one of the more underrated comic artists of this generation. In particular his depictions of Vampirella are some of my favorite the last 10-15 tears running. Unfortunately, this book does not do a very good job in regards to the overall selection of artwork shown. Don't get me wrong, there is some great artwork in here, but ultimately there is a lot of questionable artwork included here as well. That woundn't have bothered me so much if it weren't for the fact that those images wound up being selected over much better images. if this was some huge compendium of all of his best work, then I would be ok with it, but that is not the case. What you ultimately wind up with is one of the more mediocre art books I have seen in a very long time, especially comic related.All that being said, I have seen this book discounted heavily on multiple occasions. I don't think Amazon allows people to post the prices they paid for items so I will just say that I wound up paying very little for this book overall so even tho I consider it a mediocre art book, I am content with my purchase simply due to the fact that I paid so little for it. In fact, the price I paid for this book was one of the cheapest prices I have ever paid for an art book before. So my advice would be to keep an eye on the pricing and if you get an opportunity to buy it for a really great price, go ahead and do so. Its definitely worth it if you can get it cheap. That is really the only way I can recommend buying this book. The art book market for comic art is absolutely overflowing with amazing books so its hard giving this a recommendation with so many better books out there. So again, if your a big Texeira fan, only buy this if you can get a really good deal on it. Otherwise, I have to recommend passing altogether.2 Stars!

First and foremost, calling these posters is really a bit of a stretch. Traditionally, posters are printed on a very thin paper stock and these are printed on a much thicker paper stock. This should really be called Mass Effect: The Print Collection but thats just nitpicking. Regardless of what its called, the end result is really just a great collection of Mass Effect artwork. While the artwork itself is definitely much smaller (12"x16") than the Mass Effect prints that Bioware released through Treehouse Stores, this releases allows you to buy 20 prints for roughly 1/10th to 1/20th the cost of a single art print from Bioware as those prints now run anywhere from $100 to $300+, depending on the print. So this is a great way to get some really nice Mass Effect artwork for very little money and the best part about the thicker print stock is it allows you to display them on their own, just by leaning them up against something, although if you want to matt and frame them, that is certainly an option.All in all, I have become a big fan of these Poster collections.  I also own the Assassins Creed Poster Collection, The Halo Poster Collection, Gears of War Poster Collection, and The Elder Scrolls Online Poster Collection. Some of the other releases had 40 posters as opposed to 20, but even with just 20 posters, this is still just a killer deal. Honestly, if your looking for gaming art that doesn't cost a significant amount of money, then these poster collections are just a great option and if your a fan of Mass Effect Art then this purchase should be a no brainer.5 Stars!

I really can't say enough good things about this piece. Just when you think Kotobukiya couldn't get any better, they release a statue like this. It really is brilliant in every possible way. First and foremost, I absolutely love the color. Its like a cross between a metallic red and magenta and that glossy metallic paint that Kotobukiya uses really adds an extra oomph of visual flair. Then you have the pose, which is both dynamic yet subtle and it definitely has that feminine touch, which you absolutely want with a piece like this. As for the hair, its actually one of my favorite aspects with this piece. Kotobukiya can definitely go a bit overboard at times with the crazy hair, but the hair on this piece really finds the perfect balance. Its crazy, but not overtly so and the replacement hair looks just as amazing. Last but not least, you have one of the best faces I have seen yet in this line of statues. While I definitely prefer these statues with the masks on, this is one statue I would seriously consider displaying without the mask. I will probably wind up alternating, just to mix it up from time to time.The bottom line - Kotobukiya has really outdone themselves this time around. They have produced what is arguably the nicest statue yet in this series. I can't speak for others, but this is definitely my favorite statue up to this point. The colors are amazing, the paint job is spot on, it has a beautiful pose and the hair and face are absolutely perfect. Even if I could, I wouldn't change a single thing with this statue. Just an absolutely brilliant job all the way around. Kotobukiya is without question one of the premier statue companies on the market and the fact that they continually raise the bar higher and higher....well, its a real testament to the overall quality of the company. If I could give this statue 6 stars, I would. Again, just absolutely brilliant.

I openly admit, I use Itoya's Profolio Professional line almost exclusively for prints that are 13x19 and smaller. Unfortunately, Itoya doesn't make an 18x24 version in the Profolio Professional line. Itoya does offer an 18x24 in some of their other lines, but those options are below the level of quality I look for with portfolios and presentation cases. Hence I needed to go outside Itoya for my 18x24 prints. I tried quite a few different models, from a handful of different companies, and was never really fully content with the overall cost and quality....well, that is until I tried Prat's Start 4 Presentation Case. Make no mistake about it, the Start 4 is one of the highest quality portfolio's on the market.First and foremost, the cover is made with real high quality leather. The cover is soft, has a beautiful appearance, and the seam work is just top notch. I have never been a fan of hard polypropylene covers as they just look cheap and feel cheap in your hands. Nice leather covers on the other hand, like this cover, are just a real pleasure to hold and look through. Not only does the leather give a beautiful appearance, it's also extremely comfortable to hold and look through. The cover is also slightly padded, which just adds to the overall comfort of holding the portfolio and looking through the artwork contained within. Basically, you get a sense of the overall quality of this presentation case just from picking it up and touching it.The Interior is just as nice as the exterior. The internal ring mechanism is extremely high in quality and the pages are very similar to Itoya's Polyglass pages, which are some of the highest quality pages on the market. It comes with 10 pages to start with (20 prints) and additional pages can be purchased in packs of 5 or 10. According to Prat, this presentation case is rated to hold up to 30 sheets (60 prints), but personally, I never go above 50 prints per portfolio or 25 pages, especially for larger cases/portfolios like 18x24. They just get too heavy and unwieldy. My advice would be to see what the portfolio is like with 25 filled pages (50 prints) before adding another 5 pages (10 prints). I now own 3 of these cases and 25 pages is the perfect amount in my opinion. Of course, others might feel differently on the matter so again, I would recommend filling it with 50 prints and then decide whether to add an additional 10 prints. This case is also fitted with an internal elastic band, which is a feature lacking from a lot of presentation cases. It keeps the pages in place while stored. Unless its stored flat, larger pages can actually begin to sag and droop over the years. the elastic band prevents that from happening.Overall, the Start 4 is definitely one of the more expensive options on the market, but that is because its one of the highest quality options on the market. You get what you pay for and the Start 4 is definitely worth every last penny! I am both a professional photographer and an avid print collector and the single best advice I can give to people is not to skimp on the storage side. At just $50-$100 per print, your looking at an overall value of $2500 to $5000, with a full 50 print portfolio. With that in mind, ask yourself if spending $150-$200 is really too much when your storing that kind of value in it? The $150-$200 price point only adds around $3 to $4 to the cost of each print. Personally, I just couldn't imagine putting that kind of value into a cheap $50 portfolio. Again, the best advice I can give is to buy a quality portfolio/presentation case like the Start 4. Not only will it protect your prints better, but it also makes looking through your prints a more enjoyable experience.Bottom line - They say you can't judge a book by its cover, but this is one of the rare cases where that just isn't the case as this is one book that definitely can be judged by the cover. The Start 4 is a very high quality/high end presentation case. Everything about it just screams quality. Its become my go to presentation case for 18x24 prints. If your looking for a high end presentation case...this is definitely one of the best options on the market. Its definitely pricer than your average presentation case, but its worth every lasts penny and then some.5 stars!

I own a really large cloth covered tool bag from Stanley that I use to store all of my extra cords. It literally weighs like 30 pounds and is absolutely chock full of every cord imaginable. RCA cables, audio cables, coaxial cables, HDMI cables, adaptors, speaker wire, Apple microphones, various power cords, charging cables, external hard Drive cords, old school VCR cables, and the list goes on and on and on. Honestly I don't think there is a single audio/video cord in existence that isn't in that bag. there are actually cords in there that I have no clue what they go to.Anyways, I haven't used my various iPods in a long time, at least 10-12 months, so when I finally decided to pull them out and start using them agin, I was at a complete loss as I couldn't find my various iPod charging cords. I decided to look in that bag and while I was at it, get rid of an many cords as possible. For example, I must have had at least 15+ RCA cords which I received when buying various DVD players throughout the years. Unfortuantely, most of the cords in that case are literally brand new. So I decided to give all the old/used cords to the Salvation Army and kept most of the brand new cords for myself, even tho I will probably never use the vast majority of them. Anyways,  I finally stumbled onto the bulk of my iPod charging cords, but unfortunately they were in really bad shape. I don't know what chemical's Apple used in their old cords, but whatever they used, it had started to break down the rubber coating. they were just super sticky, as if someone had poured a light layer of syrup on them and then let them dry. I immediately got on Amazon and order replacement cords for all of my iPods.One of the cords I purchased was the [Apple MFi Certified] Stalion cable and I was definitely impressed. It really feels like a high quality cord and best of all, the exterior rubber coating is really soft, which makes rolling the cord up incredibly easy. I have been using it for a few weeks now and have absolutely zero complaints. If your looking for charging cord for your iPod, Stalion cords are definitely one of the nicer option. Not to mention the cords were pretty inexpensive. I just hope the same thing doesn't happen with these cords.Highly recommended!

Alan Moore's Batman: the Killing Joke is easily one of my favorite comic stories of all time. Its definitely a bit darker than most comic fare, but that is exactly why its become so hugely popular. I won't give any spoilers away, just in case there are comic readers out there that still haven't read it. that being said, if your a fan of Batman and the Joker.....well you should consider this an absolute must buy. I already own the comics in which this story played out, but when I discovered they had a hard cover edition on sale, it took me all of 60 seconds to order a copy. As much as I enjoy collecting regular comics, there is just nothing like a nice hard cover!Again, if your a Batman/Joker fan and haven't already read this story....well, it really should be the very next book you buy. this is really about as good as storytelling gets in comics. All in all, an absolute must buy for all Batman/Joker fans.

I am a bit late to the game when it comes to Kotobukiya's Bishoujo line, but this is definitely a case of better late than never as these statues are without a doubt some of the more unique super hero statues on the market. One of my favorite aspects to these statues is that most of them have very dynamic poses. I have never been a fan of statues that have the character just standing there in a basic pose. the more dynamic the better in my book and Koto certainly doesn't disappoint in this regard. One of my favorite comic artists of all time is the late Michael Turner and one of the main reasons is due to the kinetic energy most of his artwork contained. Characters literally feel like they are about to jump right off the page. A perfect example is Michael Turner's Ms. Marvel #1 variant cover. She really feels like she's about to jump right off the cover. Well, the same can be said of Kotobukia's Bishoujo line. They all appear to be right in the middle of some dynamic motion/action which really makes them some of the more exciting statues on the market. This effect is really multiplied by the crazy hair styles that Kotobukiya normally uses. Spider-Woman and Starfire are perfect examples of the crazy Koto hair. It really reinforces that kinetic energy and movement that these statues possess.Another aspect of these statues that I love is the paint that Koto uses. Not only are their paint jobs always top notch, they also use a lot of shiny and metallic paints which ultimately add just an extra oomph of visual flair. Spider-Woman is a perfect example as the shiny red paint on her costume just pops and looks absolutely amazing. If you were to replace that paint with some normal dull red paint, the end result just would't be the same. Another great example is the recent Batwoman statue. the shiny/metallic paint on that piece really makes all the difference in the world.If I have one complaint about Kotobukiya's Bishoujo line, it would be that their not limited editions. While they do offer certain variants of particular statues, usually at shows like the San Diego Comic Con, which are limited editions. the basic line itself is not limited. As a longtime collector of both Sideshow statues and limited edition prints/lithographs, there is just something about limited editions that I find extremely appealing. A lot of that has to do with knowing exactly how many pieces exist out in the world. If I had the choice between an open edition and a limited edition which cost a little bit more money, I would take the limited edition each and every time. I sincerely hope that Kotobukiya changes this aspect of the line and starts making them limited editions. Of course, the main benefit to open editions is the company can produce as many as they want, but that really doesn't change with limited editions as all the company has to do is make a small change to statue (usually dealing with color), and they can just as easily produce a 2nd edition of the same exact statue. They can really make as many editions as they want, so long as some aspect of the statue is changed, to distinguish it from the other editions. So producing limited editions by no means limits Koto to producing just a set amount, which makes thier choice to go with open editions a bit confusing, especially given how popular limited editions are today.Anyways, even with this line being mostly open edition, Kotobukiya's Bishoujo line is again, one of the more unique lines of super hero statues currently on the market and considering I mainly focus on female super heroes, both with comics and statues, its a line that is literally right up my alley. The Spider Woman statue is a bit smaller than their other statues, but that is only due to her crouching down pose, which is actually one of my favorite aspects to this statue. Its a perfect pose for this character.Bottom line - Between the beautiful paint job, the amazing colors, the dynamic pose, and her crazy flowing hair....well, they all add up to one amazing Spider Woman Statue. In my opinion, the Bishoujo line is not only one of the more unique statue lines on the market, but its also one of the more entertaining statue lines on the market. They really are just a joy to look at and Spider Woman certainly doesn't disappoint in this regard. All in all, Kotobukiya did an amazing job on Spider Woman and no Bishoujo collector should be without it.5 Stars!!

I will openly admit, Neil Degrasse Tyson is no Carl Sagan. The original Cosmos was one of the single greatest series every produced for television and a large part of that was due to Carl Sagan. He was just an exceptional speaker and his excitement for astronomy was infectious. That opening 15 minutes of the first episode was simply breathtaking. Here are 2 of my favorite statements made during that opening:The Cosmos is all that is or was or ever will be. Our contemplations of the Cosmos stir us -- there is a tingling in the spine, a catch in the voice, a faint sensation, as if a distant memory, of falling from a great height. We know we are approaching the greatest of mysteries."in a ship of the imagination, unfettered by ordinary limits of speed and size, drawn by the music of cosmic harmonies. It can take us anywhere in space and time. Perfect as a snowflake, organic as a dandelion seed, it will carry us to worlds of dreams and worlds of facts. Come with me. . . ."It wasn't the background or some amazing CGI that made that opening so powerful, it was Carl Sagan's passion and his ability to convey that passion though his incredible speaking ability. I am a HUGE fan of Neil Degrasse Tyson, but he just doesn't convey that same sense of passion that Sagan did. He has a much more monotone method of speaking so you really didn't get that same level of passion or excitement that the original series gave you.That being said, this updated version of Cosmos was still brilliant and Neil Degrasse Tyson did a great job with the series. We have learned so much more since the original Cosmos aired so there was a legitimate need for this updated version. This series was just hugely entertaining, incredibly interesting, and the updated graphics/CGI were absolutely mind bending. These kinds of programs get kids interested in astronomy and this updated version of Cosmos was just a massive success all the way around. The people behind this series, many of which were behind the original series, should be very proud of their accomplishment. Just an outstanding job all the way around.The bottom line - I immediately purchased this as soon as it was made available and have watched it multiple times since then. I am a space junkie and an amateur backyard astronomer and I can never get enough quality space documentaries. This really is a brilliant series all the way around and I can't possibly give it a higher recommendation. I know Sagan would have been 100% satisfied with this updated version and that is really the best compliment I can give this series. In all honesty, this series should be part of every public schools science curriculum. Yes, its that good!5 Stars.

I have been collecting art books for well over 10+ years and gaming is definitely one of my favorite genre's for art books, probably due to the fact that gaming has played such a large role in my life. Unfortunately, many of the art books released in this genre are really mediocre at best, especially the smaller art books that get included with many special edition games. I really wish the gaming market in general would become far more serious about the overall quality of these books. That being said, there have been a small handful of releases that have been exemplary in every way possible and The Art of Blizzard Entertainment sits at the top of that small handful. this art book is epic in every sense of the word.First and foremost, the book itself measures roughly 10x13, which is bit larger than most gaming art books. That of course is a very good thing! If there is any market where the saying "the bigger the better" holds true, its the art market (books, prints, etc.) and this book certainly doesn't disappoint in this regard. When you combine the overall size and the overall length, which is 376 pages....well, you ultimately wind up with one massive tome dedicated to Blizzard's artwork for Diablo, Starcraft, and Warcraft. It should really come as no surprise to Blizzard fans that they have some of the most talented artists in the entire gaming industry. Their in game cinematics have continually pushed the boundaries for in game cut scenes and are renowned the world over. I still watch the original World of Warcraft video from time to time and even 10+ years after initially seeing it....well, its still as breathtaking today as it was when it was first released.Again, the titles covered in this art book are Blizzards 3 main IP's, those being Diablo, Starcraft, and Warcraft. For those familiar with these games, you know there is just a massive amount of artwork with which to choose from with these series and thankfully, Blizzard did an absolutely brilliant job choosing which artwork to include in this book. For those that have purchased previous art books, you will recognize a lot of artwork from previous books, but don't let that deter you as there is also a lot of new content in here, enough to make this a worthwhile purchase even for people that purchased previous art books. One could really think of this as the definitive edition. If you really have a problem with this, I would recommend selling your older copies and buying this version.The book Itself is really quite beautiful. It has a nice quality cover and binding and the paper is actually nicer than I was expecting. Its just a quality art book all the way around. I really like the cover picture as well. They could have easily gone which a much more dynamic piece for the cover, but I actually really like this more basic approach. In my opinion, it really is a perfect cover piece. I usually put more stock in covers than I should, but thats just how I am. I just love beautiful covers and this one certainly doesn't disappoint. All in all, there are over 700 pieces of art in here including paintings, concept pieces and sketches. It also has invaluable insight and commentary by Nick Carpenter, Sam Didier, and Chris Metzenary all of whom have played an important role in making Blizzard the studio it is today.The bottom line - The Art of Blizzard Entertainment is without question one of the best video game related art books I have ever purchased. Its just massive in scope and is definitely the one Blizzard art book you don't want to miss. Its chock full of beautiful paintings, sketches and concept work and has extremely entertaining insight from the people that have made Blizzard what it is today. Again, if owning previous volumes bothers you, due to much of the same artwork being used, sell your previous books and buy this one. I myself own all of the previous art books and while those are still amazing in their own right, this book trumps them all. If your a Blizzard fan, an art book fan, or just an avid gamer that enjoys looking at amazing video game artwork, you really owe it to yourself to add this to your collection. This is really the pinnacle of video game art books. It simply doesn't get any better than this.5 Stars!

I received a box of these caramels as a gift when Sanders first introduced them like 5 years back. I am an AVID Sanders fan so my family normally sends me Sanders gifts during the holidays. I actually remember very clearly the first instance I tried these caramels. I opened up the box and was absolutely blown away at how amazing the salt was when paired with Caramel. I had never had sea salt caramels before, or any type of salted chocolate. The box was literally gone by that evening and these caramels have become a staple in my house ever since.I am very fortunate as I live in the metro Detroit area so Sanders products are very easy to find. The grocery store that we go to actually sells these caramels, both in boxes and individually wrapped singles. The CostCo. by me also carries them, but only the dark chocolate version. While I do enjoy the dark chocolate version, Its just not as good as the milk chocolate. In all honesty, these are the kinds of candies you really have to be careful with as they are so good that you can wind up eating too many, thus giving yourself one serious stomach ache!!Sanders was literally on the verge of going out of business back in the late 90's and early 00's, that is until Morley Candy swept in and purchased Sanders back in 2002. At that point, all of the Sanders fountain shops had closed and the only products you could really find anymore were the hot fudge products at various grocery stores. Morley has done just a remarkable job bringing Sanders back! There are now 6 fountain shops in the Metro Detroit Area, with more being planned, and the Sanders product line is significantly larger than it has ever been before. One of their best lines is called the Woodward Collection. The Sea Salt Caramels belong to this line of products. It also includes Dark or Milk Chocolate Cherry Cordials, Butter Almond Toffee, Milk Chocolate Cashews, Cherry Almond or Pecan Torties, Caramels with Drizzle, and of course Milk or Dark Chocolate Sea Salt Caramels. The Sea Salt Caramels are definitely my favorite, but this entire line of products is absolutely amazing!!Bottom line - Sanders is back in a big way and their line of products has been expanded dramatically in recent years. Sea Salt Caramels are one of their newer products and make no mistake about it, they are well deserving of the Sanders name. The caramel is rich and gooey (not a firm caramel) and the salt just adds a perfect kick to the overall taste. Sea salt chocolates and caramels have actually become very popular in the candy market these last few years and I have tried my fair share of them. That said, none of them come close to matching Sanders Sea Salt Caramels. Wether your a caramel lover, a chocolate lover, or just a candy lover in general, you really owe it to yourself to order a box or two. This is about as good as candy gets!!5 Stars!!

The art of Red Sonja is an art book from Dynamite that is really right in line with their other art books like the Art of Vampirella and the Art of Dejah Thoris. You get a basic intro at the beginning of the book, which goes on to explain how the character first started. Its short, but I actually enjoyed this aspect of the book as I wasn't familiar with how Red Sonja got started. From there, it jumps right into the artwork and overall, its a decent selection of Red Sonja work. Like Dejah Thoris and Vampirella, Red Sonja really seems to bring out the best in a lot of artists that depict her. Some of the artists in this book include Alex Ross, Jim Lee, Adam Hughes, Frank Cho, Art Adams, Mel Rubi, Frank Brunner, Pablo Marcos, and John Cassaday.While there is a lot of great work here, there are ultimately some selections that I just didn't agree with simply due to the fact that there are a lot of better choices that they could have chosen. Of course this is purely subjective so others might disagree completely. Don't get me wrong, there is still a lot of quality work here, but there are also some selections that just shouldn't have made the cut and that is ultimately why I gave it a 4 star rating instead of a 5 star rating.The quality of the book is right in line with Dynamites other art books. It has a quality binding, mid-level quality paper, which is really what you should expect from all of the art books in this price range, and a nice quality glossy cover. Dynamite does not disappoint in this regard. For the price, your getting a quality art book that will last a long time if properly taken care of.Bottom line - While its definitely not Dynamites best art book, its still a quality art book and a must buy if your a big fan of Red Sonja. There is some questionable work in here, but is quickly overshadowed by the quality pieces in this book, and there are definitely some amazing pieces of art in this book. Red Sonja is just one of those characters that seems to inspire the best out of the artists that depict her. By the time you get through this book, you will be thankful you bought it!4 stars!

To start this off, I will openly admit that I am not a fan of motion controlled gaming. Maybe its because I have been gaming for 30+ years with some sort of controller in my hand. Whatever the reason, I just vastly prefer a controller in my hand as opposed to motion controls. That being said, I absolutely LOVE what Kinect bring to the Xbox One console outside of motion controlled gaming.My single favorite feature that Kinect brings to the console is without question Skype. I have a cousin who lives down in Florida and we play online games together at least 3-4 times a week. We actually grew up together in Michigan and we were both video game nuts back in the day. I still remember the all nighters we used to pull playing games like Karateka and the Sierra and LucasArts adventure games. Unfortunately, he moved down to Florida with his parents when I was roughly 13. As soon as Xbox Live went live back with the original Xbox, we started playing games together online.
