I'm probably a pretty good audience for this book: I'm a professional photographer, I live in New England and I love Vermont. but I'm also always looking for new places to shoot in Vermont. I'm also write the "Traveling Photographer" column for Popular Photography and so I'm always looking for interesting places to share with readers.While this book does provide some good ideas, it is somewhat lacking in its concept and execution. For one, it's a pretty thin book--it could easily be doubled, there are tons of places that I've been and shot that aren't mentioned.Also there are almost no useful maps--and non are really specific to the places. There are chapter-opening maps that are very general, but that's about it. In fact, I get the feeling that this text was written a long time ago and then just rebirthed. Any book like this today would have GPS coordinates listed so that people could find exact locations quickly and reliably (granted, not all of a rural state like Vermont is adequately mapped yet, most of it is). I did find some useful thoughts on places, to be sure, but there just aren't enough to justify the price.The photos in the book are adequate at best, but I won't blame that on the photographer. A lot of times a photographer's best work doesn't show up in a book for one reason or another--largely because editors are picking the photos, not the photographer. I am willing to accept that this photographer is better than the book shows. But there are not many photos in this book that would lure me to a place. Open a Sierra Club calendar sometime and you *need* to go to those places is you're a photographer, they are that enticing. The photos in this book just don't have that strength--and they should.The technical information at the front of the book seems a bit out of date to me. He talks about filters a lot, for one, and with everyone using some type of editing program these days, filters are mostly added after the fact. He does say one thing that I love reading and that is that every photo in the book was shot with a tripod--Bravo! The first thing I tell my students is that if you want to see a ten-fold increase in image quality immediately, get and use a good tripod--for ever single shot. I really love that he gives that advice. Digital is barely mentioned in the book (another reason that I suspect this is very old text).So, while the book has some basic places and ideas that are useful and the writing is very pleasant, I think the book could have gone into a lot more depth and covered places like the Northeast Kingdom more. If you're new to shooting in Vermont, buy the book, it's certainly helpful. But if you already know the place a bit, you won't get as much from it.

This is an extremely well made and conveniently-designed case for smaller tablets and it's got me wishing that Verso made a case like this for laptops. Even though the description didn't mention it, I was kind of hoping it would be big enough to accommodate my Fire HDX 8.9 and it's just a tad too small. Oh, well. It does fit my BLU 8.0 tablet/phone perfectly and so that's what I'm using it for--and I'm glad that tablet finally has a safe home.That said, while it is a moderately well-padded case, unfortunately, I don't think that this case by itself offers real protection from breaking tablet glass. It is a nice soft and padded case, but there is no stiff liner in the outer sides that would protect the case against a heavy book in a backpack, for example. If the tablet is already in a protective case, then it would be just fine. My Fire HDX, for instance, is housed in a really rugged protective case and if that would have fit in this case, I'm sure the two would have offered complete protection. So, if you are buying this to shove in a kid's backpack (or perhaps your own suitcase), I would really think about first putting their tablet in a hardshell case--and then seeing if both will fit into this Verso carry case.As far as the construction of this goes, as a soft outer case it's near perfect. You just couldn't ask for a more thoughtfully-designed carry case. There is a small pocket inside (good for a cleaning cloth, perhaps) and a really nice outer pocket in which I have my BLU manual and an extra cleaning cloth. (I don't want to put the a/c charger in there because, again, I wouldn't want that pressing against a tablet. Yes, there is padding, but I'm not sure it would be a good idea to pack a hard charger in with the tablet.So, while I really like this case a great deal, I would not count on it to protect a tablet by itself, but it in conjunction with a hard-shell tablet case, if they both fit, perfect. The inside has a really nice soft-brushed lining that is both attractive and gentle. In most respects, so nicely made, hard not to give it five stars.

It's very hard not to like this laptop a great deal considering some of the features that it has and the (to me) astoundingly low price. Compared to a Chromebook, for example, you get a whole lot more computer for a modest jump in price (for the same screen size). The computer has a very solid and professional feel to me and I disagree with a few other reviews that say it has a cheaper feel--I don't find that to be true at all (and I own another ASUS, a K501LX 15.6 Inch, that originally retailed for around three times as much).Perhaps the most important thing for me in a laptop is that it has enough flexibility to integrate well with other toys--and this laptop has a lot of integration flexibility--more so than that K501LX, in fact). For one, it has three different USB ports (one of which I use almost 100% of the time for an Amazon Basics mouse--I am not a trackpad fan, particularly if I'm sitting at a table and have a good mouse surface) and it has HDMI. The HDMI port is an excellent addition because it enables me to plug the laptop into my Epson projector and give slide shows (I teach photography workshops) or even watch a movie--which I did first thing. It also has an SD slot, so you can download photos or sound files quickly.The screen, important to me because I view a lot of photographs (both online galleries of other photographers and my own images) is actually quite good--a much better graphics quality that I was expecting to be honest. Yes, the screen has its limitations, no question, this is not a high-end screen. The screen has a slight warmish cast (you can correct that with a calibrator, I assume) and it has a matte surface, so it doesn't have that great snap that a high-end glossy screen has and it is certainly no match for my Apple retina display (nor should it be at this price). Yes, there is a drop-off if you turn the screen a bit, but I tend to sit right in front of the computer, lol, so it's never an issue.The computer is surprisingly fast, but so far I'm using it mainly to surf and use built-in software features. It's *great* that it came preloaded with Windows 10, by the way. I've yet to install Office and that's got to happen soon so I can use Word (would be great if it shipped with Word, but that's asking a lot) but I don't think Word will run slowly. You can add one 8gig chip to bring it up to 12gigs total, which is probably a good idea if you are gaming. The very first thing I did with this computer was to watch a movie and again, if you were to compare it to a higher-end screen you'd see a difference, but otherwise it's very acceptable--your eyes do get used to whatever screen you're watching provided it's not totally inferior and this is far from that. The speakers are touted by ASUS as being great, but I'd rate them more as adequate and I ended up toying with a small blu tooth speaker (just to test the blu tooth range) and ended up listening to most of the film through that. But again, having blu tooth capability (and you can run a wireless printer, which is nice) is nice, too.The laptop has a solid and substantial feel. The keyboard is actually comfortable, but it's not backlit so you'll need a light in dim situations. But I will say the wrist area is super comfortable and the whole keyboard has a nice feel to it.Overall, I really just wanted this laptop to keep in the den so that I can surf or do some research while I'm watching the tube, or watch a film sitting on the back porch, but I was surprised that it's a more substantial machine than that. I think this would make an excellent laptop for a high school student or anyone that didn't want to invest big bucks into a higher end computer. Based on price, I can't see an obvious reason to give this less than five stars, but of course that must take the affordable nature into consideration. But on the other hand, I can hook this computer up to my Epson projector (or my Vizio TV, for that matter) and my other ASUS lacks HDMI port, so this one actually wins that battle.Hard to believe you can buy laptops today for this price--and just how light and nice this feels compared to laptops only a generation or two ago.

I think that Season 5 of Curb is where the show did two things: it hit its comedic stride and it started to fall apart. Larry David, king of the self-indulgent comics can be the funniest thing on wheels when he's at the top of his game, but he can also drag you down into a pit of inside jokes that are so inside only he understands them. Don't get me wrong, I love this show, I have watched every episode several times, but at times he gets so hung up on minor plot things (and blows them up into giant plot things without substance) that I find myself reaching for the fast-forward button. Too many hospital scenes, for one, and just a bit too much dark humor at times. Still a great series, David is a genius of the highest order and this series kind of lets you look inside his mind and life to a pretty intense degree. Some of it is the funniest stuff you'll ever see, some is not.

I originally saw this movie in the theater when it first came out and I recall it as being more interesting than it was on my recent viewing. John Cusack is great, as usual, but the storyline is ploddingly slow at first and really never gets into high gear. I compare the grifting aspect to that shown in several David Mamet films (like the Spanish Prisoner, a brilliant movie) and it is just not as interesting or as insightful--Mamet takes you into the con and he lets you see how the cons unravel. Stephen Frears, the director of Grifters, does not; instead he tends to use the cons as a backdrop to a kind of weird mother/son drama. While I found the movie tolerable to watch a second time and Cusack is a joy to watch, I just didn't think the script held up. I'll watch it again though, primarily for some good acting.

I've tried lots of other brands of duct tape and this is the best of them all. Last year I used a roll of this to staple through after I wrapped my screened porch in plastic (I just tacked the plastic in place first, then went over the stapling areas with the tape--worked beautifully. By stapling through the tape it's far less likely that the plastic will rip out in a storm--and I learned the hard way (going out in sub-freezing weather to redo the plastic before a blizzard). (Using 5/16" T50 staples into pine wood strips, in case anyone is curious, lol.)I find a million uses for this tape and often buy bright colors to put on garden tools so I don't lose them in the grass. How nuts is it that most garden clippers have green or black handles? I also put bright pink tape on my eyeglass cases in case I put them down. It took me decades to learn this simple stuff, lol.Buy Duck tape, it's good for you and its far better to have it when you need it than to need it when you don't have it.

I love getting batteries in bulk, especially as winter approaches New England and all the little flashlights and radios need fresh power. These are packaged as six four-packs and they're very convenient. Hard to really say how their strength compares to non-Duracell or store-packaged batteries, but they work great. I use this size for my digital Olympus voice recorder and a few gadgets around the house. A bargain at the price considering I recently bought 4 AAA batteries at the grocery store (Duracell) and paid $5. Buy quantities and stock up, you'll be happy that you did.

I really like these towels a great deal and as expensive as they are, I seriously think I would choose them over paper towels in the future. I have always hated paper towels because I feel that we're all wasting trees just to wipe off countertops--and even the best brands just fall apart in a few minutes. Many paper towel brands are now using recycled materials, but we're still tossing out millions of paper towels a day. You start to cook a big meal and you can go through a dozen in no time. Cloth towels are nice, but they get filthy (and smelly) fast and it's just more laundry to do. It may seem like a minor issue to people that don't cook a lot, but I spend a lot of time in the kitchen.So, when these towels arrived, I took one out to test it and decided to see how long I could abuse it before it just fell apart. I first dampened it, wrung it out then wiped down the kitchen counters and it did a good job and not a sign of a tear. So I wiped down the stove (I'm not the neatest cook in the world either, lol), still fine. I then rinsed it quickly and walked around the house and wiped down my office tables, the tops of my computers, several hard drives, cleaned my office phone and then the keyboard. Still, no tears. So, for fun I yanked it hard (it was still pretty wet) expecting that I'd sacrificed it for sure. No tears, nothing. That one towel has been hanging around my home office ever since and it's still using it. Not sure how they'll work cleaning furniture with spray wax yet, but that's next.These towels are obviously designed for and marketed to the food-service industry but I think that Georgia-Pacific would have a lot of success marketing this for home use (particularly if they lower the price a bit or package smaller quantities for home use). You can use one paper towel all afternoon in a kitchen instead of going through half a roll of paper towels. Yes, expensive, no doubt, but there are 150 of these in a box. If you use one a day and toss it out (and you probably won't--I've hung them up to dry and they are fine on the second use) then one box will last you five months. Even if you use two, you're still going to go nearly three months before restocking (compare that to adding paper towels to your shopping list every week).  I'll gladly pay more if I can buy one box that will last me nearly half a year instead of buying those big clunky dozen-roll packages of paper towels that I can never find a place to store. I'm sold.

I love this series, I just absolutely worship some of the episodes. Larry David is a comic genius and he really created something unique with this series. Some of the episodes are a little weird (too many hospital scenes, Larry!) and some of the jokes go on too long, but overall this is a fantastic example of what a great comedian can do when he is left to his own devices.This final season got a bit weird--he got divorced, for one--but there are moments of hilarity that only he could write and produce. He's also become a really fine actor. I miss this series, but it's nice to have all eight seasons for FREE on Amazon Prime!!!

I've been a professional photographer for more than 40 years and B+W  filters are by far the best filters that I've ever used. I've used virtually every brand (Hoya, Tiffen, Nikon, etc.) and B+W tend to be superior in both optical clarity and in their construction. These filters are made in Germany from Schott glass and they are the only filters that I truly trust not to degrade lens sharpness or to introduce flare from internal reflections. And what is the point of spending premium dollars on a lens only to stick an inferior piece of glass in front of it? B+W filters are carefully coated on all sides (the filter actually consists of two pieces of glass in a rotating mount) and things like glare and off-color transmission are not a factor.If you're considering a polarizing filter you probably already know what they are used for: to reduce surface reflections in any non-metallic surface (they won't reduce reflections coming off most painted metals, like a car fender, etc.). They work beautifully at eliminating reflections from things like glass (so you can shoot a store window display from the outside, for example, which I do a lot when traveling), water (kind of cool to be able to photograph a trout in a stream or goldfish in a garden pond and remove the surface glare), wet autumn foliage, etc. The filters work best when you are at 90-degrees from the sun and not at all when the sun is behind your or directly in front of you and because they are in a circular mount you can adjust the intensity of the effect. The physics behind how they work is a bit intense but essentially they block certain superfluous rays of reflected light that desaturate colors (blue sky) and cause surface glare.One thing that is mentioned less is that polarizing filters are far superior to "haze/UV" filters when it comes to reducing atmospheric haze in landscape photos. It's kind of a miracle to stand there and turn the filter and watch haze simply vanish. They work particularly well at darkening blue skies in landscapes (though you have to be careful that you don't over-saturate them to the point of getting nearly black skies). Color saturation (fall foliage is a good example) can be super enhanced using a polarizing filter. Because you can increase saturation in editing so easily these days, there are fewer times when I'll use a polarizing filter for that, but they are still important for removing or controlling reflections. And you can use them to enhance saturation in the camera, particularly if you don't do your own printing or editing.The claim that B+W makes that these particular polarizing filters increase light transmission seems to me to be true, but it's a kind of tricky thing to quantify. Typically the light loss from a polarizing filter is about 1 2/3 stops and I think you are probably gaining that 2/3 stop (maximum) back. There's really no way to measure unless you're comparing two filters in the exact same situation at the same moment. The amount of light loss really doesn't matter in terms of exposure (particularly if you're using a tripod because you can just keep the same aperture and slow the shutter down, so you're not messing with depth of field changes), but it does help keep the viewfinder brighter which is nice. The coating on these filters appears also to be 100-percent neutral--I'm detecting no color shift whatsoever (and you do see a color cast with some filters, no question).I really think if you're going to keep a lens for a while (or have multiple lenses of the same diameter) and you need a polarizing filter, you're better off spending the extra money on B+W filter and taking good care of it. A filter will last forever if you take care of it, so it's worth the price.

I think this is one of the finest and most original motion pictures ever made.  The movie is based on (somewhat loosely) the book Shoeless Joe, though much of the movie's plot was created by Hollywood writers.I'm not sure why this movie touches me so deeply, but it does. While purely a fantasy, there are elements of reality that are beautifully portrayed: the father and son relationship, for one. Kevin Costner is fantastic, as is James Earl Jones. And Burt Lancaster--what can you say? Possibly the greatest actor that ever lived and his role in this, while short, is brilliant. Fabulous.Lots of special features on the blu ray, too, despite what I read in other reviews. There is a Bravo special ("From Page to Screen"), deleted scenes, a roundtable with Costner, Bret Saberhagen, George Brett and Johnny Bench, etc.And if you have a blu ray player, don't settle for a dvd, buy the blu ray, the quality bump is significant.

I really love the concept of having a counter-top hydroponic garden and this is my first. So far I love everything about this: it's very simple to set up, seems to be made relatively well and you can have it up, running and planted in 10 minutes or less. I think it was a great idea to make it so simple and while I'm still waiting for germination (I'll update in a few days, according to the set-up guide germination can happen in as fast as a few days for some plants). I'm going to keep a log next to the unit to track when the pods were started, when they germinated, room temps, etc.I'm a pretty active outdoor gardener, but one of the things I miss (I'm in Connecticut) is that when early October comes, most of my garden is past--the last tomatoes are on the vine, the cucumbers are done, all I have left are some squash and a few herbs. What I'm really looking forward to growing in this are the herbs that came with it. Nothing, but nothing, beats having fresh basil in your kitchen to cook with and up until now I've had to grow winter basil under a Rube Goldberg mess of lights and pots and trays. I really love this idea and if it works, I'll probably try a larger one.Here are some good points:* There is a light timer that keep the light on for 16 hours a day and it comes on at the same time every day (you can modify the start/stop time, but the duration is always 16 hours).* There is a water-fill line in the small tank so you know where/when to add water.* The liquid nutrients are poured in through a front well so it's convenient, even if there are plants growing..* There is a timer/light at the top that reminds you, every 14 days, to add nutrients.* It's very simple to assemble: basically you just insert the grow bulb into the housing, set the tray in place, add water, raise the light to the correct height for the plants you're growing and plant your pods. There are nutrient instructions in the kit.According to the very simple quick setup guide the unit should be placed away from additional light sources or areas of hot (coffee pot) or cold (drafty window) and the optimal temps are, like outdoor plants, dependent on the type of plant: lettuce, for example, likes cooler temps and peppers and tomatoes like warmer temps. I keep my house pretty cool in winter (not by choice, lol), so I will probably tend toward more cool-temp loving plants.Cons? I think the pods are pretty expensive and I hope they come down in price as more and more people do this. You can,apparently buy empty cones and sponges and start your own seeds, but I'm not sure yet how much they cost. I'm really hoping the bulb does not contain mercury (in case of breakage) but I have *not* seen it mentioned. I believe I read that the bulb lasts for six months, but I have not priced replacement bulbs yet. I'm doing this as much for the experience as the produce, however, so I will endure some of the costs and just consider them the cost of a new hobby.Overall, very satisfied and *very* psyched to be able to grow hydroponically in winter. I am a photographer and will document growth, etc. and post photos with updates.Update: Since my original review (five stars), I have decided to downgrade this by one star because it is *not* an LED light, it's a CFL and it is described as an LED. CFLs contain mercury and are potentially dangerous if broken. CFLs are also more costly to run 16 hours a day than LEDs, I think. Given a choice, I would always choose an LED option. I am still extremely happy with the product, the bulb is my only complaint. It's housed pretty safely, however, so probably not a danger, but just keep that in mind.

Buying batteries in bulk is the way to go. When you compare prices (even against other Duracell packs) of four or eight batteries against 24, these 24-packs (and larger) are a bargain. Also, if I go to the store, I always cheap out and just buy four or eight--and then regret that cheapness later. Since I started buying larger packs, I never seem to run out. These are packed as six four-packs of AA batteries.I am a photographer and go through a lot of AA batteries in accessory flash units (Nikon SB 900 currently) and while there is no question that Lithium batteries are longer lasting than these, they are also super expensive. I hate just tossing batteries away when they are used up, but that seems to be the current reality.In any even, I think these are very reliable batteries, affordable and while not the best batteries made, are very good and long lasting.

These are very soft and gentle blankets and, as far as I know, they are the first fabric made from bamboo that I have ever handled. They are so soft, in fact, that they feel as though they've already been washed and dried a few times, they have that sort of nice "just out of the dryer" feel. They are on the thin side, no question, but I think that babies are far better off (and more comfortable) in a blanket that maintains their own body heat, or even releases some heat, rather than heats them up to much, particularly when sleeping.The patterns are nice but very faint (and I'm not crazy about the gray stripes), also. I suspect the patterns will fade a bit more as they are washed repeatedly, but no matter, they look pretty.The one thing I'm a bit confused about (just in a curious sense) is the actual fabric content and why they are called "muslin" when in fact they are a blend of 70-percent  "viscose bamboo" and 30-percent "cotton." Muslin is traditionally a 100-percent cotton weave and cotton comes from cotton plants. To confuse matters more the Amazon description (not the box) says "70-percent Rayon." Rayon is actually a regenerated cellulose-source fabric, typically made from plant or wood fibers and is actually considered a partially-synthethic fabric (because it's manufactured, but it is still from natural materials)--in this case, bamboo. Plenty of room on the packaging, I'm surprised that since the fabric is so nice and cushy, they didn't describe its unique bamboo source more. (I've do photography for the textile industry which is the only reason I've read about this.) I think it might actually be an interesting selling point.At any rate, you won't be disappointed in the softness of these blankets, and they will feel very natural and very comfortable to your baby, I'm sure. Rayon weaves tend to last a very long time through many wash cycles also. And the size of the blankets (40 x 40-inches) is very generous.

I'm genuinely impressed with two things about the HTST9: both the audio quality and the surprising ease of set up. When it arrived I stared at the box for two days fearful I was going to be involved in yet another complex set-up process but it wasn't. Basically all that you have to do is to connect the bar (via HDMI) to your TV and then reroute your other HDMI devices (in my case a Sony blu ray player and a cable box) to the bar and then plug in the power cords for the bar and the subwoofer and you're done with the wiring aspect. The rest is just the typical menu/language set up and getting to know the remote (more about the remote below).This is really my third generation of sound devices for TV/movies and it is clearly the hands-down winner.  My first system was a Panasonic surrounded-sound (seven speaker) system that is now pretty much antique but was surprisingly great in sound quality. The trouble was that it was a part of an integrated dvd player/system and the dvd player was horrible. But there is definitely an advantage (even over this great sound bar) to having speakers physically placed around the room--no question, that type of system rocks. My next system (and I use it in my bedroom and it's great) is a Bose Solo 15 Series II. For a small and pretty affordable ($429) and unobtrusive system, that Bose machine produces superb sound.This Sony sound bar, however, while it lacks that "behind your head" quality that a surround-sound system has, is still incredible--and I mean incredible. I have it in a 14x20' den and while it won't blow the roof off, it comes close. It's such a different experience to watch a blu ray disc on this that you feel like you've entered another era in sound quality. You simply can't imagine the difference from those cheesy (in my case Vizio--but the TV picture is great) built-in TV speakers. I'm of an age where I've been "losing" the dialogue on most TV shows and many movies for several years. This bar has restored a lot of sound I didn't even realize was there. (I noticed watching "The Middle" that I can actually hear Brick's whispers, lol). In fact, I'm glad I live in a house and not an apt or I have a feeling I'd be getting calls. There is nothing I love more than watching movies in the middle of the night on weekends and this sound system just rocks. It actually scared me a bit with the first movie I watched ("The Boat that Rocked," great film) because the music was so powerful. But the dialogue was clear, defined and Sony has done a great engineering job separating vocals, background sounds and music. That separation is something I think most people will notice immediately. On a normal TV those sounds are all bottle together and it's hideous to be watching a great quality image with horrid sound.I found a few things annoying--like having to have yet another remote sitting not the table in front of me (the remote doesn't control my Sony blu ray player, I was hoping it would). And I still have to play remote roulette when it comes to shutting everything down--otherwise you look up later and realize some of the gear is still turned on. Just annoying though, it has nothing to do with the quality of the bar.The set up, as I said, is fast. In fact, I was surprised at how short the quick set-up guide was but interestingly they do not repeat that set-up stuff in the full manual that is included--so save the quick set-up sheet if you think you'll need it (I'm sure it's on the Sony site).One thing that made me laugh about the remote is that there is a "football" button there for a special football broadcast mode that is supposed to provide a few levels of stadium sound. I haven't watched a game with it yet but this Sunday, it's coming, lol. Also, there is a USB  port at the end of the bar for listening to music (or watching photos, though I haven't yet tried) from a flash/thumb drive. I have not tried the bluetooth system yet and don't really plan to since I have another system for music.By the way, the bar's grille cover is not attached when it is shipped, so be careful in unpacking to handle the bar itself carefully. Also, the subwoofer is pretty heavy--have a place nearby to set it down and get a hand under it as soon as you can.Overall I would say this is a pretty expensive system and will probably come down a bit during the holidays. The set up is quick and painless. The sound is stellar and while it does lack the geographic spread that a surround-sound system offers, I can't say I miss it much. In fact, I've been thinking I might actually prefer this bar regardless but I don't have the other system any longer for comparison. The sound separation of the ST9 is pretty amazing. And I surely don't miss a couple hundred feet of wire going under every piece of furniture and up the walls.

The Epson VS340 XGA is a very bright and a very versatile projector for many different kinds of uses and I think is particularly well suited for sales meetings, classroom lectures and any type of small gathering where having a flexible a/v projector is important. Its not designed to be an entertainment projector (and its not marketed for that), but you can easily show virtually anything that you can load into your laptop (Youtube videos, slide shows, etc.) or save to a USB/flash drive type device. You can also connect a digital camera or camcorder directly.I teach photography to small adult groups and its really a very nice (and silent!) projector in that situation. Ive been using a much older and much less bright (and certainly less colorful) projector for a few years and this is a quantum leap forward in a lot of ways.  For one it remains cool and for another its almost silent.The set up of the projector (and I hate learning yet one more device, it seems I spend half my life doing that) is painless and fast. It comes with a printed quick set-up guide and the full manual is on an included cd. Even before you buy the unit though, you can find both the quick set-up guide and the manual as pdf (or HTML) files on the Epson site (just Google the model # and word manual and it will pop up) and I strongly suggest you read through them before you buy so that you can compare certain features (with other Epson models and with other brands). I really prefer reading the manual online like this because Im looking at it on a 30 monitor instead of a small paper page and you can always print out full pages of just the topics you need (I printed out several pages on Mac laptop vs. Windows configurations). The online manuals have live links (yay!) so you can jump from one page to another via their suggestions. And the pdf files print easily. The cool thing about having live links in the manual and having it as a pdf on your desktop is that if you have a question while youre setting up, you can just do a quick search and usually find the answer.Still, I wish it had come with a printed manual to read first just because I like reading manuals in front of the TV and dont want to print out 150+ page manual.Setting up the projector is really just a matter of attaching the power cord and then attaching the media (laptop, USB/flash drive, etc.) and then turning on the machine. The quick set-up guide is very simple, easy to follow and while you should read the manual, you dont have to read it for the initial tests. One other nice feature in the full guide is that there are size/distance configurations to tell you how far you have to be from a screen or wall to get a certain size of projected image AND for various aspect ratios (this might sound like Greek, but its very useful when you want to guesstimate how big a screen you need in a given size room). For example, to get a 50-inch diagonal projection (4:3 ratiopretty common for slides), you have to be 58-79-inches from the wall/screen. Not bad. That means you could watch a slideshow in your living room at 50 inches if youre only six feet from the wall. (Im going to try that soonwith a movie.) Theres a cover slide, too, so you can leave the image on and just close the lens. There are ratios for 16:9 too in case you want to watch a movie.The manual is extremely well written and illustrated and if you've ever hated an obtuse user manual, you'll be praising whoever wrote and designed the graphics for this one--particularly if you're reading it on a big screen or a laptop. I write a lot of tech stuff for a living and writing good clear instructions is a lot tougher than it looks.The projector is very bright and the color is nicely saturated. I tried it both with room lights on and in a darkened room. Obviously the dark room really pops better, but even with two lamps on 10 or so from the screen, it did well.The projector is extremely versatile when it comes to connections/configurations and you can use a laptop, a VGA video source, a camera, or something very simple like a USB/flash driveI used a thumb drive for my first tests. If you have the space to keep this set up, for instance, you can come home from a day of shooting photos with a digital camera or video camera and then just plug it into the projector to review your days take. Cool.There is software built into the projector so that if you have folders of images, for example, you can choose folders and sub-folders and then navigate to specific images and folders. Youre far better off if you create a slideshow in your computer, of course, and then just operate the show from your laptop or whatever. Interestingly, while there is no LAN capability built in, you can buy a LAN adapter for this so that you can operate from a wireless network. If I can afford the adapter, thats something I will absolutely do in the future (even if only to testbut I havent been able to find a price yet.) By the way, according to the manual there was supposed to be a VGA cable in the box, but I did not get one. Not sure why I need it yet, but I want it nonetheless, lol.Also, if you use several projectors and/or configurations, you can SAVE the configurations from the projector to a USB device or directly to a computer via cable (and presumably via the LAN once you set it up). If you run an a/v dept at a school, this is a life saver.One cool (bad pun) thing is that because of the LED lamps, you dont have to let the projector cool before you shut it off. I had it going for like 30 mins the first time and it was virtually cool. Compare that to fan-cool filament bulb projectors where you must leave the fan running until the bulb is cooled or you risk burning it out. (These bulbs are rated to live 10,000 hours, by the waywhich seems like infinity to me, but we'll see if they last that long, lol.)Finally, the projector has a zoom lens and it has is easy to control via a ring slider and also you can adjust for keystoning quite easily. Also, you can operate virtually all controls (even navigate images in a folder) using the remote. If you are a teacher or salesperson, the remote is great.Cons? I wish that it had a carry handle (like the old Kodak and Elmo projectors) built into the front to that it was easier to carry (its not heavy but who wants to drop it?) and I really wish it came with a carry case or had one as an accessory. Im going to have to buy a case and finding one that fits wont be that easy. And Id love a rechargeable version, but not sure thats even possible.Overall, I think this is a really good presentation projector. I wish I had the next brighter model to compare, but for what Im doing this is generations more sophisticated than my old hot bulb projector and a lot quieter and entirely cool. As a movie projector? I haven tried it yet, but will shortly and will update this then. Sorry for the long review, but if youre buying projector youre going to live with it a long time, you may as well know what youre buying. I have not used a lot of projectors (maybe five) but of those that I have used, this is the best so far. Can't wait to try one of those killer home entertainment models one day!

This is one of the most fun summer movies of all time. I'm rewatching it now for probably the 20th time and it just never gets old. Richard Dreyfuss and Bill Murray are so perfect together that it's a wonder that it's their only picture together (or at least I think it is). You know the plot: Bill Murray plays an out-of-control multi-phobic nutso that latches on to his new shrink: Dreyfus. What Dreyfuss' character doesn't realize (at first, though he soon discovers it) is that "Bob" is the patient from hell. Much of the movie was filmed at Lake Winnipesaukee in New Hampshire and the setting is just spectacular.I find it hard to believe that there is anyone that hasn't yet seen this class comedy, but if you haven't, try it. I think it might even be on Amazon Prime for free.

Update 10/29/15: As we're heading into hard freezes here in New England, the grass is now very well established and I would say germination was overall very good--slightly better in the sunny areas, but not thin anywhere. I probably applied some of the seed a little more sparingly than I should have, but it will oversees in spring. Looks good. Here's the original review:I have to laugh at some of the reviews I read of this (and other) grass seeds because apparently a lot of people believe that if you just buy grass seed and toss it into your yard, you'll get a great lawn. But growing grass (like growing almost any plant) is a lot like painting: the better the preparation and attention to detail, the better your results will be. I have been using this Scotts mix with great results, though I have to admit, I've had good results with several brands of seeds. (Also ironically, I'm not a big lawn fan, but I live in a suburban neighborhood in Connecticut, so I'm stuck with having some lawn.)I have used this Scotts seed mix (a blend of three different types of grasses for both sun and shade: Abbey Kentucky Bluegrass, Divine Perennial Ryegrass, and Red Fescue) in both spring and now fall and it produces quite well. (I actually think fall is better if the temps are warm because the established root systems will begin to grow earlier in spring.) It does produce better in some areas than others, but how could this not be so if it's a mix of different seed varieties? The purpose of buying a mix is that very few yards have a uniform amount of sunlight (or identical soil type) from one end to the other. Most yards have trees, shrubs, houses, outbuildings, etc., that modify and vary the amount of light in different areas of the yard. By planting a mix, you can feel relatively assured that some of the seed will be ideal for at least one particular area. No, the sun-loving seed probably won't do well in deep shade, but that's exactly why there is a shade seed in the mix.Preparing the soil (even for over planting) is so important.  If the soil can't make contact with the soil, there is no way it can germinate to produce a good root system. Prepping is simple: just mow then rake the area you're going to over seed and then spread. With new areas (or recently reclaimed gardens, etc.), it's a good idea to loosen the soil but not too deeply. If you loosen the ground to too great a depth, much of the seed will fall below the depth at which it can germinate: all seeds need a mix of soil, sunlight and water to germinate. Roughing up the top inch is probably the best depth. I recently decided to eliminate several raised vegetable beds (I give up, farmer's markets are cheaper and easier) and so used some of this seed to replant lawn where the beds (they were 4x12' each) had been. I raked the soil (about 8" higher than the lawn) out and feathered it into a spreading pattern and then stomped it down a bit, then raked it gently and seeded it with a hand spreader. I would say I got a very high germination rate--though it's September now, so we'll see how it handles the winter. Right now I am very pleased with the thickness of the growth.Also, water the seed immediately and then water it ever single day (unless it rains). Grass seed (even coated seeds like this) desperately need water. You can't skip a day and on hot days (particularly in six-hour+ sun areas, you have to water a few times a day. I just leave a sprinkler in one area, then turn it one a few times a day (on hot days). Often people will see grass sprouting and stop watering it and that causes a high percentage of seed to just dry off--particularly if the temps are in the high 70s or in the 80s for days at a time. If I see a thin patch after 10 days or so (the grass will probably start to germinate in 5-7 days), I'll talk around with a hand spreader and give a little more seed. But putting too much seed is not a good idea because grass will "crowd out" and die.Finally, if you need more topsoil, buy a few yards and just spread that over your existing lawn and then rake it in a bit. I did that last year with this seed and it worked superbly in an area that is in heavy shade and I couldn't get to grow for years.I honestly can't say if this Scotts seed works better than other brands because you only use one brand at a time and I've been using Scotts for about 10 years now. I over planted with this particular mix about 10 days ago and I would say I see a substantial amount of growth. And last spring's crop is holding on strong.Preparation and watering are everything.

I have to say that I loved every word of this book and I can't wait to read it again. Yes, the first 100 pages or so (which is a lot, granted) are kind of slow slogging setting up the financing for their epic road trip, but as someone who always dreamed of creating such a wild project, I still found it fascinating. Most author would skip over this preemptory material and get right down to the trip, but then you'd be sitting there halfway though the book wondering, "Where the heck did the guys get the money and the truck to make such a wild journey?"Once Cahill and his partner get underway, it's a riot to read just how unprepared (after a year or  more of preparing!) they were for some aspects of their trip. And when you read the *scary* accounts of crossing the Andes, all of your fantasies of "Gee, I'd love to go on an adventure like this" simply vanish--they vanish over a 7,000-foot cliff to certain death (in a snow storm).If you are a devoted nonfiction reader and you can muster the patience to read the backstory of how this trip came to pass, I think you'll really appreciate the time you invested and just how amazing the road trip really was (from Tierra del Fuego to Prudhoe Bay). I have to admit I was a bit disappointed that the end of the journey (the U.S. portion) seemed like it was rushed (in the writing) and I wish they had gone into more detail. But I gather that after a month of almost nonstop driving and very little food or sleep, they were both pretty much hallucinating.Anyway, I love adventure books. Would love to find more like this.

Oh, am I having fun with this, lol. The only real Mustang I've ever owned was a 1967 (with a 289, but not the High Performance version) yellow with a black vinyl top  'Stang that my poor father bought new as a fun car and had to surrender to me a few years later when I got my license. I guess he knew that was coming. So it's a lot of fun to revisit my Mustang days...I can almost smell the burgers and fries at the local drive in. Oh, and I got the colors I wanted: white with a blue racing stripe.This remote control car is substantially larger than I thought it would be (around a foot long and fairly wide--I guess the 1:14 ratio should have tipped me off) and it feels pretty substantial, too. I was so anxious to try it that I made a special trip to buy batteries (you'll need 4AA and 2AAA batteries), lol. I really thought the cats might like it zooming around the hardwood floors of the living room, but so far they have been sitting in the next room staring with mild interest and a bit of alarm.This thing really zooms along pretty quickly, but cornering a car this big takes some room--it does not turn on a dime as some of my little cars did when I was a kid. And the range is only about 60' (I haven't tested that yet), so on my street that's about one yard's width. That's not bad, but I have seen kids at a local park with cars that are responding at twice that distance. But for the price, I think this car does a very respectable job at responding to commands (via a trigger-type controller, not a joystick--and the trigger takes some getting used to) and, as I said, it's pretty zippy.I have no clue how long the batteries are going to last, but I suppose at my age (see the first paragraph for an estimate of that) I'm not going to be wearing them down or the neighbors will think I've lost it (or the kids down the street will beg me to let them borrow it). Also, the car rides pretty low and though the tires are pretty big, if you hit a stick or grass patch, you may have to do a quick rescue. I'll try it soon on rougher turf and see how it does. The body seems pretty solid, but I'm not a kid, so I'll probably treat it more gently--hard to tell what a 10 year old could do to it.Overall I think for the price this is a pretty neat car. If I'd gotten this as a kid, I'd have been over the moon.

I just reread Potshot for the third time and I'd forgotten how much I enjoyed this book. Spenser gets involved in cleaning out an Arizona town of evil doers and he enlists the help of some of his favorite gentlemen thugs: Chollo, Teddy Sapp, Hawk, etc. The story is typical Parker: half completely believable, half somewhat preposterous and that's just what I like.A lot of Parker's characters are somewhat cartoonish, but in this book I think Parker slowed down a bit and he really rose to the occasion. The storyline is more dense, covers a lot of geographic territory (Boston, Georgia, LA, Arizona) which is somewhat unusual for Spenser, and the characters are certainly more developed. And the investigation is more intense, a bit more real and certainly very exciting.I get the feeling that Parker enjoyed writing this book a lot and I really enjoyed reading it (three times!). Each time that I read a book I write down the start/finish date, and make lots of notes about the plot lines, settings, descriptions, etc. (hey, I'm a writer, what can I say) and this book is just filled with my notes--all of them positive. The ending is kind of fun, too.A lot of Spenser books move along through the sheer force of Parker's dialog (no one is better, no one) and his settings and plots are usually pretty bare bones. But this book is a bit different--it's much richer and that makes it a much more fun read. I actually tried to slow down reading this because I was enjoying it so much.A great book to read on a cold winter's night.

Larry David just gets better and better. I love being able to watch this whole series whenever I want via Amazon Prime. I had to cancel HBO when I was relying on cable (to save a few bucks) and so never got to see this season. It's a blast watching it now. Where else are you going to see a billionaire screw up his own life at every turn. :)

I'm new to Lawrence Block, though I love first-person narratives in detective fiction. I'm a big fan of Robert B. Parker, but I was looking for something perhaps a bit more complex (great as Parker was, his plots tend to run a bit toward the cartoonish) and I got my money's worth with this book. He does change the perspective from first to third person (that took some creative courage, lol), but the book starts out giving you such a great firsthand look through the protagonist's eyes that you love the character immediately. Block is, to be sure, a much slower-paced read than someone like Parker, but the plots and characters are a lot more complex and soulful. I've seen other reviewers suggest that perhaps Block was writing at a lesser creative level in this book, but I have nothing to compare it to. I found this book to be very thought provoking and, again, very soulful. I live about an hour from Manhattan so much of the setting is ultra familiar to me. I loved the book. If you like Parker, I think you'd like Block.

I've been using Coleman propane lanterns since I was a teenager and I've loved every one and kept most of them for years and years. As much hassle as real mantels can be, they emit the most pure and brightest light I can imagine. I've bought and owned several battern-powere lantern, but none comes close to propane for sheer illumination. If you're camping alone in a relatively remote area, it's nice to put this lantern on a rock or tree stump and have good vision for quite a distance (easily 50' if you're burning on high power).As someone else mentioned I think there needs to be a better way to attach the base (though sometimes I just stick the propane tank in a pile of gravel or dirt and it's pretty steady) so that you can move the lantern quickly. I also miss the tie-on mantles (though it took me a long time to get good at tying them).I rarely use propane indoors, but with winter coming here to New England, I love having a super bright lantern like this to set out on the front step to make the neighborhood more cheery when the power goes away.

I think this is an excellent and very useful book and I am, I gather, the ideal audience for it. This is, to be certain, a beginner's book. I've seen a few reviewers criticize it for being that--but how on Earth do you criticize something for being what it is meant to be: a starter's guide. I'm a Mac person (by nature and by experience) and I think that someone (even a very experienced Windows person) would still need a basics book to operate the Apple OS. You aren't born with this knowledge (unless you're under 20 years old, maybe, lol).I have just acquired my second Windows laptop and fortunately it came with a Windows 10 update (my other Windows laptop has 8.1 installed and I use it as little as possible). The 10 version, however, is much closer in style and ease-of-use to a Mac, so seems much more familiar to me. I'm learning to navigate it substantially faster than I learned on 8.0  and 8.1. And you have to admit, Windows laptops are a boatload cheaper than a Mac laptop.This book is perfect for a dinosaur like myself that needs to be walked through each aspect of the OS one task at a time. It begins with a good look at the basic interface, then moves into a chapter on customizing that interface for your own work. Most of the remaining chapters are very task-specific and deal with things like surfing the web (which may seem too basic for some reviewers, but if the editors were to have omitted this, they would complain that essential basics were left out), sending emails, downloading and viewing images and videos, editing documents, etc.My only real complaint about the book (and I have voiced this complaint about other books in and out of the series) is that a lot of the screen captures are just too small to read (if you're in your 20s, wait until you're in your 50s). Things get worse when the background color for the screen is black and the type is white. The answer is simple: either print a much larger book, the size of a big phone book, or add pages and make each important capture larger. I would imagine that owning an e-version of this book solves that because on my tablet or Kindle, I can probably increase the screens to full size. Duh, yes, you can just look at your computer, but you are not always sitting at your computer when you are reading. So not necessarily a deal-breaker issue, but in the publishing of days gone by, this would probably be a 500 page book (it's just over 300) with larger graphics. (Personally I think that if you buy a print version of any book that you get access to the e-version at a substantial discount.)I'm very satisfied with the book and I think the author took the right road by making this ultra-basic. I write how-to books for a living (and full confession, I have written books for Wiley in the past, but no longer work for them) and I firmly believe you should never presume the reader has any existing knowledge when it comes to a basics book. It's better to be too basic, or redundant to a certain degree, than to throw the reader under the bus just to appear to be very hip and knowledgeable. Going ultra-basic but still being comprehensive is a skill that it takes an entire career to master.If you're new to Windows (and particularly Windows 10), I really recommend this book very highly.

This is a very difficult movie for me to review for this simple reason: I think the script has a lot of holes in it, and yet I love the movie. This is the story of a man who has given up hope, and is dragged back to the world of hope and miracles (kicking and screaming) by a series of events all centered around a woman who thinks she sees the image of Christ on one of his exterior walls.Luke Wilson is the star of the movie and a large part of the reason that I like the movie so very much is that he's simply a perfect actor. Having to act within the limits of a script that, as I said, has some serious holes, he manages to pull this whole film together. He emotions, his body language, his facial expressions very powerful. I loved watching him act.I really can't detail the things I think are weak in the script without putting some spoilers in this review and I don't want to do that. It's just that a few things seem to happen with no explanation (and I'm not talking about the miracles that seem to occur pretty regularly in the film) and there is one somewhat crucial scene that is just kind of glossed over quickly.Anyway, I loved the movie. I'm holding back one star because of my personal issues with the script. There is a very fine documentary on the making of the film that was really entertaining and I think all film students should watch it. If you like quirky and offbeat films, and if you know of Luke Wilson and like him, you'll love this movie.

I bought this book to help me to some travel research for a photo trip that I was planning. While that trip got postponed, I ended up spending a lot of time with this book just because I discovered so much that I didn't know about Wisconsin. This book is just packed with information and it's all delivered in an extremely interesting and readable way. In fact, I will go out on a limb and say it's one of the best-written travel guides that I've read in a very long time (and I'm a travel writer by profession).The author, Thomas Huhti, obviously knows and loves Wisconsin and I found myself reading about places I'd never heard of before. I don't know if the author had a staff helping him research the text, but he did a fantastic job of research and organization--and I'm not sure it's a job I'd ever welcome taking on. A *lot* of work went into this book. (And no, I don't know the author, lol.) I loved the small reference to the fur trade helping to build cities, and how fishing seems to be such a large part of the state's recreational history.My only disappointment in the book is that other than a small section up front, all of the photos are in black and white. I would love to see a lot more color photography. There are lots of small maps, too, and they are simple and easy to use--clear maps being a rarity in a lot of travel guides.If I was heading to Wisconsin (and I hope I am soon), I'd be thrilled to have this book along. By the way, I find it almost impossible to believe that the publisher has allowed this book to go out of print--perhaps they are planning an update.

C'mon, Larry David is the king of them all y'all! The series is really hitting its stride by season 4 and most of the major characters have been introduced. That this entire series is FREE on Prime is worth the price of Prime! Some episodes are a little boring at times, and there's a lot of dark humor, but overall, stellar. Lots of great guest stars in this season, too.

This is a pretty dumb low-budget film, but I actually like dumb low-budget films, lol. The big surprise here was seeing Ralph Wait, the dad in the Waltons, as a beach bum philosopher/guru. It's worth watching for that. It's really not that bad of a film and if, like me, you remember the 60s vividly, you'll probably get a kick out of a some of it. The filmmaking is surprisingly solid, except EXCEPT for the weird flashback out-of-focus scenes, they are annoying and very humorous. Thank God for the fast forward button!It's free with Amazon Prime (and I hope a lot of these old B movies show up there) and so what the heck, you can watch it for free and get a look at Daddy Walton with a beard dressed up like a hippy. :)

I have a small antiques business on the side and these labels are perfect for tagging all sorts of items from lamps to furniture. With the smaller things (a vase, lamp, etc.) I can use the string to tie on the label. And with larger items like furniture, I can simply tape the string to the item. The nice thing about tags of this size is that I can put pricing information, as well as some identifying information. Also, everything in the antiques biz is about the "story" behind the item, so having room to jot down a quick history or provenance about a piece is great.The tags are very strong and they take Sharpie ink nicely. Even better, the Sharpie ink doesn't bleed through at all. Cheaper tags do bleed through which means you can only write legibly on one side. With these, I've been writing on both sides and unless you hold them up to a very bright light, you'd never know there was writing on the other side. I wouldn't mind if the string were a few inches longer, it would help get it around lamp bases and things, but it's workable.By the way, these are nice if you're selling books, too, because you can insert the price tag as a bookmark. The grommet is super strong, also. The price seems high at first, but when you consider you're getting 1,000 labels, let's face it, that's only four cents a tag (at $40, the box).

The first thing I have to say about this light (bear with me a minute, I just have to rant a bit)  is that whoever designed the retail packaging (not the shipping packaging, I mean the product packaging) was obviously a bored engineer. Everything these days is over packaged and I find it hugely annoying. I had to cut no less than five pieces of tape, untwine a wire tie and then cut some ribbon at the bottom whose purpose I have yet to figure out. I also found the battery installation to be annoying--you have to find a micro screwdriver and unscrew two screws--and then you have to deal with another ribbon. I gather that the battery compartment screws are there to prevent kids from pulling out the batteries, which is an excellent idea, but it's a bit time consuming.The light itself is fine, it's not terribly bright which I gather is a good thing since it's just a nightlight. You want to comfort kids, not keep them awake staring at the light, lol. One minor criticism is that the entire monkey face is not evenly lit. The mouth area is shadowed a bit by the inner workings of the lamp so it's darker than the rest of the face. I also don't particularly understand the use of black opaque eyes instead of white--which probably would have made the eyes light up a bit. But no big deal, this is a nightlight, not a glowing monkey portrait.The on/off switch is easy to use and big enough so any kid can find and operate it. The handle is nice and solid and molded into the lamp. It seems well built, solid, unlikely to break unless someone tried really hard. And the battery compartment while annoying (to me) is secure and that's the key thing.I would think that if I had had this in my room when I was really small I would have found it comforting and I do like the idea that it shuts itself off after 30 minutes. I think small kids would think this is a fun present.

Another great film from John Waters (and from Johnny Depp). I love these early films of Baltimore that showcase early rock 'n roll and soul music--and dancing. Just a great, fun film with a silly but entertaining plot. Waters' great skill is capturing a moment in time and revealing it in all of its strange, funny, romantic and silly perfection (and imperfections). To be sure, Waters looks through rose-colored glasses, but he always errs on the side of humanity and humor and that is what makes him a genius.But someone tell me, what has happened to him? Where did his movie career go? Come back John!

I live in New England just a few miles from the coast and only blocks from a river where Captain Kidd is said to have buried treasure (too bad he didn't say where), so reading about pirates has been a hobby since I was a kid. This book is a great account of the pirates of the New England coast, so it's perfectly aimed at me. The writings a tad stodgy at times but it's not a difficult or boring read by any means. In fact, every time I pick it up to read a few pages, I end up reading several times that. You will learn a great deal about the history of pirates, of New England and of sea commerce and there's lots and lots of adventure along the way.I think any New Englander will get a great kick of of this book and I have to say, for the price I paid used, it was a great find (and even new these Dover books are quite a bargain--and the quality of the printing is just fine). I'm not sure kids or teens would get much out of it, but anyone that's of a certain age will just love it. Great, fun read.

This is the one of two Sony Blu-Ray players that I own. The other is a 2013 model S5100 that, for some reason, now costs more than twice what I paid for it. This newer edition (2015) is a significantly better unit in some ways and costs half the price of the older version. Go figure. The good thing is that, as I played with this new model, I had a point of reference in the same brand and model line, which is rare but nice.First let me say that set up of this player is completely simple. All that you really have to do is plug in an HDMI cable and the power unit and you're done (at least with the hard connections). Funny, when I set up the older unit, more than a year ago, I was a bit afraid of connecting it up to my router. I guess I just didn't have much confidence such magic really worked. OK, a computer yes, but a Blu Ray player? I was wrong with that one as with this one, making the signature to my router was simple. Also now, as then, I used making my connection to Amazon (Prime Video) as my test case and aside from having to tap in a password, it's a breeze. In fact, for someone with as little confidence as he has in all things wireless, it was a piece of cake. I was watching an old episode of Cheers in minutes.Even though I have a comparison unit (they are in different room, naturally), I can't honestly say if the wifi is any faster and that is partly because this new S5500 unit is in my den, at the farthest point from my router. Any speed delays I'm seeing are probably entirely due to that. But in all fairness, they seem almost identical to me in speed. I'm planning to add a signal booster soon (recommendations welcome) and when I do, I'll probably have a better appraisal for a speed comparison.This unit has 300 streaming apps as compared to 100 with the older unit and you'll be old before you go through them all. Some apps really suck, but that's the fault of the provider of that app, not Sony. Youtube is painfully slow on both units and that's something I don't understand. When I get the signal booster I will try again and if this new unit is faster (significantly) I will update this review. Oh, how I'd like to watch more Van Morrison concerts on Youtube!OK, so that's wifi connection. As far as blu ray quality goes: superb. The first movie I watched on this was "Get Low" with Bill Murray and Robert Duval and I'm so happy that I own it on blu ray. But I also watched "Something About Mary" on dvd and yes, there is a marked quality improvement over watching it on a straight dvd player. No question, the dvd quality is enhanced.I have not tried a mirroring configuration yet, but I hope to do it soon. That's a little beyond my lame skill sets, but I'll try.Also, I am only listening now through the very moderate-quality speakers in my 42" Vizio so I can't really comment on audio quality. But I'm going to add a speaker system or sound bar to this soon and I am hoping that the sound is good. I have a Create speaker system hooked up to the other TV and it's massively better than the built-in speakers (and for like $40).For under $100 I think this is a bargain and, honestly, I would spend too much time wondering. For that kind of money, this is a steal. I'll update this review in a few weeks when I've played with various features more.

Even though my "outdoor" furniture is in a screened-in porch, it is still prone to getting rained on when there is significant wind. Up until now, an approaching storm meant that I had to push the furniture away from the screened perimeter of the porch and, in a really bad storm, bring the cushions into the house. The couch and chairs are weatherproof, but still no point in getting the cushions wet if I don't have to. Up until now I've been using cheap plastic painting tarps (1 mil) from the hardware store--they do the job, but they won't last long and they are none too pretty to look at.This Soto cover has really solved that problem in a big way because now, if a storm is approaching, I can just cover the couch and not worry about it. The cover is just barely big enough for my couch (it's a bit on the large side), but it does cover it. And while I don't really need them the tie-down straps are plenty long enough and if the furniture were out on the patio, would be great to use. The fabric, while thin enough to be lightweight (I can cover the couch by myself in just a few minutes) appears to be very strong and it has already been tested in a downpour on a windy day so I know it's rainproof. Getting the cover back in the case is one of those things I'm not particularly  patient with but it wasn't a problem, as you fold and push the air out, it collapses again nicely. Also, I can just slip the case and cover right under the couch, so I don't have to go hunting for it.I can't say if the vent holes do or don't allow rain in because again, the furniture is indoors, so partly protected already.I really think these Soto covers are a good solution and for the price, a bargain. I'm not sure how they would handle winter outdoors, but I really don't think they were designed for a New England winter. I'm planning on getting a pair of chair covers soon. I hope I don't have to use it, but the warranty seems good, too.

This is a fun toy and cats, all cats, love to chase stuff like this. Unfortunately, it is also extremely dangerous if you are not watching the cats every second. For some reason known only to cats, they love to chew off pieces of this and they will swallow it. For that reason I played with it once, saw them growing at it and threw it away. I should have known, but I was hoping we could just play with it and not have to go through that whole chewing thing. A fun toy if you are supervising constantly, but otherwise, I don't trust it (or rather, the cats).

This is a good basic case that does a good job of protecting the tablet. I have better cases for various tablets (a great OtterBox case for my iPad), but for a simple protective case at well under $10, this works fine. If you're really on the go a lot or have kids that tend to shove stuff in backpacks and then use the backpack for a pillow, you might want to look at a more rugged case, or if you want advanced features like magnets that sleep/wake your tablets. But again, for a good accessible cover at a ridiculously cheap price (especially with Prime shipping), a good deal.

I am the right age that I grew up with the Andy Griffith show and after all these years, I still believe it was the finest television show ever produced. I've probably watched some of the episodes hundreds of times, easily, and they never get old. I'm thrilled that the entire series is now available for free on Amazon Prime Video and I put the entire series in my watch list. Running out of reasons to keep paying that cable bill.

This toy really brings out the kid in me and if I had seen this when I was small, my parents would have been under merciless assault until they bought it for me. As it was, for every birthday they had to buy me a new Havahart trap so that I could catch and release animals, which I did almost every day in summer. I knew every opossum in the neighborhood on a first-name basis.I'm going to give this toy four stars because I think it's an incredibly clever idea and it does do everything it says it will--the vacuum works (though it's not very strong), the light lights up (it's greenish and kind of cool looking after dark) and it seems pretty well made. If the vacuum were stronger, I would absolutely give it 5+ stars. I first tested the gun with the little foam butterfly that comes with it and it picks that up just fine (you have to make sure the magnifying lens is turned sideways or it blocks the vacuum draw). Then I tested it on bits of cat fur (easy to hunt down in this house) it works pretty well with those. I tried to catch a housefly but he was a tad faster than me and every time I put the gun near him he demonstrated why compound eyes are such good protection--impossible to fool him.I can't wait to find an insect that is slow enough for me to suck up. I think the size of the bugs you can catch will be limited to about the size of a dime, otherwise they won't get past the magnifying lens (at least not willingly). But I think for small moths and perhaps fireflies, it might work just fine (of course, when I was a kid a mason jar worked just as well!).The gun is pretty nicely made, but let's face it, this is intended for kids and they can destroy anything. One thing that I like is that the batteries (4AA, kind of expensive to refill) are in a compartment in the handle that requires a screwdriver to open--which means the batteries won't be falling out in the backyard. That was a good design decision.Fun toy! I wish I had it when I was 8, I would have been up nights chasing bugs. I wish the vacuum was stronger but otherwise, a nice toy or gift. I'll have to get the bug cage next.

This is a tale about a young boy who isnt like the rest. He cant seem to find joy, emotional connection, or excitement in any of the pursuits that occupy his peers. That all changes once he attends his first funeral and finds an insatiable lust for the dead.This story isnt called The Loved Dead for nothing!I listened to this story as an audiobook production complete with spooky sound effects that added to the already creepy atmosphere. The narrator spoke in a sinister tone but at times got a little whispery and was sometimes drowned out by the sound effects. He also stumbled a little here and there over the words. I caught it which is rare but good because it means the story hooked me. Id advise listening to this version with headphones and not in your car.After some confusion about the co-authoring credits on the title, I did my usual 30 seconds of internet research and learned that this story was written by C.M. Eddy and revised by H.P. Lovecraft. It was written in 1919 and I imagine it was quite scandalous back then. But, now? Well I can only speak for myself, but I fear I am too jaded to get too bothered by the vaguely disturbing writings of a serial killing perv who enjoys purple prose. It had some creepy moments, to be sure, and I am certainly glad I am finished spending time in this guys head.If youre looking for something to get under your skin for 48 minutes this story might be meant for you.*I received a free copy of this audio from the publisher/author/narrator in exchange for an honest review and that's what you're getting.

I am feeling so incredibly unmotivated and since there are already a zillion reviews of this book here, there and everywhere, I shall be brief. Is there really a need for a zillion plot synopsis-ez, anyway? My lazy side says no, no, theres definitely no need today.I didnt like the characters but I still liked the book. I dont know why. I just did. I didn't like it quite as much as Gone Girl but it still kept me hooked. Please dont ask me to explain. As I mentioned, Im too lazy for all that today.Libby, Ben, Melissa, Deandra, Runner and whoever else Ive already forgotten? Yeah, theyre all jerks in their own little ways and are mostly horribly unlikable people, with all sorts of human failings. Only mom was sympathetic. That poor woman had terrible taste in men and a bad luck cloud hanging over her head but she did as best as she could to provide for her kidlets.Libby is the main character and shes a depressed, selfish, miserable mess of a woman who cant seem to function in society if society is not paying her way. Ugh, spare me your boo-hoo-ery and get thee a job. I have no sympathy for this type of person but you dont care about that. Anyhow, this is the story of unlikable Libby. When Libby was seven, her mother and two sisters were murdered. And yes, that is horrible but shes now 31 and still trying to live off sympathy. Because Libby has run out of cash, she decides to accept an offer from a group of creepers called The Kill Club who live and breathe for secretive true crime conventions. They pay her to start digging into the events that destroyed her childhood. This finally gives her some oomph and she uncovers all kinds of ugly tidbits and secrets. Oops, I guess I cannot get through a review without rehashing some of the plot.It was this darkness simmering just under the surface that I loved so very much about the story. It kept me guessing and it kept me reading and I couldnt get enough of the deep, dark, awful secrets. Perhaps I am just as bad as those kill club freaks.The story jumps back and forth between the present day and the days leading up to the massacre and is written in such a way that it hooked me instead of frustrating me. I listened to this on audio which I highly recommend if audio is your thing. There were several narrators and they all did the writing justice, adding emotion and nuance to the written word.

After reading a few reviews here, I was a little leery about this. I had fears of it bending and breaking and being a cheapo piece of junk. I've purchased many a clothing rack only to have them break under the weight of only a few skimpy dance outfits so honestly wasn't expecting too much. A BIG thank you goes to the reviewer who figured out how to put this together so it was more stable. I followed those instructions (both the screws facing forward) and have had absolutely no tippage. It was a smidge taller than I anticipated but that's my fault for not reading the specs, it was a breeze to put together, required no tools and works great for holding all of my wet laundry that can't go in the dryer, As long as you evenly balance out the weight on both sides, I don't see how you could tip it. My husband recently put a heavy winter coat on one side with nothing on the other and it didn't budge. I think it's a great buy for the money. I've been using it for several weeks and nothing has popped off or bent. If that changes in the future, I'll be sure to let you know.

Percival Whyborne is a shy, socially awkward kind of guy, comfortable hiding away with moldy old tomes. The thought of taking a lunch outside his office and having to actually converse with someone is out of his comfort zone. He can speak 13 languages and can read even more but he doesnt think that any big thing.Hes sweet and modest and hiding himself from the world for more reasons than shyness.When Griffin Flaherty, a handsome PI walks into his life and ask Whyborne to decipher a mysterious journal his world is about to get a whole heck of a lot more exciting. As you may have guessed, this is no ordinary old book.Some very sinister things happen and Whyborne finds himself playing a huge role in all of it. Hes also forced to put some demons in his past to rest which resulted in some pretty great character building. Along the way, he and Griffin become friends and in between mystery solving and monster slaying theres plenty of time for innocent kisses and a whole lot more.Widdershins is a strange mix of monsters, mystery, and action along with a well-developed sweet and very sexy romance. I was worried it would fall down and fail me but somehow it all works. There is great care taken here to develop all aspects of the story. It has spooky atmosphere and lovable characters. There was only one point where I had my doubts, when Whyborne discovers something in Griffins room, but I got over it and cannot wait to read more."This audiobook was provided by the author, narrator, or publisher at no cost in exchange for an unbiased review courtesy of AudiobookBlast.com."I listen to a ton of audio and I am pretty picky about narration. This narrator did a decent job with Whyborne but unfortunately a not-so-great job with Griffins character. They have very different personalities but sound exactly alike which left me feeling a little confused here and there (though I admit that is not too difficult a feat).
