For my mistress box with a thick panel (Richeson), I ended up drilling halfway and then carefully carved out a hole just enough to bury the center head screw, and used 4 wood screws to secure the plate instead of using the supplied bolts and nuts meant to be installed through the bottom panel. If my box panel were thinner, I would've been in trouble since the bolts and nuts would've protruded into the base glass palette area. For most smaller pochade boxes with thinner boards, you can use some cheap 1/4-20 x 1/4" tee nuts you can buy on Amazon (or hardware stores) along with a wood panel piece to screw on to the box.

I was hoping that CJ's review on 2012 would be outdated by now but it's not. It's 3 years later, but somehow the same inconsistency persists. The sketch box package photo shows the Amazon's ad pic with 1 covered brush compartment, but the contained sketch box has 5 compartments without a brush compartment cover. The wooden box was dented and scratched up a bit although its packaging box was pristine. The box's actual dimension is 12.75" x 9.75" (not 9.5"), the internal dimension is 9 x 12 (1/16" short on both), and the lid doesn't open fully and stays up at about 97 degrees supported by the rear hinges. I bought some 1/4-20 x 1/4" tee nuts to mount this box onto a tripod to make it into a plein air pochade box, but the top and the bottom panels are no thicker than 1/8" thin boards so I had to get creative by adding a wood panel piece to install/attach the tee nut to the very thin board. The box is inexpensive enough but I would've liked the ad photo box instead. I'm baffled how the product could be incorrectly marketed for years without a correction but it is what it is...

Well, I just HAD to try this after seeing many Youtube videos (buldak bokkeum myun or fire noodle callenge) of people trying this ramen. I can take spice pretty well, but even then I was a bit scared to try this assuming it's probably a sadistically hot inedible product aspiring fame through people's agony. With the cooked ramyun bowl in front of me, I breathed in deep, meditated a little, and then took the first bite. I must say I was both disappointed and relieved at the same time. It was not nearly as spicy as I had expected, and it was quite tasty! The sauce flavor is akin to the popular Korean dish Ddukbokki, except it's a little more savory (chicken?) and spicier. The sweetness tapers down the level of spice, and I finished the bowl without flinching although my nose pooled sweat long afterwards. As for a relevant gauge, if you enjoy and can eat Buffalo Wild's "hot" wings, then you won't have trouble finishing this. I also noticed that many people prep this noodle incorrectly and comment that it lacks flavor. The noodles won't lack flavor if you don't dilute it down by cooking it like other common ramen noodles. I noticed there's no English instruction on the received product anywhere, so I decided to post the translated cooking instruction:1. Boil 3 cups (or more) of water, and then cook the noodles for 5 minutes.2. Drain water (leave about 8 spoons worth), add the packaged liquid hot sauce, and then return to stove to stir the noodles at low heat for about 30 seconds.3. Turn off the stove, then mix in the dry sesame/seaweed package with the noodles.On step 1, I've boiled for 4.5 minutes instead for firmer noodles.Step 2 is important - you should pretty much drain off most of the water you see using your fork/chopsticks as strainer as you pour off excess water off your cooking pot, and you should have just enough water hidden in noodles for a saucy consistency, not liquidy. Stirring on heat with the hot paste incorporates the flavor and thickens the sauce. If you end up with too much juice, raise the heat a bit and evaporate off the water until the sauce thickens.When properly prepared, the sauce should be thick enough to coat the noodles and allow the sesame seeds to stick to the lifted noodles.I noticed that my received product's expiration date was less than 6 months away (8/30/2015). I will have no trouble finishing the noodles before the expiration, but it can be off-putting to buy any almost expired product. I'm not sure what the usual expiration is for the ramyun given the inclusion of the liquid paste, but the noodles didn't smell stale nor rancid as I could usually tell from almost stale ramyun noodles.All in all, this was very worth a try to resolve my curiosity after laughing so much at Youtube people's reactions, and I feel superior and stronger!oh~~ my stomach is starting to burn...Update: Curiosity got me to try the more convenient cup ramyun version of this (my packs were gone too soon!), and I prefer these cooking packets hands down. The cup noodles are much thinner and less chewy, and you don't get as savory deeper taste attained by cooking the liquid paste with noodles. The cup version's instruction tells you to drain off all water before adding the flavor packets, so you're definitely supposed to consume these with practically no liquid. The thicker noodles in the cooking packs need help to infuse the flavor in the step #2 above (the reason to leave some water to cook off), and you get 140g instead of 70g (small cup) or 105g (big cup) instant versions. Besides the packs being much more affordable, you get more of it along with much better taste when you prepare it properly. Time to order some more...

Well, I just HAD to try this after seeing many Youtube videos (buldak bokkeum myun or fire noodle callenge) of people trying this ramen. I can take spice pretty well, but even then I was a bit scared to try this assuming it's probably a sadistically hot inedible product aspiring fame through people's agony. With the cooked ramyun bowl in front of me, I breathed in deep, meditated a little, and then took the first bite. I must say I was both disappointed and relieved at the same time. It was not nearly as spicy as I had expected, and it was quite tasty! The sauce flavor is akin to the popular Korean dish Ddukbokki, except it's a little more savory (chicken?) and spicier. The sweetness tapers down the level of spice, and I finished the bowl without flinching although my nose pooled sweat long afterwards. As for a relevant gauge, if you enjoy and can eat Buffalo Wild's "hot" wings, then you won't have trouble finishing this. I also noticed that many people prep this noodle incorrectly and comment that it lacks flavor.There's no English instruction on how to prepare the noodles; No wonder so many people eat it incorrectly on Youtube with excess liquid.1. Pour boiling water to the indicated line inside the cup, and wait 4 minutes (put the liquid flavor pack on top of the cup to heat it during this process).2. Open the lid and stir the noodles well with chopsticks [or fork], then pour out all excess water. Add the liquid pack and mix in well.3. Add the dry flake pack and consume.I've tried the cooking pack version of this (not instant cup), and I prefer the cooking packs hands down. You get 140g of noodles in the pack instead of 70g (small cup) or 105g (big cup) instant versions, and the thicker noodles taste more savory and dare I say even more spicy when prepared correctly.  If you like the cup, you'll love the packs. I'm knocking out one star here because I don't like the thinner noodles in the cup version and they cost too much despite the convenience. I'm going to stick to the pack version from now on.

I decided to try this bird house after sadly returning another window bird house made of green recycled plastic. The other bird house would not stay up on window and kept dropping by itself with just its own weight, and I almost gave up on trying another window house. This made out of cedar is lighter and much better made, and it also has 3 good quality suction cups, as to 2 on the other. It is so much more stable and has not moved since I've placed it on a window. I've stained/sealed it in redwood tone to improve longevity outdoor, and also put clear tapes over the side top half-moon holes; I'm pretty sure these are there to improve light (for viewing) than for ventilation, and I didn't want rain to enter through the side holes. I've learned that mirror viewing films tend to scare nesting birds away, so I've taped a piece of black roofing felt on the inside of the window to simply flip up for viewing later. It was practically impossible to view my chickadee nest in a birdhouse the past season, so I can't wait to get a better view with this product. I am very pleased with the purchase and I'll update if I see any nest activity.

I was hoping this product would be at least as delicious and fragrant as some of the common vending machine coffees I've tasted in Korea. The most fragrant coffee I've tried was actually at a small cafe in Korea, so I had to try this based on the reviews here. Although individual packaging is convenient, the coffee flavor is nothing extraordinary and falls flat compared to my expectation. You can prepare a similar tasting coffee with Coffee Mate + sugar combined with one of the more popular instant coffees in the US,  If you're looking for convenient sweetened premixed individual packaging at about .22 cents a pack (to mix in with 1/2 cup hot water), then this might be worth a try. On a side by side taste with another more common premixed coffee, Nescafe Cafe con Leche (got mine cheap at local Kroger), I preferred the Nescafe over Maxim.

I've been using human tartar scraper that you often see in dentist's office to clean my dog and cats' teeth for years since they were puppy/kittens. It's significantly tougher to clean more defiant cats' teeth but it helps to use a large towel to wrap the cats in a burrito fashion and strap the cat burrito with an adjustable belt (OK PETA, I don't need a call). If you're squeamish or lack the dexterity to do this, you'll need to spend hundreds a year to keep your pets healthy through regular vet visits, and be under the expense and mercy of anesthesia's side effects. I've just tried this new tartar scraper that doesn't look like a captain's hook, and I noticed that it allows for a safer scraping angle and it's much easier to use than a hook shaped scraper with a pointy end. Healthy gums won't bleed as much and the pets won't flinch dangerously if the gums are not painfully inflamed from accumulated tartar, so I end up semi-torturing my beloved pets pretty often with the towel burritos for their sake. They get to keep their healthy teeth longer (along with overall systemic health) and I get to enjoy their fresh breath and avoid vet expense and unnecessary risks.

My eyes were suddenly crusty with yellow discharge when I woke up in the mornings and I noticed slimy clear substance that I could pull out in long strings out my eyes. I thought perhaps I may have contracted a minor infection and decided to try this product while waiting to see my opthamologist on a delayed appointment. The eye drops did sting a bit but they were tolerable. The day after the initial drops, I noticed significantly increased yellow discharge. After few more days of use, the yellow discharge and mucus inclusions completely went away and I was waking up with clear eyes again. Whatever the ailment was, the eye drops took care of it by the time I saw my Opthamologist. When I asked about the symptoms after my healthy eye exam, he said it could've been anything such as allergy or seasonal irritation. I showed him the Eyebright drops bottle for his opinion, and he said the ingredients are safe to use as he saw nothing harmful. I asked about the msm (sulfur) that some of the reviewers complain about, and he said the ingredient is perfectly safe for most people who are not allergic to sulfur (cabbabe, broccoli, cauliflower, etc). As for the eye floaters that some reviewers report of clearing, I already knew the answer but the Dr. confirmed that there's no supplement that will make eye floaters go away; However, the larger floater segments can break to smaller pieces and become less noticeable in time. For those buying this to clear floaters - please don't waste your money. I've done my research on this since I had floaters since I was a child. Eyebright herb, which I've also tried ingesting, may improve eye health and possibly prevent worsening of floaters, but the only procedure to clear existing floaters is an operation called Vitrectomy (strain out eye fluid with surgical needles) for bad enough cases only. For those with eye irritations, this product may be worth a try. I found out MSM actually provides many eye benefits that you can easily google to research, as do other included ingredients Grapefruit Seed Extract and Apple Cider Vinegar (probably what causes the stings). I can't call this product soothing, but it helps with eye strains and irritations and my eyes do feel more refreshed after the initial stings.

This cutter/stripper worked perfectly well on stripping my RG6 cable. One thing you should keep in mind- You WILL end up cutting your finger if you do not pay attention!  I actually saw many posts noting such and ignored the warning prior to using the tool, but on one occasion I didn't pay close attention after repeat procedures and didn't have my finger in the circular loop while rotating the tool, and ended up with a nice cut through my finger. This mistake is surprisingly easy to make and I actually wish the razor sharp cutter wasn't built-in or have a protective cover on it, so please be careful.

I use this directly on a Lowe's 2 gallon bucket along with chicken nipple waterer (threaded style oasis poultry water nipples) to function as an automatic waterer. It works perfectly to stop any water overflow and I like the adjustable arm to modify the water level as needed. My initial shipped valve was missing the compression nut ferrule to allow for 1/4 tubing to stay on water-tight, so you may want to check for any missing part as soon as you get the valve. I control the water refill time at the spigot with a digital water timer (Orbit 91213), so I can't attest to how the product would fare in the long-run under constant water pressure, and this will probably be dependent upon your incoming water pressure. Our water main (location where water enters house) psi is set at 75 (was initially at 50 psi), and the float valve works just fine to stop any water overflow whenever I've tested. I avoid having water hose left under pressure since I've lost a few of our garden hoses that way (especially after we increased to 75 psi to improve shower) along with costly water waste. I would personally not risk such failure especially for indoors, so check your psi and use a timer if possible or at very least use a pressure regulator and/or partially open your spigot valve to lower water pressure. I use all three measures - pressure regulator, timer, and float value. It's better to be safe than sorry.

These work fairly well. They are heat resistant but not incredibly so. I got these for a school demonstration where I had to hold something in very hot water (140F) for 15 seconds or so. I could do so with these gloves, but it was uncomfortable after 10 or 15 seconds. Given I couldn't do it at all without these gloves, I can affirm they provide some protection. But I think it is more for non-submersed cases where the little nubs keep the heat away from most of the glove.The gloves are identical left/right. This is good in one way, but also means they are a tad uncomfortable. Your thumb feels pulled back a bit when you put these on. It isn't bad, but noticeable.I received these gloves free of charge in exchange for an honest review.

These headphones sound good, are comfortable, and affordable.I use these when working around the house (doing dishes, cleaning up) and find the Bluetooth feature wonderful. The sound is decent with enough bass for music to sound good. They aren't "wonderful", but are very good and I have no complaints about the sound. I'm moving about so concentrating on hearing a finger slide on a guitar string isn't what these are for.They stay in my ears just fine although I don't know what the loop is for. It seems a but useless. I tuck in under the fold in my ear but honestly can't tell you it makes them any more secure. They fit fine and don't fall out.They seem to work for at least three hours or so and take a few hours to recharge. Overall I very happy with these.I received a pair of these headphones in exchange for an honest review.

I received these as a review sample free of charge in exchange for an honest review.I tried them for a week or so and don't use them. While the sound is fine, I found them inconvenient to use and they felt "unfinished" from a design perspective.The good:- The sound was fine. Nothing wonderful, but good enough for listening while moving around.- The earbuds were comfortable.- The charge lasts several hours.The not so good:- The wires are a bit short. If I move around actively, the part on my shoulders rotates enough to pull on the earbuds even when they are pulled out their maximum amount.- The controls are not intuitive. Volume up/down and next/prior track are easy to confuse. I can't quickly find on/off without looking. The controls are somewhat symmetric, so buttons on the left mimic those on the right and you have to remember which is where.- The voices change. Some of the prompts (headphones on, ready to pair, etc.) are in "unaccented" English, others are strongly accented. Still understandable and fine, but it would give a better use experience if it was all in one voice.- The writing molded into the headphones (e.g. on/off, +/-) isn't crisp. Legible, but not a sign of quality.

These are very good replacement bulbs for some track lighting I have in the kitchen. However we are not using them, so I can't give them a great endorsement.1) The bulbs were much bluer than we anticipated. Others talks about the color being off and that may very well be the case. Perhaps if I had gotten the 2700K bulbs it would have been better.2) Our track lighting fixtures have a glass back that gives a warm glow from some light leakage from the traditional bulbs. These LED bulbs have no such leakage (perhaps good in many cases) so they appear dull from the back. There are two pictures included with this review. In the first the fixture (in the foreground) is shown from the back and is on even though it looks off. The second picture is at a very short exposure so the room looks dark but this is done so that lights are not over-exposed. The light on the left is the traditional bulb; that on the right the LED bulb. Note how the traditional bulb is all aglow. This looks nicer overall and provides some light on the ceiling around the fixture (the third picture has a slightly longer exposure; note the light on the ceiling). The LED bulb is just the disk and the contrast between the disk and the darkness behind it makes it a bit glaring.3) These bulbs are a little bit longer than the bulbs they replaced, perhaps 2 or 3 mm. Ours have a screw-on ring and you might be able to see in the first picture that it doesn't quite go on all the way.I may try the 2700K bulb, but am reluctant because, even though the color might be right, the fixture might not look as warm and attractive.I received two bulbs in exchange for an honest review.

These are polyester pants that live up to the reputation of polyester pants. They look shiny, are very thin and do little to keep the cold out, and drape poorly. When you walk your legs sort of show through (shapewise) as the fabric has no stiffness.I'm never going to wear these after having my wife laugh after trying them on. They would be fine if I was a waiter or a young person in band or another school event, but these are not something most folks would find nice.

Great model for a child or Star Wars enthusiast. This is easy enough to put together (15 to 30 minutes) and is solid enough to withstand being played with. It is prepainted so no disappointment from smeared paint or foggy windshields. My nine year old was able to put it together easily and it is a great size to play with and pretend it is flying about.The only thing I can add to the other reviews is that my son was initially disappointed that it wasn't a Lego kit. The box graphic is similar in style to Lego (although clearly it isn't) and his initial impression was it was Lego caused some disappointment. Once he figured out what it was, that he could put it together, and that it had sounds and actually was a bit more realistic without all the bumpy Lego artifacts, he was quite happy.

Dot is cute and for a robot that doesnt move, shes got quite the personality. (To me, the voice and name sound feminine, but technically Dot is ungendered.) The software and hardware are generally well done, however there are some sticking points that make it less than ideal.If you have the money, go for Dash over Dot. I think Dash can do everything Dot can do  and also move. But Dot is surprisingly fun on her own.The good:1) Dot looks kind of cool with the lights in the eye and ears.2) The software clearly has a lot of thought put into it. It is graphically great for kids to look at.3) There are many options for sounds, lights, and links. Robot will respond to sound, voice, tilting, and button presses. Random elements are also included. You can even record your own sounds and use that.4) There is a great deal of thought going into the training exercises. I think there are still some bugs/improvements to be made, but it is generally good.5) My daughter found it to be cute and engaging.The bad:1) No volume control. Just one loud volume. Forget about a kid playing when the other is trying to sleep or you are trying to drive. It would be nice if both sound and light intensity were adjustable.2) The training exercises are a bit rushed.a. Almost immediately after completing a training program you get You finished this step! Ready for the next one? (You can only select a check mark which takes you to the next.) What if I want to run that step again to see what happened? This is especially frustrating with the tilting exercises. You tilt Dot to make something happen and on to the next step. You cant tilt again to repeat, which you naturally want to do to verify something is working or to see how much you have to tilt for Dot to register it.b. When you complete a step you dont get a chance to practice it for the reason above. My son wanted to change the Disco Ball light order in an intermediate step but couldnt. This was an opportunity for him to reinforce what he just learned rather than just mimicking the prompt, and it isnt allowed. You can do so when the whole exercise is completed. If you do, youll end up at the front panel and find your place again.3) The language in some places can be a bit obtuse. When you link behaviors together, theyre called states. And the cool pictures we make with states and links are called state machines. Do we really need to know this? Does this help my 9 year old in any way? It is never mentioned again.4) The software really only works if you have one child playing with it (or if you have three devices with the software). I have three who might use it, but only one iPad. After the first child went through the learning exercises, the lessons were marked as completed. Subsequent kids didnt get the same training. They could go back manually, but that wasnt the same. Similarly all the tracking of projects and unlocking of new levels is done for everyone if one kid does it. I cant even find a way to reset things except for deleting and installing the software.5) Dot can be a bit sassy. There are some expressions kids cling on to and parents hate hearing. Dot does some of those. For example Im gonna go with, no6) Abilities are locked down until you achieve something through Scroll Quest. The advanced learner cant just unlock everything and go for it. One child went through it. I reinstalled so the other child could go through it, but they didnt finish, so they first had to go through everything again just so he could access the options at the level he was originally at.Also:1) Im not sure who Eli is (Dots name or someone else) but s/he shows up in the text of the software from time to time. It would be nice to be able to name my Dot.2) To be clear, although it is round, Dot does not move.3) My son was not as impressed as my daughter. He likes things that move (cars/tanks) so the voice and lights didnt do much for him. He was done with it pretty soon. Hed likely like Dash.

The box says "The Right Quality and Size for Business" and this is geared towards a small business.I can't help but compare this Georgia-Pacific product to what we've been using at home for a long time now:Scott Extra Soft Double Roll Tissue, 9 Count (Pack of 4). The price fluctuates, but what we use now soft and strong enough and typically very affordable. The Georgia-Pacific product is meant for businesses which have somewhat different requirements, but is great for home use too.The Georgia Pacific is full height roll, being a full 4.5 inches wide (more than a  inch wider than the Scott). It looks good on the dispenser (Scott looks skimpy) and provides better hand coverage. The cardboard core seems a bit stronger as well which might make a difference in a dispenser where they are stacked horizontally. Although it is 2-ply, it doesn't feel softer or stronger than the 1-ply Scott.Individual rolls are wrapped in tissue paper and attractive enough to leave an extra roll or two in a bathroom. Both claim to be a double roll but the Georgia-Pacific is 400 sheets per roll vs 264, so the Georgia-Pacific will last 50% longer per roll (assuming everyone uses the same number of sheets. Both have sheets that are 4 inches long), so fewer roll changes.Overall the Georgia Pacific seems well made and a solid choice and may have some advantages that make the slightly higher price worthwhile, especially for small businesses.

This is a fairly large air purifier unit rated for a room that is around 200 square feet. If the room were square, that would be a room 14 to 15 feet on each side. So a decent sized room but not a very large one. I never believed the smaller units did much so I'm a bit gratified that their room size to purifier filter/flow ratio is more reasonable. My son, who suffers from allergies (we have cats and dogs) often has trouble sleeping which wakes him up early. He seems to be sleeping longer with this unit on, so we are hopeful.This comes with the allergy filter, which includes a dust filter, HEPA, and activated charcoal filter. It is thick and feels solid and takes up much of the area of the device, so that is what determined the size. The unit is large but not overwhelming and it is good looking so we are fine with it in his bedroom. It would look just fine in a living area as well. Setting it up was easy.It is also very quiet. There are five fan speeds and one can hear level levels 2 and above, but only 4 and 5 might be distracting in a quiet room. It is white noise, though, so typically not a big deal. On automatic the unit typically stays on level 1 and I have to make sure it is working by feeling the flow coming out of the back.My main concerns are:1. It reads the air quality but it shows the highest rating. Once it showed one red segment, but that was only briefly. I'd be more confident if it showed some more obvious improvement. I have no reason to believe the air in my home is particularly good, although we do use expensive air filters on our forced air system.2. It runs on the lowest fan speed or is off when in auto mode. I suppose because it senses the air is good, but I'd like to see it working more. It makes sense to not be on if the air is good, but then what's it doing?3. They don't tell you how to use it. I know how it works (sleep, auto, timer, etc.) but why not just leave it in auto mode all the time? I understand sleep makes it quiet, but is it different than having it on at the lowest fan setting? And why would I want it on a timer so it comes on before I get home from work? Or why have it shut off after a given number of hours? Is there some reason I don't want it running all the time? I understand the filter likely wears out with run time, but if it's cleaned the air too early, it shouldn't wear the filter much. I put it in Auto and am just leaving it on unless I can figure out otherwise.4. The filters are expensive, but at $100 aren't that unreasonable. Given we pay $5 for a Miele vacuum bag and $10 for a filter for our air system, it isn't outrageous if only changed once a season. I have no indication on how long it will last, but it would be reasonable if it lasted three or four months.5. (small issue). I wish there was a pocket or place for the remote on the device. It's not like you change it often, like you do a TV. Can't they have a pocket on the back? Or even some place on front that it would slide in and act like a control panel. It's just sitting on top, looking funny on an otherwise attractive unit. Like the too many remotes in our lives (we even have one for the lights in our pumpkins!), it is hard to find a place we'll remember it isn't used often and where the kids will put them back or leave them alone.Aside from the "how to operate" quirks, this is a well designed units that, at least initially, seems effective. I am an engineer and it seems to me that they've made all the right design choices. If any air filter is going to work, this one should.
These are very good, do what they say. Just couldn't say "I love them" since nothing particularly stands out. But these are absorbent and competent towels in a nice size for the kitchen.

These Khaki's fit as I expected, so I believe they are true to size. The New British Khaki color is slightly darker/richer in person than in the picture which I am happy about. They are comfortable and good looking although I do not notice a difference from the 2% Elastane material. The fabric does not feel stretch at all to the touch. Very straight legs (Slim Tapered) so there isn't a great deal of room if you don't fit the bill.A metal zipper and riveted button make these seem durable and overall they seem well made. These are five pocket pants, the fifth being a coin pocket on the right side. The back pockets are without buttons (great!) and are reinforced to hold their shape.There are a few touches keeping them a bit informal. There is orange in the center of the front rivet and in the logo on the back.

This has worked very well for my family. Even with a power strip it was difficult to fit in all the micro USB and Lightning connectors to charge our devices (tablets, phones, Bluetooth headphones, fitness devices). The size of the AC adapters are such that you'd block more than one power socket with a single charger.This lets you plug in one thing and get 5 USB outputs. In one I put a cable for charging my iPad, in two others I put in micro USB chargers for my headphones and phone. That leaves a few for the kids to use when needed.Using the old adaptor I was using, if I was viewing a movie on my iPad and the battery would run low, plugging in to the standard adapter would slow down the discharge but wouldn't stop it if I continued to watch the movie. I'd have to stop watching and put the iPad to sleep to get it to charge. With this unit my iPad actually charges a little (very little!) but allows me to watch the rest of the movie at least without worrying about it eventually shutting down.Phones and other things are such low power that I don't notice any difference in power.This works great and is convenient. The only thing I recommend is to get some short cables to reduce the rat's nest of cables coming out. You don't need a 3'/6' cable. Get some 4 inch or 6 inch cables to make it a little neater. I wish they gave us a few cables instead of the USB light, but the light is kind of nice.I received this unit at no cost in exchange for an honest review.

We are fans of Annie's mac and cheese products. When shopping at a conventional store, my 9 yo wouldn't let me buy what he called the "cheap stuff". I asked what he wanted and it was Annie's that he pulled off the shelf. We had tried Kraft out of nostalgia and he was having no more of that.Annie's typically has a better flavor and this is no different. I can't say I noticed the "butter", but it is in the ingredients. Whey is still very near the top, so it is still the dominant flavor.Shapes such as these can be harder to cook as they remain hard at the intersection. I typically take them out early. These suffer less from that because of the generally open profile of the shape. The kids like the shape, but no big deal.It is a 6 ounce box, which is typical for Annie's organic versions but less than the store brands.Many prepare this differently than stated on the directions. My take:While the pasta is boiling, I heat the milk and butter in a small sauce pan. I'll mix in the cheese mixture and make a smooth mixture, sometimes a little on the runny side. I take the pasta off when it is still firm, drain completely, and then add the cheese sauce. In a few minutes (burner off) the pasta will absorb some of the cheese sauce water, making it thick and finishing the cooking of the pasta. This avoids the clumpiness of mixing the cheese right in and also allows me to add other things as the mood hits me. It does have more clean up.

We have some Calphalon pots and pans that are a decade or so old, stainless steel inside and out. Over the years they accumulated a brown varnish from cooking oil spills/splatters and dark black spots from who knows what. This pad did a great job of removing the varnish inside and out and, with some elbow grease, also removed the thicker black spots. It took some effort to remove the blackened bits, but they came off in the end. The pots look very good, with no scratches. These are cladded on the bottom with aluminum and the bottom (which touches the burner) has blackened over the years. These pads can remove some of that but it seemed like it would take a long time and wear out the pad to remove it all. I'm happy with the upper portion looking great and the very bottom having the blackened surface. I imagine if I wanted to get rid of the black on the bottom, I'd have to use something more abrasive; these pads won't do that.After two pots (a medium sized saucepan and a 12" fry pan) the pad looks to be in great shape and should be ready to go for several more, which I plan to do as we use them.The pad has a very slim plastic coating on one side. One reviewer said it has tiny diamonds embedded in it, which I believe could be the case. It is a very fine scrubbing action and you feel resistance, but not scratching. It is best done wet and with some soap (as per the directions.)The direction also indicate that this isn't for food residue and such. Cleaning a greasy pot will clog the pad, so do that with something else. Then use this pad for one final pass to remove any varnish or burned-on material.

As others have posted, this is two dice and five cards to add complexity/randomness to Fluxx.I would recommend this to folks who are:- Experienced players looking to breath life into a game they may be becoming less keen on- Folks who are "expert" players and understand the rules comfortably- Want less strategy and more randomnessI would not recommend these for:- New players- Games with people of mixed experience- People who wish to keep some strategy in the game.In my opinion, strategy is already a small part of Fluxx. You can choose your keepers and change the goal accordingly, but the randomness of the rules changing will often make strategy not pay off. Throw in the dice and it becomes even more unlikely your strategy will pay off. So why play at all if it is just random? Some of us like random (e.g. solitaire is mostly over when the cards are initially dealt) and just want a way to interact and relax. These dice don't seem to work for strategy fans.Newer/younger players are already confused by the rules changing and the game dynamics (rules apply instantaneously...!) and adding this element just makes it seem even more chaotic.It's nice to have, a bit pricy for what it is, but not for everyone.

I printed these on my inkjet printer (back paper feed) for labeling holiday bins. They turned out very nicely in the end but it was a bit more work. There are the logistical issues of getting the in the right orientation in the printer and then folding on the laminate cover. Also (and this may sound petty) you have to do 10 at once. So you can't just go from bin to bin as you would with a label maker; you have to have 10 set to go. And if you make a mistake, you can't just redo one. But they look great and work very well.The good:- Excellent looking results- Printing labels allows variety of text, images, etc.- Appear durableThe not so good:- Expensive, about 40 cents a label- You have to do 10 labels at once (5 sheets of 10 labels). What if you just want one?- You have to feed the paper the right way in your printer (both side and top/bottom orientation)- You have to be sure your printer isn't scaling or other printing issuesOther- Alignment and application of the clear laminate is straightforward, but a bit nerve wracking as it is all or nothing and an expensive mistake.

My nine year old put this together with some occasional help from me. He enjoyed it but couldn't get everything done himself. in the end the project kind-of worked. Perhaps with a bit more time and patience we can get the plane to fly. The air car and other items work better.This kit has thin square wooden sticks, plastic connectors, and specialized parts that are assembled into a variety of propeller driven racers. The wood on the sticks seemed very high quality; smooth, stiff and dense. It was sometimes difficult to slide the wood into some of the plastic bits for young hands but I was able to do it just fine. The directions can be unclear at times (e.g. which of the three holes in the wing spars does the stick go through?)That said, my nine year old likes it. This was almost three stars because of the directions and this might be difficult for those who aren't "handy." But this is a fairly nice kit (better than many of the consumer-grade science kits) and if you are looking for an hour or two of distraction for your young builder, it might be worth while.

As advertised, this is a fun light for bars/parties/informal fun settings. My son likes it in his room and will go to sleep under a different color. The remote is handy and you can have fun with it playing tricks on friends who don't know much about the light (we had someone believing the light responded to their voice.)It is just for fun, though. The colors are not very pleasant otherwise. The white is a bit harsh and none of the colors are particularly warm or comforting.The remote works well; it dims three levels and can be brightened three levels. There are four mode buttons, but really only two modes. Both Flash and Strobe go from one color to the next abruptly. One setting is just slightly faster than the other. Both Fade and Smooth transition smoothly from one color to the next, just at slightly different speeds.If you turn the bulb on and off with the wall/lamp switch, it comes on in strobe mode, which is frustrating. I wish it remembered its last mode so I wouldn't have to look for the remote. I suppose they want you to leave the wall/lamp switch ON and just use the remote for on/off, which is what we are doing. But sometimes we forget.The metal around the bulb is a little sharp. No cuts yet but it feels like it could cut if grabbed strongly. It isn't great for a table lamp.The light is primarily directed upward but it works OK with a shade to diffuse it more broadly.It is a fun and inexpensive party light.Disclosure: A free sample was provide in exchange for an honest review.

This is an excellent water bottle for those of us who appreciate glass containers (no BPA, no scratches/bacteria growth, etc.) Of course the lid is plastic, so there is still a bit of plastic to deal with. The bottom and sides are also plastic barriers for protecting the bottle but they do not come in contact with the bottle contents.It doesn't leak and the lid is heal securely in place.Why is it four stars?:There is a gap between the plastic outside barrier and the glass bottle inside, so it hold less than other bottles of its size. Just under two cups by our measure. This gap is to protect the glass, but it feels bigger than needed and maybe could be smaller if the plastic was a little thicker.It is a bit hard to clean. You can put it in the dishwasher but you have to take it apart. They recommend removing the silicon seals, which isn't trivial. They are in recesses of the plastic, so you need to pry them out and I worry about cutting them. One seal is near the top between the bottle and the outer shell and is a bit hard to take off too. Once you have it apart, the lid, bottom, outer shell, and glass can go in the dishwasher (we used the top rack). The glass is thin so doesn't fill well in our rack. We have to support it with plastic cups and containers or else it falls over. As a result we just rinse it out by hand every day and dishwash just once in a while. I don't know if that defeats the purpose of having glass in the first place.A minor issue is that cap has a little slide to lock the cap closed and it isn't clear what position it should be in to unlock it. The lid is a bit stiff so you aren't sure. If you look closely there is a lock and an unlocked lock on the switch. If you see the locked lock, it means it is unlocked (so slide it over the locked lock to lock it) and visa versa.Disclosure: I received this as a free sample in exchange for an honest review.

Definitely a winter shirt, but fits well and looks good. It is a "Large", which I ordered based on my wearing large T-shirts; so it was just a guess but it worked out well.It is a casual button-down with two buttoned pockets.The material is thick and it feels, and looks, substantial. The collar is lined with a light-colored and soft material, adding to the casual look. The rest of the shirt is not.I am looking forward to it getting cooler so I can wear this more regularly.

These are the headphones I wear all the time now for listening to podcasts, movies, and music while doing chores. These aren't great for serious music listening, but their benefits far outweigh any downsides.The good:- They sound very good. Not audiophile quality, but good mid-tones and voice. Not particularly strong in bass or vivid treble.- Works very well with my Windows Phone and my iPad. The volume controls, next/previous tract, and pause work great. Holding the Vtin button in for a longer time activates Cortana and/or Siri so I can issue voice commands. Incoming texts are read to me via Cortana and calls are received and managed as expected.- Paired quickly and easily.- Last a long time, at least four hours. I've yet to run them down.- I'm not sure if these have active noise canceling, but these are very good at excluding outside noise. When chopping wood they serve as very good ear protection.- They fit snuggly in my ears and won't come out when the ear hooks are put in properly.The bad:- These can hurt when not adjusted properly. The ear hooks have to be in a very specific orientation for me to not hurt. It took a while to find the right spot. I put the ear hooks in the right place and held them tightly while I rotated the headphone so it slipped relative to the earhooks until it was in the correct place.- I am using the smallest ear hook even though I am an average sized man. I am OK with them but I think a small-eared person might have a hard time making these fit well. I did use them without the ear hooks and they still work well, just not as snug.- The cord is a bit stiff and if you tap it or rub it, some of that noise goes into the headphones.- The USB jack cover is a bit hard to get off.Just FYI:- The volume up/down buttons are also used for prior/next track. This takes some getting used to as you have to hold the button down and wait for a short silence before letting go. You get used to it, but might still change the volume accidently.- The Vtin button serves pentuple duty: headphones on, headphones off, start/stop, pairing, and instigating Cortana/Siri.+ Pairing is only occasional, but if you start from off and hold the button down (it will say power on, but keep holding)  it will pair. You can't just hold it down when they are on, you have to start with it off.+ To turn on, let go when it says power on.+ To turn off, hold it down for a long time until it says off.+ To start Cortana/Siri, you hold it down while on but let go before it goes off. How long is that? Until you hear the beep. Let go right away or you'll turn them off.+ Start/stop is a quick press.These headphones were provided to me for free in exchange for an unbiased review.

I've used these for a few weeks now and find them to be very good strainers. They've been through the dishwasher several times but no rust yet (although dishwashers are a bad idea since strainers tend to catch food going through it, so only as a last resort.) So a very good deal.I almost picked 4 stars because they aren't luxurious. The handles are open on the bottom (a slot running along the middle, saving material and allowing the plastic to cool appropriately during manufacturing I presume), so not the most "comfortable", but they aren't uncomfortable. Just an indication they aren't top of the line. But they don't pretend to be nor do they charge for them as if they were, so I have no issues and would recommend.These were provided to me free of charge for my impartial review. No restrictions were made on my review nor did I receive any other compensation.

Works like a charm!I had two WD 1TB black drives lying around and this was a good deal. The WD drives were on the compatibility list so I bought the unit and set it up. Within an hour it was up and running on my network without problems. I am just using it for NAS so no cloud or stuff, although the DLNA seems to just work. I copied our pictures and movies to the appropriate shares and they are indexed and available via any DLNA device (such as a TV or a phone with the right app.)It wasn't terribly clear which software to download and how to run it. The program is a tiny shell that hooks into a browser-based control system. I just open the app, click on the settings, sign in with my admin password and do everything via the web interface. I don't really see much value to the program itself.If you know a bit about computers and shares, you'll manage just fine. If this is alien to you, it might take some time. It was easy but not plug-and-play or leading you by the hand.I set up a share for a family member and gave them their own read/write password. Set up file history on their windows 8.1 PC to point to that share (using the share id/password which is different than their logon) and its been working great. Every time I've check they've been fully backed up.I am a big windows fan but find it frustrating when dealing with network drives when they ask for credentials. They assume you are on a domain with the name of you pc (you'll see that near the bottom of the sign-in box.) Instead of signing in with username and password (which is interpreted as thisPC/username and password) you have to type //IX2-2/username and password (or maybe one slash at the beginning?) so it know to verify it on the NAS and not your PC.I intend to by a UPS for it so that it will spin down gracefully in the event of a power failure. I am using it in a mirrored RAID configuration but no files exist only on the NAS. Primarily sharing media and backing up computers to it.

I had these refrigerated for flavor (they don't have to be) but smoothies are typically cold in my house. Twist the top off and there is a small (3/8"?) hole through which you enjoy the smoothie. It turns out well to suck and squeeze the container and you get almost all of the smoothie out easily with no mess or fuss.This is strawberry-banana, which is a common flavor for our household (we have kids). But it tasted a bit too "enhanced", perhaps from the added sugar and whey protein isolate.  Also there was a texture to it that was unexpected; I am thinking that is from the added soluble fiber.Overall I thought these were fine but not something I look forward to having. Their nutritional value makes me feel good about having them and they are fine for an occasional grab and go situation (running late, not wanting to go out for lunch.)

These were very good. I liked them because of their crunchy peanut butter flavor. It reminded me of peanut butter cereal (Captain Crunch or Bumpers), although a bit more oily. It was the oily coating that felt a bit odd, a little like the white coating on some inexpensive white coated pretzels. Regardless of how healthy they actually are, the oily texture and sweet taste made me feel there were likely more healthy alternative. I enjoy them but perhaps once in a while. If I need a healthy treat, I'll find something a bit less processed.

Four stars because "I like it". The pasta was very good tasting and had a good texture. Close enough to regular Barilla that it's not worth trying to discern a difference.I followed the directions (3/4 cup water in saucepan for 10 minutes) and the pasta was done in about 8 minutes when there was still water left. So I drained it in a colander as I do with regular pasta an it was fine. This obviated any advantage this provides as far as cleanup. It also made me think the second step of cooking it with added sauce would have made it too soft. You add salt while cooking but they give no idea how much. I add salt to water boiled for pasta, but since most is drained away, I can just guess the amount. For this it all stays with the pasta so you have to get it right. So you'll have to make this a few times to learn the amount of water, the time, and the amount of salt that works best. It was a bit faster to cook (still about 10 minutes, but you don't have to wait for a larger pot of water to boil first.)This was fine and perhaps a good plus for those in a hurry and trying to make one-pan meals (mine was chicken and Tuscan spices with olive oil). However boiling regular pasta may be cheaper (I'm not taking into account to cost of boiling six or eight cups of water instead of 3) and feels less finicky. This 12 oz box isn't enough for my family of 4 and 2 boxes would be too much.Very good pasta and likely worth getting to learn to make if time and convenience is your priority.

We normally use Finish Powerball Tabs Dishwasher Detergent Tablets and decided to try these to see if they were worth the extra money. We didn't notice any obvious difference in our plates and glass during normal use. Maybe there was some slight improvement upon closer inspection, but nothing that we'd pay extra for.Over the Powerball Tabs we use, these Quantum Max Powerballs claim they prevent redeposits, protect glass, and increase shine/sparkle. We use ceramic plates, clear glasses (but not wine glasses), and stainless tableware and we didn't notice a difference. Perhaps if we had wine glasses it would be more important. We are a bit wary about how they increase sparkle and shine; are they leaving something on our glasses/plates?We did appreciate that this is packaged very compactly, saving space under the sink. Also the tabs are completely dissolvable. The Powerball Tabs we normally use are wrapped in mylar we have to tear open. The tablets inside feel a bit drying on the hand so they aren't pleasant to handle. These tabs we just pop in the dishwasher compartment and we don't feel we need to wash our hands afterwards.The extra costs of these isn't that much and we would consider getting these again.

I was given this product free of charge in exchange for an honest review. There was no payment or expectation that the review would have a certain rating.My car only has Bluetooth for the phone, which uses the car's directory system and such, which is inferior to using my phone directly. Additionally my car didn't support audio, which prevented me from listening podcasts from the phone. I purchased a  Kinivo BTC450 Bluetooth Hands-Free Car Kit for Cars with Aux Input Jack (3.5 mm). It worked great that I was going to order another for my wife's car, but lucked into this review model. It works just as well, with small differences here and there.I plugged the USB adapter into my power port (aka cigarette lighter outlet), the headphone-type plug into my Radio's Aux jack, and turned on the radio to Aux. Pressing an holding the button initiated the pairing which went very well. After that my phone pairs automatically when I turn on the car. A press of the button/knob starts my podcasts where I left off. Turn the knob clockwise and it advanced by 30 seconds, counter clockwise and it goes back 10 seconds. Press the button to pause, press again to resume. Press and hold to engage Cortana via voice, which allows me to make phone calls, start music, send texts, and do other things hands free. When I receive a call I press the big button to answer and again to hang up. It is very simple and effective and just simply works. With music turning the knob goes to the next song or to the beginning of the current one or back one song.This works virtually identically to the Kinivo with the following features I noticed:Compared to the Kinivo:- power is through a USB plug, so any USB adapter will work. You could even use this in your home office by plugging it into a USB adaptor and the audio through some computer speakers. The Kinivo is terminated with a car power plug, so it is car only.Rotating the knob back and forth is easy and intuitive. The Kinivo has small buttons which are a little hard to press (but fine, so not really an issue.)The Parateck audio jack comes straight out, like a headphone jack. If your Aux jack is on your radio face, the cable will stick out a about an inch. The Kinivo is right-angled, so it keeps it neater when plugging directly into the radio, sticking out only a quarter inch or so.The USB adapter is separate on the Parateck and one is provided, but it is long and sticks out the port by about an inch. Then the USB plug sticks out a little in addition to this. This may or may not be an issue depending on your port location. The Parateck takes one of the two ports, leaving one free for phone charging. The Kinivo power plug is more compact and, with no USB to plug in, is overall much less prominent. It has a free USB port as well. You could always use your own USB adaptor.The Parateck is black, slightly smaller in diameter, but somewhat thicker so it is easier to grip. It has a little chrome accent so is a bit more visible than the matt gray Kinivo. The Kinivo is almost invisible on my gray dash (which I like.)My wife says my voice sounds slightly more tinny when using the Parateck.To mount the parateck you mount a small plate to your dash with double-sided tape. The Parateck then attaches to that magnetically. This makes it easily removable. The Kinivo mounts directly with double sided tape which meant I had to rip it off when I used it in my rental car, then clean up the tape residue, and reinstall when I got home. If you are going to move the device around, the Parateck might be a better deal. I don't know if they sell extra plates; that would be a nice plus.They both work great so your choice may be a matter of what feature set works for you. The Parateck is likely more friendly for those of us with "fat fingers" and don't have an issue with the aux and power jacks sticking out (perhaps it in the glove box or on the console.) The Kinivo is lower profile for the device, jack, and power, so nicer if you want it to disappear more (you still have the wires.) Having a slightly better microphone is a plus too.

This is a colorful "graphic novel" with a complicated/crazy plot revolving around violate and her mom and dad and their adventures in space as they look for a new school for violate.There are plenty of reviews detailing the plot and more of the book. I write this review just to say my two sons are still looking through this book two weeks after we received it; often just before bed or when hanging out in the afternoon. They say the like this book a great deal. Anything that gets them reading it great as far as I am concerned.There are a few "sassy" scenes and a "what the fudge" here and there, but that is par for the course with kids books. Overall I'd recommend this.

I used to use witch hazel from the discount drug store all the time for a refreshing feel and astringency. When I was offered this I thought it might be nice to see what a top-notch version felt like. It does feel very good but I can't say that it is so much better than the other, less expensive, brands that it is worth the extra price. The rose water is fairly strong too, for good or for bad; you'll be smelling roses for a while after you put it on.This is a fairly expensive bottle for a fairly high price. That means you dab it on with a cotton swab. Part of what was refreshing about the conventional brands is that they are inexpensive enough to use liberally and even it use it on legs/backs/arms without worrying cost.I like it (definition of 4 stars) but I don't love it because I have to be careful with the amount I use and because I smell roses too long after application.

In this thick book (277 pages) you'll find hundreds of times when you are struck by Truth.  I didn't find it a book intended to be read quickly - there isn't a plot you want to get to the end of - but I did underline several passages on nearly every page that are worthy of deeper pondering.  This is a book meant to be studied and reflected upon.  I am not from a military lifestyle but I found the wisdom in these pages universal.  Greitens is well-educated in the great philosophers and writers of long ago and he pulls from their eternal wisdom in his advice for cultivating resilience.The only possible negative is that the writing is disjointed.  As this is a collection of letters the author wrote to a friend in need, subjects jump around and get repeated.  In truth I think this preserves the rawness of the writing and so I prefer it this way.  Each paragraph or two can be read separately and used as a subject to think about during the course of the day.I strongly recommend this book to everyone who is interested in examining their life to make it richer and more meaningful.

We've been using Frontline Plus for quite a while and decided to give this a try. It went on easily and, so far, we see no difference. It is hard to tell as it is winter and fleas are not typically a problem this time of year.We have two cats and are going to continue using Frontline Plus on one and Sentry on the other. They use the same formula in the same percentages so we don't expect any difference, but we'll let you know if we see any.If it continues to work well, it will be a great value.

I use these in a high school shop where band saws, drill presses, and chop saws are used to cut wood and aluminum and these attenuate the sound sufficiently that I don't worry about hearing loss. I supervise students and so appreciate being more aware of what is going on than if I use the in-ear or over-the-ear protection. I am average sized and these fit well, though I imagine they could be too large for some.

This sweet old book is worth trying to find.  I read it through interlibrary loan as it was too expensive to buy.  It isn't a must-read book, but it is a pleasant read and shows the life in early New Netherlands by following a newly arrived family throughout their daily routine over the course of about a year.  It is divided into ~5 chapters but is easily read in one or two readings.  My boys are in third grade and they enjoyed the book.

This is an incredible book, much more informative and touching that I expected.  It tells of the Puritan Anne Hutchinson and her family's journey to America and settlement at the Massachusetts Bay Colony.  Anne was a minister's daughter and had strong personal religious views that were not the same as the colony's.  When she began to give religious talks at her house she was punished and eventually banished.  The book focuses on Anne's youngest daughter and 11th child, and in the afterward it becomes clear why.  Anne is portrayed as an incredible woman, strong and gentle in spirit, deeply spiritual and a dedicated mother.  I'll admit I cried when I read the afterward.  My 3rd grade boys were riveted.

A beautiful and simple story of William, who wanted to build a house in the New World like the one he grew up in in England.  At first he makes a great English house but as the differences between England and America become apparent (warmer, windier, more snow...) he had to make changes to the house to fit the climate.  In the end a cousin from England arrives and asks 'What kind of a house is this?'  All is well as you see in the last drawing that the cousin is  building a 'New World house' next to William's.Side images in pen and ink show sweet images of William's two children as they are exploring their new environment.My sons are 9yo and while this book is probably written for children younger, it still has value for them as we discussed the changes William made  to his house and why.

The beauty of this book is in its woodblock illustrations, which are represented as carvings done by the boy whose journal we are reading in the text.  The story follows a year or so in the life of an indentured servant (based on a real child named Christopher Sears) whose ship was originally headed to Jamestown but was wrecked and the passengers were taken to Plimouth instead where they had to earn their keep.  When a year has passed and a ship is available to take the Sparrowhawk's passengers to Jamestown, Christopher wants to remain in Plimouth.  The question is, will he be allowed?  I read it in two evenings as a bedtime story to my 9yo sons.

My 8- and 9-year old sons and I really enjoyed this biography of William Bradford.  I highly recommend it.  There are 14 chapters and we read two to three each night at bedtime.  This book tells of William's tumultuous childhood, the struggles he went through to get an education and to go to the church of his choice, and his meeting and connection to the Brewsters which ultimately lead him to America.  The last three chapters explain the trials to get to Holland, travel on the Mayflower and ends around the time of the 'first Thanksgiving'. Though I read the book aloud to my sons, I would say the book is simple enough for a 3rd grader to read to himself.  William suffered many losses in his life but the hardship seemed to strengthened William's character made him the great, compassionate leader he became.

I installed this on my Nissan Leaf and installation was as easy as with any wiper; just slide it on the "U" at the end of the wiper arm until it clicks. It hugs the windshield well and does a nice clean wipe of the wet windshield, as would be expected for new blades, and they seem to behave well at my commuting speeds (about 45-65 MPH.)The look very much like the same design as those that came with my Leaf in that they have a segmented backbone design. The cheaper blades come without a cover and you can see the metal and wire bits pretty clearly. The segmented blade design on those does a decent job of spreading the pressure out evenly on the wiper blade so it is in better contact with the window. I believe the cover on the "better" blades provide aerodynamic stability at speed and keeps out leaves, ice, and other debris. The covered blades I've used in the past (Michelin, I believe) had a one-piece backbone that provided the springiness and protection. Sometimes these could be too stiff, meaning that on a relatively flat portion of the windshield there would be more pressure on the ends than in the middle and you could get streaking in the middle of the blade.These blades are a combination of both. The backbone does not provide very much springiness to the wiper. That is done with the softer metal inside. The outer part is in four pieces that are hinged together but without and springiness. So it works well on the windshield while also offering the aerodynamics and protection.I've only had these on for a short time but my expectation on blades is that they last about a year (I replace them prior to my annual inspection and am disappointed if I have to replace sooner). If these perform any differently I will update this review.

We got this product simply for enjoyment; no one in the family has medical issues we were intending to address.  Imagine my surprise when I found that it truly seemed to help my plantar fasciitis.  I had recently been told the pain I was having in my foot following a two-hour jump at a trampoline house with my children was plantar fasciitis and was trying to remedy it with stretches, rolling and an insert for my shoes.  It was slowly improving but still bothered me.  Amazingly I have had almost no pain in my foot following my first 30 minute session with this machine.  Maybe it was coincidence but I'm crediting this machine!The level goes from 0 to 99.  Using the remote you increase one level at a time.  I don't feel anything until I set it to ~15.  From there to ~level 30 it feels tickly, sort of 'pins and needles' or like something is crawling on your foot.  Not sensations many folks try to recreate.  After level 30 you get the full muscle contraction coordination I think the machine is intended for.  The session has a varying schedule in which each minute has a different rhythm and intensity.  I like the change in sensations this creates.  I have had 30 minute sessions using level 44.  At this level it feels very different, though for me it is still pleasant.  The muscle contraction causes my big toe or foot to move uncontrollably (my toe raises and my foot points) during the higher intensity parts of the session and that feels really interesting.For this review I have just tried increasing the level to 60 and that's an entirely different experience - probably what I'm supposed to be doing all along, actually.  The machine definitely controls my muscles at this point and I wonder if my calves will feel sore or anything tomorrow.  It is not painful in the least right now; quite the contrary, it feels so interesting!  I think I'm going to do level 60 session from now on!I have not used the pads for other parts of my body nor have I used the 'Step' part of the machine (in fact I can't figure out what it is for or why someone would choose to do it).Two things I really don't like: the beep that accompanies each level increase with the remote and the fact that there isn't a pause button for when I get interrupted during a session.  It isn't hard to start over but I do have to listen to that annoying beep for each level I pass to start over.(And just as a side note, I sometimes do it wearing socks and it feels the same as barefoot.)

Accurate, compact, easy to use app.  App can keep a history of time and temperature, which is great.It would be nice if it also had an offline mode to take the temperature and display it, and then later sync it to the smartphone.  It only works with the smartphone present.

The dogs like this dog food.  High in meat based protein, low in fat, good ingredient list.  Those ingredients make it a healthy food.  If you can afford it this is a premium dogfood that is worth considering.  I'd also suggest looking at the dogfoodadvisor website to see a detailed breakdown on every ingredient.  Spoiler alert they gave the dogfood 5 stars as well.

Dogs love them (they got a little crazy).  They remind me of a Slim Jim meat stick.  Ingredients are healthier than a Slim Jim, can't complain about anything on that list.  Nice dog treat.  We break them in half as dogs aren't sure the most efficient way to eat them when they are long and slim.

It's got a nice 4 x 18650 battery pack, charger, and a bonus headlight strap. Everything is pretty basic.Pros:* Cree XML-2 led* 4 x 18650 battery pack* SmallCons:* Optics aren't even, really bright in the center and not so bright through the rest of the flood.* Headstrap is not very good (basically mounts a handlebar on the front of your head).* Description has a car charger, but none in package* Description has USB cable, but none in package* Claims of 2400 lumens out of a Cree XML-2 are rediculous on their face.  I'd estimate 800 lumens comparing to other lights.

I don't like typical kaki pants.  These are clearly jeans that are kakhi (aka "Chinchilla") colored, which is what I wanted.  It's a bit more of a casual look without looking sloppy compared to traditional kakhi pants.As far as fit waist and length are spot on.  They are straight leg with a bit of a taper, so people with thicker thighs might not fit them well.  But they aren't skinny jeans, they don't cling to my legs like that.  It's a nice classic look.The fabric is a bit softer than typical denim, but they are thick and cut just like normal jeans.  They are just for people who are tired of blue.

These are jeans.  They are a nice dark black so you can wear them in professional situations, I wore them with a polo and they looked good.  However, they don't replace a pair of black slacks for more formal business attire.  They are clearly jeans even if they are nice jeans.The fabric is a mostly polyester blend with some cotton.  It looks like normal denim but has a lot more stretch.  I wore these straight from work to rock climbing without changing.  I have done a ton of walking in a short time and think they are more comfortable for walking than typical jeans.  They don't have a gusseted crotch but are a bit thinner than normal cotton denim and have a lot more stretch, so you can totally move around however you need, they won't restrict you.The fit is slim fit.  They aren't skinny jeans, but they aren't loose either.  If you have thick legs you will likely find these too tight.  For me they were a perfect fit, they didn't have a lot of loose material but weren't clinging to me either.  They fit and size about like a Levi 514 if you have tried those jeans.As with most black keep in mind these will show dust (though they dusted off with a hand better than normal denim jeans) and you will get hot in the sun as they soak up those rays.Overall, I'm really happy with these, they have earned a spot in my closet and in my life.

There are a lot of water filters out there, this one is best for an extended base camp or a large group backpacking.  The two things that set it apart from other water filters are it's lifetime of 18,000 liters and that it filters out viruses without the use of chemicals.  Filtering out viruses is probably not needed for backcountry wilderness purposes, but is a really good idea if your water is coming from somewhere in or downstream of populated areas.It is a little big for most backpacking trips where the extended life and virus filtering aren't needed.  For that use case consider the Platypus or MSR (same filter), Katadyn, or the Sawyer.  All of those are smaller/lighter and also use a hollow filber filter but don't filter out viruses.  For larger groups or longer term use the LifeStraw Mission is your best bet.Platypus GravityWorks Filter System, 4-LiterMSR AutoFlow Gravity FilterKatadyn Gravity Camp, 6-LiterSawyer Products SP162 Two Bag Complete Water Filtration System, 2-Liters Each

Pros:* Flexible neck is easily adjusted and stays in place* Long battery life when not plugged in* Touch button senses finger capacitance, better than regular button or switchCons:* Round male plug on one end of USB instead of micro or mini usb plug, requires use of non-standard included cord for charging* Brightness only good enough for a book, keyboard, or other small surface not whole desk* No USB wall power, just USB cable included.* Shiny plastic is either sleek or looks cheap, I lean towards the latterNeutral but worth noting* Light is very white, many may prefer more of a yellow light than this provides* Base is lightweight, making the light move easily when bumped but the light weight is good if you travel with it

The screen is the same size and resolution and ratio as the iPad Mini 3.  It looks as good.  The thickness is the same.  Both the ipad mini 3 and the Asus ZenPad S come with similar configurations of ram and storage.  The intel proccessor in the Asus is quite fast, and the ipad isn't a slouch itself.  On specs alone it is a virtual tie.The choice between them will come down to price, service, and preference.  The Asus ZenPad S is cheaper, so that's a clear win.  Apple service is hard to beat.  iOS vs Android will be debated forever, personally I prefer Android but if you prefer iOS the iPad comes with that.Overall I'd take this Asus ZenPad S over the iPad mini 3.  It's cheaper and runs Android while being equivalent quality and specs.  Great little tablet.

When a leading consumer magazine (you know the one) did a sunscreen test all of their recommended sunscreens contained all 5 of the active ingredients Avobenzone, Homosalate, Octisalate, Octocrylene, and Oxybenzone and no other active ingredients.  Unfortunately they didn't test any stick sunscreens, but guess what the active ingredients list looks like for this stick:Avobenzone (3%), Homosalate (15%), Octisalate (5%), Octocrylene (10%), and Oxybenzone (3%)Based on that ingredient list in those concentrations there is an almost certain chance that this sunscreen would test well.  I also know that living in the hot sweaty south the stick style sunscreens tend to apply easier and in my experience last longer.If you are looking for a spray sunscreen that you don't have to rub in that also has these active ingredients, in fact it has the same proportions as this stick other than it also has more Oxybenzone, look at the Marathon Mist SPF50 6oz  I tend to use that spray for full body coverage and apply a stick to my face.

This review is for the 3 port hub with gigabit ethernet (HT-UE01).  I bought it so I'd have a wired ethernet option for my Macbook.  The Macbook didn't recognize the ethernet port out of the box, but after installing the drivers from the HooToo website the ethernet works very well.  For me the 3 port USB hub is just a throw in bonus.  As such the hub seems to work out of the box as well as any USB hub, namely most devices work fine and a few devices just really like to be plugged in directly and not go through a hub.Inside the Ethernet is driven by an ASIX AX88179 chip.  The manufacturer of that chip seems to have good driver support for Mac, Linux, and Windows.  You can see the same ethernet chip in the newer rounded Anker USB 3.0 to RJ45 Gigabit Ethernet Adapter, but that model is more expensive than this one and doesn't include a 3 port hub.

The Cree-XML is a bright and efficient LED.  The T-6 was a high binning version of that.  Now the XML-2 is out and about 20% brighter, but the original is still pretty sweet.  Putting it in a waterproof focusing flashlight and including a 26650 battery and charger make this a real value.  I like the flashlight a lot.  Compact, bright, focusing, etc.The focusing mechanism works very well once you zoom out just a bit.  All the way zoomed in it actually projects an image of the LED.  Just slightly wider it makes a nice square spot and as you go out the wider flood becomes more round.  The light is very even through 95% of the range.The 26650 works great and will give long lifetime.  The plastic sleeve allows you to use it with the narrower 186650 batteries if you already have some.  The included 3 AAA holder works, but is slightly narrower so it doesn't fit snugly, the flashlight is also slightly less bright with the AAA batteries and will last a lot less time.  Still, having the AAA as an option is good when traveling.It would be nice if the flashlight had a lower low setting for things like reading a book at night in a tent.  But overall it's hard to complain about a flashlight being too bright.I was provided this flashlight in exchange for an honest review.

Pros:* Earphones and cable stay in place and don't move through the most vigorous workout.  This is the real difference between these and others.* Cable wraps around your head and is off your neck, cable also is stiff and stays put during movement.* Simple to pair and use.* I like the white.Cons:* My wife has banned me from wearing them in public because she doesn't like how they look.  They are bulky around your ear, they look a bit like a hearing aid rather than a set of headphones.* No apt-x support makes the sound just OK, not great.* Not as comfortable as other Bluetooth headphones I have, I can't wear these more than 20 minutes at a time without them annoying me.* More expensive than other bluetooth headphones that have better sound.Full disclosure: I was given these in exchange for an honest review.

All the printers that support the HP61 ink also support the HP61xl ink. The xl ink has cheaper print costs per page, but barely. If you do much printing at all you should consider buying a printer that takes an ink cartridge with cheaper per page printing costs.61: $0.075 per B&W ISO page61xl: $0.0724 per B&W ISO page934xl: $0.0343 per B&W ISO page950xl: $0.0176 per B&W ISO page970xl: $0.0132 per B&W ISO page61: $0.1266 per Color ISO page61xl: $0.1096 per Color ISO page935xl: $0.0761 per Color ISO page950xl: $0.0587 per Color ISO page970xl: $0.0514 per Color ISO pageSwitching from a printer that supports the 61xl ink to a printer that supports the 950xl ink will save you significant money in ink costs. A leading Consumer Magazine (you know the one) rated the Anco31 as their third best wiper blade and rated it a best buy.  The Valeo 600 came in first and Rain-X Latitude came in second, but both are much more expensive.The Bosch SteelTech seem to do a good job wiping away water.  In my informal testing out of the box the performance of the Bosch SteelTech is comparable in rain vs the Anco 31.  This makes them a good buy.  However, at the time of this writing the Anco are cheaper on Amazon.  Also, the leading consumer magazine does more exhaustive testing than I do and they haven't tested the Bosch SteelTech yet, meanwhile the Anco 31 are a proven product.In summary buy these if you want, they are fine, but buying the Anco 31 is the smarter move as they are cheaper and well tested.

These are good.  They sound is decent, they are lightweight, etc.  But at the end of the day I preferred the Soundpeats Qy7 V4.1 Bluetooth Mini Lightweight Wireless Stereo Sports/running & Gym/exercise Bluetooth Earbuds Headphones Headsets W/microphone for Iphone 5s 5c 4s 4, Ipad 2 3 4 New Ipad, Ipod, Android, Samsung Galaxy, Smart Phones Bluetooth Devices (Bl....The SoundPeats QY7 look almost identical, but cost about $5 more.  I found the Soundpeats slightly more comfortable.  The audio is also noticeably better on the SoundPeats QY7 because they use a slightly higher end bluetooth autdio chip from the same manufacturer (CSR) that supports apt-x.  These Jadaol use a CSR8635 and the SoundPeats QY7 use a CSR8645.  Apt-x makes a difference and the slight upgrade on the audio chip is in my view worth the $5.In the interest of full disclosure I was given these headphones and the SoundPeats QY7 in exchange for honest reviews.

I have no idea how they can throw this many mounts in at this price and make a profit.  This has every kind of mount I could imagine needing.
