Everything seems to work fine and is equal in quality to the original go-pro branded accessories.  Literally my only complaint on the whole set is that the selfie stick doesn't extend as smoothly as I'd like.

I was pleased with this product overall.  It is a good waterproof bluetooth speaker.Pros:* Waterproof* Nice controls* Decent sound* Pairs well* Charges with standard micro-usb plug* Kickstand is handyCons:* At maximum volume there is noticeable distortion.  Turning the volume down a notch or two produces clear sound.* The volume is adequate. At this price and size it's hard to complain about the volume, it's fine for the shower or a smaller room, but if you had a larger pool, a party full of people, or a lot of background music it might not be loud enough.* The bass is adequate.  At this price and size it is really hard to complain, but if you need a lot of punchy bass something this size really just doesn't give that thump

I use this with the Torque Pro app for my Mustang and Subaru.  With it I can see realtime info, see and clear trouble codes, and see additional diagnostic information that can help diagnose problems that affect performance but aren't bad enough to trigger a check engine light and associated trouble code.  The connection is reliable and the device itself is super compact.

The best source of protein you can choose, as far as having a good balance of all the essential amino acids and lack of toxins is going to be lean meat or seafood.  Chicken Breast, Sirloin Steak, Sockeye Salmon.  Those are examples of real food you should consider eating before relying on protein powder.  That said, smoothies can be quick and convenient and often a good way to get your fruit and vegetable intake.  When you make smoothie it is often nice for it to have a source of protein and protein powder fits that bill very nicely.Whey protein isolate is the best protein powder you can choose.  Heres why:Whey protein isolate vs concentrate.  Concentrate is cheaper.  Isolate removes the milk fats and carbohydrates and leave almost pure protein.  It is important to remove the fats not because all fats are bad for you, but because some types of fats probably are bad for you.  Milk fat contains approximately 65% saturated, 30% monounsaturated, and 5% polyunsaturated fatty acids.  Those 65% saturated fats are the ones most scientists believe are unhealthy.  Also the carbohydrates in milk include lactose, which a very large number of people have trouble digesting.  Because whey protein isolate doesnt have the saturated fats and lactose of whey protein concentrate most scientists consider it to be healthier for you.Soy protein isolate is another alternative.  Soy is considered a complete protein in that it contains all the essential amino acids.  The main downside to Soy protein isolate is that it has a concentration of Saponins of 10.6 g/kg.  The full health effects of Saponins are still being studied, but several peer reviewed articles have shown Saponins to increase intestinal permeability also known as leaky gut. Leaky gut can cause low levels of inflammation throughout the body and other short term and long term negative health effects.In summary, Whey Protein Isolate isnt quite as good as eating foods naturally high in protein, but it can make a healthy smoothie even healthier.

Overall this is a nice product that does what it says well.The pros:* Tested output voltage on 12V jumper leads with electrical meter and it measures up.* Tested output current with electrical meter under lower sustained load and it produces good power* Tested output of cell phone charger with current meter, it also measures up.* Small, compact, lightweight compared to lead-acid battery portable jumpstarters* The universal charging cable with old iphone, new iphone, micro-usb, and mini  usb is probably the coolest adapter cable ever.* Both wall and car charging plugs included* Handy compact carrying case stores easily in back of car next to spare tire.The cons:* Would have been nice to be able to charge off of USB* Jumper leads are very short* Flashlight button is too easy to accidentally press and turn on.In the interest of full disclosure I was given this product in exchange for a fair and honest review.  However, the rating is what I would give the product had I purchased it myself and I do regularly give poor reviews to poor products that I am given to review.

The rear diff plug on my Suabaru is a 13mm square drive plug.  I tried to get it loose with a 1/2" (12.7mm) drive and a cheater bar but it wouldn't budge.  I decided before I applied serious force with a car jack on the cheater bar handle I'd better get an exact 13mm drive.  It turns out that this drive isn't any larger than the 1/2" drive and I ended up not using it.  holding the ends right next to eachother either they are exactly the same or you just can't see 0.3mm difference.

The RV roof had serious leaks around seams where the roof meets the walls.  Tried several times to seal it with various roofing caulk, none of which worked well or for long.  I put this magic tape on and leaks stopped completely and hasn't leaked at all in the couple years since applying it.  I liked it so much when the slide out started getting some cracks in the 20+ year old roof I bought another roll of this and applied it over the cracks.  Just great stuff!

On my manual Subaru Forester the front diff shares a fluid reservoir with the manual transmission.  This means you don't want limited slip additives getting in and messing with your synchros.  With this red line gear oil my shifts are smooth and fast.  Everything at the auto parts store had LS additives (and I did put Mobil1 gear oil with ls additives in the rear diff).  This stuff is great, I couldn't be happier with it.

I like the heart shape and the crystals. The black crystals seem a bit more grey then black, but the understated nature of not having color is nice sometimes.  All around it is nice enough. I used it as a stocking stuffer and it was very good for that.  I think it would also be a nice impulse gift for a daughter.  I sometimes like to use gifts like this to be a physical reminder of a pleasant time, say giving it to your daughter on the way to a concert you are taking her to.However, be aware that like most jewelry at this price it is small. 18" is shorter than most men like me realize, it doesn't hang down very far. The chain is thin and the piece itself is relatively insignificant in size. If you are planning to buy it for your girlfriend as a gift for an occasion like Valentines day, a birthday, or Christmas you may come up short of the desired effect and have to open your wallet a little wider.  However, if you are just buying it as a surprise no occasion gift it will probably go over better than flowers.

I purchased these expecting them to be pretty terrible, I mean they are so inexpensive.  They were going to be stocking stuffers.  After they arrived I realized they are actually really nice.  The first thing I did was keep one for myself, for quality control purposes you understand.  The next thing I did was upgrade them from stocking stuffers to gifts to friends.  I first filled each with good quality alcohol matching the personality of the recepient, you know who you are jalapeno tequilla, single malt scotch, and ginger rum.  The next thing I did was order another set of 5, because I have more than 4 friends.

Fast charging.  I hooked this up to the USB power meter and it put out 0.867A and 0.977A in each of the two ports charging a 1A device.  That's really impressive and is faster than almost any wall charger I've tested.  I also like the grippy rubbery case and the almost universal blue leds to indicate battery charge.So, why not 5 stars?  First, the packaging says "Pre Charged & Ready To Go" which just isn't true.  My unit came almost completely discharged (single blue dot on the battery indicator) and needed to be charged for quite awhile before it was used.  Second, the flashlight while really just a throw in isn't very bright.  But mostly at the time of this review you can buy similar quality and capacity chargers for a lot less money.  I think this is a fine unit that will serve you well, but so are some others that you can pick up a lot cheaper.In the interest of full disclosure I received this unit in exchange for a fair review.  These opinions are my own.

Superior Thread Masterpiece thread is beautiful to sew with. I use it for quilts (piecing) and apparel.This color is so different, but so perfect. I am addicted to gold-ey colors with a green cast and this fits the bill in a rather "superior" fashion!
Excellent, easy to sew, pattern

I recently read Alice Hoffman's book of the same name which I thoroughly enjoyed and gave a 5 star rating to. Honestly, when I read the book I was not even aware that a television mini- series had been made of the book so I was eager to see how well the show followed the book. I had been ignorant about the story of Masada and have been inspired to read some non-fiction now.I have to say that I was surprised at some of the changes they made in the show ...some of them did make sense. I was pleased at how the series provided me some visuals of what the area may have looked like....the dust (which I feel may be quite accurate), and ditto to the water cisterns and the clothing. Having visuals sort of reinforced the book although, for me, the book had much more impact than the mini series.Had I not read the book first I am not sure what I would think about the series...it wasn't a particularly forceful show, but I certainly do not feel that it was as bad as some reviewers. I enjoyed it, but was happy that I had read the book first.If you choose only one thing to do....read the book.

These Chacopel marking pencils are just about my favorite marking tool. They mark well, can be sharpen d to a very fine point (sharpener included with each package) and they fade and wash out completely....though I do check if I have any doubts about a particular fabric. There is a color that is suitable for any project. There is one yellow and one white and a combo pencil that has pink and blue. I am back for another order of the !
Excellent Clover Quality! Works perfectly and quickly....I use a cutting mat as a surface rather than a wood block and have had no,problems or excessive marking

While I am not sure that I would choose this tool to as a compass (one of its stated functions), I do like it very well and a button hole spacer (absent using a Simflex) and measuring device for hems etc. standard, excellent Clover quality. I am pleased with the purchase.

This stabilizer  was included with my Janome 8900 but I wanted it to use on my Hello Kitty portable (Computerized version 18750)  that I use for traveling and classes. It works well and does the job of stabilizing even fussy fabrics.

First off I should mention that:1: I purchased this solely for use as a seam gauge- not for the foot that comes with it.2: I purchased it in "used-good condition".I have recently returned to apparel sewing after sewing only quilts for many, many years. I did not need this to mark a quarter inch seam since my foot does a perfect job of that and I am skilled at eyeballing a quarter inch. I am not as good at knowing 1/2" and 5/8" seams though and I wanted to use this marker for that purpose. I did not want to use a magnetic marker since I fear even a bit of an issue with my beloved computerized Janome machine. I also wanted/needed a marker that is movable.The marker arrived in original packaging..but showed use on the "renewable" and "moveable" sticky backs. The material used to attach this  seam gauge to your machine bed is not like double stick tape - it is more like the rubbery thick tape that can be used to hang posters on walls without damage....you may know the blue tacky stuff I mean (called Elmer's Poster Tack) . I just ran hot water over the residue that was stuck to the tape and it adhered just fine to the base of my Janome machine and to my clear acrylic desk top. No problems with this....though I wish that there was a better solution.The seam measure itself is between 1/8" and 1/4" thick... Thinner over areas where the tacky stuff is and thicker over the non tape areas. In that regard it does provide a solid, stable surface to run material against. The material that the gauge is made from is not flexible- it's just plastic ...maybe a little more soft than regular plastic though...which is actually a decent attribute. It does have a bendable forward edge that can go along the front side of your machine if it is not set in a cabinet or flat surface. I just used mine flat and it looks just fine- perfect, straight line.I could have used a stack of post it notes I suppose but this looked like a better alternative and in fact, after trying so many different "measure gadgets", I think that this may be the best current alternative available.If I had a seam gauge wish list it would include a strip of about 1/8" thickness that was long enough to go the length of the  machine and part of my table (or as long as I wanted it to be), it would be flexible enough to feel nice and still do the job and it would be eminently, easily,  'reposition-able'. Until I find a better "mousetrap" this will suit well enough. I do wish that it was available without the foot though...that will go unused and un-needed. I think that is a bit expensive for what it is...but buying used here on Amazon made the cost just a bit more palatable.It's the best thing that I have tried and it will be a help, but it could be much better IMHO.

Before I begin I mess to confess that I was offered this sketchbook at a reduced price for my review.It is hackneyed phrase that "this is my honest review" but since I am an inveterate 'journaler' and art dabbler I do think that my review is based on many years of "paper experience".  I am fond of using Stillman and Birn sketchbooks, and Quo Vadis, Rhoda and Moleskein journals, but I  am always on the lookout for good quality sketchbooks and journals since Imuse a lot of them!  My primary concerns when using a sketchbook or journal is how much "bleed-through" I experience when using inks and mediums. The beautiful, creamy colored 60# paper in this Leda Sketchbook has a very smooth, superior, texture. It's a perfect surface for writing on as well for just about any sort of pen, pencil, ink or light color wash you may want to use on it's pages. I tried using a wash of watercolor and had excellent results. Fountain pen ink has very minimal bleed through as do Sharpies and gel ink pens. My Sharpie Pens (fine tip) showed NO bleed through at all!The attached images show the journal, it's nice gray page marker and sturdy elastic strap. I am particularly fond of the cover material used on this sketchbook...it has a wonderful, almost slightly rubberized, texture that ensure a good hold. The book itself opens flatly for ease-of-use. The pages DO NOT have the slightly wavy appearance that my camera seems to have captured...the color is perfect, the pages very smooth but a slight bit of tooth to ensure excellent acceptance of  your chosen media. The surface provides a pleasurable experience to work on. I would not suggest this sketchbook for heavy wet mediums or textured substrates , but for pens, pencils, inks, light washes and most anything else it is a great choice at a good price point too. It works well for my one and ink practice calligraphy.For me, this is a 'local' company too and since I like to patronize "in-state" suppliers if I can this is an extra good thing for me personally. The contacts that I had with the company were all very quick and very cordial- so I think that their customer service must be superior.So there you have it....my sincere remarks about an excellent choice in sketchbooks!

I think that this pattern notcher is a fantastic deal and it does what it was meant to do perfectly! Perfect pattern notching at last!  It is well constructed (mine was not as shiny as in the image). I am very happy with it...shipping was very quick!

I have to admit to being quite ignorant of India's history, and I chose this book from our library without high expectations, although I have enjoyed other books by Michelle Moran in the past. I think that this is one of her best works yet! The story of of the protagonist, Sita Bhopal (one of the rani's extremely skilled female guards), and the Rani is riveting. Unexpectedly, I was hooked from the first page of the Prologue. The plot moves along very well throughout the book and the characters are beautifully defined.A side benefit was learning a bit about the history of this Indian State and the English takeover. I learned about Hindu gods and goddesses as well which was very enjoyable. As always, after I finish a great historical novel I always read more of the facts, and I found that this book adheres well to established history. Now I would like to read more about India and it's history and religion...something that had previously not been high on my personal "to do" list. Yep! I really did enjoy this one!

i have had a couple of back surgeries, and when I over do something- especially outdoor chores, I feel it a lot. Today I tried these in place of an adhesive, menthol derivative patch that I had been using. They do produce a pleasant warm effect, of a quality about like the lower settings on a heating pad. I am not fond of the papery band which is used to wrap and attach these patches. It is bothering my skin a bit - then again I have quite sensitive skin so most people may not mind this feature as much as I do. I also found that the slight tension on my back from the more adhesive kind of menthol pad felt good just by holding the skin in a bit for some reason. I think that these are quite pricey too unless purchased in bulk. If I feel badly enough to need these I would prefer my chair and heating pad, but, if you are not able to sit like that and you hurt, and you have to keep going, then these are probably a good alternative to not accomplishing anthing!

I love this product. It really does make you look a bit airbrushed. My only problem is that it seems as though every time I use it I break out (which is not the norm for me) just a bit on one part of face or another. I cannot  definitively say that it is the product at fault, but I do have to wonder. My skin is highly sensitive though, very fair and I normally do not wear a foundation at all...so it could just me me.Other than this small issue this is a wonderful product!
What can I say about Blue-Q boxes? They are delightful, whimsical, well made and useful - that's what!This is my third cigar box. I love them!

I bought this book specifically for one pattern, but was pleasantly surprised to find that there were many patterns in the book that I like a lot and that will be added to my list of quilts to make. The book itself is beautifully printed, includes good directions, and great images. It's thicker than many quilt books are, very satisfying to hold. This book had not been on my radar but I am SO glad that I bought it! It's a keeper
I am a real fan of these exfoliating cotton pads! They work really well and, like all of the Swisspers products that I have used, they are excellent quality!

A friend brought one of these to our weekly sewing group. Before we left that evening 19 people had ordered one of these!This is a pretty straight-forward little LED lamp. There are two levels of brightness and you can use the lamp with either battery power or with the included outlet plug. It's lightweight, but it is quite well made.Are there better or brighter on the market? Probably, but this one works very well and I don't think that you can beat the price. It's great that they are offered in colors too.All in all this is an excellent little task light for sewing, crafts etc at a low price point and fast shipping. What's not to like?!
I am a fan of Belkin products and this little gadget does not disappoint. Having different colored cords makes sorting easier. Well made and works perfectly.
Well made and does the job. I like this cover and the quality. I wish that the swivel was a bit easier and that the stand was a bit more stable. All in all though a good value
Great quality nut bag! I have to confess that I use this bag for dyeing with plant materials rather than for making nut milk, but the bag is well made, lasts a long time and works perfectly.

I purchased a used copy of this book simply because I loved the pattern that is on the cover! The price that I spent was worth the price for that one quilt alone and I did find  a second pattern that I also like a lot. Both of the quilts that I especially liked use fabrics to make the design.In general, I was underwhelmed by the other nine quilts in this book - some have a  modern, minimalistic slant and other just strike me as a bit boring. The quilting on these quilts is a feature that I did enjoy though. You will find inspiration in the pages of this book. You may love just a couple of the patterns as I did or you might love them all. I am glad that I purchased the book because the two patterns that I like were worth the price.

This is one of my favorite of all of Kaffe Fassett's books. I fell in love with the quilt on the cover and just had to make it, although I did use some other colors for a bit brighter effect.The quilts in this book are a bit more subtle than the usual super vibrant colors in most of the quilts in Kaffe Fassett books. As the title indicates, Kaffee Fassett's line of shot cottons and stripes are the primary 'ingredients' in these quilts. Many of the patterns are based on "old time" classics that are "re-invented" by using more modern color choices. I find that I need to starch the KF line of shot cottons since they are fairly lightweight and I have also become very fond of Pepper Cory's new line of shot cottons from Studio-E because they have a bit more heft.This book is a keeper for me and, judging from the number of friends who have purchased it after looking through my copy, it holds a wide appeal for both "Kaffe-a-holics" and "regular" quilters alike!

I just cannot decide between 3 and four stars! It should rate 5 stars from me, and I have struggled with what to say about this book.The book covers one of my favorite periods of history and recounts the amazing life of Margaret Beaufort, her loves, marriages and the fall of the house of Lancaster. As far as I can tell from studying the facts, this book was spot on historically.  Henry VI is portrayed much as I imagine he might have been - as is the redoubtable Duke of York and Warwick, the Kingmaker. This should have been one of my favorite reads, but it just missed the mark a bit.The author includes many quotes from historical archives and contemporaneous 15th century journals that are generally, but not always, placed at either the beginning or end of a chapter. Oddly enough, this is the part that I am not sure that I liked. I found that reading the quotes (which you certainly want to do) through off my 'timing' and my feel for the novel.  Although the relevancy of the quotes was excellent I almost wish that all of the "footnotes to history" were included in some other way - though exactly how it might have been better presented I have not been able to decide.This book will delight those of us who thrive on British history and it will also be most enjoyable for those who just love a good novel. I am certainly glad that I read it, but I came away from it feeling somehow less than satisfied. Is it worth the read? Resoundingly "yes!". Will it be one of you favorites? Read it and see.

this was larger than I had anticipated, but it works very well. It allows me to press quilt block seams open in order to avoid bulk.I do not think that the "wooly", plaid, side is real wool, but it does not matter to me. I use high heat and steam for pressing seams open along the side with the heavy canvas.Good quality, good vendor, good price.

This is a versatile pattern. I like it enough that I even accidentally ordered a second copy!I gift these and use them - they ar perfect for knitting or sewing projects and I have even used them it the kitchen!

I pre-ordered this book as soon as I saw it. I was not disappointed and this one was well worth the short wait! A group of friends is doing a "Lots-of-blocks" challenge. Many are doing more traditional 6" squares but as soon as I saw this book I knew that it was the project for me!The book is very well laid out, the illustrations are well done- as are the instructions. What I really like but this format is that it is a "pick-and-choose" method. You can either follow the directions for the included (excellent) projects or you can choose your own pattern combinations - which is what I am planning to do. It's sort of like playing "building blocks" for quilters!I have been a fan of Elizabeth Hartman's work for some time and this book is really the icing on the cake! Lots of fun!

I make a lot of bags and have used a variety of different fusible interfacing a over the years. Why it took so long for me to learn about Pellon SF101 though is beyond me. This is a fantastic product and works perfectly for me! Because it is a lightweight cotton fusible it is soft and adds just the right bit of stabilizing. I love this product enough enough that I bought a bolt of bolt it after I used up two packages of this small size.This packaging makes trying it easy to do. I bought two of these packages before I bought the bolt! Great product!

This fabric came from Fabric.ComI was what I needed.Shipping was just a bot slow( I have been spoiled by my Prime membership now)For me, that was not an issue, and I appreciate being able to find the particular fabric that I needed at such an affordable price.

I had been interested in trying these clips for some time. I had hesitated to buy them in the past because I was not sure that they would work any better than what I had been using and because I though that they were. Bit too pricey for my personal exchequer.When I found that they were being made in these wonderful, bright "gummy" colors and were also available from a be sore for a price that was reasonable though- I had to give them a go....and I happy that I did!Clover Wonder Clips really are "a better mousetrap"! They work beautifully- that means better- than what I had ben using for years. They are perfect for sewing, quilting and for knits as well.

A friend gave me one of these pins to try and then I was unable to locate them because we did not know who made them. I was so happy to finally find them. I like the longer length and slimness of the pin, plus who can resist a button shaped pinhead?! They work very well, comparable to another, more expensive brand. I will be back for more as small gifts.

I actually bought these to use for my olive oil that I keep in a wine bottle. I currently have an oil spout in the bottle (like the Stainless Steel Classic Bottle Pourers with Tapered Spout), but the way my kitchen is designed, I keep the oil in a place that constantly gets knocked over and I'm always afraid the oil is going to spill out. So I thought these would be a good solution. Unfortunately, they're too small and just slide right out of the wine bottle!

Due to the layout of our rental house, we can't get any cross ventilation so even when it's nice out, it's hard to get the cool air in. We didn't want the hassle or expense of an actual screen door (even the cheapest wooden ones are $50, plus all the necessary accessories like springs and whatnot) so I found this solution instead. And it seemed perfect! We could keep the garage door open which would give us a direct line of ventilation to the back door.Except.We didn't clearly think it through that we'd obviously have to leave our big garage door open as well--which would be fine except for two things:1) Our neighborhood is a bit Stepford in that garage doors are always closed--if a door is open, it's because someone is physically pulling a car in or out, someone is walking through the garage, or someone is working in the yard. Otherwise, they're closed. (We've lived here almost a year now, and I can count on one hand the number of times I've seen garage doors just...open.)2) So, even if we wanted to leave it open, we have A LOT of stuff in our garage that is kinda messy and cluttered. And we probably don't need to worry about theft or anything, but do we want to take that chance? Of course we'd only leave it open if we were home...and there's only a few months a year when we'd want cross ventilation anyway (spring and fall, otherwise it's just too hot or too cold)...but it's still something to think about.Additionally:- We discovered that our cats have no problem exiting through the screen...which is a problem, unfortunately, as they are inside-only cats. So when we do leave the door open, we have to keep a strict eye on them which is annoying. My husband has already had to chase one back in the house after we left it open while he was mowing the lawn.- If you install these near a metal door (like the door to a garage), the flaps are constantly sticking to the door. It's fine if you're just going in and out of the house and closing the door behind you...but when you go in and our and want to leave it open, you have to stop and make sure the flap closes behind you.- While I like the ease of simply installing with velcro and sticky tape...it's a major PITA to remove if you decide you don't want to use it. I'd like to see a version that comes with, maybe, metal tack strips that you just screw in.+ I do like that in the off season, we can just remove the whole thing and store it until we need it again.So it may sound like I don't recommend this item...but I do...if you have the right conditions.
A bit pricey overall but not too bad. Delicious pizzas. Good service. Close parking in a parking garage if you can't find street parking.

I received this as a gift but I had actually gotten a similar versions of this game for a niece (Educational Insights Raccoon Rumpus Game). I have to say I'm glad I waited, as this game is for a bit older set and is a bit more complicated than the racoon version. I am also a fan of another Educational Insights game--The Sneaky, Snacky Squirrel Game.You get 4 Koala cards with 3D koala faces, 20 outfit cards, and 2 jumbo dice (one to pick the outfit piece and one to pick the pattern). I like that the instructions are printed ON the inside lid of the box top. (There's an insert with directions in other languages, but I threw that away.)I really like the small form factor of the box--5.5" x 8" x 2.25"--because it's easy to throw in a bag and doesn't take up a lot of shelf space. That said, it could still be smaller yet as there are two big 1.5" empty cardboard-filled sections that could be eliminated (but would then leave less space for instructions and product design).Outfit die: shirt, shirt, pants, pants, shirt and pants, and underwearPattern die: flowers, stripes, checkered, zig zag, polka dots, and a starThe object of the game is to be the first person to collect five outfits. You lay out all the outfit cards, roll the dice, and the combination you roll tells you what kind of outfit you need to find. You might get a checkered shirt or flowered pants. If you roll the shirt/pants combo, you get to select two outfits instead of one. Rolling a star means you get to pick whatever pattern you want. However, if you roll the underwear, you lose ALL of your outfits. A game can be finished fairly quickly--I think we played three games in about 20 minutes.I was worried that there might not be a big enough selection of cards, whereby maybe you'd roll a polka dot shirt and there wouldn't be any left (due to other previous selections) but we never had that happen in any of our first five games. Yes, it's completely random so it COULD happen, but I was happy that it didn't seem to happen with any frequency (or, in our case, at all).The recommended ages for this game are 3+. I wasn't sure how well my almost-3yo would do, but she actually understood it pretty well and was able to pick out the matching outfits. Her biggest problem is that the dice are really big so she has to roll each one separately! It's bordering on being too young for my 6yo, but he enjoyed playing it just the same (as did I).The "bonus memory game" included is just separate instructions for another game to play with the same cards: place all cards face down in a memory-style format then use the pattern die to determine what outfit you need to find. If you flip an outfit card and it matches, you get the card. If not, the next person rolls a new pattern and picks a new piece. So, memory, but with the twist of needing to remember separate patterns of shirts and pants and matching them to currently rolled die.So, how can I give the game a five-star rating when all the sub-categories are four stars? Well, for the price and small form factor, it gets bumped up! I'd definitely recommend this game.

HAIR BACKGROUNDI have very thick wavy hair to the middle of my back. I typically only wash my hair once a week (maybe twice in the summer if I've really been sweating) and usually just rinse it thoroughly. I fully blow-dry and straighten it maybe once or twice a month. It hasn't been cut in in over a year (I don't get it cut very often anyway, plus we've moved and I hate finding a new stylist) so the ends are in pretty sad shape. If I don't put product in my hair, it tends to get quite flyaway as it dries.THOUGHTS ON PRODUCT- The directions are only printed on the outside packaging--AND in very small print. I read them, thought I'd remember them because they were pretty easy, but a week later I couldn't remember and had already recycled it. So I had to search them out. Annoyingly, the actual product website doesn't list them at all--WTF?--and the best place for instructions are the Amazon product reviews. So it would be helpful to have the instructions on the bottle.- Speaking of the bottle, I hate the small tubes. Especially since everyone is going to need a different amount, why not just put it in one big bottle? Less waste for sure and more likely a bigger pump which would make it easier. It was a huge PITA to spritz that little bottle and there was always some left that couldn't be pumped out. I had planned on using the entire vile per day (since I have lots of hair) but I got tired about 3/4 of the way through. A bigger bottle would also be more convenient to store (tubes don't stand up and they obviously roll, so they need to be thrown in a drawer).+ The smell is quite pleasant and does not last long. I could only smell it as I was spritzing it. My 6yo son even recognized it as vanilla.+ I was impressed by the quality of the shower ("activating") cap. I have a large head plus a lot of hair and, honestly, most shower caps don't fit or the elastic isn't strong enough to keep my hair contained without also being in a pony tail or clip of some sort. But this one was large enough and had strong enough elastic that I wasn't worried about failure at all. I will definitely keep this to use post-treatment. It has actually saved me the $5 of buying the shower cap I usually use (Betty Dain Stylish Design Mold Resistant Shower Cap). All that said, I don't see the point of the cap at all. You're out of the shower and using it on towel-dried hair--what good does putting it in a cap do? Maybe keep it damper longer?RESULTSI saw and felt zero improvement the first day. The second day I noticed that my hair felt a little better, but it didn't really help with the flyaways I normally experience. Day three was the best overall, with the ends feeling not nearly as dry and damaged as they usually do. But, this leads me to believe there's a cumulative effect, and as expensive as it is, there's no way I'm using this on my hair every day or even every other day.So overall I give it two stars. It did give some results, but not nearly what I'd hope for at that price and not something I can fiscally continue on a regular basis. Add the bad packaging decisions to that and I just can't recommend this product.** Edited 5/10/15 to add a picture of the instructions. I dug through my recycling to find it!

I always have a box of disposable gloves in my kitchen for messy tasks like working with raw bacon and raw chicken or cleaning the sink with bleach. For the food issues, I will stick with regular gloves (I've used other varieties of Venom gloves). But for the chemicals that might splash? I'd definitely use these.My husband said they are a godsend when staining wood. I've seen regular disposable gloves actually disintegrate after a bit of use, but these stayed intact throughout the whole project!I have seen others mention that these gloves can be reused. I agree they COULD be, but take that with a grain of salt. If you are THAT type of person, these may be just the ticket. But honestly, for me, I don't want to take the time to wash/rinse them, peel them off (or pull them off then turn them right side out), dry them, etc. I typically just want to pull off the gloves (grab the glove at the wrist and pull them off over the messy part of the glove) and toss them. So for me, at 40c a piece, these are a definitely gloves to keep for more specialized usage.But I'm definitely glad we now have these in our arsenal.

First things first, I love the way they fit in my ears. Once they're in your ear canal, you just lock them in and they are NOT coming out, even if you drop your phone or mp3 player. That alone is almost worth the price.They sound really good playing everything I threw at it (classical, jazz, top 40, bass, spoken word, etc.) but I am NOT a big audiophile. I had no issues with muddled sounds.I don't have an Android so I couldn't test how they worked with the controls, but I used it for a few phone calls and it worked perfectly.I like the flat cable. It has a movable locking clip that secures the cord to your clothes.Overall, the quality is very solid and I'd say they are definitely worth the $70 price tag. I've had cheaper ones and more expensive ones and I would choose these again. I just wish they worked with iOS.

Wow, time flies! I bought this item from Amazon on February 16, 2010...and 5+ years later it's still going strong. (Caveat: I don't use it every week as I have five other Flip & Tumble bags I rotate through.) But they've been loaded to the max (the cashiers are loathe to stuff it full but I tell them to keep going) time after time as well as washed multiple times and they're still excellent bags!Yes, they do get wrinkled, but who cares? I'd much rather the bag hold a lot, be sturdy, easy to carry, be easily collapsible, and compact (diaper bag, purse, glove box, etc.).

I'm generally a huge fan of Amazon-branded products, so I was excited to try these. Unfortunately, I really dislike these. They don't even come close to my current brand of wipes (Costco's Kirkland brand). I've tried about half a pack trying to like them and it's just not happening.1. They are not wet enough. At first I thought they were just drying out, but even after pulling a few sheets, they still felt too dry.2. You always get multiple wipes when you try to pull one out.3. It takes multiple wipes to clean any type of real mess because they just don't seem to work well.These are going back.

To be honest, I didn't pay close attention when requesting this book--I mistook the Grade Level 4-7 as the age level. (I have a 6yo and wanted this for him as his first chapter book or as something we could read together). Unfortunately, it was a bit too old for him. Since it was above his reading level (no fault of the book--only my lack of attention), I tried reading it to him, but it was just outside his comprehension level and his mind wandered after just a few paragraphs. (I don't mind explaining what things are or defining words for him, but there was SO much of it I had to explain that it was hard to read.)That said, the first chapter sucked me in. We learn Genuine's back story and that she's a wish-fetcher and the chapter ends with her and her Grandma thinking how fetching others' wishes can eventually help them. Of course I had to read the whole thing myself to see what happened!Overall it was a pretty quick and enjoyable read. You could almost hear young Genuine in your head and the dialogue and turns-of-phrase put you right in the small town south. I'll definitely be keeping this book around until my son is old enough to read it, as there are lots of good life lessons to be learned.

I love coconut milk but hate the price, so I tend to buy off brands or wait until it's on sale...and then I can never remember where I found it in the store so it's a pain to buy. So when I had the chance to try this, I was excited. And I was not disappointed. I think this was the first time in opening a can that the thick cream was all at the top and I had to dump the whole thing out to see the watery part. I made my typical coconut rice with it and it was delicious! You can't beat the price for delivery and I am placing my Subscribe & Save order now!

** ITEM RECEIVED FREE FOR REVIEW **I recently purchased another great item from this Made in the USA company (NeverCurl - Stops Rug Corner Curling) and they offered this item to me for free if I would review it.I am always on the lookout for cool cell phone accessories, so accepting this item was a no-brainer for me. We tested it out in DC-suburbia driving conditions on a Mazda CX-9 with an iPhone 5S and iPhone 6+. Both obviously fit when placed flat and both actually fit in the angled grooves as well (we both have thinnish cases) without any trimming necessary.Honestly, at first we weren't thrilled with it, because the 6+ tended to be a bit top-heavy and it came flying out of the holder after a gas-fueled start from a red light (hubby apparently thinks he's a race car driver). But, to be fair, we realized that the holder had been sitting (or perched, possibly precariously) on the curved portion of our dashboard. Once we put the holder on a flatter section of dashboard, it held much more firmly. It held up very nicely for all of the driving we did after that. However, that said, I'm not ready to give up my Mountek nGroove Snap 2 Magnetic Car Mount for this holder, but I do like it more for just tossing a phone or sunglasses on the dash so they don't fly around.For the price, I'd say this is a definite winner. I would do 4.5 stars if I could, but am rounding up to 5 because it fits a variety of phones, can be trimmed to fit around cases, is easy to move between cars, is inexpensive, and is Made in the USA.

I have used this on my toddler for general redness or when she asks for cream. I like the smooth consistency of it as compared to, say, Butt Paste, but I also feel that those thicker products are for more serious diaper rash issues. She seems to like it as much as other diaper creams I've used, but she's not exactly old enough to list the differences. :) So overall this is a welcome addition to our diapering arsenal.

Over time I've tried everything from Vaseline to Avon to Bath & Body Works to Cerave to Aveeno to Johnson & Johnson. Lately I've been getting away from the heavily scented B&BW lotions and just going old school and am currently trying to get through a bottle of horrible Vaseline brand that feels like greasy water...so I was excited to try this as my general after-shower moisturizer. I honestly wasn't expecting much but I really, really like it. There's a barely-there scent, it goes on smoothly and quickly soaks in, and lasts fairly well. I'd give it five stars if it was just a smidge cheaper, but overall, it's a great every day lotion and I'm tossing the crappy Vaseline one immediately.

I am not a food snob in any sense and I'm not even that picky. Give me dollar store mac and cheese or chicken nuggets and I can be a happy girl. So I didn't hesitate ordering these on a friend's recommendation.Whoa.Big mistake.First, these taste nothing like any pad thai anything I've ever had (and I've had my fair share, from cheap to expensive).Second, there is some WEIRD ASS flavor in there that is really off-putting. Granted this is a personal taste issue and I'm not even sure what flavor it is (my first thought was lemongrass which I know I don't like, but going by the ingredients, maybe the tamarind?).If you think you want to buy these, please please please buy a single cup somewhere to try. Now I have 11 of these that will be donated to the local food pantry.

First, I paid about $15 for this at a warehouse club. And honestly, at that price I think it was overpriced. I can see this in a $5 clearance bin and that would be worth it.At first glance, I thought the plastic display bin was for the mixing of the paint so all the paints would stay together. It says that's what it's for, but you need to mix each paint in its own bucket (you need to empty the powder in THEN fill water to the line on the bucket). I guess you could put the paint in there after it's mixed, but there are cutouts for the brush and paint bucket (see photo) so it didn't seem like dumping the paint in there would be a great idea. But, keeping the paint in individual buckets was neat, too.I also first thought I'd be able to mix small portions of the paint for more than one day of use, but unless you want to play around with how much water to add to how much powder, you need to make the whole batch at once. I ended up having the kids choose four colors for one day and saving four colors for another day.The powder does not mix in well. I happened to do the white first and it looked nice and smooth (although VERY thin) but the colors were horrible. They were bubbly and foamy and never got smooth (I even got out a mini whisk). I had expected more of an actual paint consistency--but it almost looked like watercolor water with barely any viscosity to it. And if it sat for more than a minute or two, you had to stir it up again.The brown was also like that. Orange, yellow, green, blue, and purple were clumpy foamy messes. Red was the strangest of the bunch and that was like clumpy wet paste.As you were painting it didn't seem like any kind of paint at all--it was super thin with more viscous clumps now and again. And the cheap brushes (see next item) didn't hold much paint so it took forever to actually paint anything. You also had to keep stirring otherwise it would all clump up at the bottom.The included foam brushes were super cheap--much worse than dollar store foam brushes. They barely lasted through the 30 minutes of painting and my kids are gentle. I think you were supposed to mix the paint with them as well but that didn't seem like a good idea.It does look cool as it dries, though (it just looks like regular chalk)--and the kids liked that.So overall, my kids (6 and 3) had a great time and it got us all out of the house for a brief stint one afternoon during spring break (and we still have another session to go to use the last four colors). I'm glad we did it, but I wouldn't buy this again (I actually briefly thought about returning it) and I certainly wouldn't pay as much as I did. I think next time I will google a recipe and make it myself.***EDITED 4/2/15 TO ADD: Looking at the drawings the next day, they are much brighter and thicker than you'd get with normal chalk...which I'm guessing means they will last longer, too. So that was impressive. But I'm leaving my review at 2 stars.EDITED 4/4/15 TO ADD: They wash away pretty easily in the rain. Only the heaviest (thickest) parts of the drawings were left after a brief rain shower. So I'm upping my rating to three stars.

I bought these for a 2000-mile road trip so the kids could easily stay plugged in and charged. By the end of the trip (approximately 30 hours of use), the fabric on the end of the cord (where it attaches to the phone and gets the most movement) was starting to fray and you could feel that the plastic casing was a bit loose. They haven't fallen apart yet but I can tell it's only a matter of time. But, for the price paid, I'm willing to live with that.

Surprisingly, the towel was soft right out of the package without being washed! It is a bit on the thin side, but I knew that from the description so it wasn't a surprise. It's just fine for a pool or beach towel for a child. My almost-3yo girl loves it. We've washed it once so far (on vacation) and it is nicely soft. We'll see how it holds up over multiple washings.

Because of my own stupidity and rush to get something super well-rated, I didn't read ALL of the description. So...this isn't what I needed. I have an entryway runner that constantly slips off it's supposedly non-slip slip-pad and I thought this would be perfect. And while it is very cool, they are definitely right in that it does not stop the slipping. Bummer for me. But the item itself is very cool and seems very sturdy and well-made, and I now know my rug corners are safe!

I bought this hoping our family would like it enough to make the switch--or at least substitute it off and on because I'm trying to be a good mom and get more whole grains in our meals. Unfortunately, this just didn't taste that great.I made it with butter and Parmesan like I normally do and to my more refined (comparing to my 6yo!) palate there is no way this would ever pass for normal pasta. Maybe if it got buried under my super delicious thick spaghetti sauce it would be more passable...Was it awful? No.Was I clamoring for seconds? No.Did my picky 6yo eat it? Yes - and I was gobsmacked.Did my noodle-loving 3yo eat it? No, because it wasn't the right color.I haven't tried any other whole grain pastas, but if this stuff is any indication...I won't be rushing to try any in the future. We don't eat that much pasta anyway, so it's not a big deal (to me) to eat the stuff that we really like.So three stars for passable, but not terribly enjoyable.

The pros?They're heavy and the construction seems solid.Had no issues with the wheels on hard flat surfaces.The cons?You can't use it on carpet.Difficult for beginners to use--heed the warnings.Very expensive for what they are.
I use this as a face wash for myself and my two kids (5 and 2) and I love it. It has a barely-there scent, it feels luxurious, and doesn't dry our skin. I will continue to buy this.

I have just-past-shoulder-length wavy hair that gets frizzy upon drying. I have a cupboard full of products that try to combat this, and most are okay. I would say this one is slightly above average in that when my hair actually does dry, it doesn't look frizzy at all. It does NOT seem to last all day, however, which is partially why I've docked a star. The other reason is I really don't like the scent. I'm generally not bothered by scents, but there was just something strange about this one. The only good thing about the scent is that is didn't seem to stick with you--once it was on your hair and you washed your hands it was unnoticeable. I would definitely recommend this product.

I love fabric shower curtains so when we moved into a new house and the kids bathroom needed an update (out went the palm tree fabric curtain!), I opted for this colorful yet neutral pattern (I gave my 5yo so about three to choose from and he picked this one). I was momentarily hesitant because even though it said FABRIC, the "100% polyester" threw me...but yes, it is fabric.My only concern is that it doesn't match any of my current blue, green, or tan towels...they're all a few shades off. :)

We tried a balance bike with my son and he never liked it, so we're trying again with our daughter. Hubby said it went together well enough (and I didn't hear any swearing so I believe him) and it appeared my daughter was going to like it...she was VERY excited when she saw the box...but we haven't yet been able to actually get her ON it to try it out (though she fits--she's tall for two). I guess the idea of it is still more exciting than the actual item. I'll update if this changes.

I honestly wasn't expecting the spray to look like liquidy lotion...that was a big surprise when I first spritzed it on my 2yo. And after I finished spritzing her entire body and rubbing it all in, I felt like I wanted to go wash my hands (so not much different than any other sunscreen I've used). I'm not a maniac when it comes to organic stuff for my little ones, so I'd probably not get this again due to the price.

I chose this book because it fits our family--my husband likes to build things, we have a son, AND we have a Boston Terrier (though her name is Maggie, not Gus!)...and this is definitely a project that could happen in our lives.It's a cute story of a father and son building a wood fort in the backyard, starting with drawing the plans then going to the hardware store, starting the build, stopping for lunch, painting, and then enjoying the end results together.I will say that I am fond of kids books that rhyme, so right off the bat I liked this book. That said, sometimes the rhythm of the rhyme is off by a word here or there which drives me nuts...but this book doesn't succumb to that issue. YAY!The drawings are bright and colorful. Both my 5yo and 2yo like the story and ask for it often.The only proofreading/editorial issue I have is that the plans show a 15x18x12 "fort"--much larger than any normal kid fort would be AND much larger than the actual fort ends up being. Does it matter in any sense? No. But I'm an editor and it jumped out at me because I'm trained to look at things like that. :)All that said, overall I give it four stars because I think the age range is a bit off. I would rate it more towards the lower end of the 3-8 range unless it's your 8yo reading it himself.

I was very interested in trying this model Vitamix as I currently own an older model (the 5000) and have been drooling over the newer features. No, there was nothing at all wrong with my 5000 and it still worked perfectly but I really liked the newer container with the better handle grip...and the grass is always greener, right?The short version?If you have an older model that still works, there really is no need to spend the money to upgrade. There are slight differences between the two, but each gives you the same results. If you've never had a Vitamix and are tempted, you would not go wrong with this model.THE MINOR DIFFERENCES:5000: Nothing happens when you plug it in.6300: When you plug it in, a blue light comes on (see photos).5000: The lid is a bit hard to get on.6300: The lid style changed and it's much easier to get on/off.5000: The container has a simple plastic handle.6300: The container style has changed and it has a more molded hand grip (see photos) which makes it easier to handle.5000: There are two toggle switches--one to switch from variable to high speed and one to turn the machine on/off.6300: There are two toggle switches--one for pulse and one to start/stop the machine (the machine is ON when you plug it in).5000: When making a smoothie (juice, yogurt, protein powder, frozen whole strawberries), I just use high speed and it works fine.6300: When making a smoothie, there's a smoothie setting. It wasn't as powerful as the high speed setting on the 5000 but it did get it mixed it just took a bit longer.Overall, it's a great machine. That said, I personally don't see the need for the specific settings (smoothie, frozen desserts, soup) but they don't hurt anything. I've also never had a need for the pulse setting, but now that I have it, I will try it.

*NOTE* This review will be updated once we do a complete install--we were going to install it in our current home but then found out we were moving so didn't want to go through the full installation just to have to remove it in two months. So we only briefly set up one camera. That said, our new house will be a MUCH better fit for the system as we have no view at all of the driveway/front of house and our office will be downstairs so we can always have the monitors on.So, a few quick notes on what we've experienced so far:Everything seems sturdy and well-built. I would have thought the included cables would be white, not black, as most soffits are on the white spectrum and a black cable seems to stick out a bit (but this isn't a deal breaker). Hubby said the setup was easy with the QR codes. He did notice that the connectors that go into DVR box are a little loose so we kept losing the signal. We set up one camera in a second story window pointing at our driveway and were able to detect movement (and were also able to see the red light from the driveway when it was dark out).

We've had good luck with most every brand diaper we've tried for our daughter, and these were no different. They fit her fine with no sagging or much overlap and they didn't irritate her in any way. But there's no way these diapers would last for 12 hours. I would definitely buy these again.

Mutta nears the end of his astronaut training and is on top of the world! Meanwhile, Hibito is dealing with the repercussions of PTDS and is hitting pretty much the lowest point of his life.This set contains some of my favorite episodes in the series. The contrast between Mutta's victory and Hibito's struggle makes for some very emotional content. The entire series Mutta has been jealous of Hibito, while Hibito himself has always had an upbeat attitude. But now he has hit a large snag in his life plans and it isn't so easy to deal with. Naturally he keeps this a secret from Mutta, who continues on being jealous of his little brother even as Hibito is losing everything.This set contains episodes 65-75 (11 episodes) out 99 total.

After 3 recap episodes, this set finishes up the survival training, covers the Comeback Competition (they build a rover!), and introduces some back story for a couple of characters. Hibito returns from the moon a little worse for wear from his adventure there...This show still continues to enthrall and inspire me (not the recap episodes though). I really enjoyed Hibito's second arc, nearly as much as the first one. Mutta's storyline is still lots of fun to follow, but it is a fun change of pace every time the show switches to Hibito, and he tackles different issues than Mutta.This set contains episodes 52-64 (14 episodes) out 99 total.

Hopes Peak Academy is where Super High School Level geniuses attend, but they hold a lottery every year to invite a normal student to attend.Makoto Naegi is a completely normal kid with super high school luck, as he has won the Hopes Peak Lottery. Sadly, it turns out to have been super BAD luck, since upon arriving to the school, he blacks out, waking to find he is trapped in the school with his new classmates and a maniacal living teddy bear named Monokuma who informs them the only way to leave is to kill someone. Let the games begin!I had lots of fun with this series. It is a pretty unbelievable premise, but I trusted the show to give some sort of explanation by the end and my trust was not betrayed. The characters dont get a whole lot of development, since this is very much a plot driven show. The murder mysteries and the mystery of the school were lots of fun and the story flowed along fairly well. Monokuma was hands down my favorite character.I have never played or heard of the game that this was based before watching the show. I had read somewhat mixed reviews about it, one from someone who had played the game stating that it was confusing and left lots of stuff out.The only thing that confused me was the ending, which after some lengthly wiki reading, turns out to have been very close to the game. Actually, it seems to me that the show followed the game very closely. The game is called DanganRonpa: Trigger Happy Havoc (dangan' means bullet and ronpa' means refutation in Japanese). The game is the first in a series and it seems that other games flesh out the original story quite bit. I hope another one of the games get adapted :)One thing I thought was kind of fun about this show is that it is really, really, really obvious that it is based on a visual novel. It does things like introduce each character with their own character sheet, frequently give you data in a game like format (like the way you find clues), and for the trials Naegi gets Truth Bullets and you can totally tell he is the player character. I liked how the show embraced its roots, but it might bug other people.

Akihito Kanbara is a second year high school student, a member of the literature club, and an immortal half yomu. The last one is good, because when he meets first year Mirai Kuriyama, she shoves a sword made from her blood through his chest. Mirai is from a long line of yomu hunters and her clan has long been shunned due to their strange blood manipulation abilities. For some reason, she seems it have it out for Akihito and keeps trying to kill him while he tries to befriend her.Talk about a rough introduction. Despite not being able to die, Akihito still feels pain. And because he is indestructible, he doesnt seem to have bothered to learn any sort of basic defense, while Mirai is a trained warrior. So he gets stabbed a lot. Eventually they call a ceasefire (she agrees to stop stabbing him), which was a relief. It was kind of hard to accept his interest in her when she kept making him bleed.I kind of expected to hate Mirai, since she is the sort of character that normally annoyed me, but I actually liked her. Unlike so many cutesy characters, she actually seemed cute. She also turns out not to be as dumb and annoying as you might assume from her initial treatment of the main character.Both Akihito and Mirai had rough pasts. Through their friendship they start to heal and move forward. Then the ending comes and shatters everything. Surprising information is revealed and something equaling surprising occurs. There is a little bit of weirdness in the last episode, but overall the ending actually made me like the series more (good endings really make a difference).Beyond the Boundary is an entertaining show. At only 12 episodes, it is the perfect length to tell the story it starts out to tell.

This is my third puzzle feeder. My first one was a Catit Design Senses Treat Maze and the second was one of those little treat balls. I really liked those two, but the ball was kind of messy and I have 4 cats, so one food bowl seemed cruel. So I decided to try this one out.Ever since I was introduced to puzzle feeders I have loved the idea. Not only does it slow down my cats eating (so less throw up!), it makes them think, keeping both them and me entertained. It is lots of fun to watch them figure out a new bowl :) This was wasn't too difficult for them, within 10 minutes of sniffing and poking at it, the smartest cat of the bunch had it figured out. Her less intelligent followers were at least intelligent enough to copy her and within 15 minutes they had all snagged some food.My biggest complaint is that this bowl tends to make great journeys across my kitchen floor. I fill it up in the morning on one end and by evening it is on the other side of the room. I have half hearty attempted to solve the problem with little success. I will note though that there is a ceramic version of this bowl available which might not have this problem. Keep that in mind when purchasing.If your cat is new to puzzle feeders, I would recommend starting them off with one of the ball styles. If they can't handle that, don't torture them with this.

This warmer is just as pretty as the pictures suggest. I looked at a dozen different warmers before settling on this one and overall I am quite pleased. I got it specifically to heat wax tarts, though it can be used for aromatic oils as well (though this specific color only has 'wax' in the title, other colors include wax, so it is intended for both).I used some wax tarts I picked up from Walmart. Initially it took about 45 minutes to heat the cube enough to melt it and produce scent. Even if you've never heated wax before, you can probably tell that is way too long. Fortunately, on the subsequent uses it worked much faster. The problem is that the plate is a little too far from the bulb, so it doesn't get very hot. Once the wax has melted and the surface area has increased, then it doesn't need as much heat to remelt it. I have heard that you are supposed to replace the wax after every use, but I find that extremely wasteful, since the wax I use has lasted up to 20 hours worth of burning (I don't leave my warmer on all the time).Since I need maximum heat to use this warmer with wax, I don't really use the dimming function, but I think it would be really useful with oils.In summery, I love the way this warmer looks and if you reuse wax than its functionality is acceptable as well. I am excited to try it with oil, but have a  lot of wax that needs to be used up first!

I had never actually purchased star anise before now, but I went through reviews, checked my recipe (Vietnamese pho), held my breath, and took the plunge. I was very pleased with the results. The majority of the stars arrived intact and the smell was lovely. Actually, the smell was lovely and STRONG. As another review said, you really need to store this in a sealed bag of some sort or your kitchen will smell like star anise (nice, but not suitable for everything).The packaging had Chinese all over it, so I assume this authentic (though I don't care as long as it tastes good).

Make sure you order this product based on the US size!! It is clearly marked when you chose the size, so it shouldn't be hard to pick the right one. I am a US medium (8-10) so I ordered the XL and it fit great. It is a bit of a wiggle to get into, but once on it is comfortable and very cute.You can't tell from the pictures at all, but the suit part under the dress is light colored (white I think) on the torso and black for the bottom, which is actually in a swim short style instead of regular bikini style bottoms. I found that to be a pleasant surprise, but if you don't like swim shorts, well, consider yourself warned.It will take a few weeks to arrive, since it is shipping from China, but it is worth the wait. I have been looking for a swim dress suit like this for ages, but found that they are not really that popular a style in stores here. Most of the swim dresses on Amazon seem to come from China.

Hibito is living his dream on the moon and loving every minute. Except the minutes he is about to encounter after a soon-to-occur disaster.Hibito's moon arc is my favorite story in the series. The exciting stuff all takes place in this set, but the repercussions continue on until the end of the series. Hibito finally gets some attention and growth as a character.Mutta also gets some excitement in this set as he starts his astronaut training! (Finally!) Perhaps to honor by Hibitos moon excitement, Muttas first training is a survival training, involving a long trek through the desert. New characters are introduced and Nitta gets some backstory.

This organizer arrives assembled, all you just have to put the drawers on the rack. It doesn't seem very big, but it holds quite a lot. The drawers slide in and out smoothly, and the design prevents you from pulling the drawers out vertically. There is a decent amount of space between the two drawers for taller things. I use it as a craft supply organizer, but it would probably work great for beauty produces or small kitchen things, like spices or measuring cups.The biggest problem I had with this drawer set, is that it's too long to fit in most places I tried to stick it. The width is good, but I wish it had been made wider and shorter. For now it is stowed on the floor, which is not very convenient.Still, this is a great little set. It's light, but seems solidly constructed, smooth drawer action, space between drawers, and it looks nice too. With only the complaint of it being too long, I am overall very happy with it.

Yato is a very minor god without so much as a single shrine to his name. This is a fact he intends to change, one 5 yen coin at a time. After saving a girl named Hiyori from a traffic accident, she tracks him down and befriends him. Then they are joined by Yukine, who has the ability to transform into a sacred treasure, a weapon that can be used by a god. Together the three of them battle beings called you and slowly learn about Yatos past.I quite enjoyed this series and Yato as a character really grew on me. His past isnt particularly detailed, but it does a good job of illustrating how and why he ended up as he did. Most of the story is him developing relationships with Hiyori and Yukine, something that develops into a particularly great scene.The ending wraps up the show nicely, but the manga is still running and a second season was announced 3/31/15. There is also an OVA, but it is not available domestically. I believe it is just a side story though, so not essential to the main storyline.

Yuuki Hase notices that his classmate Kaori Kujomiya always seems to be alone, so he decides to try and befriend her. She rebuffs his overtures at first, but soon reveals that it isnt that she is unfriendly, she just suffers a condition that causes her memory to be reset every week. Its hard to make friends when you cant remember them, but Yuuki is determined to make it happen.This was a cute show. At some points Yuukis obsession with Kaori becomes annoying/worrisome, but overall they have a good relationship. It was actually kind of funny how long it took Yuuki to realize he actually had a crush on Kaori (the only person denser than him is Kaori).My favorite part of the series was actually the subplot that involved to secondary characters (Kiryuu and Saki). It was cute and they are my two favorite characters :)The premise is an interesting idea and the show does a fairly good job of tackling the issue in a believable way. I think the biggest weaknesses were that it goes kind of slowly at times and in the end I couldnt really buy into the reason for Kaoris memory impairment. But for the most part it is a sweet little story of romance and friendship.

This set first focuses on Hibito and the launch (though from Muttas perspective, not Hibito's), then finishes up with the end of the astronaut exam and the results.Trivia: When Hibito makes it to the moon, he is dubbed the Moon Rabbit (or something like that) by the Japanese media. This is because the Japanese, instead of seeing the Man in the Moon, see a rabbit pounding mochi (rice cake).Hibitos screen time is steady growing, which I enjoyed, as Hibito is actually a very interesting character. Kenji and Serika also get more attention, each get their own episode telling their backstory and fleshing them out as characters. An eccentric new character is also introduced.This set contains episodes 27-38 (12 episodes) out 99 total. At this rate, the last set (number 8 at the current) should come out  around April 2016. That would make it a little over a year to release all sets for the series!I saw the entire series on Crunchyroll, but am working on collecting the DVDs as well :)

Kyosuke Hyobu is the leader of the secret ESPers organization PANDORA. The organization is dedicated to fighting those who would entrap, enslave, or kill ESPers. Sometimes their methods are a little questionable.Hyobu reminds me a lot of Magneto (X-Men). He is dedicated to the protection of his kind, but a little less than considerate for normal humans. As he is the central character of the series, you tend to sympathize with him more than not, even as you recognize that his ideas are flawed (speaking as normal human that is).This series is a spinoff of a show called 'Psychic Squad' ( Zettai Karen Children), which I had never heard of, much less seen before watching this show. As far as I can tell, this series takes place either in the middle or towards the end of the original series (at least, in this series the kids are in their early teens instead of being 10). The main characters for the original show show up briefly, but this series is really dedicated to their enemy, Hyobu.I was able to follow along with the series just fine without having seen the original show. I was a little confused when the girls showed up, but I could still understand their role as opponents of PANDORA.I think Hyobu was a interesting character and he straddled the line between good and bad guy really well. His backstory was well done too. There were things I didn't particularly like about this series (some of the characters were annoying and the plot not terribly strong at points), but I really liked Hyobu and thus found the series an entertaining experience.

2 Minutes into hunger strike. I am strong and determined.5 minutes now. Beginning to feel week.The seeds. They are taunting me!Edward the cynical hamster muses on the meaning of futility of existence and perfectly describes what my very brief chocolate strike was like.Most of the entries are very short, but that is hardly surprising, considering the strain poor Edward must have suffered, forgoing food while writing all of those words.Illustrations accompany many of the entries, but the more desperate entries are simply harsh words, black against the white of the page, begging the reader to imagine the darkness of his words all on their own.This tale is not for the faint of heart.

"On the three-hundredth anniversary of my birth, I finally managed to conquer the world."So starts Perfect State, a clever little sci-fi story about reality, emperors, and dating. The main character, God-Emperor Kairominas, was surprisingly easy to relate to, even though, as of the quarter-century anniversary of my birth, I have yet to conquer anything. The other characters don't get much time to shine, but Shale and Bask made good use of their appearances and I liked both of them a great deal.The story is fast paced and humorous, though the ending gets a little... serious. However, it is a really short story (about 71 Kindle pages). Calling it a "novella" feels misleading. To me, novella implies a short novel. Perfect States is really just a short story. I would have purchased it regardless, but would have preferred to know how short it was beforehand (NOTE: when I purchased the book and at the time I wrote the review, the page count for this story had not been posted).

Shio Ogura is a Japanese high school student with an obsessive love of guns and military. This alianates her from her more normal classmates, but during a class trip to Taiwan it seems like one of them might be willing to befriend her. In Shios moment of happiness, she is attacked by monsters and the area turns into a war zone. In order to save her new friend, she must join forces with agents known as E-Gene Holders and discover her own e-gene - the soul of Oda Nobunaga, one of Japans greatest warlords.I started watching this on a whim and was surprised to find myself continuing all the way to the end. I was interested in Shios slightly unconventional attitude (she had lots of fun fighting and killing monsters, but it wasnt exactly how she had planned to live her life). As with any series involving historical characters, it was fun to see who they brought in and what weird powers they might have. My two favorites were Newton's power of gravity manipulation and Gandhi's force field ability.But the thing that impressed me the most was the ending. This isnt a very complicated series and the characters dont get a whole lot of development, but the ending contains a nice twist, a pretty good explanation for events, and a rousingly fun battle scene.

Azuma Kazuma has a dream - to make a bread that will represent Japan itself and replace rice as a breakfast staple. In order to help achieve his dream, he wants to get a job at Pantasia, a world famous bakery. But the path to JaPAN (pun used extensively in the series, 'pan' being the Japanese word for bread) is not going to be easy!I saw this series years ago and still remember it with great fondness. The baking battles can get pretty ridiculous and the taster's reaction to the bread often hilarious. It generally transports them to an exotic local, such as in one case, Heaven. The characters are fun and Azuma likable, though not very bright. But who needs smarts with his skills?If you enjoy baking, it is fun to see the different techniques used and laugh at the seriousness baking is treated with. If you don't enjoy baking, then... you can still enjoy the same things.Yakitate is 69 episodes in total and this set contains the first season (27 episodes).Ahh, I can't wait to watch it all again on DVD!

During the Iron Age somewhere in Europe, a young boy named Horus (Hols) pulls the mystical Sword of the Sun out of the shoulder of a rock giant. At the behest of his dying father, Horus returns to his people's ancestral lands. He finds the people of his homeland terrorized by the ice demon Grundewald and he vows to defeat him and protect the village. He makes several new friends, one of them a young girl with a lovely voice whom might not be entirely trustworthy...While watching this movie I assumed that it was based off of some Norse legend, but a little internet research revealed that it was actually based on an ancient legend of the Ainu, the aboriginal people of Northern Japan. The European setting was chosen to make it more appealing to international viewers. So the title is misleading - there is no indication of anything Norse and it is never even suggested that Horus is a prince.The animation is quite good considering its age and my biggest gripe was about the quality of the picture. I watched this movie streaming over Netflix, which could account for some of the lapse in quality, but I think most of the problem is that it is just old. The voices are noticeable from a different era as well (I watched it in English, the only option on Netflix), which simply added to its charm.This movie is a fun experience and it is very different from anything produced today. It is short, simple, and sweet. But as I said before, it is an OLD movie and you have to be prepared for it going in, else you might give up early on. I enjoyed it, but it isn't going to become a favorite of mine.

UPDATE 3/27/15: Canary released a software update that adds some features and settings. It is now easier to make emergency calls from the app, they added a panic widget for iOS, and they finally got preferences for setting the default home mode (Disarmed or Private)!I got this device through the Indiegogo campaign and have had it running for a couple of weeks. I have run into a few minor issues in the app, and twice was unable to access the live stream, though I still received notifications.Setup was really, really easy. Steps: 1. Remove device from packaging2. Plug it in3. Download and launch app4. Follow the app's very simple directions (read a couple of screens, allow it to sense your location and deliver notifications, then connect your phone to Canary using yellow cord and let it sync, then update)5. Spy on your cats, dogs, children, or unsuspecting home intruders!And that is it! So simple. Mine was up and running in less than 10 minutes, after which I immediately left the house and not long after was showing my family what my empty living room looked like LIVE!The Canary automatically detects when you (or all users, if you have more than one person on the account) leave home and puts itself into Armed Mode, where it automatically records video when it senses movement and then sends you a notification.
