Most flea bites occur below the knee, the nearest lymph nodes to be affected, therefore are in the groin - how, Cohen asks, would the disease have spread to the armpits or neck?5) The areas of the city where most rats would congreate would be near grainaries (an abundant food source).  Yet in examining the locations of where the outbreak of the plague took place, the epicenters of disease are not near the grainaries, but in the poorer parts of town.6) the assertion that the bubonnic plague became pneumonic is also challenged, Coehn arguing that pneumonic plague is virtually unheard of in moden (since 1894) outbreaks of the bubonic plague, and that it is not as virulent as that transmitted by fleas7) in comparing the mortality across Europe, there is a seasonal variation that is in congruent with fleas (and their hosts, rats): in the Mediterranean the greatest mortality took place in the hot, dry summer months, while in northern Europe they took place in the cooler, wetter autumn.\8) Cohen also demolishes the long-held belief that the plague was brought west via Central Asian merchants, the fleas living in bundles of wool; wool, Cohen claims, is not a suitable host for fleas, and therefore cannot be the way in which the disease was introduced to Europe.While his reconsideration of what has been long-considered canon is controversial, he makes a strong case.  Each of his points are meticulously cited and researched from sources acrross Europe.  His analysis of this evidence is carefully considered and convincingly argued.  Even when there may be evidence to the contrary (as in the findings by paleomicrobiologists in 2000 that DNA taken from the tooth pulp of plague corpses in Montpelier that it was indeed Y. pestis) is brought up, ever the scholar, Cohen rightly calls for corroboration from other grave sites.  What troubles me wasn't his challenge to what has long been accepted as historical and epidemiological fact , but the lack of a plausable alternative to Y. pestis, and the consideration that perhaps modern Y. pesitis may have evolved in the 600-plus years since the 14th century.As Cohen writes in his conclusion, "... I contend that the unquestioned orthodoxy that the late-medieval plagues had to have been modern bubonic plague is not only wrong, it has retarded our knowledge of both the disease and its social and cultural consequences."  Even though nothing has been contributed to address what caused the Great Mortality if not Y. pestis, his scholarship is honest and first-rate, and the questions he raises (and his role as historical iconoclast) warrant attention.  An excellent history and a brilliantly argued reconsideration.

A few years ago I read The Shape of Water (Inspector Montalbano, Book 1), and was disappointed.  Based on that experience, I had reservations about reading another murder mystery set in southern Italy.  I was wrong.  _I Will Have Vengance_ is brilliantly written.  It is a tragic and lyric mystery, with an emotional punch to the solar plexus at its conclusion.  Like the opera that plays such a crucial role in the unfolding of the story, it is evocative, stunning and an emotional rollercoaster.  I am thrilled that I stumbled across it, and am looking forward to the next story by De Giovanni.Set in Naples in the early 1930s, Arnaldo Vezzi, a primadonna tenor, is found murdered in his dressing room.  Commissario Ricciardi is summoned to solve the case.  Vezzi was a talented artist, a "god among tenors", with connection to Il Duce himself - there is political pressure from on high to quickly solve the case.  In his investigation, Ricciardi discovers that in addition to being a a world-class talent, the deceased was also a world-class monster: abusive of those around him, arrogant, self-centered.  There was no end to those who hated him; ironically, those same suspects relied on his talents to make their living (as agents, stage managers, cast and crew.)But Commissario Ricciardi has a secret of his own: he sees and hears the last thoughts of the recently deceased.  They haunt his every movement, be it while he has an espresso (a child run over by the tram stands in front of the window, her mangled body clutching a rag doll saying, "This is my daughter.  I bathe her every day") or a mafioso whose throat was cut, laughing at the young man who threatened him with a knife.  In the dressing room, Ricciardi sees the final moments of the tenor as he sings "Io sangre voglio, all'ira m'abbandondo, in odio tutto 'amor mio fini" (I will have vengance, all my love shall end in hate.") - a line from the opera.  Armed with this knowledge and his considerable powers of deduction, De Giovanni takes readers on a fast-paced investigation involving the Church, the opera, and a woman across the alley from Ricciardi's apartment.In addition to a first-rate murder investigation, the writing (and translation) are beautiful.  The tragic images of the dead are hauntingly described, their effects on Commissario Ricciardi profound.  As the Commissario says, "Believe me when I tell you that damnation is the relentless perception of sorrow, day in and day out.  Other people's sorrow that becomes your own, that stings like a whip, that leaves wounds that won't heal, that go on bleeding, that infect your blood."  Sorrow - and loss - are themes that permeate the book.  One gets the sense of the awful burden that homicide detectives must bear, shouldering the responsibility to find those who have committed murder, the profound loss felt by the victim's families, and the daily ration of sorrow that is the bread-and-butter of their job.A parallel theme De Giovanni explores here is the motive behind murder.  He writes, "The same energy that drives humanity can divert it until it becomes infected and festers, then explodes into violence .... hunger and love are the source of all atrocities."  These twin forces are shown again and again both in the story and on the stage.  It is simply a masterful work that was a joy to read.  This is easily among the best books I've read this year.

The Camel of Destruction is an Arabic metaphor, similar to the English "loose cannon" -an event (or person) that wreaks havoc and destroys all in its path (from the analogy of a camel that becomes untethered and runs amuck tearing down tents, trampling and breaking things.)  In Michael Pearce's imaginings, it is also a fitting image for the financial crisis that precipitated the English occupation of Egypt, finance, banking and urban development the McGuffin of this story.The mystery begins innocuously enough - a mid-level bureaucrat in the Department of Agriculture commits suicide.  Or perhaps, it was murder - which is how the Mamur Zapt (an old Ottoman title for the political police) becomes involved.  What follows is a complex story involving competing economic interests in 1910 Egypt between the Khedive (the titular ruler), the British (the real power in the country), Nationalists, Islamic fundamentalists, and the fellahin (rural peasants).  As with the other Mamur Zapt mysteries (The Mamur Zapt & the Return of the Carpet: A Mamur Zapt Mystery (Mamur Zapt Mysteries), The Mamur Zapt and the Donkey-Vous) the mysteries and their resolution are fun, but the real treat is the descriptions of Egyptian life.  The interplay of traditional gender roles, the legacy of Ottoman (and Mameluke) governance and corruption, the descriptions of the sights, sounds and "feel" of the city are wonderful.  For example, Pearce writes,"All Cairo loved a procession, which was just as well for there wre plenty of them.  There were wedding processions, funeral processions; there were processions to mark the end of Ramadan and the Rising of the Waters; there was a procession to 'smell the air', when half of Cairo trooped out of the city on the first day of the khamsin to savour the coming of spring.There were processions to mark saints' days and there was certainly at least one saint's day every week.  There was a porcession to mark the birthday of the Prophet, marred only by the fact that the interfering British would no longer allow devotees to lie on their faces in the street of the Descendant of the Prophet to ride over.  ... The best time fro processions was during the pilgrim season ..."Pearce is a tremendously entertaining writer; and if the mysteries themselves take a back-seat to the scenery, so much the better as an armchair vacation.  A recommened author as well as series.

David Dickinson's Lord Powerscourt mysteries (Goodnight Sweet Prince, Death and The Jubilee) are light, fun mysteries- a perfect summer distraction.  In his twelfth novel, a visiting scholar discovers that the Elgin Marble is a fake (the type and quality of the stone isn't what it should be.)  Given the concurrent heist of the Mona Lisa, the British Museum is anxious to resolve the case as quickly (and quietly) as possible.  Enter Powerscourt.The mystery itself is a veritable labyrinth of clues, dead-ends and possible tragedies (as the title implies.)  Figuring out who is the responsible party in the theft and where the Marble is destined was so complex that I had to stop trying to solve the case in advance of Powerscourt and just let Dickenson take me along for the ride.  This I enjoyed, tremendously - until the final reveal, at which point I felt a bit cheated.  However, this is not why I give the story 4 stars.  One of the charming elements of the series is are the supporting characters - Lady Powerscourt and Lord Powersccourt's hard-drinking friend, Lord Johnny Fitzgearld.  In this installment, they are scarcely mentioned; in fact, red herrings and possible culprits to the crime are given much more attention than either of these characters, to its detriment.The series is delightful, the characters and their interrelationships a real strength to the narrative arc.  That this is given such short attention, in addition to a sleight-of-hand conclusion cost it a star.  That said, Dickinson is a solid writer and for fans of mysteries (or of fin-de-sicle fiction), this is a sure hit.

For those unfamiliar with Jim Butcher's "Dresden Files", he has mixed elements of detective noir with the supernatural to create Harry Dresden, Chicago's only professional wizard.  This isn't Harry Potter - think more Philip Marlowe with the ability to use magic.  The series (Storm Front (Dresden Files), Fool Moon: Book two of The Dresden Files) are fun (if light) reading.  In _Side Jobs_, Butcher presents a series of short stories featuring characters from the novels, all the stories set between the longer stories.Some ("A Restoration of Faith" and "Aftermath") have never previously been published - all the stories have a brief preface by Butcher detailing when in the series each story takes place, a bit about why the story was written (or for whom), and what Butcher was thinking when the story was written.  I loved the stories - the story behind the stories was a special treat, as it is so rare that readers get a glimpse behind the curtain.  As with any collection of writing, some stories resonated with me more than others.  "Herorot" (taking place between White Night (The Dresden Files, Book 9) and Small Favor (The Dresden Files, Book 10)) - a tale that connected Beowulf to the ancient concept of a "honeymoon" with a dash of Valkyrie, was particularly entertaining.  "Love Hurts" (set between Turn Coat (The Dresden Files, Book 11) and Changes: A Novel of the Dresden Files) gave readers a glimpse of what a relationship between Dresden and Murphy might be like - a bit syrupy, but a fun distraction.  "Aftermath" (two hours after _Changes_ ends) was another winner - a story told exclusively from the perspective of Det. Sgt. Murphy gives one a sense of what lies ahead in the series.Taken as a body, it was also enjoyable to see Butcher's evolution as a writer ("A Restoration of Faith" was a story written while he was a student at the University of Oklahoma's Professional Writing Program), and to have stories told from the perspectives of others (Harry's half-brother, and Mac all get a chance to show what their lives are like outside of the broader story line.)  For fans of the author, this is an easy sell.  For those unfamiliar with the author or the series, the books are a fun distraction and purely escapist reading in all the best ways.  I recommended.

Let me begin by saying I am a fan of Hammett specifically, and of noir in general.  The previous Hammett stories I've read The Maltese Falcon, The Thin Man, Red Harvest, The Continental Op) I've all enjoyed - even the Continental Op has grown on me.  However, _The Dain Curse_ is convulted, difficult to follow, and as a previous reviewer noted, akin to a soap opera in the unfolding of the story.The story begins with a diamond burglary, but soon unfolds into a series of murders, Gabrielle Dain, daughter and heiress of the owner of the burgled diamonds at the center of the violence.  As the plot unfolds, the story takes some really odd turns involving alternately a cult involved in human sacrifice, murder camoflauged as accidental death to perhaps cover-up another crime, and morphine addiction.  With so many unlikely events occuring at once, the book at times  had my head swimming.  Perhaps this is why the Continental Op, typically unsentimental and jaded, shows a more gentle and softer side in this story.  For this reason as well as for the convoluted storyline, _The Dain Curse_ is as unlike anything else I've read by Hammett - and it is the worse for it.  Even the snappy dialogue is diluted here.If you are new to Hammett, this is not the book I would recommned reading as an introduction.  For those who have read his other work, this seems to be an anomaly in the canon and is not his best work in my opinion.  That said, even on a bad day, Hammett is a better writer than most, for which I give it a mediocre rating.

I had never heard of rosehip oil until my sister introduced me to it when she purchased a bottle for herself after claiming that Miranda Kerr swears by it. Not one to ever turn down potentially looking like Miranda Kerr, I began looking into rosehip oil as well in hopes that it would improve my acne-prone skin. I was initially wary of it since I have combination, acne-prone skin that gets oily throughout the day, and knowing that oil is often the cause of my acne, I was hesitant to put even more oil on my already sensitive skin.This rosehip oil was surprisingly not greasy as I expected it to be. It reminds me of tea tree oil, if you have ever used that. The product is far from greasy and is easily absorbent upon application. I have been consistently applying this product to an acne scar on the side of my face, and although it has only been a few days, the scar is noticeably beginning to fade away. Huge upside to this product is that it is a very generous size (4 ounces) for the price, so I can apply it liberally and use it as an all-over serum rather than a spot treatment. It is an incredibly versatile product that can be used as an acne treatment, facial toner, daily moisturizer, scar/blemish treatment, and makeup remover, to name a few. As I mentioned, the generous size of this product allows me to use it liberally and experiment with the countless ways to apply it. Overall, very impressed with this product, its many uses, and its overall effectiveness.Sample provided by Majestic Pure for the purposes of unbiased testing and reviewing.

I have been fortunate enough to test many different power banks ranging from different designs to varying charging capacities, but this is of the best power banks I have tried. In fact, it is the one I use on a daily basis because of its simplicity, functionality, and high capacity charge.Best features of this product:+ Powerful charging capacity. With its 10,000 mAh capacity, I am able to fully charge my iPhone 6 from 0% or 1% approximately 4-5 times with the amount of stored power that this device contains. From 50+%, I can get at least 10 charges from this power bank. For comparison purposes, I have a 3,200 mAh battery case that I can only get 1 1/2 charges out of before it goes dead.+ Not sure what it is about this particular power bank, but whenever I use it to charge a completely dead iPhone, the phone turns on way faster than it would with normal charging via an outlet adapter. Awesome benefit that I didn't expect to have.+ I travel often and am usually in conferences/meetings that last all day, so I love that it only takes about 3 hours to fully charge this power bank to 100%, and I can then use it to exclusively charge my phone for the next couple of days.+ Simple, stylish, and portable. Its not too heavy for its size and capacity, so it is easy to carry around in a purse or backpack. The power bank is sturdy and substantial, and its simple design is sleek and aesthetically appealing.+ Great LCD screen/digital display to clearly indicate exact remaining charging power.Overall, this 10,000 mAh power bank is a high-quality portable charger offering several unique features that helps to give it an edge over its competitors in the highly-competitive power bank market. Highly recommend this product and would give it 10 stars if I could.Sample provided by iPowerBuddy for the purposes of unbiased testing and reviewing.

Setavan's stretch mark removal cream works quite well to diminish the appearance of stretch marks. However, keep in mind that it is not an overnight miracle cure, and will therefore take several applications before yielding visible results.Pros:+ Skin is smoother and firmer around my stomach area. The small "tiger stripes" have not completely disappeared (as expected - this is not a miracle cream), but the stretch marks are not as obvious as they used to be.+ Helps my scars fade in color and intensity. The white stretch marks on my stomach were very apparent, but after 2 weeks, they are starting to blend in and not be so obvious.+ Light fragrance that is not overwhelming like other stretch mark creams (i.e. Palmer's cocoa butter).+ Easy to apply evenly despite being much thicker than lotion.+ Subtle but visible results after 2 weeks.+ Beautiful, clean packaging that makes it look much more expensive than it actually is.Cons:- Seems to work better as a moisturizer than a cellulite remover. It reminds me of an anti-aging serum that works well to hydrate face but does not immediately attack anti-aging signs. This stretch mark cream has done wonders for my skin in terms of moisturizing and smoothing it, but has not immediately attacked stretch marks the way I would have liked it to. The scars are slowly fading, but I don't know if they will ever completely go away.Overall, this product is great and is of very high quality - it improves, lifts, and firms scarred skin, but I would have liked to see more long-lasting results.Sample provided for the purposes of unbiased testing and reviewing.

If you don't have a black 10-feet length lightning cable in your life, stop everything you are doing and buy one now. The white ones are nice, but get dirty way too quickly. I love that the black cords can better withstand daily wear and tear while still looking new. Take my word for it - once you go 10 feet, you won't go back to anything shorter than that. And once you go black, you won't go back (to a white charging cord, that is).I previously always had to rely on an extension cord in order to comfortably charge my phone while using it in bed. Extension cords are often unreliable and can sometimes stop working out of nowhere, so I began using power banks to charge my phone out of desperation. I figured I might as well try out a 10-feet cable since I was too impatient to wait 2-3 hours for my power banks to charge, so here I am now.This cable is amazing. The 10 feet length can reach across huge rooms and every single friend and family member of mine have asked where they can purchase one. After a mishap with some low-quality "Apple certified" lightning cables I purchased online that constantly popped up an error message and stopped working after 2 days, I had been reluctant to buy any chargers that weren't manufactured by Apple itself, but fortunately, this particular charging cord has restored my faith in buying non-Apple/Apple certified products.Best features of this product:- Highly convenient length. At 10 feet long, this is more than 9 times the length of a normal Apple lightning cable. So much easier to work with and use - I can actually use my phone from my bed while it is plugged into the wall without having to use an extension cord.- Black color better withstands daily wear and tear.- Good quality and comparable to Apple. I don't notice any differences in the time it takes to get a full charge.- Durable cable. I've had many Apple chargers become useless from the wire starting to wiggle out of place, but this one has held strong so far.- Most importantly, does not pop up any "accessory not supported" messages. This was my biggest concern, but I am thrilled to find that I have not gotten any error messages so far.Overall, a great value for a product that is comparable, if not superior to with its 10 feet length offering, Apple lightning cables.Sample provided for the purposes of unbiased testing and reviewing.

I'm fortunate enough to have tried many different brands of infuser bottles, but this one stands out as one of my absolute favorites. Infuser bottles all pretty much work the same - you just unscrew the infuser chamber, add whatever fruits or vegetables you want into it, twist it back in, and voila. As a result, I look for three features that typically set apart one infuser bottle from the next according to my personal preferences: 1.) design (color scheme, etc.), 2.) visibility of brand logo (I dislike when the company's logo is branded all over the bottle), and 3.) size of canister holes (some bottles' holes are large enough that pieces of fruit will escape).This particular bottle by Basily meets all of my requirements - the design is simple, the blue color scheme is versatile and unisex, there is virtually no brand logo on the bottle, and the infuser chamber is nicely sized so that pieces of fruit will not escape the canister. Overall, the design and quality are both very impressive - I love that the design is so simple and clean and just allows the functionality to speak for itself. Because there is no brand logo on the product, I typically reach for this bottle more than others because its full transparency, when combined with pretty fruits and vegetables in the middle, is very aesthetically appealing. I always get compliments at work and the gym whenever I use this bottle - water is honestly so much more refreshing and fun to drink when I am using this product. Would definitely recommend to those who are trying to decide between this product and another similar one on the market.Sample provided for the purposes of unbiased testing and reviewing.

Amazing purchase at a great price ($8.50 at the time of writing!) I'm a huge beauty junkie so my drawers are filled with products, but I have to say this clay mask is the best one I have tried. This jar is HUGE and substantially heavy, and considering you don't need to use that much each time, this jar is sure to last you months. I look forward to using this each week - it's kind of like a spa getaway within the comforts of my own home.Before using, I clean my face with a Konjac sponge to clear my face of any particles or residue that might prevent the mask from being completely smooth. I mix the product with water from the faucet, apply the mixture to my face once it comes to a good consistency, and leave it on for 20 minutes. The most difficult part about this process in my opinion is cleaning off the mask, only because it can get pretty messy. I usually wipe as much of it off with my hands as I can, then use a washcloth to clean off any remaining parts of the mask.My face always feels incredibly soft and smooth upon cleaning off the mask since this mask helps to exfoliate the dead skin cells and thoroughly clean out pores. Previously, my skincare routine consisted of an exfoliator followed by a mask, but this product has allowed me to combine those two steps into one. I have acne-prone skin and I definitely feel like this has cleaned out my pores to aid in reducing acne breakouts. Love this product and often recommend it when friends ask how I have been managing my acne breakouts.Sample provided for the purposes of unbiased testing and reviewing.
