Both main characters, Kate and Walker, are well-described, likable characters; the chemistry between them is amazing, passionately annoyed at each other one minute and passionately loving to each other the next.  Kate has picked mostly losers to date; she doesn't mean to, of course.  She decides to go to a dating site to find Mr. Right.  Ryder, Mr. Right, turns out to be Mr. Wrong, and comes with lots of baggage.  Walker is a yummy detective who saves her life more than once.  Some might think "One Night" is too short, but that doesn't take away from it being a good read; also it is not a cliff-hanger and stands alone well.  This story of romantic suspense is definitely a winner!(I was asked to read this book and write an honest review....my pleasure!)

Book 1, "Wolf Tale", introduces us to Wyatt Wolfe, a Cherokee American Indian.  He is back from war with some memory problems and determined to not put himself in a position of having to fight again.  But Wyatt is inhabited by a spirit that wants to take over his body; the only person who seems to be able to help him is Chance, a woman who's loved him all her life.Book 2, "That Which Survives" has a wonderful love story of Senna and Konnor.  They both have memory loss of large amounts of time.  This story is very complex and has lots of twists and turns and surprises.  The strange happenings are attributed to ancient times and mans quest for power and money.Book 3, "A Matter of Trust",  is maybe the strangest yet.  It is also about people searching for something very old that gives special powers to whomever holds it.  Max and Nikki dream about eachother before they meet.  This is also a complex story.

The "Titan" series just gets better and better!  In Book 7 Titan is hired to find a stolen Nuclear weapon and the codes to arm it.  Roman Hart is assigned to the case by Jared.  Meanwhile, at the CIA, Beth is given an opportunity to do field work.  She goes undercover to find out how a money launderer is involved with terrorists.  The suspense in this story is good, with surprises.  The romance between Roman and Beth is sensual and heartwarming.

Wow!!  "Papal Justice" is a treat!  This story has everything you need for excitement and suspense, The Jefferson Group in lots of action, evil terrorists, Cartel Leaders, Priests, Brothers, and The Pope.  The story starts with a massacre and kidnappings.  What follows has lots of twists and turns, surprises, and killings.  This story brings out lots of emotions, and, as usual with C.G. Cooper's books, you won't want to put it down till finished.

Every C. G. Cooper book deserves 5 stars and "Chain of Command" is no different!  There is a traitor in Congress no one knows about; murder means nothing to him if it gets him the Presidency.  His manipulation starts a chain of events that becomes noticeable when General Douglas Ellwood commits suicide.  President Zimmer asks Cal Stokes and The Jefferson Group to investigate the suicide as it relates to the proposal by Congressman Thomas Steiner to defund the Marine Corps!  This is a complex story with many characters and a truly imaginative plot!  The writing is fast-paced and crisp!

The way Will sees himself is so different from how others see him; he's sure the things he did when a teen make him somewhat of a bad person, not worthy of love.  Everything changes for him when he meets Harper and her brother Jeremy.  I LOVE this story of redemption and basic human kindness.  Will is a wonderful character; Harper is a strong woman and devoted to her brother.  Jeremy was in an accident and has limited cognitive abilities, but is always upbeat.

A Mayor of a small town has a rare disorder that in the late stages is causing him to lose his mind.  He has gone into hiding after committing atrocities, but he is not done yet.  The search for him has stopped; the police think he is dead.  Danny Sullivan has come to town to try to find him.  He hasn't forgotten Mandy who runs the local Bed and Breakfast.  But she has secrets that have her living in fear.  The romance in this story is well-done; the suspense is good.  The storyline is bizarre and sad.

If you like stories with babies, you will enjoy this good read.  Kat has a 'one weekend' love affair and finds herself pregnant and alone.  She tries to find the military man who is the father but he never responds.  Her son, Connor, is the image of his father.  This story of a war hero, grief and redemption has some good surprises for the reader.

Twin sociopaths murder 7 women before they die at 17 years of age!  Now, someone wants revenge!  This is a fascinating story of the effects of excruciating violence and evil on the family of the perpetrators.  Two parents who ignored the many signs of sociopathy, are torn apart by their shame and guilt.  Meanwhile, the families of the victims are dealing with insomnia, grieving, helplessness, rage, and despair.  Who is it who goes over the edge?  The storyline is unique and well-written by Alexa Grace.  "Profile of Retribution" stands alone well, and there is not a cliffhanger.

The author, Glenn Trust, says he is "fascinated by people" and it shows in his books; he must study human nature as his characters are well described and thought out, falling somewhere in the grey area between good and evil.  Although 'boss' Budroe is a sadistic megalomaniac who doesn't seem to have any redeeming value as a human being.  In Volume 4, he comes back to Pickham county to start a war against the law there.  He is not satisfied with having one of the largest criminal networks in the country; he wants to be world known.  Meanwhile, George Mackey and Sharon ( great romance) and Fel are waiting for George's murder trial.  As a lawman the year prior he hunted down a serial killer and killed him vigilante-style.  This is a complex thriller that will hold you enthralled till the end.  This is not a cliff-hanger; can be read alone, but is better read in order!

In Alabama, Wilson Hilliard is dying.  His friend and associate, Bernard, has helped keep him alive long enough to see some vengeance against a group of men who Wilson feels have wronged him.  We again meet Jess and Dan, who are now married and expecting a baby.  Dan is the Chief of Police and Jess is the Deputy Chief of Major Crimes.  Sylvia, the Coroner, is falling in love with Buddy, a local P.I.  When men start dying in bizarre ways, Jess and Lori have to find the killer, hopefully before Jess gives birth.  This is an interesting romantic suspense, but we never really learn what horrible deed these men have done to Wilson to deserve to be murdered.  Maybe the next book in the series will clarify this.

This is the first of Michael Prescott's books with Abby Sinclair as a main character.  She is a fascinating character, a hunter of stalkers.  Abby is a singular person, preferring to be alone and work alone.  She has a Masters in Psychology and trained for years to learn how to act, how to fight, and is technologically savvy.  Working with the Travis Protective Services, an investigative and bodyguard service, Abby does up close and personal threat assessment of stalkers.  This story is fast moving, exciting, and has lots of surprises.  The writing is, as usual with this author, crisp and imaginative.

This is Kendra Elliot at her best!!!  Excitement and romance mixed in with evil and more evil; this is a can't-put-down-until-finished story!  A small plane transporting a ferocious serial killer crashes in winter in the Cascades.  As luck would have it, the only survivor is Darrin, the serial killer.  A "hasty team" is sent out for search and rescue.  There is a nurse, a former Marshall, 3 other cops/search and rescue types and a wonderful large dog!  There are many surprises and twists and turns.  The characterizations are superb and the plot imaginative.

I'm a little surprised by the many 5 star reviews for this series co-written by Melinds Leigh and Kendra Elliot, both excellent authors.  The story is good and the mystery and romance that run thru the series are interesting.  But, as I read the novellas, I realize I'm feeling these are not the usual high quality I see from both authors.  I think it is because these 'novellas' should just be one book, in my opinion.  Book 3 highlights the relationship between Zane and Stevie, Carly's sister.  The drug problem in this area in Oregon is still killing people and the police have no idea who is manufacturing 'C-22'.  In Book 1, Bill Taylor dies of an apparent heart attack; in this book we find out he was probably murdered.

Carly is a Social Worker, working for CPS, living in Solitude, Oregon.  Seth is a highly respected cop.  Brianna is their 6 years old daughter.  Seth and Carly are separated; but their lives intertwine when a dangerous drug is being sold in their area.  This is a fast moving novella, and interesting.  This is, however, Book 2 of 4, all roughly the same size, and all about this small town area in Oregon.  I wouldn't call this a cliffhanger, but it does give a feeling of being one book, cut into 4 short stories.

This book is a fun read!!  It may not be very realistic, but then it is fiction and meant to entertain!  This is a complex, engrossing, and thrilling story of not just one vigilante, but a whole group of government sanctioned vigilantes.  They are called "Discreet Activities Covert Team."  Jonathan Addley is the head of this secret team, even though his title is "Director of Police Relations".  Jonathan discovers something shocking about a millionaire and enlists his help.

WOW!!  "Ten years of research, six years of training, and three years of getting ready for this moment".  Allie repeats this mantra to herself frequently during the day from hell.  Ten years ago, Allie's sister was sadistically murdered by a serial killer.  Now, she has used herself as bait to find him.  This is a smooth, fast-moving, monstrous thriller that will grab you where fear lives in your soul!  I would love to read more books about Allie and Apollo......please, Mr. Sisavath!

You will love the Wilde Family, but Mia is my favorite; she really is wild and sexy and funny.  Cameron is sedate and dependable, and an experienced P.I.  Everyone thinks they hate eachother; they don't.  In fact, they have amazing chemistry, and one night they give in to the need for eachother.  Then Mia receives certain pictures, and everything changes.  This is an exciting and heartwarming story, maybe a tiny bit predictable, but a good, quick read!

If you like horses or horse racing, you should be reading Bev Pettersen's romantic mysteries.  "Color My Horse" takes place mostly at the 'backside' of a racetrack.  The characters are full bodied, well-described, and for the most part, lovable; especially Mark, the trainer, has such a warm heart and is a sucker for a pretty girl or horse!  The mystery is not predictable and the romance is heartwarming.

Loved it. Just finished the series today. The only complaint I have is the ending. The ending isn't bad, mind you. It's just that I expected more. I think probably it all depends on whether they continue the series.I like that it can show violence without it being overly graphic. I mean, there is blood, but we're not talking anything worse than you'd see on regular television. There is slight nudity, but in only two episodes. The main thing here is the story. It's driven, you'll find yourself holding your breath and oddly enough, seeing the perspective for even the bad guys.It is what it said it is. Imagine if we lost WWII and if both Japan's and Germany's ideology continued on. Imagine if there were a treaty between them to bend certain rules, like Japan agreed to anti-semitism. This comes at the perfect time. A time of terror. A time where innocents die and we have to decide for ourselves what we're willing to sacrifice to stay free.On the lighter side, I think the scene stealer is the antique dealer. He is hilarious but still so cool. I would have liked to see more of him. The actor was simply amazing.I truly hope there will be a season 2. Enjoy!

This is great and inexpensive. Granted, I question the legality of it all, but the NFL's price gouging makes this patch affordable. One tip though because I know this will come up eventually. Please be sure to read the product information and measure whatever you're planning on using it for, to make sure it's the right fit.This is surprisingly a great quality patch. It looks just like what the picture shows. Though it says it's an iron-on patch, I don't recommend only ironing it on and expecting it to stay. Thick patches don't usually do very well as iron-ons. You could iron it on where you want it, then stitch it on or use fabric glue instead. Stitching is your best bet.All in all I'm very VERY pleased. I bought these to make a football jersey for my black lab who loves the Seahawks. ;) I want to put it on the jersey front, where the neck would be (or on the back, so others can see it better). Glad I found this!

These are great and inexpensive. Granted, I question the legality of it all, but the NFL's price gouging makes these patches affordable. I was disappointed in one review where they said that they're too big and it took over a month to arrive. Well, yeah. It says so right there in the product information. Please be sure to read it and measure whatever you're planning on using it for to make sure it's the right fit.These are surprisingly great quality. They look just like what the picture shows. Though it says it's an iron-on patch, I don't recommend only ironing it on and expecting it to stay. Thick patches don't usually do very well as iron-ons. You could iron it on where you want it, then stitch it on or use fabric glue instead. Stitching is your best bet.All in all I'm very VERY pleased. I bought these to make a football jersey for my black lab who loves the Seahawks. ;) I want to put them above each sleeve, but finding a mirror imaged patch was next to impossible. Glad I found these.Go Hawks!!! ;)

I can't believe the reviews I'm seeing. This is not a body spray. It's basically water, with a small scent of something of which is a total mystery. My daughter is a lavender freak. I told her to close her eyes and I'd spray it on her and I wanted her to tell me what it smelled like. Her answer? Water. Yep, it smells more like water than it does like any scent at all. I could just put a few drops of essential oil into a bottle and add water to get an even better scent. No. I'm not kidding. Believe me, I wish I were.I'm so disappointed. I will never buy this again. I really miss the spray I used to buy that is no longer manufactured. I can't think of the name of it right now, but it had a fresh lavender scent that was light and airy. Too bad, this will not qualify as a satisfactory replacement.

I got the largest size and it still didn't fit my medium sized dog. Yes, the measurements are posted and mine fit the measurement for size 5, but she could get it past her toes. The depth is small and it doesn't list what that is. It's a really inexpensive set, so it may be worth it to go ahead an order set, to if it fits yours. In any case, these are for small dogs only. No mediums or anything.It ships from China, which I know is bad for some people. It does however tell you it will take a long time to get here, so that shouldn't surprise anyone buying them. Still, expect you to forget about them and then be surprised when you do receive them. Well, that's what happened to me.They're surprisingly well made for the price. I mean, the quality isn't Martha Stewart, but it is your simple standard. I was expecting something badly sewn and was pleasantly surprised when I got them, even if they were small. My daughter works for a vet and all of the employees have dogs, so she took them to work to give them to someone who wanted them.All in all, it's a great deal if you have a small dog. Just don't buy them if your dog is medium or larger.

I think we are all well aware of what the stories are basically about. These are not Disney versions, of course. They don't necessarily live "happily ever after" and many of the stories are downright cruel and frightening. That said, I've been in search of the ultimate version of this book. As of the date of the writing of this review, I have not yet found that. Because I collected a number of popular Kindle versions (all of these reviews are based on Kindle versions), I thought I'd compare them here so you can choose which one best fits your needs.A few of things to know first.1. I view illustrated books on my desktop, so when I talk about illustrations, imagine them being much larger than on a tablet.2. When I refer to an "ATOC" I mean an active table of contents. That is, a TOC (table of contents) that has clickable links so you can go directly to a title story (or chapter) in the book. To me, that is crucial in any Kindle edition.3. Why am I linking to each one and not saying which one is the edition you're looking at right now? I realized that some editions contained reviews that had the exact same link as other reviews in some books. In the comments of this review, I will provide a link to illustrate what I mean. In any case, the point is that you can see the link for the exact edition I was speaking of so it's very clear.4. I rated the book 5 stars and that's because of the original text of the Grimm brothers' writing. Each edition would get a different rating, which is listed in it's comparison review.---Grimm's Fairy Tales (Illustrated)This edition has an intro, biographies of the brothers and illustrations. It has 4 main issues that detract from its usefulness:1. It contains only 62 of the original 211 stories which is unacceptable, at least for me.2. The images are very washed out so they are not clear at all. In fact, I'd say most are unclear. They are also not as large as one would expect. I would imagine them being near-useless on a tablet.3. There is neither an ATOC nor TOC. The best you have is a list of stories it contains (without page numbers) and that is all.4. Finally, paragraphs are only single spaced without indentations. For this reason they run together. That does not mean that the book is one large paragraph, it's just that there is only a single line break and not a double. For sentences that end at the left side of the page, it will look like one long paragraph.This one gets 3-stars at best. Its best feature is that it appears to not have many spelling or grammatical typos, which run rampant in Kindle editions. This could be a better book if they would simply reformat it and make an active TOC.Grimm's Fairy TalesThis edition has an ATOC but no other special features such as an intro, biographies nor any illustrations. It is simply bare bones prose.This version is similar to the one above in that it has single spaced paragraphs, but thankfully each paragraph has an indentation so it is easy to spot new paragraphs. I do like the text formatting better than the one above. It highlights rhymes very well.It's main downfall is that it too only contains 62 of the original 211 stories.This one also only gets 3-stars. There is no feature here that is all that worthy. You're missing most of the stories and you get no extras.Grimm's (Complete) Fairy Tales (Annotated)This edition has an ATOC, introduction and biographies of the brothers. It however does not have any illustrations, sadly. That would make it near perfect, except for the annotated thing, which I'll come back to.This edition is the most exhaustive of the three. It has 210 of the original 211 stories, which means if you want all the stories, this is the book for you. Most of its text formatting is better than the others as well. Paragraphs are double spaced, but the thing I don't like about it is that it doesn't highlight rhymes like the previous version.The one very serious problem I have with it is its claim of being annotated, when it very clearly is not. There's not a single annotation throughout the book. I'm not sure why they claim it to be so. Perhaps the print edition is annotated? In any case, I can say with the utmost authority that the Kindle edition is definitely not. What a disappointment!This one gets 4-stars simply because it does contain all of the stories. It looks like one story may be missing (I'm not going to go through all 211 to see which it is, but it could be that one was combined or a number was missed. Either way, it's the most complete version.---All in all the one I find most useful (so far), even if it's lacking, is the so-called "annotated" version. If you're wanting illustrations, then I would get both that one and the first one. The second one is, in my opinion, the least useful.The truth is that at the time of this writing there is not yet a perfect edition in Kindle. Perhaps one day. If you find one (that is low priced) let me know in the comments and I'll take a look at it.Hopefully this helped you in your choice. If not, please let me know how I can improve it.

I think we are all well aware of what the stories are basically about. These are not Disney versions, of course. They don't necessarily live "happily ever after" and many of the stories are downright cruel and frightening. That said, I've been in search of the ultimate version of this book. As of the date of the writing of this review, I have not yet found that. Because I collected a number of popular Kindle versions (all of these reviews are based on Kindle versions), I thought I'd compare them here so you can choose which one best fits your needs.A few of things to know first.1. I view illustrated books on my desktop, so when I talk about illustrations, imagine them being much larger than on a tablet.2. When I refer to an "ATOC" I mean an active table of contents. That is, a TOC (table of contents) that has clickable links so you can go directly to a title story (or chapter) in the book. To me, that is crucial in any Kindle edition.3. Why am I linking to each one and not saying which one is the edition you're looking at right now? I realized that some editions contained reviews that had the exact same link as other reviews in some books. In the comments of this review, I will provide a link to illustrate what I mean. In any case, the point is that you can see the link for the exact edition I was speaking of so it's very clear.4. I rated the book 5 stars and that's because of the original text of the Grimm brothers' writing. Each edition would get a different rating, which is listed in it's comparison review.---Grimm's Fairy Tales (Illustrated)This edition has an intro, biographies of the brothers and illustrations. It has 4 main issues that detract from its usefulness:1. It contains only 62 of the original 211 stories which is unacceptable, at least for me.2. The images are very washed out so they are not clear at all. In fact, I'd say most are unclear. They are also not as large as one would expect. I would imagine them being near-useless on a tablet.3. There is neither an ATOC nor TOC. The best you have is a list of stories it contains (without page numbers) and that is all.4. Finally, paragraphs are only single spaced without indentations. For this reason they run together. That does not mean that the book is one large paragraph, it's just that there is only a single line break and not a double. For sentences that end at the left side of the page, it will look like one long paragraph.This one gets 3-stars at best. Its best feature is that it appears to not have many spelling or grammatical typos, which run rampant in Kindle editions. This could be a better book if they would simply reformat it and make an active TOC.Grimm's Fairy TalesThis edition has an ATOC but no other special features such as an intro, biographies nor any illustrations. It is simply bare bones prose.This version is similar to the one above in that it has single spaced paragraphs, but thankfully each paragraph has an indentation so it is easy to spot new paragraphs. I do like the text formatting better than the one above. It highlights rhymes very well.It's main downfall is that it too only contains 62 of the original 211 stories.This one also only gets 3-stars. There is no feature here that is all that worthy. You're missing most of the stories and you get no extras.Grimm's (Complete) Fairy Tales (Annotated)This edition has an ATOC, introduction and biographies of the brothers. It however does not have any illustrations, sadly. That would make it near perfect, except for the annotated thing, which I'll come back to.This edition is the most exhaustive of the three. It has 210 of the original 211 stories, which means if you want all the stories, this is the book for you. Most of its text formatting is better than the others as well. Paragraphs are double spaced, but the thing I don't like about it is that it doesn't highlight rhymes like the previous version.The one very serious problem I have with it is its claim of being annotated, when it very clearly is not. There's not a single annotation throughout the book. I'm not sure why they claim it to be so. Perhaps the print edition is annotated? In any case, I can say with the utmost authority that the Kindle edition is definitely not. What a disappointment!This one gets 4-stars simply because it does contain all of the stories. It looks like one story may be missing (I'm not going to go through all 211 to see which it is, but it could be that one was combined or a number was missed. Either way, it's the most complete version.---All in all the one I find most useful (so far), even if it's lacking, is the so-called "annotated" version. If you're wanting illustrations, then I would get both that one and the first one. The second one is, in my opinion, the least useful.The truth is that at the time of this writing there is not yet a perfect edition in Kindle. Perhaps one day. If you find one (that is low priced) let me know in the comments and I'll take a look at it.Hopefully this helped you in your choice. If not, please let me know how I can improve it.

I see plenty of complaints of formatting and picture size, but perhaps those were previous versions. Whomever formatted the book can upload updates. I believe a number of older reviews probably had earlier editions. The one thing Amazon needs to be sure of is notifying customers of better editions.Though I have not checked rhyme-by-rhyme (I mean, there are just so many!) it appears to have each rhyme and every illustration from the original 1916 edition. I like to read illustrated books on my desktop (Kindle has a desktop app so you can do that) and the images appear to be large enough to see just fine. I would imagine on a smaller tablet, maybe not so much. For this reason, I recommend using a desktop for this book.The rhymes are well transcribed. I imagine that the text here was copied from Project Gutenberg, which offers Kindle editions for free. It is completely readable. I see a lot of complaints of only getting the first few sentences, but that is no longer the case. It could be that those users were unfamiliar with the original text and assumed that the two-line rhymes were incomplete, when in fact they actually were.The one thing that is definitely wrong, hence the 4-stars instead of the full 5, is that the text was centered throughout the book. That is the one thing that seriously irritates me to no end. The centeritis that floats throughout the world wide web. I cannot fathom why writers love it so much. It makes words appear more jumbled than they actually are and it is definitely not aesthetically pleasing, in my opinion. I hate it. It irks me because the author, Ms. Wright, published hers aligned most of the text to the left, but some with some in-between lines with an indent. Clearly, text alignment in the original was well thought out.Still, that is my only complaint. It's a great electronic edition and is a bargain for the price. I would like, however, to echo getting an additional hard copy for children too. They'll find it fun to look at.

It's a great game. I just finished all the Agatha Christie ones and that's been my entire hidden object experience until this one. I was really surprised at how different it was. As others have mentioned, there are two ways to play. I took the more laid back way. What surprised me most is that it's not just hidden objects. In fact, there really aren't all that many hidden object screens. The majority of the game has logic puzzles. I saw a lot of reviews mentioning "puzzles" but that didn't explain to me what kind of puzzles they were. Some are memory games, some are matching several shapes with other several shapes (it's a bit more challenging than it sounds), some are connecting different things by swapping tiles (sometimes wires, sometimes book covers), some are tracing lines by numbers with a total number not to be exceeded and some are creating shapes when the original is distorted. Those are just a few of the many types of puzzles there are.The story is strange and pagan based. It just wasn't all that compelling for me, but that's okay. The game part was fun, and that's what matters most. The one thing I didn't like were the way quests were organized. It's inside a large city and you slowly make your way through the city. I suppose you could say each level is a new part of the city. The thing is, you'll be on one side of town, then it'll tell you have to go to the X part of the city to find an object. You then have to go all the way back (it's like a maze) and then it has the nerve to tell you you now have to go to yet another part of the city. Couldn't they just give you a shopping list? I would say a large percentage of the game play time is going back and forth through the city and that annoyed me, which is why I've given it only the 4 stars. Had that not been an issue, then I would've given it 5.The graphics are okay. We're not talking HD now, but it's quite beautiful. I played it on my Win 7 laptop, but it did have moments of lagging. I don't think it's my computer because I didn't have this problem with the other games. I suspect that the main character does most (if not all) of the female voices, but even so, it's enjoyable.All in all, I do recommend it. It's definitely worth the $3 (for the download) that it is, at the time of this writing.

I will say that the liquid part of the product works wonderfully. It has some interesting ingredients (Water, Coco Betaine, Disodium Cocoyl Glutamate, Glycerin, Honey,  Colloidal Oatmeal Lonicera Japonica (Honeysuckle) Extract, Potassium Sorbate, Sodium Benzoate) too. I put it on my dog and it really did help her itching.She has environmental allergies and is allergic to grass. Unfortunately grass is just something she will have to live with. I've tried a number of things. I even tried a canine cortisone spray but was aghast when I realized it had alcohol in it. Alcohol?! What moron put alcohol in an anti-inflammatory?! Poor thing. I tossed that one quickly.I really haven't found anything that truly helps (I've even Googled home remedies and tried so many of them). I have found that using this really does help her. The problem though is the sprayer. The sprayer doesn't work after one or two uses, so be prepared to pour into your own sprayer. For this reason it loses two stars. I have run into this problem before with other spray products and there is simply no excuse for it. Since it is a repeat offender, there is no reason this should be happening. Clearly, they're not testing their end product and that is bad business.I also want to say that the price here is too expensive. I got mine for about $6 at Petsmart. Check your local stores first. Just saying.===========Update: Just after posting this I contacted the manufacturer about the problem. Within one hour they responded saying they would send me another sprayer and I had it within two days. I have since upgraded this to 5 stars. It's entirely possible that this was just a defective item. If I don't post back, you'll know that the new sprayer worked. Cheers!

There is really only one thing I want from a cookbook: recipes. I don't care about the preaching on food safety or environmental concerns. Really. I don't. If I wanted a book on that, I'd buy it. What I want are recipes and just get to the recipes! This book resorts to this very fluff in order to fill the book.As for the recipes, I was very excited to see that this boasts recipes for all seasons. I was buying this because I'm taking a winter trip and would like to have a romantic winter picnic. I used to live in Alaska, so I'm not talking that kind, but this time it'll be in Socal and I live along the Gulf Coast. You see that winter weather here is more like Autumn for most.Anyway, I selected this book for its winter ideas. I was really disappointed to find that though this book does have a few all seasons recipes, they are very few. Summer has only 7% less than what Spring, Autumn and Winter have combined. I'm not talking about number of pages or recipes, but Kindle gives us percentages, so I'm talking percentage wise of each of those chapters.If you're wanting a frugal picnicking cookbook, then this is not the one for you. From Grilled Salmon Fillets to Artichoke Salad to Barbecued Butterflied Lamb, these are not for budget households. The foods are expensive, but they are also very elegant and upscale. As far as that is concerned, you have to decide for yourself which you prefer.Another thing is the amount of alcoholic drinks without substitutions is a problem for many. My ex couldn't drink any alcohol (he was an alcoholic) and I think because of my many years him, I just don't have a taste for it. Either way, it is disappointing that there were not some creative suggestions for drinks that didn't have alcohol. Obviously not all drinks have alcohol but each menu does suggest it and does not suggest an alternative.Now that's the bad. How about the good? The good is that the recipes do sound original (there are a few in there that aren't; like the chocolate chip cookie recipe -- I've made the same cookies for over 30 years and my kids, now grown, still act like children when they eat them). There are a lot of things in there that I had not thought about, as far as picnic foods. Many sound very good and I look forward to trying the high number of summer recipes provided. As mentioned above, there are a lot of elegant dishes so if you're out to impress someone, this is a good source.I have both a paperback copy and a Kindle version. I saw where someone complained about the Kindle version's format. The formatting is actually very good. The problem stems from the size of the Kindle. If you turn it where it's longer width-wise, it'll format much better. Also, turn off highlighting if you have it on. That often obscures part of what you're trying to read. Anyway, I don't usually use my cookbooks on my Kindle, but on my Kindle for PC, which makes it even easier to see. The one thing that I don't like about the Kindle is its lack of photos and illustrations. Gee, I guess I need to check my paperback because I can't remember if it has them or not. I won't say since I'm uncertain.All in all, it's helpful but not the book I was hoping it would be. The recipes do sound delicious and if that's all you're after (and money isn't an issue) then this is the book for you. If you're looking for recipes that are outside of Summer, then look into other books first and compare to this one. If you're on a budget, then skip it entirely.

I have this speaker that uses a cord and I'm very happy with it, but I was ready to move on to something cordless such as a bluetooth. I read the glowing reviews here and ordered it with trepidation. I've seen a lot of glowing reviews and then I get a piece of garbage, but I've also seen a lot of bad reviews and struck gold. You never really know sometimes.Anyway, it paired easily with my S2, but it did take a minute before it would show up. Once paired, I was amazed at its sound. I thought the sound on my other one was grand, but this is just unbelievable. It's designed so that you don't have to have two speakers. I see a lot of questions about using more than one, but it isn't necessary nor designed to do so.It gets quite loud and I have no static or shaking sound at all when it's fully turned up. The documentation says it'll last 4 hours via bluetooth and 12 via aux cord. Mine lasts longer, so far.  In any case, I was so impressed I bought 4 more and gave them out for Christmas this year. Every single one of them absolutely loved it! They were really impressed and one asked me if I spent a ton of money on it because of its quality.One thing to note. Of all of us, only one required a PIN number. The number is on the bottom of the speaker. It doesn't say "PIN number" but is a 4-digit number. It's also located on the bottom of the plastic jar-container as well.To be honest, I was really happy with my other speaker, but I am so happy I decided to upgrade. This is just a great speaker!

Love these things! They are so useful for a variety of purposes. I got these to store not just files, but to cover in fabric for out-in-the-open storage. They look great on shelves, dressers without mirrors, buffet furniture, etc., so long as they're covered in fabric or something.Being a nurse, I have a lot of experience with file archives and these are definitely comparable to the commercially made containers. They're very sturdy, are easy to put together and I think the price here makes them a great value.

At the time of this writing, the product information does NOT list that it is 100% polyester. I can scarcely believe that many have used high heat settings using this, because you should never, EVER, use high heat on polyester. That makes this useless, as a pressing cloth. I suppose I'll use it instead as a wide-meshed cheese cloth, but wait, it can't take boiling water either.All in all, I do not recommend buying this. [[B0051EONNU This one is much better]], but does have its own flaw. It will require an adhesive seam to stop it from unraveling. Otherwise, it is the perfect cloth.

The price for this is perfect. You can use it on all heat levels from very hot and steamy to a low iron. It prevents shine and protects the fabric, just as it is designed to do.It's only problem is the unraveling. It WILL unravel, unless you make a seam with it. Once it begins to unravel (which was very soon after purchase, I think I used it twice), it deteriorates very quickly. I'm about to use an adhesive seam and I'll see if it stops it. If I don't post back, then it means it worked.Now I did try buying [[B001I1P48S this one]] but the product description (at the time of this writing) does not say what it is made of. To my dismay, it is 100% polyester. I'm amazed that reviewers are so pleased saying it can take the heat very well. Polyester isn't supposed to take high heat. Needless to say, that one was tossed to the side and maybe I'll use it as wide mesh cheese cloth or something.As for this one, I can vouch for the heat settings. Works like a charm! It only loses 1 star because it should have been seamed.
This is just your standard tracing wheel, but it does exactly what I want it to do. It is serrated, which is always welcome because they mark much better.All in all I'm very pleased.

Not exactly the ideal set. At the time I bought this, I couldn't see the wheel very well and assumed wrongly, that it was serrated. It isn't. On the surface that sounds okay, but serrated works much better with tracing paper.I don't know why others are having pen trouble, but mine isn't dried up. My guess is that it's not really dried completely, but has retreated and needs to settle toward the top.One tip that may help with some of you is to store markers (pens as well) with the writing end facing downwards in a cup. Many turn it the other way, where the writing end is up. That actually dates back to leaky refillable pens, in breast pockets. Today though, you're less likely and besides, the cup won't matter so long as you're not using Grandmother's china. The problem with the upward issue is that the ink retreats backwards resulting either in what appears to be a dried up marker, or a pen that takes a few minutes to write.Usually, you can work that out by storing markers in cups with the writing end down and then the ink will move toward the writing end, dampening the tip. I'd let it sit like that overnight and then try it again. You may be surprised at how well it works after all!Anyway, I digress. All in all this is an okay set, but honestly had I realized the wheel wasn't serrated, I likely wouldn't have bought it.

I need this not for jewelry, but felting over wires (I'm using Sarafina tutorials for making movable felted animals). I didn't have a pair of craft pliers, only my husband's which are covered in gunk. This was a little cheaper than this more popular model, but there was (at the time of this writing) no size description. I preferred to know what I was getting.These are not the same size as a standard pair of pliers, but are not tiny. They're perfect for my needs and I'm so excited that I bought them. My fingers were getting cramped (and injured) doing it the old finger way.All in all I'm very pleased. This is a great smaller-than-average plier that is still big enough to handle easily.

I live in a first strike hurricane zone and to put it plainly, Katrina took off my roof. That said, as a child who grew up during the Cold War, I never expected to live past 30. I was sure that we'd be nuked. Then when Orson Welles warned us that Nostradamus predicted 1998 to be the end, I fully believed that it would be. It was all nonsense, yes, but here in my mid-forties now, I still have a nagging worry that something may happen. Not zombies, but something.All that said, my husband and I are looking to rely less and less on technology and more and more on ourselves and nature. My hope was that this book would be a good start in the right direction. It's too bad that it was disappointing.I have read that blistering review here that had some reasonable arguments and some not so much. For example, it is true that there are fire bans in certain parts of this country but in a serious disaster, police will be incapable of enforcing those bans during a serious crisis. Survival is key, despite fire bans. I'm not going to die because someone has banned fires.My problem however is with all the advice but at the same time all the secrets. For example she says (not exact words but you'll get the meaning) "You can buy a certain manual washing machine for $60," and leaves it at that. A certain one? How do I find it? Where did she see it? We'll never know because she does not share any of her resources. I mean none of them.How many of us get books on hobbies and in the back it has a list of online stores where you can get supplies? This is supposed to be a book about disaster readiness and she doesn't have a list on where to obtain supplies. Really?I appreciate her efforts and there is indeed a lot of helpful information. I just think she needs to share a little more of her knowledge that she was unwilling to do for whatever reason. I seriously doubt product (or business) placement applies here, for the very reason those craft and hobby books ARE able to share their suggested suppliers.Perhaps this can be an addition in a future edition. My advice is that it IS handy, but get a book that has resources too.

I initially was going to move on to another model when a review that had a tip on the problem caught my eye. I read the comments which praised the review, saying how helpful that was. With renewed enthusiasm I clicked the Add to Cart button then bought it.I'm sorry I did. To begin with I believe that the review that has the helpful tip was a different model. That review specifically says button. This current model doesn't have a button but a switch. Holding this type of switch down for 5-10 seconds does absolutely nothing. It's like this typical household switch, which would not respond to holding it down for any length of time.I'm sorry to say this, but it's going back. I had high hopes for it but alas it is as defective as many others appear to be.

I bought mine at a walk-in store, rather than on Amazon. I wanted a cooler that was big enough to hold my lunch, some water, and whatnot while I was out on errand days or whatever. I have a great system now that helps me avoid a drive-thru fix, that I always really REALLY want to get.I hate those soft-sided and padded coolers. They are not nearly as well insulated as the hard coolers are. Also, Igloo has never failed me as far as coolers go. It's a brand that I trust, which says a lot coming from me. I don't believe I've ever actually said that before.I bought this salad keeper, this sandwich keeper and these freezer things. I alternate between sandwiches and salads, so I only use one of those. I toss in one of the freezer things, either  a salad or a sandwich and a bottle of water, and I'm all good.I love them all! It's perfect for a great meal and is just the right size for me.As for the 6-pack thing, I can't say. It's definitely small enough that it probably wouldn't hold that many and then don't even think about adding ice or an ice pack, of some sort. However for me that didn't matter because that's not why I needed it.All in all it's perfect for me, and I'm very pleased.

I will have to agree with a couple of reviews here, so let me address those first.To begin with, I didn't buy mine here on Amazon. I was at Walmart and found them there. I was looking for a sandwich keeper that had a freezer container. I had previously bought this salad keeper (which I did buy here on Amazon) and I fell in absolute love with it. I wondered if I could find a similar container for sandwiches. When I was at Walmart, I remembered about it and looked for one. The thing is, it's cheaper at Walmart, much cheaper ($8.97).It's also true that this has absolutely too many lids. The top of the freezer tray is sectioned, so that the vegetable containers sit within those sections. Each separate sectional vegetable container (which again, sits in the top of the freezer tray) has a lid. Why? Why not separate the freezer tray from the vegetable container seat and use one lid to cover the sectional portion of the box? If they did it that way, there would only be 2 lids, but instead there are double that amount. Still, that's only two extra so it's not a horrible thing.This is still a great container, despite its shortcomings. The freezer gel stays frozen for a couple of hours without a cooler, and just about all day with one. It's great for picnics with the kids or whatever.I bought this small cooler and these freezer things. On errand days or days out, I just toss in the freezer things, my sandwich and some water, then I take off. This helps me avoid a run at a fast food place while I'm out and about.All pieces are dishwasher safe and all pieces are microwave safe, EXCEPT for the freezer tray. That's easy though because it doesn't need heating anyway.I sure wish they had these when I was still working. Why does all the cool stuff come out as I get older?========== UPDATE ==========I wanted to add a comment about the Sistema product someone else recommends. I personally don't see how it's better at all. Where is the freezer gel pack? What happens when you've rinsed your carrots and you put them in the container? Does it leak all over everything else, including your sandwich? It looks like it does. Then what if I want to have pudding and veggies at the same time?No. I don't like that one at all and now I'm rethinking my lid complaint. I could even put soup in one of the sectional containers and if it were all one piece, then it would spill into another section.Yep, this is definitely the better option... for me anyway.

These are so cute and they fit very well. It's spandex, so it's good and stretchy. It's great for exercising and such. I love them!I also bought this dress in fuchsia and wear these shorts (in plum) underneath. I'm loving it! They're quite versatile and I'm very happy.

I bought the fuchsia dress (note that they have spelled the color wrong, as many do), to wear at the beach, over my swimsuit. It's absolutely adorable and would look great as a regular dress too, except that it's just a wee bit sheer. I would feel the need to wear a slip under it if I were to use it as a dress, but if you like sheer then you'll be okay. I also bought these shorts to wear under it too. They're cute together!It's soft and comfortable too. The fabric doesn't breathe well though, so on hot days it'll be sticky, but any spandex clothing would. It's too bad that spandex isn't breathable, like cotton. Woe is the earth on that score.I've seen where someone complained about it being cheap, but hey... you get what you pay for. Surely no one thinks they're going to get a Donna Karan for the price we're paying here, right? That said, don't expect to be using it with machinery. It IS sheer and it IS spandex so it will rip with sharp objects. Of course, most dresses would.If I had to list a complaint, it's probably the banded breast area. I'm rather buxom and so my girls are not fully covered by the band. For you well endowed women such as myself, go larger. You can always hem the bottom and take in the straps. That's one tip I wish I had known about.Other than that, I'm very pleased.

This is a lovely scent! I was at Penney's today and bought mine. It is truly beautiful and has a soft scent. It isn't overpowering at all.I saw a review by someone who complained that you couldn't smell the vanilla. You're not really supposed to. Lavender by itself plain is a bit on the spicy side and is strong. Vanilla sort of relaxes the scent and tones it down. This perfume definitely qualifies for Lavender and Vanilla scent.I have worn Estee Lauder's "Beautiful" for 30 years, but now I have a new signature perfume and it is this one. That says a lot, I think. :)

These are your standard stretchy pants. They're made to feel like cotton and they fit perfectly. Just be sure to check how long 21" is on your legs. I actually bought these for my mother and they were mid-calf on her. The photo does show mid-calf, so keep that in mind.All in all it was just your standard leggings, but I like all the color options, which is hard to find a lot of the time.

These are exactly what the doctor ordered for me. There really isn't a whole lot to say about them. They're the right size, they're heavy duty and will block out what is written behind it. They run through the printer just fine and so forth.One thing for you OpenOffice users... You can also download the MS Office template at their website and it imports just fine into OO. I personally don't like the border they have on the templates, but that's easily fixable by deleting them, if you're like me.All in all, this was a great buy for us.

The size of the purse portion is just about perfect. It'll hold my Galaxy S2 and credit cards, which is exactly what I was looking for. The problem I have is the shoulder strap. It is absolutely way too short and is obviously NOT a women's size as the product title says at the time of this writing. It goes all the way up to my armpit, I kid you not.At least you can buy a sufficient strap or use an old one from a purse or even a camera case. Still, I wish that (again, at the time of the writing of this review) it was more clear on the length of the shoulder strap.
I'm not sure what happened, but it didn't fit my phone. That is, it snapped on fine enough, but the phone ports don't line up with the openings on the case.

According to Amazon, I bought this back in June of '10. Mine is still working for me, as though I bought yesterday. It was one of the best buys I've ever made, but I need to explain a couple of things.The manufacturer says to NOT use this with temperatures over 550. Most silicone mats cannot tolerate temperatures over 500, so I make my limit 475, just in case. It's a good idea to verify any temperature with an oven thermometer (this is the one I have) because not all ovens are made alike and sometimes the temperature fluctuates.It is easy to get clean. Everything pretty much slides right off. Occasionally there is something unusual that will be a little stubborn, but soaking it in warm soapy water usually does the trick with those. However, it IS dishwasher safe.Also, you can cut it if it's too big. There are some silicone mats that don't allow cutting, but this one is okay, according to the manufacturer (the link for the spec sheet is the first comment for this review).I see questions for gas ovens, but I wouldn't suggest it unless you contact the manufacturer. It's better to be safe than sorry.All in all I'm very pleased. I highly recommend it.

I bought the Salmon 13.2-oz (at my local pet store, but will buy here in future) for my dog's monthly flea/heart prevention, which requires a meal when taken. She is allergic to just about anything and everything and also has a sensitive stomach. She's an 80 lb. dog and I give her 1/2 of a can before I give her the medication, then the remaining half after.The first time I gave it to her she danced around so happily you'd think I was giving her a prime rib fresh off the grill! She loved it and it's super healthy for her too. So now once a month she'll get this as a special treat. :)I sure wish I'd known about this. My elderly dog who died a couple of years ago may have lasted longer if I could have mixed this in his food. This is great for dogs who are sickly or whatnot.The important thing to know is that this shouldn't be their only food. We wouldn't just live off of tomatoes alone, and they shouldn't live off of this alone either. Just a FYI.

I don't know what picture they had before, but the the board I got looks exactly like the board in the current picture. The size is perfect too and is standard for ribbon memo boards, that being 20-inches by 18-inches. There are coupled sawtooth picture hangers on the back so you can hang it lengthwise or widthwise and one large plastic hanger that you can use to hang on a hook. In other words, you can easily hang it any which way you want.Mine easily went up with a couple of Hercules hooks, that I borrowed from a friend. I have never tried them before now, but love them so much that I just ordered some for myself! In any case, unless you use a hook, you'll need two nails (or hangers or whatever) to hang it up.Below is how I hang it evenly, when I have no help. You see, coupled sawtooth hangers are often attached unevenly, which makes leveling difficult. I've been doing this for over 30 years (my husband was Army so we moved a lot and he was always gone, such as Gulf War I, etc.) and I figured out a trick that I wish I had figured out so much earlier, in my life. I will share it with you here.1. On a flat surface, turn the board over so that the back is facing up. Make sure that you are using the edge that you want to hang.2. Lay a long piece of paper over BOTH of the sawtooth hangers on the back edge. Note that a standard sheet will not be long enough, you can either tape together two sheets of paper, or use wax paper, parchment, etc. You just need to have it long enough to cover both.3. Do a pencil rubbing over each sawtooth. If you don't know what a pencil rubbing is, Google it. It's really easy but does require a pencil. Amazon won't allow me to post links so you can see what it is.4. Mark a dot under each rubbing, where your nail will go. That is, exactly the spot where the sawtooth hanger will land on your future, but presently imaginary, nail.5. Tape (use a mild adhesive tape, like cellophane, but not heavy duty such as duct tape) the paper on the wall. You can now move it around, until the line-up is right.6. Use a ruler to line up both dots that you drew below the hanger. If you have a leveler (they're cheap at Walmart) you can put that on top of your ruler, to ensure accuracy. Usually though, I just eyeball it.7. Nail your nails (or insert your hook if using the hooks I mentioned above) right through each dot on the paper.8. Once both are in, carefully tear the paper off the nail (I say carefully because sometimes smaller nails come right out with the paper) and then hang your board.Oh and during #6, you can alternatively draw a line connecting your dots and then use the leveler to line up the line when you tap it to the wall. Either way works.Good luck and hope this helps!

I have to admit that I initially bought this for two reasons.1. I would like to have my own chicken coop (very soon).2. Cookbooks are always a plus.I will say that I wish she had written more memoir-ish stuff, hence the 4 stars instead of 5. It seems that the actual focus of the book is on recipes, rather than memoirs, and that's too bad. I love animals and hearing about farm life (if you agree you simply HAVE to read James Herriot's All Creatures Great and Small series books). When I was a child, I visited my father's farm every summer and I hated it at the time. As a 6-year-old I saw it as a symbol of the divorce of my parents and I resented watching him with his new wife (who incidentally divorced him a number of years later). I surely wish now that I'd had a more open mind about the farm (not necessarily her), but I digress.Janice Cole's stories are sweet, amusing and highly informative. For example she sends a gentle, but strong, message that chickens need protein and should not be vegetarian. Yay for her, for not succumbing to what society wants to hear. I love that!The recipes are organized by what is in season. That is pure genius, in my opinion! It is always best to capitalize on what is plentiful. It's not only cheaper, but also healthier, because they're fresh. It's funny because I always categorized my recipes by name, or by type, or whatever (I use Living Cookbook 2013), but categorizing by season is simply brilliant! I may have to re-think my entire system.I own the Kindle edition, and I have to admit that I haven't noticed any formatting issues, which is a blessing in and of itself. Cookbooks are frequently victimized by Kindle formatting, but as far as I can tell this one has remarkably escaped from the evil-formatting curse.All in all I have to highly recommend this to anyone, if for no other reason than just simple fun and great food!

First off, this isn't going to be a review of what is included in the book. There are plenty of reviews that explain that. Mostly this review is going to focus on how it is presented. I am a stickler for organizing things in a simple yet logical way.Also let me say that I really wanted to love this book and very much wanted to be able to give it five stars, but unfortunately that is not going to be possible.I also was disappointed in the publisher not allowing us to search for the "Look Inside" feature. Many books will let you search and had I been able to search, I would have saved myself some money. This was a lesson learned. If you can't search it, then it's very likely that the publisher is afraid that you won't buy after you search.I just needed two things out of this book. My requirements seemed simple enough to me:1.  Tell me how much sodium and potassium were in foods.2.  List the foods I normally eat (I don't eat unusual foods)The problem is that I didn't think I needed to include this part:3.  Organize it where it would be easy to find what I am looking for.I suppose I should have made that a requirement too, because this book is a total fail on that part. I spend more time trying to figure out where the heck something is, than actually finding the answer.Let us use tomatoes, as an example. Where would you expect to find tomatoes? Technically it's a fruit, but if you go to the fruit section, you won't find it. Okay, so maybe its in the vegetable section? No, it's not really there either. Would you have guessed that it would be a vegetable sub-heading called "Fruit (Seed-Containing) Vegetables"? I kid you not. We'll forget for a moment that there is no such thing as a "fruit vegetable" (it's either or, not both), but to assume that we would know to actually look for that type of sub-heading is simply madness.This means that most of the vegetables you are going to be looking for, could be under no less than 8 different ub-headings. EIGHT!!! You cannot simply open the book, turn to the Vegetable section and look something up. That's not how this book works, at all.Another example is the sub-heading "Flower, Stem and Stalk Vegetables". Really? I've never EVER heard the term "stem vegetable". There are plenty of city folks who have never even gardened before, in their life, so how would they know where to find their vegetables?I see no reason at all why the entire thing cannot be done alphabetically. If you go to look up a word in a dictionary, you don't expect to have to look up the word 'run' under a heading of Verbs, so why is this book organized in such a way? It doesn't make any sense.Then there is another problem with the entries too. You will not find bell peppers under "peppers, bell" nor "bell peppers". In fact, you'll not find any entry that has both those words (bell AND pepper) in them. You'll find a global word that says "sweet peppers" and in that order too. It's under Sweet, NOT Peppers. I use this example because it's an example of theirs on how to use this book. Normally I don't need to actually read instructions on reading a book, but this is definitely required reading for this one. Don't even try looking for "blackeye peas" because it's not under "blackeye" and it's not under "peas". It's under "cowpeas" and there are people out there who have no idea cowpeas and blackeye peas are one in the same.Let's talk about portion sizes. The title says very clearly "Portions Commonly Used". Really? I've yet to meet anyone who eats a single raw tomatillo. That's the nutritional information you get. The correct information is that they are "commonly used" boiled. They'll give you potatoes boiled and spinach boiled, so what's the deal with tomatillos? Then, what are 9 pieces of cilantro (I get that they are sprigs, but ...) and how would that figure in a "bunch"? Most recipes call for chopped or bunches, but never "pieces". Calculating that would be next to impossible.Now my other gripe is about #2, which it also failed on. Imagine my surprise when I read that it has a "dish cloth towel gourd" but does NOT have "poblano peppers". It has "jalapeno peppers" and has even a "Hungarian pepper", but it has neither anaheim nor poblano peppers. Those are used in a lot of dishes here in America and I don't know about you, but I've yet to EVER see a recipe which includes the "dish cloth towel gourd"! I am just dismayed at these entries.All in all, were it not that it carries meticulous information about some foods, this would get a single star. The information contained in this book, if you're lucky enough to find it, is valuable. For this reason, it gets two stars. Honestly, it probably deserves 3-stars but that would insinuate that it's actually a good book, which I believe I've demonstrated that it is not. Is its content useful? Yes. Can you easily use its content? No.Also, you may wish to know that a large part of this information is available for free at the USDA website.  Just Google "National Nutrient Database for Standard Reference". Granted, not all the information in this book is in the database, but I'd say most of it is.In the end, if there was another book that met all 3 needs above, then I'd warn against this one completely. How then could I say this is an okay book if I wouldn't recommend it against its competition? I've not found another book that does what this one does (yet). I surely hope that I will some day, or that they'll fix this one. For now, this is the best bet you have, but in the future check to be sure that there isn't another.

This is the DTP482 model and their official site (Component Design Northwest) has the manual available for pdf download, if anyone is interested. It's a decent unit for a decent price and so far I'm very pleased for the most part. I like that it does most of the thinking for me and that I can use it for hot oil and candy (so long as they are within the proper temperature range; less than 482F) as well as meats.That doesn't mean it doesn't come with a couple of annoyances; hence the 4-stars instead of 5. The first of which is the most important to me and is the eyestrain to read the small things, such as Meat Modes. For us forty-somethings and above, be prepared to have a magnifying glass handy or squint trying to hold it as far away as you can without a reflection. It would be nice if it were backlit, but it isn't.Problem two is the reflection. It has a very reflective surface so it's hard to read at times, even for you young people out there.All that said, it seems to function very well. Time will tell me how well it works, and we'll see. If I have any problems I'll be sure to update it here.It does come with some sort of a hook that the instructions don't mention at all, and a magnet you can attach to it. That's so you can just put it on your oven door. The only problem for me is that my oven door isn't metal. My oven vents are metal, but there is no way I'll put that thing on the vent. Needless to say, that stuff for me is useless.It still has a little stand on the back of it, so you can rest it on the counter or whatever.Finally, and I see many complaints (or questions) about this with other products. For me, I could care less but I know for a lot of you it makes it a big deal breaker. The device IS made in China. If that's important to you, you now know.Overall I find it a very convenient and helpful device. I'm very pleased with my purchase.

I was very pleased with this episode. The problem with documentaries such as this is time. There is a lot to be told in a short amount of time. If you want true in-depth information, then I recommend a book. However if you want a visual, and seeing people who lived through it, then this is the one you want.This documentary interviews several living survivors, which of course were children at the time of the pandemic. They share their memories, the loss of their family and friends, as well as their pain. There are photographs of overcrowded hospitals, reminiscent of the hospital scene in Gone With the Wind.One adult surviving victim recorded her tribulation and her writings describe the absolute pain and suffering she went through. I am a nurse and have worked for 23 years. She shared something that I had never even heard of, in all of those years. I had to look it up. I won't spoil it for you, but let's just say she went through 'hell on earth'.I do want to make a correction though. One reviewer wrote how the second wave was not at all mentioned, in this episode. That is incorrect because it most definitely was. It's important for me to say that because I'd hate for anyone to ignore this, thinking that were true. Perhaps the reviewer saw another documentary and confused it with this one (there is no verified purchase, so that seems likely). Anyway, I just wanted to make that point.All in all, this is a very moving, if not frightening, episode of the great American Experience series. I highly recommend it.

I had Book Collections until now. I used the other one until I couldn't stand it anymore. This one is a super improvement. I wrote some of this for the other review, but it definitely applies here because it is a comparison of them. Note that BC is the other one and C is this one.* BC requires you to either "copy to" or "remove from" each folder. C simply says Categories and you can check the ones you wish to use. That alone is much less tedious than BC.* BC requires you to keep selecting the book again after each edit, unlike C which is one edit only.* BC window automatically closes after editing a title instead of going back to the previous window, so if you want to edit more you have to go back to the beginning.* BC and C scans for books each time you want to download one (C even does it at startup which annoys me). I have a suggestion about that further down.* In BC when you're in a folder you cannot simply move a book (you can copy it and delete it, but you cannot move it). It snaps back to uncategorized then you have to move it. The way Categories words in C this isn't an issue.* In BC when you edit book information it is completely deleted once you copy it to another folder. That alone made me scream in frustration because not only was it not reading titles properly but it wasn't reading edits properly either. C remembers the change.* Finally, for some reason BC was checking my ibirdpro information and I've yet to figure out why. That was rather disturbing even though ibirdpro isn't all that private, but the fact remains that it IS checking it when it starts up.What NEITHER BC or C have that is absolutely necessary:* Retention of location memory, bookmarks and highlights. Again, I'm sure this is an Amazon issue but developers need to put the pressure on Amazon for its consumer sakes since Amazon refuses to listen to us.* Ability to categorize cloud books. This way we don't really have to scan for new books. Only when we select 'cloud'. I hate not being able to find the one book I want to read in the cloud because I can't find the book I want to read in the cloud. I don't keep all of my books downloaded. Only the ones I'm reading within the next month or need to refer back to on a constant basis.All in all this is the best there is. It does it well and it does all that it can do. If only Amazon would care about its consumers enough to let us have all the features it needs. *sigh*

This is a glitchy app that still misses the most important function, open with bookmarks, highlights and location memory. It may be an Amazon issue and Amazon needs to get on the ball and fix the whole situation, if you ask me, but alas, that has yet to happen.I personally think Collections is a better choice. Note though that you must find the right app for your particular device. It's not a global app, which is good news for those who can't get this one working on your device. My review for that one is linked in the comments here.The quick problem is that this app is tedious and clunky. I'll offer more detail in a moment, but the other one I like better is quick and efficient. In my opinion, the other is a near-perfect app and I've nothing at all to do with the company that develops it.This is actually more of a comparison between this app and the other one. Note that BC is this one and C is the other one.* BC requires you to either "copy to" or "remove from" each folder. C simply says Categories and you can check the ones you wish to use. That alone is much less tedious than BC.* BC requires you to keep selecting the book again after each edit, unlike C which is one edit only.* BC window automatically closes after editing a title instead of going back to the previous window, so if you want to edit it you have to go back to the beginning.* BC and C scans for books each time you want to download one (C even does it at startup which annoys me). I have a suggestion about that further down.* In BC when you're in a folder you cannot simply move a book (you can copy it and delete it, but you cannot move it). It snaps back to uncategorized then you have to move it. The way Categories words in C this isn't an issue.* In BC when you edit book information it is completely deleted once you copy it to another folder. That alone made me scream in frustration because not only was it not reading titles properly but it wasn't reading edits properly either. C remembers the change.* Finally, for some reason BC is checking my ibirdpro information and I've yet to figure out why. That is rather disturbing, though ibirdpro isn't all that private, but the fact remains that it IS checking it when it starts up.What NEITHER BC or C have that is absolutely necessary:* Retention of location memory, bookmarks and highlights. Again, I'm sure this is an Amazon issue but developers need to put the pressure on Amazon for its consumer sakes since Amazon refuses to listen to us.* Ability to categorize cloud books. This way we don't really have to scan for new books. Only when we select 'cloud'. I hate not being able to find the one book I want to read in the cloud because I can't find the book I want to read in the cloud. I don't keep all of my books downloaded. Only the ones I'm reading within the next month or need to refer back to on a constant basis.Though this app was a first for organizing books for Kindle Fire, and was a great idea, it is just obvious that they are more interested in the money, since they're charging for an app that has never even been through a beta test. Bad BAD business.For all these reasons it gets two stars. It really deserves only one star, but it was the first book organizing app for Kindle Fire so that's at least notable.
There are many, but this one is my absolute favorite. It should have been in Fallout. I just love it and come back to this one again and again. Definitely worth the purchase!

Rarely do I absolutely hate a game. In fact, to date this is the only one I've ever actually hated.I downloaded the game because it was a bubble shoot (love those) AND because I believed what they said above about it having "options for ... [the] timer" and "[a] settings screen...".On the Kindle Fire there are no such things. I had my son look at it, just to make sure that I didn't miss anything and no surprise, he agrees. So let's go over all that it is lacking on Kindle Fire (I cannot speak for other devices).1. There are absolutely zero settings at all.2. There is no timer option. I wanted a timer option because I hate timers. I don't mind games that have them, so long as I can turn them off. I have a busy life and can't always just keep playing because the timer is going and the game won't stop.3. There is no way to get back to the game home screen (not the KF carousel, but game home screen). This is not to be confused with the KF's back button, that will do it, but the game itself has no option at all to get to its own home screen.4. There is no ability to pause the game, except to use the KF home button.For me, this game is a total fail all the way around. There is not one single thing about this game that I like and it is going to be permanently removed from my KF.If you have a Kindle Fire and don't mind timed games, not being able to pause it and not being to get back to its own home screen, then this game is for you. Otherwise, steer clear.

I really love bubble shoot games (I'm not an Angry Birds fan and prefer this type). This one is okay, but it's different than most. The goal for this one is not to simply clear the screen, but to gain more bubbles as you clear the screen.I'm not sure I agree with its shots. *Almost* always I can get between two bubbles to shoot the ones just above them, so long as it's not important to do so. If I *need* to get between two to bring down a large number of bubbles, it won't go through. This seems obviously fixed. Additionally, if you avoid a matched set of bubbles it will continuously give you that color bubble over and over and over again, but that never happens with colors I do need.I am a busy person and hate timed games, this one is thankfully not timed. I never can understand why we are forced for timed games. Those are a 'delete the game' for me. Not everyone has nothing to do but play games.It works fine on Kindle Fire EXCEPT that it's Save and Exit doesn't work properly. You have to either bring up the bottom Kindle Menu OR the top Settings Menu, then return to it and the Save and Exit will come up. Not sure about that glitch.Finally, I don't like that there is no level system, but I suppose that's because the goal is gaining bubbles. Still, it feels like I'm just in an infinite loops of going back to the beginning over and over and over again.All in all, I'll play it, but I don't particularly care about it.

First off, this isn't a review for the TV show. Anyone with a brain knows that the show is a solid 10 on a scale of 1 to 5. My review is for this particular DVD set.The pro is that you can get all of series 1 and 2 as well as the Christmas Special for one low price. There are a few select extras without any commentaries and that is about all.I don't know if it's a manufacturing issue, or if all are made the same way, but I was exceptionally disappointed as I watched the show. All of series 1 and parts of series 2 have serious color issues. Everyone's faces look so pale and sickly with red splotches all over their skin. It looks like everyone has the measles.Now I will admit that I have a new blu-ray player (which I love). However, I do not have this problem with other blu-ray discs. On the other hand, I have a very limited number of blu-ray discs since I'm just now getting into the blu-ray world.I'm reminded of the quality of the Pride and Prejudice DVD set that I bought as soon as it was first released on regular DVD (post the VHS world). It too had color wash out issues.Also, I am so disappointed in the lack of blu-ray features in this set. For Christmas, my husband bought me this set along with the new blu-ray player. Maybe it was a bad set to start with, but it has such interesting features! One clever one is saving your favorite parts of the films. My assumption was that this was a standard, but perhaps not. Either way, I wish that a series so great as this one would have taken the time to infuse rich features like the Hitchcock set.It's worth noting too that if you purchase the separate series blu-rays (this one and this one), you'll likely (at present in any case) get a complimentary digital copy of the series via Amazon's Video Library. I actually bought them first, then cancelled those in lieu of this set. I'm very much regretting that decision now. This set does NOT come with a free video library copy.All in all, I'm gravely disappointed. Because it is a blu-ray I expected quality HD and that was what I did not get. The final disc worked fine, but not the others. Well, you get what you pay for, I guess.

This is an excellent book. The author (not the same Paul Newman that is a movie star) is clearly an expert on the subject of the middle ages. The pages are loaded with information that most of us would not even think about. It is clear and concise, and written in a very understandable way.Mr. Newman is very meticulous with every last detail. There are sketch examples of many things, but admittedly those are very few in comparison to its content. It is not simply about clothing, for example. It is about the dye for the clothing, the many cloths that were available (which were made in Europe vs those imported), who could afford which cloth (nobles vs peasants), how theses cloths were actually made and even how they made the thread or string that they sewed it with. That's only a very small part of the clothing chapter and there is just so much more. It's is an exhaustive encyclopedia, in my opinion. After reading this book, I feel like I earned an actual degree on the subject and you likely will too!Which brings me to what this book is not. This is not a stylized written book with a flair for words and rich content such as artwork or poetry. It is anything but that. Some reviewers have called his writing dull and boring, but even if I thought that were true, his writing does not make it any less informative.
