You wouldn't tell your professor that his lecture was boring because even if it were, it would still be information that you need to know. If you want to learn about the middle ages, then you must deal with whatever style it is. Sure, he is no great story teller, but there is no story to tell since this is a reference book after all.Now let's talk about the 4 stars. Why only 4 stars? I would have given it 5 stars until I read a comment (a comment in the Kindle edition extras) about not noting sources. I had not even noticed that, but the commenter was right. On the other hand, the introduction pretty much explains his credentials in that he has "studied" art and literature of the time. Unfortunately there is not much known about this author, except that he has written several non-fiction books about the middle ages (it's worth noting that at the time of this writing, the other books are not yet available on Kindle), so he appears to be knowledgeable. That said, the reader was absolutely correct though on his sources of information. They are not listed at all.I'm not saying that I don't trust his judgement or information, it's just that those who would like to learn more about the details Newman describes will be sorely disappointed. There is no way to know how he drew his conclusions. For this reason, and ONLY this reason, it gets 4-stars instead of 5.All in all, I highly recommend this book and look forward to the Kindle editions of his other books.

I was very excited about this player, even though the reviews were love it or hate it. I like to think myself reasonable and will often give things a chance. It's too bad then that it didn't work out.The first one arrived and we happily plugged it in and hooked it up and turned it on. Hmmm. Nothing. The blue light said ON and the splash screen came up for about 1 or 2 seconds then it went black. Okay, well maybe we need to insert a disc, so we inserted the disc. It said loading. There was a lot of grinding noise and nothing ever came up. So we ejected and put another disc back in. Maybe it was the disc, though it shouldn't have been since it was brand spanking new. That didn't work either. Okay, so this was a dud.Being the patient people we are, we notified Amazon that we wanted to exchange it for another and waited for the exact same model to arrive (which by the way was thankfully a very simple process AND since I my original order had included an additional $4 for overnight shipping, Amazon sent the second model overnight as well).We got it early this morning and unfortunately, we experienced the exact same behaviors that the other one had. It too is a dud.Needless to say, I'm disappointed. Two different players with the same problem spells trouble. This time, I'm going to go with this one. When we bought the Toshiba, we paid $66 at the time and the Sony we're getting is a bit more ($88), but the reviews appear more solid and still does most of what this one does (not 3D though).

I bought this and a "P" is for Pooh cross-stitch book too. I have to say that both are excellent books. I cannot choose between the two, but for a newborn or small infant, this one is probably better and for toddlers, the other one is better. This one has more pastel colors whereas the other one has brighter more primary-like colors.The information says there are 33 designs, but really there are 35 because two designs have separate mirror images.The instructions are fairly clear, though some previous knowledge of cross-stitch is required (e.g., french knots, lazy daisy stitches, etc.).Instructions are also included for:... a photo album cover... decorating a lamp... a door pillow... a quilt... a tote bag... a wall hangingIt is a pleasure to have this as an addition to my crafting library.

I bought this and a Pooh Baby Collection cross-stitch book too. I have to say that both are excellent books. I cannot choose between the two, but this is more for toddlers than the other one. This one has brighter, more primary-like colors whereas the other one has more pastel colors, which is better for newborns and infants.There are 20 designs (21 if you separate the Pooh eating honey design) all of various sizes, and text too.The only thing I didn't like was the birth announcement text. I would have liked to have had a choice other than the alphabet in all lowercase, but I suppose it was more child-like that way. Still, I would have preferred a choice and the sampler text doesn't match the birth announcement text size either.The instructions are fairly clear, though some previous knowledge of cross-stitch is required (e.g., french knots, lazy daisy stitches, etc.).Additional instructions included are for:... magnets... pillows... a tote... a quilt... a wall hangingI am thrilled to have this as an addition to my crafting library.

Not sure why the verification thing isn't working, but I bought this mp3 here at Amazon.I have to say that this is probably one of the sexiest songs I've just about ever heard. Until now, that award was tied by two songs, both incidentally are Sarah McLachlan's songs, "Possession" (piano version) and "Ice" (NOT to be confused with "Ice Cream").This song is very close in sensuality as the others I've mentioned. It's quite wonderful and for 99 cents (at the time of this writing), it's a bargain!

Right out of the box, the TV refused to come on. I called the manufacturer, thinking we'd hooked something up wrong, but no. There should be a home screen if the power is on despite if anything is hooked up to it, according to tech support.He said he could send a replacement (he emailed me a form that I am not happy about because I have to fax it to him along with a copy of the invoice, this is an additional expense I shouldn't have to make) and then once I got the replacement I could send this one to him. While I was sitting there on the phone with him, the TV suddenly came on. Odd. We turned it back off and no surprise, it wouldn't come back on. About 10-15 minutes later it finally came on again. lol! It's the strangest thing. The tech guy said it should not take that long to warm up. He said he thought that maybe it would do that if it were about 40F, but one, it had been sitting in the house a couple of hours and two, we live in Mobile, Alabama. It rarely gets 40F and even more rarely that temp in November! It was in the 60s when it was delivered.So, we're leaving it on until the new set gets here. Now all that said, let me talk about its function. Keep in mind, this is obviously a defective TV set. When the new one comes, and I've no idea how long that will be, this may change.My non-HD Directv picture isn't all that great. In fact, I'd say it's slightly blurry. On the other hand, the HD picture from my son's games and the bluray and even Netflix are all amazingly clear. I think it's just time to upgrade my Directv receiver.I don't use the TV sound because I have a surround sound system. However, I will say that it works beautifully with even the oldest surround system known to mankind. Ours is a 1996 RCA, with RCA (red and white) plugs... I kid you not. It was top of the line in its day, but it is ancient now. Unlike our other TVs, this new one finally has an RCA out plug for old stereos. I couldn't believe it! That alone makes it worth its purchase, in my opinion.There is still a problem though. You would think that since the TV is putting OUT the sound, that it (TV) would control the volume it is sending out via the jacks, but nope, it doesn't. That means you'll have to use yet another remote, the one for your receiver. If I had one serious complaint, that would be it. Even my ancient rabbit ear TV would at least control the volume out via another source. I'm not sure why this one failed on that.It's very lightweight, has tons of plug options and even swivels. I really do like this TV. I just wish that it powered up better because were it not for that, I'd keep this one.The other thing is that I want you all to know that the tech support was very helpful. I called at 5:30 p.m. CDT and not only managed to get someone, but managed to get someone who speaks clearly and I didn't have to wait but less than 1 minute. I couldn't believe it. That is always a good sign. Also, he emailed me the forms and by the time I hung up and got to my desk, it was in my inbox. I love companies that treat you like a valued customer and this one did just that.All in all, I think it will be a good deal. If only it worked right out of the box and I wish I didn't have to go through the trouble of sending it back.The link to download the PDF manual is in the first comment under my review here.UPDATE: Just got the new set. I first contacted the manufacturer but I didn't like their exchange policy. I would have to fax (I don't have a fax) a copy of their form that they emailed to me and an invoice (which Amazon doesn't send with it) that I would have to print out from my Amazon account. Then I'd have to wait for their ship labels and once I got those, I would have to take the TV down to UPS or wherever. I ended up exchanging it with Amazon and they'll even send someone to pick it up. So much easier!Anyway, the new TV works like a dream. I'm very satisfied. It takes no more than 5 seconds to turn on. That was fresh out of the box. I'm not sure if there is a battery in there, but after being plugged in overnight, it came on instantly the next morning.All in all, I'm very satisfied but I do have to recommend some sort of external speaker system. It has a headphone jack, so if you can find external speakers that have that same jack, you may be able to use those.

I didn't buy these for the conventional purpose of using them as grocery bags. I bought them for my chest freezer and I am so glad I did!Having a chest freezer makes it nearly impossible to stay organized when it comes to freezer foods. I tried keeping an inventory, I tried stacking everything neatly in order, I tried crates, I tried all sorts of things. I ran across a blog somewhere that suggested something like these. Figuring it wouldn't work, but I could use the bags anyway if it didn't I bought them.I am thrilled with them for this purpose! I can even color code them for foods. The other day my son was looking for hamburger patties I had put up. He asked me which bag they were in and I said "the red one" (red meat, get it? lol!) and he found it in 2 seconds flat.Now I know a lot of you are thinking my review is useless for you because you plan to use them grocery shopping. How wrong you are! What is notable about this is that with all that heavy frozen meat, all those frozen packages with sharp edging (yes, they get sharp when frozen) and so forth, they are strong and can handle it!These are very well made. I expect they will last for many years and they will wash very well.All in all, you can't go wrong with this. There are endless other ways to use them too. It just takes thinking outside of the box.

This showed up on a list of the funniest books of all time.  It is classic British humor involving the tales of 3 British male friends and a dog taking an extended boating/camping trip down the Thames.  The mix of content is about 50/50 on the events of the boat trip and their observations and commentary on the human experience.  The humor is seldom laugh out loud, but a mix of sarcastic insight into the foibles of modern (for that period) life and society and their travel travails.  I found it a very enjoyable read.

Very thick (a good thing if you want bumper protection), fits well, looks reasonably OK (not ugly).  A little softer and "cushy" than I expected (but I still think it will provide good front bumper protection). My only somewhat negative thought is I think it is overpriced.  For the price I was expecting extremely high quality and firmer rubber/cushioning material. But otherwise satisfied.

I moved to an older historic building (circa 1853) with very thick brick/masonry/lath and plaster interior walls.  The building has a "whole building" WiFi setup with routers on the first and 4th floors. My condo is on the second floor, immediately up the stairs from the first floor router and with pretty good line of sight placement for the WiFi signals.  In fact in the front portion of my unit the signal is great.  Unfortunately, I work from home and my office is in the rear of my unit - farthest from the router.  As a result, I was getting very weak signals on both my Mac desktop and my work Windows laptop.  I had an extender/adapter put in my front living room to boost the signal, but it didn't completely solve the problem. So after doing some research I tried one of these for my Mac (it plugs directly into the computer), did the setup (pretty straightforward) and was very pleased with the results.  My reception and signal strength is now "very good" - not excellent, but certainly good enough to make it painless to use my Mac.  It worked so well that I bought one for my work (Windows) computer as well.  However, the installation software comes on a CD and my Windows laptop doesn't have a CD/DVD player!!  So, after some head scratching, I put the CD in my Mac, copied the installation software to a USB drive, and put the USB drive into my laptop, and voila! it worked.Overall very satisfied, and the price was great and they even look nice.

I live in the city, and street parking is the norm.  You walk down the street and see beautiful cars, then look at their bumpers - very sad.  "Bumper Contact Parking" (i.e. back up until you make contact with the car behind you) is the norm.  Although I have a parking garage space for my car, getting around town requires street parking.  So when I first moved here and saw all the bumpers ruined I started looking for bumper protection products on Amazon.  For the front of my car (a Mini Cooper) the license plate is/would be the first point of contact, so I bought one of those thick, rubber protective license plate covers (great reviews) to protect the front of my car.  After much research for a rear bumper protection product, I decided on the Pacer Performance strips for two reasons. One, the reviews were consistently outstanding. Second, most of the other products were far inferior in terms of providing protection.  These are heavy duty - I mean REALLY heavy duty. They are made out of hard rubber, very good quality, and between the two of them they cover the entire rear bumper of my Mini.You would think from looking at the product photo that they're more for protection than aesthetics, but once applied they really look cool and sporty - and boy do they protect your bumper.  One word of caution - be absolutely positive of your placement on your bumper (location and level) before you press even one small portion of the product on your car.  The car adhesive is extremely strong, and once you make contact you CANNOT remove it and if it is crooked (not level) or not in the right location - you're out of luck.  I went so far as to put a piece of masking tape below where I want them to go and checked it to ensure it was level, and THEN gently pressed one of the product on my car and worked from that end down to the other end.  There are two matching pieces.  The end result, again, is really attractive and no worries anymore about bumper scrapes and dings.  Highly recommend and would buy again.

I appreciate authors that can write descriptive prose of scenery, settings, feelings, loneliness, and regret in language that literally seeps into your being, putting you in the same place and time as the character.  Per Petterson can do this, and do it well.  I understand the praise and critical success for this author and this book.  But ultimately, I need a book that has more of a plot - a storyline, and this one does not. It is written, in a manner a bit too long, of the observations, thoughts, and reflections of an old man and events that affected his life.  As a short novella it may have worked for me - the language is amazing, leaning towards Hemingway in long sentences echoing a stream of thought.  But as a novel - a book - it fell short of the mark.  I do not criticize other readers their 5 star reviews - the author is truly talented.  But my own taste runs a little counter to what the author offers.  I finished the book with mixed feelings. Glad to have the weariness of scene-setting over with, but also hoping, along the way, that a denouement would appear.  It never did.

I came across this book while reading an article on the "10 funniest books of all time."  Of course there are inevitable arguments about what should or should not be on that list, but the fact that I was ready for a humorous read after several excellent but depressing WWII novels, Wilt looked worth a try.  Briefly, Wilt is a career underachiever at the small Fenland College of Arts and Technology.  Continually passed over for promotions and pay increases, his life is on a dead end path consisting of teaching classes no one else will take to vocational students working in labor professions, i.e. butchers, bricklayers, etc. who are only attending because the government is covering their costs and it gets them out of work for a while. Wilt sleepwalks through these classes, having given up on trying to expose this underclass to literature at any level.  But, as it turns out later, his exposure to these rather rough but street smart and rather plain spoken (yes, there is sexual language) group actually prepares him for the travails he will undergo later in the book.His marriage to his wife Eva is equally dissatisfying. She is convinced he will never amount to anything - and frequently reminds of him of this shortcoming.  She envisions herself as an enlightened woman, constantly pursuing (but never sticking with) various yoga, meditation, and similar "new age" interests.  Wilt's life, in short, is dreary, repetitive, and wholly unsatisfying. One of his outlets, in a sort of "Walter Mitty" turn, is to take his dog for walks and not only dream of, but logically think out plans to get rid of Eva.  He sorts through various ideas, from poison to auto accidents to - whatever. They are more stress relief efforts; his desperate attempt to at least visualize a better life.The real story begins when Eva meets a new age couple, the Pringsheim's, Sally and Gaskell. They are unbearably pretentious and off the map sexually liberated. Eva is of course entranced, and Sally senses that Eva can be manipulated (sexually and otherwise), and as a result Wilt and Eva attend a party at the Pringsheim's house.  It involves nudity, crude language and acts (the only part of the book I found less than satisfying was the Pringsheim's - they are definitely "not likable," but do serve as a good foil and plot device for the story).  It is at the party that Wilt, as a result of machinations by Sally Pringsheim, becomes 'attached' to an inflatable female sex doll, "Judy."  And the real story begins...Wilt ends up leaving the party to go home to find a way to "unattach" himself from the doll, while Eva ends up (liberal amounts of alcohol involved) leaving with the Pringsheims on a boating trip.  Wilt, not overly concerned about Eva's absence and unknown whereabouts, decides to use "Judy" as a means to practice his plans for getting rid of Eva.  This leads to "Judy" ending up at the bottom of a construction hole at Fenland College, and Wilt being investigated for the murder of Eva.  His adversary is Inspector Flint.  The remainder of the book focuses on his conversations with Inspector Flint and others in their efforts to get him to confess to Eva's murder.The interaction between Wilt and Inspector Flint (and his other police peers) is hilarious. The satire is marvelous and entertaining.  The interesting part is that Wilt, a career sub-achiever, finally comes into his own.  He knows he is innocent, and as the investigation goes on (filled with endless police mixups, wrong assumptions, and an exasperating inability to break down Wilt), Wilt gains confidence and a sense of self worth for the first time in his life.The ending, as is the entire book, is entirely satisfying and appropriate.  This is inimitable British satire, done well.  Aside from the off-putting Pringsheims, the characters are well drawn (in a caricature manner) and the central humor, again, is the bumbling police vs. the suddenly inimitable Wilt. I laughed a lot throughout, and think you will as well. It is a light read, and a good break from reading "heavy" novels.  I wouldn't put it in the class of Wodehouse, but it certainly does have elements of his writing style. Read it and enjoy.

I was very pleased with this windshield phone holder.  I like it because it's small, simple, unobtrusive, fits very securely on my windshield, and swivels.  Every feature you could need.  You buy others for a lot more with goosenecks, adjustable brackets, etc. but frankly I don't need all that and it would just take up more space on my windshield.

Great "light" read.  Basically it's a career frustrated, cynical college English professor writing a never-ending litany of 'Letters of Reference' ("LORs").  The laugh out loud part is he can't resist going the "too much information" route.  Yes, a lot of them are similar, but the length of the book, the variety of addressees and topics, and his ever-increasing inability to simply "stop, you've said enough" make it very enjoyable.  As I said, a good light read, very humorous and truly well-written.

I didn't like this book, but finished it anyway.  I had read one previous by the same author, and it was marvelous, so I know she can write.  And that writing talent shows in this book as well. But the plot, storyline, structure, and characters are unbelievable, unlikable (for the most part), and undeveloped.  As other reviewers have noted, she uses the (gaining popularity) method of jumping from one character's narrative perspective to another. The result breaks the flow and frankly is a mess - you're just beginning to get engrossed in one storyline and perspective, and then it changes to another character.  Alice and her Husband are unlikable - Alice has terrible judgment for being such a 'smart' woman, and her husband is a nut case.  Jenna, her left behind daughter (there's a pun in that line re the ending) is unbelievably precocious for a 13 year old. I could go on, but trust me the other characters are thinly developed and don't add much to the plot - you even tend to forget who is who. Some criticize (mildly) the Elephant angle.  I liked it, but then again, I am fascinated by Elephant behavior.  If you REALLY want to read a wonderful book on the subject read "Elephant Company," a true story based on one Englishman's life in Burma working for a Teak company where Elephants were the lifeblood of the industry from the early 1900's through the second world war.  This book barely touches the surfaces of Elephant behavior.  Read 'Elephant Company' (a great story as well) and you'll fall in love with Elephants forevermore.  I can't recommend this book, and I will be more careful regarding ready Jodi Picoult in future - i.e. download a sample.

Liane Moriarty is one of my favorite authors.  I read "The Husband's Secret," which prompted me to read "Big Little Lies," (which in my opinion is her best novel, soon to be a movie with Nicole Kidman and Reese Witherspoon), and now "What Alice Forgot."  Liane has the ability to make her characters so vivid they literally jump off the page.  Her dialogue is wicked good, interspersing humor, angst, and the highs and lows of everyday life in a "I wish I could write like that" result.  That talent and ability is what saves this novel.  It has some weaknesses in plot, construction, and believability, but somehow her brilliant words on the page keep you up late at night.  Other reviewers reveal the plot - Alice loses her memory of 10 years spanning age 29 to 39 - she can remember nothing of that period, not even her children's names or the fact that she even HAS children.  As she slowly discovers, primarily though interactions with friends and family, what has transpired over the last 10 years she's amazed. She finds that she has changed from a young, sort of "whatever" person to a driven "super mom" who is a 24/7 dynamo in everything from social activities to personal health  - in other words, the complete opposite of the young Alice.  Oh, and her Husband Nick is divorcing her. And her children don't really like her.  I could go on.  While this is an interesting plot device, it really stretches the bounds of believability.  Also, in terms of construction, the author inserts lengthy "diary" type entries by Alice's sister and her grandmother.  Frankly, they get in the way of the story, and made it about 100 pages longer than it needed to be.  I found myself going "oh no" when I saw one coming up, know the next several pages would be the meandering thoughts and musings of the aforesaid relatives.  In my opinion it was distracting.  In believability, the sheer fact that both Alice and her Husband changed so completely, and then in some ways (after her memory came back) reverted to their younger selves was, well, I don't know...hard to accept.But, having said all of that, I couldn't put it down.  Liane Moriarty is that good of a writer.  And I will continue to read her books.  She is able to take an amazing cast of characters (it usually takes me about 30 pages to figure out who's who) and spin a tale that is both provocative and fun read.

I bought this for my wife - who admittedly has a weakness for the latest exercise gadgets. But to her credit, she uses them all, and the few that don't meet her standard are swiftly carried off to be donated to the thrift store.  I read reviews before buying this, and they were mixed.  All reviews cited the good workout, but some talked highly of the quality, while others described it as "cheaply made."  After receiving it and putting it together (amazingly easy - you can do it in 15 minutes - don't go looking in the box for all the listed bolts and screws - they're already installed) I was impressed with the heft and quality of the pieces.  My only observation less than 100% positive is that, while there is no danger of it tipping over, it is not 100% stable (by that I mean "motionless") on carpet.  It needs a solid floor, but it will in fact work on carpet.  It is fully adjustable (the height of the upper handles can be raised or lowered), although there is no resistance setting - but for this type of machine you don't really need one.  If you want a more strenuous workout just lengthen your steps (all the way to the bottom vice halfway down) while using it. The little clock/timer is worthless, but my wife doesn't need it.  The grips, foot pads, and frame are all impressive. She loves it.  Plus it folds up neatly to be stored in a closet or unobtrusively against the wall.  I would buy it again given our experience.

I had previously read Herman Koch's "The Dinner" and loved it.  After reading the first few pages of this book in preview mode I noticed, again, how adept the author is at translating a character's innermost feelings, biases, perspectives, and observations into words.  One of my literature professors once told us that a very good writer can express something in words so well that it resonates in our mind as if we had thought of it ourselves.  We literally stand in the shoes of the author and view the world through his (or her) eyes, but it's so vivid it's as if we arrived at the same thought at the same point in time. Such an author is Herman Koch.  His stories (at least the two I've read so far) are not pleasant - the characters are flawed, unlikable, and exhibit the worst side of human nature.  But, we all know or have observed people like this - we recognize them instantly - in a sense becoming so immersed in the story that it's as if we are there, in those scenes, as an invisible observer.  I can understand those reviewers who didn't enjoy the book - it is not a tidy book, with likeable characters, a well-framed plot, and a "tie up all the loose ends" ending.  It is a character study of the darker side of human nature, taking us to where most of us have never gone before, but, given the right circumstances, one never knows what each of us is capable of doing. I found it delicious reading, enjoying the mastery of a not only a brilliant author, but a brilliant observer and interpreter of human nature, albeit the darker side of same.  While I don't envision a steady diet of delving into the dysfunctional side of human behavior - the occasional read, done with the excellence of the author, is a fascinating journey.

I love Liane Moriarty's books!!! This is my second of her books (the first was "The Husband's Secret") and her ability to tell a 'can't put it down story' is first rate.  The two books I've read (and from what I read about her, this may be a central theme), are oriented towards female leads, set in Australia. One could almost characterize them as "chick lit," but that would be grossly incorrect.  Both books had multiple characters (it takes about 30 pages to get the characters sorted out in your mind, but trust me, you will), and the way she interweaves their story lines is seamless.  There is drama, humor, mystery, and (in the two books I've read) murder/death. There are nasty characters and good characters, but they are not caricatures - they come to life on the page.  Her ability to write dialogue is unparalleled.  Two of the most enjoyable reads I've had this year.  I strongly recommend you give Liane a try - you won't be disappointed.

I make by book choices by reading the reviews and reading the opening section of the book - these are both amazing features Amazon has provided and one of the primary reasons I am an avid Amazon books fan and buyer.  But this book proves the occasional exception - you can't always depend on reviews.  Now that I've read the book, and wasn't terribly impressed, I went back and reread many of the reviews and noticed a consistent theme - almost all were long-time "fans" of both the authors and more specifically, the character Aloysious Pendergast.  As I read the opening section, it appeared that (as others have stated) this series is somewhat of a "tongue in cheek" approach - to be taken lightly.  The initial introduction to agent Pendergast made me think "OK, this is going to be sort of a Sherlock Holmes character - brilliant, big ego, independent, doesn't suffer fools, etc."  I can handle that angle - I love Sherlock Holmes.  As I read further, I find that agent Pendergast does not even come close to living up to those expectations. He is far from brilliant (thoughtless blunders throughout the book), pompous, and downright rude - not a likable character.  And, he is not even the central character in the story.  Other NYPD detectives drive most of the plot, which is all over the map, and as the book nears closure the two female characters take over the story and, as another reviewer noted, we witness a fantastically unbelievable sequence of out of character events and actions by these two ladies that suspend belief - all to save the life of Aloysious who, frankly, given his negative qualities, may not be worth saving.  I was also put off by the authors use of 4-bit words when 2-bit words would more than suffice. I imagine they were showing their extensive vocabulary, but really, why not just say a person died of alcoholism rather than some esoteric word I need to look up in the Kindle at-hand dictionary?  So, to sum it up:Cons- Aloysious Pendergast is neither likable or brilliant- The story has so many holes in the plot and unbelievable moments it all seems contrived- The characters come and go - very little continuity, with the exception of Lieutenant D'Agosta - the only character I actually liked- It is "Romance Novel" quality writing adapted to a mystery genrePros- It wasn't so bad that I quit reading - I did finish it.I don't plan on reading any more books by these authors

There are very mixed reviews for this book, and I can understand it.  It is more of a deep psychological character study than a novel.  There isn't a lot of plot, per se, but the interplay, both in dialogue and background writing, among the characters is spot on. This is a dysfunctional group, who on the surface are not only upstanding, but highly regarded and well known citizens. The book delves into, and does an excellent job of giving significant insight, into their flaws, prejudices, jealousies, and lies in the course of an evening dinner.  I found it fascinating and thoroughly enjoyed it - and clearly see why it is/was a prize winner. If you're looking for a traditional novel/story with a beginning, plot setup, plot development, and tidy ending don't look here. If you're looking for brilliant writing and character insight, you'll enjoy it.

Excellent writer, elements of an epic saga, but a little too much self-importance in the characters.  By self-important I mean drawn as caricatures - the Southern oil man, his ruthless father, his psychotic wife, and his philandering. The main character's over-confidence and irresolute values that belie an innate opposite result - poor judgment, braggadacio, and outright stupid statements and actions that lead to terrible consequences for himself, his wife, and his partner.  More like a soap opera than a saga - at least for me.  I did read it all the way through, but aside from some compelling dialogue and well-drawn, but one-dimensional characters, I was glad to finish it - and i mean "glad to be done with it."  Likely not going to be reading anything else from this author.

I purchased this set of songs due to already owning Inlakesh's "The Dreaming Gate", which has an Australian (didgeridoo") foundation but adds both nature and other soft instruments to create a remarkable meditative/ambiance/new age sound that goes on my iPod "Airlplane" playlist (i.e. noise-cancelling headphones, calming music). The Gathering is similar, but different. Still soothing, with a little less of the didgeridoo foundation but retaining that excellent mix of sound that, in total, put the listener in a different, much calmer state of mind. Suitable for listening while reading, working, or just chilling out - I find it a very enjoyable and necessary component of my eclectic music collection.

Admittedly, I was attracted to try this book as much by the low price ($1.99, Kindle) as I was by the erudite and positive reviews. It is a collection of four novellas, written primarily in first person form. The most famous is "Letter from an Unknown Woman", which leads off the collection, but I truthfully enjoyed all of them.  Written and set in the early years of the 20th century, the dialogue and settings are consistent with that milieu, but nevertheless timeless in their story lines.  Each of them portrays, in different ways, a compelling event, character, or life lesson, with elements of tragedy, but not overdone in that regard.  They cover plots ranging from the (literally) lifelong obsession of a young teenage girl through adulthood who is obsessed with an older man who happens to take an apartment in the same building as her family.  Even though her family moves away, her obsession never wavers and her whole life, focus, and thoughts center around this 'man of her dreams,' who has no knowledge of any of this. It goes beyond the simple story mechanics and edges into observations of the human psyche, in a very enlightening, somewhat macabre, but also very readable approach.  The other stories, in their own way, portray "life lessons' - not in a preachy way, but through simple dialogue, leaving the impression to the reader.  I can't think of a better way to introduce a change of pace and reading style into your book list which provides so much in so little reading time - around 2-3 hours.

As I said in my review for the 10 foot long version of this charging cord, I've learned my lesson about buying inexpensive lightning cords that are not apple certified.  They either don't work or they stop working after a month or two.  Lesson learned. This cord is great - very sturdy with a thicker cord and thicker plastic piece holding the lightning pin connector. The only downside is you need to have an iPhone case with a charge port opening large enough to plug the connector all the way in.  For iPads, no problem. Great cord, good handy length, very satisfied

I've gone the route of buying inexpensive charging cords for my iPads and iPhones, and finally learned my lesson - you get what you pay for.  Most of them didn't work, and those that did stopped working after a month or two. You need to buy either Apple, or Apple certified charging cords.  Yes, you'll pay more, but how much did you lose buying those less expensive inferior cords?  This monster is heavy duty. The cord is much thicker than the Apple cords, and even the end piece with the lightning 8-pin connector is thicker and more sturdy.  The ONLY downside to this cord is the size of the lightning connector piece.  It may not fit through your iPhone case charging slot.  I have both an iPhone 5c and 5s, and both have Speck cases. The charge cord opening on the 5c case is too small to accommodate this cord, but the case on the 5s accommodates it fine.  Since the 5s is my traveling phone I'm happy - which is why I bought the 10 foot cord.  Hotel rooms are not always well-designed in terms of where they put their power outlets, so no I have no problems having the phone close by (e.g. night clock, etc.) with the longer cord.  Very satisfied.

This is a fantastic read.  I finished it in two days - couldn't put it down. It is really three linked stories. The first is the abduction/kidnapping of "Alex," a 30 year old woman, for essentially (at that point in the book) reasons unknown - presumably random cruelty. She is subjected to a horrifying experience, so those of you with tender stomachs beware, there are very graphic descriptions of torture and suffering.  Miraculously, through a believable chain of events and realization she is a determined, smart woman, she escapes.  The French Police are involved, and we are introduced to (in more detail) to the lead inspector "Camille", who reminds me (in a very positive way) of Agatha Christie's Hercule Poirot.  Very small in stature but with millions of "little gray cells", he leads us on a combined action and mental deductive path as he works the case. The second "story" is that of Alex escaped and in the world.  As it turns out, she is not what we thought she was - an innocent victim, and without spoiling the story, murders occur, and she is the likely suspect - but no one can find her.  The third story begins when Inspector Camille begins to unravel her life, relentlessly tracking down her past through friends, co-workers, neighbors, and finally her mother and brother.  The final denouement is the detainment and questioning of her brother, and this is where Camille's supreme detective and intuitive powers come into play.  He is masterful - every bit Poirot's equal, both in the mental and verbal sparring with Alex's brother as he slowing reveals the facts at exactly the right moment, drawing the case closer and closer to a most satisfactory, but somewhat surprising (you won't realize it until the final paragraphs) ending.  A masterful work, and one of the best books I've read this year. Inspector Camille is the star, but the author paints all of the supporting characters extremely well.  If you like detective stories, police procedurals, and  just plain can't put it down reading, this book is for you.  Highest recommendation.

I enjoyed this book immensely.  Like many, I enjoy mystery/detective novels, and this is among the best.  It is more along the lines of a police procedural, and stays true to that format throughout - which is a good thing.  Yes, it does provide good character descriptions so that we feel we know not only Wallender but his colleagues, but most of what we find out is clearly in the context of police work - no wandering off into other character information that drags us off the storyline.  And the storyline is intense.  Wallender is pursuing the most difficult prey - a serial killer who seemingly offers no motive or pattern upon which to base a methodical investigation.  It is Wallender's determination and dogged, self-exhausting approach to finding the killer that makes it riveting.  He foregoes sleep and his own health issues to stay on top of the case and his police team.  Once that process starts in earnest, this is a page turner - you might be ready to go to sleep but you just have to see what's on the next page.  The plot evolves masterfully. There are subtle clues, chance comments, and Wallender's logic that slowly tighten the circle on identifying and finding the killer.  Wallender is relentless, and despite setbacks and missed opportunities, he does succeed.  My only minor note is that I suspect some of the dialogue was affected by translation from Swedish, but very minor and not at all detracting from the enjoyable read.  This was my first Wallender book and I look forward to reading other books in the series.

I think I may have finally exhausted all of the Bertie and Jeeves books/stories by Wodehouse, so in a sense this is a sad day for me.  I suppose over time I'll have enough mental distance to read some of them again, but I feel as if I've lost a treasured group of close friends.  The unique, and very different, characters of Bertie (the loutish but well-intentioned moneyed upper-class wastrel) and Jeeves (the classic "gentleman's gentleman" who anticipates every need, magically appears when needed, and applies his "huge brain" ("eats lots of fish", per Bertie)) to consistently delivers Bertie (and others) from precarious predicaments.  There are no plots, per se, to these books; just the wonderful repartee, musings, and misadventures of Bertie countered by Jeeves unflappable demeanor and ability to "save the day" at the denouement moment.  I won't describe the details of the story because they are ultimately irrelevant - it's the dialogue and situations that carry the day.  IMHO there has never been a humorist as brilliant as Wodehouse.  I love his other 'series' (Blanding's Castle, Uncle Fred, etc.) but Bertie and Jeeves top the list.  My life has truly been better having discovered this exquisitely entertaining world old P.G. created.  This one won't disappoint.

The perfect travel stand. Folds completely flat, well-made, very sturdy.  Your phone won't "tip over" due to rubberized feet and solid construction. Adjustable angles.  Fits in your pocket.  Very satisfied with this item - I'll never look for another stand.

I liked this book, but found it dragged a little, and frankly had a hard time keeping all of the characters straight.  Probably the best part about it is the author's writing style.  Very straightforward and direct - uses words economically.  The milieu is interesting - the backwoods area and people of upper Northeast Pennsylvania.  Survivalists, hunters, meth labs, subsistence living - sort of a "Deliverance" cast in the Northeast part of the country. The central character is of that culture, but also a lawman.  He works doggedly to solve two murders, one of a "person unknown" and the other of his deputy.  He does a great job of describing the physical environment and the characters in the area.  But again, I wasn't really "grabbed" by the plot, found it somewhat difficult  to follow the characters and the evolving plot line - it shouldn't take that much work.  I did enjoy his writing style and the book came to a satisfying closure in pulling all of the various characters and plot line together (unlike some other books I've read recently.  If they had 3 1/2 stars I would've given it that.

I've gone through numerous iPad cases/covers since I bought my iPad 4 a couple of years ago.  Everything from the "rugged" covers (didn't like) to slide-in cases to - you name it.  I finally tried one of the Smart Cover versions and really liked it, primarily due to it being light, not adding much thickness or weight to my iPad, and pretty much suiting my needs.  Unfortunately the one I purchased was made out of pretty cheap vinyl and within a month the corners were separating, etc. - so back to searching on Amazon. I found this "leather" Smart cover and I've had it about a month now and really like it.PROs- I don't know if it's real leather, but the cover looks very nice and is very well made.  Much more durable than my previous cheap vinyl cover.  it looks like it will stand up to handling for a long time- There is a unique magnetized portion of the cover (hard to explain - I think the listing shows how it works), but in folding up the cover into a triangle shape to use it as a stand you fold it so that the leather side is facing out, and the outer edge of the leather cover magnetically connects forming the triangle base.  Pretty cool - and it holds its shape and position very well- well made and durableCONs- the only con, and it's a minor one, is that I think the magnetized cover, when folded over to use the iPad in landscape or portrait mode, can accidentally put the iPad to sleep.  What I have done is to always fold under the outermost section of the cover so that it doesn't extend all the way to the back edge of the iPad - a minor issue. That solved the problem.Over all, very satisfied, and the price is unbelievable. It looks beautiful, and for me the thin cover allows me to use my Anker stand with the iPad fitting in the bottom slot, whereas thicker covers do not.

It's been a few years since I read a Carl Hiaasen book.  I remembered the 2 or 3 that I had read as being enjoyable, humorous reads.  This one just didn't do it for me.  Way too formulaic, as if he was pulling in his standard characters, events, and storyline (or lack thereof) in a cut and paste fashion.  It was a labor to read.  Can't recommend this and given this book I won't likely choose another from him.

This book has no weaknesses.  It grabs your interest from the very first page and holds it right through to the end.  Its probably my shortest duration read of the year (not shortest book  I just couldnt put it down).  First, it is eminently readable; the author has a way with words and storytelling that show real talent.  The setting is Western Australia, and while the focus is more on character than environment, she manages to mix excellent dialogue, descriptions of the country, people, setting of time and place, and cultural milieu perfectly.The storyline focuses on a couple, Tom and Isabel Sherbourne, newly married  after World War 1, living on a remote lighthouse post one hundred miles off the shore of southwestern Australia.  The insights into their characters, primarily Tom, is telling, as he deals with the terrible memories of his time in the trenches during the war, the friends he lost, and the Germans he killed.  He is eminently likable in terms of his values and character.  He meets Isabel (or I should say she meets him  and sets her sights on him) not long after his return from the War and his obtaining a post as a remote Lighthouse keeper  a job well-suited to his desire to get away for a while to deal with his emotional war memories.  They fall in love, get married, move to the remote Lighthouse island and set up as typical newlyweds.  Isabel desperately wants children, but after multiple miscarriages becomes resolved to the fact that their marriage will be childless.  No plot giveaway here, because it briefly opens the book, but one day a boat washes up on shore with a dead man and a young, but very alive, baby girl.From this point forward the book moves away from its day-to-day life of a family focus (which is still interesting), to a character study of the decisions they make, and eventually the consequences of those decisions.  It covers many perspectives  love, innate desires, rationalization of decisions, internal turmoil resulting from those decisions, doing whats right in a broader moral sense vs. doing whats right on a personal level, all carried off in a very deft manner by the author.  I had a sense of what the ending would be, but frankly was never certain.  Not until the last few pages does the reader find out the denouement.  In the end I would say it probes deeply into several life realities; how seemingly logical in the moment decisions can have long term consequences, how life is filled with both good events and bad events and their outcome (and our sanity) depends more on how we deal with them than the events themselves, and that life is never perfect and we must learn to make the most of what is given us, and cope with what is taken away from us.In summary, I found this book enjoyable, with likable but deep and interesting characters, and perhaps most importantly made me think (and will continue to make me think), about how our decisions, our character, and our attitude toward lifes ups and downs determines our ultimate satisfaction or dissatisfaction with our lives and ourselves.  Strongly recommend.

It's really mystifying to see all the glowing reviews for this book. I was very disappointed, for many reasons. First the entire first half of the book is tedious. I guess it's supposed to set up the second half of the book, but if so it could have done so in fewer pages. I was ready to give up on the book at the 50% point.  The two main characters are not likable, occasionally to the point of disgust.  I understand that characters don't need to be necessarily likable (e.g. Anna Karenina) but c'mon, this is a summer read, not classic literature. I'll admit at the 50% point it did grab me, and I'm thinking "ok, here' s the payoff for the miserable first half."  I won't write a spoiler review, so I'll just say that the second half sets the reader up for what could have been a sublime ending and frankly, even with having to wade though the first half, I would have written a positive review.  But sadly the ending is...extremely disappointing, unbelievable, and unsatisfying.  Have I made my point?  I literally felt cheated - a waste of my time is the best way to describe my feeling. Again, I wonder what book the praising reviewers were reading. It wasn't this one.  Don't waste your time. .

I wanted a bluetooth transmitter for my iPod Classic.  I bought this before seeing that there were models that attach via the iPod 30 Pin connector port.  This one attaches via a 3.5mm to 3.5mm double male connector (included with purchase, as well as a charging cord).  I think in retrospect I would prefer the 30 pin connector version since it sort of makes the iPod/Bluetooth device one compact unit.  Anyway, I can tell you that it does work, but not at a great distance from your speaker.  Max range line of sight is about 10 feet, and if any walls or doors are you are in the way it will not give a clear connection. When the connection is clear you will get good music play on your bluetooth speaker. The sound quality is more dependent on your speaker than on this device.  I am buying an inexpensive compact (no wire, one piece, metal) 3.5mm to 3.5mm plug that will come close to making this a "one piece device" with my iPod Classic.  Pairing is relatively easy, but be patient.  Put it in pairing mode close to your Bluetooth speaker and be prepared to wait about 10 seconds before pairing completes.  From that point on it should pair easily with the same speaker.

I did an unbelievable amount of research before buying this portable bluetooth speaker/speakerphone.  I watched dozens of YouTube videos, tried out as many models as I could at airport kiosks (I do a lot of traveling - hence the need for something portable).  My firm criteria was a) good sound quality - not ultra priced headphone or speaker quality, but not "tinny" or cheap sounding, b) ability to use (easily) as a speakerphone with my iPhone with good sound quality both talking and listening, and c) handy travel size and construction (i.e. can take some rough handling).  This one meets my standards on all three criteria. The sound is great - amazing bass from something about 4.5" in diameter. The Treble and Mids are great as well - you will enjoy your music, much better than your iPhone or iPad can produce.  Second, pairing is easy.  When you press the Power On button a pleasant female voice says "Powering Up,"  When you turn on Bluetooth on your phone or tablet the device says "Pairing," and when paired is successful says "You are connected."  I went with the black with red outer ring model because the controls are easier to see on the red ring, plus the black/red combo looks cool. It's built solid - no cheap plastic feel here.  And it comes with a carry bag,  a carabiner to hook to your bag, a 3.5mm to 3.5mm male connection cord, and USB to micro-USB charging cord.  I highly recommend - buy it and you won't regret it.

This is a very well made, utilitarian iPad/iPhone (or similar) "must have."  It's not as big as I imagined (I'd say it's about 4" tall X 5" wide) but that's a good thing - easy to throw in your bag for travel.  It is rock solid in construction - it will hold your full size iPad without as much as even a hint of a wobble.  It's infinitely adjustable for any angle (just push in the round ends of the swivel bar and move to the position you desire), and best of all it holds my iPad with the Smart Cover.  If you have a thicker cover you may have to remove the rubber inserts, or let your iPad st on top of the holding ledge vice inside it, but my Smart cover fits with no problem.  I have tried a couple of iPad stands and this one is hands down the best of the bunch - and looks cool as well.  Buy it.

I have trouble sleeping - or I should say "going to sleep," at night.  Odd, because I am tired, go to bed, but once I'm in bed the ol' mind starts working and....well you get the picture.  Lots of us like that out there. So I need help getting to sleep. I used the Ibuprofen PM tablets, and they work, but I wanted to try something else, so tried these.  The first time I tried them i woke up "groggy" the next morning.  Didn't bother me - since my objective was to get to sleep.  As I began to take them regularly I found that the groggy feeling went away and I slept normally, went to sleep reasonably well, without laying awake too long, and awoke feeling fine.  Close call, but I think I like these better than the Ibuprofen PM (different chemical - forgot the proper name).  These definitely work, and the price is great.

This is a reasonable cell phone holder for you car.  It holds the iPhone easily, but doubt it would hold the newer mega phones (i.e. Samsung Note, etc.).  It does work, but I was expecting something very "sticky" that would hold onto the dash without sliding around.  This one is just "OK" in that regard.  I tried it in a couple of cars and unless you have a pretty flat area it's going to end up sliding around, and maybe off the dash onto the floor.  I wouldn't buy it again, but since I have it, I find it useful.  I'll keep looking.

Practically everyone is aware of the slavery epoch in our history, and I guess common sense and logic tells us it was an unpleasant period. But never have I read such an intimate and dispassionate objective description of life as a slave as well done as this book.  Based on true events, it describes the kidnapping of a free african american family man from the North who is dragged into slavery in the South, and the ensuring (again, very objective) chronicle of his life as a slave over 12 years before, through extremely good luck and the perseverance of his former Northern benefactor, he is finally restored to freedom and family. What struck me was the inhumanity with which slaves were treated in a life of constant fear, extremely hard work, meager food and living conditions day after day after day. It opens your eyes, even if you think your eyes have already been opened.  Read it.

Art (i.e. winning a Pulitzer Prize) does not always equate to good entertainment.  This is a difficult story, abounding in very depressing descriptions of the miserable political and quality of life environment in North Korea.  The chronicle of the title character is somewhat fascinating, somewhat saga-like, as he undergoes suffering and maintains his sanity and a somewhat positive outlook on life, but the neverending onslaught of misery and oppression of North Korean life, while undoubtedly accurate and well-written, does not overcome the discouragement at reading page after page of just plain bad things.  I have to admit I gave it a good shot due to the Pulitizer Prize credential, but couldn't do it.

I read a previous Harry Hole mystery from Jo Nesbo, who some have claimed as "the best mystery writer in Norway."  While I am in no position to judge that, I can wholeheartedly say that she knows how to write a riveting story.  I'm actually about halfway through the book at this time, but it's a page turner with a compelling lead character, and well-drawn supporting characters.  The writing, the story, the plot line, the ability to provide you little details but leave you hanging for the threads to come together makes this a can't put down read.  I'll definitely read more Nesbo in the future.

I'm not sure how this book got consistent excellent reviews.  It is basically a monologue, written in first persion form, more as an essay than a story.  The narrator (an apt desriptive term) is an aging, dying, preacher (minister, etc.) from a long line of preachers.  The author has an excellent command of language, but that was only enough to hold my interest about a quarter of the way through the book. I kept waiting for other characters to emerge, other dialogue, a plot, a story.  I think it might have worked well as a short story, but not a novel.  I'll caveat my review that I stopped reading about a third of the way through - maybe something magical happens later on and all that's missing cited above magically appears.  But my patience wore thin.  I can't recommend this.

My Fiat is, as you know, a tiny car - but with a huge windshield. After careful measurement I figured these would fit, so ordered them.  They are well made - not cheap, and fit my car perfectly.  I had always had the "single" large foldable shades before, but after getting these I find I prefeer the two separate pieces; they give you more options for coverage and are easier to use.  As for the other reviewer's problems with folding them up - c'mon folks, it ain't that hard?  One hand on top in one corner, one hand on the bottom on the opposite corner, and just "twist" them closed into a small circle - which stays closed by the way.  Oh, and they are excellent at blocking the sun.

I wish I had time to write a longer review, but it would only echo many others.  Let me just say that Anthony Doerr has a gift for writing. His imagination and apparent knowledge of the world and arcane events, cultures, craftsmanship, and history is excellent.  Even in-depth research, which I'm sure he did, doesn't give you the kind of knowledge he conveys - in a most elegant writing style.  A top ten book for me this year.  Strongly recommend.

This magnifier is just OK.  The slide cover mechanism is a little cumbersome - it does work, but not as smooth as I had expected.  Overall not quite the quality I wanted.  My major issue is with the magnifier glass/plastic portion.  There is a lot of distortion around the edges.  The usable portion is a smaller circle in the center of the area. The item is not big to begin with, so you're not getting the full magnification across the entire lens area that you might want or need.  I generally reach for my non-lighted L-shaped 3 X 5 glass magnifier with an inset circle with stronger magnification for the really tiny close-up magnification rather than this one.

Yes, there are some aspects of this very well written debut novel that strectch believability, but in real life we see these things happen, and in the end I found it to be an engrossing read.  Those of us that are growing older can certainly empathize with the aging Ruth and her evolving issues with both recognizing her onset of dementia and weakening ability to cope with it.  In this state she is the perfect victim - isolated, alone, and (as we learn from her recollections of younger days), burdened with a "willing to go along" personality.  Into her life comes the unexpected, "too good to be true" Frida, who's strong presence and assertive behavior Ruth willingly succombs to, blithely indifferent to Frida's increasingly invasive intrusion and control of her life.  What I found unbelievable (but again, this happens) was Ruth's son's reaction to this sudden change of condition; He readily accepts Frida's thin explanations of her presence - perhaps too quickly glad to distance himself from concern about his aging mother's welfare.  By the time he  realizes his mother's risk, it is too late.  In a sense, the ending was inevitable and no surprise, but in spite of that I found this to be a page turner.  I literally read it in two days.  Ms. McFarlane has talent; her dialogue is superb, catching the nuances of Ruth's confusion in the present and her vivid memories of the past.  Cast against the cunning, illogical but seemingly logical arguments of Frida, she is helpless, carried inevitably toward her fate unable to cope with the strength of her predator Frida, as sure of her prey as the allegorical Tiger in the night Ruth hears, but never sees, prowling through her house. Aside from the story and the enjoyment of reading it, this is a representation of the world as it can be, where the weak are spotted, tracked, and ultimately fall victim to the predators in our midst.  Sons and daughters, look after your parents.

I've purchased numerous "Apple or Apple compliant" AC to USB charger units with hit or miss results.  When I saw this unit it prompted research on it and similar units, and I finally found out why some work and some don't.  They have different voltages!  I don't have an iPhone (yet), but I do have two iPads, and I'd get frustrated when I bought an "Apple equivalent" charger and it wouldn't work on my iPads.  The answer is that they were only generating less than the 2.1A needed for the iPad, and were likely generating only 1.0 or 1.5A, sufficient to charge an iPhone or Android phone.  So, after considering both the corded and uncorded (this model) I went with this one.  I have enough clutter, and didn't need or want a cord to exacerbate the problem.  Since receiving it I've been very satisfied. The outlets are clearly marked for the types of devices you can charge from each USB port.  As a result, my desk/work area top is much less cluttered, plus it's small and very handy for traveling.  Very Satisfied.

Other than being a little difficult in the beginning following the dual story lines from WW II to 1999-2000, the story begins to get a good rhythm and takes off from there.  Harry Hole is the prototypical beaten down but persistent but talented detective.  Smokes too much drinks too much, too often caustic, but ultimately knows himself and his business.  In other words, you may not like him in person, but you love reading about him.  Other reviews will tell you the gist of the plot and story, so I won't repeat it, but will say that I thoroughly enjoyed the book and recommend it.  "Greatest detective novel ever written in Norway?" I doubt it - but very good in any case.

This is an amusing and pleasant read, for about 100 pages.  After that, it becomes interminably repetitive and self-absorbed.  The author writes in an engaging style about life in a small New England town and his adoption and growing interaction with his dog Atticus and their mutual evolution into a renowned local twosome in accomplishing the physical and mental challenges of climbing all of the 4000 foot mountains in the state not once, but twice in a single winter. He presents himself as an iconoclast, writing and editing a local paper, touting himself as the lone voice against local political shenanigans, and tries valiantly to describe how his ability to overcome physical (he reveals his weight at over 300 pounds early on) challenges is eminently worthy. But put simply he tries too hard, and succeeds, at putting himself and, by association, Atticus, in the center of their own little universe, touting their accomplishments and ability to see the true beauty of nature while too often pointing out the inability of others to do the same.  Ultimately, this persistent theme of self-importance and blatant lack of any evolution of the story beyond simple numerical progress ("we made four peaks today") caused me to put it down - I could take no more.

I have lived long enough to have read articles, books, textbook sections, and seen movies about the institution of slavery.  I have also read books about the horrors of Nazi Germany's death camps and the plight of Jews throughout WW II Europe (e.g. Jodi Piccoult's "The Storyteller", Elie Weisel's "Night", among others).  The Holocaust, more recent and therefore more easily recalled, described, and verified, displays man's inhumanity to man and, perhaps more telling, the social acceptance, handed down from parents to children and reinforced by political and social leadership, of the inferiority of another race as justification for treating them no better, and often worse, than animals. Reading first person accounts of life in the Nazi death camps gave me some sense of how the day-by-day, no end in sight inhumane treatment including verbal and physical abuse, near starvation, lack of any medical care, and lack of sleep can lead one to concluding that anything, including death, is preferable to living in such conditions.  I guess I never really put slavery in that category of suffering - until reading this book.I always knew that slavery was terrible - my own sense of human equality and common sense told me so.  But unlike the Holocaust, slavery had its rose-colored glasses perspectives as well - witness "Gone With the Wind," et al.  But Solomon Northrup's story, especially the ten years spent in the Louisiana bayou on Epp's farm, portrays it in stark, brutal terms.  What must it be like to spend every waking hour in fear? From the lash and interminable back-breaking labor to the reality that you have no worth beyond serving the needs, financial, physical, and psychological of not only your owner but every other non-slave person in your world?  And no matter how terrible and physically punishing this day was that the next day held the same, or worse, outcome?  It was into this hell that Solomon Northrup was consigned for 12 years, and the sheer luck through which benign help and pure coincidence restored him to his freedom somewhat restores faith in human care and courage in helping his fellow man.The story is compelling - a page turner - and Solomon's account is articulate and objective.  Yes, it is not pleasant reading of such horrors, but it is written more as a documentary than a novel - a diary, as it were. Yes, it was slavery at its worst, and yes, even Solomon talks of owners who were more humane towards their slaves, but even those few, in perspective, separated mothers from children, husbands from wives, and had no qualms about selling their "property" into far worse situations. It was "the way life was" in those times.  Everyone, young and old, needs to read this book.  Not to wallow in self-guilt of the sins of more than a hundred years ago, just as none of us bear guilt for the Holocaust. But to better understand not only the glory, but the depths, of our country's history.  And while human cruelty and disregard for the value of life will be with us always, perhaps better insight and knowledge about its suffering and consequences can in some small way prevent it, in any form, from happening again.

I've accumulated about 5 or 6 iPad covers, ranging from the bare bones thin rubber slip-on to the "leather-like" book style where your iPad slips sideways into the inner pocket area to the rather nice Devicewear book style model with the little "clip" that ensures the iPad won't slip out of the several grooves available for upright landscap horizontal stance use, etc.  Of those mentioned, the Devicewear is, by quality, the best.  It has a very well-fitted hard plastic case that your iPad literally shoe horns into (not easy to get in, but never worry about it falling out), and I liked the "tab and groove-channel" feature to prevent slipping. But I also found that those cases are really great for landscape use (watching movies), but not so great for portrait applications or taking photos. I even bought a bluetooth keyboard that snaps on top of the iPad, made of aluminum, with the result that it looks like a small laptop, and if you do a lot of typing it's great.  But when I really analyzed how I used my iPad - basically just grabbing it and holding on my lap (at home) or on the fold-down table (plane flights) I could do without the front cover, wanted something a little rugged that would protect it well and also protect the screen (even if there is no screen cover) with a raised area to prevent the screen from contacting the floor first if dropped, so decided to give this one a try.  It comes in three pieces and zero instructions.  It's already assembled, so you have to take it apart first.  When I figured out you need to remove the outer silicone cover first (not intuitive), it was reasonable easy (a few tries) to separate the two plastic pieces inside. The iPad fits well into the bottom piece, then you simply work your way around the edge snapping the top and bottom pieces together (be sure you've got it turned so it aligns with the right buttons, switches, and camera).  It's a pretty snug fit once done. Then put the silicone cover back on (it fits snugly, so you'll have to do some stretching at the corners to pop it on).  Once on, it fits well, and the appearance is fine.  It does make the already heavy iPad even heavier, but I don't consider it a problem. It does protect the iPad very well, in my opinion.  Most of the iPad controls (charging plug, microphone, speaker, etc.) have notches cut out for them - no cover flaps (the speaker has holes, vice a cutout).  The exceptions are the side volume controls and the home button, but I find it easy to control them/press them through the silicone cover easily marked and tactile raised areas designed for that purpose. Finally it has a fold out stand on the back.  I had read many reviews about these fold out stands being "cheap" and breaking quickly.  I find this one one well made and unless you're crazy and pull it out very hard it's not going to break.  So you have a great stand for landscape use (watching movies, videos) and yes it works for portrait mode as well.  But frankly I usually hold my iPad on my lap or lay on a table when using portrait mode.  I think the Pros of this cover are that it is well made, protects your iPad, has a good stand, good fit, and easy access to all ports/controls/buttons.  The Cons are it makes your heavy iPad even heavier (not much of a bother to me - I like the solid feel), and it's not going to win any beauty contests - just your basic black.  Time will tell if this is the "keeper" iPad case/cover for me, but so far I like it - and the price is very reasonable. Oh, and it comes from China so you'll have to wait about 2-3 weeks to get it.  But it did arrive as promised.

I wasn't really looking for an external speaker for my iPad, but in browsing around on Amazon I saw several relatively inexpensive speakers with good to very good reviews.  Given the average built-in iPad speaker, at the prices I was seeing, I started doing some research across the various products, and settled on this one.  The factors that 'sold' me were the compact size, the ability to use it standing alone or attached to the iPad, the rechargeable battery, and most of all the very good reviews on the sound volume, clarity, and quality.  At this price I could't resist.  After receiving it, I found it well packaged and attractive, in a 'techie' sense.  I charged it for 3 hours as instructed, then tried it out on my iPad and the sound was very good.  Certainly not audiophile quality or anythng close, but a marked improvement from the iPad internal speaker. The size makes it easy to pack and use.  It comes with a charging cord (USB, but you can plug that into an AC adaptor) and a dual end audio connector (3.5mm? - the standard plug-in jack).  As an added note and recommendation, I purchased the "Bongiovi DPS Pro" app, which is a music player app.  I tried several (Accudio, Stella, Equalizer), but Bongiovi beat them all hands down.  It has a 'DPS' sound processor that really, and i do mean really, works.  It enhances the sound of music on your iPad (they also have a Mac version, which I also purchased). The difference with the DPS turned on and off is night and day.  The music quality, clarity, and refinement will blow you away.  I think the iPad app is $3, and the Mac app is $20.  And you can customize it to your earphones, headphones, or external speaker models.  But back to this product - with or without the DPS enhancement it's a must have.  Highly recommend.

This is a "readable" novel - I finished it. I don't finish books that don't hold my interest in (pick one): compelling writing, compelling plot, outstanding use of language, or interesting characters.  This one meets the mark in interesting characters and a sense of learning more about what slavery, and day-to-day relations between race were like pre-civil war, but that's about it.  There are a range of characters from the young black woman who had supposed magic powers, a plethora of "bad people" led by a ruthless slave trader woman, an honest and courageous widowed farmer who treats her slaves with honor and integrity, and a lesser group of low-character types on the trail of any negro target they could catch, abduct, or otherwise capture and turn for profit.  This leads to a range of concurrent storylines which detract from the plot - not add to it.There are a few likable characters - the widow farmer, her male slave, the "Woolman" (a black man who has left society to live mysteriously in the swamplands of Maryland's eastern shore), but the remainder are in a contest over who can be more vile, greedy, or contemptuous.  Read it if you are hostorically minded and interested in learning about slavery with some elements (few) of the underground railroad, but if you're looking for a good story and a good page-turner read, pass it by.
I had to replace the battery in my home alarm system and this one was an exact match (make and model) so I bought it, and it works.  Not much more I can say.  It certainly works and I'm satisfied.

I need reading glasses, to the point that I have about 15 pairs stashed everywhere, but since I'm farsighted I don't need glasses for driving, etc.  So too often I find myself at a store (that I have driven to without glasses), and even though I have some in my car I absent-mindedly go into the store without my glasses and when it comes time to read the fine print on a box, lable (including that pesky small faint % alcohol content on wine bottle labels) I was at a loss.  So I bought this little gem (and it is little, maybe 1 1/2" in diameter) to keep in my pocket all the time and it has proved to be a lifesaver.  The little plastic case it folds into is padded, which is great, and it slides in and out on a hinge very easily (there's an indentation in the case for you to "grab" the magnifier.  it is 8X power, plenty powerful to read any small print.  if you, like me, are farsighted, need reading glasses, and somewhat forgetful about having them with you all the time - get this.  You'll be glad you did.

I looked at pages of loupes on the Amazon site before buying this one. What caused me to choose this one was that it was all-metal; the others at this price point are a combination of metal and plastic, or all plastic.  And if I have to change a battery with a little tool, I definitely want metal, not plastic. Second, although I couldn't really confirm it until I got it, is that it is well made in terms of opening and closing easily, yet it stays closed when closed.  The loupe portion is large enough to easy look through while holding up close to your eye (and holding the object of interest about an inch away from the other end, and it works whether you wear glasses or not - just a slight adjustment in how far you hold the object of interest from the loupe is the only adjustment needed.  The lights are perfect - very bright, and I would not buy one that didn't have the LED lights. They are easy to turn on and off (the switch is very small, but your thumbnail/fingernail will easily flick the switch.  It worked right out of the box, and I love it. The power is great - you can read the smallest print you will ever need to read, and can check dates on coins, stamp markings, etc.  Haven't tried it on diamonds, but then again I didn't buy it for that and the jewelry shops always have a (much better) loupe you can use.  For my needs, this fits the bill perfectly.

This is one medium-to-heavy duty magnetic pick up tool.  Very strong pick-up magnet, good quality flexible metal extension, and a very comfortable handle.  Not much more you can say - except if you need a magnetic pickup tool (and you likely will) this one will fill the bill in spades.

I was expecting something a little on the cheap side, but functional. This is inexpensive, but definitely not cheap.  It is very well made, works very smoothly (the extension is effortless - no sticking), and is solidly built.  Easy to grip, and the mirror is good quality and easy to see.  Everyone tool persion or homeowner needs one of these (I guarantee there will come a time when it will be indespensible) - so why not get it now at this price?

I was a little disappointed.  Not a lot - it is a fine pen, but from the writeup and the reviews it sounded so good that just using it would improve my c****y handwriting.  It does write smooth, and is comfortable in your hand, and I guess everything it claims to be, but IMHO so are many other pens out there these days (mid-range rollerballs).  Just my opinion - maybe you will find otherwise.

You're not getting designer glass cases here - just functional, well-made, vinyl (kind of leather looking) cases that will hold a pair of reading glasses easily.  They are too small to hold larger glasses or sunglasses, but the price is low and the workmanship is great - not "cheap" looking at all. Again, get them for function (protecting your glasses, althought they are soft-sided), but better than carrying around your reading glasses unprotected.  At this price I bought about 4 of them - in every color.

My wife and I have an historic condo in a circa 1890's building - a truly lovely period place with high ceilings, wide moldings, huge pocket doors, marble fireplaces, wood floors, etc.  it cries out for period-piece furniture and "atmosphere" consistent with it's heritage.  We both love candles, but they have their drawbacks, from real flames in an older buidling (not a good combination) to dripping, wick-cleaning, etc.  Nevertheless, they are worth the effort.  When saw these I had to have them.  First, they look EXACTLY like real wax candles - and even kind of feel "waxy" (although they are not made of wax). And the electric "candle" light is authentic - and can be adjusted from just "on" to a "flickering" real candle effect.
