Yershons score to Mr. Turner functions more as a musical touch-up instead of a full-on narrative. The musics nature to evoke movement in the listeners mind is a very interesting thing, but it never does anything to really stand out.Mr. Turner is a fine score for what it is, it wont wow you or change your life. However, its approach and simple structure is worth exploring. There is life in this score, and it comes out in strokes of motion as dictated by simple strings. Never does it feel like a period piece score or a biopic score, and for that its noteworthy. The score simply exists, but since it feels like a floating creation it lacks a narrative flow and is light on emotional depth.

Bank$tas is a piss-poor excuse of a raunchy comedy made with practically no budget, but also no talent either. Two finance grads get hired by a top investment bank only to discover their boss is creating an investment fraud scheme with student loans. Cue the sex, drugs and rock and roll. If you can get through the trailer youll notice that it looks like it was made by film school dropouts. I cant say its any better for the score by Steve London. The score feels like a hashed up and phoned in attempt of copying that gritty comedy style that other composers and filmmakers are doing much better.I could go on bashing this really bad film, but instead of me saying how much is sucks I will try and analyze why it sucks. First of all, no central thematic structure (any structure for that matter). Each track feels like it was scoring different scenes in the same style. Its an electronic score that just reuses loops and beats. All the textures and stylings feel like something cooked up in Garage Band or someone who is vaguely trying to channel the Ocean's Eleven scores but hasn't seen the films since they were in theaters. Nothing ever amounts to anything or leads anywhere. For comparison lets look at a great composer like Christopher Lennertz who is absolutely owning the R-rated comedy genre right now. His scores are tons of fun, characteristic, stylistic and work with the comedy happening onscreen. You can look at something like Horrible Bosses or Ride Along and see how music should work in a comedy of this nature. Bank$tas is an example of how it fails. This is the result when a composer is handed a poorly made film probably filled with the writers' and director's favorite music as temp, and decides to phone it in. The music opens with a terrible original rap song, sort of moves into some jazz sounding stylings, and ends up in the 70s porn category of sounds. And if the opening original rap song wasnt enough, dont worry because they have a closing "End Title" rap song too. Be sure to check out tracks like Limp Dicks and Smoking Strawberry Fields, because everyone knows that titties + weed = comedy.Save yourself the embarrassment and waste of time. Bank$tas is a piss-poor excuse of a movie and a piss-poor example of the craft of film scoring. Im amazed this got a soundtrack release, simply amazed. Filmmakers, and composers specifically, should study this if they want to know what not to do. The music feels so mechanized and inorganic, as if a human had nothing to do with it. Zero emotions, zero character, zero atmosphere, zero structure and a style that would best suit a toddler banging on one of those Casio keyboards you had in pre-school. I don't wanna come across an old bitter dad (I'm only 27 anyways), because I love comedies of all nature. I love stoner comedies, I love dick jokes and physical comedy involving bodily fluids. Gratuitous nudity? Sure, toss it in... as long as the comedy works! This Is The End? Hilarious. Henry Jackman's score? Perfect for it. This wreck of a score and film thinks its funny without ever being funny, and that's why it fails so badly. Bank$tas gets the coveted zero star rating, I think a first for Film.Music.Media at the time of this review.

Here we are again, the completion of another Middle Earth trilogy from Peter Jackson and Howard Shore. As I reflected back on The Hobbit films and scores, I realized they didnt leave as much of a lasting impact as The Lord Of The Rings. The thematic impact of The Hobbit scores were much less, and this is mainly due to the fact that Warner Brothers forced Jackson to make three films out of a a 320 page novel. This resulted in Shores score having to feel thin, sort of stretched, like butter scraped over too much bread. as Bilbo once said. The final product is a 3-act story being spread across 3 lengthy films instead of 3 books being adapted into three lengthy films. That doesn't mean though that Howard didn't perfectly accompany the narrative here. We indeed to have some brilliant scores, including this one. The first score was a great introduction to this journey, however the main motif of it wasnt written by Shore. But he ran with the Misty Mountains motif and made it work. The second score, while strong, lacked thematic structure. It had to fill space for most of the second act narrative and pretty much kill time till movie #3. Now for The Battle Of The Five Armies, we truly see that Shore was saving the best for last. We finally have fully realized thematic structures, and the score becomes a tremendous experience.What you notice about this score is that it truly hits the ground running, and thats expected since this entire film is the third act of a story that has taken us two films to get here. The added narrative filler does hurt the trilogy somewhat and story-wise makes them inferior to The Lord Of The Rings trilogy, but in no way are The Hobbit films bad films. The Battle Of The Five Armies is a whopping epic of a score. Shore weaves themes with propulsive melodies to build a sense of scope and magnitude that we havent heard since The Return Of The King. Rousing battles, threatening intensity, wholly organic emotions and a swelling tone of regality make the whole score an absorbing epic. Shore references some familiar themes from the LOTR trilogy that creates a nice bridge and truly makes these films feel part of Middle Earth. We wrap up the journey in a nice sentimental fashion that reminds us that Frodos journey is what lies ahead. Overall, The Battle Of The Five Armies does a fantastic job of providing a rousing climactic epic to this adventure embedded in a world of fantasy.Howard Shores music for Peter Jacksons adaptations of the Middle Earth saga has become an iconic part of our culture. In many ways it was the Star Wars of a different generation; a truly engrossing journey filled with characters we love and a story we resonated with. Middle Earth felt like a real place because of Shores music, and the characters felt real because of the thematic arcs he built for them musically. The Battle Of The Five Armies is a superb final act to this long and sometimes tiring journey of Bilbo Baggins, but after 3 films we can smile contently as we have another great trilogy worth getting lost in. WaterTower Records fantastic special edition treatment of the score is worth snapping up immediately to complete your collection.

I grew up in the time when the genre of trailer music became a thing. Before advertising music, movie trailers just used other movie scores almost as a temp track. I remember the trailer for Braveheart and how it used Mark Mancinas Speed. I remember the trailer for The Lost World and how it used Hans Zimmers Backdraft. The brotherly composing duo known as E.S. Posthumous brought this sort of epic cinematic music with a modern edge to the spotlight, even though Yoav Gorens Immediate Music can probably be credited as the pioneer of music licensing libraries. E.S. Posthumous never really composed music for trailers, even though their music was used in them a lot. As a budding film score enthusiast it was easy to fall in love with these trailer music companies like Immediate Music, X-Ray Dog, Extreme Music and many more. As the internet evolved we were able to use it to find this rare sect of music that was never released commercially. Using Napster and Morpheus, people like me could build a trailer music library of sorts with many thanks to soundtrack.net at the time. Thankfully, we dont live in those dark ages anymore. Trailer music is celebrated and cherished these days as a way for composers to really try out different styles and genres that will hopefully entice production companies to use their music to build epic 2-minute teasers.This compilation album is a gathering of some great trailer music composers out there, and while in no way a score album it definitely represents many characteristics of film scores. My only issue with compilation albums (of any kind), are that they are usually a pieced together list of tracks that don't relate to each other. I would much rather have full albums from these music houses, and luckily many of them have CD albums available. But for a sole purpose of having a sampling of different styles of trailer music, this album is a good starting point. Not all the tracks are fully inspired here, and you'll probably find yourself leaning towards certain composers over others. In a time where digital music has broken the album experience, I kind of turn my head at compilation albums. Why would I want someone else's playlist of music when I could build my own? Music houses like Immediate Music and Two Steps From Hell have released amazing albums of their music, those are worth checking out way more over a compilation in my opinion. I feel that celebrating trailer music as a real genre of music by having these music groups release albums of their own music is fantastic. I feel like releasing a piecemeal compilation actually reverses the idea of trailer music as art and takes it back to being simply disconnected commercial tunes.Epic Music, Vol. 1 is a great way to get different styles of trailer music in one package. Hopefully it will inspire you to seek out these music groups own albums of music that does wonders to spark the imagination. If you just love swelling and emotional tracks then youll get a rise out of this album, but its also a great mind sparker for filmmakers. If youre into editing, writing or shooting of any kind then I cant tell you many times Ive used trailer music to spark ideas in my own work. Definitely check the album out to hopefully spark your own curiosity. But since I'm not a fan of compilation albums of any kind really, I highly suggest seeking out the solo albums released by these awesome composers. But if you want to get your feet wet first in this genre, then, this might be the album for you.

You know...It's funny: When it was announced that Rare would be bought out by Microsoft, they made it seem like it would be a decision that would greatly enhance not only the Xbox lineup, but Rare's own creations. Over a decade later, we learn not only has the famous development team churned out way less titles than when they were with Nintendo and prior, but notable franchises such as Conker and Banjo-Kazooie haven't fared well at all from the purchase. This installment in particular pretty much convinced Microsoft to have Rare only make Kinect Sports games from that point on until this year, when they suddenly released one of the best video game collections ever made.But anyway, Banjo Kazooie: Nuts and Bolts is the FIFTH Banjo game in the series, NOT the third. You see, despite Rare being owned by Microsoft, they were still allowed to make games for the Game Boy Advance and eventually the Nintendo DS, two of them being Banjo games; 2003 saw the release of Banjo Kazooie: Grunty's Revenge, an original platforming-adventure that took place between the first two games, and two years later there was Banjo Pilot, which was basically a kart-racer except with planes. Because THQ, the titles' publisher, didn't promote them much at all, they've become drastically overlooked in comparison to the other games in the series.So if anything, I would gladly consider Grunty's Revenge to be the real "Banjo Threeie" over this crap.The first glaring issue with the game is how egotistical it is of itself. The story is basically a re-enactment of a meeting at Microsoft (or so I like to think of it), as Banjo, Kazooie, and living 80s computer L.O.G. remind me a lot of bickering executives. L.O.G. persuades to Bear and Bird that nobody likes playing platformers anymore (Because Super Mario Galaxy totally bombed, right?), and that kids today just want to shoot things. The result? L.O.G. shoves the duo into a mission-based game involving cars. No, seriously. How L.O.G. decided to pick a car theme out of the idea that kids like shooting games is beyond my knowledge.Missions are held within various themed worlds as can be expected, but everything is so ridiculously played out this time. Each world opens up like some corny television program, and the supporting characters of each world are literally placed in a role as if they were actors. Whatever happened to the naturally whimsical feel of the original games? Nuts and Bolts instead has everything mechanically in place, and the game itself constantly likes to believe there isn't even a fourth wall, as everything is pointed out as they know they're in a game. They even talk about wondering if this game would be successful, Kazooie complaining about not having her abilities from older games, etc. I thought video games are supposed to make you think you're in another reality that's unlike our own, not outright admit it's all a setup from the get-go.Because of the mission-based play, don't expect to do much when you're not assigned anything; the environments are basically empty playgrounds you could explore by driving your car. The missions themselves are usually things that involve your car (Duh), but even when you try your best to ignore the fact that this carries the Banjo Kazooie name, the missions don't feel as robust or rewarding as platforming challenges one conquers in the adventuring titles. They feel a lot like the missions from Mario Kart DS's Mission mode, except less fun and with lesser variety. Certain objectives are rather vague, while some others can be frustrating all because the car's wonky "realistic" control schemes would throw you off.Because of all this, I actually ended up getting BORED playing this game, which is something I never expected a game by Rare to cause. I was increasingly growing tired of doing car-based missions that all require me to sit in the thing and drive it in ways that aren't as reliable as they should have been. The scary part is I gave this game many, many chances to appeal to me, but every play session I attempted, I ended up wanting to play anything else on my Rare Replay disc and/or Banjo Kazooie: Grunty's Revenge. Don't play this game if you don't want your memories of Bear and Bird tainted.

Quick disclaimer: I paid $2 for my used copy. Easily the only deal I ever found good enough for this game.For those of you that have been living under a rock or something, Angry Birds is a little game that Rovio released on mobile devices for $0.99 back when smartphone gaming began to take off. Because of that, it quickly became a cultural phenomenon and spawned numerous more games. I'd be fine with that, but then Activision came along and got an idea: "Let's make easy cash on this trend by releasing overpriced $40 ($20 for handheld, but that's still $19 more than the original price) versions of some Angry Birds games for store shelves so little kids can spot them and bug their clueless parents until they fall into the scam!"There's a reason why I didn't buy this Nintendo 3DS edition of Angry Birds Star Wars when it came out; supporting full retail priced Angry Birds is like supporting Destiny: The Taken King.Anyway, Angry Birds Star Wars continues the simplistic physics-based mechanics that the series has been known for since its debut in 2009. You use your eyeballs to scan the level layout, slingshot some birds across, and hope that they crush the opposing green pigs, whether by direct means or toppling over wood or stone structures. The birds are color-coded, as what unique ability they can use (especially in the case of Star Wars) depends on the color of the bird. For example, red birds can swing the lightsaber, and yellow birds shoot with Han Solo's signature blaster.The level designs proudly emphasize on its surroundings, as you could try and knock out the pigs right then and there, but there are also ways you could strategically launch birds in areas that would cause catastrophic results against the pigs. There are mirrors that can reflect the blaster lasers, TNT boxes to blow up, and the game even takes a few cues from Angry Birds Space by including some gravity-based layouts. With well over 200 of these levels, plus 20 more levels that are apparently exclusive to this version of the game (not that it would justify the purchase alone), there's plenty of bird-slinging action to go around. It's madly addicting to fire off a bird or few, and it's always satisfying to watch the layouts get destroyed by your antics. Star Wars makes things even more interesting thanks to its theme and unique Jedi powers the birds carry. It's somewhat odd that this game runs in 30fps instead of 60 (I mean, really? It's freaking Angry Birds!), but it's easy to get used to, and is by no means a dealbreaker.Angry Birds Star Wars is indeed recommended, but of course, only if you buy it for cheap. Now that copies can be spotted for as low as $4 (if not lower, considering how much I paid for mine), I think it's okay to buy into it if you have a few bucks to spare and/or aren't as fond of doing this stuff on mobile phones as you would on a Nintendo handheld. It's nowhere as criminal as the initial price, that's for sure.As for the business practices to begin with, they certainly get a -1/5.

How the crap do licensed games keep surprising me in expectations? Various games based off of movies or television shows are usually considered to be the bottom of the barrel for video gaming, yet I tend to find that they simply fluctuate in quality. Activision's video game based off of the new Spongebob movie certainly sucked big time, but the game based off of frickin' G-FORCE of all things is actually not bad! Heck, whole development teams like Wayforward and Telltale Games are notable for defying the majority rule of licensed games; they consistently make their games well!Being that the Game Boy Advance has always been home to excellent portable games and surprising gems, I was hoping that this game based off of the Mucha Lucha cartoon would be decent enough. BOY WAS I WRONG! Turns out this is one of the worst beat 'em ups I've ever played. Oopsie. Imagine playing a game like the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles arcade classic; strip out the charm, variety, and make the controls and hit detection sloppy. Oh, and make the bosses easy enough for you to button-mash on the A or B button to beat. That's this game. If it wasn't ultimately repetitive enough to be fighting the same kind of baddies over and over, the lousy lack of effort in the mechanical workings would definitely work its way in to irk you throughout your potentially short-lived playtime.

Back in 1996, Kawasaki's notable appearance in the video gaming industry was a sponsorship in Nintendo's superb water racing classic, Wave Race 64. Fast forward to 2008, Wave Race 64 has already seen a release on the Wii Virtual Console sans the sponsorship, but Kawasaki allowed for another development team to feature its name on a jet skiing video game. The difference, however, is that this development team is the bane of the Wii's existence, and while Kawasaki Jet Ski is probably the best game they've created, it doesn't seem like it really says a whole lot.Kawasaki Jet Ski's menus REEK of "budget (or lack of) title", as they are some of the most static uninteresting menus I've seen in a Wii game, although that may as well apply to pretty much anything put out by Data Design Interactive. The thing that irks me here however is that it's pretty obvious they wanted this game to be their own Wave Race, but Wave Race had animation and charm in their menus. This doesn't.There are three game modes: racing, balloon popping, and stunt performing. There are only ever four courses per mode, but the main racing selections apparently pretend there's more to it, as there are Bronze, Silver, and Gold cups, and all the modes have "two classes". To save you some time, though, I'm going to be blunt and tell you that the only difference between the cups is that the tracks are in different orders; the classes also don't affect anything at all in any mode whatsoever.As shameful and poor as this game seems, there is actually something to the racing gameplay that I do think works well enough. Contrary to most of DDE's games, the controls actually WORK (albeit slightly inaccurate)....when you're not doing the stunt performances. But anyway, the game functions similarly to Wave Race in terms of control. You steer your jet ski left and right around the water, and newly added to this simple formula are Nitro balloons, which allow you to use a Boost by shaking the Wii Remote once after the bar is filled to the extent of your liking. I actually do think this has good potential, but the tracks are simple in design and don't take advantage of the racing as Wave Race would do. And since there's really only four of them, your interest would fade before long.Speaking of four, the balloon popping and stunt performance modes have that amount. The balloon popping is super-strict, as it just BARELY gives you enough time to pop each and every balloon or balloon chains scattered around the tracks. As for the stunts..........Again, the control is broken here. Data Design Interactive has always been awful at putting in motion control, and that's apparently how you do the majority of the stunts.I could imagine this game being a guilty pleasure of mine for when I'm bored and feel like racing in a cup (not all of them for obvious reasons), but as I see it in reality, the game is absolutely bare-bones and totally not worth playing through any more than a cup. There are far better options out there; after all, there IS a Wave Race game on the Gamecube, and the Wii is backwards-compatible with Gamecube games, so that may as well be your calling if you crave these kind of games.

Holy crap, guys! Yet ANOTHER gem on the Wii U? Nintendo, you shouldn't have! Since you have though, I will gladly crave every single bit of it.Anyway, when Mario Maker was first announced, I liked to joke about it and call it the "New Super Mario Bros. development tool", and at best I thought it was a cute little tool and nothing much more. Fast forward to one of the biggest events in gaming history, the Nintendo World Championships, having made a grand return and ultimately epic finale by using levels made with the game, and now I'm all over it! As the 30th Anniversary title for the Super Mario Bros. series, not only does it knock the 25th Anniversary game (a direct retail port of Super Mario All-Stars for the Wii with underwhelming extras) out of the park, but buying this game feels like getting the keys to an amusement park! Heck, it could even be better!So what makes Super Mario Maker special? Well, if you haven't known by this point, YOU CAN MAKE MARIO LEVELS!!! It may not be the first video game to utilize a level-designing concept, but COME ON! IT'S FREAKING MARIO!! The franchise that practically invented the platforming genre, and with this title, YOU are in control of it! And not only do you get to make your own Mario levels, but you can also play levels made by pretty much anybody else that owns the game by going online via the "Course World" feature. As of this writing, it's been reported that there's already a MILLION levels uploaded to be played by people around the globe, so I think it's safe to say there's plenty of content here!What I was personally blown away by was how instant getting to play other levels is! Levels, online or not, can be selected and played on a whim; the option is there, but you don't even have to download them! You can just play from the get-go, and the variety of levels people have made have been absolutely stunning (although I guess there's an over-abundance of levels that troll you or play themselves). If there are levels you don't like, you can just move on and play others. Or better yet: You can MAKE YOUR OWN!At first, the level designing aspects are a little bit limited. You don't start out with ALL the customizable sets, but once you decide to sit down and create to your heart's desire, you'll realize that even with the content you start out with, the sky is pretty much the limit. There are countless ways any selectable object could be used! Enemies can be stacked on top of each other, you can make them fly, grow big, or stuff them in blocks, blocks and coins can be spread around and laid out in any way imaginable, etc. It's also a good way to challenge yourself and learn how to make decent levels with such content handed out so far. As time passes on while you play with the course maker, however, you'll get more and more to work with until you finally have all the sets of objects available, and that's where things get kicked into high gear! Flying Koopa Clown Cars, Yoshi, P-Switches, vines, and many more course elements would be put to great use as YOU, the designer, cram and make as much use of these things as possible! Even sub-areas and selectable sound/visual effects would be available for you to toy with the level atmosphere!With such a robust level creator and editor, I can't believe I'm about to say it, but I had so much fun creating levels in Super Mario Maker! Usually, level editing isn't all too exciting. In fact, even when I get to make my own independent games this day and age, and while the ideas I usually have appeal to me quite a lot, there are certain inevitable instances where game designing would feel kind of tedious. But with Super Mario Maker? I found myself wanting to do MORE levels after I've unleashed a new creation! The Mario Paint-esc interface makes it incredibly easy to build your level, and you're able to switch between testing and editing the level, again, ON A WHIM! It's an absolute joy finding your urge and witnessing your designs come to life before your eyes! It's even fun when you experiment with certain objects and watch how they work during gameplay; it makes things interesting as you learn about what happens, whether or not it works, and how you could put it into effect if it does.You start out with two themes: One for Super Mario Bros, and the other for New Super Mario Bros. U. However, like the objects, you eventually get to use Super Mario Bros. 3 and Super Mario World themes. I personally think it's misleading to call these "themes", there's more differences between the games than just the graphics. For example: If you pick Super Mario World, you'll get to use the spin jump and ride Yoshi, and if you pick New Super Mario Bros. U, you get to wall jump, ground pound, and do that twirl in the air. I never thought Super Mario World would look any better than it already has, but the HD and even-more-smoothed-out control convinced me otherwise. Super Mario Bros., definitely got the biggest benefit; considering how limited the original game was, it's quite amazing to see how it can now be given a variety and scale that is on par with its successors. While not every enemy and platform from each game is selectable, the sets are composed of a compromise of objects you can use for each theme. Super Mario World, for example, doesn't have the Chargin' Chucks or fireball-spitting flowers present, but you can use Hammer Bros. and Chain Chomps, so the selection is still far from underwhelming.Playing a Mario level (assuming the user-made level doesn't feature anything that trolls the player or takes control away) is as fun as it's always been, except you can finally bask in the glory that is the 80s and 90s Mario games with brand new level designs! The control has been refined to perfection (especially for Super Mario Bros.), and the new elements that you'd discover by means of playing various levels can make the titles feel fresh and new again. Never would I have thought I'd be facing Bowser Jr. in a Koopa Clown Car while avoiding Magikoopas and Wigglers in the original Super Mario Bros! And regardless of how the level itself fares, and whether or not if it's your level, it's always fun passing the controller to someone else and see how he or she would react.Perhaps the closest things there are to an actual structured campaign are the 10- and 100- Mario Challenges. These challenges have you play through a series of randomly selected levels (the most being 16); the 10- Mario Challenges go over Sample courses (and as such, unlock more), and the 100- Mario Challenges grab levels from the Internet. Interestingly, beating a 100- Mario Challenge grants you an unlockable Mystery Mushroom costume, which can also be done simply by using Amiibo. When Mario uses the Mystery Mushroom, he turns into whatever surprising sprite you set it to, and literally any Amiibo out there can allow Mario to turn into the characters those Amiibo represent (That is, if you're not up to playing loads of levels through 100- Mario Challenges, but I think I'd rather do that anyway).The Amiibo and Mystery Mushroom usages are sadly more-or-less for decoration, as Mario doesn't gain any special powers or anything like that. However, that's a mere nitpick for what is otherwise probably one of the greatest Mario games to date. The possibilities with the courses you can make or play are ENDLESS! I STRONGLY recommend you pick this one up if you like fun! Don't own a Wii U? Then maybe it's about time you get one and stop missing out on stuff like this!For those of you who already own the game, here are my levels I made and uploaded for all to play!Nostalgia Bound Vol. 1: 9FIB-0000-0043-1979Nostalgia Bound Vol. 2: 7611-0000-0043-63BBSituational: 7962-0000-0043-87B1Nostalgia Bound Vol. 3: CAA4-0000-0044-D88BHow to Troll Awfully: 85A8-0000-0047-23FCRemembering the Undersea Melody: 0288-0000-004B-12F8Beyond Scope and Scale: 4BCD-0000-0054-739BDonkey Kong Junior Returns: C78A-0000-0063-9DD2The Mountainous Castle: 83A3-0000-0069-2ACCPS: If you worry about encountering one too many stupidly hard levels, do yourself a favor and play the 100 Mario Challenge on NORMAL difficulty. Expert may sound like fun, but trust me; there is about 95%+ less levels that purposely try to screw you over if you play it in Normal, as there are instead way more levels that could actually be tolerated and beaten more comfortably.

You've seen bunches of video games based on movies and cartoon shows every now and then, but then suddenly we have a game based off of.....a nature documentary. This is going to be a FUN one, guys!Arctic Tale is a video game where you control a polar bear, and eventually you get to control a few other animals as well, but it's mainly about the polar bear. Kinda. I honestly wouldn't even know if this is even supposed to be an actual adventure, because the game's missions are often, if entirely, composed of minigames. It may seem like the game would be a 3D platformer starring a polar bear or something like that, but then suddenly your bear will be a living shuffleboard disc or sliding down an ice slope with half-working controls.Despite that the back of the box says the Wii's Nunchuck controllers are usable, the game itself encourages you to take it off the Wii Remote. Instead of moving via an analog stick, the game thought it would be better off for you to POINT AND CLICK (whilst holding down a button) to get the polar bear moving! It could probably work in a game solely created to be a story-orientated point 'n click game, but the story here is totally minimal, and the structure is set up like another genre.The minigames you have to do are just as crappy of course. The most functional minigame in the lot is probably the shuffleboard one, with its ice physics being the only flaw about it relatively to everything else. Certain minigames are outright uncontrollable, and others are simply embarrassing. The most major one is the polar bear fighting, where one bear would duke it out against another by shoving each other on an ice platform. Sounds like fun? Too bad you don't control any of it! It's all automated as you button-mash to quick-time events, and the bears themselves look like they're very lazily struggling to put up any sort of fight whatsoever, so it's often unintentionally hilarious to watch.All things considered, Arctic Tale is exactly how you may have expected it to turn out on the Wii: Sloppy, unpolished, and unplayable.

After one of the greatest and most recognizable arcade games in history came into the scene, the yellow muncher that starred in the hit went on to be featured in sequels for years before the home console became immensely popular thanks to the likes of Nintendo. Pac-Man and two other games in the series would be ported faithfully to the Nintendo Entertainment System, but in terms of new games, Pac had to wait until the Super NES era to get some more. While they've had their time in the spotlight briefly, out comes Pac-Man World on the Playstation in 1999/2000 to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the chomping ball's existence in gaming. Little did as much people know, however, about the OTHER Pac-Man game that came around during that time.Pac-Man: Adventures in Time is a tragically overlooked game in the franchise that was only ever released for PC during the witnessing of the 21st century. Rather than being developed directly by Namco, production was handled by Hasbro and Creative Asylum, so I guess they didn't...promote it much?? I personally managed to stumble upon this game a very long time ago as I was, and still am, a huge-enough Pac-Fan to play more of the series than just the arcade classics. But enough about me; let's talk about why this game is a must-play!If you can excuse the brief but silly storyline about an amulet that stabilizes Pac-Land's freedom from terror being smashed and scattered across time, Pac-Man Adventures in Time should make anyone that's played a Pac-Man game feel home, because the game consists of running around a maze, eating all the dots in the maze, being chased by ghosts, eating the ghosts after consuming Power Pellets, and snagging bonus fruits and other objects worth points. It is the typical arcade-style Pac-Man formula (with the ability to jump a la Pac-Mania), presented in a gorgeous Sega Dreamcast-looking 3D world.With that said, I'd be lying if I said this was exactly like the originals. Being that this is a retail video game made in 2000, there are 45 mazes you go through before you end up beating the game, each handful being divided up into several different time periods, whether they be in the Wild West or in Prehistoric Times, for example. The mazes may have their own subtle gimmicks, such as a button by a piano that causes the ghosts to stop and dance, snakes that when awake will bite and stun Pac-Man upon contact, rolling boulders, and even extra maze layers. The mazes themselves often (but not every time) tend to borrow the designs of ones from Pac-Man and Ms. Pac-Man, but the little things added in each maze do help give it a nice sense of variety and keep things fresh.Every division of mazes, there will be a couple times where you play a bonus minigame. The minigames don't necessarily have to be beaten to move on, as their goals consist of getting good amounts of points to score, but they are fun little distractions in their own right, if a little lacking at certain points. Whatever the case may be, though, you better hope to get as many points as you can, because while Pac-Man: Adventures in Time doesn't SEEM hard, extra lives are rather scarce, as you could only get one every 50,000 points. One may most likely not be challenged too much when playing most of the game, but when the time comes, it will hit HARD. Perhaps my only real complaint with this game is that even when saving your progress, the amount of lives will stay the same. Since the game asks you to save every couple mazes, there fortunately is at least time to change your score for the better.As progress is made in the game generally, there is actually a healthy dose of unlockable content. There are plenty of extra mazes with features unique to those mazes, the minigames could be freely played, and you could not only view the little cutscenes that play throughout the game, but also unlock bonus "outtakes" and other little bits of goofiness with Pac-Man and co. It's fun to make the extra effort to achieve these things, as well as check them out.All things considered, Pac-Man: Adventures in Time is a lovely hidden entree that should be very tasty for Pac-Fans or gamers in general (but especially Pac-Fans of course) that are willing to play a game on the computer. What makes this even more recommendable is that this game can actually run just fine on pretty much every Windows computer there is (Not that I've tried on Windows 10, however; I currently own a Windows 8), so fans of any Windows generation could buckle down and love this game!

If you thought Mario Kart 8 was already one of the best games in the series and a top-tier title for the Nintendo Wii U, just wait til you see that there's yet another positive to be known about the title: For the first time ever in gaming history, there's a video game that has reasonably priced DLC! This is actually a bundle of two DLC packs for the game, but it's a lot easier to judge it as one.Not only do you get to have new characters come to the Mario universe to kart around such as Link from the Zelda series and Villager and Isabelle from Animal Crossing, but there are also four brand-new cups featuring half-and-half of shiny new original tracks and shiny new renditions of classic courses from Mario Karts gone by! Certain tracks include locations from the aforementioned series our new drivers are from, AND F-Zero and Excitebike; it's like this game is turning into Nintendo Kart (Although there are still a good dose of Mario-related tracks)! And I dunno if Nintendo implanted some sort of mind-reading device on me, but somehow they knew I wanted Ribbon Road and Cheese Land to return from Mario Kart Super Circuit! They're here, and oh my god they're simply BEAUTIFUL along with the rest of the DLC and game!!!If the concept of a handful of characters and four cups to choose from sounds familiar to any of you out there, that's because that's the same kind of structure the Mario Kart series used to follow until Mario Kart DS (where courses from older games were brought back and first put into a retro category). Considering that Mario Kart 64's digital price isn't too far from this DLC's cost, I'd say it's just like buying an oldschool Mario Kart! After all, it certainly is as much fun as such (though some of you may actually find it all even better)!

Ever since WarioWare decided to test out ability to tilt the Game Boy Advance, Nintendo seems to have since used this series as kind of a demonstration for what their newly designed game console could do. Just like WarioWare Touched showed off the two screens and stylus, Smooth Moves on the Wii explains that there's even more you can do with that fancy Form Baton you have in your hand. You could point and click with it, sure, but you could also use it as a weapon, a steering wheel, a method for you to nod your head, a dart, and the list goes on! Yep, this is another zany frantic entry in the WarioWare series alright!In typical WarioWare fashion, the objective of the game is to play through a bunch of few-second microgames a host character provides, and the minigames themselves will be all sorts of weird and entertaining. They often have you execute simple motions, but the Wii's motion controls do help this game benefit quite a lot, as many of the motions tend to indeed feel like you're part of the action on-screen. The setup for each minigame is always different and unique, and their conveyance is straight to the point. Pitch the ball! Pick up the phone! Fly! Shoot down a giant nose rock!If anything, the main game does tend to feel like it's over too quickly, but there's plenty of replay value to be had. There are full-length minigames such as Balloon Trip and Can Shooter that you can play until you lose and obtain your high score, as well as a selection of modes to play with friends and family! These can be microgame barrages players must clear to survive, or they can too be full-length minigames such as Bungee Buddies and even a very functional game of Darts (Which absolutely craps on Game Party's Darts)!Fun, fast, and high on humor, WarioWare Smooth Moves is a Wii game I can easily recommend to anybody that craves fun and humor. Just remember: Cans are your mortal enemies!

With Rock Band 4 destined to be released in a couple months, I figured that I may as well give my thoughts on Rock Band 3.......for the Nintendo DS! So not only do we have a Rock Band game on the PSP and a conversion of Lego Rock Band for the DS, but we also get a version of the numbered sequel on the go! While certain home-to-small-screen transitions of video games have been handled as half-hearted cash grabs, others give the handhelds a complementary experience, and that's exactly what Rock Band 3 provides.If you've played the other portable Rock Bands before, you'll know what to expect from this one. If not, don't worry; I got ya covered. Unlike the Guitar Hero games on DS, you don't need a peripheral to play this game, so not only is it less expensive to boot, but it can even be played on a Nintendo DSi or 3DS. Instead, you play using the DS's own buttons. The A, B, Y, and X buttons are all for hitting the notes (they are assigned to the specific colors of course). The unique difference (between consoles and DS anyway) is that you gain control of all four instruments, each with their own layouts of notes, and you must hop around to use them via the L and R buttons. To do well at earning stars on your performance, you must react quickly when one instrument's note layouts ends and another starts up next to you and keep hitting the notes without missing one for note streaks. And of course, the mic can be used to double your scores temporarily (a la Guitar Hero's Star Power)All things considered, the resulting rhythm gameplay is neat and addicting. Playing songs, especially on difficulties like Hard mode, make the game fast-paced and the combo-triggering can make for a good motivation to try and keep at it. The music selection amounts to a healthy 25 songs, and most of them are goodies I'd be happy to jam to. I actually like this game more than I do Lego Rock Band, because not only are the graphics much more interesting to look at, but what I wasn't so fond of in Lego was that you were able to stick with one instrument during gameplay, and if you do that, you'd just experience repetitive rows of notes throughout the song. Here, Rock Band 3 requires that you keep going and help the entire band stay on their feet, especially considering not taking part in the other note tracks would mean the other instruments may end up in desperate need to survive with the whole band. It keeps gameplay NOT repetitive by making use of all four note tracks instead of making that an option. And as far as I can tell, the campaign isn't rehashing songs as much as Lego Rock Band's.It's Rock Band on the DS made more fun than before, and for that I wholeheartedly recommend this game to rhythm game fans, and for those interested in playing a Rock Band game, but don't feel like going through the tedium and spending of buying each peripheral. It's inexpensive, portable, and a great play. Now if only there was a 3DS version of Rock Band 4.

Ever since I played the first Happy Feet game based on the movie for the Nintendo DS, I had the lowest expectations possible when deciding to play this one. However, while I won't ever bother watching Happy Feet Two in any sort of form, the video game tie-in toyed with those expectations constantly. This game was created by Wayforward, a development team known to make some pretty good games for cartoon shows and movies alike, as well as the now-well-known Shantae series. Despite that, though, I'd still hastily toss this one away.Happy Feet Two is a 2.5D side-scrolling platformer plagued by the many problems tolerable or better quality platformers tend to avoid; Mumble moves too slow, and there's no run button, the levels are dull and repetitive since they are structured similarly just with different layouts, slowdown can occur even when there's seemingly no reason why it should, the boss fights are utterly pathetic and drag for too long, and the secondary characters you unlock don't even do JACK because they can only be onscreen temporarily and when their times are up the camera focuses back on Mumble anyway!The game does try to spruce things up a LITTLE bit. After all, there is one level where you control krill, and there are a few times where the game transitions to sledding for the fun of it, but even then these don't detract from the fact that this game is one heck of a dirty stain among Wayforward's usual lineup of games.

While Sonic has yet make a new appearance in the gaming industry since 2013's Sonic Lost World (I REFUSE to count the Sonic Boom games as pure Sonic titles because they are just licensed games to tie-in with the Cartoon Network show - Not unlike shows such as Spongebob or Adventure Time), there's always a great time to reflect on the Blue Blur's past, and Sonic Mega Collection Plus does a fantastic job of delivering the high-speed platforming action that true fans crave and then some! That is especially considering this version of the collection contains even more games the Gamecube counterpart lacks.The original Sonic trilogy that graced the Sega Genesis the same way Mario paved his way as Nintendo's mascot is here and very well accounted for! There is a reason why these games put Sonic on the map: They are incredibly FUN! Filled with vast and vastly gorgeous level designs, wise balance of speed and platforming, and iconic characters, Sonics 1 through 3 & Knuckles have often been considered by various people as some of the greatest platformers ever, and they practically guarantee the value for this compilation alone!Still, there's light to be shed on the other games in the roster; Sonic 3D Blast is no high-speed platformer, but it is a good game in its own right, as it provides an interesting combination of Sonic (albeit in an isometric perspective) and arcade classic Flicky (a little platformer where you fetch birds and take them to the exit door), whose Genesis port is unlockable in this collection along with the obscure Ristar. Sonic Spinball is a pinball game (Clearly) featuring Sonic as the ball, but the game isn't really that good, especially considering you have to use the flippers to make Sonic fly into particular spots that may be a chore to reach. Dr. Robotnik's Mean Bean Machine, on the other hand, is a fun Sonic-ized version of Puyo Poyo, a classic puzzler from Japan.New to this Plus edition are six games from the library of the Sega Game Gear. Twelve of these were unlockable in Sonic Adventure DX, but here, half of those are available here by default (The other half being in Sonic Gems Collection). The Game Gear version of the original Sonic the Hedgehog is actually a pretty underrated gem, featuring totally different level designs and even new environments; the gameplay is a little more simplistic (No loop-de-loops for example), but the platforming is still there and it's still fun. Sonic Chaos and Sonic Blast try to act more like the Genesis titles, but they suffer from a few issues that may not make them as enjoyable; I still personally like them, but they won't be everyone's cup of tea. That statement DEFINITELY goes for Sonic Labyrinth and Sonic Drift. Sonic Drift is basically Pole Position with Sonic characters, and Sonic Labyrinth is just plain boring. Lastly, I don't understand why we need the Game Gear version of Dr. Robotnik's Mean Bean Machine here when we already have the Genesis game, which is the same game with better graphics and sound.Regardless of a few duds, though, Sonic Mega Collection Plus is a must-have for any Sonic fan or gamer that wishes to enjoy some Sonic games! There'll at least be a few games you'll enjoy in here, and that fact would already be worth the price of admission.

Despite that the Batman Arkham series had made its debut by this point in time, Batman: The Brave and the Bold wears the style of an oldschool platform/beat 'em up hybrid. Based on the cartoon series, Brave and the Bold has you or you and a friend play as Batman and one of his amusingly dorky sidekicks (except for the elderly not-dorky in-universe inspiration for Batman's crime-fighting duties, Hawkman). The game is divided into four "episodes"; each episode begins and ends with animated FMV footage looking just like the cartoon, and sets the tone for the game itself each time, which is nothing short of a psuedo-serious escapade with lighthearted humor sprinkling over the action.Truth be told, while the game is pretty arcade-like and straightforward for a retail Wii title, this game is actually pretty fun! Granted, the difficulty is clearly geared towards kids (if the infinite respawns and the fact that the goons generally don't put up a real fight), and the platforming can be rather basic at times, but what really makes this game shine is the presentation and combat. The game is coated with stylistically colorful graphics, almost identical to the cartoon's visuals, save for some 3D background elements. Along with that, there are a surprising amount of ways to beat up bad guys.Combos could range from being simple button-mashing punches, or you could uppercut, do stronger punches (albeit with a slight delay before executing them), grab and throw, etc. When you gain a huge-enough combo, you could pull off a special move that deals out a lot of damage, and there's even a feature that allows you to briefly call in a DC hero from the show to deal out some extra hurt. All that said, the fighting is hugely satisfying and does a great job of making the game for me. And while the game may be easy, there is a competitive element if you play with a friend, in which you'll both be scored against each other at the end of the level - Not unlike what Mario and friends have been doing lately.Overall, I had a good time playing through this game. It may not pack much of a challenge, but everything else checks out fine, and it'll definitely be a blast for kids that are fans of the Caped Crusader.

Evidently, no one bothered to try and create a portable stellar experience for the Playstation 2 title, Legend of Kay. Now, I haven't played the console game, but if this is what I'll be expecting from the televised play, then the Wii U and Playstation 4 remasterings may as well be recalled and tossed in the trash. There is no effort made to even provide action in the gameplay! All you do is run and jump, searching around for the desired object or location of interest the on-screen arrow points the direction to. And since the environments have no real way to make one area stand out from the other, there'll even be times where the arrow points you right into a wall, and you have to figure out how to get around that wall. Why isn't there a map on the bottom screen instead of a picture of the land you're in? Why can I only attack by jumping on an enemy, if there are any? It's absolutely ridiculous, and it makes for one of the worst DS games I've ever played. I had more fun sliding downwards the icy mountains in HAPPY FEET for DS. Considering how horrible I thought that game was, that says a lot.

While I like that Nintendo decided to freshen up the formula with Mario Party 9, many players still yearn for a good Mario Party that doesn't involve being forced to ride a car through a board that has a finish line; that is especially if the series could return to the charm and fun its second game provided (Mario Party DS comes close!). With the series's Wii U debut, Mario Party 10......does pretty much everything the same way its predecessor has, except there seems to be certain things subtracted during the process, which is NEVER a good sign for a sequel.Is it just me or has there been a lack of game modes in the series lately? The main game modes are the usual Party Mode, and newcomers Bowser Party and Amiibo Party. That's pretty much it, and the latter isn't even playable if you lack any Amiibo (which is an additional cost each figure by the way). Naturally, I haven't been able to try out that mode, but looking at some gameplay footage online, I don't think I've missed out on much.Bowser Party is the mode this game loves to emphasize on in the same way New Super Mario Bros. 2 loves to emphasize the fact that there are millions of coins you can collect. However, unless the person playing as Bowser is not as good at Mario Party as the opposing players, this mode is completely ONE-SIDED! Bowser constantly has the advantage here, because when it's his turn, he can use a handful of dice blocks at once and easily catch up to the players' vehicle. This causes a minigame to appear where the other players must dodge Bowser's attacks in various different ways, but if Bowser does well in this area, then those players don't even have a chance to begin with.Party Mode works exactly the way it did in Mario Party 9, except with a couple less boards...Seriously? What's this game's excuse, especially if all the boards have finish lines like last time? For those that haven't heard about Mario Party 9's style of play before, while Mario Parties 1-8 feature boards that loop around in elaborate circles with multiple paths, Mario Party 9 features boards that have an end, and the results are determined there.Along the way to the end, there are spaces with all sorts of features that, along with every player being stuck in a moving vehicle, makes it seem like as if luck plays a bigger role to determine one's victory more than skill ever could. Players gather Mini-Stars, but dice rolls (not just from you) and the events that the spaces landed on will cause will make or break those gains anyway. Mini-Stars could be handed over to someone else, tossed aside altogether, or gained, all at sporadic moments. Even when gathering Mini-Stars, it still doesn't feel as satisfying as collecting Stars or even Coins for that matter.The minigames are....well, they're Mario Party minigames. They're zany little competitions in undefined Mushroom Kingdom lands as always, to say the least, and this is the aspect where players utilize skill the most. Some of them might still be based on luck, but they still aren't that much worse than events that would occur on the board. One thing I like is that there aren't too many minigames that use motion controls, instead relying on traditional D-Pad/analog and buttons.All things considered, Mario Party 10 can still make for mindless fun, notably for those not looking for a legit skill-based competition. However, this simply isn't how Mario Party should be conceived, and it once wasn't. I personally think Nintendo should make Mario Party 11 a downloadable eShop game in the same kind of structure and charm as Mario Party 2, but with different boards, outfits, and of course minigames. That's it; that's all that really needs to be done. For now, we have a retail game with an underwhelming amount of features that pushes luck above all else. For a good multiplayer game with Mario and friends, go for the fantastic Super Smash Bros. or also-awesome Mario Kart 8. Or for a better Mario Party experience, you could obtain Mario Party 8 for play on Wii U or preferably Mario Party 2 via the Wii Shop Channel.

-I've recently gotten into college, and there's a gameroom with consoles like the Playstation 4 and Xbox One set up and ready to play; I'll finally get to play through games of those consoles! That said, here is a review for one of them.-As console generations continue onward, many gamers expect to witness new titles with groundbreaking boundary-setters that older game systems wouldn't be able to compete with. However, it seems that with every console launch, there will always be that exception that tends to just be there for the sake of having a simpler game pulled from the depths of a simpler time. In the Playstation 4's case, that would be Knack.Knack is a video game that is typically referred to as a platformer, but it's really more of a beat 'em up. As the title character, you run across various different environments with only jumping across gaps or higher platforms to worry about until the level blocks you from progressing any further so you can kill the enemies that stand in your way. You punch and thrash those enemies however you can, the door blocking you opens, and the formula repeats. I hear that this game was meant to be kind of a Crash Bandicoot game, and while I can believe it, I moreso believe that it's more like Crash of the Titans than along the lines of the original PS1 trilogy, except with better combat and more satisfying control, but less level design and more forgettable characters.If there's one thing that I can't help but cringe at, it's the story and characters that play their parts within it. With a game like this, a minimal storyline is all we really ever need, but instead this game goes full-blown cinematic every level, only to tell a plot about a tribe at war with humans and stuff. Knack is apparently not his own character, but rather is he just a (albeit scientifically crafted) tool for the humans to win this war against the tribe of creatures. On top of that, you'd think Knack would be a mute character like Crash always was, but instead he TALKS. In an ADULT MAN voice. THAT VOICE comes out of THAT ARTIFICIALLY CREATED GOLEM. What?!Painfully awkward design choices and lack of levels being levels aside, Knack is still a good time. Just don't expect your favorite platforming mascots to be disturbed in the middle of the night over this.

Believe it or not, despite the success and fandom that Adventure Time was showered with since its Cartoon Network debut, it didn't see a video game adaptation until two years later. Fortunately, the development team that took upon the idea of a game for the show was none other than Wayforward, who had worked on various other titles such as the Shantae series and the acclaimed DS retro revival that is Contra 4. Surely enough, these developers were reliable, and the final result ended up doing the cartoon justice.Adventure Time: Hey Ice King! Why'd You Steal Our Garbage (Yep, that's the real title!) is a platform game that is basically one giant homage of Zelda II for the NES, except much easier to actually play through. You control Finn the Human, and as him you run, jump, and use your fists or trusty sword to deal with pesky creatures that lurk around the levels. His shapeshifter talking dog friend, Jake the Dog, is also present and accounted for, but since he doesn't feel like moving around on his own, he rides in Finn's backpack and can be used for additional attacks or powers, Banjo-Kazooie-style. Outside the side-scrolling levels, you roam around in a top-down environment looking for places to go. You reach these places, you talk to townspeople or whoever else, and then accept their quests as you try conquering your overarching one.The plot in this game is more in line with a "one-off" kind of Adventure Time episode, in which the story is just exclusive to that episode and doesn't focus on a tale that would span an entire season. In this case, the Ice King, being the lonely old sap he is, decides to give Finn and Jake something to fight him about by taking their garbage and making crappy garbage princesses out of them to "rescue". Along the way, Finn and Jake also have to make some investigations, whether they be for a talking house's parasol aggressively taken away, or a search for Princess Bubblegum's pantyhose (No, seriously).Adventure Time's sense of humor varies, but for the most part, the show would hit the sweet spot and make me laugh often. That holds true for HIKWUSOG, albeit the dialogue is spoken through text instead of voice acting. Regardless, there are lots of funny lines within the writing, and there are a couple times where the humor is shown visually (Such as the big scary monster at the top of the hill - Those of you that played this part know what I'm talking about!) and hits hard! There are also various references to specific episodes (Donnie the obnoxious grass ogre, the thingy that copies Finn and Jake's movements, Finn's little robot "son", etc, all make an appearance in the game), and there are even a chunk of references to classic video games ("But enough talk! Have at you!").The humor, plot, colorful graphics, and surprisingly radical soundtrack wouldn't really mean too much in a video game, though, if the gameplay weren't up to snuff. Fortunately, Wayforward contains experienced people, and they know their way around the platform genre; in fact, I think this game uses the same kind of engine as Shantae: Risky's Revenge. Finn is capable of doing plenty of moves; he can punch/swing his sword, do that in the air, a slide kick on the ground, have Jake pull a punch with his stretchy arm, and use him for abilities that would be unlocked as the duo make progress. It especially helps that Finn is ultimately satisfying to control, as the movement is precise and accurate all around!Not everything about the game is perfect, of course, hence my 4-star rating instead of a 5. While there is plenty to explore, and a healthy cast of characters and settings, the level designs can feel rather bare at times. Not exactly in terms of the obstacles you face, but it feels more like as if the game is playing things too straight; the levels don't ever gain an over-the-top feel like the varied courses in games like DuckTales or the Super Mario Bros. sequels. Also, the quests are mostly fetch quests, which can be somewhat of a letdown for certain people out there...Not really me, personally, but it does get a bit tedious as I keep going further down the line.Nevertheless, Adventure Time's video game debut is a solid one. It may not be better than some other games Wayforward has created, but it certainly is great for a game based off a Cartoon Network show, as well as one of the better DS titles released nearly at the end of the library's lifecycle.

After having two critically acclaimed puzzlers dominate over consoles and PCs, the Portal franchise has been around some rather strange whereabouts lately. We first hear that the LEGO take on the Skylanders toy-to-life formula will be bringing Portal into their mix of licensees, and now we suddenly have Zen Studios providing mobile devices with a Portal pinball game! But you know what? I totally welcome this stuff, especially this. For just two dollars, you get a mix of pinball goodness and Portal's atmosphere and sense of humor!The Zen Pinball game engine is indeed in effect here, as the mechanics are pretty solid, and the pinball play in general is as fun and addicting as pinball usually is. You don't really have to be a Portal fan to enjoy this game, but it does help considering you get quite a few snarky lines from antagonist GLaDOS, and there is some fanservice spread around the virtual table. Above all else, though, the game packs quite a punch as the pinball title it is, and it is definitely what I can call two bucks' worth of fun; it's another quality title from Zen Studios's line of pinball games.

While good ol' Crash Bandicoot has expanded his horizons on the Playstation 2 and Xbox, Vicarious Visions seems to have decided to hold back for the marsupial's then-latest Game Boy Advance title, Crash Purple. On the surface, it seems like it would be a pretty epic crossover between Crash and Spyro; after all, the two have been seen as partners/rivals ever since they gained dominance over the Playstation as unofficial mascots. Unfortunately, what we're provided with here is not anything that a regular Crash Bandicoot platformer can't triumph over...because platforming is not this game's ideal gameplay.Crash Purple is a collection of minigames that consist of various different gameplay styles, such as hopping on crates, riding to the goal, jet tubing, navigating via tank, etc, while the usual platforming formula is demoted to glorified HUB worlds. Yes, this is what the formation of a Spyro and Crash crossover has led up to. To be fair, though, a lot of the minigames aren't half-bad. They all have an emphasis on arcade-style mechanics and simplicity, basically serving as bite-sized levels that happen to shift between different types of gameplay. That said, you better make sure you get all the Crystals (by beating the minigames) and Gems (by smashing all the crates in the minigames), because unlike the previous GBA Crash games where you just get a not-so-ceremonious ending without collecting them, this game WILL NOT let you progress to the final part without them.What also helps add to this cartridge is that, just like the GBA version of Crash Nitro Kart, there's a hidden minigame that is accessed by holding L and R while booting up the game. That minigame is called Spyro Party USA, which is literally Crash Party USA from Nitro Kart, except with Spyro dancing onscreen instead of Crash. Nevertheless, it's a simple and fun rhythm game with addictive qualities to it such as the Crash-esc music enhanced by electronic beats, and the nature of the rhythm genre in general.As for Crash Purple as a whole? It's a fun game, but I personally prefer its predecessors if you want a great Crash experience on the go.

There's something that needs to be said about Pac-Man's inclusion in the new Super Smash Bros. game. Being that Namco was helping out in the game's development, I was hoping the yellow muncher would show up on the roster as soon as the game started counting off the newcomer trailers. After months and months of waiting, with no sign of Pac-Man anywhere, I thought to myself "Sigh...I guess it wasn't meant to be...Even then, they'd probably use that stupid Ghostly Adventures design". And then out of nowhere, a friend of mine showed me a trailer where Pac-Man made it in after all, and my jaw dropped. They beat the odds! Pac-Man's in Smash! He looks better than ever, and it's the REAL Pac-Man! And when I finally got to play as him in the game, I was wowed by how great he felt to control and how much love and detail was put into his inclusion.I guess beneath all that rambling, what I'm trying to say is - The Pac-Man I know still has the same kind of appeal that Mario still enjoys for decades on end. That Pac-Man led a creative series of games that all had real effort and care implemented in at least most of them. In comparison, Ghostly Adventures makes Pac-Man feel dead and beaten. I thought I'd relate to the characters a little more considering this variation takes place in a high school setting, but it turns out that these characters are just the usual lazy children's cartoon stereotypes that plague equally lame children's cartoons.As for the Ghostly Adventures video game....I've said everything I needed to say about that one. That's why I'm surprised Namco decided to follow it up so quickly with a sequel. But hey, who knows? Maybe they fixed everything that was wrong with the original game and/or made elements better and more fun to play with. After all, this Nintendo 3DS version is actually a port of the console game this time around, so maybe I can expect some real change.But NOPE - This game does everything the same way as it did when it was called "Pac-Man and the Ghostly Adventures" in the year 2013.Granted, there's slightly better shooting segments that pop in every now and then, and there are new power-ups, but those are just things that are there to only SEEM like they spruce up variety. The music isn't the utterly forgettable orchestra heard before, but instead it's utterly repetitive soft electronic music. Voice acting is still as horrible as before, and like last time, there's an option to mute only the voices. The graphics are......meh. They are visuals. There's scenery. It's not a bad looking game, but it sure is tastelessly bland. In fact, the framerate has the potential to kill all visual appeal; the game runs choppily at not even 30 FPS.Even if you do get past that, though, the gameplay is still boring. I mean, the control is fine, and Pac-Man's attacks and powers do work, but the level designs make the entire adventure feel soulless. There's NOTHING interesting about anything that happens, other than what the power-ups can do, but even then, they're only there just so you can make progress in the level, and not because the power-up would be fun to use by itself. It's all note-by-note by-the-numbers platforming without bells nor whistles. Unless if you count the bad voice acting.Do yourself a favor; if you own a Wii (or Gamecube/Playstation 2/Xbox), grab a copy of Pac-Man World 2. It's a platforming game, too, except it's my personal favorite Pac-Man game that's not from the arcades. THAT'S how great that game is.If you own a Wii U though, that's okay, because Namco Museum Megamix (if you don't already own Remix) will also provide an excellent Pac-Man experience thanks to the much-improved port of Pac 'n Roll included in there, among many arcade classics and remixed games.DO NOT buy this or the previous Ghostly Adventures game. Neither one provides an enjoyable experience, especially not one that's nearly as fun as the games I've mentioned above. Now if you excuse me, I'm going to resume Smashing it up with Pac-Man!

I never gave anything too much thought after watching YouTuber Caddicarus's game review on Nothing Can Stop Mr. Domino a good while back, but after a casual browsing through games for the Wii, I came across this title, and my eyes lit up. After glancing at the boxart and some screenshots, I was curious and I went to Gamestop to buy the game for $3. Despite dominoes being featured on the box, Domino Rally really isn't related to the Playstation 1 title at all. Nevertheless, it's worth looking into.The first thing about the game that almost instantly came to mind was its style. I'm really surprised this wasn't a Japan-only game, because the localization is shockingly minimal; there are Japanese words with plain English captions at the bottom during cutscenes (although English-speaking voice actors dub over the characters), the music in every level contains lyrics sung in Japanese, and the game is generally REALLY weird and off the wall in a good way!Story doesn't play the biggest role in the game's focus, as each of the eight levels in the game have their own little conflict for protagonist Minon to solve. For example, the first stage has him recover a little girl's balloon stuck in a tree, the third stage has him answer a family man's phone so he can win a trip to Hawaii, and the sixth stage has him running across zoo animals to keep them quiet so a male elephant can confess his love for a female elephant. The cutscenes are just as brief and charmingly kooky.Really, this is more about doing these bizarre tasks than it is about dominoes (which is probably why this game's Japanese title doesn't mention dominoes); Minon putting down a line of dominoes for him to walk/run across (or using certain surroundings as such) is the only real connection. However, that's actually only the surface of the gameplay. You see, not only do you point at the screen and press B to put down and add to the domino lines, but Minon has only so many dominoes to put down. You have to use your surroundings to your advantage, recharging your ammo of dominoes by shaking the Wii Remote when using the scenery to run upon. It also helps Minon to run faster. There will also be a couple instances where Minon has to run across living beings to calm them down, so you must figure out how to manage your domino placements to your advantage in those situations.The game is somewhat tricky to learn at first, but once you get past the learning curve, you'll find Domino Rally to be good quirky fun while it lasts! It's kind of a real shame that it's tucked away in obscurity, as its upbeat Japanese charm is hard to dislike.

Believe it or not, this is actually a home port of the original Street Fighter. Street Fighter I. The predecessor to Street Fighter II. The birth of a fighting game empire. Why am I emphasizing on this so much? BECAUSE THIS FIRST GAME IS ABOMINABLE!! It's honestly amazing how there could be such a great fighting game franchise spawning from something as bad as this game turned out to be, but it's true. If the Street Fighter games that followed afterward are so much fun to play, though, what makes this such a flop, you may wonder? Well let me explain...To be fair, the graphics are pretty good for late 80s standards (especially considering how dominant the NES graphical style was then), and the CD-quality soundtrack is a big improvement over the Genesis-y sounding music from the arcade cabinet, but everything else about the game falls flatter than the floor. The voice samples, for instance, are hilariously muffled and are just barely intelligible when reading captions. Other oddities such as the black screens for announcing rounds are awkward in comparison to just simply having the fighters stand for a moment before the announcer says to fight. Ryu and Ken are also the only playable fighters, unfortunately. And then there's the control...Oh dear Lord the control...When you think of a game made by Capcom, it's bound to have tight control, right? Well, Fighting Street's controls are utterly BROKEN! There are severe delays for EVERY FRICKIN' MOVE YOU DO, your character jumps in such a clumsy diagonal angle, and I would LOVE to see if someone can pull off a Hadoken without mashing buttons for minutes on end before figuring out how to do it! The button combinations are as good as non-existent, but if you do somehow pull off a move like that, that move actually takes out more than half the opponent's health! Way to tease us with immense frustration, developers!Speaking of immense frustration, let's talk difficulty; if you thought having to constantly struggle with getting Ryu/Ken to execute the right attacks and maneuvers was bad enough, just wait til I discuss the AI! There are loads of computer players out to beat the crap out of Ryu or Ken, and they don't take it easy. As I was playing through the game, there was this one opponent that headbutted me twice, and apparently just those two hits were enough to kill me! THAT'S how cheap the game gets! And it's not like I could dodge quickly either; good control or not, you get ZERO reaction time for some of the enemies' attack patterns!Simply put: Be very, very, VERY thankful that the Street Fighter series you get to play is nothing like the game that paved the way for it.

The Genesis-exclusive sequel to the arcade classic, Golden Axe II plays almost exactly like its predecessor, but with new layouts and enemies to deal with. I'm not complaining, though; the beat 'em up gameplay of the original is back in full force here anyway! It's still a lot of fun to beat down the slew of incoming baddies with either my weapon or an animal I can ride. It's especially satisfying to have them tossed into bottomless pits or killing giant boss enemies!Returning from the Genesis version of Golden Axe is The Duel, which turns this game into a fighter where you fight one enemy, and move on to the next one (or ones?) after claiming your victory over that enemy. It's an interesting, fun take on the beat 'em up formula that serves to add to the overall package. And I believe it does that fine.If you've played through the first Golden Axe, you won't have any trouble playing through this one as well, but you'll at least still have fun doing so.

I'm not saying that video games shouldn't at all contain cinematic experiences, but this is what I usually look for in a game: A colorful, fluidly playable, and thoroughly fun time whenever I pick up the controller. Donkey Kong Country Returns is a fantastic example of this, and it helps that it's a long-awaited sequel to the Super Nintendo trilogy that broke ground by combining SGI computer graphics with addictive platforming gameplay.  With that stuff in mind, Retro Studios had quite a bit to follow up to, but in my eyes, the result was beyond expectations!As the big ape himself, you run, jump, bop on enemies, and collect bananas as you race your way through each level in the eight worlds provided. The 2.5D structure is not unlike that of games like Nintendo's own New Super Mario Bros. Wii, but the execution makes all the difference, and Donkey Kong Country Returns manages to pull things off in a better fashion. This game doesn't play things safe; it brings out the big guns nearly every level! Everything is elaborate and pompous; from the absolutely gorgeous jungle scenery to the hidden collectibles and bonus rounds waiting to be found to the bosses and their patterns to the kooky barrel-riding and mine carts to even the many ultimately eventful ways Donkey Kong can finish a level! Not one detail is lacking!Diddy Kong joins in the fun as well, but in a slightly unusual way. In single-player, you can't really get to play as him, but you CAN use his jetpack, as it can allow you to hover briefly, making for some pretty sweet jumps! Furthermore, while the Super Nintendo games have alternative and competitive 2-Player modes, Donkey Kong Country Returns allows a friend to join in the main adventure at the same time! Cooperatively! In this day and age where online multiplayer has taken the industry by storm, sharing the same couch is still a blast, and games like these prove it.With or without a friend, though? Don't expect this one to be a walk in the park. Believe it or not, the Donkey Kong Country series has been known to be rather challenging at times, and Returns makes it pretty darn clear this time around! It's not like Mario where you have a good chance of simply breezing through. You'll be losing a good number of lives! Possibly per level later on! And the clever level design will make sure that you should stay on your toes. Fortunately, gathering up lives and other kinds of help won't be a problem because Cranky Kong hosts a shop.Throughout each level, there are Banana Coins you can collect. They're obviously not in in-your-face locations as bananas are, but collecting them allows you to purchase things from Cranky's shop. Among them are extra lives which can be bought off with these Banana Coins. So this allows you to rack up the lives to dozens upon dozens pretty easily! As challenging as the game is, though, the overall product is top-notch and filled with fun and excitement! Probably the most difficult part of the game is thinking of how I could complain about it! I'm serious!

Nintendo may have had an awesome 2014, but this is one of the couple games that shouldn't have worked out in that favor. From the moment I laid my eyes on the first trailer for Yoshi's New Island, I was unimpressed to say the least.
