The pre-rendered graphic look didn't fit well, making the scenery and characters look slightly muddy (Which is very ironic considering Shigeru Miyamoto didn't want the original YI to have pre-rendered graphics), and the giant Shy Guy and egg looked like it's only there just for the sake of there being a giant Shy Guy and egg and not for unique design aspects. I've skipped out on this game for a good while now, but recently, my little brother obtained the last Platinum award from Club Nintendo. Since we already have the better selections from there, the closest thing my brother got to being a new pick we could enjoy was Yoshi's New Island. Unfortunately, the game was exactly as I expected. And the trailer didn't set my expectations radically high.First and foremost, let's address the music for one quick second because that's the first thing that pops into my mind when thinking about this game and when the title screen appears: I ABSOLUTELY HATE THIS SOUNDTRACK! It's bland, it's boring, it's repetitive, it has no right to be remixed throughout the game, and the kazoos give my ears nightmares! I could make better music with my own vocals!Anyway...Yoshi's New Island is the THIRD Yoshi's Island game in the series, but it seems to try and act like a SECOND game, as if it tries to ignore that Yoshi's Island DS existed. Rather than make its own storyline about babynappings like that game did, New Island decides to piggyback ride on the Super Nintendo classic's story, and shove it straight into a pig shredder! The soft, warm ending of the original game gets shockingly butchered for the introduction, and the narrative from then until the beginning of the game is informal, clashing with how Yoshi's Island usually tells the story.After that rocky intro, the game at least plays like a Yoshi's Island game. You're Yoshi with Baby Mario strapped to your back, and you must go venture around in colorful landscapes and face off a variety of enemies by throwing eggs and eating them to make more eggs. For the most part, the play style at its core is pretty unharmed, which is easily the best thing I can say about the game. Yoshi's Island's style of play has always been very fun, and it's great to at least see this game carry that gameplay. What bothers me, though, is that Yoshi can't transform into something by popping a bubble; instead, you must go through a trippy door, which completely separates the level from the segment Yoshi's transformation is in, and you must control him via tilting the 3DS. Why am I forced to interrupt my platforming level to do something completely unrelated to said platforming level? The tilting control even applies for Yoshi's old transformations, so if you expected to roam freely with the Yoshicopter or submarine like in the first game, prepare to be disappointed.In fact, one of my biggest problems with Yoshi's New Island (aside from the music) is what I've somewhat slowly noticed throughout my time playing the game; the game subtracts from miscellaneous content from its predecessors. Any variety that was brought into Yoshi's Island DS is nowhere to be found here, as this game wants to mimic the Super NES title, except it doesn't even address everything! Where are the Fuzzies that make you dizzy? The Baseball Boys? The Bandit minigames for extra rewards? The bonus chances at the goal when the roulette selects a Flower? The various objects that originally used Mode-7 for 3D display but would look great in 3D here? THEY AREN'T HERE!!! Any enemies and additional gimmicks that DID make the transition to this game were moved to later worlds or levels. If that weren't enough, the level design is actually simplified - Sometimes, I hopped and/or ran across the terrain, not getting attacked, without a second thought. And most of the time, before I knew it, I suddenly made it to the goal quicker than I thought I would. This isn't the original Super Mario Bros. This is YOSHI'S ISLAND! Both Yoshi's Island and its DS sequel were filled to the brim with elaborate and challenging level designs. What the heck happened here?This even applies to the boss battles. Kamek, for some reason, has to be the boss in every fourth level of each world. While the battle has decent variations, the overall result is still easy and doesn't give off an impression. The #-8 boss battles do a better job, but they still lack the charm and memorability of the older games' bosses. Baby Bowser felt like a slap in the face, to tell you the truth, because he was pathetically easy to defeat (His changing up the height of floor structures didn't even do a thing against me). So I thought, anyway, before the game's ending psyched me out by calling in-GROWN UP BOWSER?! Yes, that's right folks - We have unnecessary time travel in the game, and in order to get to defeat Bowser to get the best ending, you must complete every level without using wings. Or as I like to call them, the "You Suck Wings".The You Suck Wings are this game's way of telling you you died too many times in a level, to carry on the tradition that New Super Mario Bros. Wii shouldn't have started and that games like Super Mario 3D Land shouldn't have continued using. Don't get me wrong; the game is very easy and hardly ever picks up the challenge one bit. I guess I just failed to try on a couple parts and decided to use the wings to scrape by.Look. If you haven't played any game in the series yet, and are looking for an enjoyable platformer on the 3DS, this really isn't a terrible pick. However, when comparing it to Yoshi's Island and Yoshi's Island DS, it can only be seen as a massive downgrade. I think I'd like to talk about Donkey Kong Country Returns for a bit as an example of a sequel to an old game done right; everything the game does builds upon what the original Super NES trilogy set up, from the elaborate environments and smart level designs to the downright epic boss battles and combining remixed nostalgic music with new original music that equally sounds great. In fact, I bet if Retro Studios developed Yoshi's New Island instead of Arzest, this game would've been made with as much heart and effort as Nintendo themselves put into the original Yoshi's Island. For the sake of playing something better, I can't say I recommend this game over the other Yoshi games (including Yoshi's Story) at all. It's a misstep in what's otherwise a fantastic year for Nintendo.

After debuting on the bigger screen, Kirby hops back over to everyone's favorite monochrome handheld! This time, he's bringing pretty much everything he's learned from his last adventure and then some. Kirby's Dream Land 2 takes the concept of making things bigger and better and takes it to the extreme, particularly considering how short the first game is. While Dream Land 1 lasts five stages (the last stage being a mish-mash of the other four), Dream Land 2 follow's Kirby's Adventure's concept on having Worlds divided into levels, immediately making for a bigger game!Expanded as it is, though, the game never loses a drop in quality because nothing is simply padded out for status quo. All of the levels Kirby ventures through are populated with fun level designs and enemy variety. The enemy variety absolutely helps Kirby out in this case because he can now suck them up with that giant mouth of his and absorb enemy powers to his benefit! First appearing in Kirby's Adventure, this feature absolutely helps give Kirby a defining mechanic, and it's always a thrill to tinker with the various ways Kirby can kill enemies and work his way through the stage! Even more so when Kirby equips an animal buddy!Presentation-wise, the game is still very sound. Oddly, the composers seem to have actually toned down the rapid upbeat style of the usual Kirby soundtrack, save for any songs reused from the original Dream Land. The music is still good stuff, but it just seemed rather jarring to me. The graphics are far more consistent, as it shares the same pompous graphics that the first game proudly boasted. In fact, there seem to be some extra details lying around in all those pixels.Gorgeous-looking, great-sounding, and all-out awesome to play, Kirby's Dream Land 2 is a Game Boy gem that makes its portable predecessor look like a demo!

Dreamworks Super Star Kartz is an interesting case in a way; it was originally going to be a reboot/remake of Crash Team Racing, but for whatever reason, Activision canceled the game before even looking over its prototype. High Impact Games, however, did rework their sadly abandoned project into a new game: One where ogres, aliens, and zoo animals race together! So technically it did in fact see the light of day, just not in a fashion that's connected to Naughty Dog's farewell to Bandicoot lovers everywhere.A mishmash of Dreamworks licensees and Mario Kart, Super Star Kartz features an all-star cast racing in go karts on courses inspired by their respective movies. As you can expect in every race, items will be thrown around like there's no tomorrow, drifting will be a powerful tool for boosting, and ramp stunts and special moves also come into play for the drivers' benefits. There are four cups with three tracks in each, with the last cup consisting of reversed variations of three existing tracks.While the game does also seem somewhat rough around the edges, the zany racing action is actually pretty solid for a game that's not a direct copy of Nintendo's flagship mascot racer. Granted, Mario Kart is the source of inspiration for pretty much every other kart-racer out there, but Dreamworks Super Star Kartz evidently provides the same kind of bouncy and tight kart movement that Crash proudly boasted way back when (although not to the same degree, as this game can still be kinda loose in comparison), and the item selection does a decent job of getting brief chaos done.The graphics may be far from the best I've ever seen on Wii, but the courses do show a nice amount of detail and eye candy, which include but aren't limited to things like the flying dragons in Berk, as well as Susan and Insecto roaming a city in the background of the spaceship track. The music is....well, music, but the voice clips could have used some work; the substitute voice actors don't provide the same charm as the movie voice actors, and the clips recorded are repeated too often.But all in all, Dreamworks Super Star Kartz is a solid kart-racer for the Nintendo Wii. It doesn't beat out Crash Bandicoot's karting forays, nor would it ever step on Mario's shoes, but you can still have a good time from it if you're looking for, well, a kart-racer to enjoy, and if you're a fan of the movies represented here.

This game threw me off my guard by total surprise, but not really in that good of a way. At first, Putter Golf does exactly what you expect it to do: Provide a decent miniature golf experience on the original Playstation. The courses can be pretty fun, and there is even a selection of courses with unique little gimmicks. When playing alone, however, as soon as the CPU begins its turn, that's where the game's biggest flaw comes into play. For some odd reason, no matter what difficulty you select, the CPU player ALWAYS gets either a Birdie or a Par. Take a good guess which one the CPU scores more.Putter Golf will likely be a much better time if you have someone to play with, so you can actually have a legitimately fair game. But unless you're a pro at this game, and can always score a Birdie or higher, then you may as well stay away from the single player modes. And if you're totally by myself then....You're out of luck.

Beat 'em ups don't seem to be as common on mobile as they should have been, but Fist of Awesome helps feed my cravings for one, and for the most part, it did them justice. This is a button-masher (er...screen-masher) to the purest degree; you move to an enemy, and beat the everloving crap out of him! The retro-tastic graphical style and excellent music definitely give this game a great flavor, but this would have been a total five-star extravaganza if there was more variety. The enemies all play out the same way, and the game should TMNT-ize the levels by providing level elements that serve as unique obstacles or at least interactive decorations beyond reading or talking to stuff. Other than those things, though, this is a pretty good game, and it's worth your time.

Retro and addictive, League of Evil is a fantastic and neatly crafted mobile platformer! The game is divided into four worlds (not counting the bonus "Impossible" or "Lite" worlds), and each one lasts around dozens of bite-sized levels. What do you do in each level? Run, dodge, kick attack, and get rid of those evil scientists at the end! The platforming is top-notch, as you have just the right control over the protagonist, as well as a variety of moves; he can double jump, wall jump, and do an air kick. And despite the levels being short, this game will last a good while thanks to the overall world length and the increasingly difficult challenges you face as you progress. Topped with excellent 16-Bit-ish graphics and a radical 8-Bit-ish soundtrack, League of Evil is a must-own.

Ever since its jump to another company's arms, Crash Bandicoot has been degraded from a wacky marsupial with attitude to a hobo-like creature with a whiny voice. While I'm not too fond of Crash's new character design, Crash of the Titans is actually not too bad of a game. At least not for the Nintendo DS. It's a 3D platformer with a linear perspective that's almost exactly like that of Naughty Dog's PS1 trilogy (complete with a few 2D sections and bonus areas). However, there's still a lot to be desired.Yes, the platforming does feel pretty good, and Crash's fighting moves aren't too shabby, but the level designs are blander than they should have been. There are a bunch of boxes to smash up, and there are collectables, but there is a major lack of any sort of real punch that the older games have been peppered with. Instead, the focus is almost solely on the combat, which isn't too bad, but if you're going to make this a platforming game, you may as well put effort into those aspects, too.That said, the combat's okay. It can be ultimately satisfying to beat the crap out of an enemy, and it's even better when you get to hijack an enemy and use him for your own benefits. To the game's credit, it does get more strategic as to which enemy to take over, and some of the moves are pretty cool to unleash. It would have been nice if there were more fighting sound effects, though. Your normal hits are near-silent.Lastly, there's the matters of the overall presentation, and even that, like all else I mentioned, is a mixed bag. The game does show polish in some areas, but not in others. There are a decent amount of cutscenes with fully-voiced dialogue, but the writing tries too hard to land a joke (going as far as to have a laugh track for the supposedly funny lines spoken). The graphics look remarkably great for a DS title, but the music is considerably average and pales in comparison to the catchy and fun tracks of its predecessors. There's definitely some good things about this game, while there's also things about it that should have been improved on. If you're curious, and/or are a Crash Bandicoot fan, there is some fun to be had, but don't have high hopes for it.

If you thought nothing but arcade-style games could be accomplished with squares and rectangles for graphics, prepare for a title that would single-handedly blow your mind; Thomas Was Alone is a platformer featuring multicolored shapes, and you solve loads of clever and fun puzzles along the way to beat the levels. Shockingly, however, the interesting gameplay isn't the only thing that makes this game an absolute gem among the millions of apps. What helps the game find itself is its sound department.Topped with atmospheric music, Danny Wallace tugs on emotions with a strong narration constantly throughout the entire game. The square shapes are each given unique personalities, and a series of events complement each one's actions that YOU control and NOT watch cutscenes to see unfold. The curious and observant square, Thomas, meets with short orange square Chris, who is at odds with Thomas, but they both meet up with more characters together including Claire, who wants to be a superhero, and John, a yellow rectangle wanting to show off his impressive jumps. There are eleven chapters in this game, and the story introduces a new character every chapter. The result is the most powerful story one can ever experience with such simple graphics. Seeing that this story is deeper than many, many big-budget games is just a bonus!If you pass on this game, you are doing yourself a major disservice; Thomas Was Alone is probably one of the best Android games I've ever played.

Believe it or not, Mario is no stranger to pinball tables, but there has never been a pinball video game starring the plucky plumber. Well, the good news is that there was a development team that realized this, and has put this out for the good ol' Game Boy Advance. Unfortunately, the team might have been too small to work with such a big Nintendo property. While Mario Pinball Land/Super Mario Ball does hold a lot of promise, the problems are few yet incredibly major.The game mashes up the pinball style of play with a Super Mario 64 structure; collect Power Stars by slinging Mario as a ball into enemies and grabbing keys by defeating bosses. On paper, the concept is really good. However, here's the major flaw: Navigation. In order to get anywhere, you must use the flippers to fling Mario to doors and paths, which is EASIER SAID THAN DONE. It's not like in any Mario platformer where you can just move him with the analog stick to that door. Oh, no. Here, you have to hope Mario rolls down to the direction the door's located! There are numerous instances where Mario would hit the door open, but then constantly miss the opened path. Or maybe Mario would hit something else by accident and trigger more frustration. He could hit paths that I don't want to go to. And this problem is worsened during missions where you must hit enemies in specific ways (such as hitting snakes before they go the manhole in the middle, or hitting Shy Guys to change their color - all Shy Guys onscreen must be the same color)! Heck, maybe the problem wouldn't be as jarringly apparent if the pinball physics were completely accurate. But they aren't; they are surprisingly unreliable for a Nintendo-published game.It's not like no one made an effort to make this game good, though. There is a lot of positive weight to this, too; the music is appropriately catchy and has the typical repetitions of a Mario soundtrack, and the graphics are actually some of the best the Game Boy Advance has to offer. The pinball mechanics also do have their merits, since it IS, well, pinball, and you could even use a few items to help a little. It's just a big shame the physics haven't been tweaked up enough and navigation isn't any easier. The bosses justify this even further, especially Bowser. You just had to hit them a few times and they're dead, but Mario's bound not to hit them when you need him to.

This is one of those few games that I pick up from Gamestop for as low as ONE DOLLAR, and yet I spend the day wondering why the game is this disposable. On top of that, while a lot of rhythm games tend to center around just a gameplay mechanic (which isn't bad at all, mind you), there are some out there that go beyond the call of duty and provide not only said mechanic, but also their own charming characters and settings like any other genre could. This jovial entry, for example, made an impression on Dreamcast gamers in 2000, and now eight years later, Nintendo fans get to join the party without purchasing expensive maracas!What makes Samba De Amigo tick is its emphasis on motion control. Granted, motion control isn't the most reliable feature you could implement in a Wii game, and there are even a few times where the control could feel imprecise, but it otherwise works pretty dang well here! Using the Remote and Nunchuck as maracas, you rhythmically shake them as you point them up, down, or in the middle, and the result works great! And it certainly helps that the large 40+ song soundtrack is full of great choices!From Mambo Number 5 to Low Rider to Tango With Me, the selection of songs is surprisingly varied, and while the dancing scenery may not get nearly as much attention as the six spots on the interface, it sure does reflect the pompous energy that flows throughout the game. That too also varies as you play different songs, as you can see Samba dancing with other dancers such as Rio, Linda, and even Sonic and Ulala make cameo appearances as dancers! Apparently, they have great taste in Latin-esc music.Music gamers everywhere need to pick this one up. Considering how cheap it is now, there's no excuse! It has all the colorful dazzles of a mascot game, as well as the uniquely fantastic formula rhythm games usually contain.

It doesn't have the robust levels and epic chiptunes of the classic Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles games, but this Android game based off the movie is actually pretty good! The game is based all around touch screen-based combat (similarly to Ninja Gaiden: Dragon Sword for the Nintendo DS), and the game pulls that off nicely, if not slightly loose in comparison to that title. Nevertheless, it has its addictive quality, and the beat 'em up aesthetics do hearken back to the Turtles' glory days in video games. I'd say this is well worthy of your four bucks.

Formerly an unofficial mascot of Sony, Crash Bandicoot makes his way towards multiple game consoles like certain former mascots before him, but in the hands of different development teams this time. In this case, Traveler's Tales has whipped up Wrath of Cortex. While this may seem like a drastic change from the original Playstation, this game actually follows the footsteps of its Naughty Dog predecessors; you run forward/right, collect peaches and a Crystal in each level, break boxes, hit bonus rounds for more peaches and 1-Ups, etc.With that said, the platforming is addictive as it has always been! There's something about the simple run 'n jump style of play Crash offers that keeps me hooked. Box-smashing and collecting peaches always feels good to do, and the action can be constantly kinetic for the most part. This formula alone just makes the game a winner in my opinion. However, there is a doze of other gameplay styles serving as other levels, but while a couple are pretty good, the other couple aren't as satisfying. The Marble Madness-style levels are a treat, and the plane combat levels at least control nicely, but levels such as the kart-racing (ironically).......suck. The bosses aren't really much to write home about, either.But with lush colorful worlds, a catchy and vibrant soundtrack, and addictive gameplay, Crash Bandicoot: Wrath of Cortex is fully recommended for fans of the little guy's previous platforming conquests. It might not be as on par, but it's still fun to play regardless!

Mikey Shorts would have been a fun, thoroughly enjoyable game if it weren't for the fact that it had absolutely no challenge whatsoever and repetitive level design. Mikey Hooks, on the other hand, DOES change the formula enough to make it actually good! There are now enemies, spikes, pits, and other hazards, as well as a hook-swinging mechanic that, while disappointing to see you can't use it at will, is still fun to use when given the opportunity. This game is pretty much what Mikey Shorts should have been in the first place.

I've gushed over this game a number of times on my review of the console/PC versions, and now that there is a portable edition that I can take with me on my 3DS, how could I possibly say "No"?! Now, this 5-Star rating isn't actually for everybody to follow; if you own a PS Vita, skip this and grab a copy of Rayman Origins for that handheld instead; as far as I can tell, it's a perfect direct port of the big-screen counterparts. This port has a number of small-to-moderate technical issues; the frame rate's cut in half, there's no multiplayer, the music isn't as crisp, and there are even a few times where the music halts to the sound of nothingness. Regardless, if you own a 3DS, and want to play this fantastic game on the go, then it's worth your time and money.As for the game itself, Rayman Origins bursts with superb level design, colorful graphics, and a vibrant and catchy soundtrack! Although the 3DS version may not have the super-smooth 60 FPS of the console game, the visuals still impress me, as the entire game looks like a lush cartoon, and goes as far as to play like one, too!The gameplay is initially pretty simple: You run, jump, and collect shiny yellow Lums. However, like any great game, you will be introduced to more powers such as punching, gliding, and even running on walls! The levels reflect upon these cool abilities you obtain as the game progresses, and they're full of some of the best platforming challenges out there.

You know, it's games like these that make me realize there is another benefit to being Jewish: There are no crappy Hanukkah games. It doesn't help that this particular one is based on a live-action Disney movie, so it's bound to be an unworthy cartridge.The Santa Clause 3 is a very basic run-of-the-platformer devoid of anything interesting, and while sixteen levels sounds like a lot, you'll blaze through the game before too long. The game tries to add a little bit of variety by throwing in pointless bonus minigames, but they play badly anyway and don't influence anything. This is just another licensed game, nothing more.

Years after the numbered sequel to what's considered to be one of the first "modern" rhythm games comes a game for the Nintendo Wii that sports the familiar art style and emphasizing for rhythmic play from the same developers. Unlike games such as Parappa the Rapper, though, Major Minor's Majestic March......is actually not good. I mean, there are some interesting things about it, and the gameplay does have the potential to be fun, but there's so much wrong with the game that the negatives outweigh the positives about it.If you enjoyed the fully animated cutscenes and fully casted voice talent of Parappa and UmJammer Lammy, prepare to be sorely let down; there's only ever two characters speaking (The narrator and "G.G.G.G."), and the narrator tells the story literally like a preschool children's book, with non-moving, still images onscreen in place of cutscenes. What happened? Was the budget too small?And then there's the tutorial, which can't be skipped, and moves slower than necessary....but that's all I can say about it. As for the actual game, again, it does have ingredients for a fun time, but everything else neglects those. At first, the game seems ungodly frustrating (more on that in the next paragraph), but if you take the time to learn it, you'll realize it's ungodly a CAKEWALK. The play mechanics consist of rhythmically waving the Wii Remote/baton up and down, while also pointing it at passers-by to force them into your marching band and power-ups which you can easily abuse to the point where you could probably spend 10% of the level actually doing the waving your Remote. There are power-downs that affect your party, but the power-ups can not only improve their stamina, but can also allow the game to take control from you and play itself for a brief moment of time......and these power-ups are very abundant.The control alone is partially an issue, because it involves the Wii motion control. On the surface, it does its job; you wave it and the game will react upon how you do it, but then there's the portions where the game wants you to change your tempo. EASIER SAID THAN DONE. When I try doing this, I end up getting distracted by whether or not I'm really shaking slower or faster, and I would never know how to rebalance until I take a moment to regain my initial stance. To come to think of it, I think this game would work better as a Nintendo DS game; the stylus would make for an easier approach and better responsiveness. The game also just needs to improve literally everything else.I would also like to point out that there are a couple of whole screens and stuff in this game that are just extremely pointless to begin with. The bonus stage portion "Drill Mode", interrupts your game to make you waggle the Remote in various ways just for points. Because points reeeeaaaaally maatteeer (no they don't). And after each stage, the game asks "Who's performance did you enjoy the most?". Why does this matter? What difference does it make? All my band members take part in contributing to the melodies that will never stay in my head after a second.Yes, even the music is not good. In a rhythm game, that's a major blow. Even if some of the rhymes were somewhat corny, I always get a kick out of listening to the music from the Parappa games, because they're catchy and fun, and are part of the reason why I go back to playing them! Here? Monotonous marching band-ish music that I can't remember even during my play session with it. The only song that stood out was the ear-grating half-melody from Stage 6.I've been curious for a while as to why this game was poorly received, and even Rodney Greenblat, one of the creators of Parappa and this very game, was not satisfied with it. Now that I finally played it, I can totally see why; it truly is a mess.

This is my first smoker and it was easy to assemble (that is saying a lot from me) and took less than an hour with help from a friend (it is heavy).  Afterward, you need to pre-season to get all the stinky fumes out of it and prepare it form its smoking future, by heating it for about three hours at 275 degrees, and adding 1/2 cup of dry wood chips during the last 45 minutes of the seasoning cycle.  I so far and smoke some chicken breasts and winter vegetables (squash, eggplant, and peppers), and both came out very delicious. My experience with this smoker has been good (so far). Maybe next up is a turkey?

Anyone who bakes (especially decorated sugar cookies) will appreciate Reynolds Parchment Paper.  I have been using it for years for my holiday baking and clean up is a total breeze.  If it calls for a greased baking sheet, I line the pan with the parchment paper then lightly spray cooking spray to keep the item from sticking to the paper (particularly important when making things like croissants or turnovers).  No more baked on pastry shell or cookie decorations - that baked on sugar can be a nightmare to get off (and you can scratch the pan). You can even transfer the entire sheet of cookies to a cooling rack by pulling the paper onto the rack with the cookies on it. I even occasionally line a jelly roll pan with parchment paper and cook bacon in the oven when preparing brunch.All my cookie pans and sheets still look relatively new - something I could not say about the pans I used to use which became what my mom called "seasoned" really quick.

Love the c-fold towels - these towels are a very economical choice for my bathroom.  No fancy towel holder need be applied to your wall.  Rather than purchase fancy disposable hand towels, for my guests to dry their hands, I place these in an elongated bread basket next to the sink in my guest bathroom.  They can also do double duty for clean up such as the mirror or cleaning up messes on the counter.

The Let it Snow Snowman is even more beautiful then I imagined it would be.  Same Lenox quality, and very detailed.  I like the snow globe's "tummy". I placed a tealight behind him and it really looks pretty with the light casting through it while the snow dances in the globe.  Can't wait to display  it with the rest of my holiday decorations next month.

My sister has a similar device and keeps recommending that I get one so that I could track my sleep since I tend to be tired a lot of the time.  An added bonus is that this one is nice looking and sort of resembles a watch. I have a large wrist (size 8), so I was worried that this would not fit.  It does fit (albeit a bit snug), but the latch seems to have a mind of its own.  Occasionally when I wake up, I notice it missing and lost in my bedding (am I that active a sleeper?) .  It was interesting to learn how little sleep I get according to the jawbone!  But I really do not think that the activity counter is accurate.  Even on my most sedentary days, I get credit for all kinds of activity I do not recall doing (perhaps in my sleep??)

The slinky dog is a soft plush toy with the added bonus of retractable coils that make him stretch to 3 feet. It looks just like the dog featured in Toy Story (I think the original one was a wiener dog). It is pretty large - about 15 inches tall, but very cuddly and soft - perfect for a toddler to snuggle with.

I don't iron that much, mostly because I tend to be too lazy to pull out my iron and other accoutrements to do a task I really don't enjoy.  I never imagined that there was such a difference between a basic model like I have had the last 15 years and the Black & Decker Alllure.  It is lighter and yet much more powerful.  Most important, the water reservoir does not leak like my current model - aggressive movements can cause the water to come shooting out of the top.  This one also generates a lot of steam.  Tons.  With an easy to read panel and push button technology, setting the heat and fabric type is a breeze, as is the ironing.  In addition, the cord remains relatively straight rather than the tangled mess that mine has become.  I was actually enjoying how relatively easy and painless the process was that I ended up leaving my ironing board set up and ironed pretty much everything in my closet over a three day period - I feel like June Cleaver now!

I had to check the packaging to make sure that this was a woman's watch - the face is pretty large - about 1.25 inches in diameter.  I have an eight inch wrist, so purchasing watches and bracelets without trying them on is always a crap shoot.  This watch was about 8.5 inches and I removed two links to make it fit properly.  It is very nice and I I love the two tone finish (still on the fence about the crystals - they kind of make it look cheap). I get compliments on it - just do not like how enormous the watch face is.
Cute and easy to swaddle baby.  I love the gender neutral colors since we were not sure if baby would be a girl or boy. Its like giving my fresh out of the oven niece a bear hug.

Completely unreliable.  Burned four and so far three do not work in anything but my computer, and why would I need to listen to them on my computer when i can just listen to iTunes.  The one that did play in my CD player skates and skips some of the songs altogether - of 16 tracks, only 4 play all the way through.Would not even make a good coaster due to the hole in the middle. Total PO$.

This is my first time using a Proactiv product.  While I do not have acne (other than the occasional blemish here and there), I do have extremely oily skin that also gets irritated easily when I use an alcohol based toner to clarify my skin.  While this Proactiv night cream really clarifies the skin, it does so without hash chemicals that normally burn or chap my face.  I woke up with little to no oil residue -  a nice change of pace!

Chocolate and almonds... my favorite combination!These bars are super thick and full of delicious full almonds.  They are 2.8 ounces each, and come in a package of five, neatly displayed in a gift box.  They are much larger than the candy bars usually found in the store - more like the specialty ones for fundraisers (but still seem bigger than normal), and are very "chocolatey" for lack of a better word. I would have liked to have given them as a gift, but they were calling my name and well...They arrived in perfect condition, no melting or breakage.  The only problem now is trying to say no to temptation

I really like this apron.  (black chalkboard design with white writing). It is made from durable high quality twill fabric, with an extra large pocket in the front.  I volunteer at a local soup kitchen and need some way to carry my keys and cell phone while preparing meals, and most aprons have very small pockets which barely hold either (let alone both).  One thing I like the most is the adjustable strap at the top.  You simply pull it over through the loop and can adjust if you want it higher or lower. Though the fabric is a little thinner, this apron reminds me of the one I purchased a decade ago from Circulon.

My nephew loves to play with these in the bath tub - makes bath time an event.  I especially love to hear his propeller imitation!  The toys are made from recycled plastic, so it is nice that my coke bottles are not ending up in a landfill!

Huge disappointment.  I purchased this as a gift for a friend and it took forever to arrive and once it did, I was so busy wrapping her present that I did not realize that I was shorted the timer.  She told me that her iPhone 5 fell out of it due to its flimsyness.  So it is a useless piece of crap.  I won't buy anything that is not Amazon prime anymore, particularly stuff that arrives on a slow boat from China.

I use ChapStick all year round for sun protection - I have tried many other brands like Burt's Bees, but always end up coming back to ChapStick - an added bonus is that the unit cost is significantly lower than other brands, while my lips still feel moist and don't get chapped and flaky..

Works okay - provided you are printing a document very heavy on text.  When I print pictures, the quality is a bit less in the quality department.  It was easy to set up and takes generic toner cartridges which helps save $$.

This is the perfect sized cover to keep my fire pit from the elements - whether it is rain that could lead to rusting or the eminent attack of my neighbor's pine needles that tend to give off too many sparks when they find their way into my backyard fire.  It is very sturdy - made of a breathable canvas material similar to a tent.  It fits right over the fire pit and there are elastic cinches that allow you to pull it to fit your fire pit.

This is a God-send for my active four year old niece - particularly for a recent road trip. Once she figured out how to work it, the Whammer kept her entertained for the majority of our nearly three hour drive to Lake Tahoe.  Great for building a child's understanding of phonics and actually learns along with the child by adjusting to the child's learning level to keep them engaged.  It is a relatively well priced item as well and will be invaluable for readying her for Kindergarten.

I remember playing with the little people play sets when I was a youngster and boy have they changed.  This set stands about 2.5 feet high which is the perfect height for a toddler.  My nephew just loves coming over to play with this - loves to make the plane (or is it a helicopter) "fly" down the pole while he dances and carries on conversations with the little plane passengers.  There is also a fuel depot, tower, and food court with seats overlooking the airfield. Very clever - but you definitely need more little people in this set.He loves it so much that I am looking forward to getting the raceway set also.

I got this product because I have difficulty using granulated fertilizers.  I always seem to get too much in one place and not enough in the other despite using the whirly thing to disperse it.  Here in California, water is pretty scarce, and if I overfertilize with the granulated products, I tend to burn my grass.  I tried this out last weekend in my backyard and it was a quick application.  I like how it went on evenly throughout the yard.  I waited a couple days to water per the feedback I have seen on the comments section, so as to not wash away the product. I water my yard for two minutes per section every other day and so far no burn spots.  I typically get weird clover-like clumps of hot pink flowers in my yard each spring and after dousing the patches where it tends to start, I have noticed that there has been little to no growth.  It did not seem to work well on the dandelions in my yard, but since there are few, I was not too worried.Because I have pets, I kept them inside until the fertilizer had dried as a precaution - I also do this when I spray for mosquitos.

My beagle/rotty mix has breath that can kill.  This package is designed for medium sized dogs between 25-50 pounds; Kirby is 32 pounds so falls right in the target.The greenies chew treats combine the best of both worlds - something to keep him busy chewing while I do chores that also helps freshen his breath.  He really lops onto these and gets pretty proprietary (and they keep him busy for hours).  Unfortuatnely, the other dogs in the pack are too small for this particular product, so I did a search and purchased "teeny greenies" for the others.

I got this mesh caddie to use while traveling.  It is the perfect size for carrying toiletries to and from the bathroom, or to store them in a single place rather than letting them pile up on the counter.  It folds flat when not in use.  The outer pockets (there are 7 of them) can hold assorted products like shampoo, conditioner, etc., as well as hairbrushes, dental products and make up accessories - the sky is the limit.  The inner section is perfect for holding hair dryers, wash cloths and a curling iron.I travel with a sister who manages to take up the entire bathroom with all her stuff; can't wait to show her how compact my stuff is!

About four years ago I received a set of packing cubes as a bon voyage present.  Now, I never leave home (even for a weekend) without them. ThoughI am already a pretty good packer, when I use the packing cubes, I tend to pack much more efficiently.  And unpacking is a breeze, as I can keep the items in the cubes and place them in the drawers for easy retrieval.  They are especially good for when you are traveling to multiple hotel locations and don't want to completely unpace each time.  I use one of the smaller ones to store a spare set of clothes in my carryon - after being stuck in the same clothing for three days while en route to Africa - it's a must!I use them to store dirty clothes, packing the dirties just as efficiently so that laundry is a breeze when I get home also.  I never leave home - even for a quick weekend getaway - without them!

The tiny bite-size morsels are perfect for my teacup Yorkie ad chihuahua.  They both devour this food like it was meant for humans (they tend to like what I am eating better).  I like that it does not contain grain, as one of them has a sensitive stomach and tends to not be able to keep food with grain down.

These wipes are very refreshing and ideal for people with oily skin.  Despite being north of 30, I still experience the occasional break out. They may bit a bit too effective for those with normal skin, causing dryness, but since my skin tends to be on the oilier side (I prefer to think of it as overly moist), they work great for me.  I like the refreshing gentle scent the best - they have a minty fresh scent that does not smell like your average disposable face cloth.  I also like that the wipes have a textured surface that allows you to scrub problem areas.The only drawback is the current on-line price - I would purchase them at a local CVS or Walgreens rather than paying $5 for shipping.

The InterDesign round knit bin and thick and holds its shape really well.  I received the small one and it really is pretty small.  I have it sittingon the counter hodling hairbrushes, combs, and make up brushes.  Its thick construction allows it to retain its shape and stand vertically without additional assistance, making it pretty durable.I love the blue and white stripe - perfect casual or beachy color scheme for a bathroom.

Prefer these over the plain black on white label tape that comes standard with the P-Touch labelmaker.  They are easy to peel (but cannot be re-positioned easily once you have placed them).  The ink also does not rub off of them which makes them more hardy.  I purchased them on Amazon at a fraction of what they cost at my local retailer (Office Depot).

This is a great cover of a relatively dated 60's song.  It was featured in an episode of the CBS TV-series "Stalker" which has become well known for incorporating some of the most interesting covers in their final act each week.Spin's version of "Happy Together" is such a different interpretation that makes it nearly unrecognizable from the original source material.  When I heard the lyrics the first time, I thought "is that the Turtles song?"  I was taken by complete surprise.  With a menacing bass line and a vocals filled with breathy angst, it seems like a much more contemporary song.

The Girls of Mischief Bay tells the story of three female friends at various stages in their lives and how they each tackle a crisis in their lives.  One is searching for meaning while on the brink of losing a loved one; ones marriage is in collapse; and one is on unending merry-go-round search for romance, despite being her own worst enemy and lack of compromise.Fans of Mallerys light hearted romantic novels will be disappointed, as there is little light heartedness, and even less romance.  Instead, the book is filled with undeveloped characters, each of whom never seems to learn from her mistakes. This is the start of a new series  I may sit this one out since I prefer her romantic comedies, which are better developed and offer readers an escape.

Mari had an unorthodox and abusive childhood at the hands of her grandmother.  She managed to escape her grandmother and eventually married and had two children.  On the outside, her life seems pretty ordinary, despite some of Mari's idiosyncracies.  But when husband Ryan tries to cash in on her broken childhood by moving the family to the remote home that Mari would rather forget to write about her story, it causes Mari to reevaluate her blind faith to her not so deserving (and self-serving) husband.  The story has lots of twists and turns and is told using multiple viewpoints, which is a story telling technique that I don't really care for.  But overall, Hart's storytelling is so compelling and thought provoking, that I fould myself reading well into the night.

Shay is the tutor of a London, a teen who is moving back to the states to be reunited with her father after her mother's death.  A chance meeting and one night stand with Jay... turns out to be London's father.  Shay navigates her own issues with her family, while tutoring her charge and co-habitating with her own "Mr. Rochester" (minus the crazy ex-wife in the attic); Jace is reluctant to continue the relationship with Shay considering the daughter that he has not seen in nearly a decade in the house and just down the hall.  And he is eager to get back to his life on the road. thinking London will be better off in boarding school.  Shay tries to bring the durly teen (and her father) out of their shells... but what next?Ridgway's latest is a spicy and fun story - though a little too much time is spent on Shay's self-inflicted angst about ther family and past.  It is the second book in a series ("Take my Breath Away" is the first), but definitely can stand on its own.

Being fair skined, I rarely venture out without sunscreen.  I typoically use Neutrogena creame sunscreen, but prefer this product since I do not need to spread the sunscreen with my hands.  This product sprays on evenly and dry with a very light scent that is not overpowering or noxious like some of the products I have tried in the past that smell more like bug spray that can clog your sinuses.

Ever wonder what goes on in the constantly changing mind of a toddler? Well, "Must Push Buttons" is a cute story about a little boy (that seems to be on the verge of ADD) whose thought processes are constantly changing, but one thing is certain - he loves to push buttons on just about everything... daddy's phone, mommy's phone, the remote control. He also wants to try on  mommy's shoes, eat a snack... The graphics are bright and capture the readers attention, but the kid seems like he's in desperate need of a nap or someone to say no.

This device kept crashing when I tried to use it.  I found that when it did work, my readings were pretty inconsistent, particularly when compared to my regular meter, which I have been using for several years .  I don't get that much activity on my phone, but it seemed like when I received an incoming call, the device would fail.  Too many bugs for me to use as a reliable resorce to test my blood sugar.

This waffle maker is ready in a jif (less than five minutes to heat up - it'll take you longer to make the batter) and makes yummy thick evenly cooked waffles.  There is an outer rim that manages to catch any "extra" batter in case you overfill.  It wipes clean with a damp cloth similar to panini makers.

Good product that retains its shape.  Only drawback is that I prefer feminie hygeine prefer products with wings, but unlike some of the other products on the market without wings, these Stayfree Maxi's retain their shape and wick away moisture.

Finally found a dog food that ny chihuahua with a very sensitive stomach can tolerate.  The chunks are about medium size and she has no problem swallowing them.  I have tried so many other premium dog foods and she tends to get sick with all of them.  The vet recommended trying a "new protein" and venison seems to be her go to protein!

What an incredibly novel cover of a 60's classic tune.  I never liked the original song when it was performe by the Rhonettes's because I just don't care for the sound of the 60's motown music.But I neard this during the closing act of the TV show "Stalker" and was so intrigued by the etheral and haunting vocals that I had to seek it out.  It is just such a different sounding song - the vocals are really ethereal and evoke a completely different scenario than the original uptempo version.  I would love to find more stuff by this artist.  I love when artists cover material in a way that is so different than the original that a listener does not even realize that it is the same song.

What a nightmare to install!  I am a visual learner, but there are no instuctions on how to install the software, so you need to download them first if you are visual like me.  The initial install took what seemed like forever but was actually about 25 minutes.  It failed and when I checked the Amazon site for recommendations, I noticed the review recommending that you not check for uodates.  It installed much quicker after that, and I also did not have any updates awaiting my attention, so that was kind of annoying.I am a Pinnacle Studio user, so I was really curious as to how this would work in comparison. The instructions for creating video slideshows is much easier and much more straighforward than with Pinnacle (I often have to refer back to notes with Pinnacle).  I am looking forward to trying some of the other features to create slideshows.

Set in Regency England, Lady Sophia's parents are determined to marry her off to a duke. But Sophia, seeing how unhappy marriages tend to be amongst the gentry, is determined to marry a man who earns his own living rather than inherits it. So she elopes with George, a mere solider. But when Sophia discovers George is actually a rich duke, she is furious at him for lieing to her. Can their marriage be saved?At only 30 pages long, this book barely has enough time to set up the premise and conflict. There's about 28 pages of set up, and only 2 pages of resolution where Sophia and George have a happy ending. There is limited plot and zero character development. As the reader I felt no emotional connection to the characters. The premise was half way decent, and maybe if the story had been expanded upon into a novella length story, it might have been ok and I might have given it three stars. But in it's current state two stars is the best I can give. I can't believe the author would normally charge $2.99 for this short story that took me only fifteen minutes to read. It's not even worth 99 cents, and even for free I didn't enjoy it. Not a book I would recommend.

To say this doll is gorgeous is an understatement. Her dress is breathtaking. Pictures don't do it justice. The dress is soooo poofy especially if you take the doll out of thr box. The skirt is covered in sparkles. The top of the dress is a soft velvet. Her shoes are silver high heels. Her face mold and makeup are perfect. She has real eyelashes. My only complaints are that her hair is too thin. You can actually see bald spots in the back. She also.doesn't come with a doll stand (which is weird because every other Disney limited edition doll comes with a stand). So if you want to display her outside of the box you have to find a doll stand that will fit. Also, her box shape is a bit weird aa it's nothing like previous LE doll box shapes which all match. Also the box isn't very sturdy.This doll is special in that she was released for Disneyland' s 60th anniversary and the only place you could buy her was at Disneyland. She retailed for $120 and 5000 dolla were made. You can currently find her on an auction website that shall remain nameless for pretty close to the retail price.

I hated this game. My biggest complaint is that it's dark and dreary. Everything is gray. There's absolutely no color and it's so depressing. When I think of Disney I think of vibrant color and warm happy feelings. This game does NOT provide that! In addition the game is hard to navigate, there are too many controls/actions to remember, and the ultimate goal of the game us very unclear.Overall not a game I would recommended.

I made it two thirds of the way though this book before stopping. The story just didn't hold my attention . It follows Nora Beasley, a young woman who has arrived at Bellamy Manor to serve as a governess to the Duke's three children. But when King Rupert, cousin of the Duke, is taken with Nora, will the Duke allow the King to take her for ill intent, or will the Duke protect her.This book was a bit strange. It could have been good, but it was just.... boring. The characters were flat and one dimensional. They evoked no emotional response in me as the reader. And often times there actions made no logical sense. I also didn't like how scenes would change suddenly. It was very confusing. Plus there were a lot of typos and grammatical errors.Overall this book just didn't hold my interest. Not a book I would recommend.

Katie, Josie, and Hannah own three adjoining ranches that their husbands all cared for together. But with the recent deaths of their husbands, the ranches are suffering. Knowing they need men to survive, the send away for mail order husbands.  Katie marries Jason, Josie marries Jim, and Hannah marries Peter. So far so good. This was a decent premise. But from here things fall apart.Josie's husband Jim is violent. Within only hours of arrival, he threatens to shoot anyone that comes on his property, even though in the past all three couples shared the properties. Can the others get Jim to see reason?Other than the premise, there was nothing good about this story. It didn't flow well, and the characters didn't make sense. For instance, in the first scene, Katie is screaming that she will never remarry. But in the never next scene she's getting  hitched, with no explanation as to what changed her mind. And then after only a couple hours, she's head over heels in love with Jason. Seems a bit fast. Then Josie, who's clearly marries a violent brute, defends Jim's actions and is in love with him immediately. Really? After he threatened to kill her friends?Additionally, this book ends on a cliff hanger. There is zero resolution of the plot. If you want to know what happens, you have to pay $9 for all three kindle books. But between the horrible characters, disturbing, jerky plot, and tons of grammatical errors, it's just not worth it. I manages to download all three books for free, but considering how bad this first book was, I won't be reading the last two, even though they were free. Not worth my time. I will be deleting the books from my device and will not be buying any more books from this author.

Colton spends his time caring for his ailing mother and his injured father, while trying to keep up with the ranch. While the idea of a wife and family appeals to him, he knows his other obligations won't permit him to marry.  But when he finds a newborn baby abandoned at the under construction orphanage, Colton is determined to take the baby home and care for it, as he suspects the baby is family. How he'll find the time to care for the baby, God only knows.Meanwhile, New York City socialite Rebecca Sterling is determined to care for the baby herself. Recently jilted by her ex fianc, Rebecca has traveled west to oversee the construction of a new orphanage in the little town of Evans Grove. Seeing as the newborn was clearly left at the orphanage, that makes himself her responsibility. Unable to come to a consensus, Colton and Rebecca make a compromise. Rebecca, the baby, and young Heidi, another orphan in Rebecca's care, will temporarily move to Colton's ranch to care for the baby together. But once the orphanage is up and running, Rebecca will move back to New York.But as Rebecca spends more time with Colton, she wonders if she wants to go back to New York at all. Will Cotton give her a reason to stay in Evans Grove?Overall I really liked this book. It was a sweet romance. I also liked that the author spent a lot of time developing Heidi's character. A lot of authors would have glossed over a child character. But Heidi brought dimension to an otherwise an typical historical romance.I did, however, struggles a bit with the plot, particularly in the beginning. This is the third book in a series, and I haven't read the previous two books. The author didn't do a very good job of explaining the first two books. But I was able to get the gist.Overall, a nice, clean romance that I would recommend.

Dr Emma Allen is on her way to Oregon, nor because she wants to go to Oregon, but because she needs to care for her sick sister Anne, who us determined to go. As soon as Anne is settled in Oregon, Emma intends to head back East. But that's assuming she survives the hardships of the Oregon Trail, as well as the annoyances of handsome trail master Zachary Thatcher.Zachary Thatcher is flabbergasted when he discovers that the beautiful Emma Allen is not only unmarried, but she's traveling the Oregon Trail without a man to guide and protect her. To make matters worse, the fool woman is a doctor,  one who's determined to stick her nose into everything with her unsolicited advice. If he stops the wagon train every time she has a sick patient, they'll never make it to Oregon before winter.Can these two stubborn people work together to care for the train headed to Oregon? And is there are future for them after they get there?This was a very enjoyable book. I really liked Emma and Zachary's characters. However, I was very disappointed in Anne's character. She's stricken with grief after the death of her husband and child, and that's understandable. But I was expecting to see Anne's character develop a bit by the ending, but she didn't. She wa just as depressed at the end. And I honestly thought the premise was illogical and forced. Anne is so depressed she doesn't care if she dies. But then she is insistent she go to Oregon. Someone who doesn't care if they live or die wouldn't give a fig where they live. Just didn't make sense.Overall, this was a goid book that I'd recommend.

Love these! The stones are so smooth. Most other fish tank gravel has small indentations that make it easy for icky bacteria to grow. But these stones arw so smooth they take only seconds to wash and they keep my fish's tank water much cleaner for much longer. A bit expensive but definitely worth it.

After the death of Lady Hawkehurst, Hannah Fletcher is determined to fulfill her promise to her late mistress: she has sworn to provide the best possible care for her Ladyships three children. But as the children's governess, she inows there's only so much she can do. The children need their father to return home from war, and they need their father to take an active interest in their lives. So when Lord Gavin Romney returns home with a war injury, Hannah knows she must help his Lordship form a relationship with hus children. But will she be able to avoid falling in love with him in the process?This was a sweet, clean historical romance. I liked both Hannah and Gavins characters. I would have liked there to be a little more actionaction and for the story to have moved a bit faster. But overall an enjoyable book that I would recommend.

Love this shampoo! It has a great fruity smell. The consistency is perfect, not too thick, not too thin. It lathers very nicely, especially considering it's an all natural shampoo. It rinses out well and leaves hair clean and soft. However the $19 and change Amazon is asking for this 13 oz bottle is ridiculous. I got a 16 oz bottle at Wally World for only $11.

Three and a half stars.I got this book as part of the Kindle First program. I enjoyed reading it. It's a nice, relaxing, light romantic comedy. It's the kind of book that I can totally see as a "chick flick". It's very reminiscent of "Sweet Home Alabama".The female lead, Kendall, is so focused on advancing her career as a serious news reporter that she doesn't give any time to her love life. And when Ty Bishop enters the picture, although she's very attracted to him, she knows he will only distract her from her career goals of joining a morning news show in New York City. Will she give true love a chance?Overall this book was pretty good. It's by no means unique though. It's a typical romantic comedy. Other reviewers commented on how "deep" they thought this book was and referenced the childhood emotions Kendall and Ty struggled with in regards to their parents. But to me, "daddy issues" are a bit cliche. All that being said however, I still enjoyed this book.There is one sex scene that's moderately descriptive, so just a head's up if that bothers you.Overall, a nice read. Glad I picked it as my Kindle First. For free it was a worthwhile read. But I honestly don't think it's worth the $5.99 the author would normally charge, because as I said, although I enjoyed it, I don't think it was anything super special.
So cute! Makes a perfect present for wedding favors or any romantic occasion, and for threw bucks it's such a good value.
Just used this today to make homemade blush. It is very, very, very sparkly. So if you like pink glitter, this is a good choice.

A very nice cover. I got the white and it looks feminine yet professional. I do have two complaints though. The plastic frame cracked after only about six uses. It still fits my tablet snuggly and it's fine to continue using it. But if it gets a second crack, I think a whole piece of the frame will fall off and then the cover will be useless. Also, when the cover is open with the front and back cover touching, the two covers tend to stick together so tightly, when you pull them apart it sounds like ripping two pieces of Velcro apart. While not a huge problem, I do use this tablet in a professional meeting environment, and have gotten a few looks since the sound is so loud it's rather disruptive. But overall I would still recommend this product.

Pretty pleased with this product. I used it for me Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 10.1. It works well, although it took three tries for the blutooth connection to finally work. The keyboard is lightweight yet sturdy. Pretty easy to type, although I wish it was just a bit bigger to make the trypingf even more comfortable. But overall a great product for the price.

Very pleased. This is perfect for dolls that are tall but have a narrow waist. I used it for a 17 inch tall doll with a waist only slightly thicker than a barbie doll's waist and it fit perfectly. Great item and a great price.

Pretty good. I like that it has a mix between of both horizontal and vertical slots. The fact that it holds so many photos is also great. My only complaint us that it seems a bit flimsy. Some of the slots have already pulled away from the page. And rhe beige color is boring. But overall not bad for the price.

Book 3 of 3 in the After the Storm Series.Dr Nora Mitchell, while used to prejudice, is getting desperate. She needs to find a job as a physician, or else her father us going to force her to marry one of his ancient business partners. Nora hopes that she will find a job in High Plans, a town that has recently been ravaged by a tornado.  Zeb Garrison, one of the founders of High Plains, knows the town us desperate for a doctor. But are they that desperate that he could even consider hiring a woman to fill that role? Zeb is determined to scare her off and send her back to New York, so he agrees to hire Nora on a trial basis. But nothing seems to faze the young woman. Before he knows it, Zeb is forced to admit to himself that Nora is a top notch physician. But can he admit that to Nora, and can he admit that he's fallen head over heels for the lady doctor?I loved this book. It really brought to the fore the struggles women in the medical field had. To think that some people would rather have no doctor than have a female doctor is so sad, but very realistic of the time.  I really loved both Nora and Zebs characters. They were realistic, relatable, and believable. And as the third book in the series it wraps up all the loose ends from the first two stories. My only complaint is that if you haven't read the first two stories, you might struggle to keep up with all if the characters and plot that the author assumes you know should know from the first two books.But overall a great read that I would recommend.

Book 1 of 3 in the After the Storm Series.While on their way to Kansas, Emmeline and her family get caught in a tornado on the Kansas plains. The tornado kills her father, and leaves her 15 year old sister Bess mute. Meanwhile the 8 year old orphan twins they were caring for also disappeared during the storm.  But despite the tradegy, Emmeline is determined to care for her bedridden mother, her mute sister Bess, her volatile 12 year old brother Johnny, and her 5 year old sister Glory. But at 19, how can she care for her whole family?The answer comes in the form of Will Logan, one of the men who founded the town of High Plains. Will hires Emmeline as a cook for his ranch, and the two begin to spend a great deal of time together. Emmeline is fond of Will, but memories of her physically and emotionally abusive father keep her from ever considering marriage. Can she overcome her fears and give love a chance?This was a very good book. The characters and plot are likeable and believable. Will Logan is a fabulous male lead. My only complaint was that the book never tells us what happened to the twins. If you want to find that out, you have to read all three books of the series. I hate it when books don't give you closure. (While I didn't read the second book in the series, I did read the third, and it was also a very good book.)Overall, this was a good story that I would recommend. It's clean, easy, light reading with a feel good happy ending.

This is book 3 of 3 in the Alaskan Brides Series.Memories of her past life haunts young Viola, who once was forced into a life of prostitution. Now she lives in Alaska and supports herself as a seamstress. But despite her new life, she can't get over her free of men. But when handsome missionary Thomas Stone gets injured trying to save a baby Viola is caring for, she feels obligated to open her home to him while he heals. Initially afraid of him, as time goes on Viola realizes just how kind and gentle Thomas is. Can she overcome her past, or will it come back to haunt her?I had mixed feelings about this book. My biggest problem was that this is the third book in the series, which was not made clear on the paperback version I purchased at a local used book store, otherwise I would have read the first two books in the series first. Unfortunately, I wouldn't call this a stand alone novel. The action in the book starts in the very first sentence, and many characters are mentioned in the first few pages, characters I obviously had never heard of before. The author assumes you have read the first two books, but since I hadn't, I was lost. For instance, I thought the Dr and his Native American assistant were married based on their interactions, only to find out a third of the way through that they weren't. The author also several times mentions a "midnight sun", and I had no idea what that meant. Finally half way through the author mentions the midnight sun in connection with Alaska's days if all sunlight and no darkness\sunset. Then I finally got it. But I wish the aurthor had made it clear from the first reference.Also, the characters and storyline were a bit boring and slow. It felt like it took forever for anything to happen.Overall this was just an OK novel.

This conditioner is a solid for stars. I love that it's all natural and doesn't have the chemical garbage in it that most hair products have. And unlike other all natural hair products, which tend to be thin and runny, this one is very thick and creamy.  I gets all the knots out of my hair and it leaves my hair soft and shiny. I've also noticed that one bottle lasts me a long time, much longer than most other conditioners I've tried. I will be purchasing again.

This product does NOT work. All I wanted was a simple pedometer that keeps track of how many steps I take each day as a way to monitor my activity and to motivate myself to get up and walk a bit. Based on the other reviews I thought this would do the trick, and I thought the $7.99 price tag was reasonable. Unfortunately this pedometer doesn't work.For starters, when I tried to press the reset button to get it back to zero, I had to press long and hard to reset it. I also noticed the reset button didn't fit quite right and looked like it was about to pop out. Additionally, there are no directions on how to use it or how to change the batteries in English. The only directions provided were in what I assumed was Chinese. But it seemed pretty self explanatory so that wasn't a huge concern.After finally getting it to reset, I decided to try it out while walking up and down my local main street. I put the pedometer in my pocket and off I went. After about an hour of continuous walking, I decided to check it to see how many steps I'd taken. According to the pedometer, I had only taken 90 steps in the past hour. Right. Clearly it wasn't working properly. I gave it a slight shake (heard something inside it rattle) and put it back in my pocket. After another hour, I checked it again and was pleased to see that it now read 6000 steps. It now seemed to be working. Yet another hour later I checked it a third time and was dismayed to see it still said 6000 steps. Ugh.Overall, this product clearly didn't work. It's a peice of junk. What a waste of money. I'll probably return it but I'm not sure if it's worth the return shipping fee and my aggravation.  So I'm still on the hunt for a pedometer that actually works but doesn't cost a fortune and doesn't have all the bells and whistles that I probably won't use (ie the Fitbit). Anyone have any suggestions?

Just ok. A little bit big for my Nexus, so it slides around a bit. And you can tell it's cheaply made. But it was the best cover I could find if I didn't want to pay a fortune. If you're on a budget, this will work. But don't expect any compliments on it. It's a no frill, bare bone necessity cover.

This got returned. The cushion is wide enough for me, but it wasn't long enough. There was a gap between the end of the cushion and the end of the chair I was sitting in, and it was a small chair. The gap made my legs uncomfortable.  And this has to be the wimpiest memory foam ever. Memory foam should be firm and supportive, but this provided no support as soon as it was sat upon, and I'm an average size and weight woman.  Very disappointed. I bought this cushion because it had the highest ratings here on Amazon. If this is the best orthopedic cushion out there, then no wonder we all have back, hip, and joint pain and problems.

This is a great wedding present for any coffee lover.  I was very impressed with the quality and details of this set. This a great functional gift, but one that still shows personal interest in the person you've bought the gift for.Highly recommend.
A good, all natural shamoo. Leaves hair ckean and soft.

A pretty good conditoner, especially considering it's all natural. It took a while for my hair to adjust to all natural shampoo and conditioner, but after a couple of months it did finally adjust, and I've found that the Aubrey Organics line of conditioners does a good job of actually detangling my hair, which most all natural conditioners can't seem to do.My only complaint is that I don't like the smell. It's not pretty or feminine smelling. It doesn't have a nice flora or yummy food scent. It smells very masculine. Fortunately the smell doesn't linger too long after rinsing it out.

The leopard cub I received looked nothing like the one in this photo.  His proportions were entirely out of whack. He had HUGE shoulders and a very TINY head. He looked like a cub on steroids. And his plastic whiskers were bent in every direction. His tail was very short, nothing like real snow leopards who have very long, very fluffy tails. I understand Hansa hand makes their plush, so maybe I just got one that was poorly made by someone who needs to enhance their skills.  But this leopard was so bad looking he quickly got returned and I'll hesitate to purchase a Hansa product again. I expected much, much better from a hand made, $45 item.

Very cute and sweet. These bunnies are of good quality. I love how their ears are lined with pink satin. This would make a great present for someone who had just had a baby girl.My only complaint is that the way the baby bunny is held, she's too short to sit flat on the ground. So she kind of droops down, and then it no longer looks like the mama bunny is kissing the baby bunny. Still a nice item though.

A cute little read with likeable characters. I wish the story had been expanded on a bit. Fifty pages felt like an awkward length. Too long to be a short story but not quite long enough to feel like a fleshed out novella. But I would still recommend it.

Three and a half stars.Caroline and her parents are heading west via the Oregon Trail in order to escape the horrible memories associated with the Civil War. The first day of her journey, Caroline finds herself attracted to John Brand. But she knows between her plain looks and her overprotective parents, there's no way John will court her.Meanwhile John can't take his eyes off of Caroline. He wants to court her, but with his terrible past he wonders if any woman will ever want him. Can Caroline and John have a happily ever after?This was a cute book, simple, easy to read with likeable characters. I just wish the story had been a bit expanded on. It seemed like Caroline and John fell in love at first sight, and there was very little development of their relationship. The story was also highly predictable. And there were a good amount of typos.Overall, a fair read.

Two and a half stars.This is the third book in the Lone Star Series. The first book follows Marty, the second follows Alice, and this book follows Jessica. However it also spends a lot of time continuing Marty and Alices' stories. If you've read the first two books and liked them, then you'll be happy that we finally get a resolution to the conflict started in book one surrounding the death of Alice's father and the man that is stalking her. If you haven't read the first two books in this series, then I would strongly recommend reading those before reading this one. Even though I read the first two books fairly recently, I still struggled to remember the back stories and was confused quite a bit of the time. So I can't imagine how hard it would be for someone to read this book without having read the first two.In this book we follow spoiled, self centered Jessica Atherton. Having come to realize just how selfish she is, she decides to become a better person and to focus on others rather than on herself. But when wealthy Harrison Gable makes it clear he wants to marry her, she is tempted. Harrison has the money to allow her to travel the world and to live in comfort. But at the same time Jessica's heart is drawn to Austin Todd. A former Secret Service agent, Jessica knows he has secrets of his own. Will he ever share his heart with her?I have to say I was pretty disappointed with this book, for several reasons.First, as I said, I had a hard time remembering all of the details from the first two books, and Tracie Peterson did a very, VERY poor job of jogging my memory. I wish she had provided a summary or intro at the beginning of the book, recapping the details the reader needed to know from the first two books. At the very least she could have done a much better job of weaving those details into this book. I've read plenty of sequels where the first few pages are devoted to jogging the reader's memory, usually via a dialouge between two characters. It would have been nice if Peterson had done something similar, but apparently she couldn't be bothered. Thus I couldn't remember who was married to who, who was related, and minor plot details of the first two stories.My second issue was that I didn't really like Jessica. I give her credit for recognizing that she's selfish, but she didn't actually do anything about it after her realization. One quick apology and one wedding gift will not make up for years of not caring about others. Jessica should have been more proactive in proving that she was no longer selfish and mean. But instead, all she does is repeatedly ask her mother, "Do you think I'm selfish?" and after her mother assures her she's not, she simply goes about her merry way until her next self critical breakdown. So unfortunately I didn't care for the main character. And in general the book was very repetitive.My last issue is that the book is poorly written. The book has a ton of typos and clearly the publisher did not spend enough time editing it. The scenes also changed abruptly, and aren't resolved. In one instance, we read several pages about how Jessica is so excited about going to a concert with Harrison, but we don't get to read anything about their time together at the concert. Peterson doesn't even give us one sentence to let us know if the evening went well or not. The whole scene just felt random and useless. Why build an event up like that and then not even tell us how it went? It doesn't make any sense. In another scence, the scene ends with Jessica aiming a gun at Alice's stalker. It was very exciting, and I was eager to read the next scene to see what the stalker's reaction would be. Would Jessica have to shoot him? Would Austin come to her rescue? But in the very next scene, without any preamble about how Jessica got out of that sticky situation, we see Harrison proposing to Jessica. Wait, what??? Where did Harrison come from?
